description:
I was walking around the area and was looking on yelp and came across this restaurant. It is walkable from the Moscone convention center. It was a Saturday night and I stopped by for dinner without a reservation and the host said the only availability for 1 person was at a the bar. The full menu is available at the bar. There were several seats open at the bar. 

The restaurant is upscale and the ambiance was lively. The lighting is dim so don't leave your reading glasses at home. 

The bartender was knowledgeable and made several recommendation. I ultimately went with the butter chicken and garlic chive naan. The food came out quickly and both the naan and butter chicken were the perfect temperature. The butter chicken was surprisingly better than I expected. It could have been a bit spicer, but was creamy and flavorful. The naan was the perfect balance between crisp and soft. The portions were plentiful and after having the naan I still had some leftover chicken and gravy. Unlike most of the Indian restaurants I have been to rice is not complimentary but a separate side order. I did not order any dessert but they do have quite the selection of Indian and non-indian desserts along with wine pairings. 

Overall, what I ordered was delicious, the service was excellent and I would return to try the tandoori dishes which the bartender had also recommended. However, because the food was a little pricey, I gave it 4 stars. I would suggest making a reservation in advance if going with a larger party.
author: Dave S.

description:
This would be five stars if it weren't for the service. THE BUTTER CHICKEN IS THE BEST I'VE EVER HAD. SO GOOD. I REPEAT, SO GOOD. Actually, all the food is tasty af. 

My main complaint is the service:

1. I was never asked if I wanted a drink order. Literally. Never asked. 
2. When it came time for dessert, there was an oddly huge push. A little more attention should be given to drinks. Most people enjoy things in addition to water when consuming a large meal.
3. About 0.00001 second after paying our sizable bill, a waiter approached and asked us to VACATE the table since someone else wanted it. What the hell? Talk about rude.
author: Melissa T.

description:
The weekday lunch buffet was a disappointment. I had high expectations since the lunch buffet was $23. Most Indian lunch buffets are usually around $15. Tandoori chicken was dry as it had been sitting awhile. I have visited other places where I have seen staff check on food frequently and switch out new batch when necessary. Would be great if they invested in steam bath to keep the food warm. Selection was small since I normally see 8-9 entrees at other places. Amber only had 6, 3 meats and 3 veggies. They had swai Cajun spiced that day. Swai is cheap white fish. I've been this once place they had cod on the buffet line. 

Having tried 20 plus different Indian lunch buffets nothing at Amber stood out. I would give them another try to see which dishes would be rotated out. However I would not recommend people go out of my way to visit this place. I can see Amber being good to settle Indian craving if you work nearby. If you have time to travel a bit further I recommend Taj of Marin across the Golden Gate Bridge in San Rafael and Saffron Bistro a bit south in San Carlos. 

Lastly I would like to note this was the only Indian restaurant I have encountered which used paper straws. This would have been 3 star rating for average lunch buffet experience. Plus 1 star for having environmental friendly straws.
author: Jason X.

description: Three of us ordered curries- all of them were really really good, but the butter chicken was a standout. The full food menu is available at the bar, and that's where we sat. How could you not, when the bar-top is illuminated and there's fancy lights on the wall?!
author: Alex G.

description:
Had their weekend lunch buffet and it's pretty much the closest you would come to getting authentic North Indian food in San Francisco.

The chicken tikka was the standout out of their appetizers and the taste took me back to the streets of Delhi. The tandoori chicken was dry and a stark contrast to the power packed flavor of the chicken tikka. There's a diverse spread of main courses and plenty to choose from both non vegetarian and vegetarian. They also have a live counter on weekends where they make dishes like pav bhaji, dosas, or some other dishes.

The only sad part was the naan. If you've eaten butter and garlic naans in India then this would disappoint you just like the other indian restaurants in the Bay Area do in this respect. Good naans are such a commonplace in India that you almost take it for granted and in the US, they are rare and hard to find. 

Next time I'll try the a la carte and hoping it would be even better than this buffet!
author: Akshat G.

description:
What a lovely ambiance this restaurant has. Really enjoyed dining at Amber! We made a reservation which is definitely highly recommended during the weekends since this place gets pretty packed especially in the evenings. We were seated pretty soon; didn't have to wait too long.

The food and drinks both were quite good from our experience. We were enjoying the ambiance so much that we were here for really a good amount of time, like almost 2.5 hours. We started out with a couple drinks and they were good. Loved Amber Blush! We had Paneer Vegetable Skewers for appetizer and this dish was truly amazing! Felt so original and unique. They have some unique selection of breads and we were really excited to try them. Laccha paratha was okay, was little tough so was quite chewy.

Rating the following out of 5:

AMBIANCE - 5
Absolutely beautiful!

FOOD & DRINKS - 4

Drinks -
Amber Blush - 4
Mango Mojito - 3
The first time it was quite sour so we asked them to make another one and they made it for us without any fuss.

Food -
Paneer Vegetable Skewers -5
Butter Chicken - 4.5
Paneer Kadhai - 4.5
Garlic Naan - 4
Chili Thyme Naan - 4
Laccha Paratha - 2
Veggie Biriyani - 2
Biriyani was pretty basic and it had a bit of a strange smell.

CUSTOMER SERVICE - 5

WAIT TIME - 4

HYGIENE - 4

PARKING - 
You know how crazy parking can get in SF. We parked our car in Union Square parking.
author: Harshada K.

description:
If you are looking for good authentic Indian food this is your spot in SF. The restaurant itself is beautifully designed and even has a decent bar inside. 

My wife and I had no plans for dinner and definitely weren't even thinking about Indian but walking around and checking Yelp we came across this place and decided to give fine dining Indian a chance. Truth be told I had never had "fine dining" Indian before so was sort of looking forward to it when we walked in. 

Since it was late and we weren't too hungry we decided skip on the appetizers and order a couple drinks and entrees. We went with their Butter Chicken, Naan, and Cucumber Raita. I regret not ordering the butter chicken spicier, but other than that everything was excellent. We did make a reorder of naan which took longer than it really should have to arrive but that was fine because everything else with the service was excellent. 

For dessert we went with their Rasmalai which was by far the best we have ever had.

It is a bit pricey but for the quality of food and exception service it's well worth it. Will be back next time in SF.
author: Harman B.

description:
Whenever I travel for work, I'm usually the designated person to research places to eat. My criteria: vegetarian friendly, close enough to walk from the convention center, and takes reservations.

I found Amber on Yelp, after trying to find something that wasn't super expensive and was vegetarian friendly. My boss loves Indian food - and so did the BF. They were meeting for the first time and I wanted to find somewhere that would be quiet enough for us to chat, but also wasn't a trek from the Moscone.

Amber was perfect. We were shown to a corner booth table that was quiet and really allowed us to chat. Our waiter was very friendly and knew just how much attention to give us.

I had the Butter Chicken Curry Pot with a side of garlic naan. My boss had their Saag Paneer Curry Pot, which I tried some of. It was my first time trying it and now I'm cooked. Saag Paneer is spinach cooked with cottage cheese, garlic, and cream. It's sort of like an Indian version of creamed spinach with paneer. Both were phenomenal and I wish I had more naan to mop up all the sauce!

We split the lava-style chocolate cake for dessert and it was amazing - just the right amount of sweetness.

I think we were at dinner for about two hours and we were never rushed to leave. In fact, we stayed after we paid the check and no one pushed us to go. We would've stayed longer had we not all had travel days the next day.

If you're looking for delicious food that caters to both vegetarians and meat lovers, definitely look up Amber.
author: Michelle T.

description: I reserved a table for a friend's birthday dinner and called ahead to let the restaurant know. They went above and beyond into tricking my friend that it was just a table for 2 when it was actually a table for 8. He was most definitely surprised! The food was excellent - I split the tofu kofta and the pesto naan with a friend. The rest of the party was satisfied with their food as well. To top it off, they brought out two plates of mango sorbet (one plate for each half of the party to share) for the birthday boy. Overall, the service was excellent and the food was delicious. Definitely coming back!
author: Ash B.

description:
We get free food at work from our cafeteria, but sometimes you want something a little different from the norm. The many benefits of working downtown is the abundant food options to choose from. 

Amber India provides that luxury and one of the few places that offers an AYCE option for lunch during the weekdays. They have locations in Santana Row in San Jose, Palo Alto, Los Altos and Mountain View. The lone San Francisco location is between the Four Seasons, Park Central, Jewish Museum and Marriott Marquis alley on Yerba Buena Lane. It's in the same strip as Delarosa, Tropisueno and Beard Papa. 

For $21.95, it's a pretty good deal for what they serve, from chicken tandoori, curries, biryani and vegetarian dishes. To be honest, it's your typical AYCE dishes that you'll find at similar Indian restaurants, but the flavor and spices are legit. Also a far cry from our usual cafeteria food that can get boring and bland. I don't want to sound like I'm complaining about free food, but sometimes you just want something authentic that's a fiesta in your mouth that you'll end up doing a siesta after. 

Here's a tip: Better get here early for lunch since a majority of the patrons will be choosing the AYCE option; it can fill-up pretty quick. However, you can also make a reservation to avoid the lunch hour rush.
author: John G.

description: Hmm where to start 1! The food was simply amazing. Chicken makhani was delicious and the lamb roganjosh made me drool. I think i have said enough about the place ;)
author: Sharad B.

description:
One of the best Indian restaurants I've been to, outside of India.  The service and the food was impeccable. The butter chicken was probably my favourite dish. The naans and lacha parantha were excellent.  

I would also strongly recommend the Saag paneer. Wish I had the appetite to try out more dishes. 

Overall I can't say enough good about this place. Definitely worth visiting if you're fond of Indian food.
author: Anant G.

description:
I came here for dinner and I wasn't super impressed. For the price point, the food is lackluster in taste and portion size. The butter chicken was really rich but I didn't feel like the quality of the chicken was great. The saag paneer was alright. Naan and rice were standard. 

If you're looking for good Indian food, definitely look elsewhere. If you're craving great spicy food, head next door to Ippudo and try the spicy Karaka pho for about half the price of an entree at Amber.
author: Megan K.

description: My boyfriend and I love coming here. I'm basic af, I get the butter chicken and a hard Mango Mojito, which is such an amazing drink. The service is very good and the ambiance is beautiful. They take Yelp and OpenTable reservations. Food comes out hot and fast and retains very authentic flavors.
author: Gauri V.

description:
Food here is pretty good. Sea bass was my favorite. Portion is generous so I would recommend not to get more than two or three items on the menu. I was already full with appetizers. 
Service meh, they would come often and ask us if we were done with our dish... it was bothersome. I think service people here need to have a common sense and visual judgement. Would I come back, most likely no
author: Betsy E.

description:
It's been several years and my tastes in Indian cuisine have changed over time, plus I think the buffet has adjusted as well. I also checked out the weekend buffet versus the weekday one, which is a bit more expensive but on the flipside you get all-you-can drink Mimosas! There's nothing like orange juice and bubbly along with a range of Indian food to perk up a Saturday!

We showed up around 12:45 and had no problem finding a seat even though it was pretty busy. Even though it's a buffet, it doesn't have a huge  set of selections (maybe about 20 choices) but what's available is both delicious and varied. On top of that, the majority of the options are vegetarian; there's a select few meat options (I believe primarily chicken and goat) but easily 80% of the dishes were vegetarian friendly. Each of the dishes are labeled with the main ingredients listed and while the heat level isn't indicated, it's not hard to tell based on the listing of the chilies and spices, so pick wisely.

A made-to-order dosa table is also available at the buffet, so you can get a fresh and piping hot dosa right away. Our waiter brought over an order of naan and kept our water and Mimosa glasses filled regularly. We happily went back for seconds and thirds, although I think we wound up skipping the dessert table because the main options were so delicious.

I've been to a few Indian buffets over the years and Amber, by far, tops the list. I'd be more than happy to come back here, the price is well worth it!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
The open-buffet offer with bottomless mimosas for about $25 makes Amber India a very special place. 

First off, they serve pretty decent Indian fare. I really enjoy their butter chicken and recommend their chicken biryani. Their saffron rice and any variation of fish I have tried here are delicious. Both the rice pudding and carrot halwa are perfect ways to end brunch if you enjoy sweets. I have had many a brunch here after which I regretted not having stopped myself after enjoying a reasonable portion. 

In terms of decor, this is a pretty upscale looking place with a friendly laid back atmosphere. Don't get me wrong, dining here is also a good option but the polished look, the delicious food and the brunch deal make this a deal you shouldn't miss.
author: Doruk B.

description:
Who can say no to yummy Indian food? This place definitely has plenty of that. 

Tried out a variety of dishes during my visits here and they all ranged from good to really good. The paneer skewers and Paneer Masala are favorites. That said, compared to other Indian restaurants in the city, they have yet to wow me with one of their dishes. If you come over lunch, they'll have a buffet which makes for a smart investment. I do recommend making a reservation as it can get busy. Pro tip: often they still have seating places near the bar if you do tend to crash the buffet last minute. 

Garlic Naan is okay. I eat so much naan that I might be too spoiled. This one is a tad too oily and needs to stay in the tandoori a bit longer. 

Good cocktails and big wine selection. In the weekend, they offer bottomless mimosas. Woo!

Why not 4 stars? The service can be quite inconsistent. When I was there last week, it was top notch, but I had visits where I felt like a ghost. That is, until I had to go to the restroom and I transformed into an obstacle saying "excuse me" constantly while trying to maneuver past tables and waiters.
author: Ellen H.

description: The buffet is fantastic, has a lot of variety and all of the food was very fresh. The Tandoori Chicken was extremely tender, I've never had such tender chicken in my life. Nothing I had tasted bland.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Food was good, although I only liked one of the three vegetarian sides (or curry) for naan.
The pineapple halwa was good. The tea was decent.
In general, the place has great ambience and good Indian food.
author: Kiran K.

description:
Highly overrated. The food was low quality or okay at best. We ordered kadhai paneer. At this price you would expect that the paneer would be very soft! Heck I can make better Indian at my home. The naan was good and soft. A friend had butter chicken and they said it was mediocre, the chicken was not very tender.

The crew though, was very courteous.
author: Kshitiz S.

description:
My favorite authentic India restaurant in SF. Lunch time is AYCE, butter chicken is included, VERY tasty and worth it. Dinner time is regular menu, lamb chop is one of the best. They also serve different wines to pair food. 

Service was also very good, they constantly refilled water for me. If you love India food, this one you must go. 

Strongly recommend it!!
author: Keira R.

description:
Disappointing. I hadn't been to Amber in years. Used to eat at the restaurant in Los Altos 3 times a week. 

One of the waiters (shorter and stocky) clears his nasal passages with a snort like an old man every time he walked out of the kitchen. Sounded like a pig snorting and it was very unappetizing. 

The old Amber had nice tablecloth covered tables. This one has black spots around every air vent. The old dishes up the rice. Not here. 

One person. Two curries and a very small gulab jamon dessert and the bill was over $80.
author: Rocklin M.

description:
Okay but nothing too memorable. In fact, as I write this review a couple weeks after my meal there, I already forgot what I ate there until I looked at some pictures to jog my memory.

We went on a Tuesday evening around 8 pm, and to my surprise there was still a wait. Luckily they let you leave your phone number, and I got a text about 20 minutes later that our table was ready. One complaint I had around this process is that they don't send you a confirmation text when you first give them your phone number, so I was half doubting whether I gave them the right phone number until I got the 'your table is ready' text.

I had a rose gimlet ($12) to start, which was pretty standard. I did like the presentation with the rose petal on top though.

Neither my friend nor I were very hungry, so we each went with one entree. I ordered the lamb korma ($25.95), which is lamb cooked in a creamy and mild curry sauce. Overall for Indian food, the flavoring is on the bland side, which was perfect for me as I don't like strong spice-y tastes. They were also able to accommodate my request to make it not spicy so I didn't have to worry about the spice levels. The lamb meat itself was a little tough and dry but otherwise was fine.

We ordered a naan, a multi grain roti, and some rice to share on the side, and while the naan and rice (called pulao here) were decent, neither of us liked the multi grain roti.

Service was good, and our server was very attentive in checking up on us periodically to make sure we were still doing okay. 

Our meal ended up being close to $100 after tax and tip, but I don't think the food was quite worth it.
author: Dianna H.

description: We have dined here before and had great experience in the past. So came back again. But this time was quite disappointed with the food. We went for weekend Buffett  at the peak time(1pm) but most of the food was cold and felt like was lying for long time. I must say what we got in exchange of the price was not worth it.
author: Sampurna G.

description:
I'm not big into Indian food, but I still had an okay experience at this establishment. I liked some of their small dishes and their selection of cocktails. Speaking of cocktails..

If you want a mango lassi but also a cocktail, why not ask the waiter to spike up the mango lassi? That's exactly what some of my friends did here at Amber! They were more than happy to accommodate that, although they were skeptical about how it would taste. You couldn't even taste the alcohol, which is perfect for those who don't like strong drinks, haha.

Anyway, about the food... I liked the bread basket a lot (different kinds of naan) and the sea bass. The lamb chop was pretty dry though, and my boyfriend and I didn't enjoy that much.

Service was pretty good. Props to the servers to having to deal with a large party of 10!
author: Christina W.

description:
TLDR: Take it for what it is, and you'll like it. AND THAT BIRYANI KILLZZZ

It's Indian food in SF, from my experience the city itself doesn't have the best Indian food. However, this place is solid if you take it for what it is. You aint getting the traditional flavors that I have come to love as a proud brown male, but when I accept that it's enjoyable. Butter chicken is stupidly sweet but hey it's pretty good lol. 

The buffet is a good option for a weekday lunch if you're trying to not work for the rest of the day (food coma)

I would have given this 2 stars but I added a star for each of the following:

- They have easily accessible onions+lemon+green chilis. During the buffet they're a part of the platters. But during dinner, when I ask they'll immediately give precisely that. Any other indian restaurants around the area will look at me like "uh wat" and then just not give me anything or not give all of them. It's like bruh.. it's an indian restaurant. Mans likes his little spread with his food you know? Should be a common request

- THE BIRYANI. god damn.. I've never been a bit fan of biriyani until I came here - I've always been a roti/paranthe type of fella. At dinner I think it's called the "Murgh Parda Biryani". Murgh means chicken, Biryani is the name of the rice dish, and Parda means curtain or covered if I'm not mistaken. This biryani is cooked in a pot covered in naan dough so it's completely encased in bread and stupid dope. You gotta break the bread to get to the baryani and you use the bread to eat it too. super cool tbh. And I've gotta say, the flavor of the baryani is spot on. Pour in some dahi/raita and it kilzzzz. tangy, flavorful, everything you need. This is legit all i get whenever I come here.
author: Samraaj B.

description:
Tasty and different Indian food. I am a vegetarian :) and ordered the below:
Appetizer - Palak Chat & Cauliflower Bezule
Entree- Kadhai Paneer, Malai Kofta and Bhindi Jaipuri along with assorted basket.

Food Quality/Taste - 9.5/10
Service- 10/10
Ambience - 10/10
Price - Expensive BUT can't complain as they have maintained SFO standards

Only thing I didn't like is that they make malai kofta with tofu which is kind of weird combination for indian cuisine. Was disappointed with malai kofta but it wasn't tasting that bad.
author: Jay J.

description: Traveled for work to SF. Stumbled upon this place and wasn't disappointed. Food was good. Good ambiance too.
author: Christina P.

description: I was so so impressed by this spot near the financial district! It's centrally located near the Westfield mall, and I would always walk past and be very curious. We finally had the chance to check it out one Thursday night, but even for a weeknight at 8pm, the wait was 30 min+. Once we got seated, after checking out the nice ambiance, we scoured the menu and honestly, it was really hard to choose, because they've included very classic dishes both in the original form and/or with a twist. We ordered the Butter Chicken, Biryani, and Garlic Naan, and that was more than enough for the two of us, even being very hungry. For the price point, although higher than a lot of other Indian restaurants, the serving size is justified. We've already gone back a second time in the last two weeks, so safe to say we found our new favorite downtown spot!!!
author: Marites S.

description:
The restaurant is clean an quit trendy, a kind of business restaurant, it isn't like the most Indian restaurant. The food what we had was good but not that special in combination with the price it doesn't make it the best deal. We had a saag for paneer what nice and spicy. Take care it doesn't come with rice. Beside it we had a also a samosa plate, was ok but was not close to a traditional samosa. 
The naans where good and traditional.
author: Jurien V.

description:
I went to Amber for a team lunch. We booked the place in advance as most of the reviews indicated that this place is usually jam packed during lunch hours even on a weekday. We reached around 12pm and immediately got seated. 
The buffet starts with a section fresh salad follows up with starter and main course. They had the usual Butter chicken, Tandoori chicken, Matar paneer, pakora, tadka dal, dry subzi, fish, goat curry and naan. 

What I liked and tasted -

Matar Paneer - Paneer was really hard but gravy was rich and creamy.
Goat curry - Really good !!! The goat was cooked perfectly and was just melting in mouth.
Butter Chicken - It was little too sweet for my taste I made it work by pairing it with mint chutney. 
Tandoori chicken - Overcooked/Dry,
Chicken Biryani - I felt the rice were mushy and over cooked. (Check pictures for reference)
Naan - Really soft and cooked perfectly.

Desert -

Gulab jamun - Nothing special - tasted good !!
Sooji halwa - It was dry and over roasted/cooked.
Kheer - I liked it, a little watery still has the perfect amount of sweetness and flavor.

Overall, great place for team lunch, service was quick and prompt.
author: Simran K.

description: Came here on a Sunday during brunch and I have to say they have the best deals for the location and type of food they offer. The deal was all you can eat and all you can drink mimosas for 25 which is not bad in the financial district. They have so many option of Indian food, the include south and north Indian food in their menu which I find a plus.
author: Poonam M.

description:
A beautifully appointed Indian restaurant in the heart of San Francisco, right next to art museums. We were here for lunch with a small group, and it was very, very crowded with large groups. Appointment is highly recommended! Luckily we had one so we were seated quickly.

Lunch is buffet. Restaurants make money on people like me for buffet. I don't eat much at once, and a half of the plate if occupied by salad, usually no seconds/thirds... It was too busy for me to plan well for my plate at the buffet (I think I missed out a lot), but the food was all fresh and dellicious! Lots of variety to choose from. 

Would love to go back and try some more!
author: Tamami T.

description:
Had Meal Pal here for their Butter Chicken and it was delicious! Great combination of flavors, a nice tomatoey taste, and there was an intense amount of flavor without going overboard in saltiness. The place is normally a nice sit-down restaurant and it looks like they have a good selection for the buffet, but unfortunately I didn't get to try that since I got my meal to go.

The Meal Pal portion comes with rice and a piece of naan, and a small side salad which was more like a few pieces of lettuce with some dressing than anything. Overall though, with the curry being so excellent, I can see myself coming back with or without Meal Pal. There is a short wait while they get the food, but it wasn't too bad.
author: Tyler T.

description: Delish Indian food and atmosphere in a great location. One of my fav places in San Fran.
author: Cindy F.

description:
A quick meal was needed and after 10 minutes on Sunday at 7 we were seated. 

With our toddler in tow, we let our waiter know, though not to waste, that we would appreciate haste. 

Our hunger was real and was quickly extinguished by the delivered meal.

The garlic naan was delicious and its delivery was expeditious. The butter chicken had a flavor that for the rest of the night I did savor. (Though it lacked rice, it was otherwise nice.)

Molten cake or creme (ginger) brûlée? It was the latter we tried today. Delicious and subtle was the dessert, each bite a note in a Mozart concert.
author: Mike A.

description:
My coworker (a vegetarian) suggested Amber India for their Sunday buffet lunch.  We arrived at promptly noon when the restaurant opened.  The buffet is among one of the priciest (~$26/pp including drink), but quality wise among the best.  They have the usual Northern Indian favorites like Tandoori chicken, Saag Paneer, Biryani, Naan, and pakora.  In addition, they have various chaat items (Indian Street Food) and a Dosa station (savory stuffed crepes).  Service was friendly and prompt - our plates were cleared quickly and servers offered refills of your beverage (mango juice, mimosa, etc.).  

My favorites:

* Saag Paneer - I love the herbed, pureed spinach with paneer (cheese). 
* Both Tandoori chicken and Seekh Kabob were seasoned and juicy.
* The Dosa was thin and super crispy.  I liked eating it with a side of sambar (spicy vegetable and lentil stew).
* Pani Puri - these crispy, hollow bread bowls are supposed to be filled with that green, spicy sauce and eaten in a single bite.  My friend mentioned they cost a few cents each in India but most Bay Area places charge $1 each.  So go for the buffet and pig out!

Probably the only dish I didn't like was the semolina hawra dessert, which had a strange texture.  I prefer carrot hawra like the one made at Favorite Indian in San Ramon.

Overall, a solid 4.5 stars rounding up to 5 for the exceptional service and freshness of the buffet offerings.
author: Daniel C.

description: This is one of the better Indian restaurants for truly Mughlai cuisine. Just FYI, this is not the food Indians eat at home. This is the "dining out" part of the extensive cuisine. The flavors are rich at Amber and the vegetables are cooked just right. The dal makhni and paneer are must-try dishes!
author: Shradha A.

description: Absolutely love this place! Must try here: tandoor appetizers, chicken biryani and mouth-melting lamb kabobs.
author: Nikita A.

description:
My meal at Amber India was a disappointment. 

We arrived for an early dinner on a Sunday afternoon. We started with cocktails-- I had the Kiwi Daisy. It was tart and not too sweet, but still didn't have much flavor. I wasn't impressed, and based on the quality of the drink I would have guessed it would cost $7, not the $15 we paid for it.

For a main dish, I ordered the Navaratan Korma. Now, this isn't supposed to be a spicy dish, but it is certainly supposed to have flavor. The dish I was served was downright bland. There was barely a trace of spice-- there wasn't enough ginger, or garlic, or cardamom, or masala. If there were any cashews or golden raisins, they disappeared in the sauce. I believe there were some almond slivers? Everything was drowned in the heavy cream sauce, which not only muted flavors, but also upset my stomach after the meal. The vegetables were not cooked properly, and many of them were overcooked and too soft. I had the naan, which was just fine but nothing to write home about. Personally, I thought it was a bit too dry. And the laccha paratha, which is supposed to be flaky and buttery, came out heavy and chewy. It was somehow dripping with grease, yet extremely dry and tough. The only thing I really liked here was the papadum, which is really the same in most Indian restaurants and not made in-house. 

At $19 for the korma, $5 for naan, and another $5 for paratha, I would have hoped this meal would be much, much better. Everything I ate here was overly greasy, flavorless, and tasted like it cost a fraction of what we paid. I've had college campus Indian food that was better than what I was served here. I would not recommend coming here when there are so many good Indian restaurants in the Bay Area.

Oh, and when my plates came out-- both the appetizer plate and the main dish plate-- they were both dirty. Come on, Amber India, you can do better.
author: Bhiravi R.

description: Amber India is a great place to eat with friends and family - and who knew it would be so good for brunch! My friend hosted her 24th birthday here with bottomless mimosas included - and it was fantastic. The service was fast and it truly was bottomless even with a party of 20 people. Def recommend for large parties and big events!
author: Alysia T.

description:
One of the most quality Indian restaurant in SF
Great foods with Vegan and Gluten free options 
Nice interior 
Wonderful customer service
author: Vy L.

description:
We a had a delicious dinner here last night.    We ordered the whole fish branzino, the scallops, lamb and vegetarian dishes.   We drank an excellent albarino and we ate lots of nan.     

Everything was wonderful except for the homeless nut person who pressed her face against our window during our entire dinner.

Management should install some fabric (sari-like) drapes for these windows.   The window coverings can be roman shades,  plantation shutters or a decorative grill like the ones in their beautiful bar.

Do something so you have the option to shield an off-putting view during dinner.
author: Calvin L.

description:
I have been here a few times before, and I think this is probably my worst experience. The service was definitely a lot worse than usual. A group of us came here for the brunch buffet which is one of the better brunch buffets in SF. There is endless food and the fresh pav bhaji stand and pre prepared bottomless pani puri is worth it. What puts amber brunch over the top is the option to have bottomless for free. You heard that right, FREE. 25 dollars for bottomless food and drinks is unheard of. 

Unfortunately this time, the wait staff rarely filled out drinks and kept seeming like they were trying to push us out. I think we came on a busy Saturday because usually they are a lot more laid back. Overall, the food is good, but brunch buffet's that are rushed end up not being a great experience. I was also disappointed in the drop off in number of vegetarian options s mentioned by many other reviewers. It felt like previously, there were a lot more options and now it has reduced significantly.
author: Vaibhav S.

description:
This is a great lunch spot if your feeling hungry.  Not a fan of the cuisine but this place does it right.  It's got a great selection tandoori and curry along with fantastic Nan.  The service deserves a call out due to attentiveness.

Food 4
Service 4
Overall 4
author: Patrick C.

description: Love this place. Food is awesome. Location and ambiance are great. Always enjoy the experience here.
author: Colette W.

description: Indian food buffet near the conference center. Not the best Indian food I have had, but several dishes were very tasty. Mediocre naan, but the goat and butter chicken were good. I'm from the Midwest so the pricing in San Francisco is alarming, but even after being in town for a few days I wasn't expecting a $30 lunch buffet. Lots of seating and excellent service, kid friendly.
author: Kiki D.

description: Wanna impress your Bumble date? Take them here! So fancy so delicious! My husband's and are crazy about Indian food especially here at Amber! Cocktails are so delicious Berianni rice and butter chicken and don't miss the awesomeness of Cauliflower Bezule  I could eat that every day for every meal!
author: Linah S.

description: Always love coming here! Such delicious food, great service and the vibe and atmosphere is super positive. If you're looking for good Indian in SF, this is a good place! It's not a cheap/quick place...but perfect for work lunches or dinners!
author: Alex H.

description: We just love this place. They have great spread and each and everything taste so yummm... I loved their Idli Manchurian and sea bass fry the most, the fish was just melt in mouth. My hubby is their kadhi-pakora fan and above all we just loved the mimosas.. mango mimosa is something I had for the first time and I am in absolute love with it... Really an amazing place for weekend brunch
author: Susmita D.

description:
What a delicious lunch buffet! Watch out, as you may end up over-eating and suffering that afternoon food coma.

Came here on a weekday with some co-workers to indulge in the lunch buffet. It seems like a pretty popular place, as we had to wait 5 minutes for the staff to clear a table for us. While no one likes to wait during your lunch break, if you do so your patience will be rewarded! Plus, since it's a lunch buffet, you won't have to wait for your food to be cooked which saves time.

What i appreciate about this buffet is the variety of options. There are many choices for vegetarians, and a good few meat dishes for the omnivores. While all the food is delicious, I especially liked the goat curry, which I feel is rare to find at a buffet.

In addition to the great choices for entrees at the buffet, there are also lots of choices for dessert too! I tried them all because I'm a fatty and it was A++.

Bonus: the wait staff refills water glasses regularly, which is rare for lunch buffets.

If you can be lethargic in the afternoon, do it! Stuff yourself at Amber and embrace the afternoon snooze.
author: Angela C.

description:
Interesting deal for all you can eat and all you can drink for brunch. But the food was pretty mediocre. But nice ambience to get together with friends. 3.5 stars honestly. 

India clay oven is where it's at!
author: J P.

description: A fine dining experience for Indian food. I'm not one to spend a lot of money on fancy food so this was not my cup of tea. It is located in a very upscale part of the town so it's highly recommended between businesses for special meetings. They have some different dishes which are not typically found in Indian restaurants which I want to give them credit for. Their innovation is much appreciated. Very decorated and great service.
author: Julia J.

description:
Good stuff: The Butter Chicken was fantastic. Came out really quickly. Has a tiny bit of spice, stronger than mild, I'd say. Garlic Naan was cooked perfectly. Nice and fluffy on the inside, but crisp on the bottom and edges. Water was refilled often. Rice was standard. 

Sad Stuff: The Paneer kebab sticks were quite terrible. They took surprisingly longer (still fine), but the yogurt on top of it was just disgusting. Then after coming home and feeling the rumbles, both of us wonder if it was actually rancid. 

I'd go back for the butter chicken, which packs a punch of flavor and a bit of heat. Never ever getting that paneer kebab again, still regretting it a day later...
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Highly overrated restaurant. The lady at the reception was really bad. They don't care if you dine in or not. 
This restaurant is not kids friendly. Strollers are not allowed in even if ur baby is sleeping in it. They asked us to get the baby out and leave the stroller at a corner( even when i told them my baby is sleeping n they saw is themselves too).
author: Arvind T.

description:
I went to this restaurant during the JPM Healthcare conference with my colleagues.  Everyone raves about this place which is why we decided to go.  The entrance is unimpressive...when I walked in, it felt like a low budget Chinese restaurant.  They also have ipads on the table that allows you to browse the wine list.  It is super confusing because you can place the wine in a basket for purchase but it does not work.  My table was waiting around on the wine when the waiter finally told us we had to order through him.  

I eat Vegan and the food was just okay.  I had vegetable samosas, cauliflower (not good), sauteed spinach, and naan (no dairy or eggs).   The sauces were delicious and the fried spinach  was amazing.  Overall I would recommend this place but I was not overly impressed.  The vegan ice cream is to die for! I think it's homemade.
author: Brittni D.

description: This place is so delicious! It has nice ambience  and the food is everything.  I got the lobster  curry  so yummy. The grilled lamb chops  were perfect.  Butter chicken  and naan was yummy.   It might be the best Indian  food I've  had in a while.
author: Monica B.

description:
Came here for dinner with a group of friends. Didn't expect this place to be so poppin' but luckily we were able to snag a 7:30pm reservation.

=Palak chat appetizer: 5/5 Unlike anything I've ever had before. They were able to deep fry spinach into tissue paper thin crisps, and the sweet/tartness of the pomegranate seeds complemented the spinach perfectly. I would recommend this!

=Salmon kebab: 4.5/5 Not an authentic Indian dish, I know, but it was healthy and delicious nonetheless. The salmon was juicy and cooked perfectly. The salmon itself was pretty bland but went well with the mint sauce and the sweet brown sauce it came with. My only (minor) gripe was that the pineapple wasn't very juicy/sweet.

=Kulfi: 4/5 Tasted like a creamier ice cream. Yummy. I believe we also had the rasgulla but maybe I'm just not used to the taste/texture, it wasn't as tasty as the Kulfi for sure.

Overall, I had a pleasant dining experience and I wouldn't mind coming back on special occasions.
author: Sylvia Y.

description:
The food is great. Flavorful definitely worth trying. I had the chilli shrimp and garlic noodles with chili chicken the shrimp was better than the chicken. I'm a chicken lover but they all don't fly lol

The noodles we're good. Not soggy or to soft just right.

Not too spicy just right.
author: Mychelle T.

description:
The food is pretty standard - nothing special at all. I will say that I like the restaurant's decor as its a bit more formal than other Indian restaurants in the area.

Why only two stars? It really comes down to poor front end management- the hosts are rude with lots of attitude. I've been to this restaurant three times in the past and have always encountered a rather rude welcoming. Last time I came here there was a group of six before me and they were seated but when my turn came, I was told that they couldn't seat me and the restaurant was now closed due to an issue in the kitchen. OK but why would you seat the party of six right before me? That made no sense to me and also was my last time coming back. 

I think there are much nicer Indian restaurants in the area like August 1 five, Rooh, Dosa. Not to mention much more friendlier staff!
author: Sal V.

description:
Wow. It has been a while I had a good buffet. 
Amber seemed to satisfy all my cravings.
The desserts, omg the desserts were so so so good. I'd recommend the kalakand.
Appetizers were really good too
author: Asmita V.

description:
This was my first visit to Amber India, even though my favorite cuisine is Indian. I live far, far away in the east bay suburbs. There were some great things and some not so great things about this place.

I was dining with two friends, and we decided to order the Tandoori platter for our appetizer, which was a good choice. Unfortunately, it took almost an hour to come out of the kitchen, but it was a Saturday, and we were not in a rush. The Tandoori meats were superb.

We each ordered a curry. My friends ordered rice and naan. I ordered roti, and I ordered my food spicy. Everything came out except my roti, which took another 10 minutes. My food, lamb korma, was very bland, and I pointed it out to our waitress, so she took it back to the kitchen. My friend had been served a nicely spiced dish, Lamb Rogan Josh. So the cooks mixed up some Rogan Josh sauce in with my korma sauce and sent it back out to me. The korma was supposed to be creamy, and the rogan josh was a sauce heavily dependent on tomatoes, so the two did not mix well at all. I am not sure why the chefs decided to do that, but it was a bad decision. The lamb in both dishes was extremely tender, but the sauce on mine was spoiled. I took it home with me, but I ended up tasting one bite and throwing the rest out. 

Our waitress was an angel and took pity on us for our long wait. She comped our Tandoori platter and brought us out some free strawberry sorbet; it was delicious! We also ordered gulab jamun, and it was some of the best we had ever tasted. 

I conclude that this restaurant is an uneven experience deserving of 3 stars.
author: Gail E.

description:
Enjoyed a number of good meals here in the past but seems to have lost some of its luster. 

Service was uninspiring and rushed things. Curries came out cold and the creme brûlée desert looked and tasted like it was prepared hours prior. We sent it back and had it taken of the bill but the server didn't seem to care about any of it. $300 for 2 starters, 2 mains and wine for 4 ppl. Just an overall disappointing meal. 

Would only come for the lunch buffet. At least you'll get your curries hot then.
author: Neil W.

description: Visiting from San Diego, we decided to try some Indian food. From the moment we walked the staff was welcoming and friendly. Even though it was very busy, Saturday night we only waited about 10 min or less. Our server Daniel was very helpful and  had some great recommendations, butter chicken was delicious, cauliflower bezule, murgh parda biryani and cucumber mint raita all very good.. we truly enjoyed our dinner and service here. Highly recommend.
author: Lisette P.

description:
Delicious food yet pricey
Nice atmosphere and decorations yet I didn't like the dim lights 
Wished they had outdoor seatings, it would be really great when the weather is nice
author: Hanan A.

description: Lovely higher end restaurant! One of my bffs treated here yesterday for my birthday & it was nearby the Metreon where I saw Jurassic World 2: Fallen Kingdom. Anyhow, it's a little by dark with little ventilation but the food, service, ambiance & Location make up for those. All items are charged separately & are more expensive than an average Indian Buffet. Although the bill came out to $120 for two ladies who didn't drink any liquor, each of us had perfectly packed doggy bags. Additionally the cottage cheese milk dessert  called rasgullah, was made from scratch & is the best one I've ever had! Bathrooms are clean & full of privacy. It's definitely a treat to go here here cuz it's chic & use iPads to read the wine list!
author: R C.

description:
Aesthetic and upscale Indian food place. 
Just as we entered the restaurant on a Saturday night, we were told 40 mins to wait. We were able to get in before 40 mins 
Menu is decent - with a lot of vegetarian options (they could do more paneer options)
Paneer tikka skewer is really good! So were the other entrees we ordered, portions were good wrt to how upscale they are. 
Deeply disappointed by the Mango Lassi though (both the flavor and texture were not impressive)
Pesto naan was good in itself but didn't go with the entrees we ordered (Kadhai paneer, korma and moilee) 
Garlic naan and roti were good.
Overall vibe of the place is great - fast service (waiter seemed the be in a great rush)
author: Pranam D.

description: We've had dinner here before and enjoyed it. Today we tried the lunch buffet and it was great. A huge fan of the chaat and the made to order dosas. Will definitely be back.
author: Morgan F.

description:
Amber India is a really interesting restaurant to me...it's unlike any Indian restaurant I've ever been to or ordered from. To begin with, the menu is a bit unusual and different from any other standard Indian menu that you've probably ever seen. They have items "from the clay plot" like truffled chicken tikka, salmon pineapple kebob, and "duet of cauliflower and broccoli." The items from their "curry pot" menu start to include some of the more familiar items like butter chicken and saag paneer, but the names and descriptions of each dish seem really unusual and like they're trying really hard to be fancy and trendy and "San Francisco-y" if you know what I mean. While you can order chicken tikka masala if you ask for it, they don't actually have it on the menu. I found that out this week when I ordered food to take out. I've eaten here a few times but have always gotten their chicken biryani. I'm not a huge biryani fan but a coworker recommended it to me here and so I tried it and I LOVED it! The raita here is also the best I've ever had. This week I wanted to branch out and order something different so I got the chicken tikka masala with white rice and garlic naan. I didn't check the bag before I left and when I opened it up at my hotel they had given me brown rice. That was a bit annoying. The tikka masala was good but wouldn't say that it was the best I've ever had. The garlic naan was disappointing. Of course I'm going to eat it and enjoy it because it's toasted bread with butter and garlic, but overall the texture of the bread was meh. 

Most of their meat entrees range from $25 - $35 and their vegetarian entrees are around $19 - but guess what. They don't include rice, so you have to pay extra. WTF! I hate when places do that. At least lower the cost of the entree then if you're going to have to pay extra for rice but at Amber India, you're already overpaying for the entree and then you have to pay $5.95 for the ride to eat with it. And it's not like the portions are any bigger than what would get at any other Indian restaurant. So, for a standard meal of chicken tikka masala and rice, you're paying around $31 and that's not including tax or tip yet. I don't know about you but that's a lot of money for food that I'm not over the moon about. While I won't disagree that they likely do use fresh and high quality ingredients, it doesn't stand out enough to me where I'm OK with paying these prices. I've only eaten here during work travel so I get to expense my meals, but out of pocket I'm not sure that I would come back here ...if I did, it would only be for the biryani and raita!
author: Emily T.

description:
Amber India & the restaurants along Yerba Buena Lane charge the prices they do because they cater to downtown employees & tourists (two groups who can supposedly afford to splurge.) For your money here, you're getting all the luxuries not always guaranteed at a Tenderloin hole-in-the-wall: sophisticated atmosphere, mindful service, beautifully-plated dishes, cleanliness. Still, I can't help but wince when I see items in the $29-$34 range. 

We ordered: 
-- samosas ($9.95): potato & pea dumplings had a crispy exterior, spiced mushy interior, & was served with a mint & a tamarind chutney. 
-- claypot roasted lobster ($34.95): didn't try, arranged to look as gorgeous as a Michelin-rated meal. 
-- chicken tikka masala (was not on the menu; I don't recall price): so much delicious, spicy sauce to dip garlic naan into/spoon over basmati saffron rice. 
-- non-alcoholic drinks ($7 each): mango mojito & amber crush (hello, raspberry & pomegranate sweetness!) 

Though the menu exhibits impressive variety, I'm not likely to return. I like to sample several (okay, many) items; can't do that here & still have enough money left for shopping in Union Square!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
OK food. Rude staff especially the bearded receptionist guy. Average service and not kids friendly. 

Highly not recommended if you're with children. Plenty of other better places for Indian food.
author: Vatsal B.

description: It is one of my fave Indian restaurants in SF. All the items are tasty and they doing an especially awesome job with the non veg items. I recommend the butter chicken and lamb boti. Parking is near by in a garage on Mission st. Be sure to make a reservation as tables fill up fast.
author: Anand P.

description:
Great service and delicious Indian cuisine.

Wonderful saffron rice, curry lamb stew and AWESOME freshly baked Nam.

Very nice decor and good value for the money
author: Elaine W.

description: This review is long overdue and I really don't remember much about the place, the service, etc. anymore. I do, however, remember how I thought the foods were pricey but so good especially the buttered chicken (chicken curry). By far, the best I've had. And that's the number one and perhaps the only reason I'd go back to Amber.
author: Celina A.

description:
Protesting in San Francisco can work up quite an appetite! 

Fortunately, Amber India wasn't far away.  My friend Victoria and I walked as fast as we could, eager to satisfy our craving for authentic Indian food.  Lunch time at Amber is busy!  Packed!!!  The buffet draws large crowds of people.  

Despite the busy atmosphere we still felt like VIPs.  We were greeted and seated immediately.  Our waiter informed us of our options (buffet or we could order off the menu) and was very pleasant.  Somewhere during our visit our waiters changed or we had multiple waiters lol.  Either way, I don't mind!  After waiting in line for maybe...10 minutes?  We finally got our hands on some creamy, yummy butter chicken, jasmine rice, chicken biryani, pakora, salad, tamarind sauce, and they even have green spicy peppers to savor with your meal!

We also enjoyed some delicious mocktails prepared by Shahil.  Shahil was busy multitasking but still made time to check in and provide great customer service.  Our waiter Bingra was also super attentive and kind.  Our water glasses were never empty and he made us feel at home.  Bingra went out of his way to please us and ensure that our lunch was perfect.

Amber must be the Bay Area's favorite Indian restaurant, because even NBA champions like to dine here.  Festus Ezeli of the Portland Trailblazers (former Oakland Warrior) was also standing in the buffet line!  I was so very lucky to meet this humble, friendly, and sincere man while enjoying my meal.  Obviously, Amber India is a popular choice and loved by all.

Stop by for lunch (the buffet) or dinner, you will not be disappointed.

Thank you Amber India for an amazing lunch and experience.  You made my day!
author: Tricia N.

description:
One of the best --if not the best Indian restaurants I have ever been to. For appetizers, try the duck skewer- amazing and perfectly spiced. My wife loved the Butter chicken and I had the lamb curry. We argued over which one was better.
Get the mango mojito as a compliment---it was a superb dining experience.
author: Tim F.

description: Delicious.  Excellent service, excellent food.  I had Butter Chicken, Saag Paneer, papads, and garlic chicken naan.  All very good.
author: Tracy S.

description: Amber India is a very good restaurant for Indian cuisine. They have well presented dishes here, a good decor, and many dishes use organic meats sourced from California farms. The Byriani here is done the best possible way, Dum-style, where it is sealed into a container with a pastry on top, keeping the moisture, flavor, and heat inside until it is ready to serve. They have an excellent Baingan (eggplant) dish that uses baby eggplants and stuffs them. Mango Creme Brulee here was a great dessert option, too. In addition to the excellent food, service was very good and attentive, and they have a nice selection of wine available.
author: Matthew S.

description: I went here for lunch with a colleague. When we were seated, we realized we were at a table right next to a table where our manager was seated. When we asked to move, the staff was really rude saying we would have to wait another 30 mins before we could be moved. We ended up asking the hostess to move us and she promptly did. The food was decent. I'd say, good enough for a business lunch. The palak chaat was good at the start, but it's a big serving and gets too oily to finish.
author: Sharadha R.

description:
First and last time here... came out of their restaurant a few minutes ago, due to bad service. 
It's a rainy Monday night and they had ton of open tables at 6:30 pm. I was alone but wanted a dining experience after a very long day at work. The hostess said the only table for single person is at the bar... I wasn't thrilled but I said OK and went and sat at one of the sofas by the bar. After a few minutes of sitting, the bar tender walks over and throws the menu at my table without even saying hello or making eye contact and walks away... I wanted to try this place for a long time and I told myself to let it go and stay for the food despite the bad service. I sat there for a while and no one was coming to even bring a glass of water and I decided no matter how good the food is if I'm spending a $100 for dinner this is not the experience I want to have. I walked out and shared my frustration with the hostess, which then tries to make me go back to the bar and offers to talk to the bar tender to come assist me... NOT worth it! 
luckily Blue Stem next door is my go to and I always have a great experience not just with food but also service... I'm enjoying a nice cocktail and steak sitting at a nice table as I'm writing the review. It's not the original option that I was hoping to have tonight but at least they are consistently pleasant.

I posted pictures as I finished my dinner next door over an hour after they refused to give me a table, they have plenty of them open and bar is empty, yet the bearded bar tender couldn't bother to say hello!
author: Shell S.

description: I met a friend for dinner recently in San Francisco. Since she lives in San Francisco, I had her pick out the restaurant. We were both craving Indian, so she suggested Amber India. Fantastic suggestion - Amber India is great! Amber India in the SoMa part of San Francisco. The restaurant itself is tastefully decorated. Definitely have a reservation! We ordered: samosas, the tandoori chicken, the sea bass, and the naan. Everything was delicious. The service was good. We will definitely be coming back again!
author: Irene L.

description:
If you love Indian food and you're near Market Street in SF, I highly recommend Amber India! Please make a reservation as we had to wait about 45 minutes for a table, but it was worth the wait.

Everything we ordered was delicious and fun and we'll definitely be back. I can vouch for the following entree's:

Butter Chicken
Saag Paneer
Tandoori Sampler
Garlic Naan

Thank you, Amber India for a delicious meal!
Next time we're in SF, we'll be back.
author: Brian P.

description:
Yes it's pricey, but it's worth it. It's upscale, and without a reservation, you'll be waiting a while. But they also have a bar area with some first-come seating, and they serve the same menu. The food has presentation to it, and the taste is pretty damn good. This is one my favorites. 

Things to try: Pani Puri, Palak Chatt, Dal Makhani, Saag Paneer, Badam Bhara Baingan, Bhindi Jaipuri

For the non-vegs: My husband always goes for the Frontier Lamb Chops or the Murgh Parda Biryani

Desserts: all of it. really.
author: Avani G.

description:
It's the best Indian lunch buffet in town. Butter chicken is their signature dish and everyone goes for that, but the baingan bharta and palak paneer are pretty good too, and the fish filets at the end of the buffet - though few even touch them - are delicious. They'll bring as many naan baskets as you need, but order the garlic naan; it's particularly good. 

The wait for the buffet is hit-or-miss, though. Some days the line moves swiftly, but other days there's a crowd of dozens waiting.
author: Alex L.

description: The ambience is great. The appetizers were more flavorful and tasty than the entrees. Food came out fast and in an authentic presentation.
author: Tai C.

description:
Good ambience, bad food!! This place is pricey, that is fine but the taste of the food is not even close to indian food. If i heat my togo food the day after, i assume that will taste better. 

Ambience is good for an indian restaurant but everything else, including service is bad. I had higher expectations from this place, but it was an utter disappointment. Breads were frozen ( no fresh breads), curries were spice-less and sweet. Not even close to good indian food. Big no, if eating good indian food is on your mind.
author: Ankur G.

description: Amber India is a North Indian restaurant with very nice ambience. The food is heavy and creamy and it is definitely on the pricey end. Sharing an appetizer, 2 main curries and sides you will be paying around $100! It's a lovely night out and I recommend the organic dal amber as a vegetarian. The Kumbh Hara bhara pyaz kofta is also worth a mention being an inventive dish differing from the standard malai kofta.
author: Ruchi M.

description: This place is really good! I went for the lunch buffet and left full and happy. What makes it different than your typical Indian lunch buffet is the atmosphere and the action station. It's more on the upscale side compared to other places- it's really beautiful inside and the buffet even seems fancy. The quality of the food was great, too. What makes this place really stand out, though, is the action station. They do Indian style crepes and vegetarian Indian "sloppy joes." All delicious! Give this place a try!
author: Lisa T.

description:
Just wrapped up a dinner at Amber tonight. The food was probably the best Indian I've ever eaten, and I've had my fair share of Indian food. 

The Chaat was delicious, the Samosas had a ton of flavor, the Cauliflower app is a must try. We also got the Lamb vindaloo, and Biryani and both were delicious. I really don't think you can have a bad meal here.

We ended on the Galab Jamun which is freshly made to order with vanilla ice cream and it was hands down the best I've ever eaten.

If you really enjoy Indian food, you really can't go wrong here.
author: Gina C.

description:
I have had at Amber before and has always been decent.  But of late, the quality has come down, especially at buffet.

For Vegetarians, the choice has dwindled in the buffet.  Nan quality has come down as well.
author: Venkatesh K.

description: Great Indian buffet in the SOMA area - the food is authentic and delicious, with very unique spice combinations and dishes. The ambiance is lively and modern, with tradition coloring reflecting Indian and Asian traditions. I bring many business associates here to experience the friendly service, great food, and excellent location (easy Ferry, BART, and Metro access). It can definitely get crowded at peak times, so you may want to make reservations, arrive early, or prepare to wait a bit. And, it is always worth it!
author: Eric F.

description: "Amber India" has all the attributes of a perfect Indian restaurant. Delicious and as close u can get to authentic indian food, stylish ambience , perfect for any meal...friendly staff ..Recommended dishes - Cauliflower Bezule, Spinach Roti , Daal and Paneer...
author: Sanchit K.

description:
God I love this place. I've come here for dinner as well as weekend lunch, but the best deal is on weekends hands down. 

For ~$25 you get the lunch buffet and bottomless mimosas. The food is excellent, with everything from pani puri (the liquid for it comes out of a dispenser and into double shot glasses!!) and freshly-made dosa, to various types of vegetable and meat dishes. It is so worth it. I didn't know about the mimosa part until a young couple sitting near us mentioned it. My life has changed since then. Really though, I come here for celebrating with friends all the time now. Service is great, they can tell when you're celebrating and refill quickly, and they also do mango mimosas! 

Dinner is very nice too, as it's a classy place. I can't remember exactly what I've ordered, but I've never had a bad experience here. It's always worth
author: Alka M.

description:
Had dinner at Amber last night. They staff was accommodating and friendly. The place has a modern and clean vibe.  Started with some Taj beers and some tandoori chicken and lamb. Both cooked perfectly with char on the outside while retaining its juiciness.  The lamb had a great spice to it which went well with the tamarind and cilantro sauces. 

We shared entrees and ordered the butter chicken, lamb vindaloo, and some vegetable dishes with naan and rice.   The butter chicken was the best I've had. The lamb was also nice and presented well with the bone on.  Great overall
author: Jason B.

description:
Amazing food and beverages. We were a party of 14 (booked ahead of time). They gave us a private area and couple of servers. Servers were really friendly!!

Palak chat, cauliflower bezule, duck kebobs and chicken were all soooo good.
author: K P.

description: We had the buffet lunch on a Saturday afternoon and we were pleasantly surprised.  They had all of our favorites like Butter Chicken, Tandoori Chicken, vegetarian dishes, cooked to order foods....so many selections and very tasty.    They bring the naan bread to the table and graciously give you more if you ask for it.  And the kicker was bottomless mimosas/sparkling wine.  Now that was a a deal!    The only downside is we were sat next to two couples who became increasingly very loud the more they drank.  The tables are very close together so it is hard to get away from the loudness.  I would recommend a table right at the entrance or in the back room - way in back.  I will definitely return.
author: Ginger O.

description:
Food: outstandingly delicious. I am generally picky about Indian food. These people know how to mix all the right flavors with the right amount of grease (a.k.a not too greasy).

I loved the sophisticated flavors.

We got their:
-Paneer skewer, excellent texture and flavor.
-Samosas, excellent flavors. Samosas r a hit or miss, but at this place it was a hit for sure. 

-Veggie Biryani: excellent 
-Veggie Kufta: excellent
-Dahl, excellent
-Spinach dish, excellent 

Their special cocktail menu is alright.

The ambiance was nice. A nice family dinner evening.

Come here for their food!
author: Mary N.

description:
Great indian foos with a unique mix kf traditional and modern indian dishes. Right balance of flavors and presentation. 


Ask for Danial to be your waiter and he will get you the right indian dining experience.
author: Suhair D.

description:
The only Indian restaurant in entire USA that is consistent with superb quality, delicious taste, variety in menu with ultimate experience . Even the lunch buffet is a hit! 

8 years, 50+ visits and not even single complaint.
author: Rohit P.

description: Finally get to try the lunch buffet with coworkers.   It was a splurge for lunch at $20 + 18% service charge.   Good selection and the dessert had the right sweetness.  Lots of vegetarian selections for the buffet.
author: Drew B.

description:
I liked but didn't love this place... 

Space- Walked in for a super early dinner and got seated next to the open service area even though there were several open tables in the dining area (remained open even as we  were leaving)... Overall space was interesting though 

Service- good, attentive service 

Food- ordered the four spice sea bass based on waiter's recommendation- ok but super salty.. Was using the chutney to reduce the salt... Served with an undressed salad and unflavored quinoa... Ok while I get this is a modern interpretation of Indian food, flavor can be modern too- add seasoning.  Also the portion size of my dinner varied drastically from my dinner companions.  While Indian is often served family style, in a modern interpretation that should probably be mentioned....   Mango brûlée was delicious and scraped clean...
author: Tazeen L.

description: The food and drinks were amazing. We sat at the bar with Brianna as our server. She was super attentive and I've never had better drinks. I had the Lamb Rogan Josh and my girlfriend had the Chicken K. Both were spectacular.
author: Mike L.

description:
Service: 3 stars

  Waiters don't know how to clean tables properly. They dropped untencils on floor.

Food: 4.5 stars

  Food is hit-or-miss. A few items such as the Truffle Chicken is awesome. Probably the best Naans in all of Bay area. If your looking for authentic Indian food then you might want to pass. Amber is more progressive food.

Cleanliness: 3 stars

  Not the cleanest places. Low lighting makes it a little hard to notice.
author: Jay D.

description: Tried this place while visiting San Fra in business. I am a huge fan of Indian cuisine and tried several places back in Manhattan where I live. This place is ok but nothing spectacular. Somewhat fancy with solid menu but lacks authenticity and true quality. Not recommended.
author: Alfredo S.

description: The bar managers were very helpful when my friend and I wanted to have dinner at the bar but it was packed! They move a few tables around and we were seated right away. I'd highly recommend the truffled chicken tikka with saffron rice. They also have a few wines from India. I tried the chenin blanc and was pleasantly surprised.  Who knew?
author: Hayley H.

description: Fancy overpriced Indian food. Sorry, I mean everything was tasty. But the four of us dropped over 3 bills here. That included 2 mango lassi's and 2 alcoholic drinks. The food was really the bulk of the cost. I also somewhat blame the over ordering of the two gentleman of the table. I could've been satisfied with way less but I stuffed myself and there was maybe 2 small boxes taken home. Anyways we had a bunch of stuff like the samosas, paneer and vegetable skewers, Kashmiri rogam josh (lamb curry), saag paneer (cheese curry pot), bindhi jalpuri (okra curry), pesto and regular noon, and biryani (spiced rice cooked). I think the biryani is a ripoff - it's rice cooked or served in a naan covered dish and it's almost $30. I think all the curry pots were a little too salty for me. They had depth of flavor but the more I kept eating them, the more I didn't want to. The ambiance of the restaurant is romantic, I would describe it as. It's dark, the tables are close together. But yeah, eh I don't think I'll be back.
author: Alison W.

description:
Three stars if for the food, very good options in the buffet and good quality food for its price. They lost two stars from me because of their staff, very unpleasant and rude. The person at the front desk is so rude and snobby.... they need to get people who are little happy or company needs to keep them happy so they atleast smile and be nice.
The price i am paying there, i deserve better behavior.
Also second it happened that their credit card machine was not working and they can you please give us cash... really.... such a good restaurant on market street does that.... hmmm
author: Bhawna V.

description: Great food! Good variety. Authentic flavours and a great place for a good family lunch or dinner. I went for the buffet on a Saturday and it was one of the best Indian meals I have had. Definitely recommend this place!
author: Divya G.

description:
I think that Amber India is a good restaurant because we liked the food and the restaurant.There was samosa,Butter chicken tandoori chicken we loved it.

The server asked us what to eat, and offered us best options. As a kid from now on this is my best place to eat and enjoy.....thank you. Love from angel & Adi....
author: Manish T.

description: I usually don't give two stars. But I have to do it. The ambience and decor is amazing, but the food is just pure bad. It is a 30 dollar lunch buffet, the appetizers are nice but the main course is tasteless. This is one of those places that add stuff in the food so you get a bloat and you don't eat too much. I ate and my stomach was hurting. This is just bad name to Indian food. Now the ambience is nice, but come on if the main course is terrible what are you here for? Greasy, tasteless and additives to make you bloat. Please save your self.
author: Shivaji D.

description: Had dinner at Amber, we were greeted in a friendly manner and quickly seated on a Friday night! Our server was delightful and insightful.  As an appetizer we ordered the Samosa which was tasty as was the naan. We ordered the chicken tandoori which was cooked perfectly, it was very tasty. We also had the Badan Bhara Baingan (baby eggplant) which was very tasty and cooked to our liking.  The only downside to our experience was we never received the 2 other appetizers we ordered before we received our entree so we asked them not to bring it out.  Overall a good dining experience.
author: Brian S.

description:
Awesome food and drinks! Spinach chaat, samosa chaat and Peshawari chicken were awesome. Appetizer portions are small but main course portions are good for sharing. 

Tried palak paneer, amber daal, butter chicken and okra and everything was delicious.
author: Rohit G.

description: Overrated, expensive, and the food is average quality. They acted like they were doing us a favor when we walked in and asked for seating for two without reservations on a relatively quiet night. Unbundled pricing means you can order a $20 curry and expect to pay extra for either rice or bread. Food is clearly mostly frozen stuff that's warmed up, and it's not warmed up much. Great place to go if you don't know what Indian food is supposed to taste like.
author: Vikram N.

description: I've had dinner here more than once during various visits to SF, and each time I'm reminded what a fine restaurant Amber India is. Start with the Aloo Peas Samosa and Palak Chat. We usually also get the assorted bread basket. Saag Paneer is a must-have. Chili rubbed fish kebab got great response from our party as well. Finish with the Chocolate Molten Cake. Service at the table was excellent. Very attentive and friendly staff.
author: David W.

description:
This place serves great Indian (and fusion) food. The buffet is definitely more on the expensive side for Indian food in the city but it is definitely worth it for the variety and options they have, especially over the weekend. 

The bottomless mimosas and sparkling wine on the weekends and the addition of a separate food station over the weekends also add to the value.
author: Rohit S.

description:
The mango lassi is to die for. Definitely could be shared by 2-3 people though. Very sweet and thick. 

Go for the lunch buffet. Cheap and yummy. One of the better buffets I've been to. The butter chicken and yogurt dip are my favorites!
author: Becca U.

description:
YUM! This place as a really nice lunch buffet. It's the nicest I've seen so far! Lots of options and not enough stomach space to try it all. 

Also be sure to get a mango lasse!
author: Alex M.

description:
I went to Amber on a whim, and there was about a 10 minute wait around noonish on a Sunday. 

The buffet was pretty impressive. They had a variety of savory and sweet dishes, as well as a cook who was making a vegetarian curry special for brunch. Hands down the best item was the butter chicken, though.

And, get this - unlimited mimosas too! I've never been to a boozy Indian buffet before, but I was into it. The mimosas are well made and extra fizzy. And, at $26, I feel it's cheaper than other boozy brunch places. 

Would definitely stop by again.
author: Victoria L.

description: We started with the palak chaat which was a little different than expected, but non the less tasty. A light crunchy spinach snack to start of a heavy meal. Great environment to set the mood. Also had their speciality butter chicken and chicken biryani which was great. The presentation of the chicken biryani is unique. Food tastes very fresh! Definitely recommend!
author: Moiz T.

description:
I'm a long time fan of Amber, visiting it a couple times a year on business trips to San Francisco. It's usually solid Indian in an upscale environment. On this visit, Service was exceptional, as always, but I found the quality of the food significantly diminished. Rice was clumpy.  Curry dishes lacked flavor and complexity. Prices had increased. 
Their proximity to Moscone ensures capacity but seems to have made them less attentive to quality.
author: Ellen C.

description:
It was my first visit to Amber and I was very pleased with the experience.
The quality of the food was outstanding
The staff and customer service was excellent.
author: Ramon A.

description: Being Indian I can tell you that this place is WAY overrated...the kebabs we had at Happy Hour were great the beer was ok, but the dinner was horrible we had chicken tikka not on the menu i know now why it isn't.  When u pay over 4.00  for garlic naans it bette be damn good, they were burned. The rice was warm the service was OK nothing to rave about.  Honestly keep your money and spend it at the Galleria and grab yourself a pretzel.
author: Yuvraj C.

description: Solid Indian food and the kitchen was willing to accommodate my spicy desires. They brought out several different levels of spice and while it never hit my threshold I think the chefs chose to make sure the food was still tasty no matter what. I appreciated that approach.
author: Josh S.

description:
I wish i could give 0 or -ve stars. Pathetic restaurent, worst food and ambience. I would prefer going to a street truck food where customer is respected. The guy (with beard) at front desk is so rude and offensive, doesn't really care to even answer properly. They need to go back to basics and understand what their business is and who they are serving.
I will never again visit this restaurent and also DOES NOT recommend this to any one who wants to have a happy meal.
author: Venu I.

description: The place is ideally located in downtown SF and the ambience was great. Paneer and chicken were both awesome.
author: Vinay G.

description:
Was not so impressed w/ the food here. 
5pm-enter the restaurant and seated
5:10pm-rec'd water and ordered
5:45pm-rec'd appetizer
5:50pm-asked about our food 
5:55pm-food finally arrives
6:20-leave restaurant

Ordered duck skewer appetizer, quinoa ($7/lamb ($27)/lentils ($19), mango lassi

The duck was very gamey. Lamb was bloody spicy (wasn't asked the level of spice we wanted). My tongue burnt so badly i could no longer taste anything. Overall, prices were extraordinary high, service painfully slow (esp when we arrived it just opened).. Would most likely not be returning.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Stumbled upon this restaurant because it was walking distance from my hotel.
What a pleasant surprise. As soon as we walked in we were greeted courteously by the host and hostess. We were seated almost immediately. 
The server was very knowledgeable and patient going over some of the menu items.
We tried the Tandori chicken and Tikka Masala with some Naan 
Everything was deliciously prepared and the temperature of the food was perfect. 
Will definitely come back the next time I am in San Francisco to try some of the other menu items.
author: Tristan K.

description:
On our visit to SFMOMA, we decided to take a break and have lunch. We decided on Amber. My wife and I love Indian food, but she isn't into the curries. 
The price for lunch, a la carte, was quite expensive for lunch, but they did have a luncheon buffet which was, I think, $25. 
There was a good selection of dishes to choose from and all delicious, even the desserts were tasty. 
Lots of Indian people patronize this restaurant during lunch which I thought was a good sign.
author: Charles D.

description: My husband and I arrived about 45 minutes early to our reservation (we were hungry!) and while they couldn't accommodate us we waited in the bar where we ordered 2 excellent cocktails.
