My gosh, this place is exquisite! The best buffet I've ever been to. Perfect for a lunch-time date or office getaway splurge. The staff was so attentive, it felt like a fine dining experience. They didn't even rush us out even though we stayed long after everyone else (the buffet closes at 2:30 pm). 

I normally don't like butter chicken but theirs was wonderful with big chunks of meat and not too sweet sauce. Honestly, everything was delicious. I like that they also have hearts of palms in their salad. The raita was a great salad dressing (the mint chutney is also equally as amazing).

We plan on coming back for dinner!
author: Kristy O.

description: Dissapointed very over priced lamb kebabs very dry and tasted strange, spinach & paneer curry tasteless. Biriyani was really good. We didn't eat the food that wasn't good they just took it back and didn't seem to care we just said it didn't taste right. They still charged us full price for everything then made us wait ages because they forgot to bring the bill. I'm from UK but with Indian origin so I know very well good Indian food.
author: Aisha Q.

description:
This review is for the lunch buffet. We came in around 1 pm and as expected the place was packed. Being really hungry we (me and wife) jumped right to the buffet after waiting for few minutes at the hostess.

... And here's the summary:

1. Location : pretty easy to find

2. Service: slowwww and the somehow they fail to serve the naan warm !!! Everytime.

3. Buffet spread: average more skewed on non veg than veg

4. Ambience: average to poor if you take the price into account - cramped space

5. Food quality: quality of ingredients were right up to the mark while there were some shortcomings on the menu selection - I mean who keeps deserts which are all too sweet :) and a mix veg item consisting of broccoli and sprouts ( cmon broccoli ... )

6. Food taste: I was pretty impressed with butter chicken and chicken biriyani, both were stand outs while in vegetarian dishes only thing I could see which was proper was paneer kadai all other were just fill ins. 

Overall a 4 star rating with room for improvement in veg selections and BTW price for buffet for 2 pax was around $45. 

Cheers :)
author: Abhi P.

description: Good food and good atmosphere! It's one of my regular stops for Indian food in the city. The place can get a little busy at dinner time, but usually have no problem grabbing a couple seats and dinner service at the bar. Highly recommend the lamp shank with curry! They have a decent happy hour appetizers and drinks. Last time I got the Marz Julep which was really good!
author: James S.

description: One of the best Indian food I had in US. it's a bit expensive but worth the visit. Good appetizer and deserts.
author: Vishal C.

description:
This was one of the most expensive Indian buffets I've ever experienced eating BUT the food, the service and the overall experience was worth every penny. Our total bill with tip and tax came close to $60 for 2 people.

The buffet will suit vegetarians and meat lovers. There are so many dishes that I'm not familiar with but everything tasted so good. I got to eat a little bit of everything. The selection is quite a lot from the salad bar to the hot dishes to the desserts. Some of the desserts I've never seen served at a buffet before like the jalebi (deep fried yummy orangey goodness). These are desserts only sold at specialty stores. I was really impressed. 

The actual restaurant layout was a bit tight. It was hard to get up and around people when I was making my rounds to the buffet bar. Their bathroom is super clean and fancy.

Parking is always hard to find but we parked at a structure and walked about 2-3 blocks before finding this place.  We got lost but I'm sure the locals or those who are familiar with this area will have no problem finding this place.

**RECOMMENDED**
author: Sharr K.

description:
They do the best Indian food in the city(period)
I can add a bit to it ;)
And they are listed on DoorDash, for dinners only I think!!
author: Mukta B.

description: Ever since I tried the food at this Indian restaurant for the first time a few weekends ago I have been craving it again! The interior of this restaurant is so clean and beautiful looking. There is even a nice bar area upstairs when you enter. My friend and I split an order of butter chicken, basmati rice, garlic naan bread, and samosas to go and that was way more than enough food for us. The chicken with very rich so that made me full quick. The food we ordered all tasted great. I can't wait to go back soon!
author: Jen C.

description: Have been coming here for their sumptuous weekend brunch and also have hosted my birthday lunch twice at this place ...what can I say I love ALL of their food ...esp the butter chicken and lamb chops ...my fav place for Indian food
author: Tanya A.

description: Centrally located, big restaurant with separate and nice-to-sit bar area. We had the buffet at Saturday lunch, which was very good, but twice the highest price I ever paid for an Indian food buffet. Everything was good, but attesting to what I had, the paneer in yogurt/pepper sauce was awesome. Clean and spacious restrooms.
author: Yoram Y.

description:
Best Indian Food in the city? Not by a long shot. Priciest Indian food in the city - sure thing. 

Sea Bass - EXCELLENT

Duck Appetizer & Lobster curry - GOOD

Rogan gosh, Biryani, Chicken tikka - below average.

Service - Fair.

Not impressed & Not disappointed - Just average.
author: Saddle U.

description:
This is by far one of the best Indian restaurants I've been to in the states.  I do admit that it is pricey, but the foods aromatic flavors make up for that.  

When you walk in you are greeted immediately.  We made an open table reservation and had no problem with any waiting. 

The restaurant was very spacious and the decor is elegant.  

The service was great.  They were very attentive.  Took drink orders right away and didn't rush us to order but also didn't ignore us when we were ready to order our appetizers and entree. One small piece of our naan was burnt.  They brought us a new piece to replace it when I mentioned it. 

There is an actual full bar and extensive drink menu which is not typical of Indian restaurants. Most Indian restaurants that I've been to are family owed and you can tell. 

We recommend the palak chaat.  It was a unique twist on tradition chaat.  Flash fried spinach with the Bells and whistles of traditions chaat. The garlic naan doesn't have an over powering taste of garlic as well so it doesn't take away from the entree. 

All in all,  it's a classy restaurant that serves Indian ... Not an "Indian restaurant" (anyone that goes to lots of Indian restaurants will know what I mean).  It really would only work in big cities due to the cost.  We would definitely come back if we are back in San Fran anytime.
author: Roshni S.

description:
First of all this place is named Amber India....and my name is Amber so I had to go in lol
The restaurant was so beautiful inside. The decor, lighting, ambiance, was very romantic and perfect for our first dinner on vacation in SF. The savory potato turnover for appetizer was very tasty but in my opinion a bit spicy. I'm not a pro on Indian food at all but I wish the food overall wasn't spicy. As my entree I had the shrimp and scallop dish which was really good as well. Our waiter, Joe was amazing. Very attentive and pleasant. I would go back to this place if I'm back in town.
author: Amber V.

description:
I have been going to Amber for the past 4 years or so and I recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting SF who wants an American touch on exotic cuisine. This is one of my favorite food and drinks spots in San Francisco.
As a huge fan of Indian food, Amber's spice level is so on-point, and reflects the authenticity of what India is known for... spices. Well duh, that's a no brainer and the best advice I can give is; if you ever have to add salt to your Indian dish than chances are it has not been prepared very well. 

The ambiance is trendy and chic. If you just want to go in for drinks they have a great happy hour and the bar is located to the right when you first walk in. This area is separate from the larger part of the restaurant. 

The main reason I love Amber is for their brunch. It is a favorite SF brunch of mine. The food doesn't reflect the average "New-American" styles that most brunches offer but instead is an "all you can eat" India buffet that is exquisite and mouth watering. Let's just say that one plate will not do justice. The best part is the bottomless mango mimosas, they are to die for. You can get all this for just under $30 per person... Oh and bottomless naan too. Sounds like a steal to me considering that one mimosa costs about $10. 
When I leave Amber I am always satisfied with the service and come out feeling a little drunk. 4 words: A Job Well Done  

Xo-S
author: Sierra L.

description:
In SF for a conference and after a 15+ hour day I was just looking for a good, relatively quick meal. Being next to the Marriott during a conference I expected it to be packed, and it was. I got a seat at a bar table and was quickly taken care of. The seats are super uncomfortable but it was ok. 

The food is very good though more than I feel like Indian should be. I was also shocked the korma didn't come with rice? For $17 I feel like it should have. Mixed reviews on the services but overall very good.
author: Leslie H.

description: Very elegant place. Low food quality, at least vegetarian dishes. If you are alone they push you to bar where you are alone turkey!!
author: Ajay G.

description:
Exceptional food for an Indian lunch buffet (this is coming from an Indian person)

Food was fresh and refilled often

Biggest selling point for us was the included sparkling wine (NOT CHAMPAGNE because not from France) with the buffet
author: Vishal B.

description: Definitely a five star restaurant, all dishes are excellent, service top notch and the prices match, oh well.  We keep this place for special occasions.  We had sea bass curry, lamb curry and saag paneer all well worth it, very yummy.  Best north Indian you can find.
author: Kent P.

description: Great food. Really good ambience. Nice service. Lot of variety for buffet. Plenty of choices for veggies. Perfect for office team lunches. Something for everyone. Reasonably priced at $20.
author: Ninad N.

description:
Amber India's decor is modern yet colorful - in synch with the vibrant cuisine. The bar is backlit and above the shelves of alcohol, ornate patterns in various hues are projected. It's also a primo spot for people watching as the floor to ceiling windows face one of the busiest stretches of Market street.

 I have never eaten in the main dining room, but have enjoyed drinks and appetizers in the bar on several occasions. 
The happy hour cocktail list is fairly limited, but the appetizers are innovative and delicious. The last time I sidled up to the glowing bar was during the world series, the place was so empty I thought I spotted a tumbleweed rolling through the vestibule. My two happy hour buddies and I had the whole place to ourselves. 

We turned the flat screen to the Giants game and ordered a few snacks. The bartender recommended the Bhel Puri - a mixture of papadis, puffed rice, sev, onions, potatoes, raw mango and chutneys swirled into a round cake-like shape resembling uncooked top ramen. It was crunchy, sweet and savory, and got mixed reviews from the three of us. I liked it but probably wouldn't order it every time. Next, we tried the Chicken wings - also sweet and savory, but the glaze had a bit of spicy kick. The Indian "pizza" was a bit tricky to share, but worth the mess.

By the time we finished up, the game was over, and people were trickling into the dining room.

All in all, a very good happy hour deal in a beautiful setting.
author: Carole B.

description: This place is always busy and for good reason. Everything is amazing. The murg kalimirch is one of my favorite dishes, the spice is perfect and it is just so flavorful. The korma is also fantastic and the gravy is insanely good. They will tell you the butter chicken is the signature dish and it is very good, but they do everything just as good!
author: Jacob K.

description: I have only one word for the experience that word is exquisite. The flavors were delicate and the presentation beautiful.  This was hands down the best Indian food I have had. The flavors, textures, and presentation were spot on. I always like a definitive review in a new place that tells me what to order. So here you go. Order the butter chicken, saffron rice, and garlic naan. You will be glad you did.
author: Shawn H.

description:
I was here last night, and the food was great, but the service really stood out!  Our server Joe made great recommendations.  We were looking at other customers' food, trying to figure out what they ordered, and a second server could see we were perplexed and came over and explained the dish to us.  Finally, one of the busboys spilled some water near me.  It barely grazed me, no big deal, but the manager rushed over to make sure everything was ok and offered me a premium drink on the house.

Thanks for the great service, and I'll be back!
author: Warren S.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS FOCUSED ON THE LUNCH BUFFET AND NOT THE ALA CARTE MENU.

The lunch buffet is one of the most disorganized events you'll see. The food is placed around a pillar at one side of the restaurant which is very congested to begin with. Add to that mix the folks trying to enter the buffet line from both ends without any sense of organization.

Food quality - average. The food was quite oily and unhealthy. The naan (India bread) was put on our table even before we got up to get the food to our table and was never once replenished throughout our meal. The bread was cold and hard by the time we started eating.

Service - Service was good in that our water was filled often, server stopped by a few times to check in on us etc.

We went with a group of four including three kids (Two two year old and a six month old). The kids only ate fruit and OJ from their parents but the restaurant decided to sneak in a "kids lunch buffet" charge of $14.95 per child on our bill. They took it off politely when we inquired but not without further ruining the experience.

In summary, an overpriced lunch buffet by any standards and miles away from "authentic". I will not be returning for sure but might come back to try the ala carte menu to see if I get "more of the same".
author: Kabir S.

description:
Ethnic cuisine is all about creativity and art. And I got pretty creative with Amber India DAT experience.

In a stroke of genius, I took a healthy serving of rice and mixed it into my bowl of delicious Butter Curry Chicken. The rice was kinda like cereal and the curry was kinda like milk. I was kinda like eating cereal.

Nan (Indian Waffle)
Lentil (Indian Chili)
  
Part of this complete breakfast.

$35 (DAT price) is a fair price to pay for discovering a breakthrough in Indian Breakfast. The meal also includes an appetizer (Duck Kebobs or Spinach Chips or Calamari), Nan (Pesto or Garlic or Chili), and a dessert (Mango Creme Brulee or this one other delicious thing) of your choice. The service was also stellar. I like this place : )
author: Ringo M.

description: Horrible service at the lounge. Second time here at the lounge. The girl who took the order never checked back. I ordered a drink and some starters. The starter arrived but the drink never showed up. I tried to catch her attention but she was busy talking with someone at the bar. Halfway through my dish.. her service ended and I saw her leave .. no passing on to another server. Great. I caught attention of another guy twice who pointed me to someone else and said he will get to the order. I guess he did not take orders. But never got any attention.. and it wasnt even that crowded for a monday evening. The second star is for the restaurant which has better service than the lounge. The guy who looked like manager came in and apologised for the error after pointing out that idont want to be charged for it but that was about it. I am done with the lounge for now.
author: Shital R.

description:
We have been a regular at Amber india, since we live in the city, and enjoy Indian food. Just had a baby, and have been ordering in from Amber as well. This review is for our visit today to the restaurant, off course with our baby. Made our reservation for 1:45pm. The manager or reception desk man was outright rude, our baby had fallen asleep in the stroller, so we requested for a table with little space to park it, just so we don't have to wake up our baby. He suggested he following options : 1) pull her out of the stroller and you can keep the baby with you?! We said we do not want to wake her up. 2) he repeats the first option and says I can give you a booth... Still doesn't solve it for us! 

He was outright rude and unrealistic, there were a couple of tables empty near the entrance, but he stated the policy of the restaurant as 'no strollers are acceptable in the restaurant'. In a city like San Francisco a restaurant with ample space needs to be more accommodative to a sleeping baby(and yes she wasn't a crying loud screaming baby, which I can understand would disturb your guests). Having worked in hospitality for 10 years, this was a completely unacceptably restaurant rule.
We didn't want to waste time arguing and graciously bowed out of the situation. Beware, staff is rude, and Babies are not welcomed in this place...wonder how they accommodate accessible guests with wheelchairs which is a mandate by law?!
author: Anisha Y.

description: Loooooooved the weekend lunch buffet! Food quality was nothing close to buffet style but way better! Restaurant is very neat and classy located in a perfect spot for your weekend city walking! Crew were professional and polite, they allowed my friend to bring in his bike also offered to watch it for him.
author: Rana K.

description:
This place is delicious! There butter chicken with garlic naan is absolutely incredible. You can ask them to make it spicy if you are looking for some extra flavor. They shred the chicken and it literally melts in your mouth. 

We also tried the Palak chaat. They lightly fry some baby spinach and put some yogurt and chutney on top. It was one of the best appetizers I have ever had! Highly recommended!
author: Mickey S.

description: This restaurant is fantastic.  The room is gorgeous and every single person on the staff is friendly and wonderful.  Lots and lots of wonderfully tasty vegetarian options.  We started with the Crispy Potato Turnovers (Savory Potato Parcels, Garbanzo Stew, Trio of Sauces), and they were off-the-charts delicious.  For my entree, I had Kumbh, Hara Pyaz Kofta (Golden Chanterelle, Shitake, Cremini & Spring Onion Dumplings, Onion, Tomato, Fenugreek Sauce).  I asked for it to be spicy and IT SURE WAS SPICY -- in a wonderful, fantastic, mind-blowing way.  Our server was caring and attentive.  I can't wait to go back.  A+++++++++
author: Thomas M.

description: Possibly the best Indian restaurant in San Francisco. Everything I've had is delicious, and they have a cool bar with top drinks and service. I don't go as often as I'd like due to price. There's plenty of great Indian restaurants around, but when I want to splurge, this is the spot. 4 stars due to price. 5 stars for everything else.
author: Keagan G.

description:
I'd heard a fair amount about this place and it was pretty mixed, so I was delighted to find how much I liked it. The food was a bit unusual (to me at least) for an Indian buffet but I thought the quality was excellent, the dishes interesting, and the food very tasty. There were a good number of vegetarian options and everything seemed to be refilled pretty frequently. The fried okra was one of my favorite dishes.

It was really easy for our group to go with a reservation and be seated. I didn't pay so I can't comment on the cost, but I would go back.
author: Lisa K.

description: I had dinner at Amber with two friends and we all agree the food was wonderful. The Tandorii sampler, a seafood curry and a lamb curry were all richly flavorful and well prepared.  The service was a bit slow to start but finished very well.  There is a very reasonable wine list.
author: George W.

description:
I have taken multiple teams here for lunch and we always had a great experience. The buffet has a decent variety although I have seen more items at other places but the quality of food is definitely great.

The staff is attentive and the interiors is pleasant.
author: Moses P.

description:
DO NOT GO! The vegan and Vegetarian food sucks. Felt like check forcefully made food. It was tasteless and moreover the quality of food was very low.  Also the service was okay. Specially the manager is very rude to talk too. 

I would strongly recommend don't waste your money on trying this place. Looks fancy but there is nothing fancy about it.
author: Pruthvi Z.

description:
Once you get seated the lunch buffet is actually amazing. One of the best i've had. However getting seated is no small feat. Seating order seems based on who can annoy the hostess the most. 

Our group goes in, "25 minute wait" we go stand outside to wait since the front area isn't very big. 

Groups come in, some walk back out, others i never see again. 25 minutes pass. then 30. My friend goes and stands next to the hostess stand... we're "next" for about 10 more minutes.

We finally get seated, and eat our fill. 

I'll have to remember to come early or late for lunch if this is the destination.
author: john W.

description: Good Indian food friendly waiters but the portion is small. Dessert might be a true blast. Definitely worth a try
author: Nancy W.

description:
As an Indian woman, I beseech you, fellow Indian restaurant visitors: please stop staying the words "TIKI masala"... There's no such thing as "tiki masala". Stop making shit up. Just because you order the same dish ("chicken tiki masala 4ever y'all!") every single time you enter an Indian restaurant, doesn't give you the creative license to change its name. As if it isn't bad enough that "the most popular Indian dish" at restaurants is nothing but a British invention created for non-Indians. We already have to deal with bullshit from colonialism where dishes like "mizhagu thanni" were changed to "mulihagatahawany" because forked tongues couldn't wrap around Indian languages and then decided to rewrite our own history for us. 

The food is good here if you like that Indian McDonalds kinda fare... which lets face it, everyone gets that craving once in a while for that creamy diarrhea inducing Indian junk food :)
author: Bhavi A.

description:
As an Indian-American, growing up, "eating out" consisted of going to Indian restaurants, so I've mostly avoided eating at them. In addition, Indian restaurants usually make their food too greasy, causing you to fall into a deep food coma right after. 

Amber was a pleasant surprise and stark contrast to this. The food didn't have the typical "same" curry base which the Indian entrepreneur makes his/her profit off of. I ordered the Butter Chicken, while my friends ordered lamb, potatoes and peas, and Kofta. We placed two orders of rice and two orders of naan (one plain, one pesto). Each curry had a distinctive base, which meant this food was not cheaply made and definitely worth the price tag. The palate was full of flavor and was definitely less fattening (more healthy) than other Indian restaurants (that I know of, in the South Bay).

I appreciate that they offered a brown rice option (only ~$0.50 more than the white rice). While the price tag was hefty, the food was definitely worth it. 

The atmosphere is definitely a bit classy. I wouldn't feel comfortable coming here in jeans. It's definitely a date/girls' night out spot!
author: Deepti N.

description:
The food is pretty good. They have a lot of different varieties on the menu, from seafood to vegetarian dishes. However, place is pretty pricy. The meal always ends up costing ~$100 for two people (after tip). 

Pros: 
I really like their tandoori salmon, the fish are tender and flavorful. 
Bf loves their butter chicken curry
Impressive selection of wine/cocktail menu. They even have mocktails. 

Cons: 
The calamari appetizer was underwhelming. This dish was more like a soup with few pieces of boiled calamari. Not a fan.

They also have a bar/lounge area that serves cocktails and select appetizers for a quick bite with friends.
author: Nancy Z.

description: I liked the buffet the first time I went there but with time I can see their quality is being downgraded. My last two visits to this place were not very good. Very less options in buffet and al a carte dishes are not good at all. Overall I realized you're just paying for a good ambience here not the good food which is not acceptable to me. So probably I won't visit this place again.
author: Shabnam G.

description:
Sensual and sumptuous. Soft, creamy, flavor-filled, bright, and filling dishes.  

 **I first came here about 12 years ago (either Palo Alto or Mountain View) and I've been talking about it ever sense, this is my first time back and it still holds true! 

We started with the Palak Chat: Flash Fried Bloomsdale Baby Spinach, Yogurt, Tamarind Relish, Cranberry - This was like eating a perfectly made savory dessert. Crunchy spinach, a bit like kale chips, covered in a mouth watering and satisfying yogurt-tamarind relish. 

Next we had the the Mustard Cauliflower + broccoli: Broccoli, Cauliflower Florets, Grain Mustard, Turmeric Yogurt. Again, it was perfect. A great change from the first dish, this is more like a healthy tangy bbq. 

We finished with the Veggie Korma: Broccoli, Carrot, Zucchini & Peas cooked in a Cashew Nut Cream Sauce. The cashew cream sauce is to die for! Absolutely delicious, silky smooth. The Chianti paired really well with the dish, it helped the food shine while maintaining the flavors of the wine, no washing out or increasing the heat of the food. 

Don't forget the basmati rice + mint raita
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
The foodie in my wants to say "This is not how Indian food should be" but my taste buds say "Screw what you think this is good food" It's funny because if the restaurant was simply called Amber my mind wouldn't be having this discussion. In the end I love enjoy a good meal at Amber India from time to time. 

I've been here many times because a close friend is head over heals over the place. As a regular the service is always excellent for us. Prices are a bit on the high end as far as Indian food goes but you're partly paying for location and a nice looking dining room. 

The naan here is one of my favorite things. I could probably sit around and eat their pesto naan till my head fell off. But I always have to leave room for their Frontier Lamb ribs, one of my favorite lamb dishes around. Though I do recall getting a couple more ribs than I did on my last trip. (I wish I had been keeping track) Though the dishes are meant to share they are small enough to devour on your own. I'm also a fan of the sea bass, tikka masala, and the butter chicken. Desserts here are hit or miss for me but that is probably more of a palette thing more than anything. A little to sweet in many cases for me. I'd rather finish with a nice cup of tea or another glass of wine from their decent selection. 

If you're on the more traditional side of Indian food dining then you'd best steer clear but if you're just looking for a great meal or a place to introduce someone to the world of Indian cuisine, Amber is a great way to break them in.
author: Joco F.

description: Fine indian dining at its best...overall experience was probably the best I have had at an Indian restaurant in US. Flavors are delicate and presentation is great. We went for dinner so we paid big bucks:):). Lentil dish, paneer skewers and mixed meat platter were amazing. Folks looking for heavy spices and oil might find some dishes bland...my son did not like the Saag Paneer for this reason.
author: Foodie K.

description: Pathetic and Rude service. When we call to reserve the table we had been told that we must leave by certain time. We were ok with it, but it took over 40 min to get the food and we had beeen asked to vacate the table at least 3 times.
author: Redmon I.

description: Really nice food. Little expensive but better than many other places in South Bay. A lot of vegetarian options. Had live counter for Besan Crepes.
author: Kinchit R.

description: I love amber.. have been here so many times.. but the bartender today was mean beyond words.. really.. unbelievable!! She was a blonde with short hair... she is so mad at something and showing it plain at us.. wow!!! We r regulars here and this is not usual..
author: Deebs M.

description:
Me and my Huby came here to eat before , this will now be our second visit to Amber India.It's conveniently located right between Mission and Market St in the Yerba Buena area. WE LOVE IT HERE! Staff is incredibly attentive and the environment is very clean with the five star look. We went on the weekend to get the Brunch Buffet. It's all you can eat Fine Indian Cuisine the foods quality is amazing!! Especially the fish!!! LOVE LOVE LOVE ALL THE SPICES IN THE CURRIES 

Also included:

UNLIMITED FRESH BAKED NANN 
BOTTOMLESS MIMOSAS or Sparking White Wine     

THE BEST PART IS OUR BILL WAS ONLY $62 with the 15% tip 


DEFINITELY A MUST FOR INDIAN FOOD LOVERS
author: China D.

description:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 3.5/5.0
Value: 3.0/5.0
Decor: 4.0/5.0
Overall: 4.0/5.0 

I'm biased towards hole-in-the-walls for desi food, but I'm happy to make an exception here.  The a la carte dinner menu is very very good albeit a bit pricy, but the real value is the [almost as] high quality weekday lunch / weekend brunch buffet spread.  Good for both herbivores and those more on the carnivorous side of society.  The spot can get quite crowded on weekdays and the buffet line is long-ish from noon till 1pm especially when there's a convention, so usually a good idea to make a reservation and show up earlier.
author: Damian W.

description:
Great food! Honestly every dish I got was so tasty. I would highly recommend going for the lunch buffet but go early so you don't have to wait in line.

For dinner I would recommend the cauliflower, the butter chicken with garlic naan. I honestly thought the SF location had much better food than the Santana Row location.

Supposedly it is organic too so its perfect and decently healthy. Very nice decor and moderate/good service.
author: Kunal T.

description: Went here for dinner while in town with ACS.  Service was good, prompt, and polite.  The flavors of the food were decent, however, I found it a little overpriced, entrees are in the $20+ range, and while that may be typical prices for SF, I am sure we could have gotten a better deal elsewhere.
author: Romulo R.

description:
You must get here early , else the wait can be long. The place had a very nice decor and pretty spacious. Glancing at the buffet menu, it was pretty limited in food choices compared to many I've been too. 

I have my go to dishes which were the butter chicken, goat meat , and fish. Everything else was just okay for me. They ran out of certain items and didn't refill it for a while . For about $20, tad bit pricey . However, you're in the city!!
author: Nhung T.

description:
We made a reservation for team lunch( buffet) the day after memorial day and it was a disaster.
I have come here before for weekend lunch and i liked it then. this was the first time we went to an indian restaurant as a team and was hoping food would be good but we were very much disappointed.
for over 23$ per person, they served below average food with no taste and not a good spread.
They just had one non-veg  appetizer(which was very cold and  had rubber like texture btw) and 2 non-veg curries. Chicken biryani was very bad as well. very few vegetarian options.
overall we are very disappointed and would not recommend to anybody.
you can easily skip lunch buffets.

service was great though.
author: Sri S.

description: Wow. First time I have ever left an Indian restaurant still hungry. And our bill for three people was $100 without any alcohol or other beverages. We were three adults and ordered three main courses - tandoori chicken, a lamb curry and a bindi vegetarian main course. Plus an order of nan bread and a side order of raita, the yogurt sauce. All main course portions were amazingly small. We are all lean health-conscious people who do not overeat so we are not gluttons. It was embarrassing because one of our party was a cousin visiting SF for a few hours on a flight layover and we wanted to give him a nice dinner. The decor was lovely and the staff was polite but Amber India is pricier than most Indian restaurants and we expected portion sizes comparable to more modestly priced Indian fare.
author: Deborah B.

description:
We went for lunch buffet and it was a horrible experience, food was just about ok and we also ordered wine, and that was terrible.
It turned out these guys have no knowledge of it, priced high with absolute poor quality, see attached pic.
When we raised this poor quality concern, we were told they have many years of serving experience and we should not expect anything better, really!! Even the restaurant manager was rude and acting as if he was serving free and didn't care at all.

If possible avoid this place, very disappointed, will find much better food and service on street side food. I will be reporting this place to food quality department for sure..they might actually make people sick with their food and wine.
author: Viny A.

description: Overpriced and tasteless. Should realize if you are going to charge a premium the food has to taste accordingly, not be tasteless. I pay $30 for 4 small blobs of badly seasons and unbeatable fish bass kebabs. And the waiter was stingy to give me rice instead of salad.
author: Hisham M.

description:
My uncle and I went on a weekday - Onolicious ...good grindZ. Fresh vegetables and place was 'poppin.' Recommended for family or dinner dates.

I do not know about weekends... service and food may possibly be different as there is a larger crowd waiting for a tables. My uncle and I had a blast on a Thursday. I would come back to see how the consistent food ans service is on a  weekend.

I  recommend to reserve a table before coming into that restaurant.
author: Romit P.

description:
Wow! This is my favorite place in San Francisco so far. The buffet at lunch is amazing and such a good deal! 
We paid 51$ for two people, for HIGH-QUALITY food and unlimited mimosas (mango or orange) - included in the price. 

Lots of staff was around checking to see everything was ok for us.
The style of restaurant is classy and pleasant. The buffet is not huge but a good size - big enough to try many different flavors!

For proteins, it has 3+ different kinds of chicken (grilled, green kebab and butter chicken - my fave, reminded me of Chicken Tikka Masala in Europe), one type of fish (moist) and goat.

Also, there are many types of vegetarian dishes to choose from including saag aloo, chana masala, lentils, lotus and snow peas, mushrooms, cottage cheese beans and of course rice (it wasn't dry at all like it can easily be)... I tried little portions of everything, it was too tempting! There were different/distinct spices and sauces for every dish, which was great!

In the starter sections, you can find little hot buns to fill in with chopped veggies (Indian street food they said!), salads and chickpea square cakes, those were so yummy!
We had butter naan and whole wheat naan: thin, served hot. They were both good.

We were sooo full by the time we got to dessert but we had to try the carrot pudding. It had nuts and raisins and lots of spices. We loved it and would have eaten more if our stomach would have allowed us to! :-D

We also had vermicelli kheer, pretty good, but not as great as the pudding. 
Fresh fruits are also available as well as fruit custards, but we didn't try those.

We went back last night for dinner and it was as AMAZING. Such a classy restaurant. It's not buffet at night FYI. I had the Ferry Market Vegetable Korma with cashew cream. The portion had lots of different fresh crunchy veggies (peas, asparagus, zucchini), it was too good!

We've had Indian food in Spain, the UK, France, the Netherlands, Middle East and different states of the U.S... 

Amber India is definitely one of the BEST Indian restaurants we've ever been to!
author: Leslie S.

description:
Located near Yerba Buena Gardens, this is the perfect place for a date night or outing with a group of people. My husband and I made reservations (Open Table) in June for dinner on 8/5/16 (Friday). Our reservations were for 8 pm and we arrived 30 minutes early. On a weekend night, don't expect to be seated before your reservation time. We were told to wait at the bar until 8PM. You can take the chance and walk in w/o a reservation and sit in the bar area and order food. However, with the appetizers, bread, soup, and entrees, there would not be enough room at the mini tables. 

My husband and I were taken to a corner booth which was perfect, best seat in the restaurant for two. We were given an expansive wine menu to look at on the IPad. Since I was driving, I opted out but my husband ordered the Liberty Ale (on tap). We ordered the bread basket for starters which comes with three types of bread: Spinach Roti, Laccha Paratha, and Naan. This is more of an appetizer for 3-4 people, so we had to take some to go. The Laccha Paratha was my favorite because it had some jerk spice that made it flavorful. We tried the crispy potato turnovers because they were new to the menu and this dish was amazing. The garbanzo stew made this dish. The turnovers for this appetizer are tiny, but the dish is worth trying. My husband and I also split the tomato soup. It was delicious and my husband said it was easily in the top 5 best tomato soups he has ever had. The tandoori flavor really shined through in the soup and was unlike any tomato soup I have tasted. 

For the main course I had the Lobster Cream Coconut curry and it came with an empty lobster shell on top for presentation. It was delicious and tasted similar to a vegetarian Korma but still different. It was nice to see fresh chunks of lobster tail in my dish. My husband ordered the Lamb Korma and he said his was very good, but my dish reigned supreme. We ordered the saffron rice to go with the curries because it is not included like it is in some Indian restaurants. 
This restaurant has good size portions. Keep that in mind when ordering. My husband and I run everyday and we had a huge appetite during dinner which is why we decided to order dessert. We split the mango crème brulee and it was divine; the perfect ending to a wonderful date.

Also, for the reviews that mentioned noise: Yes, it is noisy in the restaurant and tables are close together. However, all the ethnic restaurants that I have been to in SF have close proximity seating (Mamacita, Ler Ros, Sheba, Foreign Cinema, Slanted Door, etc).

Atmosphere 5*
Price 5*
Location 5*
Food/Taste 5*
Service 5*
author: Kristina Nichole D.

description: Great location as it is close to BART. I love the modern decor and the multi-level floors. I have always received attentive and helpful service.  Their seasonal mocktails are flavorful and they have full bar.  Order the basket for the bread as they include a sample of various Indian breads, which are delivered warm to the table. We ordered family style to share and everything was delicious: samosa, cauliflower, lamb, and kebab sampler. Even the white rice was flavorful. The price is very reasonable too.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Hands down the best Indian restaurant in the bay area. 
Garlic naan - A+
Sautéed Okra - A+
Spicy potato turnover - A
Palak Chaat - B
Golden Chanterelle, Morel & Spring Onion Dumplings - A+
author: Nate A.

description: I would give zero stars but I can't. Absolute waste on your money. Horrible service and they can't get any order correctly. My entrees came out before my apps. I decided to give it a try and the food was really bland and they didn't even bring all of the sides for an entree. They kept telling us they were sorry for the backup and then kept messing up. Seemed to be extremely understaffed and could not keep up with demand. Don't even get me started on the pricing. It was $30 for 4 pieces of bland chicken. Charged 15% gratuity for the worst service I have ever had. Try other Indian restaurants nearby and don't waste your time waiting on your food for an hour and a half for it to be completely wrong.
author: Ash G.

description: My fiancée and I ended up getting dinner here because we didn't want to wait forever to get a table at tropisueno next door. I wasn't expecting Amber to be that good but it was waayyyy better than I was expecting, I enjoyed everything we ordered. We got the cauliflower bezule, samosa, butter chicken and garlic naan. The butter chicken was flavorful and a pretty large amount of food, two is just barely finished it. Prices are a bit steep but that's not surprising considering the location in SF. The restaurant itself is fancy and has a nice ambiance. I would probably come back here again or try out their San Jose location
author: Teju S.

description: Mouth-watering menu that combines traditional Indian dishes with new combinations and ingredients.  The four-spice sea bass was out of this world. I liked the kick to the spicy naan. The samosas were good, but didn't taste substantially different from samosas I have tried elsewhere. I'd come back for the sea bass, and to try some more items from their menu. The restaurant is a bit pricey, but the food is very good.
author: j j.

description: Wow, best Indian I have had outside of Seattle to date.  In a word, elegant... I love the variety of the dishes, so fresh and every bite fighting for my taste buds like a group of pigeons over a slice of bread.  The ambiance is that of a five star restaurant, likely the prices to be inflated, but justified.  Best mint chutney I have ever had.  I enjoyed the veggie pakora and saffron rice.  The little potato cakes were great too (not sure what they were called because the buffet lacked name cards).  I think the only reason why they couldn't get 5+ stars is the slow naan service.  Would go back again!
author: Ben F.

description:
Crazy travel schedules and random layovers chanced me upon Amber India one random weekend.  Ravenous, delirious, and jetlagged, we wandered in.  I'm not really sure what the vibe was.  Light and airy, modern Indian.  Layered wall fixtures, accent colors, and different.  Maybe I've been away from Nor cal for way too long.

Anyway, on to the food.  Most of the items we had were pretty good.  The duck kabob appetizer is a definite must to start the meal off.  Great flavor, deliciously tender.  The scallop entree was fresh and well balanced with flavor.  The palak paneer, one of my usual favorites to order at Indian restaurants, fell a little short in flavor.   All in all the curry and meats were great.
author: Pauline M.

description:
Still dashing good food. I have been going there since 1998. They are still doing great job. 
Manjeet Does a great Job. Baljeet was our Server and he did a great job.
author: Dylan R.

description:
Amber is the one best restaurant in San Francisco where I can proudly take any of my friends and they will get a real touch of nice North Indian type food.
You cannot even complain of ambiance here. The setup is very classy and the bar area is huge so it's easy to get seats there on weekends when you don't have a reservation.
It's always crowded.
Coming to food, everything in the menu has a very classy description and they even give the information from where they are sourcing there food like chicken from Marie's ranch I guess.
Now the taste of the dishes are divine. I have tried almost everything in the menu and nothing has disappointed me ever. Special call out to some of the dishes like their samosa, tandoori chicken, butter chicken, Kumbh hara pyaz kofta(mushroom balls in creamy sauce) are the best ones.
It's totally recommended place to team parties and date nights.
author: Mimansha B.

description:
This was my second time there after a year. We went in for a birthday celebration, an hour before closing. Love the ambiance for this restaurant. The food was good, we tried the palak chaat and aloo tikkis for appetizer. For entrees we had the Baigan badaam which we all loved. 
One thing we did not appreciate was when we asked for another round of naans and we were told the kitchen was closed. But the warm juicy gulaab jamuns made up for that along with the chocolate molten cake. But I will definitely be back again sometime soon.
author: Amandip S.

description: I really like their happy hour and chaat selection in the lounge. I tried their lunch buffet and it was good.
author: Saima P.

description:
I didn't have the great experience as others. For me it's over hyped over prices average tasting restaurant.
I went on a weekend after a friend insisted but to my surprise this place has not much to offer when it comes to buffet. I didn't try all carte but now couldn't dare to try. I have been to many Bay Area Indian restaurants and this place is one of the best.
author: Gaurang D.

description:
Great tasting high quality food with a very upscale ambience.
Stepped into the restaurant when it was about to close even then the people in there served us patiently with uber quality of food and great service. 
Loved the ambience and interior design.
author: Vani J.

description:
very good experience
Food was served hot and at the right times
service was excellent
restaurant is beautiful
Highly recommend
author: Steven M.

description: One of my favorite spots for Indian food now. Indian food at its finest.!!Love the place, great flavors starting from appetizers to main course to dessert.
author: Khushali B.

description:
Really good deal for brunch! We went here on a Sunday around 1pm and the restaurant was busy with customers. Bottomless mimosas and buffet for only $35 per person. I really enjoyed my mango mimosa and all the delicious vegetarian options at the buffet. I got to try many dishes I would not normally order and was so full at the end of our meal that we needed to walk it off before we went into a food coma. 

Great choice for small groups or large groups. We had a group of 8 and felt very accommodated. The service was excellent. I lost track of how many mimosas I had because they kept refilling them before they I was even finished! This is a great option for brunch if you want to get out of your comfort zone and try something interesting and delicious.
author: Taryn S.

description: I'm giving this place 4 stars because the service was fine, the place had nice decor, but the food was way too spicy and there were small portions. The only thing I really liked was the butter chicken.
author: Isabelle W.

description: Overall, we enjoyed the restaurant.  The food was better than our other frequented restaurant in Hayward, My Favorite Indian.  The quality of the food at the buffet was good, and we especially liked the "popcorn rice" that was at the beginning of the line.  Our only complaint was that the price was pretty hefty for what we got (pretty limited number of options).
author: Jerry H.

description: The space off Market is beautifully designed, but more importantly, its layout is conducive to dinner conversation and is supremely comfortable (remember chairs and banquettes with cushions? They're here!). Crispy, perfectly spiced samosas with two dipping sauces, butter chicken to rival any other (who needs chicken tikka masala?), Rogan Josh with a reduced, deeply flavored sauce and tender, high-quality lamb (what a nice change!), beautifully made naan, paratha, and roti (all served in a made to order bread basket), and great beverage choices. All dishes served to exactly the heat level requested and all sauces as described on the menu, rather than a host of nearly identical sauces served in many other Indian restaurants. Yeah, 5 stars without reservation (but do make a reservation, as this gem is very popular).
author: Sharon P.

description:
Delicious? Yes. Good value? No. I walk past Amber all the time. The decor and setting are chic, and it is by far the fanciest Indian restaurant I've ever been to. I came here for dinner and the place was packed, I would highly recommend making reservations ahead of time if you want a spot. 

As far as the food goes, the food is really good; it's the price that kills me. The naan and butter chicken were some of my favorites, but expect to pay double what you would normally pay at a good Indian restaurant. Entrees are around $20-30 and do not come with rice or naan, all of those are sold separately. 

Honestly, I have to take some of the blame for this bad review. It appears, I should have gone for lunch not dinner. The buffet sounds amazing, and @$20 a person, it is significantly cheaper than the $100 tab I ran up during my dining experience. Well, lesson learned, and I will definitely be back to try out this legendary buffet.
author: Alex L.

description: I really wanted to like this place. Service was excellent but the attention to detail on the food was a little hairy.
author: Edward T.

description:
My mom and I came here last week and had a lovely experience. I made reservations with opentable and the host seated us on time. The restaurant was not packed at 6:30 but the place filled up by the time we walked out. Amber India has a very inviting feel. Its warm rich colors and cozy booths make me want to come back for a date night. The menu is extensive. Great options for the drinkers at the table and 5-6 pages of food.  

We started with the lamb chops (4) and samosas (4). The lamb melted in your mouth and the samosa were crispy and had the perfect balance of spice. Then we split butter chicken,  saag paneer, murgh kaalimirch, and of course orders of garlic naan and basmati rice. If we had any idea how generous their portion sizes were we probably would have ordered 1/2 the amount. 

It's a 10 min walk from my home and I can easily see myself dining here on a monthly basis. There aren't too many Indian restaurants in the city that are mindful about their ingredients and Amber India is on point. 

I have already raved to my coworkers and we are now planning a department lunch. Really looking forward to coming back and trying even more dishes from their fantastic menu
author: Denniz S.

description: I've held off writing a review of Amber India because it used to be a favorite, and the delivery food we've received has been somewhat inconsistent. Sometimes it's great, sometimes it's pretty bad. We've been willing to pay a ridiculous amount (compared to other good Indian restaurants) for their butter chicken, because in the past it's been white meat and very tender...despite the bones and gristle we find most of the time. Tonight, however, it was ALL dark meat, and horribly fatty. Plus we found another LARGE bone while eating, which is a big turnoff. Will be finding another restaurant to order Indian food from going forward. This is too expensive and too inconsistent.
author: Nora L.

description: Super awesome and authentic Indian food. The nans they serve here are best in the world. Bit expensive but worth the price.
author: Ankit P.

description: A very busy joint and crowd control at the buffet lines could be better. Food tasted fresh and good. The seating in the bar area leaves a lot to be desired for. Seems a bit understaffed
author: Satish C.

description:
Holy deliciousness! Their Happy hour goes til 6:30pm I think and is sooooooooo good! Their drinks are really amazing. My fella had a Manhattan last night and he said it was the best one he has ever had. I am not a whisky person but it was really aromatic and though I couldn't drink the whole thing, I took several sips because it smelled so good. I got the Elderberry Mimosa- super tasty and the last time I was there I got the chicken with goat cheese and some yummy chutneys. It was on happy hour for next to nothing but it filled me up as it is a generous portion. It is right down the way from my fellas work so I have a feeling they will see a lot more of us. 

Aside from the food and drinks the space is gorgeous. I think we have avoided it before because it look really expensive but is actually one of the most affordable places in the neighborhood. So fancy!
author: Kim A.

description: Wayyyyy overpriced Indian food!  Not that good either. Entrees came in little bowls instead of plates. Too spicy,small portions, not a lot of meat. Bill for my wife and I was $100 for very little food. And it gave her diareah. She called it $100 diareah.  Atmosphere in main room is nice, we were in the back room, not quite as good.
author: tom d.

description:
We went for the lunch buffet which we enjoyed very much. There are a lot of choices and everything we tried was very good. It was fairly  busy at lunchtime with the hostess asking us if we made reservations. Reservation for lunch??
I can certainly see why a reservation for lunch would be necessary.
Overall, a good spot to stuff yourself on Indian food.
author: Michael L.

description:
Tried buffet once. It was not a good experience. First of all we went there at around 20 mins before they close the lunch buffet, but receptionist did not tell us about it. Later when we sat at the table, server mentioned that pick-up whatever food you want from buffet as we will be closing in 20 mins. Reluctantly we had to grab more food than required and eventually we had to waste some of the food. I think server/receptionist should have told us about closing time so that was could have visited another restaurant.

Secondly food quality was not that good. Also I found its every expensive.
author: Momu G.

description:
I visit this place every once in a while, and have also tried a la carte a few times. Overall, it's extremely high quality and good in terms of hygiene and presentation.

People who haven't tried Indian food maybe due to the smell or presentation that you may have come across, I'd recommend starting from here and easing yourself into the cuisine.

Do try their weekend buffet as it always has extra stuff like live counters with pani puri, pav bhaji, besan chilla etc.
author: Nitish S.

description:
I have visited Amber twice or thrice in the past and to be honest it has been one of my favorite Indian joints to head to,whilst in San Francisco.
However,I am thoroughly disappointed with my experience at the restaurant on Sunday. It was my nephew's birthday and since it was mother's day too,the whole family decided on doing brunch/lunch at Amber.This plan was made around a week back and my sister even called and made a reservation with them,with specific requests for a baby chair and a regular table and not the high chair tables cause we had elderly people with us.
However on arrival at the restaurant,we were greeted and guided to a table that was a high chair table,the exact opposite of what we had requested for. When we asked one of the persons at the counter for assistance to switch to a regular table,he was awfully rude and simply told us that everyone else had requested for the same and in simple words,we basically had to make do. We managed to speak to one of the in-house managers who promised to get us a change of table within a few minutes.But when nothing happened for 10 minutes,we carried on with getting our food.Since it was mother's day we had no option but to eat there,as we wouldn't be able to get a reservation anywhere else at the last minute.
Just for future reference,if one is in the hospitality department,it is sort of a part of your job duty to be kind and pleasant with the customer.Secondly,if everyone else had made a request for the same and you couldn't fulfill our request,then we should have been informed in the first place,so we could have arranged for an alternative.I haven't experience such terrible customer service,in a while,and I am really shocked at the way we were made to feel.
The food was fabulous, as always.However,I know as a matter of fact,that I'm never going to visit the place again.As a customer,I would rather make my peace with average food than terrible service,and I really want to thank Amber specifically for ruining my mother's day experience!
author: Shraddha N.

description:
Being a "Desi" I believe I have a credible right and the backing of my taste buds that have grown up eating such food to give everyone an honest review of my dinner experience. 

The ambiance --- awesome 
The staff --- awesome 

The food --- DISASTER And honestly SHAMEFUL
If my dad was with me, he would have the food sent back. My mom in her compassionate way would talk to the chef and tell him "son (or daughter), the food you cook represents and speaks about our country and culture. It speaks to the many hours we labor in the kitchen to make food. And you are telling a bad story". 

Desi dinner I always served hot! Not cold as if it was sitting their for 20 mins. The chicken tikka, the lamb kebab and prawns --- cold cold (ok room temperature, but seriously)

Deception 1-- menu ---- don't write on the menu "Cajun chicken", making it out to be some exotic southern fusion recipie and get me all excited; only to serve me a chicken tikka masala. Call it what it is. Don't put lipstick on a pig and call it Scarlet Johanson. 

Deception 2---- paratha --- I won't say anything about the paratha as different regions of India and Pakistan have different varieties of paratha. But serving it cold!!! Sad!

And last --- Taking a famous dish- the Lamb Shank, renowned for its taste and effort that goes into it. A proud dish of mothers and one that chefs get bragging rights for. You totally insulted every mother and chef. Am not sure what potions in the back you are working with but Harry Potter most certainly will be interested. 
This could be my fault for ordering and not reading the ingredients but hey, I just went of the experience from 20 yrs of my life eating lamb shanks and other Desi food to compare it to. 

On the bright side ---- they have a very very good Brunch. 

PS--- could have added $5 more to the total spend and went to Kaskade tonight at pier 70! 

PS--- bad food is not an excuse for bad tip. Only bad service is. And the service here was good :)
author: Majid M.

description: My second visit to this restaurant and once again I was extremely impressed. The menu is interesting, varied and very tasty. Plus they will prepare a number of different dishes and breads for you, upon request, which are not on the menu. Our waitress Bri, was superb taking excellent care of us without hassling or hurrying us. The food was wonderful, authentic and tasty. I will definitely be back again.
author: Robyn K.

description:
Food was a-OK. Nothing special. 
Service sucks. Had dinner with a gentleman that represents one of the wealthiest nations in the world. But he and I were dressed rather casually. 

His fish dish was undercooked. The GM:manager/ strutting peacock was so aloof and unapologetic to this Arab guest you might have thought the guest was calling curry
author: Someone H.

description:
Ordered kadhai paneer and a baingan dish 
But he had the same exact curry. 
Told the manager about this and he acted very un courteous 

Will not recommend this place to anyone. 

I have dined at many fine Indian places
author: David N.

description: Best Indian food in the San Francisco!!!!
author: Clifford H.

description: Words cannot describe!!! Lamb Korma is amazing!! Service, atmosphere  are top notch. Will definitely come back!!
author: Julie F.

description: Lovely food . The unique texture of different Indian food is preserved even in Buffett . I had dinner here before and that was simply outstanding .  I can come here to eat any day .
author: Raj S.

description:
Pretty high standard Indian food! Came in during lunch time, and they are doing buffet lunch
Service: 5 stars, dish is taken once I finished, very quick and comfortable service

Environment: 5 stars, high quality seating, clean, neat

Food: 4 stars because I am not very getting used to their deserts. Too sweet and oily! A lot of vege selections, and they taste even better than meat food. I love their mint fish curry, and crispy mushroom! They have salad bar, appetizer bar, and main course bar. Very clear organized.

Overall nice lunch experience there!
author: Nina H.

description: We went for the buffet to Amber India. We tried the shahid paneer, Gobi mutter, saffron rice,garlic daal, dahi,naan bread, chicken biryani and a lot more. The food was good and the service was on spot. It is slightly a little more expensive than your average Indian restuarant. The salted lassi is very thick unlike buttermilk. It's good food but not a place I would have to visit the next time. Since it was a buffet don't have pictures this time :/
author: Nayana R.

description: I've been to amber a few times now.  Quite frankly because it's the only nice Indian restaurant in the city.  By nice, I mean it has a nice interior, a good sit down restaurant.  I've had better tasting Indian food at two other locations, but they are hole in the wall places.  Aside from the nice ambience, the food is pretty tasty, but pretty pricey!  We ordered the crispy potato turnovers and it was off the hook.  It has a nice spicy kick to it.  Followed by bhindi and saag paneer.  It was amazing.  I also enjoy the waiter serving the portions on our plates.  Just two complaints, I wish it wasn't as expensive and I wish the Indian gentleman who is always greeting customers as they enter the restaurant was more polite.
author: Seema S.

description: We need reviews to be in negative as well! The people of this restaurant are so pathetic and cheap and like street assholes! We went there to celebrate my wife's birthday with family with our teenage daughter and people who work at this place , specially men, looking at our daughter like they have never seen a girl before. One of the guy winked at our daughter and she gets so disgusted and terrified. This place needs to be sued for child abuse and harassment. How does the owner keeps such type of fucking assholes to work for them??? Never ever going to this place again!
author: Sharad Y.

description:
The decor is modern and swank, fitting for the ~$20 entrees price range. Definite date night eats but their happy hour specials is where its at.
 
                       ~~~~~ Mon-Fri  4-7pm ~~~~~ 

                                  $6 cocktails
                                    $4 beers
                  and some $5 Indian street food apps. 

* MALABRI SHRIMP - $11 - Order! Tiger prawns stir fried in this spicy cinnamon, black pepper, and star anise mixture. 
*Chicken tikka masala wings $5 - Order! Spicy Indian spin on buffalo wings. 
*Lamb pizza - Skip. lamb chucks on naan. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dC_kA-R2qb-0iEmoI4VKPg?select=U8U7bd_4UNfEn1S1zlzuQw#U8U7bd_4UNfEn1S1zlzuQw)
*Duck tikka kebab - Skip. Couldn't tell it was duck. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dC_kA-R2qb-0iEmoI4VKPg?select=sYf0n5D8OB5xxLnnakoeAw)


* Pimm's Cup- $6 - This one didn't come with fresh fruit and was a little syrupy but still good.
* Amber Rose - $6 - Even though made with gin and juice (raspberries), a pinky (in the air) drink. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dC_kA-R2qb-0iEmoI4VKPg?select=BefwJIwXJ5aYBmc2Xd4biQ#BefwJIwXJ5aYBmc2Xd4biQ)


TIDBITS - 
-Their lounge fits about 20 with the tables near the window being prime real estate for people watching. Got lucky with seating but otherwise, seats get quickly snatched by the SOMA-lians as soon as people get up.

-Located in the alleyway across from Yerba Buena Gardens, up a couple shops from Beard Papa. 


I could see why people give this place 5 stars. Happy hour value. Indian food spruced up enough to take clients. 4.33 stars!
author: Earl G.

description:
If you want authentic Indian food this is the place to go.  Starting off on a Saturday night we were seated promptly and our server was nice and attentive.  The mango lassi is thick and delicious very yogurty, I recommend getting it after the meal instead of devouring it before the food even came like I did.

For entrees, I had the butter chicken and it's flavors were amazing.  Perfect amount of spice to compliment the chicken.  When it came out I thought it was a small portion for $22 but I ended up not being able to finish it I was so full! 

Tip: the entree doesn't come with rice or naan but you have to try the fresh naan!  We ordered 2.
author: Eileen H.

description:
Excellent late dinner while staying at the SF Marriott Marquis.
Four of us visiting from Boston on business, just happened to pass by and go in for dinner.  The restaurant was pretty full but we were sat right away.  Ambience is really night.

We ordered samosas for appetizers, assorted bread basket, Tandoori Chicken, saag paneer, and a rich lamb dish (can't remember the name) with basmati rice - all were excellent and just enough for 4 people.

Strong recommend.
author: Travel Mom C.

description:
Being on the pricier side considering the abundance of Indian food options in the bay area, Amber buffet is perfect for catching up with your girls over brunch. There were choice galore for the vegetarians too. Amber stole our heart right from the divine complimentary mango juice at the start. They had a live chaat counter & we gorged down the lip-smacking Pav bhaji in a jiffy. The curries on the main course were done justice unlike the curries served at other buffet places. We relished most of the desserts except the rice kheer which was nothing out of the ordinary.
Definitely worth a second visit.
author: Nimisha S.

description: I've been coming here for years and it never fails to impress me. This place is pricey. You can expect to pay between 25-40 dollars per person based on how hungry and thirsty you are. Despite being the classiest Indian place I've been to outside of India, the food is authentic and has its own distinct flair added to boast. It's important to note that they frequently change the menu by adding and removing dishes. Currently when I go, I order the Palak Chaat and Samosa as an Appetizer. We also normally order the Bhara Baingan. I usually eat a vegetarian meal, but I do not doubt their prowess in cooking meat. I will continue you to come, always hungry for more.
author: Ravi J.

description:
A bit on the pricey side though it was a great spot for dinner! 

For appetizers, we ordered the vegan samosas and palak chaat = both *very* tasty; the palak chaat was unique when compared to any other chaat items I've had previously. We ordered the vegetarian kofta and saag PANEER entrees with GARLIC chive naan = yum! Btw I'm a huge fan of paneer and garlic ;) And, I'm VERY PICKY when it comes to the LASSI... Though this place's mango lassi was perfecto! The thickness & consistency + taste of the drink were on target. 

We were too full for dessert though they have MANGO BRÛLÉE on their menu! I must return for dessert... 

Wanted to add that I grew up eating Indian food basically every single day during my childhood - hence it will take a lot for me to give a rating of 5 stars to any Indian restaurant... Just saying! Anyhow, satisfactory service & pleasant atmosphere. Did not make a reservation - though this party of 3 was seated with NO wait on a Saturday evening = coolness!
author: Pina U.

description:
I brought my family visiting from Mumbai to Amber. I wanted to have them experience Indian fine dining in SF. However. This was one of the worst customer service experiences I have ever had!!!!!

Pros:
Good food, good ambiance, good location. 

Cons:
1) Terrible customer service!!!! Although the waiter was nice and the helping staff was nice. The hostess was extremely rude over the phone while making a reservation and in person once we arrived. We were sat at an awkward table and requested to be moved to the next table over. The hostess proceeded to tell us that you only have these 2 tables to chose from otherwise you can take your food to go!
What kind of hostess says that? I am a business owner myself and I would never train any of my employees to speak in such a manner. This is fine dining restaurant in a prime location and to be spoken to like that completely ruined our experience. Not to mention the embarrassment I felt in front of my family visiting from mumbai. They were shocked to see such customer service. If the service was such in any restaurant in India, they assured me that that place would NOT survive. 
I cannot stress enough as to how rude the hostess was. she was not welcoming over the phone either. she hung up on me before I could say thank you for my reservation. she did not greet us with a smile. 

The food was good which is the only reason we stayed. I will never be returning to Amber, and I will NEVER recommend this place to anyone.
author: Monica S.

description: Excellent food and great ambience!! We loved the mushroom koftas and the mutter kulcha ! Their Sunday buffets are amazing too!!
author: Sharanya P.

description:
Good food, Nice Ambience.
We were there for our anniversary. Wife had a good time.
Five star for the service.
author: Satish K.

description: While I only had 2 things...OMG it was so freaking good. I don't like a lot of spicey hot foods and this place does it right. I ordered the calamari and when it came, I was like huh? It was more of a soup, my server brought me the naan, and I tore it up.  Gosh I want some now. I had scallops for my main and that was great too...a little hot but with the yogurt, yummy. The service was excellent.
author: L T.

description: Mediocre representation of the rich heritage and vibrant flavours of the Indian cuisine in an equally vibrant city. Lack of creativity, variety and taste on a weekday buffet. There are several restaurants in other parts of the bay area that dish out fabulous flavors and spreads at a much lesser price.
author: Prajakta W.

description:
Good spot!

The food was pretty good - the butter chicken was definitely the best, but it's hard to go wrong with it. The battered cauliflower was also super tasty. 

Service was slightly on the fence, but the atmosphere is nice - kind of cosy and relaxed.  

Would go back for indian in the area for sure.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I lunch at Amber India about once a quarter. 

Here's why:
- I can make a reservation 
- There's a buffet at lunch which means you can get right to the eating and it's suitable for vegetarians and butter chicken lovers alike
- I can get there from my office in about seven minutes
author: Miriam W.

description: Great buffet on weekends, about $35 per person including gratuity. Wide selection of desserts, main course items, veg and non-beg dishes. Ambiance is great.
author: Thulasi N.

description: I had their lunch buffet, which was amazing. The line for the buffet can get insanely long, but moves fairly fast. I took two platefuls of food and finished it all. The food is expensive, but if you can afford it, it's totally worth it.
author: Sai S.

description: We went to Amber for lunch with a couple of co-workers. For a buffet, there were like 10 options and they keep brining you naan. There was a lot of options, but the most surprising one was basa (fish). The desserts were alright (different varieties of rice pudding). I think it has a lot of the traditional food that you see in indian restaurants, but its just at a higher scale. The service was great, my plate was always removed by the time I left to get my next serving. Overall, pretty affordable lunch place if you are looking for indian food.
author: Victor D.

description:
This is the best curry that I have had in America.  Sadly, that is a low bar and so it is still four star.  Still, if you have not had curry in the better places (UK, Durban, India etc), then this place could be a revelation.

The atmosphere is pleasant, the service attentive, the food very good (not as much as the betters ones in the UK or Durban, but up there).  

The food is clearly prepared in advance, which is a good thing.  It means delivery to the table is very fast and the flavors have plenty of time to mingle and mature.  The downside is they will not be adaptable to particular requests.
author: Steven D.

description:
Stopped in here on a busy Saturday night and grabbed a seat at the bar. Even running understaffed, the bar staff was attentive and friendly. 

Food was delicious, definitely top notch flavors. We had the butter chicken (obviously) and a lamb rogan josh. The rice is a little lacking for the price point so order a little extra. 

One thing I'll say needs work is the attention in prep. We found a couple of bones in the chicken, which I would expect not to find at a restaurant charging premium prices. But outside of that this was a very solid meal.
author: Chris B.

description:
This review is specifically for the guy in the front taking reservations.. The Indian grumpy man on a Saturday night who is rude and 'grumpiest Indian Man ever'. Ruining the name for a whole community.. Man you are in hotel management and I think 'communication, customer respect, time management and pressure management.. ' was definitely part of your skills or probably you are the owner who opened this up and forgot about the skills needed to be respectful of customers.

Amber Santana Row is so much better for management and quality of food. 

Seriously people take a break.. You are serving food because we are paying money, you are not honoring our presence by your culinary skills.. Please, Sorry and 'Let me see what we can do' is something you can learn being in America!
author: Pranamee S.

description: Wouldn't know where to start...the location, the ambience, the service, the food, absolutely everything is superb.
author: Ivo K.

description:
First time trying Amber India - did the online ordering and picked them up. 

Food is good, "clean tasting" Indian food - my comparison is based on what I tasted at Dosa SF (given the price of Amber India and Dosa is about $$$). 

I do like the fact that they have more selections than Dosa and they have my favorite Indian food, e.g. awesome butter chicken and saag paneer. 

Will I go back? Yes, it'll be my 2nd back-up place after Dosa.
author: Hendry C.

description: Get here early and beat the lunch crowd. My lunch partner and I rolled in around 11:45 and a few early birds  had ready been seated.  By the time we sat down and placed our drink order, a line was ready beginning to form.  Everything was very tasty, my favorite being the saag paneer and butter chicken. ( went back for a generous second helping of these two dishes they are bursting with flavor!) servers bring around fresh hot naan to the table that is just delicious ! Great location/neighborhood. Lots to see Enjoyed walking around after our meal.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Great Indian spot worth all the kudos it gets here. Went with 3 coworkers who were all in town from various places visiting our HQ.

Started out with the Palak Chaat (crunchy spinach) - which I'd never had before and is hard to describe, but I'd recommend it. We also had some samosas and these duck kebabs. Good start to the meal and easy to share all those things.

We had 3 things that others and the waitress recommended - the butter chicken is as good as everyone else says it is. We also had the chicken biryani (spicy! but good) and the lamb vindaloo which was melt-in-your-mouth delicious. The naan was fine (not much you can say, it's bread). It was a lot of food, in the end, I think we could probably have done with one less entree given all the appetizers. 

Service was good, and we didn't have any trouble getting a table or hearing each other despite how crowded it was.
author: Joshua B.

description:
This place was okay. To tell you the truth, no Indian person's going to tell you an Indian restaurant's food is better than mommy dearest's concoctions. Those unreachable standards aside, Indian restaurants can be pretty tasty. But to me, Amber India was nothing special.

I came for the lunch buffet with my family. The dosa was pretty bland and without much filling. The naan was a bit crunchy. The cholle, chutneys, daal, etc. were pretty forgettable. Speaking of forgettable, I forgot the name of the nonalcoholic drink I ordered, but it had "Amber" in the name and was raspberry flavored with a bit of lemon-lime soda. That drink tasted watered down.

My family wasn't wowed by any of the food, but maybe we should try their entrées instead some day. We left feeling this place had such a high Yelp rating because of its location and perhaps the service rather than its food. But I'm just speculating. Maybe they will improve!
author: Ashish B.

description:
Came here for lunch buffet. 
We like the food however I think they could have more menu options. Love the fact that the buffet includes some drink options. 

The restaurant can get really crowded. So do come early if you want to enjoy the buffet. 

And please please please try the BUTTER CHICKEN. Go crazy!!
author: Haryati S.

description: We went there for an after conference dinner. The food was probably the best Indian I have had. Very rich and flavourful. We had the butter chicken, saag pannar, and kadhai jinga. All were very nice! Recommended!
author: Eric K.

description:
I literally love this place.  Solid 5 stars.  I've been here 3 times now and have not been disappointed.

The Garlic Naan and Butter Chicken here can turn any frown upside down.
author: Ruchi P.

description:
Situation
- Lunch on a Monday at noon
- Ordered the lunch buffet for $16

Pros
- Most of the food was good
- Great service
- Very nice decor

Cons
- A little pricey (but worth it)
- They charged my credit card with more than what I actually paid

Overall
- I will probably come back, but I'm going to pay in cash
author: Dipesh G.

description: We went for buffet and it was quite good with lots of vegetarian options such as kadhai paneer, eggplant curry, yellow dal, aloo curry. There gajar halwa was awesome. There weekend buffet is even better with more options including alcoholic beverages and pani puri. We had to make reservation in advance but it was worth it.
author: Deeksha R.

description:
Amber India is solid Indian cuisine. It's a little pricey if you do a regular dine-in, so it's best for family-style.

I think the best value here is definitely the happy hour or the lunch buffet. The happy hour is M-F until 6PM and they have some good offerings. $7 Wines, $6 Cocktails, $5 Beers. They also have a good selection of Appetizers for about $6-7. The lamb and the chicken wings from the happy hour are both solid meat options with a large portion - perfect for sharing!

The ambiance at the bar/lounge area are cute, with open face windows looking out to Market Street  & Yuerba Buena. The actual dining room is darker and more romantic.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Palak Chaat - pretty good but a little on the oily side
Butter Chicken - tender with just enough spice
Pista Kulfi - good flavor but didn't have a nice mouth-feel like ice cream should
Rasmalai - sauce had a wonderful taste but the cheese dumpling had an interesting texture
