Overall, the food was pretty good, although a little pricey.  Ambiance was nice.  Service was average.  Would I eat here again?  Most likely...
author: Rose A.

description: 25 minute line for buffet at lunch. There were about 45 people in front of me snaking through much of the restaurant after we sat down. Good for dinner. Not recommend for lunch, especially if you have business to discuss.
author: David S.

description: 3.25 stars.  Essentially, you go here if you are in the Financial District and want some semi-late night premium priced Indian food.  It's probably better for a date than a standard meal.   We found the Kashmiri Roganjosh to be rather enticing, but frankly, you can find a similar product for half the price on the East Coast.  The tandoori sampler was fine, but it wasn't especially memorable either.  Perhaps we should have followed the rather insistent pleas to order wine from our lovely waitress, but I'm not sure it would have changed the overall experience.  Really, there is nothing wrong with Amber, but it's not a place I would go out of my way to revisit.  At the price point they are offering, I was expecting a more inspired meal than the leftovers I ate from North India restaurant a few days later.
author: Yelper N.

description:
Last Saturday night four of us friends went to have dinner at Amber's The food was OK, the  service was lousy , waiters did not refill my water I even had to ask them to. I thought price was too expensive for the food we had,waiters were very irritated when  we had asked  questions about the food, The guy at the front, was an old receptionist man, he was very rude I was ashamed that people to talk to  other People that way , he should not work at public-service if he talked that way I was very disappointed, If I could I would not even give them one star, I will not recommend this place any of my friends.       

- (4/23/2016)
author: Shanti H.

description: Had the Buffet here and all I can say is OH MY GODDDD!!!!The best Indian Buffet EVER!!!!  Usually Indian restaurants are a gamble not all can live up to the standard. I have never had a good experience with Indian Buffet UNTIL i came to Amber. The buffet are expensive tho about $30 for a person but well worth it, and parking is a problem  and is expensive too about another $30 to park your car in the near by garage. Will definitely go back hopefully soon.
author: Aman G.

description:
I've taken to describing restaurants as "Something (new)" in honor of Yelp's American (new) category. In that vein, this place is "Indian (new)" and good at it. The options are a mix of traditional north Indian that you can find in most Indian restaurants and newer things that are different, but delicious. For instance, they had a tandoori lobster.

We started with the palak chaat, which was unlike any other chaat I'd had. It was lightly-fried (but still dark green) spinach with some lightly sweet toppings and nuts. Really, really good and I'd get it again in a heartbeat.

We split a tandoori sampler (with chicken, ground lamb and shrimp) and an aloo gobi (spicy potatoes and cauliflower) with a side of the roti. Everything was good, but I'd probably put the ground lamb and aloo gobi at the top. Especially, when they were in the roti. They also had brown rice, a rarity in my experiences with Indian restaurants.

We finished things off with pista kulfi (lightly-sweet, hard pistachio cake). I thought it was just OK. It was both a bit too hard and a not quite sweet enough and I'm usually a fan of not-too-sweet when it comes to deserts.

Overall, this is is a nice place to grab a fancy-ish dinner and you won't be disappointed.
author: Colin D.

description:
We have passed this restaurant a few times walking towards Market. So, this time we decided to stop in for a quick drink after a movie (4/1/16). First off, the decor of the place was absolutely fantastic and the lounge area was arranged in such a way that you can mingle and watch a game on the big screen. 

We had a pomegranate martini, another drink (i can't remember the name) and the Tandoori sampler. The martini and "another drink" were prepared with vigor and care :-). The bartender knew what she was doing and kept us company as it was close to closing. The Tandoori sampler was great; Baluchi chicken, Achari Jheenga, Lamb Seekh Kebab. The sauce came in nice dipping bowls, but we really didn't need it. The food was seasoned just right to get the taste buds going. We will come back here for dinner later in the week. And "kudos" to our wonderful bartender who kept us company.
author: Marcus M.

description: This place has amazing Indian food. Great service. A little pricey but worth it. The chaat was awesome.
author: Micheal G.

description: Amber India recently changed their menu, and some of the old favs are gone, but the Nalli Vindaloo is as good as ever! This is not your hole in the wall BYOB Indian place (for that go to Shalimar). Amber is tablecloths and wine lists and a creative menu with huge portions. My fav place to grab food when downtown along Market! Oh, and on Friday, Dec. 23, when I wanted to take my family from out of town, I called for a reservation and they said they were full, but they would take walk-ins, thought there could be a wait. We showed up at 7:30 and much to my amazement and pleasant surprise, they seated us immediately! Awesome, awesome service. My whole family was very pleased!
author: Dzney V.

description: Although there were lot of booth and empty tables where they could have made us seat. They chose to give us table in walkway and the table was too high for a girl who is 5.3 tall. Tried to ask 2ce to make us seat somewhere comfortable but they were reluctant. Probably choose some place where they serve food and treat customers with hospitality
author: Bindu C.

description:
This has to be the best Americanized Indian restaurant I've been to so far in the United States. The ambiance is classy modern, the service is exceptional, and the food is eclectically wonderful. 

For the times I've been here, I've never been disappointed. It's a great place to take people who are not familiar with Indian food to have their first experience. I prefer hole-in-the-wall Indian, but let's be honest, authentic Indian flavors are sometimes too bold for newbies. 

This time we ordered the Cauliflower Bezule, Butter Chicken, Saffron Rice, and Plain Naan. Just FYI we were two people and this was a lot of food so before you decide to get a curry entree for each person, I would caution against it because curries are meant to be shared. 

Bezule was perfect. It was hot cauliflower dipped in cold coconut sauce. Butter Chicken was tasty--just enough cream and tomato sauce. Pretty good portions of chicken pieces to cream. Rice and Naan was good. I ordered a chai and I wish it could have been hotter. Also, service was great but timing was not. They brought out the main entrees almost five minutes after the appetizers so we were rushed in finishing the appetizers. Usually, I wouldn't care, but I would expect better timing in between courses for an upscale restaurant.

If it weren't so expensive, I would visit this place whenever I had an Indian craving in San Francisco.
author: Viroopa V.

description:
Palak chaat - wow
Salmon tiki - yum
Mango mojoto - to live for
Vegetarian tiki -  sooooo good
author: Eddie I.

description: Food is very yummy, especially the the paneer curry and fish fry. Just loved it. Might be a bit on the higher end but considering desi khaana in SFO and the superb taste of all the dishes, i would say it's worth it.. Will try again when i want to treat myself ;)
author: Pranay B.

description: Oh my goodness the BUTTER CHICKEN.  I can't even describe to you how delicious the butter chicken is.  Creamy, spicy, rich and fragrant.  Do yourself a favor, and order this just for yourself and don't let anyone share!  We ordered so much for dinner, including the popular seabass curry(which was also delicious) and the veggie korma, but the butter chicken is the clear winner.  Be sure to order plenty of garlic naan to go around because you'll need lots of it!  I just wish this place wasn't so damn expensive!!  I've never spent close to $200 at an Indian place ever!
author: Wendy C.

description:
The guy and the gal the host/ess table were RUDE beyond belief.  Wow.  crude, crass and cocky for no reason.  Perhaps we didn't fit their "target profile customer segment"?

Food is okay but service is not.  

Avoid it if you can.  There are better places nearby.
author: Sri N.

description: Nothing great about this restaurant. . They don't have a wide variety of options.  Plus the portions were too small.
author: Ramkumar R.

description:
Horrible horrible service- rude staff and absolutely don't care!!!

I was visiting SFO from PHX and ate there with my brother during lunch. 

We were asked to sit at a pretty weird 2 person table and when we asked to move to a better table, were met with the most obnoxious facial expression from the hostess. Maybe she is doesn't like people or her job but for $20/plate for Buffett she better not show her tantrums to print customers!

The fun did not end there. We sat and we're just chatting waiting for the buffet line to clear up and they bought some cold naans to support the main course. We told him to bring it later while we ate and the look from the waiter was like I asked him to donate an organ or something. He had his revenge when we finally got our food as we waited for 10+ minutes to get the naans and when we did get them, they were cold and soggy. Had to send them back twice.

Anyways, such an unpleasant experience when you put $50 for meal for two people!!!

Never again and recommend folks to stay away from such horrible service.
author: Amit B.

description:
Been here a few times for their lunch buffet. The selection is always slightly different each time, which is nice, but there are some consistent dishes that they always have. 

Pro tip: come hungry. I don't see how you can willingly pay $20 for lunch buffet and only eat one plate. Especially since the food is above average, but it should be at those prices. 

The line can be long, although even that is hit and miss. Standing in line snaking between dinners in the main part of the restaurant is a bit awkward, so I like to come early, get a plate, and then wait for the wait to die down before going back for plate number 2 (or 3). 

Their desserts are light and they've usually got fresh fruit, which is a nice end to such a heavy meal. 

The service is ok, but then again, I've only had the buffet. They are pretty good with clearing your plates when you go back for me, and always seem to be gracious about it. 

It's a nice splurge, especially on a day when you don't have anything to do that afternoon (read: food coma).
author: Brian B.

description:
Excellent location! I like the food as well but its loaded with a lot of butter and cream which makes you feel super heavy after the meal. My only love for the creamy dal makhani, sometimes takes me to this place. It is also expensive compared to other Indian restaurant but for sure has better ambience.  

So if you love the the creamy heavy version of north Indian food then this is your place!!
author: Pankhuri S.

description: Best Indian restaurant in California, in terms of authentic in flavors. Very rare to find a perfect black Indian lentils outside of India, but this place does it perfectly in the form of "Dal Amber". The saag paneer is also perfect.
author: Arch S.

description:
As an indian guy, I can say I have had indian food in the two best countries for indian food in the world, London and India. No other countries have such delicious indian food, however Amber India makes the cut. This place is terrific with a great set of staff running the multiple locations. I have been going here for over 10 years and have to say I cannot find a single better place in the US. 

My favorite dishes are...

Butter Chicken
Amber Dal
The Crème brûlée that changes flavors every so often
Garlic Naan
Okra 

These dishes are not the only dishes that are good, however they are my favorite and are ordered every time I go. 

Please Enjoy!
author: Shak K.

description: Amazing food, staff is very friendly, and their menu is very creative with Indian food. Easily one of the best in the bay area.
author: L K.

description:
Mediocre at best for what you pay.
Nice ambiance, butter chicken was good but very heavy. Expected a more refined taste at this higher end Indian restaurant. 
Lentils were good. Rasmalai, a classic Indian dessert, was the worse I have ever had. It known for its rich rose water cardamom infused sauce.
author: Workhardplayhard A.

description: I went to Amber India while in San Francisco for a weekend getaway and I have to say that the entire experience was pleasant. I chose this restaurant because of the Yelp reviews, the convenience of online reservations, and the distance to Market St/Union Square. It was my friends first time with Indian food so I kept it simple. I ordered samosas, classic chicken tikka truffles, tandoori chicken, basmati rice, and the pesto naan. The food was DELICIOUS... I loved the spiciness of the chicken tikka and how juicy the tandoori chicken was. The restaurant was dimly lit and modern and, even though the dining area is quite open, seating seemed fairly private. The wait staff could be a bit more friendly, but they were very attentive otherwise. I recommend this restaurant to anyone who would like an elegant dining experience in San Francisco.
author: KiKi F.

description:
"So Good".... My tongue was smoldering 1/2 an inch up!

We had the cauliflower app which was roasted and had a coconut cream sauce.  A must try!
We ordered Butter Chicken, eggplant with almond and sea bass in a coconut sauce.  The chicken was a little dry but the sauce was amazing!  The eggplant dish was spicy  deliciousness and would definitely order this again.  I enjoyed the sea bass but the sauce is a tad sweet and rich.

Our waiter Martin was perfect!
author: Marlene B.

description:
I had dinner here with my friend this weekend and had mixed feelings. We were able to be seated pretty quickly on a Saturday night around 7 thanks to space in the bar and lounge area. It took some time for our order to be taken, but food did seem to come out in a timely manner. 

The atmosphere is beautiful with excellent mood lightning giving it a chic and vibrant feeling. The lounge also had a comfy couch area with pillows and fun little seating tufts. 

Quite a few of the menu items are gluten free as is common with Indian food. My friend had enjoyed their butter chicken before so we ordered that to split with saffron rice. We each had a glass of wine as well. The chicken was delicious and very flavorful with a creamy broth. I was also pleased with the wine. 

The only issue for me was I just thought it was ridiculously overpriced... Again have I just been confined to the Midwest too long?? Who knows.. Maybe we pay less for the same food cause we have only a sea of cornfields to look at while we eat. The butter chicken came in a small little pot for 22.00. Then, what I really have issue with is being charged 5.00 for a cup of rice. So that combined with there not being a wine on the list under 10 bucks led to a rather pricey shared meal. 

Not saying it wasn't fantastic.. It was.. But so is the Indian food in my local braska haunt, and hey, my view of the cows can be equally as entertaining as a view of downtown SF.. Given the right day ;
author: Elisabeth P.

description:
We had a reservation for 5 and were a bit early. We were seated and they took our order promptly but then other groups came in, were seated, and received their food before we did. At least three tables were served before us despite the fact that they arrived after us. Our waiter came to say our food would be out in two minutes, but it was probably 15-20 minutes after that and it was already late. They also forgot to put the requested Baileys in my coffee. 

The food, however, was delicious. It was the best butter chicken I've had in a long time, and the assorted bread basket was a great way to try the various breads. My dad especially liked the seabass curry.
All the dishes were flavorful and well balanced, though nothing was actually spicy. We had dessert as well and it was good though the kheer could have used a bit more flavor/been concentrated or reduced to increase its flavor and creaminess. The kheer was a huge portion and could serve two, but the portions of the entrees were small for very high prices ($15 for a cup and a half or so of saag paneer). 

In summary, the atmosphere and ambiance were nice, the food was some of the tastiest Indian I've had, but the service was lacking and the prices were steep enough that they really should have done better. Since it was dinner with my family and they were cheerful through it all, my husband and I had a very pleasant meal here. If it were just me I would have been more difficult...

5 stars -1 for bad service, +1/2 for being extra tasty, -1 for being overpriced=3.5 stars, rounded down to 3 because of the lack of apology or voluntary compensation for the bad service!
author: Claire D.

description:
Great food and ambience. I came here for brunch with a group of 6 and the food was on point. We had a bottomless mimosas, which were great. For starters- pani puri, Pav bhaji, and dhai vada were very tasty! The main course items were great except for the vegetable jal frazi, which none of us were a fan of. It had a very tangy taste, similar to Indo Chinese food, which threw us off. The gulab jamoon for dessert was deeeelish!!! 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Dee P.

description:
The lunch buffet has a really good value. 

A bit too crowded sometimes, but the food is good and there is a nice variety.
author: Lionel F.

description: I will rate this 4 stars, however it is not child friendly.  We came her to have team lunch and invited one of our team mates on maternity leave. She brought her adorable daughter in a stroller. The front desk said we cannot bring the stroller inside. He suggested that for us to be accommodated, we had to carry the child with us. He said it's their policy not to let stroller in.
author: June A.

description: Great ambience. Ordered the mushroom kofta along with stuffed peas kulcha and garlic chive naan. Great flavour with balanced spice. Stuffed peas kulcha was the best. Also had rasmalai for dessert which is a must to have. Masala chai was also good.
author: Ashok K.

description: According to my friend at dinner, "this was by far the best Indian food I have ever had!" Delicious duck appetizer. Loved the Lobster Coconut Curry and Butter Chicken. Excellent, prompt service. Fantastic location near MOMA and Union Square shopping.
author: Catharine N.

description:
This review is long overdue.

I've had this place bookmarked for quite some time, but have never really had a chance to try it out. I've been going to Sports Club/LA, which is pretty much right around the corner from Amber. After a workout, I wanted to get something to eat. I decided not to grab something at the gym because I like to try to make a dent in my bookmarks as much as possible. So Amber popped up and I decided to finally give it a go.

I went when they had their brunch buffet. I didn't necessarily want a buffet, but the price of the buffet was more reasonable than the menu options. Plus, bottomless mimosas! The service here was a little slow, but the food was SO good. I ate so much and it was worth it.

I'm sure you're probably wondering why I am giving this place 5 stars. Well, there's a big reason. After asking for the check, I went through my gym bag. When trying to find one of my cards, I panicked because I didn't have it. I had one with me that I knew wasn't going to cover the bill. I gave it to the waiter and crossed my fingers. It came back declined. I have never, ever been in this situation before. That card was the only form of payment I had on me. So I asked for the manager.

He came and I explained to him what happened. Having an S3, I have Google Wallet. I've used it plenty of times before and have all of my cards linked to it. I've never used it as a debit so wasn't sure if I could get cash back at Walgreen's or something. The manager let me leave to give it a go. I left my gym bag there as collateral.

I went to Walgreen's, CVS and 7-Eleven. I bought small items, but no option for cash back. (Let that be a lesson to you Google Wallet users). I went back to Amber with my head down low. I told the manager about what happened and that my only other option was that I could go back to Oakland, go home and grab that card. He let me go, but told me I could take my bag.

I don't think he thought I was coming back.

On my way back to Oakland, I started thinking about the situation. I really didn't have to go back. I could have just been done with it and had a free meal. But, I went home, grabbed my card and left. I grabbed cash and went back on BART back out to the city.

I got there right at 5pm when they reopened for dinner. No one was in the front, but not long, the manager came out. It was almost like he did a double take. He really wasn't expecting me to come back. I gave him the cash, with a little extra money. He wouldn't accept it. He would only accept what I had owed.

After this experience, and the great food I had, I wish I could give this place more than 5 stars. Thank you again.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Biggest fails of my life.
1. Calamari is not calamari: its a dish made of squids dipped in Indian curry. Tastes bad.
2. Panna cotta is not panna cotta: its just custard with strawberries. The audacity to call it panna cotta, OMG.

Only if I can have a 1-1 with the chef.

Butter chicken was mediocre too. 

All the best if you are planning to visit :) my advice, don't.
author: Vibhor G.

description: Expensive weekend lunch buffet for $26.95.  Food was pretty good.  Nan was below average.Service was good for a buffet.  Lots of people eating there.
author: dylan d.

description: So bad and it has the worst service worst workers there and the worst experience, not a good food as well I wouldn't like to take my date or my family there it's too bad, I wouldn't waste a dollar there it doesn't worth a single dollar...
author: Khalid A.

description:
They are racism !
Veeeeery veery veery baaaad service !! 


Oh my god they are horrible !
author: Ab A.

description: The first time we went there we really liked it! However when we went in for buffet, the food was just horrible. It wasn't as fresh as when we had tried their a la carte items. Forget about rude staff and  limited spread, some of the meat items was clearly not fresh. Both my boyfriend and I got food poisoning after eating their buffet. I will not recommend their buffet!
author: Richa G.

description:
This is a great place right off Market St.  The decor is upscale and trendy and the food is really good.   The restaurant focuses on  modern  Indian cuisine.

I had the bhatti da jhinga which were shrimps with cardamom, pepper, clove and caraway marinade.  I find most Indian places don't usually make the food spicy but this dish had a little kick to it. I also tried some of my friend's lamb qorma.  The lamb didn't need a knife it was so tender and it was seasoned just right.

I would recommend a reservation if you go.  It was pretty busy when I went and while my friend and I were seated fairly quickly we were only a party of two.  I imagine if you were a larger group it might be trickier to get a table without a reservation.  Also it is a little on the pricey side so take that into account.  It is definitely worth a visit though.
author: Julia D.

description:
If you want good Indian food, trust this Indian and go to Amber India! 

Nothing else in the city compares to Amber. The only Indian restaurant I go to. They have great customer service and delicious food. Buffet is $22 on weekdays and weekends (I think) but on weekends you can get bottomless mimosa (thumbs up) 

If you're here for dinner try the sea bass dish, also one of my favs.

They have a really great bar as well. I often come where just to drink their masala chai after work (so relaxing)
author: Reet R.

description:
Go for the lunch buffet, and even the weekend brunch buffet with bottomless drinks and (gimmicky) dosa station! Yeah it is more expensive than your typical Indian restaurant, but then you'd be paying the same if not more for a decent pizza in the city. However, it is not worth the extra price if you go a la carte, unless you are down with paying extra for the ambiance, or just want to impress someone over Indian food.

Buffet has decent number of options, majority of which are tasty. Food is fresh and not as greasy as most Indian restaurants.

Their happy hour is solid, especially the indianized snacks they serve, though the bar area is small.
author: DJ R.

description:
Amber is an upscale Indian restaurant located near the Powell Street BART.  Don't come here expecting cheap eats - this isn't your Indian fast food joint.  Expect entrees to be around $20 and with drinks/appetizers/naan/rice, expect that cost to jump up to around $40 per person.

The inside decor is very tasteful and romantic.  The lighting is very dim and there is a lot of funky artwork and candles.  I suppose this is a good place to meet for drinks and a date.  It definitely is not a hole in the wall Indian joint that you can find a few blocks over in the Tenderloin.

Wait time for two for dinner was about 20 minutes so instead we opted to sit in the bar area where there was also a full dinner menu.  Let me tell you now, the soft seating in the bar is not ergonomic and not very conducive for eating full fledged meals.  The tables are extremely low.  I would advise either getting a bar table or just waiting for a full dining table instead.

The service was a bit lacking.  I mean, I don't expect hover waiters since we were sitting in the bar area after all, but I'm pretty sure we saw our waiter a total of three times.  

OK now onto the food.  The menu makes a big point to detail where the food comes from - what farm, is it organic, etc.  We got garlic naan, lamb korma, and vegetable kofta.  The entrees were about $20 each.

-The garlic naan, while pretty fluffy and garlicky, was actually a lot smaller than I expected.  This was probably the first time in my Indian dining food experiences where I actually thought, "I could use more naan."

-The lamb korma was pretty good albeit a bit spicier than I expected.  The lamb pieces were tender.  I actually don't like eating a lot of meat in my Indian dishes though so take my comments with a grain of salt.

-The vegetable kofta was tasty.  They only give you like five dumplings though (as is typical with most kofta entrees).  It goes well with the naan.

-The basmati rice was whatever but I was a bit disappointed that an extremely small serving of rice cost an extra $4 when a) rice is basically free and b) with the high prices of the entree I would expect the rice price to be already baked in.  It's impossible to eat Indian food without a grain on the side.

-Mango lassi was good.  Definitely one of the better ones I've had in a restaurant.

Anyway, this place is good but to be honest, if I'm paying that much for dinner, I expect high quality service but it was extremely lacking. I also don't really care that much about the decor of a restaurant, which is what I felt like half of my money was going to.  I've definitely gotten very tasty kofta at not so nice places.  And while it's true that at other Indian restaurants I may not be getting my organic cage-free meat from Mary's Local Farm... well, I think I can live without that.
author: Danielle C.

description:
This place is amazing. Every time we come to the city we stop at Amber for handcrafted cocktails beautiful ambience and a break from the hustle and bustle while still being able to see the hustle and bustle outside the windows of the lounge.

The menu is extensive and all of the dishes that we have tried are top notch.  

Great flavors great selection! vegetarian and nonvegetarian options.  

Amber is a must!
author: Sean S.

description: We usually like eating at Amber, but we had a Valentine's Day meal there which was terrible. First they informed us that only a fixed menu would be available on the 14th. The actual meal proved to be a disaster. The kitchen had major issues, and each course took ages to come out. We were there for close to 3 hours. Theres only so much romantic conversation to be made! Our server had no clue where our courses were, and we saw at least 3 other tables just get up and leave in disgust. They claimed the kitchen was backed up, but this is unacceptable when you are charging close to $200 for a meal for 2. The front desk was unapologetic when we complained while leaving. Management needs to step up and realize this is a huge let down. They also tried to indulge in weird flourishes for the V-Day menu- stick to the dal makni guys- that's what you do best!
author: Chetan G.

description: Though several years old, this is one of the newest Ambers, and is totally different in vibe, setting, ambience, service. Urban, sleek, polished, multi-level with bar on top, polished tables. The food arrives piping hot in glistening brass vessels. We love getting their tandoori fish, either the salmon or sea bass, is phenomenal, super fresh and not overly cooked, left tender and flaky, with the juices and flavors seared into the flesh.The frontier kebab or tandoori rack of lamb (Frontier) and butter chicken dishes became our mantra :-) I kid you not: the tastes were a revelation, it was as if I had never eaten tandoori lamb or chicken tikka masala before. The flavors of their butter chicken are blended perfection, a waft of fenugreek as its set on the table, the sauce rich, creamy, tomatoey and though velvety, it's not greasy or oily--and a little goes a very long way! It has shredded chicken from the tandoori--I use a bit of garlic nan to barely dip into this curry and the flavor is explosive. Unlike those early days, I can no longer eat spicy food, and we asked them to make it "mild," and they absolutely delivered! This is hard for an Indian restaurant to do, because they usually do not know how to tone down the spiciness by simply taking out the chili . . . but they did it beautifully, leaving all the flavor and complexity, the layering of spices, did not sacrifice any of this; I loved it! The remarkable thing about Amber is their consistency, over the years and from visit to visit: more than a decade ago, I wrote a Zagat review, likening a mouthful of their butter chicken to an orgasm. That curry should be patented. And to get that signature level of tenderness, the rack of lamb is likely marinated a minimum of overnight in improbable spices and god knows what else; this must be tasted to believe. I cannot do justice to it, it literally melts in your mouth and is not the slightest bit gamey. We usually get rice which is the perfect accompaniment and their assorted bread basket, which is a terrific introduction to the varieties of roti, paratha, nan . . . I need raita to go with whatever I'm having. We also always get their bengan bhartha (eggplant) and bhindi (okra), the latter they're able to adjust the spice level, but the bhartha they seem to have pre-made the spices and chili's, so if you're spice-averse, this may not be the dish for you. This is not any okra you've ever tasted: they do a helluva balance between crispy and soft. The eggplant is smoky in all the ways we bbq to be, and the fact they do this with a vegetable is a miraculous alchemical magic trick. They have lots of "modern" interpretations of classic Indian food, especially in the appetizers and also stuff not found in your typical Indian place, e.g. calamari, duck, lobster.   Btw, their ras malai for dessert is sublime! I cannot rave enough about it: it's spiked with rose water and cardamom, which is standard, but the ratio of both is .5 to .5 = balance! The consistency begs for your spoon to touch it, firm yet creamy, and it's so damn good that I say hell with my lactose intolerance, and I'm ordering one . . . my husband and I refuse to share one, we get one each :-) Their lunch buffet is insanely awesome: the choices are stupendous and the quality of each dish ridiculous, the presentation in each majestic tureen boggles the mind. It's a steep price per person, but the quality is worth it. The service is professional and clearly, these are not students bussing tables part-time, they've been to some training. Though it's the same ownership, we find the food here, despite the similarities, to be different enough that's it's a unique experience, and worthy of paying for parking and of the price tag.
author: Ranjan P.

description: I've been here many times and the food was always really good.  The Palak Paneer is my favorite.  However, the buffet today was a disappointment.  The choice of dishes was really lacking (virtually no appetizer, cold pakora's, lack of veg options) and quality of food was subpar.  I don't know if there has been a chef change or not but the preparation seemed "lazy" and not the usual Amber.  I don't plan on visiting again :-/.
author: Hil B.

description:
While I can only speak for the lunch buffet, this is the best Indian food I have had in years.

The Butter Chicken is their signature dish so DO NOT pass it up.  The service was fast and courteous and food is amazing.
author: Erica S.

description: I am so glad that I got dragged all the way down market to have lunch at Amber. It was a bit of a walk from our office but so worth it. For $20, their lunch buffet has a ton of extremely delicious food to offer and the restaurant itself is lovely and cozy. This was such a great workday treat and I'll definitely be back.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Service - slow.
Butter chicken - AMAZING.
Garlic naan - AWESOME.
Mango lasse - (small), delicious.

I'd go back again.
author: Arry Y.

description:
This week was the gamer's developer conference in the city and every place was packed even though it was a Tuesday. Bluestem was packed, Press Club was sealed off for a private party and we ended up at Amber by default.

This is pretty tastefully done and on the higher end for Indian restaurants.  The maitre D was pretty but seemed a little full of herself and copped a tude but our waitress was sweet. The cocktail that I got was just OK. I forget what it was called and I should have known better to get a cocktail with scotch in it. Scotch is best by itself. 

The food looked great and tasted OK. My favorite was the chicken kebab. The palak
salad was unique. Overall it was an OK experience.  A little too expensive given the quality of the food.
author: Sunil R.

description: I use to love coming here. Now it is overpriced, very small portions, tables stuffed on top of each other. Way better and cheaper Indian places in the city by the dozens.
author: Christopher J.

description:
Very average Indian food with a polished yet insincere wrapper. If you're interested in overpaying and dining along side a bunch of Moscone conference go-ers on an expense account, this is your place.

Service was atrocious. Server weirdly challenged my friend that a hair found in her food could have been hers - which was impossible if you had any common sense (color, texture, thickness all didn't match). Then he challenged us again. And again. It was a completely out of line and made you question the integrity of the restaurant on a deeper level.

I would not go back nor would I recommend this restaurant.
author: David C.

description:
Excellent bar and restaurant.  

Cocktails are great and the food is some of the best Indian cuisine I've ever had!

Service was top notch.  Polite and engaging staff, all with excellent personalities and sense of humour who were more than happy to chat!

One definitely to go to if you are ever in town.
author: Chris I.

description:
I've first tried Amber shortly after it opened (I am always looking for good options near where I work), and have now been going several years.

The food is consistently very good, the service friendly and attentive, and the ambience is quite nice. There is also a pretty good wine and drink list. The buffets (lunch and brunch) offer a wide variety of quality dishes (including their tasty Butter Chicken), and is quite well priced considering the quality. Ordering a la carte runs a bit more.

The last time I wnet there (treating an elderly friend with some mobility problems), I noticed that Amber had stored baby carriages, extra chairs, etc. in a way which blocked access to the elevators needed to make the space (which is on different levels) handicap accessible. My friend has enough mobility to navigate the stairs, and did not want to cause a fuss, so we did not bring the situation (which I am sure violated applicable disability rights laws) up with the management.
author: Jethro B.

description: If you want the best Indian meal ever then pay up. As far as I'm concerned, the meal was worth every penny. Amber served the best Tandoori sea bass, the best Chicken Tikka and the best Saag I've ever tasted. The sea bass rivals any friggin dish at any restaurant.. anywhere. Seriously. I actually called to ask about the preparation and the gentleman who picked up was friendly yet secretive regarding the seasoning. He did share that the fish is marinated in a yogurt based marinade over night and cooked in a tandoor clay pot in a way that draws fat away from the fish rendering it both delicious and healthy. Dang, I want to go back asap.
author: The B.

description: Food was okay, but nothing was great. And for those prices, it needs to be great. Dining room is nice. Servers were good. Bathroom was reasonably clean.
author: scott h.

description: 0 points for service and the hostess loves to keep tables open for 30-45 mins rather than seat folks who are there.
author: Puneet T.

description:
Let me preface this with the fact that I have zero tolerance for spicy food. I ordered scallops, telling the waiter that I have seriously no desire to eat anything spicy and he said it was one of the most mild dishes on the menu. Well let me assure you that despite its really good flavor I couldn't eat more than a bite- wayyy too spicy for me. The manager was very attentive and when I regrettably told him it was too spicy he was very understanding and replaced my meal with a chicken dish that was really sweet (I suspect he gave the kitchen special instructions). I hate returning food but in this case the second dish was much more on my comfort level and I appreciated his understanding.

The waiter reassured me that they were able to accommodate my "gluten allergy" and they definitely did. I had no issues
author: Sarah B.

description:
They have the best Indian lunch buffet in town. Food is awesome!

Menu is a bit pricey but the food and service have always been excellent. The best in town!!!
author: Bhanu V.

description:
Pretty disappointed when I dined here on a weekday night. The best thing was the butter chicken. 
For an upscale Indian place I really thought it would be better. Service was slow and spotty. Maybe this is a better lunch spot?
author: Angela D.

description:
Food is mediocre and very overpriced. It looks like a great place from the ambience but the taste and flavor was just not there.

There are better Indian places out there, skip this one.
author: R Q.

description: Decent Indian fusion place but little pricey. Very cool in terms of ambience, not the best taste wise though.
author: Saumitra G.

description:
Ok so this place is seriously good. One of the best Indian meals I have had in a long time.

The serving sizes were generous and the dishes were authentic and flavourful.

The butter chicken and saag paneer were standouts. The lamb vindaloo was interesting coming as a shank. It was hot as expected.

Will definitely be returning here on next trip to San Francisco
author: George L.

description:
We love this place

We went for a dinner.

Had mixed nan basket, kadhai paneer, Kofta
For Appetizer - we'd potato tikki and spinach chaat. Also Mango Mojito 

this is the only Indian restaurant that maintains quality and price both. So I would give 5 stars

fast service. and great food.
author: Jim A.

description:
Good variety of Indian food.  I love their gajar halwa ... served hot !!  Only complaint would have is if they could have Indian. Biryani and some daal as option during buffet than it would be fantastic.

Overall good food and good service
author: Vishal M.

description: Consistent lunch buffet, have been here about 3 times and they usually have a variety of rotating dishes but always vegetarian friendly!
author: Raymond H.

description:
Fancy Indian food? Nah. Definitely NOT worth the price. (

Had drinks before hand at the bar while waiting for dinner... service was pretty crappy....Our waitress was very terse and somewhat rude.

DINNER: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/amber-india-san-francisco-2?select=acGq2U_FrQ0HaLiULBkkOA#lGcVPsb4YuX37PgI0f9luA)
1. Pesto naan and the garlic chive naan -- mediocre. The two didn't really taste that much differently, and there was not enough flavor on the naan.
2. Butter chicken -- the only good part of the meal, THANK GOD. The chicken was tender and it wasn't too heavy. The butter creamy flavor was also cooked well. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/amber-india-san-francisco-2?select=acGq2U_FrQ0HaLiULBkkOA#pryOHvLiBD5tf1j4i0Bsmw)
3. Paneer Lababdar -- not good, very bland and nondescript. 
4. Saag paneer lahsooni -- a little more flavorful than the paneer lababdar, but still lacked flavor and just tasted like.... kinda plasticky. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/amber-india-san-francisco-2?select=acGq2U_FrQ0HaLiULBkkOA#vLDLJkavIgHs40AswyQiIg)

You'd think that an upscale Indian restaurant would provide quality food, but you definitely won't find that here.
author: Liz W.

description:
Amber India definitely isn't your "spiced-down-for-white-suburbia" Indian restaurant!

We had gone for the weekend lunch buffet and it was definitely worth the price. The Chicken Tandoori was legit as was the Sabudana Vada which was great and never seen at the other joints I have been to.
The Aloo Gobi too was very very good and tasted like how it's made back home. The basmati rice was spot on and was redolent, fragrant, and had great texture. 

I was surprised by the yellow daal as it was really good and tasted home-made; a rarity with most restaurant daals. The Mushrooms masala too was really good albeit a little greasy but oh what the heck!

But I wasn't too ecstatic about the butter chicken which dropped the ball on the spread but did nothing to take away from the whole meal.

I hadn't had halwa in a really long time and on having a bite, there I was walking up in the clouds; it was awesome though I must confess I may have been a little biased as it's been many years since I last had one.

The service was attentive, and this is the most upscale Indian restaurant I've been to here

All in all, the food was pretty much spot on and definitely worth the $16.95!
author: Umesh T.

description:
I have stayed at Marriot Marguis many times and never ate here, only to wonder why it was packed all the time.  Now I know.

My companions were here about a month ago and simply wanted to repeat the experience.  We ordered everything to share and they simply went for it.  We had chicken, lamb, fish, and veggie dishes with two kinds of nan.

Man, they are to die for.  Flavorful, juicy, tender.  Nans disappeared quickly and we were all stuffed beyond capacity.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Great great food. Very fresh and well cooked. The buffet ia what I had. They have a good variety if veg and non-veg stuff. My personal favorites were the Butter Chicken and the Fish fry that was a daily special. Perfect place for a team lunch or outing. Wide variety for vegetarians which is hard to find otherwise.
author: Sidhesh B.

description: An amazingly very high end, classy, good music, great ambiance, fantastic service, great menu option restaurant. I love this place. It is very fancy and food is grreeaaaaatttttt. If u going on date and want to impress ur significant other go there. But pricey keep in mind which is why i gave 4 stars. Because i have had similarly delicious food at other places quiet reasonable price. Other wise no reason to not go there. I had paneer tikka masala spicy and OMG it was sooo good tht I ordered another one. Their quantity is good size too, but if u r HUNGRY u wont share cuz it tastes so good tht u wud   Want all of it for urself . So if m there in downtown and craving indian food and dont mind paying tiny bit extra (it is a luxury) restaurant) i would certainly go there hands down
author: Neeru S.

description:
Amazing!  We had the samosas (which were some of the best I have ever had) and the cauliflower appetizer.  It was creamy and garlicky and just plain delicious.

The lamb curry was really tender and creamy which really went well when sopped up by their amazing naan.  The lentil dish (Dal) was quite enjoyable with the naan as well.

Their two sauces (spicy cilantro and a tamarind sauce) were a nice addition to everything.  

We were too full for dessert, but they had a chocolate cake that sounded really good.  

Service was good and the ambiance was warm and cozy.  I will be back!
author: Karen H.

description:
Small portions and way overpriced. After waiting 1 hour we finally got a table and to our surprise the portions are for little children.
If you are an Indian, you can get same food at home. For all others, this place may have good non vegetarian food, but the vegetarian meal is below average.
Stay away from the eggplant. It's greesy. The naan is small and so is the paratha.
For this price, they should have better food.
author: Rizwan K.

description: We placed a reservation for 6:30pm in which when we got there they said you placed a reservation for 7:30pm. They apparently "squeezed us in"...B.S. The food was also mediocre, my mother makes food 10x better than this restaurant, wouldn't recommend to anyone!
author: Chirag P.

description:
I am a regular at Amber. I have eaten there about once a month for the past several years. 
Amber is an excellent restaurant - most of the time, but not tonight. 
Tonight, I had a mediocre dinner there.
I had the Kashmiri Rogan Josh and the Butter chicken. 
The food came out about 3 minutes after we ordered. That was a bad sign.
The lamb was dry, and the chicken was dry and stringy.
I could have gone to just a standard neighborhood Indian restaurant for 60% of the price and gotten equal or better quality. 
I won't be back for awhile until the memory of tonight's dinner has faded. 
And, I'll make sure not to go on a Sunday night when the quality of the food drops because the restaurant is slow, the food is precooked, and it's served without a quality check.
author: Leslie L.

description:
SO GOOD. Idk how authentic it is since I have never been to India, but I only saw Indian people when I went in, so I'm guessing it is pretty authentic. 
The lunch buffet was AN AMAZING DEAL, you get all you can eat for only 23! And it has EVERYTHING!!!! The curries are all amazing. I would have liked the Paneer to be salty instead of sweet though. The goat curry was especially captivating. Oh and the Butter Chicken. Mmmhh... Can't get enough. The desserts are on point, too. This place is a must for any Indian food lovers.
author: Phoebe W.

description: My husband and I dined here over the weekend and had a wonderful experience. This was our third time here, and it did not disappoint. We both both ordered the signature butter chicken with nan and rice on the side. The food came within twenty minutes, and our server was very friendly and attentive throughout the meal. This is one of our favorite spots for dining in San Francisco because of the food, service, and overall ambiance. We will definitely return in the future.
author: Renata S.

description:
Pros: Great ambience, tasty food, ideal for a lunch/dinner date.
Cons: Food portion is small for the price, some items are not worth the price(esp vegan stuff), food is served after long wait.
author: Yv S.

description: Fav Indian place in the city for special occasions. Unique twist on North Indian staples served in an upscale-for-most kind of ambience. My new fav appetiser: Palak chat!
author: Arun R.

description:
I had to sign up for Yelp just so I can give this place a review. I have never came across such a rude host/manager! We had a BD dinner reservation for 20+ people and took 1 extra chair from the next to us table of 4. The host, who identified himself as manager, came up and started to lecture us how we weren't allowed to take that chair and that he has lost customers because of that..??!!! There was no extra chair in the whole restaurant?? Needless to say our mood was ruined and BD girl felt as she was at fault since she chose the place. I have to admit food was good but this is no way to treat your customers. Especially when the bill came up to be over 1500$!!!
Worst service ever! I hope the guy will face some kind of consequences! Highly unprofessional!!!
author: Alena L.

description:
Amber has a nice ambience for a special occasion (and the prices reflect that). The food is decent, but I like the food in Amber, San Jose better.

This place is probably good for people with low spice tolerance.
author: Hema R.

description: Had a great meal here on my 60th birthday. The butter chicken is rich and delicious. Everything I had was quite good and up to my modest expectations for Indian food. Good beers from India available, among other beverages.
author: Jeff D.

description: Ambiance is sterile and corporate, food is good but way overpriced, and service was the rudest I have ever experienced. My main course came out with a piece of coarse hair mixed in. My server was horrified and notified the manager, who came out and tried to insinuate that the piece of hair was mine--sorry sir, wrong color, texture, length--and OMG I can't believe you are making me go on the defensive instead of apologizing profusely and doing something besides offering me a free dessert. Yelpers, take your date or clients somewhere classier and with soul.
author: Carol L.

description: I visit this place quite often with friends and family. Hands down the best authentic Indian cuisine I've tasted in a long time. Their food definitely showcases the effort that goes on in their kitchen. It's not every day that you get samosas in the US that beat the ones we get in India. Not just the chicken, but the vegetarian dishes are par excellence. Excellent food, beautiful ambience- all that is left for you to do is find good company.
author: Rajbir G.

description:
One of the best Indian places I've been to. My only complain is that the wait is kind of long to get served. I probably sat for about 15 minutes before the menu came, and another 15-20 minutes before the food came (although this might be because I came with a large party). 

I tried a couple items, and my favorite was definitely the vegetarian eggplant dish. The eggplant was well-seasoned and very tasty. 

Their naans are very fresh and come in a basket for the table, and their mango lassi's are one of the best I've ever tried. 

Will definitely come back for another nice meal with some friends!
author: Jeanette S.

description:
As far as semi-high end Indian food is concerned, I think I can still appreciate the consistent execution of the quality fare that Amber is best known for. It's one of the only decent Indian spots near work and a solid dinner / date option in SOMA.

The interior is undoubtedly trendy, the kind of Indian posh that sometimes commands more attention than the main star of the food, which in this case is the food. Some folks appreciate Indian food a la carte, I'm more for the variety. Hence, one of life's guilty pleasures happens to be the reasons I come for their lunch buffet instead.

rices have crept up from $14-18 over the years I've been coming, the tag seems a bit steep, even for the frequent Indian buffet patron. It's really no surprise considering that it's downtown SF. Indian buffet lovers might find the price a bit much, but hopefully the food makes up for it.

Some standouts on the food front include a very creamy and delectable sag paneer, a very quality dum aloo, and a delightful bunch of fried pakoras. The chicken tikka masala is always money, but the lamb vindaloo steals the show with good spice and tasty vindaloo. Along with a delicious keema matar and a decent tandoori chicken, the food is definitely more on the versatile side. The best part of the buffet is being able to enjoy multiple winners all at once.

While I'm hoping the week day buffet price doesn't rise above $20 (already $23 on the weekends), I assume it's only a matter of time when I'm back in SF and craving Indian.
author: Jando S.

description:
We were a party of 6 and we tried the lunch buffet. 
Good:
1) location is good.
2) Desert was good 
3) The fish was amazing
Not so Good
1) For a buffet, the choices were limited. For vegetarians, the gravy based dishes were few and dry dishes were too many. But how many can one eat with rice!!
2) The butter chicken just had butter and no chicken, even if you dived at the bottom of the dish, all you can find is more butter gravy.
3) chicken in the Butter Chicken and Tandoori Chicken tastes old and rubbery.
4) The salad bowl was empty and was not filled the 1.5 hours or so we were there.
5) Perhaps, the place would do better to hire friendly wait staff, who can smile at customers and not frown at them to get out of their way. Especially when the route to kitchen is between the desert bar and guest table.A smile goes a long way.
For the price, the items in Buffet can and should be increased.
author: Monu M.

description: The food is amazing and the restaurant is vibrant. I highly recommend the sea bass and naan. This is some of the best Indian food I've had.
author: Ann S.

description:
I came here fore the brunch buffet.  I think there's a large selection here of food but the base curry sauce seems to be the same for a lot of the items - in turn, the food begins tasting the same - the shahi paneer, korma, etc.

They had a little dosa section -- which i thought was nice but the dosa was not nearly as crispy as it should be.  The sambar was a little thin as well. They didn't refill or stir the items too often either, indian curry should be stirred because the oil and sauce will begin to separate.

For ~20 for a buffet, I expected deeper flavors and a larger selection.  There are a lot of indian buffets that are half the price and have the same number of items.

They also had unlimited mango mimosas, which some of the people got. This was I think another $10-15. My friends complained that they were being very stingy with the mimosas - actually avoiding the table so that they didn't have to refill the glasses.  It's unlimited, but they limit how often they refill you.  

All in all, the food is pretty decent but the price is a little high.  I think it'd be better if the cost went down.
author: Sheena D.

description:
Went here while visiting San Fran with family, around Christmas. Walking in, the first thing I noticed was the dimly lit, yet plush ambiance. 
The server was courteous and ushered us to your table right away. However, as luck would have it, we were seated right next to the kitchen, which is probably the worst place to sit in this restaurant. The noise of servers talking in loud voices and plates and silverware clattering formed an annoying backdrop to our entire meal, and is the reason why I'm giving this place 4 stars, not 5.  
Now for the food. We ordered several dishes, and every one of them turned out to be finger licking good. I would highly recommend the Tandoori sampler, the Butter Chicken, and the Chili Thyme Naan. 
Overall, this is by far one of the best indian restaurants I've visited in the Bay area, and I do intend on going back for some delicious Indian food.
author: Harsh Deep Singh N.

description: I had the butter chicken, basmati rice and an order of roti and everything was really good. Glad this place stays open late. It's always really busy when I walk by and tonight at 9:30 on a Monday was no exception. Happy I stopped in tonight. The people were friendly and the space really nice.
author: Debra R.

description: Wow wow wow , everything was epic!!!!!! We are deaming about this place ! Had 5 in our party and everyone was memorized by the tastes!
author: David U.

description: Great Indian Food! A bit pricey, but the Ambience is very fitting, it carries the palette of rich and exotic flavors and definitely one to try if you are in town. However it is recommended to get reservation in advance because there is always waiting.
author: Shivani K.

description:
Very authentic taste of India. It was my first time trying Indian in San Francisco and Amber didn't disappoint me. 
Huge variety for vegetarians and the buffet lunch is delicious,with a lot of sweets :)
author: Astha S.

description:
I went back for dinner and the food was still good but the service slid down a notch.

Owners, please train the ladies at the front door better.  Both of them.  For all shifts.  Each time I've been there one of the two ladies flat out ignores people who walk in.  Aren't they the hostess?  Plus the ignoring one has an attitude of utter disdain.  Too bad you feel we're troubling you chica, it IS your job after all.  

I discovered they have Vinho Verde (a Portuguese white wine). Which I love and it went well with the dinner I had but it was just strange to see it in an Indian restaurant.  Maybe I'm just being a Portuguese purist.  It was chilled to perfection and I was glad to have that with my dinner.

I'm not sure if I'd choose to go back to Amber India.  After two meals and at least 9 total dishes shared and leftovers eaten the next day+ (serious, I went there with some big eaters), it's OK but not something I'll crave.
author: Asa R.

description: Wonderful food ruined by terrible delivery. Doordash sent a bicycle to deliver our food. It arrived crushed and tepid. Reheated the food was great but it felt like I was eating leftovers instead of freshly prepared Indian food. Won't be ordering from Amber India until they choose a more professional delivery service.
author: Kevin P.

description:
Been here a couple of times. The food selection is excellent. They have a broad variety of Indian dishes and they are all very tasty. The pace of the meal is also excellent. The place gets more crowded as the evening carries on, so come early. 

If you appreciate Indian food this is the place to try.
author: Henrik C.

description:
Finally had a chance to check out their lunch buffet. All I need to say is butter chicken! That was the best thing in the buffet! The chicken was nice and tender and the sauce was sooo good with the rice and nan! Yum!

The rest of the dishes were okay. I don't eat a lot of Indian food, but I normally like my food spicy and everything in the buffet was rather mild. The buffet does have a variety of food, but for $17.95 I was expecting a little more. Maybe I've been to too many Vegas buffets?

My one complaint was the amount of time I had to wait in line for the buffet. The line went all the way back to the bathrooms. I kinda wished it was spread out a little more so it wasn't solely dependant on a single file line. During a lunch rush, the line can get long.
author: Elena N.

description: Amazing! I've eaten Indian food across the UK, U.S. and several other countries.  This is some of the best. The lunch buffet dishes are fresh, well-seasoned/spiced and so tasty.  The tandoori chicken is moist and rich. The butter chicken has depth of flavor and is the best I've had. I'm in heaven.
author: FoodGirl G.

description:
I was introduced to Amber many years ago, but never got around to writing a review. First tip, get a reservation. It'll make your life easier, even if you decide that you're going later that day. 

Ambience:
Ambient lighting with nice linens. I'd put this as fine dining. People here are usually fidi types or at least nice, but not formal. Classy. Although we did come here a few years ago with our Halloween costumes and they didn't turn us away.

Food: 
I've gotten their lunch buffet, which all of it is flavorful and wonderfully spiced. Their prices are fair for what you're getting, which are high quality dishes.

As far as dinner, I've ordered the scallops prepared in a number of ways depending on the season. They're all excellent. Seared and soft, but not chewy, they're cooked to perfection. I always get two orders of papad because I love them. (Even though they have three pieces per order, I manage to devour then all.) 

The sampler tandoori platter is also delicious, but the meat was drier than my personal tastes. The spices totally make up for the dryness to a point. I'm more of a rare steak kinda gal, so take that recommendation however you like. 

We always get the cauliflower bezule because it's vegan. Don't let that fool you - it's delicious. We even ate the dried candied orange and was inspired to make our own from the dehydrator, but I digress.

The okra with dried mango powder is also wonderful for vegans and omnivores alike. It's not slimy, but retains the okra flavor. The dried mango powder is impressive and well spiced. 

The jalapeno dish is always wonderful and spicy if you're into that. The eggplant isn't mushy and it's a whole Indian eggplant, roasted. It's delicious. I've also tried various lamb dishes here and if you like lamb definitely give it a go.

The drinks are unique and their mocktails -Amber blush- would also be recommended.

Service:
The times I've been here I'd say the service is on the slower side, but on par with other fine dining with a more relaxed atmosphere. Though oftentimes we've found ourselves struggling to find someone to grab the check. That's my only qualm about this place.

All in all great food, quiet ambience, great date place if you're willing to drop some dough.
author: Amy N.

description:
Delightful find & great choice for a pre-movie dinner!

Food isn't spicy at all - but there's a ton of flavor!

Started out w/ the Bellato - strawberries & Prosecco - need I say more except it was just a bit sweet but not overly so.  Perfection in a flute!

We chose the following & had countless meals to enjoy afterwards....but leftovers are the only way to go when you're dealing w/ such delicious choices

Mushroom & Goat Cheese "fritter" - this was like an Indian version of fried mozzarella sticks & came w/ a creamy tikki tomato sauce for dipping - nice spice mixture w/ this was flavorful spicy, not heat-spicy

Mung Bean salad - prob our least favorite - kind of dry salad of mung beans & herbs

Kofta - dried apricots wrapped in a fried dumpling & smothered in a Mali-Kofta-like sauce.  This dish was actually on the sweet side & I imagine it was from the apricots & cheese....maybe if they'd countered the sweet w/ some spicy heat, it would have been a nice contrast.  Still we liked the dish a lot

Mushrooms & Peas - the kofta was nicely balanced out w/ this more savory dish - these huge, English pea pods were wonderfully tender & covered in a thick tomato sauce that was just a bit on the spicy side (yay!).  The mushrooms were thickly sliced but tender & not at all slimy which can be the tendency when stewing up shrooms

Rice for the pea dish - very, very small serving!  You'll prob want to get multiple orders to soak up all the sauce that comes w/ your entree

Assorted Breads - we liked the Naan w/ Peas best but each had their own texture & made great tools for scooping up all the Kofta sauce

WAY too full for dessert & a ginormous bag of take home & we waddled out of there happy
author: Adrienne G.

description: Food , service and ambience , are excellent . The Palak chat as an appetizer is unique and seems healthy compared with the rich main courses . Black pepper chicken was good and so was the black daal . I think this may be the best  North Indian restaurant in the Bay Area
author: Vin M.

description: Love this place. Often go here for the lunch buffet with colleagues -they can accommodate large parties. Have been for dinner a few times but for the price the lunch buffet is the best deal.
author: Anastasia J.

description:
A great location for out of town visitors. This elegant Indian restaurant is in a unique spot with the multi-story layout right off market and south of Union Square. 
The blah..they don't make very good drinks out of the downstairs bar. It is more like an experiment. 
The great..the food. The preparation and the higher quality ingredients make a huge difference. If all you know about Indian food is the bacteria-laden buffets then you are in for a pleasant surprise. The lamb vindaloo was incredibly tender and the sauce not overpowering. 
Chicken tikka and the veggie choices are delicious and a must. 
The rice was pretty standard with not special kick and the naan was a little overcooked, but once you dipped it in the sauces that problem melted away. 
Be prepared to wait if you don't have rez, but for once it's worth the wait. 
Fully expect to be paying steakhouse prices for your meal. It's worth it. 
This review is based on multiple visits.
author: David B.

description:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about. It's uber expensive and not that great. I read a review written by Brown guy who said it was the best butter chicken he's bad outside of India and had super high expectations. However what came out was less than ordinary.

The tandori paneer was surprisingly good though! I do recommend that. We also had the ferry market veg curry, chicken biriyani, okra dish and they were all just so so. The biriyani is cool. I would order it just to see how they bring it out
author: Karmen K.

description: I'm a business traveller so I eat out every week.  I love to try new places wherever I go, but this is one place I keep coming back to. Last time I was in SF I had dinner here two consecutive nights...and here I am again.  Great food, delish flavor, generous portions, friendly staff.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Living in SF for 11 years now, my go-to fave Indian restaurant has always been Dosa. BUT, after trying dinner at Amber, I think they're my new main squeeze! The Kashmiri Roganjosh left me speechless. The lamb was so perfectly flavored and spiced, and the meat was tender and juicy. I could eat it everyday. The Murg Kalimirch was also another favorite. 
The service was a little slow to begin with but got better as the night went on. The ambiance is great, but the lights are very dim, so not the best for taking selfies, or pics without a flash.
Amber is also on the pricier side, but the deliciousness and good portion size of the dishes are well worth it, in my opinion. I'll definitely be going back for more and more. Excited to try the lunch buffet too.
author: Apeksha A.

description:
The review is based on the fact that I have no idea what the cost of my meal was, since it was paid through work.  I assume it's more expensive than my neighborhood Indian lunch buffet, judging from the restaurant ambiance.  It's surprising that I had never been here before, considering the convenient location, and good reviews it gets.  

Food was very good and comes in a nice variety, including a very tasty and moist fish, a number of chicken dishes, lamb curry, and paneers.  It even features seasonal vegetable like asparagus (so now you can stop feeling guilty stuffing butter chicken down your throat.)

Most dishes are very mild; seems like a good place to accommodate a large group with various tastes and preferences.
author: Candice B.

description: I ordered paneer tikka told wanted gravy based.  Got a dry paneer tikka, asked them that's not what I wanted, so first they said they would replace instead they gave paneer kadhi.  Paid $27 for one dish and naan.  Really disappointed with service and food.
author: Victor D.

description: Amber India's buffet is great, but on this occasion, they forgot about service.  Bussing was good, but drinks or coffee were slow or missing.
author: Bob S.

description: We went last night for dinner and we sit on the bar , very poor service very poor quality of food I don't know why they have a high reviews on Yelp but for me one star is enough . Poor poor poor poor poor service
author: Michele B.

description:
Had appetizer calamari- could taste fire oven. Spiced warmly.
The. Had the kofta with naan. Very flavorful and fluffy. I was worried the kofta was dry, but it was deceptively moist. Haha
author: Kelsey A.

description:
High-end Indian food isn't easy to come across anywhere, but Amber adds a fusion element that makes it work. Overall, the food was great, but I don't think it was necessarily worth the prices that were almost double the price of regular Indian restaurants. 

From what we ordered, the butter chicken was my favorite. It was nicely flavored, and came with a good amount of tender meat. The sea bass was cooked really well, and came on a bed of vegetables. The dish was enjoyable, but with the cream sauce it didn't seem like Indian food at all! We also tried the quinoa vegetable dumplings. This was definitely a unique find on an Indian menu, and I loved the hearty texture of the dumplings. Both the roti and the naan were good, but nothing really set it apart from what I've had at other flavors. The naan did have that crunchy and chewy texture that I love though!

I'm not sure I would come back just because the food didn't necessitate spending double the amount. However, the food was quality and the meal was enjoyable overall!
author: Ashley T.

description:
This is a lunch buffet review!

OK the food is tasty - no doubt - a bit on the pricey side for a lunch buffet at $18.  What throws me is the just mad house nature of the buffet line - people cut in line, go in the opposite direction, press there belt buckle up to your back - I'm guessing this is what it feels like to get on a train at rush hour in Mumbai.  So if you want that just jostled experience for a buffet lunch you've come to the right place.
author: Steve C.

description:
Amber is not the kind of place where you would find Bollywood movie posters plastered all over the walls nor kaleidoscopic windows in rainbow colors nor waitresses in saris and red bindis on their foreheads. Oh no, this is the kind of place that caters directly to the clientele who stays at the Four Seasons across Yerba Buena Lane. The Indian decor appears more like a throwback to the days of British colonialism with everything quite whitewashed and tastefully appointed. So given the circumstances, imagine my and Jamie W.'s surprise when we discovered the food to be quite good and flavorful. 

But it ain't cheap. We started with the $11.95 Duck Tinka Kebab, three skewers of succulent duck breast, pan-fried and marinated in yogurt and red chilies (see photo). It came with a creamy, saffron-infused dipping sauce with dill and capers, but honestly, the duck was so good it didn't need the sauce. Next came the $22.95 Awadhi Lamb Biryani, which actually looked like a big chicken pot pie when it came out and turned into quite a production. Crack the biscuit-like shell on top, and there is a hefty amount of basmati rice with a generous amount of lamb chunks flavored with saffron and rose water (see photo). Delicious and hearty enough to share easily as an entree. 

However, we knew we couldn't pass up the house specialty, the $19.95 Butter Chicken, which was quite a pot of rich, tomato-based sauce filled with shards of tender Tandoori chicken breast (see photo). The texture was velvety smooth but with a nice kick of spices and quite an ideal complement to the lamb biryani. As if that wasn't enough, we also ordered a simple basket of the comparatively inexpensive $3.25 Tandoori Naan, no-frills but perfectly baked. We were both sated and tapped out because it turned into quite a bit of do-re-mi when the bill came. This is definitely the socioeconomic opposite of a place like Chutney in the Tenderloin.

FOOD - 4 stars...elegant Indian food, plentiful portions but plenty of ka-ching for the Four Seasons crowd 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...colonial India, bit sterile...seems to attract amorous couples with its mood lighting 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...polite and unobtrusive, a bit stiff 
TOTAL - 4 stars...a bit of pip-pip in their Indian cuisine
author: Ed U.

description: We went here for a dinner after the Giants game. The food was excellent with just the right amount of spice for the kids and the naan and Parathas were perfect. The service was quick without compromising on the quality of the food. They seated us without a reservation and also changed the order without any fuss when we wanted to switch dishes. Great experience. Yum!
author: Savinay B.

description:
I have been here 3 times now, sat in the bar area 2x and dining room 1x, and my impression is pretty consistent - good cocktails, good food, cool decor, and good service.

The dining area is surprisingly large and somewhat roomy feeling.  It looks small from the window and door, but it opens up a bit as you go in.

The bar area on the other hand is fairly small.  It can get fairly crowded in there and the bumping elbows may case a spill or two if drinking easy to spill drinks like a martini.

If you are looking for "old school traditional" Indian Cuisine, you might be in the wrong place.  As most slightly upscale places in the area, they put the "San Francisco flare" on the dishes.  

IMHO, the dishes I have tried are pretty good - both the main menu and the bar menu.  enough spice and flavor - and the dishes that they warned were hot were hot (even for those of us that like spicy food.

The cocktails were well made and the beer and wine list, while small, has a good selection.

Prices are a touch high to make this a regular place, but in line with the other places in the area (such as Press Club).
author: Jeff H.

description:
Excellent Indian authentic foods ,, 
Great staff, service ,,,, 
Descent place ,,,
Highly recommended
author: Omar A.

description:
Tips
- Weekend lunch buffet ($24) was decent. The included mimosa was made of mango juice and you could ask for mango juice instead. Any other drink will be extra.

Positive
- Butter chicken was good. Goat curry was very good the first time but got tougher after they restocked it.
- Nann was soft and puffy.

Negative:
- No seafood on the day I tried it which was disappointing.
- Fruit selection was very limited for a buffet.

Service was generally good except for the male manager who looked right and a little rude.
author: Ashley K.

description: Food here is outstanding. I have eaten here numerous time. The butter chicken, tandoori, Naan, Indian pizza and aloo gobi are a few of my favorites. They have a great happy hour and a full bar which is nice. The seating is a little challenging, but overall it is a phenomenal place to dine.
author: Chris G.

description:
It's been almost two months since I visited Amber with my brother, world traveler extraordinaire.  Two months later I realize that I really have to write a review. 
The food was really good - not at all the usual buffet where a lot of the items taste very much the same. Lots of different tastes and textures.  Lots of Indian restaurants tend to use way too much oil in their dishes, and we often leave disappointed because our meat was floating in a good half inch of fat.  Not so at Amber. Cosy atmosphere:  just a tad sleek but with a nice warmth to it. 
And now for the clincher:  our waiter, Prem, was outstanding!  Personable, friendly and attentive.  Great personality all around + he was always there right when we needed him!  Prem is the sole reason I give Amber 5 stars instead of 4. The world traveler extraordinaire agreed with me: Prem is a waiter extraordinaire, and we will definitely be back!
author: Nette R.

description: Surprisingly shocked by the great food.  It was crowded so I sat in the bar.  Service was perfect but the food blew me away.   Having visited India twice I was skeptical but they surpassed my picky vegetarian eating habits.  I'd have no problem going back to eat here.   Looking forward to the next visit.
author: D S.

description: Very disappointing, rude manager , very very bad service , racist environment ,the worst experience ever on my life , save your time to enjoy another restaurant better than this .
author: Layla A.

description: Good Ambience. If you are looking for tasty/authentic Indian restaurant don't opt this place.
author: Vinay E.

description:
We went on a Sunday afternoon and decided to have the lunch buffet. The food was good and better than most other Indian places we tried in SFO. The place was a little crowded probably due to the weekend. It was a little hard to reach if you follow google maps you might end up at the back of the restaurant, you need to enter from market street.
The breads came when we were nearly done with the food and the waiter also forgot to get us the tea we had ordered. He made up for it by not charging us for it and overall the quality of the food made up for all of this. (The eggplant curry was great and the desserts were really good as well)
author: S R.

description: Me and my friends came here for the lunch buffet today. Everyone likes it a lot. The service is good and the environment is also really nice. For this price in SF, it's a not bad deal. We will come back again.
author: Vickie M.

description:
The only reason I am taking time and writing review for this place is because me and my friend got sick after eating here. Like really sick - food poisoning kind of sick!! My friend was visiting for a business trip and he had to take off two days because of sickness! Some Indian places are notorious for upsetting your tummy, but I did not expect that from this restaurant after looking at all the good reviews. The taste of the food was really good, but it costed us our health. :(

I am never ever going to this restaurant again! Sorry guys just good ambience, good service and taste doesn't make it a good restaurant. Make sure you serve healthy food not tasty crap that makes people sick! I would have been better off going to McDonalds I think.
author: Latha D.

description: Best Indian restaurant in San Francisco. I have been there twice for dinner and had a great time. Food is excellent. I love their Kadhai paneer. Wait can be up to an hour even on weekdays. Ambience is very classy. I would love to go back for their lunch buffet.
author: Ritika K.

description: Very different take on Indian food. There is touch of Mughlai cuisine to the food here, but not your stereotypical heavy on cream and oil stuff. Instead, you have carefully chosen spices, combined with nicely crafted sauces that include nuts (cashews, mostly), resulting in a flavorful medley. Very different from typical Indian restaurant fair. The basmati rice is average, though.
author: S D.

description: I have been to this restaurant during weekdays for their lunch buffet and I liked it as they had good varieties including briyani for $16.99. Today (4/3, Sunday) I decided to go there to lunch buffet, the menu was not that great compared to those they used to have during weekdays. They did not have briyani but white rice.
