They charged me $24.99. Bill showed weekend special buffet. I do not believe it is worth to spend $24.99 for an ordinary food. Being an Indian and knowing what an Indian foods taste like I can definitely tell $24.99 for lunch buffet is too expensive. I am sure they will have people coming there for weekend buffet and get surprised when they see the bill. But please do mind those people who come there to San Francisco down town are mostly tourists and already would have paid a lot on everything else so I am not sure why they would charge $24.99 for lunch. Think about me I paid $24.99 x 2 and $7 for parking!. I would rather next time drive to Sunnyvale for lunch buffet. This is just my experience and me!.
author: Devan K.

description:
Meh. Upscale Indian. I've had better. 

I'd take Cafe Chaat down the street.
author: Dimple B.

description:
One of the best things about SF is the fact that you can find good food within a few blocks no matter where you're at. Case in point, our group was getting hungry after HH and a friend suggested Amber. Indian food? I'm down!! 

Awesome place in the financial district / SoMa that's near all the lounges and bars. We really just wanted to snack on some naan  & curry so we decided to hang in the lounge/bar where they have a full menu. The bar overlooks the street and hosts a few tables with couches along the wall that you can hang out as a group.  It's dimly lit and makes for a great ambiance. The server was helpful in suggesting a few favorites and was accommodating to our needs. 

Nalli Vindaloo - Tender braised lamb shank with garlic. Doesn't have a gamey taste at all and the sauce is the perfect blend of spice and curry. Hit the spot and was a pretty large portion! 

Butter Chicken - By far, one of the best butter chicken dishes I've had! The sauce had a smooth and creamy texture with shredded tandoori chicken. It is a MUST order when coming here. Don't skip this one! 

Definitely keeping this place in my back pocket when we're craving Indian food.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Great experience, Great food, Great Location, Great Ambience.

Ever since moving from Berkeley, I haven't had great Indian food in LA.  In my return to the Bay Area, I always heard of Amber India, which is tucked away next to a Coffee Bean on Market, and decided I had to try it!

I was not disappointed.  First of all, the restaurant is larger than it seems on the inside.  It's got a romantic feel and an awesome looking bar while you wait for your food.  

Now onto the best part...the FOOD.   We ordered the BUTTER CHICKEN, SEA BASS CURRY, GARLIC NAAN, ROTI, BASMATI RICE, and the CAULIFLOWER appetizer.

The curries were amazing.  The BUTTER CHICKEN had a great flavor, and is definitely a dish you should order if you want to play it on the safer side.  It's mildly spicy (just a kick) and is similar to Chicken Tikka Masala, if not identical. 

The SEA BASS CURRY....if you like fish, GET IT.  The Sea bass melts in your mouth and the curry is a great complement.  This curry is 100% mild with no kick at all, so it's a great, smooth curry for your meal.

The NAAN and ROTI were amazing as well, and you can't go wrong with BASMATI RICE.

The CAULIFLOWER appetizer is great...around 8 pieces with a coconut milk sauce and I believe it's fried.


For DRINKS...try the MANGO MOJITO (non-alcoholic).  it's a great mix of a Mango Lassi and a Mojito.
author: Patrick L.

description:
My family and I went in on Saturday 11/28/15 at around 9:30pm  We ordered only 3 main dishes  as my wife was not hungry. I ordered kebeab (minced lamb with spices)  for myself plus  chicken and Sea bass, rice and naan breads for the rest of us. Ok my order came in as four small sausages it was absolutely horrible, Was frozen half way and seemed like they just put  in the microwave for few seconds just to warm it up I took one bite and I HAD TO SPIT OUT  it was the worst by far than anything I have ever tasted by the way this specific order had  a funny smell. I'm a co owner of 2well established  restaurants  in the bay area I know what good well prepared meal made to order looks and smells like  I forgot to mention that  our food arrived in less than 3 minutes from the times the waitress took the order 
NOT HAPPY AS NO ONE CAME TO CHECK ON US AND AT LEAST APOLOGIZE.
author: Martin G.

description:
Simple tasty home-cooked-feel food.

We ordered the rice and Dal makhani - which was just perfectly seasoned and flavored. My mom approves - which is saying quite a bit :)
author: Akshaya M.

description:
After attempting to find parking in the Mission area only to find the restaurant we wanted to dine at was closed and driving around downtown SF looking for parking for the second time...it was two hours later and we needed a third option because our second choice already had last call.  Amber India is still open for another 40 minutes, yay!  

We didn't have to wait because there was plenty of seating available, but the restaurant was still decently full.  The ambiance was fancy, which was ideal for how we were dressed.  The server came by soon after we were seated to take our order.  My friend suggested the Duck Tinka Kebabs and Nalli (Lamb) Vindaloo with Saffron Rice.  I had to have an order of Garlic-Chive Naan.  I questioned her if that was enough because we were starving...when it all came out, it was definitely more than enough.  There were three skewers of kebabs--the duck was moist and tasty.   The lamb came in this large, elongated bowl and it was a whole leg bone with tender meat hanging from it.  I felt like the Vindaloo could have been more complex in flavor but it had a good amount of heat.  An appetizer and entree is plenty for two.  We attempted to finished everything but couldn't, it was too filling.

They were very accommodating last minute and service was great--very efficient and fast at taking orders to getting food on the table and bring the bill.  I would dine here again and I like that they have multiple locations in the Bay Area.
author: Hayden N.

description:
Honestly, the food was mediocre. The only difference here and other places is there was white meat chicken tandoori (I prefer dark meat). All the sauces were way more sweeter than I'm used to in Indian food. 

I'm giving one star because I can't leave 0!stars. I visited this place because it was close and had a ready buffet. My partner and I were looking for a quick lunch on a work day. We were seated and waited for 20 minutes. No waiter. we realized maybe we just go to buffet. My partner got a phone call from work and stepped outside. He told me to go ahead and start eating without him. 
    He never came back as he had to go back into work due to an emergency. I just went up and got a plate. The waiter finally came by and brought water and some naan after I had a plate. Never saw the waiter after that. I ate a then waited for awhile trying to get the waiters attention for the bill. When I did, the manager or owner came up with the bill. When I opened it, I saw they had billed me for two. The owner/ manager was extremely rude.  If I ever had a waiter even talk to me about the restaurant I would have explained that my friend had left and hadn't eaten as evidenced but the unused table placement next to me. I apologized and said my friend had left and the owner became very snotty and said he was told two people were sat and needed to pay. I simply told him no and was going to ask the people sitting next my table to verify that is ate by myself during the meal. 
  He was very irritated and said if he knew there was only one person, he would have sat me at a smaller table. We came in at 2:15, the end of lunch. I couldn't help but notice many empty tables around the restaurant as he this to me. 
   I was professional waiter for about 7 years. This is the first time I never left a tip. There are much better places to eat for cheaper but with friendlier staff. I don't need to pay 22$ for a buffet that I can get just same quality in at least three other places in the city that charge half as much. Not endorsing this place at all. It's nicely decorated though....
author: Donnie N.

description: This is my new favorite Indian restaurant in the city. Everything we tried was perfect! I've never been able to say that about an Indian restaurant before. Perfection in every way. Our Indian friends agree, too.
author: Jared M.

description: I had the worst experience in this restaurant.  The manager was so rude and racist and he judged is based on our country. My first card was declined but my brother's card worked. Then I gave the server another card and he charged the whole amount on my card. I wanted to speak with the manager and when he came he thought that I didn't want to buy and he said "go back to your country you are not welcome here" and "I know people like you" . Just because I wanted to speak to him and explain that my card was changed the full amount and my brother card was changed also, he assumed that I didn't want to buy and he kicked us outside although it was the severe mistake. I felt embarrassed and humiliated and I wanted to explain but he wouldn't give a chance. This is discrimination and I honestly thought about calling the police because I didn't do anything wrong.
author: Maram A.

description:
Great food!  Love Indian food and this was some
Of the best we have had. Butter chicken and Tikka Masala.   Very cool/trendy place, not old school Indian.  Was pricey but worth it.
author: Reesa T.

description:
I finally came back again after 4 years to Amber, this time with my SO.
It was great!

The only hiccup was the initial seating: they took their time seating us, while it seamed like other people, that came after us, were seated before us. Also, the hostesses switched while we were waiting, and the outgoing one forgot to tell the incoming one about us.

On to the food:
We shared a Crisp Tofu Tikki ($9.95) as a starter. The tomato curry that arrived with it was really good. The tofu itself was o-k. It crumbled very easily and didn't have a distinctive flavor.
For mains, we shared a Nalli Vindaloo ($29.95) and a Saag Paneer ($18.95).
Both were excellent. The lamb shank was tender, and its curry sauce was very good. We were warned that the dish is spicy (the water bearer said that "we will need a lot of water") - it wasn't that hot. The dish is large.
As for the Saag Paneer: it had a nice consistency and very flavorful cheese and spinach. The portion was smaller than the lamb shank - but it still more than satisfied the both of us.
For dessert, we shared a Gulab Jamun - two milk dumplings in sugar syrup. Refreshing.
author: Omer G.

description:
I'm disappointed to write this review. Having visited once with a colleague and enjoying appetizers in the bar, I was excited about going back.  I did so Wednesday of this week, this time by myself.  

It was around 7 PM and despite a couple of people behind the bar, three at the maître d stand and only 10-12 customers in the bar area, I never got served.  Meaning never even got the acknowledgement that I was in the lounge.  After waiting 10 minutes I got up and asked for a menu as I was giving the bartenders the benefit of the doubt.  But after serving a small group their drinks, no waiter, bartender, manager, NOBODY so much as said "I'll be right there, here's a glass of water."  I politely set the menu on the table and left.  I refuse to spend my money anywhere I feel unwanted.
author: Reg T.

description:
Flash fried spinach was delicious. Sauces are flavorful but I didn't really enjoy what I had to order. The menu is filled with great eats and I was with my teacher who was into flavor packed foods that I couldn't enjoy without something plain to accomadate. Food was flavorful.


But my three stars instead of four is for the awkward snobby waitress who gave me weird looks for eating with someone who was my PROFESSOR trying to prep me and coach me for my internship. So thanks to her she made it awkward sending over someone additionally to talk to us for no immediate reason. And thennnnn starts whispering and pointing at us and laughing between you two ginormous Amazonian ugly women. You work as waitresses. Wtf do you have to say about other people who are your customers to make you feel better. We pay you some lame tip so you can survive wearing your ugly loafers everyday that probably stink like garbage and your attitude. So stfu! :D 

Anyways..
author: April W.

description:
I was genuinely surprised with the food at Amber India. 
Got the Malabari Shrimp and it was one of the best shrimp dishes I've had.
Try the Butter Chicken as well. Its absolutely divine.
author: Ashwin S.

description:
Amber India is the perfect little date spot that can be dressed up or down depending on how romantic you want it to be. That is to say, you'll feel comfortable whether you're wearing jeans or a dress.

The menu offers fun creations that aren't found in typical, middle-of-the-road Indian restaurants, but I found the prices a tad high even with all that creativity. My friend and I split the English Peas Portobello Goat Cheese Tikki to start. It was quite tasty: croquette-like things stuffed with portobello mushrooms, crimini, English peas and goat cheese, served with a creamy tomato-flavored dipping sauce. We then split an order of the Butter Chicken, which is supposedly their signature item. Now, I know BC is about as generic as you can get for Indian food, but we both had a craving for it and decided why not? We could always come back and try something else. The dish was okay but a bit too sweet for my liking. The chicken was tender though, and they gave us a ton of rice.

I'd had a really crazy day at work, so I decided to treat myself to a cocktail too. I ordered the Cucumber Citrus Martini, except I don't like cucumber in cocktails, so I asked that the bartender substitute red berry vodka instead. It was good (but not great) and came in a very large glass which, for the price of $11, felt like a good deal.

While I wasn't blown away by the food, I was really impressed by the service. Everyone was friendly and attentive, and our waitress seemed genuinely eager to please us. The restaurant is lovely with dark, understated colors and strategic lighting.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Not an authentic indian food.. Do not get deceived by the number of ratings. 

Misleading menu on Yelp.. 

Not worth the price, for the taste! 

Today five of my friends went to have early dinner after the Air Show. The experience was terrible. The reception guy has no sense of welcoming. The chef has no idea what a spicy food! 

Adding chili powder to Biryani doesn't make it spicier. A chicken curry with out salt and more chili powder I'm not sure what to call it. 

The overall effect is we had our stomach upset. 

BEWARE BEFORE YOU DECIDE TO GOTO THIS RESTAURENT.
author: Kranthi K.

description: Service was excellent. Food is good but I would not say it is excellent. Try it yourself and see if you agree to a 3 star
author: Tiff L.

description:
Indian friends told us they rank this place at the very top of restaurants in the SF Bay Area.  While I'm not sure I'd agree with that, it is without doubt the best Indian food I've ever been served anywhere!

Decent portions (important as there were three of us sharing), wonderful flavors, just the right degree of heat in the lamb shank vindaloo (Nalli Vindaloo). We liked the signature dish, too -- Amber Butter Chicken. The surprise was the Cauliflower Bezule -- fabulous taste and texture. 

I'm looking for a reason to take some friends and really dig into the menu more, as I didn't have either their tandoori or shrimp dishes.
author: Terry V.

description: I loved everything about this restaurant. The atmosphere was lovely which many Indian restaurants seem to lack. The food and service were both exceptional! I also loved the cocktails. Would definitely come back next time I'm in SF.
author: Alisha M.

description: I am a huge fan of buffet and found that Amber has a good selection of buffet menu options along with authentic indian quality food at a reasonable price (especially in San Francisco)
author: Naveen N.

description: One of the best places to eat Indian food, impeccable quality, extraordinary service. This is as close as you can get to real authentic Indian food fine dine experience, the 'Chaats' inspired from the street food of Bombay city are truly mesmerizing and you can have them daily on all weekdays at the Bar too! The ambience of this place is out of the world, by far one of the 'must go to' venue in San Francisco. The location is 30 seconds walk from Marriott Marquis Hotel.
author: Mike P.

description: The pineapple salmon skewer has amazing flavor. I wish there was more on the skewer because it taste so good (only 3 pieces per skewer and two skewers per dish)!
author: Naomi D.

description: Quite possibly the best Indian food we have ever had. The cauliflower appetizer was insanely good!!! Butter chicken is a must.
author: Zak G.

description:
The weekend brunch is the best Indian buffet food, and the bottomless mimosas are a nice touch.  

They also catered our wedding, and it went perfectly!  More than half our guests came up to us independently to say how amazing the food was, and they were 100% right!
author: Sara B.

description: The food is amazing, we were in a rush because we needed to get to the Golden Gate theatre and traffic was hurrendous, they were accomodating even though our time to get there changed 3 times.  But the best part is the food, we want to go back and try it again.  You won't regret this experience.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Roti - eh..had better, not crunchy or tasty..quite dry
Brown rice - not bad, not flavored, it's just plain rice..I'd prefer this over the roti
Pind Da Murg - sauce is on the sweeter side..you get a few pieces of boneless skinless chicken
Dum ka Murg - Two breast wings but is skinless..the sauce is more earthy and nutty, and has a more of a spice than the Pind Da Murg

Overall service and wait time, not bad knowing we didn't make a reservation. Very ambient and the food wasn't bad. I think it's quite pricy for the portion, but we did finish everything.
author: Minerva L.

description:
Indian food is my favorite and sadly, I can't get it where I live which means I crave it all the time and it is a must-have on every vacation. SF Yelpers have reviewed many Indian restaurants, but I was worried about picking a lackluster one in a sea of options. Luckily, I decided to give Amber India a shot!

Upon arrival, I was impressed by this upscale Indian eatery and I was hoping the food would match the lovely ambiance. I decided to take full advantage of the lunch buffet. I was pleased with the wide variety of delicious options--chicken, fish, vegetarian, desserts. The standout hands down was Amber's Signature Butter Chicken. I pigged out and had thirds. That never happens, but the flavors were so glorious, I. JUST. HAD. TO. INDULGE. The delicious sea bass curry came in at a close second. 

Good, friendly, and hospitable service. The server checked on us several times and the manager stopped by to ask us about our dining experience.

Bottom line: Come to Amber India for a great, flavorful, stellar selection where you will actually WANT to eat everything in the buffet! Warning: Be prepared for a food coma-induced cat nap afterwards.
author: Pamela M.

description:
I have visited Amber multiple times since I wrote this review and the food quality remains unparalleled. I think the only other Indian restaurant in US that beats this restaurant is Rasika in Washington DC.

I had the happy hour menu twice since the original review. The happy hour cocktails were were well made and served - were not sugary or watered down. The happy hour menu was reasonably priced, delicious and of high quality (not some junk that are usually part of happy hour menus).
author: Anshu G.

description: Amber is a terrific choice for an Indian Restaurant in San Francisco. What I like about Amber is that they are unafraid to try modern takes on Indian classics. This makes for an interesting menu that is different from your garden variety Indian restaurant. The dining experience is enhanced by a nice setting and courteous service. Worth a try if you are craving Indian food but have hit your limit of chicken tikka masala!
author: Anirvan G.

description:
Quick service at an affordable happy hour price is A-OK by me.

Came by on busy friday and jumped at the chance to grab a drink here while waiting to get picked up from work. It gave me a chance to sit, sip on a drink and catch up with a friend. 

The drinks were clean, strong, and delicious. 

The place however was a little small and problems gets packed easily. thank goodness we didn't hit any of that.

This lounge offers seating at the bar, tables and walled bench with stools around low tables.

Just a quick drink and we were off. I'll probably be back again.

Until next time.

Cheers!
author: Jerico P.

description:
I wonder why this place has four star.It is definitely not a four star material in terms of food, can be in terms of ambience. 
Tried Amber India for lunch. Whether it was matar paneer or chicken curry, food tasted just average and service was ok. I have not tried other Indian restaurants in the nearby area. There might be a probability that they are worse and so this place is preferred.

I will suggest do not go with much expectations in terms of food. If you like it you will be happy, but if it is bad you wont feel sad !
author: Priyam M.

description:
Fancy Indian buffet? Yup, they got that.

Bottomless mimosas with brunch? Yup, they got that too.

A cook bar makes the trifecta.

Protip: get a second stomach.
author: James G.

description:
Excellent food, great service. Walking past makes your mouth water, and you won't be disappointed when you go inside! 

Went twice during our weekend in SF, both loung bar and restaurant serve the full menu.
author: Janny S.

description:
The food and service are very good, as they should be when you drop $150 for two kids and one adult.

The portions of rice and naan are insultingly small and it is a nuisance to have to keep ordering more of these basics every 5-10 minutes.

Otherwise no complaints although I cannot afford to ever eat here again. Three stars because it is so overpriced.
author: Tom P.

description: Let's start with the food which was exceptional. I absolutely love Indian food and have eaten from many places with kind of a mixed outcome. Sometimes food has little flavor or not enough spice but I must say that I truly enjoyed this place. The food was spot on. You also get complimentary naan which I usually don't see in restaurants in ny. They were very attentive and pleasant thanking us for dining there. I will definitely return!
author: Jeannie D.

description:
Good food. 
I've had a lot of Indian Food - not that I'm an expert - and I really like it. 
This place was quite good, but a tad on the spendy side. 
Atmosphere is decent, reasonably nice/reasonable noise level. 
Definitely would eat here again if i have opportunity.
author: Joe H.

description: We made a reservation, but when we arrived, the manager told us that the restaurant does not accept babies with strollers, and that they already refused two customers earlier this evening for the same reason (!!!?!). My baby is 3 month old and is too small for a child chair... After I insisted, because one of our friends came especially from far away and already parked his car nearby, we got a table. The service was very good, the food was ok, the saag paneer was good and the naan too, but I already had a bitter taste from the start because of this ''baby incident''...
author: Stav W.

description: Nice place, at the heart of San Fransisco, tasty food. A little pricey and only lamb is halal.
author: Amal E.

description:
A great Happy Hour spot in downtown! The restaurant itself is an elegant space with a beautiful ambiance. The bar area is more of the same albeit a bit small-ish, but it still works. Get there relatively early to secure a spot.

Drinks were priced between $4-$7, and a selection of about 5-6 small appetizer bites for $5. Good deal if you ask me!
author: Mansi A.

description: The food is terrific any day of the week, but is even better at night when you have time to savor. We enjoyed the calamari and shrimp appetizers, prepared with fresh seafood.We had garlic naan on top of butter naan, followed by a basket of breads, butter chicken, and basmati rice. Best enjoyed in groups so that you can share the different dishes this restaurant offers.
author: Stacie P.

description: I love Indian food, however it was no better at all than you might get at any other Indian place. At Amber you are going to pay three times the price for what amounts to a neat atmosphere with its multilevel dining and colorful lighting and a better trained wait staff. I was seated and inquired about ordering a tikka masala despite it not being on the menu and my server informed me that yes, the chef would be able to do this. Considering the prices and considering that lamb was offered in other dishes, I figured I might be able to order my favorite which is lamb tikka masala. My server informed me however, that for some reason unbeknownst to me that lamb tikka would take longer to prepare and that the chef could only do a chicken tikka masala. "Okay, that will work", I thought. Again, the dish was good and the service was above par but the food was zero better than you would get if you got it at any other Indian restaurant. I left thinking the only negative about the place was their prices but it wasn't long before I started feeling nauseous. That sick feeling kept getting worse and worse as the hours ticked by until I had to jump off the municipal bus at a random stop so that I could throw up. From there, I eventually got back to my hotel where I was thinking maybe a sprite and a water might help. Almost as soon as I had drank about half of each, the water and the sprite, I threw up again. I was able to hold the first heave in my mouth until almost out the door of the hotel but...not quite. The second heave along with the first came shooting out of my mouth and all over the inside of the glass doors of the hotel lobby. The 3rd, 4th, 5th, and 6th heaves left my stomach empty onto the sidewalk in front of my Mason Street hotel. Although I didn't actually throw up again after that, I felt very near to it and I felt quite sick for the next half day or so. I know with out a doubt that it was the food I had at Amber because I had nothing else to eat within any close time period of becoming sick.
author: Matt W.

description:
Can't say enough good things.  My wife had reservations at a California cuisine place, but happened by Amber while getting coffee.  We decided to keep the fancy restaurant for nights in SF.  We decided to try Indian tonight.  What I liked about the menu was that it wasn't like the Indian places by our home.  There were many dishes that looked unique.  

It was so good we came back the next night as well.

Appetizer:  dusted scallops.
Entrees: butter chicken and tandoori sea bass.
Dessert: date and walnut kulfi.

All of these were close to the best dishes I've ever had.

Great service as well.
author: chris a.

description: Hands down best Indian food I've ever had the pleasure of eating. The only problem is now nothing will compare and I will crave it endlessly.
author: Jacqueline R.

description: The brunch buffet has a good selection of food and made to order dosas! Too bad they are not consistent with lamb kebabs - most of the time they don't have it as part of the buffet... bottomless mimosas rock!
author: Aya J.

description: Great food. Great service. Had two particularly good experiences with the waiter/waitress on our most recent visits...so here's a shout out to them! If only I could remember their names :( ...sorry!
author: Kevin S.

description:
first of all, the ambience is AMAZING ! one of the best indian restaurant 
the plating is on the better side as well. 

the butter chicken is among my favorites 
the okra wasn't too good, 
n the kadhai paneer was good but not great.

service is really fast.  

dessert plating was the best! and tasted as it looked.
author: Ruby P.

description: Horrible service!! Rude employees!! Arrived at 5:30pm and asked to be sat at a different table that was not in front of a blocked door with chairs piled up next to it. One of the managers was condescending and discriminatory against us...the restaurant was empty and it could have easily been reseat it. We left - will not support this business!
author: Paolo E.

description: The best Indian food I've had in a while. I had the lunch buffet and they had the nicest spread of salad, appetizers, and snacks! I'm a vegetarian and had quite a few options in vegetarian dishes. Highly recommend!
author: Piyush D.

description:
I love this place. Went last night with co-workers and had a really awesome time.  From the food, wine, and service, I couldn't have been any happier.

Few things we tried and were happy with all:

Cauliflower Bezule 
Aloo Peas Samosa 
Malabari Shrimps (Favorite)
Tandoori Sampler
Calamari Kolivada (Pass on this - meh!)
Jaipuri Bhindi (Yum Yum)
Gulab Jamun

Let's just say the Malabari Shrimp was so amazing I asked for that as my entree.  Spicy!  Amazing!  There isn't anything on the dinner menu like this so the wonderful waiter said he could have an entree made from it!

Delicious!  I am ready to go back already.
author: Sandyann G.

description:
Eggplant was spicy but good 
Excellent service 
Yummy mango lassi 
Basmati rice 


Highlight: naan and the sauces
Downside: Overpriced Indian food. I wouldn't drive all the way to San Francisco to eat here. I can go to San Jose or Fremont for authentic, reasonably priced Indian food!
author: Jenn R.

description:
This place made me fall in love with Indian food. I even tried to cook some Indian dishes at home the next day. 

The butter chicken and the tikka masala are a must. The lamb chop (on the appetizer list) was the bang for the buck. 
I love the ambience. 
We didn't have a reservation, and there was a 1-hour wait for a table, but we sat at the bar area immediately with no problem.
author: Jackie L.

description: Hands down the best Indian for you will ever have!! The best Indian food I ever had was in London and this totally reminds me of that. Anything that we have ordered from there has always been so delicious. Highly recommend.
author: G A.

description:
This is for the lunch buffet:

The food is very heavy and leans too much toward vegetarian items. If I'm paying $16.95, I want more meat!  The experience of getting the food is very chaotic and you will be snaking through a small space, competing with waiters carrying drinks and taking away used plates. The small set of stairs separating the dining from buffet area is a bottleneck.   

A few minutes after the end, I was slaughtered by food coma and could not operate any heavy machinery, ie. my own body.  :-/
author: Miran C.

description:
If you are looking for very authentic, mouth watering, delicious North Indian food and if you don't want your clothes to smell of spices by the time you walk out, then don't look any further - you've come to the right place.

I was amazed by the flavors in each and every dish we ate at this upscale restaurant in the middle of SFO. We ate here twice - first time for dinner and second time for lunch, and each experience was just phenomenal.

I cannot stress enough how authentic and delicious each and every item was, and it was obvious that special care was taken to create such small side items like chutneys, raita etc. Every item on the menu felt very rich, just the way it should be.

Lunch buffet offered some of the traditional North Indian dishes that are not so common in most Indian restaurants, and even if they are common, then it is extremely hard to match the flavors offered at Amber India. For example: tandoori chicken is a fairly common dish, yet most Indian restaurants fail when it comes to executing the recipe to perfection where the chicken is not marinated enough, and/or it has been painted orange. Not at Amber India - here you can enjoy the real flavors.

Even the dessert selection at the lunch buffet was par excellence - not like the usual sweetened-up-stuff just to call it a dessert. Here, they were constantly adding new items to the dessert section and each entry was special and created in absolute authentic manner, delivering the divine taste and abundance of flavors in each bite.
author: Abhi G.

description: Had the butter cream chicken, lamb khori, naan, cauliflower appetizer, and rice. Didn't care for the lamb, but the butter cream chicken and naan bread tasted great. Monica, our waitress, was very sweet and attentive.
author: Sam B.

description: Such fantastic indian foot. Excellent chicken TikaMesalla. Get the most spicy version if you're into spicy foot. Went there twice in two day it was so good. Don't have anything like this in L.A.
author: Alex M.

description:
Indian food is mostly in dingy places like Shalomar or Chutney's in the Tenderloin and damn good...or at high end restaurants that cost three times the price and taste as good as those in the Tenderloin. This place was a great hybrid.

Without droning on and on (who really reads yelp reviews that are more than 3 paragraphs long anyways?), the food was your standard Indian fare and was amazing. The price was reasonable. The ambiance was clean and upscale.

Definitely recommended if you're up for this type of food while shopping in Union Square.
author: Julia P.

description:
AMAZING food! We went here for my dad's birthday, and having been here once before many years ago, we were hoping the food was just as good as we remembered it. We ordered the Amber Butter Chicken, and the Tandoori Sample Platter, and few naan's, among other dishes. The food is expensive, but the flavor and spices of the dishes are very authentic. It's a very popular place in downtown, and so it is very crowded. I HIGHLY suggest booking a reservation a few days in advance, so you don't miss out on getting a table. We had a reservation, and we seated within 5 mins after arriving there. The staff seemed a bit stressed and it felt that there weren't enough staff members to better help the flow. The space was also very crammed, and so waiters and waitresses were running into customers chairs and I could tell a few people were annoyed by it. Even with the space constrictions, the staff seemed to be on top of it, and made sure the food was brought out quick and was presented nicely. For an authentic spicy indian meal, I highly suggest going to check this place out! 

TLDR: Delicious Indian food! Great Service! Very crowded, so book early!
author: Nakul B.

description:
Really loved this place!

Yes it's on the pricier side and it's not the most authentic Indian food there is, but the food is delicious and the service is excellent!

We had the butter chicken - AMAZING! 
The samosas were small but very good!
The lamb was cooked very well and was tender and moist!
The palak chaat was different but tasted delicious

Didn't have any of the traditional Indian drinks so I don't know how good those are, but with the way everything else tasted, I'm sure they are excellent too!

The ambience is very nice..a bit noisy but you can definitely hold your own conversation without a problem hearing one another. The lighting is dim so this is a nice romantic atmosphere if you'd like to go with your significant other. 

Overall, loved it and I will be back!
author: Manjit B.

description:
Amber is rarely found upscale indian restaurant with classy ambience. 

The food is good and authentic. We ordered samosas, mango lassi and butter chicken. Everything was well prepared and authentic. 

I know that this is an upscale restaurant and prices are meant to be higher than normal, I felt they are too pricey almost borderline rip-off. 

However good the food is 21 bucks for a small portion of butter chicken is ridiculous. 

If you want to impress someone with your spending power go for it!
author: Akshay S.

description:
Two words: BUTTER CHICKEN

That is all you need to know. Oh, and that there are real Indian folks eating here so you know it's legit! 

Amber India is not afraid of spices. They have a killer cauliflower appetizer (Cauliflower Bezule) that is highlighted by a spicy mustard sauce. Hot alert! 

Only docking a star because it is buffet-only for lunch. I mean, I don't mind endlessly stuffing my face with their butter chicken but we all know the economics behind buffets: just because it's all-you-can-eat doesn't mean you should. Although the buffet does provide a great opportunity to try an assortment of foods, it is simply too heavy for a lunchtime meal. Who wants to return to work with a food coma? So I don't dig their forced lunch buffets. But that butter chicken though. Bombdotcom.
author: Judy H.

description:
This might the longest, most soulful story-type review I've written on Yelp! and Amber really deserves it not just for the food but for the exceptional customer service. 

+++++
Part I:
Last Friday, I went to Amber to share the experience with a date who wanted to try some good food before watching Gravity at the Metreon.  I mentioned a few restaurants nearby the theaters, including Amber, and it turned out to be one of two spots I could get a reservation at on the Monday before (man, SF is getting tougher to get reservations in!).  I had been to Amber before, and shared with her my experience, which was a four star experience - tasty food, a refined dining atmosphere, and good service.  She was excited. 

We arrived to our reservation a bit late, and the server was great.  She was very attentive and responsive. 
We ordered, and their saag paneer was good, as always.  But with most other dishes, we ended up being not just underwhelmed but 
The cauliflower appetizer arrived at room temperature - no heat. 
The molten chocolate cake - was super dry and had some pieces of plastic in it that I showed to the server after I paid for the check.  We had to get to the movie on time, so I didn't want to spend much time sharing with the server how our experience was not usual for Amber, so I decided to share it the manager the next day to share how things went. 

The following morning I called Amber and asked for the manager.  The phone was handed to Victor, and I shared my experience with him.  He listened carefully, and said he would speak with the chef and get back to me. 
A while later, after some food shopping, I notice I missed a few missed calls from Amber's number.  Speaking with him again, Victor shared with me that he would like to treat me and a guest to dinner - it would be on the house.  I thanked him, and took the offer, hoping that the next dinner would be better.  I made reservations for this past Friday, and I invited my friend Amir who had never been.  

++++++

Part II
Amir and I went for dinner, and it was his first time at Amber.  And it was a good one!  
Our server Sagar was super attentive.  The cauliflower appetizer that they gave us (off the menu!) was awesome.  The four spice sea bass was so tender and tasty, it almost melted.  The Lamb Grogenjosh - my first grogenjosh ever - totally turned me on to this type of dish.  The okra was packed with flavor and spice that balanced out the fattiness of the oils it came in. 
We also had some roti and flaky bread that were spot on.  
At the end of the meal, the manager Victor reminded me that the meal would be on the house.  Matthew - who I think is the assistant manager - came by the table and said he hoped everything was up to par for us.  

Indeed, Matthew, the meal was up to par.  And thank you for making that dinner a great and memorably experience for my and my friend.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I absolutely love Amber! The food is amazing and the ambiance is modern and classy. A great place to bring friends for dinner. I had several entrees off the menu and was thrilled with the presentation and taste. 

This place does get busy and reservations are generally a must!
author: John D.

description:
This was my first time eating Indian food, and I am so glad I got to try it here.  I have nothing to compare it to, but this was a 5-star meal.  Best meal I've had in a long time.  Even my 11-year old loved it.  It was two moms and our two boys, so we shared some apps: samosa, tofu tikki, palak chaat, plus we got the assorted bread basket and the butter chicken.  

Like everyone else, we thought the butter chicken was amazing!  Everything was absolute perfection, but the butter chicken was better than I can explain.  Just try it.  If you are on the fence about trying Indian food, then get the breads and the butter chicken.  That's all you need. Except that all the other stuff was sooooo good, too.
author: sheree f.

description:
Another popular yet worth-the-wait Indian place. Got there on Tuesday night at 8:45 and got really lucky that there was no wait (others had 15 min wait easily). The place has a fun, trendy and dressy vibe. 
I had lentils and naan (was tired after a long day) and it was delicious. Service was prompt and courteous. The cocktails were innovative too. 
Overall - must try for - food, drinks and ambience.
author: Neha M.

description:
Loved this restaurant!!! We were in San Fran for a conference and walked in really early because we were starving. I am sure we wouldn't have dinned here if it was not 5:30 pm on a Friday without a reservation!!!

Ambience: I know the name of the restaurant is Amber, but the amber lights are way too dark for a restaurant. I felt like I could barely see my food. They lost a star for ambience.

Staff: super friendly and honest in their recommendations (I was in doubt between two dishes and the waiter recommended one and had several adjectives for the dish to back up his recommendation).

Food: spices heaven pretty much sums it up!!! Fresh, perfect blend of Indian spices and perfect amount if heat. We had the samosas, the butter chicken and the lamb korma. Highly recommend them all! I could have had three bowls of the butter chicken!
Ah, let's not forget about the pesto naan! Made with fresh basil and EVOO, in enough quantities that you could taste both!!!

Make reservations and get the samosas and butter chicken!
author: Alice G.

description:
Still in Love. Came back a year later and still one of my favorite places. Host was engaged and happy. Waiter was sublime in her service. Water boy kept my glass full. I had a terrible seat, but when ever I eat alone I expect that. 

Had the Samosa as an appetizer. It was perfect. Could have stopped there. I had the Naan bread. I could see in my minds eye someone's mother making and baking it by hand. That alone was worth the trip. Finally, my last meal on earth should be their Butter Chicken. Comes in its own little bowl that you serve onto your plate. They brought me a new knife (mine was picked up with the appetizer) and I realized I didn't really need it the chicken was so tender.

The only weird thing is that there are NO sides with the chicken. I should have ordered rice, though the bread was more than one person could eat so I just went with it.

I had their Bombay Lemonade (called something else). Didn't care for it. It wasn't bad, just not to my tastes. I followed it up with a perfect Gin & tonic. Wonderful place, just never go there when I'm in town (and you better have reservations).
author: Robert M.

description:
So are the people of downtown San Francisco not well-versed in Indian food, or did the pretty mood lighting and mini staircases impair tastebuds? I've been meaning to try Amber for a while, so my coworker made a Friday lunchtime reservation. The restaurant filled up pretty fast, and large parties had an especially longer wait time. 

Did everyone know about the lunch buffet? We didn't. I envisioned a classy romantic meal, but what I got was a long line for food piles under heat lamps. Don't get me wrong, I like all-you-can-eat options as much as the next person (especially when they're $18.95, cheaper than some entrees on the regular menu), but the food space is set up to be a fire hazard and I felt overwhelmed with the trays of vegetable-meat-sauce combos that could only be differentiated by the shape of the lumps. Nevermind the setup, the food itself was mediocre and none of the flavors stood out to me in particular. The lamb and the butter chicken were probably the best of the batch, and none of the options were offensive, at the very least. The buffet is a good way to try a bit of everything because it includes most of the regular menu items.

The wait staff was also very insistent on us ordering drinks right away and kept trying to take away the menu, but if you are questioning whether you should get the non-alcoholic cocktails (Mango Mojito or the raspberry option), you should treat yourself today because both were flavorful carbonated concoctions, and probably the best part of our meal.

Amber isn't awful, and the environment makes up for the lacking flavors, but I probably wouldn't be back to pay high prices for average food.
author: Jessica F.

description: This place offers many classic Indian dishes and flavors, as well as some innovative ones. I enjoyed the lunch buffet tremendously. The butter chicken was my favorite, but the fish and goat were also memorable. The salads were fresh, colorful, and flavorful, and the lentil dessert was an unexpected delight (who knew that this light as air confection would be healthy, too?). Service was more attentive than one normally finds in a buffet setting, keeping dishes cleared and bringing warm naan and beverages to the table. Lovely decor and ambience. I'll be back with friends next time!
author: Holly O.

description: Great food in touristy part of town.  It is a little pricey, but the quality can't be beat.  Very upscale setting and terrific staff.  Looking forward to going back and trying the buffet.
author: Will N.

description:
Amber India is one of the best indian restaurants in the SF bay area. It's an upscale indian restaurant and  trust me your wallet will take a beating. For those people that are struggling to pay the bills or unemployed, I'd advise you to go some place else since you will easily be spending over $30 per person..Just saying! 

Now onto the food, For appetizers we had the Paneer Shimla Mirch, kadhai paneer, and baigan bharta dishes with vegetable biryani and chile cheese kulcha/ regular naan.  All of the dishes were flavorful and tasty. The chili cheese kulcha was pretty hot for my taste so if you can't handle spicy, then this kulcha I'd avoid. The paneer is really good quality and was infused with the flavor of the curry. 

Minus one star for the host who was somewhat rude when we arrived. We had a big party and made a reservation but due to traffic and construction in the area, we had to move the reservation a couple of times. When we finally arrived, the host was not very pleasant. I can understand that he was upset but at the same token-customer service should still be on point. Turn that frown upside down because your getting business. On the plus side, our server was really nice!

Overall, if your looking to dine in a nice, trendy atmosphere and grub on some indian food and don't mind spending the $$, then definitely worth coming here. This place is great for celebrating special occasions as well as coming for a date night.
author: Avni A.

description:
Overpriced made for tourists Indian food.  There are better choices for Indian food in the SF area.  
Friends from the city invited us so didn't have a choice.
author: Alex N.

description: Amber has been my go to Indian restaurant since discovering the one in Mountain View back in 2003. I always get the same thing, which is samosas, butter chicken, and naan. It's consistently excellent food and I have never had a bad experience -- which is a huge considering I have been here dozens of times over the years.
author: Nolan M.

description: Didn't get my 5th star because service was little slow. Had a dinner for 3 and came after to try buffet. Overall good experience
author: Mokhi S.

description: Had a very good meal at Amber India - had the Chicken Biryani bowl which was pretty unique and perfect for one person. It was spicy chicken and rice in a metal bowl - covered in a naan crust, and served with yogurt. It was good. I would love it if they served the butter chicken that way too. Had a good meal (and a couple of beers) at the bar; the woman bartender Lisa was fantastic.
author: Mike M.

description: Very nice indian food. Especially goat curry and moong dal halwa. Amazing experience!!
author: Priyam S.

description: Definitely bet upscale Indian food i have every had. This location is better then the San Jose spot.  May be better then fancy restaurants of New Delhi. I have one question for the chef, it's expected to serve sirka onions and green chilli at upscale Indian restaurants all over North India, it adds to the whole experience and flavours of eating in a upscale Indian, why don't you??? That's something definitely missing.
author: Atisha V.

description: Was there for my son's birthday lunch. The buffet was okay. The biriyani was awful. Goat curry was pretty good. A bit overpriced, but given the location you can't complain. The desserts are very good and their ice cream spread is quite impressive.
author: Anandarup B.

description: This is the single worst restaurant in the city - not for the food but for the people who run this place. My family and our baby were turned back despite having a reservation. The best part is the reason - 'we do not allow a baby sleeping in a stroller inside. Only if you take out the sleeping baby out and put it on the seat can we allow you in because we don't allow strollers'. It is a shame that such a staff is allowed to run this restaurant. I used to be a regular but I will never go back again to this or any of its sister restaurants. And I will urge all of you not to either.
author: Sid T.

description:
This was my fourth visit. The first time was this February. Back then, I loved the food as well as ambience. Now, the food is okay but less amazing.

Somewhat the food was salty even though rice was combined.

The service has been great!

Yes, I am hesitating to go back to the restaurant in the future.
author: Sujung S.

description: Fine Dining, Indian style, at a cutting edge traditional Indian with a contemporary fusion edge, typical of its SOMA locale, a short 10 minute stroll from our Union Square locale hotel. Rated one of the ten best restaurants in the Union Square area by a SF Chronicle writer, I thought it was worthy of a look (actually, taste). The decor and ambience was definitely not your traditional tandoori restaurant that I'd enjoyed many times living in London, or even stateside, but much more in line with the contempo San Francisco scene: red/black lighting, with spotlighting, yet warm and inviting. The menu offerings were close cousins if not siblings to the usual tandoori fare, although I found the curry and spices cranked up too many notches for my western taste buds. Our appetites were well quenched by the end of the lovely samosa appetizers, leaving little yearning for the overly spiced lamb vindaloo and chicken biryani, despite a lovely Zinfandel, but will provide a lovely meal tomorrow back home in Orange County! A lovely evening for all!
author: Kim S.

description: Classy atmosphere, with delicious food and cocktails. My friend and I got some delicious fruity cocktails to start, and then the Kumbh, Hara Pyaz Kofta and Ferry Market Vegetable Korma, with pesto naan and rice. While the service was good, we ordered mild dishes and they ended up being slightly spicy. The pesto naan was great and I would definitely recommend. My one complaint would be the 4 plus dollar charge for a small portion of rice that's not able to accompany two dishes. Overall though, great and unique dining experience.
author: Caroline W.

description:
I went for the buffet at lunch. Butter Chicken was pretty good and I especially liked the desserts, one especially, it was a halvah something or another, forgot the name. I could eat that all day. I believe it had cardamon in it. The rice pudding was really good too.
As I have gotten older I can't really eat that heavy food anymore and for me Indian is very heavy. I doubt if I would go back I can get the same food in other Indian places in Concord and the South Bay and it's not going to cost 23 bucks but then again this is San Francisco
author: .James A.

description: Just freaking pure unadulterated deliciousity!  All of it
author: Russ C.

description:
Food. Great buffet. Tasty food. Lots of selection.

Service ok. Seated right away for lunch but got the feeling the server had a lot of tables. 

Would go back.
author: Donna C.

description:
I had heard a lot about Amber from both, Indians and non (let's face it, when an Indian speaks well about an Indian restaurant, it carries more weight). :)

I went to Amber with a business partner and I must say, I was  very impressed by the service, quality of food and the menu variety. There is something for everyone at the restaurant - An elaborate menu, a great ambiance and some good wine.

However, if you are going to Amber, go with a good bunch of people so you get to order several dishes. As mentioned, they have an elaborate menu so you may want to taste many items but not have the appetite for it. That's where a big group comes in handy!

PS - Butter chicken @ Amber = Epicness! 

Hope this review helps!
author: Dhiman R.

description:
I've been to Amber India for a few work-sponsored buffet lunches. The food is ample, diverse, and tasty, and the service is great (although, honestly, at a lunch buffet, I'm pretty much taking care of myself). I never mind being invited here, but I don't think I'd ever spring for it on my own, given the $17 lunch buffet price.

Everyone loves the butter chicken (and so do I), but  one of the things I like about the selection is how many vegetarian options they have. They're always different; last I was here they had fried mushrooms as one of the dishes, which was delicious. They also had a tasty bhel puri with whole crackers, which was a first for me.

All-in-all, great food, nice atmosphere, but talk someone else into paying for you.
author: Andrew M.

description:
One of my very best friends birthday falls on Christmas eve so we all usually have  a very nice birthday brunch to celebrate her birthday.  I love this time of year and absolutely look forward to this day with my friends every year.  This year my friend asked if we can spend her birthday doing some last minute shopping at the Westfield center.  So we did just that.  We shopped until we finished our entire Christmas list then headed over to Burke Williams Spa for a quick mani/pedi. 

After all the shopping we did we were starving and my friend suggested we head over to Amber for lunch.  

Amber has a great buffet lunch for a very affordable price which includes all the Naan you can eat. 

I loved their butter chicken which was amazingly good.  Everything in that buffet was delicious! I'm bringing my husband in here next time because he loves Indian food. 

The ambiance is great and it's in a wonderful location in downtown San Francisco.  Make a day of it and go shopping in Union Square
author: Christine P.

description:
Tried out this restaurant over the weekend and I think I have a new favorite in SF. We made reservations for Saturday night for a group of six and were seated immediately. I'm so glad we had reservations because the restaurant was really busy! 
To start off with, we tried the tandoori sampler and everything was delicious!!! We also tried the Kalimirch chicken, kadhai paneer, kumbh kofta, butter chicken, pesto naan, chilli cheese naan. Every single thing was delicious! I particularly liked the chicken cooked in black pepper and I also liked their version of the malai kofta. 
The reason for not giving this place five stars is because of their dessert. After such a great dinner, you want the dessert to stand out, which the strawberry panna cotta didn't. The fruits on top didn't seem fresh and they were wayyyy too sour for my taste. 
The service was good and the ambience was nice. I'll definitely be back! :)
author: Ashita K.

description:
Yay! I love being even closer to this place now. Just a hop on Bart away from a buffet lunch with coworkers. It gets packed pretty quickly so get here by 11:30am for lunch, especially if you want the buffet which is offered on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Menu items are delicious. My favorite is the chicken biryani. From the buffet, my favorite is the butter chicken. They offer a good variety of vegetarian and meat options along with changing up the dessert section. Don't skip that! My friend usually wants to skip the dessert because he gets so stuffed from the buffet but is always glad that he didn't in the end. 

Ambiance is warm and cozy with bustling waiters everywhere. There is ground level and upstairs seating available. Waiters and servers are always courteous and helpful.

The only thing keeping it from perfect five stars is the price for what you get. This place is pricier than most Indian buffets but the tourist location makes this possible. Check it out if you're in the area or their other locations.
author: Shell I.

description: Order to go(pick up)- Confirmed time 6:12. Checked in at 6:20. Not ready. They don't really care about the order I guess to make sure I get my order soon. Waited another 25mins. Don't come here if you are in a hurry.
author: ZW N.

description:
This is another go to when I come to San Fran! Love the atmosphere, Indian but modern. Service is sometimes slow so gave 4 stars. I love the samosas for appetizer. They use to have a goat cheese appetizer that was awesome but didn't see it on the menu last time. I had the butter chicken and was awesome. My husband had lamb vindaloo and was great and huge portion. Naan is great and everything you would expect from an Indian restaurant.

I highly recommend and will return.
author: Aleaha C.

description: When I order something to go ask for how long ,she say 5min,keep me waiting 30min ,sososo bad ，
author: Lohu K.

description:
I love Indian food. It gives me warm feelings inside.  The Indian food scene I am typically used to are hole in the walls in urban areas, hard to communicate with servers, but delicious establishments( think Shalimar and Little Delhi).  When my brother decided to choose Amber India for his birthday dinner, we thought this would be the Mecca of Indian.  Not so much.

Service was extremely rushed.  The bus boys were very clumsy and aggressive when cleaning our table throughout the night.  They charged us for every single piece of bread and a side sauce. It kind of made the whole experience feel a bit cheap.  I don't mind shelling out extra money for good food and vibes.  But overall, the value of this place was simply not there.
author: Hanna A.

description: This restaurant deserve a 0 star ... one of the worst restaurant i have ever tried.. the food was bad the service was even worse and above all it was over over over priced ..me and my husband paid 140$ !!!!!! Let alone the manager !!!! Rudest person on earth ....
author: Rawn J.

description: Very good flavors enjoyed our meal but it was too pricey to frequent this place often.  For my wife and 8 year old who ate very little, our bill was $150 out the door.  Thats an appetizer, a vege dish a fish and chicken dish rice, nann and two alcoholic beverages.  Servings were small and there was not much meat/fish in our dishes but plenty of sauce for dipping.  No leftovers just enough to fill us up.    A must do for Indian food lovers if price isn't an issue.
author: Doug B.

description: Great spot for Happy Hour. Some delicious appetizers and great signature cocktails. Not too noisy even on a Friday after work lets out in the FIDI. I definitely will be back
author: Lauren V.

description: Ok Indian buffets are not my favorite because generally the food is not real fresh, but not this place.  This is the best Indian buffet I've ever had. If you like Indian food give this place a try.
author: pochini m.

description: I had the buffet and it's not even worth 10$. There was a long line and food was pathetic. If you are going for just ambiance then it might be a good place.
author: Phill Y.

description:
Amber India was our first stop for Dine about town this week. We made a reservation in advance for 8:00pm and when we arrived we waited a bit for our table and were seated immediately. When we sat we were given menus but not the DAT menu. We had to wait about 10 or so minutes later for a server because it was clear they were a little under staffed. When we finally got a hold of someone to ask for the menu they came and brought out the wrong menu. More time passed and we had to wait to ask for the right menu again. After a while we were finally presented with the correct menu. I dislike the fact that they don't offer the DAT menu when you first sit down. It's like if you came to the restaurant without knowing about DAT, you would not get the menu and I think they do it on purpose to deter people from getting such a great deal. Every other restaurant that participates will offer the DAT menu as an option right away or only have the DAT menu for dinner for the week that it goes on. So Minus a star for the difficulty in getting a menu. We were also asked to move to a different table and it wasn't a big deal since we hadn't ordered anything yet but I mean they should know who is reserved and how to set up their dinning room tables, that's a managerial hick up.

The review is not tarnished however because the food made up for it. When you order you get an appetizer, two entrees, a choice of rice and naan and dessert. You get so much more here than you would get at a Italian or American style restaurant also participating in DAT. We enjoyed the menu because it's more expansive and the options they provide were intriguing. 

For apps we ordered a lamb and duck kabob. The duck was forgettable but the lamb was flavored well and we enjoyed the sauces that it came with. For main entrees I ordered the goat curry and my girlfriend ordered the butter chicken. Our choice of rice was brown and lentils. Our choice of naan was garlic naan and chili thyme naan. Hands down the greatest butter chicken I have tasted in my life. It was life changing and may have ruined all Indian food for me in the future. The goat curry was nice but the butter chicken was the star and I couldn't concentrate on anything else. I was surprised the brown rice was cooked so well and went with the lentils and curries magnificently, it was better than most basmati rice I've had at Indian places. The lentils also had good flavor that paired well with our rice and naans. The garlic naan is your standard garlic naan, but the chili thyme naan was on point with a little spice and flavor was excellent with butter chicken. Definitely worth it for Dine about town.

For dessert we got syrup dough balls which were very sweet and tangy. We also got mango creme brulee which is essentially mango lassi in a creme brulee and it totally worked. Very refreshing and it tasted magnificent. Overall our restaurant experience was awesome and our service was really friendly despite the DAT menu debacle at the beginning of our meal and being moved to a different table but honestly, the table we were moved too was much better. Highlights if you come for DAT: Butter chicken, lentils, mango creme brulee and chili thyme naan. It was all fantastic and get what your taste buds love, but for me these were the shinning stars.
author: Jeromy G.

description: very over priced indian food place. food quality very poor. customer service top notch. not coming back for sure.
author: Mike J.

description:
One of the best Indian restaurants in SF for sure. The goat curry felt like just home-made...yummylicious!
My husband fell in love with the butter chicken 
The bread basket was so dam fresh and tasty!
The interior was no doubt awesome!

The only bummer was the unfriendliness of the host. There was a wait when we arrived. The way the host conveyed us that info as if he wanted us to leave. Secondly, we got bit late to meet the host back after receiving the table-ready message. When we reached, he literally scolded us. We had to wait again as we missed our table which was logical I agree. But when actually he got us a table his attitude was like he was doing a favor.

Else everything was great!
author: Suchismita D.

description: This is the best idian food i ve ever had in my life, it took us too long to find it as the gps took us to the other side we had to park away and walk to find it but the walk was so nice and the it is worth the walk, the butter chicken was so delicious every single bite is full of flavor, me and my other half had awesome time with awesome memories,  highly recommended
author: Ghenwa S.

description: Excellent buffet, great food, great service. And it's the first Indian restaurant I've seen offering raw brown sugar! But it's 2.5 time more expensive then other places.
author: Dennis Z.

description:
Amazing Indian food! I cant really tell you what I had or what was my favorite as I could pronounce or recognize any of the dishes. They were all very tasty with authentic flavors and spices. I loved every bite. I actually went here for a quick lunch while in San Fran for an expo. Worth it. 

The staff seemed nice enough and the ambience was great. The decor was upscale and the bar seemed good. I didn't partake in the drinks but I did see some of their unique specials. I will try to come back here next time i am in San Fran.
author: Adam H.

description: Service was very good: the server was very patient in making recommendations. The food, however, was a little overpriced. We ordered curries, which we enjoyed, but the naans were just so-so.
author: Sydney C.

description:
First the pros: ambience is good, thats it.
Cons: taste is ok, variety of food in buffet is limited, very congested, air conditioner vent was leaking right in the plate. Santana row location is much much better.
author: Aishwarya G.

description:
Classy, friendly and delicious!

Having no tolerance for spicy food, the waiter spent quite some time introducing non spicy but more traditional Indian foods to me. In the event that something does become spicy, I was offered yogurt, lemon or another dish just to make sure I was content. I ordered the curry sea bass which was absolutely delicious. Although the sauce had a mild kick to it, the sea bass was cooked perfectly with the curry sauce marinated well into it. The naan with pesto was soft and aromatic and went perfectly with the sauce from my sea bass dish. My brother ordered the dish with okra, which was quite flavorful and my friend ordered the butter chicken, which had a strong spice taste to the palette and was somewhat similar to the usual chicken tikka masala.  However, it was still delicious and one can only wonder why it is the restaurants signature dish.

Although a bit pricey, the food quality proved the price worthy.
author: Lilian N.

description:
Really awesome Indian food!

+ kofta: dates, apricots? YUM!
+ cauliflower appetizer
+ butter chicken!!
+ eggplant
+ dal
author: Sherry L.

description:
WHO DOES NOT LOVE INDIAN BUFFETS?!?!? This place is amazing. The ambience is beautiful and well-put. Everyday at lunch time, they serve an indian buffet. On the weekdays, there are less options, while the weekends have around 10-12 dishes. The buffet opens at 12PM so if you get there right on time, you can watch the servers put the fresh food into the trays.

There are various types of curries, ranging from chickpea curry to goat curry (sorry I don't remember the official names), and everything in between.

The buffet is $22.99 which includes unlimited drinks (only 1 type tho.. so be prepared to only drink your one selection). I highly recommend the mango juice or the chai tai.

I will definitely be going back again!
author: Joyce M.

description: Great place and very good food. Service is exceptional and I enjoy the atmosphere. Best Indian food in the City.
author: Eric G.

description:
Decent food, rude manager. 
Friends and I used to go there and make frequent pick up orders, they screwed up the order once. The manager was condescending and rude when asked to make good on what we paid for. Not really the type of people i want dealing with my food.
author: Omar S.

description:
Even thinking about writing this review just makes me long for the days le boyfriend and I were in San Francisco going on trips with the awesome Umesh T. I miss that!

Anyway, as for Amber India, this was the first place we went with Umesh and his cousin who I think isn't on Yelp? (Umesh, please correct me if I'm wrong!) I love authentic Indian food (the not-so-authentic stuff too, but there's a time and place for that...) so I was excited to try this place. I guess it depends on what day you come what they're serving, but chances are there's something for everyone. I personally LOVE paneer, so I was super happy with my paneer curry. The boys all seemed happy with their food too and an added bonus for le boyfriend: mango lassi. He inhales that stuff!

Now, Amber also has some side salads and whatnot which I thought were quite disappointing. But I've noticed how I find most salads in the US lacking of that fresh, wholesome feel and taste which I do get back home. I mean seriously, why is there so much sugar, salt or whatever weird stuff in salad dressings?? But I guess that's just the US. Which is sad for me because I love diving into a huge bowl of greens, veggies, honey and cheese.

So, overall I thought the food was three star, but I'll definitely try to come back another time and hopefully try a few different dishes here. Like I said, I love authentic Indian food and for me, this stuff cuts it.
author: Bekkah R.

description:
Mixed.

Very attractive, pleasant interior, although up and down inside steps could be a challenge to some people (I'm OK with it). Good impression. Enjoyable take on julep.

Starter: flash fried spinach. Five stars. I imagine flash frying spinach would be tricky due to the tendency for spinach to disintegrate. Not sure what their technique is but it worked to perfection; the spinach was crisp but melted in the mouth. Not overly spicy, right amount yogurt, cranberries, although not traditional, added pleasant sweetness.

I ordered the lamb with cashews/walnuts. I expected something like a lamb chop with nuts; instead it was a stew with nuts ground into sauce. That's OK. Nothing wrong with a surprise. But overall the dish didn't quite "hit". The lamb, although soaked in sauce, was in itself a bit dry. The dish badly needed rice; I get a mite ticked when a high price dish requires me to spend more for the rice it needs. (I did get the rice.) Lamb was well trimmed, a plus.

For dessert, I hesitated over the more traditional milk dumplings, did a quick Yelp search for reviews, but it seemed people here either did not try dessert or did not say what they ordered. I wanted something light in texture (if not calories!) so I got mango crème brulee. Clearly not traditional but done well. Good, yet not an "OMG one of the best desserts of my life!" experience.

Overall, not bad, but not quite the four star level I expected.

Service good, host should not wear reeking hair gel! Fortunately he was not my server.
author: Carol S.

description: My wife and I went there on Christmas Eve.  The service was excellent and the food was good. However, it wasn't as spicy (7 out of 10) as We wanted.  It is expensive.   Tandoori sampler was $25.  The lamb in this dish was tasteless.  My chicken was good but was also about $25.   Two glasses of medium price wine, papad, yogurt and two entrees totaled $103.  That's a lot for Indian food.  At another Indian restaurant the cost for the same quality would be half that amount.
author: Bob S.

description: I have been to Amber many times before and always had a pleasant experience .On this occasion I had a disappointing experience with a tawa shrimps that was not fresh it tasted old and smelled unpleasant . I will be back because I can't judge by one unpleasant experience the food overall is good .The service was on point .
author: Karan M.

description:
Expensive. 

The food was good. Certainly worth visiting. Caveat being that it will not be the best Indian food you have ever had in your life. The meals were tasty enough. I had the eggplant dish and two friends had the paneer dish which I tried. There was good flavor to all dishes and I didn't have any issues with the quality of the food. The naan was okay. We tried the regular and garlic naan. Not as fluffy as I like them but again, it was decent. My favorite dish had to be the cauliflower appetizer. It was stir fried and it tasted amazing. I would go back just for that dish by itself. 

Service was really good. Our waitress was attentive and patient. We talked a lot and took us forever to actually look at the menu and decide on dishes. She was very tolerant and super helpful in a non annoying way. 

My only issue with this place was the cost. It was expensive and I didn't think the food (while good), was worth the price tag. The entrees don't come with rice and you order rice at $3.50 a pop for a small portion. We had to get 5 orders of rice for a table of 4. 

Would I go back again? Unlikely. I have a feeling San Francisco has tons of Indian restaurants with good (or better) food at a fraction of the cost.
author: Dee O.

description:
Enjoyed the food. Everything else, not as much.

It's really dark in there! Part of the romantic and mysterious ambiance/decor? It's a huge place, so you don't need to expect (much of) a wait. There's also a large bar area to the side, if you need a place to chat and drink.

Came in with four friends for a sendoff dinner (shout out to Raman!) on a Friday night at 7. We were seated immediately at the big table at the bottom of the stairs (near the bathrooms). Figured that since we were in front of the service entrance/exit we'd get some attention. It took a long time for someone to check in on us to take our orders and waters were refilled twice over an hour's span. Could not flag down anyone, ever. Our waiter looked bored and cold. 

Onto the food! Garlic naan tasted fine, not particularly special. Berkeley naan has spoiled me. Roti was tasteless but maybe the style here is supposed to be that way? The Butter Chicken and Saag Paneer were amazing, the kind of good you don't want to stop stuffing your face with. Also tried the Kashmiri Roganjosh, which was hunks of tender lamb leg. Tandoori chicken came with four pieces and it was good, but not good enough that I'd recommend it to friends.

Would recommend their berry cocktail if you like sweet drinks, you can barely taste the alcohol!

Our meal came to $220 with five entrees, five baked breads, and two beers and two cocktails. Can't say it was worth it and probably won't be back for a while.
author: Tina Y.

description: I went here today for the lunch buffet and I was in heaven.  First off, this is a higher scale Indian place so expect to pay a little more then your average Indian place.  Once you know that, you won't be shocked when you get the check.  Personally, I do not think $17 is a lot for the buffet, but some people on yelp do.  If I were to order everything I ate for lunch individually, it would have been way more money.  Plus, you get dessert.  There were a ton of vegetarian options so I was happy.  The food was really good, I loved the spiciness and all the flavors.  Indian food is one of my favorite foods so I may be a little biased.  I made a reservation for lunch and I would suggest that because even though this place is pretty big, it still was full.  I loved the ambiance and the service was attentive and efficient.  I would love to go for dinner sometime too.  I will definitely go back for lunch, especially since I work so close.
author: Megan M.

description:
Some of the best Indian food I've ever had. It's pretty expensive, yes, but anyone who had yelped the place would know that it would be. I would strongly recommend tandoor sea bass and the mango chili sea bass curry. The fish was cooked to perfection, and the curry was the best curry I have ever had, anywhere. The Naan was decent (not as good as some of the places I've had in Berkeley), but that didn't matter to me, because I'm still thinking about how amazing that freaking sea bass was. I still can't really believe it. 

The service was okay, and it took a long time to get our food (we had a party of 8), which is the only reason this place didn't get 5 stars. A must-try for anyone who likes Indian food.
author: Raymond Y.

description: Excellent lunch buffet which has something for every taste preference. Try and time your visit early so you get a good place to sit and do not have to stand in line too long especially if a big business group stops by! I have only gone there for lunch and recommend it whole heartedly. Some of my Indian friends seem very ambivalent about Amber but I have never had a bad experience there. It maybe because they cater slightly to a more western taste, but either way the food is good.
author: andrew c.

description: The food here was very good. I had the butter chicken, so flavorful! Would have liked it a bit less spicy as I am a wimp, but it was really good. Sadly our server was not so good. Tall blonde male, left us drink less with zero attention for far to long...
author: Carolynne A.

description:
I came here for Dine About Town for my parents' anniversary a few weeks ago. We decided to do the dinner family style so that we could try everything, and it was all so good. Whereas my dad stuck with chicken dishes, my mom, sister, and I split the vegetarian ones.

For starters we got the fava bean veggie tikis and the flash-fried spinach with raita dressing. The crispy spinach was my favorite! I could have eaten that all night. For the main dish we ordered the Paneer Lababdar, Saag Paneer, and the Vegetable Koftas. I think my favorite of these was the Saag Paneer, but I'm always biased towards Saag Paneer. We ordered two garlic naans, one chili/thyme naan, and one pesto naan- the pesto was really good! We all ordered white saffron rice, which came with dal on the side. My dad was a little annoyed that, for four of us, they only brought 3 little bowls of dal- I'm taking 1/2 star off for that. For dessert, my sister and I got the mango brulee, my mom got the pistachio gelato, and my dad got the chocolate gelato. I really liked the gelatos- the chocolate had a touch of cardamom, which was really nice.

I'm dinging another 1/2 star because the waitress, although super nice, kept trying to rush us out while we were eating dessert. We literally got our dessert and she brought over the check, which we found a bit rude.

Would I come back? Yes! The food is really good. Having come back from India recently, I can vouch for the yumminess of this food.
author: Shrina S.

description:
