Amber has really good Indian food, and the ambience is really nice. It's a great date place, but be ready to spend some money. Each entree is expensive and not especially big, so you may feel like you're not getting your money's worth. That being said though, the food itself is delicious.

I like the buttered chicken, saag paneer, and the bhindi do pyaza. The buttered chicken is the best buttered chicken I've had outside of India, and it goes especially well over rice. The bhindi do pyaza is a fried okra dish with onions and is one of the better vegetarian dishes I've gotten at an Indian restaurant.
author: Nikhil S.

description:
I went with a large group of 8 relatives, including a fussy child and an equally fussy elderly, Chinese auntie, and all of us had a fantastic experience.  The ambiance was chic, the food was well flavored, and the service was great (a very nice woman with an Irish accent, I can't quite remember her name...)  

We ordered the cauliflower bezule and samosas for appetizers.  The cauliflower dish had a hint of coconut, and was quite yummy.  The samoses were good, but as good as samosas anywhere else.  The fussy child would only eat meat and was not exactly adventurous, so we got the typical Indian buffet fare, including tandoori chicken, butter chicken, and kashmiri roganjosh.  These dishes are solid, but again, as good as you can find them at any Indian buffet.  The dishes that shined were actually the few vegetarian dishes we got, including the baby eggplant, the daal amber, and  the paneer lababdar.  I also liked the fact that the food did not smell like it was coated in a layer of butter (even if there was plenty in it!), and the flavors of the food were able to stand out.

This is not a cheap place, but definitely worth it for a treat every once in a while.  Also, definitely make a reservation. We came in at 9 pm and the place was still packed.
author: Nancy H.

description: GREAT butter chicken! I know there are other places in the area but the quality here is nice and good for groups and dates. I think the butter chicken really stood out, the veggies were many a bit too blended, the chicken was super tender, and the calamari was not what I expected. The calamari was not fried but in a wonder spicy sauce. I also really enjoyed their samosas (4 per order). We ordered 4 dishes and 2 apps for the 6 of us and really enjoyed the food.
author: Lily P.

description: We stopped in here after reading the menu in the window, and we were really impressed!  The food is amazing. We had the four chili sea bass and the kofta made of mushrooms.  Both were fabulous   The ambience and service were great as well.  What a wonderful find -- we will definitely be back on our next visit to SF.
author: Nancy K.

description: Second visit here, both the service and food were excellent. Love the decor, dimly lit and sat next to a giant red painting. Had a soup and a curry. The food was excellent but also very rich. No room for desert.
author: Will D.

description:
The food here was amazingggg. Blown away by the food, especially the naan! Came here with a group of  4 and was seated really fast at around eight on a weekday evening. 

Try the avocado scallops and it comes with a refreshing sweet taste, was a surprise to find a hint of bananas inside. Definitely a must try due to the unique taste. The scallops was quite big too!The butter chicken was good too! 

Best dish here? Naan!!!
author: Yilin T.

description: The best Indian restaurant I've been to. Great decor, really authentic Indian food. Right in the heart of San Francisco's union square, it is one of best fine dining Indian restaurants in the US.
author: Rohan K.

description:
We were quickly seated with no prior reservations and that was incredible. But then we had to flag our waiter down because he was no where to be found. That aspect makes me give this place 4 instead of 5 stars. 

The food was amazing. I ordered the lamb and the hubby ordered butter chicken. Both were amazing and it was a heavenly experience on our tongues. But again we were kept waiting for refills on our drinks --which were also very well made. 

I would totally go again but I'd be mentally prepped for the wait.
author: Nando R.

description:
If you like hot or very hot Indian food, you will love this place.
I think the food was very good but it was so hot I'm not sure :-) 
They were doing a lunch buffet but we ordered from the menu and were pleased.
author: Katie F.

description: Great location, beautiful aesthetic, good service. Delicious food. Just a bit on the pricey side, which is why I gave it four and not five stars. $1000 for 12 people is pretty stiff, when there are many other Indian options to choose from that come in much lower.
author: Sean B.

description:
Great food, great service, great atmosphere. We love indian food, and this place is really good. We were there for dinner, and yes, it's a little pricey, but everything was just great.
We had the chicken curry masala and one of the lams on the Tandoor. Both were just excelent.
author: Maggie J.

description:
Great food, but they really need to change their workflow. apparently the food got better from the last time my colleagues went.

it was friday at lunch, and it was a massive line through the heart of the establishment. 

I would move some of the heated dishes to where the dessert isle is. the line took so long to get Seconds.

4 star on food.
3 star on the building layout
author: Morris C.

description:
Great location 
Great atmosphere 
Decent service 

Went for a Sunday lunch buffet.
Not many options. No daal or sambar or the likes.
Desserts are not the typical gulab jamun types but they had phirni which was tasty enough.

I don't mind the price (on the higher side ~25$) BUT what's an Indian buffet without a BIRYANI?! Sorry, not meant for me!
author: Sowmya S.

description:
Tried the buffet on Sunday was excellent. Biryani, tikka were pretty good for a buffet. It was worth every penny I paid for. Service was excellent with great quality food. 
The buffet had variety and lot of options for veg and non veg.
Jerk chicken wings were awesome
Paneer lababdar were few of my favorites.
Buffet price includes alcoholic drink as well !!
author: Sachin K.

description: I have been coming to Amber for many years. The food is excellent. The staff friendly. Really cool server and the food runner was nice. I had the Salmon-Pineapple Kebab. Outstanding. My guest had the Tandoori Chicken and he really like it-moist and light, with a refreshing taste. Both dishes we're beautifully presented. We started with Naan. Amazing!  I had the Reisling Selbach 2013. Interesting with my meal. My guess had a Organic Tea. If you need power sit at table 21.
author: Richard G.

description: he food is very good though more than I feel like Indian should be. I was also shocked the korma didn't come with rice .but food is really great and Delicious !!
author: Kartheek R.

description:
Upscale ambient setting. Good, but pricey indian food. 

I went here with some friends because I was intrigued by the decor and setting of the restaurant. From the outside, it looked like a romantic bar infused with an upscale restaurant.  I ordered some Paneer Tikka Masala and my friends got the Chicken Tikka Masala and Naan. Coming from the Midwest, i didn't  like how pricey the food was for entrees that didn't seem too different from back home.  I enjoyed the food, but it was only average. 

I like the presentation and environment of the restaurant the best. We had excellent customer service with a waitress that was worldly and personable. The place seems like a good date spot as well with it's rich and vividly decorated
author: Thao P.

description:
The place is spacious. We have actually been to the Santana Row and SF both amber restaurants. Staff is friendly. The dimly light place is very good for just couples of family dinners. Some
Curries are spicy but most of them are mild so it is good. Decent collection of wine is available too. The bread basket, samosa and dal are some of the delicious things to try.
author: Madhuri D.

description:
we came here for lunch on a friday and the place was busy!  The buffet line itself was pretty long.  We started by the bathrooms and there isnt much space. It moved at a good pace but there were things that were empty or out when we got to them.  like plates.  I think their dishes need descriptions too.  It is not always to tell what is in something from the name.

Overall the food was pretty good.  I had some stomach issues afterwards but nothing too bad
author: claudia y.

description:
I thought the lunch buffet was delicious, and was ready to give a four-star review until I saw that the buffet was $17 (on my first visit, my lunch was paid-for).

It's as full-service as a buffet can get (fancy plates, cloth napkins, and waiters when you need them), but $17?? No thanks!
author: Bill H.

description: Great ambience... Food taste great! Overall a great experience!!! Scope for improvement in service yet it was not bad. Price on the higher side...
author: Moazzam K.

description:
The food here is decent. I'm not sure if it's worth the price tag. Let me talk about the good part first. I had the duck dish and it was quite delicious. Also, the lamb tikka masala was very good as well. 

Now the not so good part, my friend ordered the sea bass dish based on the waiter's recommendation. However, it was too salty even thought the texture was good. Another friend of mine ordered the tandoori chicken and I thought it was way too dry. 

Overall, I don't think it's worth the $$$ sign. You can get the same quality of food elsewhere. However, it is downtown SF and it has good atmosphere. If all else fails, this is a good backup restaurant.
author: Aleck L.

description: Not a good customer service really dissatisfied... I would recommend my friends not to visit
author: Rakesh M.

description: I crave this place and think about it ALL the time. Butter chicken and garlic naan...  I had this before I moved to the city and now that I live here I have to stop myself from going all the time. I have actually started cooking butter chicken when I get a craving for Amber's the recipe isn't that hard to make but theirs is out of this world.
author: Lauren A.

description:
sunday night at 6:30pm, just 2 of us.  there was a 30 min wait, so we sat in the lounge, where you can order from the full menu.  

we sat right at the bar and eventually got our order in.  there was only one bartender and one server for the entire lounge area.  

we ordered:
cauliflower manchurian
nalli vindaloo
butter chicken 
garlic naan

The food was fantastic! Wow. I mean, it was all super flavorful and fresh and huge portions! the cauliflower was honestly amazing.  the vindaloo was on the bone, and it was so tender that it fell off the bone.  great presentation.  a little pricey but you're in SOMA in SF, so about par for the area.  

On the downside, the service was HORRIFIC.  we sat the bar right in front of the server and bartender, but we couldn't get service.  seriously.  it took 45 minutes to get our check.  it may have been that they were short staffed?  who knows.  but it kinda made an awesome meal also frustrating.  

would definitely go back for the food though.
author: Jamie E.

description:
Great trendy Indian restaurant that provides the common north Indian dishes but with a well prepared dish presentation.  We tried the Malabari Shrimp & Samosa as an appetizer and both were delicious.  The Malabari Shrimp was curry based and would go well with a side order of garlic naan. 

For the main dish we ordered the lamb vindaloo that had enough portions to feed 3-4 people.

Great restaurant overall and worth a try if you're in San Francisco!
author: Mitul B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Indian food (despite being a white girl raised in Texas my best friend is Indian and I've traveled to both North and South India so I feel like I'm pretty qualified to judge). Amber India is definitely one of my favorite Indian restaurants - probably the best in the Bay Area if not it's sister restaurant, Amber India Mountain View.

The Cauliflower Bezule appetizer is something you MUST get when coming here. Despite it's completely dairy looking exterior, it is completely vegan...yay! I'm not a huge fan of creamy things but this dish is ridiculously good. I used to eat meat and honestly this dish reminded me of eating chicken wings -.- The cauliflower is really crispy and the sauce is plentiful and flavorful. I would seriously come here just for this dish.

Onto the entrees - their menu is appropriately marked vegetarian and vegan which is always a plus, and the servers are knowledgeable about the ingredients. I always get the Bhindi Do Pyaza (okra dish) which is a favorite Indian dish for me and I have to say that this is one of the best versions I've had.

This is definitely some of the priciest Indian food you'll find - $18.95 for the okra which is really expensive for a vegetarian dish. As a result, this probably isn't a place that you'll end up going every week but definitely worth the splurge for a special occasion or group dinner.
author: Sarah S.

description: Pricey but delicious Indian food! I first tried this place about 4 years ago and recently came back after moving to SF and the place hasn't changed a bit. Amber has a pretty large food menu and also a great cocktail menu. I'm a vegetarian and I got the Kafkha Paneer which was great, and the rest of my party got the butter chicken (tikka masala) and tandoori chicken. Highly recommended if you want a fancier Indian meal.
author: Harmony H.

description:
Came here for a work lunch. Apparently, they have a lunch buffet and it's definitely the way to go. I had the mutton curry, lentil curry, aloo gobi, tandoori chicken, saag paneer, rice pudding, roasted veggies and also their made to order dosa.

Outside of Vegas, I have never seen a buffet line that long (that's what she said!). We waited around 5 minutes before the line started moving. Definitely not really something that I would do often because I would totally stuff my face. Would love to come here for a real dinner one of these days.
author: Alice W.

description:
We arrived earlier than our reservation and had a drink in their separate bar area. It's a groovy red-lit area with music played at a comfortable decibel. On a rainy night I would have opted for a warm drink but the bar area was warm so a refreshing Pilsner did the trick. My partner had a manhattan but didn't really enjoy it.

Our friends joined us at 7 and we moved to the separate restaurant area (though they do have a lounge menu). We split a few vegetarian appetizers -- samosas and a cauliflower dish that was quite lovely. 

For my entree I had a dish made with taro root, cashews, raisins....it wasn't my first choice but the Irish waitress (not what you expect at an Indian restaurant) had such a great accent and highly recommended the dish, I couldn't resist. And I'm glad I didn't. It was delicious! So much for my saag paneer routine. I feel wild.

My friend ordered a mixed vegetable dish that resembled saag paneer and was pretty yummy too. A chicken dish wasn't enjoyed but my partner's fish dish was. So there you have it...;-)
author: Leslie K.

description:
Great service, beautiful space, well-presented and prepared food with farm-sourced labels on the menu.  The food, however, is not authentic, and heavily leans towards the mild side of the spectrum.  It is also quite expensive for Indian food.  For three of us, with three entrees, one appetizer, two naan, rice, and only cocktail among the three of us (in total), the bill was $130.

The samosas were delicious, as were the chutneys that accompanied them.  They were tiny, however, and $9 for three bite-sized morsels.  The garlic naan was also delicious (much better than the pesto naan, which I didn't care for).  My entree -- the vegetable korma (can't recall the name used on the menu) -- was well-prepared but not balanced in flavor nor delicious.  It also only had five ingredients, whereas navrattan korma typically has nine vegetables.  I wouldn't order it again.  My other friends ordered a tandoori meat sampler and a sea bass, which, as a vegetarian, I didn't try.

The location is great; it's right downtown; and it's in the heart of the city, not far from Union Square, close to the Metreon.  Service, as mentioned, was spectacular.  There was a mix-up with our reservation, and it was professionally handled and gracefully managed.  I'd go back; I just wouldn't expect it to be true Indian.  It's Americanized, mild, "Indian-inspired" food more than it is true Indian.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: Delicious! 3 of us were visiting the city & decided to stop by Amber India after making a reservation on Open Table for 5pm. When we got there it smelled heavenly, and there were not many people seated yet. However, as the night went on the place was filled! Every item of food we ordered was delicious: Sopras, Butter Chicken Curry, and Garlic Naan was my food of choice - YUM!!! Would definitely recommend it despite the expensive pricing of $100 for 3 people.
author: Becky T.

description: Yum. Probably the best lamb roganjosh I've ever had. Lamb was tender and lean. Sauce was flavorful with just enough spice for a slow burn. Naan was tasty and fresh out of the oven. A winner for this business trip!
author: Jeff F.

description:
Lunch buffet ok but nothing to write home about. 
Pakoras were heavily breaded and rubbery. 
Naan bread was mediocre. 
Tandoori was ok
Chutneys were missing.
author: A P.

description:
Came here for lunch alone and opted to do the buffet. It is quite popular and lots of people arrive before 11:30 AM for lunch, even before all the buffet options are ready to be served.

Very weird to eat at a buffet alone. The service was good, but a little weird to have all the waiters/waitresses standing around staring at you eat. The buffet options are good, with my favorite being the buttery chicken. However my favorite thing from the regular menu wasn't included (the flash fried crispy spinach -- so yum!). The naan also served during the buffet is not quite as good as what is served on the regular menu.

Overall, can't complain. Great deal for $17/person buffet.
author: Siv L.

description:
Had dinner here with my wife.  There was a bit of a wait for a table, not surprising since it was friday night.

The fried spinach was amazing - light and delicately crispy.  The lamb briani she had was great, but a bit spicier than we were expecting.  I had the butter chicken, and it was very good.
author: Frederick H.

description:
Best Indian food location in the area for sure. I'm a bigger fan or quantity over quality when it comes to this particular cuisine (RARE exception), but Amber does the job in both senses.

Beautiful location with great food and admirable service. The knock on the not being 5 stars is because it is quite pricey ... and the naan is well meh.

Naan must be good and plentiful! Need moar! Haha, but yeah, Amber is definitely ready to go and solid. Check it out.
author: Joseph L.

description:
I haven't had much experience with Indian food, but Amber India's fusion style dishes definitely opened my eyes to Indian dishes and flavors. I came here for a late dinner on Sunday, but the waiter still gave us his full attention and seated us promptly. I really love the decor inside as well as the view outside the window. It's simple and dimly lit, but feels hip, warm, and comfortable. 

The five stars really is for the food. We ordered the dungeness ginger crab for the appetizer, the konju pappas, and the sea bass kokum curry with a side of roti. I can't say which was my favorite because they were all stellar. The dungeness crab was flavored with pepper and ginger perfectly and the flavors were not too strong. The sea bass was super smooth and buttery, and obviously very fresh. Their portions are actually quite large for such a restaurant too, which is nice because I couldn't get enough of the fish. The konju pappas had tiger prawns drenched in curry. Surprisingly, the dish was less spicy than I expected. You must eat this with the roti or naan because it will taste the best. However, it's also light enough to eat by itself, which is rare with curry.

I am planning to return to Amber India soon for my next dinner! It really is a restaurant worth trying out.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
I had just checked into the W across the way, and I needed something to drink, and something to eat. In that order. I wandered into Amber India and sat at the bar, which turned out to be an excellent decision.

The lovely Natalia made me a very decent Manhattan, and then at my request, her and another bar patron conferred and recommended a couple small plates for dinner: the chicken naan and the duck kebab. 

I cannot tell you how happy I was to bite into that duck; it was absurdly tender, and freaking delectable. I suppose that my tastebuds might simply have been grateful for actual food, seeing as how the dross that American Airlines serves aboard their flights cannot be categorized as such...but seriously, I couldn't believe how juicy and flavorful it was. It wasn't a huge portion for $11, but I was so unexpectedly delighted with it all the same. And when paired with the Chicken Naan, it was more than a meal. 

The latter dish was almost like an Indian (non-crunchy) tostada: spicy chunks of juicy fowl, onions and peppers and spices and saucy deliciousness atop a fluffy piece of naan. Extremely satisfying, and the heat had me pounding my Manhattan (and then my drunken friend's Melon Julep which was quite refreshing). The naan was not quite as mind-blowing as the duck, but it was hearty and flavorful, and the two of them together made a perfect meal.

Amber also serves a stellar AYCE lunch buffet (as with all unlimited spreads, I predictably ate myself sick). However, at $17, it seems a bit steep. Especially since I frequent an equally tasty (but with admittedly fewer options) buffet for $10. And that one is in NYC, The Land of Everything Being Way Too Expensive Except for Dumplings and Sunglasses. (TLEBWTEEDS, to those in the know.)

I like Amber, and I love their duck kebab...but the prices might keep me from hitting it up as often as I'd like.
author: Peter D.

description: Stopped here during lunch buffet. Not as spicy as I like although that may be just because I was in the mood for Thia but found this place first. The rice was perfect for coating with their popular butter chicken and also the cauliflower masala both where delicious although I'd skip the chicken if not looking for a very rich dish. The lentil stew was tasty although once again I'd have really liked a bit more heat to it but the flavors were well balanced. Chicken meatballs were wonderful little appetizers and the rice desserts were good although a bit clean tasting for me.
author: Tim Z.

description:
Happy hour is pretty decent for upscale place. Its a small bar area but fun and great people watching out the windows. Cocktails especially the manhattan are awesome.

Didnt like the indian white wine though. Spend $1 more for something not on the happy hour menu.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Not very spicy
The environment is great
Clean and nice 
Butter chicken 
Good place for vegetarian 
Noan is ggggreat, Can't stop eating
author: Sunny J.

description:
I'm really quite surprised by the quality of the food here because it's such a BIG BIG BIG restaurant by San Francisco standards. 
I had an almost "Cheesecake Factory" feeling when I walked in, but they have really good dishes. 
Some plates are small-ish, as has been suggested by other reviewers, but some are huge. 
You can tell you waiter what type of appetite you have and they can help cater the selections to you. 
The Naan is ridiculous as is the vegan cauliflower/coconut appetizer. 
Good vegetarian choices. 
Great experience.
author: Melody M.

description: We stopped for brunch here. Great food and selection. Glad we found a good indian brunch place in the city. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
author: Pearl M.

description:
There I was, avoiding the buffet as I am wont to do for various quality/cleanliness concerns and I get a hair in my food anyway. Hey, it happens. I've worked in restaurants and there's only one way to handle such things and Amber handled it well, I'll give them that. They removed my dish and made me a new one and didn't charge me for it. Top notch attention deserves an extra star.

But.

Indian is typically cheap, unless you're offering me some kind of unique thing. To be fair, Amber does not seem to list typical Punjabi fare on the menu and there are a lot of creative departures (at least in the descriptions), so I was willing to fork over 17 bucks for a vegetarian dish. What I ordered, however, had the same flavor that I'd expect in Indian food (the spices are of course going to be the same), so I don't get the price tag (gulp!!) In fact, I wasn't even inspired to finish it and normally I have this problem with Indian food where I can't *stop* myself from overeating. So, at least I can be thankful for that? Sort of?

Although service seemed a bit absent at times, it's understandable as the rest of my party had ordered the buffet (roughly around 17 dollars for this. My dining companions seemed to like it, but... I mean, it's an Indian buffet! You'd think they had edible platinum on there). 

This review is only at 2 stars because I've had better, cheaper Indian elsewhere and would not return here, hair or no hair.
author: Joi B.

description:
This place was outstanding!

We used OpenTable to get a reservation, so we were able to walk right in and get seated. We got a couple of the non-alcoholic drinks that were pretty tasty. I enjoyed the mango mojito quite a bit.

We then had the cauliflower and the shrimp appetizers. These were also delicious, the shrimp was quite spicy, which I love.

For the main course, we had the butter chicken, garlic naan, and a pastry with chicken and rice inside. Everything was great, except I would have liked a little more garlic flavor with the garlic naan.

Overall, this place was delicious and I would love to come back next time I'm in town!
author: Mitchell W.

description:
Very good food. Loved it.

Had about 10 different dishes and liked most of them.

I've eaten here like 3 times now. Definitely more consistent than the Amber in Mountain View in S. Bay.
author: Joseph K.

description: Haven't been here in a while but it's better than I remember it.  Our server was very knowledgeable and patient with all our questions and dietary restrictions. The food was amazing, very tasty and healthy.  And even though couple of us didn't eat any rice or naan, we didn't leave feeling hungry!
author: Dana G.

description:
I have frequented the Amber India in Santana Row on occasion and have been meaning to check out the SF location. The place is small however has a very comfortable, initimate feel. I got here around 6pm so was able to enjoy some of the happy hour offerings. Because of the area, expect to see the techie and financial crowd hanging out after work.

The HH beer/drinks were about $6 and the food pairing were a small selection of appetizers/street food for $5 a plate. We were able to snag a spot to at the bar and got squared away with our first round of drinks. We decided to try the pani puri and pakora type bread. We loved the food. The pani puri's were presented so well, the pani was actually in a tall shot glass...adorable. The pakora bread had a good taste of spice to it. The portions are small, which we expected, but for the price we paid no complaints!
author: Jessica S.

description:
De.lec.table  Food 
Up.sc.ale Decor
Ek.suh.luhnt Service
author: The M.

description:
I went here for a weeknight dinner a couple weeks ago with 2 others and I'm glad we made reservations, because the restaurant was pretty full. 

I thought the food, while not traditional Indian (more Indian with a fancy, modern, American twist), was very good and had great flavors. We split several dishes, and one of my favorites was the mango curry sea bass. It melted in your mouth! The tandoori dishes all looked good as well, but we went with the traditional chicken tandoori and were satisfied. For the third dish to split we got the Dal Amber side dish (lentils slow-cooked for 32 hours in tomato and butter), which sounded boring, but they were so delicious and full of flavor! If you like lentils, definitely get these ones, with a side of naan.

Downsides: Cocktails weren't so exciting, I could have gone without mine. And this place definitely is on the pricier side for dinner, but I think it's worth it for an interesting, nice meal out. 

As far as how authentic the dishes are, I know many of the dishes come out more fusion/modern than what you'd normally expect from reading the menu, but I thought that was a good thing. I will have to come back with my husband sometime, who lived in India for a year and is quite picky/snobby about Indian food and update my review based on what he says :)
author: Nico T.

description:
The 2-stars is for how far Amber has fallen, and the quality of food and service relative to their prices.

Amber India USED to have exceptional service and food. The dishes demonstrated a perfect  combination of being authentic and unique. Not anymore.

After a long break, we returned to this establishment to our disappointment.  The server only checked on our table once in the beginning and again at the end of service. It seems they have transitioned to a "team" plan of service which means there is no continuity of care throughout the meal. We were mostly served by a very poorly trained busser who barked at us every time he approached our table, demanding that conversation cease and that all 4 diners lean back for him to reach plates even though he was only working from one corner of the table.  No discretion whatsoever, and we were not able to enjoy a good social conversation because of his poor training.  Water glasses were not refilled reliably. Amber India USED to serve out the the family-style dishes, but has stopped that service as well and simply dumped the plates and left.  

The food has diminished in quality as well - it is now generic Indian food.  For example, the okra curry at Amber used to be slivered and crispy, quite a unique presentation - it's now cut across and rather bland and mushy, like you would find at any buffet. The dal used to have more lentils, flavor and texture; today it is mostly butter and cream, using the cheap tricks of fat and salt to satiate the diner without offering any sophistication of flavor and texture. 

The food is decent here - you can now expect consistent buffet food better than most places, and it's slightly better than your average cheap Indian take-out cuisine.  This would be fine food if you don't want any surprises; if you want to bring your auntie/uncle from out of town and not confuse them with any unique twists whatsoever - this is your place!
author: Lester N.

description: Me and wife loved the food here... Very authentic and different.  The sweet dishes were amazing too, specially moong daal halwa.
author: Devanshu S.

description:
Their front desk staff desperately needs more training! Polish their skills and their presentation 
Servers are prompt, professional, friendly and very pleasant
Their vegetarian dishes taste clean, balanced in flavors and are light in oils. 
the Mango Bruleé rocked! Prices are in accord with their tasty food & inviting atmosphere!
author: Giselle C.

description: Go for the lunch buffet...same awesome quality food for a much better price. Makes the service much more bearable.
author: Rosie I.

description:
Came here for a business lunch.  The lunch buffet provided a variety of different dishes for a stellar price.  We came here after a recommendation from an associate, and we were not disappointed.  Everything was cooked well, and was very flavorful and aromatic.  Although they have most of the americanized dishes (butter chicken), I was impressed that they also had more traditional dishes like the roasted mini eggplants, sprout salad, and palm hearts.  Definitely left with a full stomach.  I'll have to try this place for dinner.

PROTIP:  Chew gum after you eat here!  Especially if you're headed back to the office. =D
author: David C.

description:
Old faithful. I go here whenever I'm in town. It's a little too expensive, but man is it great. Staff is friendly and helpful. It gets busy when conferences are in town - so be mindful of that and make a reservation if you need one!

Great stuff. Miss it when I'm not in town.
author: Wes M.

description:
We visited this restaurant on 12/27 with my friend and his family from east coast. This is not an authentic Indian restaurant. Taste is very bland. I visited this place one year back and had a different experience. Either management or chef would have changed from then to now.

Small portions, not good taste and way overpriced. First bummer was with tandoor platter. Small rectangle plate with 4-6 pieces showed up :(. We ordered Naan and kosha murg and Butter chicken. Curries came in a small bowls of baby. Naans were good but very small.

Next worst item that we experienced with was chicken dum biriyani. I think this worst experience we ever had eating chicken biriyani. This place does not have good non vegetarian food.

If you are an Indian, you can get better food nearby restaurants or at your home.
Things have changed in this restaurant. I think the reviews are manipulated or rated high earlier, that's why the review are good. There are much better Indian restaurants out there in the same city nearby.

Enough of high ratings for this restaurant which is misleading the people to go to this place.
author: F L.

description:
Great spot for Indian meals!  I've been here for weekday buffet lunches as well as a la carte dinners.

The buffets are great with lots of options and the food is always fresh, served hot and delicious!  It does get really crowded at lunch so it helps to get there before noon.

The butter chicken, chicken tikka and fish dish were all very good.  Never made it to the dessert table but it looked yummy.

Service is great.  They will continue to bring you baskets of naan until you decline and water glasses never sit empty!

Lunch buffet is $17 and soda is $3.
author: Susan C.

description:
After going to this restaurant for years I finally decided I wasn't going there again. The Amber management has made a strategic decision not to care about service and quality of food anymore because, if the locals are not going to eat it, one of the thousands of out of town Moscone conference visitors will definitely buy into the crappy food and service thinking it's the best Indian food they had in SF! 

Bunch of us went to their bar lounge area last Friday and had to literally fight for food and attention from the waiter. The waiter was not only new new to the restaurant but new to Indian food, so he had no idea about the menu!! We had to wait 20 minutes to get cutlery after we asked him twice for water, napkins, etc. We sent food back twice since the head chef was out of town and the new chef had decided to add extra salt and sugar in the butter chicken for flavoring, the daal and chicken arrived 15 min earlier than the naan. The lamb naan had lamb all on one side of the bread, so we had to argue among us friends on who get the piece with the meat!!! If I have another $180 to waste, I will still find another place for next time. 

I'd like to believe that the service can't be worse and hopefully plates will arrive before the food does? As a kicker to the evening, the waiter decided to add extra tip on my credit card on his own since he had made our evening so memorable! This all was done without asking me, which I had to "request" him to correct on my way out. 

This is great opportunity for other Indian restaurants in the city to cash in by hiring knowledgable staff and serve a decent meal. Its only a matter of time when people start realizing they are over paying for crappy Indian food and service. BTW, I usually don't write reviews here but couldn't resist giving this one some air time... and I am an Indian, so I know what my food should taste like.
author: G A.

description:
My husband and I went on our first date here :) The day after our wedding we decided we wanted to go back to the place where it all started and enjoy dinner together. 
We let our server know we had just gotten married and had our first date there. They went above and beyond--bringing us champagne and cake with sparklers to celebrate. A top notch place with great service and amazing food! Thank you!
author: Christina B.

description:
Big crush! Only tried the lounge area, I went there 3 nights in a row. In love with their interpretation of the mimosa ( happy hour woop woop )
Also their appetizers are great & Daniel one of the bartender is super friendly.
Go!!
author: Carole P.

description: This place was amazing. The food, the choice of wine, the deco is great and the prices were appropriate. I definitely recommend this place!
author: Marc B.

description: Had the duck tinka kebab and avocado scallops, and both were creatively Indian approaches to non-traditional proteins. The avocado-banana chat which came with the scallops was interesting, but I think that dish would have gone better with rice, or some other carb.
author: S. A. K.

description:
Been here a few times. The food and ambiance is definitely above average, but it's nothing to rave about. If you want some good Indian food - you can't go wrong by coming here.

I recommend going for the lunch buffet.
author: Nitin Y.

description:
The food was delicious, their happy hour menu is available until 7:00pm with some good options, and the place has a great ambience. However, the food is very expensive considering what it is. Worth noting also that the food selected to be on the happy hour menu is not discounted. 

You're definitely paying a location premium to eat here. Again, the food is great and the atmosphere is as well, but not great value for what you pay.
author: Jacob L.

description: very expensive for indian food, but excellent taste and service was good too. can order off menu items and customize the order to exactly what you want. they take reservations which is good. location is also excellent.
author: Veba M.

description: Food was good. Quantities a little less than my expectation. Service was okay. The butter chicken and the chicken as part of sampler were the best in my opinion.
author: Joe M.

description:
Took my wife here on our first date to this restaurant and this has been her favorite Indian place since. Food is really good, and you can tell that ingredients used are of higher quality.

Very nice setting, romantic and high end.
author: Adam S.

description:
I am glad the tourists here find the restaurant great (4+ starts) because that's the only way these asshole Indian's who run the joint will survive.  The price of the dishes here are completely outrageous for the quality that is delivered.  The Tandoori Salmon Kebabs have a fishy-ness flavor to them and the Tandoori Chicken looked like it came from a Cornish Game Hen - it other word the chicken leg looks like the size of a paperclip.  

Two minutes into finishing our meal, the dickhead restaurant manager comes over and says "Excuse me, can I ask you to leave or go to the bar?  We have a larger party and we would like to use your table to put other tables together"  Are you fucking serious?  I just spent $120 in 25 minutes on two people for two dishes and drinks and you (the asshole restaurant manager) comes over to kick me out of the table after I JUST finished eating to seat another family? What the fuck is wrong with you, is this your first time serving citizens in the U.S?  In India, I can see the blunt behavior particularly since I am spending about 40 rupees on a meal (about a dollar).  

So to the manager who ruined my overpriced Indian food experience for asking me and my lady to leave the table, two minutes after we finished, here's a lasting review to deter your future customers.  

Never going back and never recommending this to anyone.  I'll even get a review posted in India-West Newspaper for this piece of shit experience.
author: Milan D.

description:
The first thing I have to say is I had the best meat here ever! The lamb chops were so tender and soft and succulent, I cant get over it! Unfortunately it was my bf's dish but I still got to eat a few bites ; ). I got the sea bass with coconut curry for my main entree which was also good. It had more of an Indian flavor than the lamb chops which was good since we were at an Indian restaurant. We also ordered samosa, duck kabobs, and garlic naan. The duck was also very tender and delish! We topped off our night with a mango creme brulee which tasted so natural! I loved how it had pieces of mango slithers in it too.

Service was good, ambiance was classy and romantic. Decor was beautiful and classy. It is also conveniently located right next to the Westfield mall in Union Square.
author: Vicky Q.

description:
One of the best Indian restaurants in the US! Everything that I've ordered here has been excellent!
They could have a better alcohol menu though, but I'm going to be partial to them considering their food and service make up for it.
Don't forget to try the biryani, okra masala and dal makhani.
author: Kaushik S.

description: Very tasty and unique vegetarian selections. Well prepared items and beautiful presentation.
author: KS S.

description:
There was no information related to the order and food was not that great 

will never order from this place
author: Srilakshmi P.

description:
There were four of us for dinner tonight. 

All agreed the appetizers were very good especially the palak chaat.  Ever have crispy spinach before?  Crunchy and sweet at the same time due to the cranberries.  Also had the calamari and the cauliflower which we enjoyed.

Entrees included the butter chicken in tomato sauce, lamb with saffron sauce, and the lamb biryani.  We liked them all, but the appetizers overshadowed the entrees.

We also thought the lamb was somewhat overcooked on both lamb dishes, however, sauces were good on both the chicken and lamb.

Plain and garlic naan were nice and soft.

Desserts included the mango brulee and the bread pudding.  The brulee was very smooth and the pudding was very different.  Unlike the western version, this one was a small round disk sitting in something liquid (chai??) topped with black grapes marmalade.

Tax & tip was $185.00. Great service, nice ambiance, and unlike your typical Indian restaurant.  Good quality food.  Plates and flatware changed frequently.

Definitely would go back just for the appetizers.
author: Shirley N.

description: Food was awesome and service good. Except that the server placed roti basket in the dish. Super pricy but not bad for a nice evening out.
author: Parag W.

description: Gorgeous decor and very nice upscale ambiance. Impeccable service. We told our server that we needed to be out by 7, it was approximately 6:15. Four of us, samosas and a coconut shrimp appetizer with a luscious sauce. I wished for some rice to help soak it up. Four small samosas, very flavorful and not at all greasy as some can be.  Two entrees, the saag paneer was hands down the best I've ever had. Amazingly fresh and vibrant flavors. We also get the Hara Pyaz Kofta, mushroom and onion dumplings in a fenugreek sauce, which was fabulous. Two orders of perfectly cooked rice and two naan competed our order.  The naan was also the best I've ever had.  We were pleasantly full and out the door when we needed to be. Our server and the rest of the staff were terrific. Quick to clear plat s and top off our water. This place is a little more expansive than a standard Indian restaurant but WORTH EVERY PENNY
author: Dar V.

description:
This is one of the best Indian restaurant in SF. Food, ambience, service everything is great!!
I have visited it many times and would love to come more. Being Indian, I highly recommend it to everyone.
author: Ankita C.

description:
On one of my few trips to the West coast, I felt like grabbing some Indian food. This place had lotsa great reviews on yelp and I decided to try the buffet.
Disclaimer to this review; I only had the buffet and did not try their a la carte.
I walked in around 2:00PM and had to wait for a minute or two as the hostess was on the phone which I did not really mind bcos it sounded like she was taking reservations. Finally seated......I took off to the buffet table. I had the onion fritters which were ok, vegetable curry was pretty decent, butter chicken was good but the biryani was a disappointment, there was absolutely no chicken in the biryani, the dessert was alright, and overall for the price I would say I was greatly disappointed.
This place is pretty pricey and I would recommend this place only if you want to eat lunch without being surrounded by peasants!!!
If you have no issues with peasants then go to Shalimar or Little Delhi!!
author: Lein J.

description:
...............had this meal on Wednesday.....it's Sunday...........I'm still thinking about it.

Came here for DAT dinner, and the food blew me away!! Right from the beginning...food was fresh ( i know even with the heavy Indian notes and cream) and had a great balance of flavor.

I am an Indian food LOVER. so I've had my fair share of Indian food and this place was GREAT.

Awesome service, our waiter was very accommodating and genuine. The butter chicken was delicious, saag paneer had SOOO many cubes of cheese in it, so yummy! Our appetizers were delicious and made me so excited for the rest of the meal.

Dessert was the greatest finish to my meal, I was still talking about it with my mom last night....


Yes, it's expensive, but you can taste the difference, trust me. I love Chutneys in the tenderloin or Shalimar on Polk. I've eaten in a handful of Indian restaurants throughout the Bay Area too..


Can't wait to come back!! Will try the lunch buffet for sure :) Yum yum!!
author: Selina W.

description:
Fancy Schmancy Indeed I Do, 

The server, manager and everyone treated us with respect and friendly service which I found unbecoming of the typical high end SF places. Furthermore these folks are extraordinarily above the benchmark for Indian dinner service.

Tandoori sampler is great as an appetizer. The lamb wasn't too overpowering it had just the right balance of herb spice to lamb flavor. The shrimp was very spicy watch out and the chicken had a nice smoky flavor if that's what you're yearning.

Eggplant was prepared with divine intervention, the quintessential Indian spices just melted in the mouth and took all of my scents for a pleasant spin. You'll definitely be begging for more naan to indulge in this dish's rich masala sauce. 

A bottle of Montepulciano married it all together nicely with its full body it cut thru the spice and heavy sauces like a torch on an ice sculpture.

To finish it off the raspberry sherbert was one of the best I've ever had. The flavor was refreshing, sweet, fruity but the best was how smooth the texture felt while rolling across the tongue.

I'll definitely be back. Thanks Amber India!
author: R J.

description:
This is a good place to go for a fancy Indian food once in a while, but I'm not blown away by their dishes. Their butter chicken and onion naan are my favorites, but other curry dishes I've tried  have been mere average. 

From my 2nd dining experience at Amber India:

Although the server claimed the dishes to be "family style," I could have easily finished one order of curry and naan/rice by myself, had I not been there with a large group of people and were expected to share the dishes. Someone at my table also had some curry spilled on their jacket while being served, and the manager was rushing us to finish our dinner to accommodate their busy dinner hours. Overall, it was definitely not the most pleasant dining experience, but I wouldn't mind going back on the rare occasion for their ambience and butter chicken.
author: Jinah C.

description:
7 pm on Fourth of July and we didn't need to wait for a table, not because there isn't other customers dining, this place is huge. 

Beautiful contemporary decor, mouthwatering dishes that melts in your mouth, great server. SCRUMPTIOUS !
author: Lucy T.

description:
Went here for a Saturday buffet. I'm a native Indian and have been to tons of Indian restaurants & buffet so I'm a tad biased.  

At $22.95/pp this is definitely the most pricey Indian buffet that I have been to.  

So does the selection/ambiance/quality/service justify the price? Well, kinda...

The buffet selection wasn't huge but overall there was decent variety between vegetarian and meat dishes. They had a jalebi (Indian dessert) counter with a guy making it fresh and fresh nann (Indian bread) brought to your table so kudos for that. Grade: B+

The taste/quality was very good. Grade: A 

Ambiance is also very good. Not your average Indian restaurant interior here. A nice comfortable place to sit and have your food. Grade: A

Service is where they really faltered. A drink comes with the buffet and we choose the bottomless Mango mimosa. First, they make it sounds like you get A drink... not bottomless. A bit cloak and dagger for me. Second, they are very good at busing the tables but they don't refill your drink until you ask (this includes asking whether you'd like a refill). When we went it wasn't super busy and there were a ton of wait staff. Now other Yelpers have remarked on this stinginess also and our experience confirms the same. Plus towards the end of our lunch (around 3p when they close) they really started to rush us and that isn't cool. Grade: D

Verdict: I'd pay ~$16 for this lunch buffet considering location, selection and quality. Keeping in mind that $16 is on the higher side of Indian lunch buffet prices. So why pay a 43% premium ($22.95) then? Well for the bottomless mimosas and service... which didn't work out. Until they fix this, I recommend skipping in favor of a place like Curry Village in Sunset.
author: S B.

description: Delicious vegetarian farmers market mixed veg korma, as well as fig chicken tikka. Excellent service. Beautiful ambience.
author: Bob S.

description:
You know a place is good when you take a friend who lived in India, and he dug the food. This was a go-to spot for happy hour when I worked in the Financial District. Their small plates are easily shareable and incredibly tasty. 

The bar area where happy hour goes down is a bit understaffed though, I felt tempted to bust out a flare to get the waitress' attention. I wish they would add one or two more to the payroll, and give the poor team a break.
author: Kevin B.

description:
So my boyfriend has been raving about this place forever but for whatever reason, he hasn't taken me here.  And without a doubt, this is entirely my fault because 99.9% of the time I choose where we dine.  Yes he suggests, but the ultimate decision is mine:)

Well since I only get to dine with my guy every other wkend due his obligations as a father, I decided to choose Amber India as the spot for girls night out.  So we had reservations for 8p on a Fri a few weeks ago.  And since my friend lives out in East Bay, she tends to be notoriously late especially when she is looking for parking. The girls didn't show up till close to 9pm.  Thank God there was an inviting bar to calm me down, since patience is not a virtue of mine.  So I had a cocktail where the ambiance at the trendy bar scene was somewhat entertaining... people-watching that is.

I have to say it was worth the wait.  We immediately noticed that the servers as well as many of the customers dining there appeared to be natives of India, which we thought must be a good sign, that the food is authentic Indian.  SO I have to admit, I am ignorant of the culture, so no intention of stereotyping, but typically I always think if I'm at a sushi restaurant, I would prefer the chef and those dining there to be Japanese, because it just tells me that it must be really good and not Americanized.

Everything everyone ordered was absolutely delicious.  I had a bite of someone's "butter chicken" which is their signature dish... very rich, but it is amazing.  My friend and I shared the eggplant and salmon dishes, which was unbelievably good.  And of course, can't have Indian food without the yummy Naan!
We chose not to get dessert, but had their coffee.... wow, really great coffee!
We were so full, they all wanted to go dancing to some club or lounge afterwards... but all I was thinking of was my escape to leave so I can hang out with my boys CJ & Bentley :) and when my boyfriend and I will come back to this fabulous place.
author: Myra M.

description:
Our server was Irish.

Every time I write a Yelp review, I want to come up with something funny to say. Reviews should really be entertaining, because you don't know me, and I don't know you, and really I don't care what your food choices are because I'm positive that mine are very different. I like Yelp a lot, and it makes a great aggregate system, but I'm a picky vegetarian that doesn't like vegetables, and you're a meat eater and/or vegan and/or gluten intolerant veggie lover and your review isn't going to be about the food that I'm going to want to order. 

So instead, I sit and I think about something that will at least make my review entertaining, so that if a stranger reads it they don't necessarily care about my recommendation, but at least they don't ask for those 3 minutes of their life back. I sat and I thought about what I could say for an introduction and the best I could come up with was that our server had a think Irish accent and haha accents are funny or something.

I am getting really bad at this Yelp thing.

So I asked many people that worked there what "Nigella" was because it was the main ingredient in this really neat looking item on the menu, and literally zero people that worked there seemed to have any idea what it was. All of them tried to make it up though because I think they were embarrassed.

I ordered Saag Paneer Lahsooni and a half order of Masala Mirch Salan along with a  Chili Cheese Kulcha naan. All of them were amazing. The Masala Mirch Salan thing is the thing with the nigella. I still don't know what it is. Also, it comes with 4 jalapenos and supposedly the jalapenos are a main part of the dish but you can ignore that part. The sauce is delicious and tastes great on rice. There is a lot of it. The jalapenos are tasty but irrelevant, even though they're a main feature of the dish.

I went with 4 people, they all ordered different things (all meat dishes so I didn't try them) and they all raved about the food, with two calling it the best they've tasted. So overall it was a great experience for everyone involved.
author: Micah A.

description:
I have visited here a few times and every time felt that it was just ok. They do have some non-tradition Indian dishes that can be pretty savory but its really hit or miss depending on the day. Their buffet has a range of options to choose from and on some days they have stations making a variety of fresh indian food. Its a good place to go if you are in downtown SF and craving higher end Indian food and looking for a good ambience. 

I do like it for group events. They have a room in the back that accommodates about 30 people and the staff makes sure that everyone is taken care during larger events. I would recommend it for a lunch/dinner party for larger groups.
author: Shikha S.

description:
Awesome Buffett! Yummy pao bhaji! 
Cutlets and fritters as starter.. Baingan curry, Chana Masala, Roti, Naan, Rice and Saag paneer :) All for this vegetarian!!! 
Delicious jalebi and kheer and halwa :) 
Good for what we paid!!
author: Sakshi T.

description:
Found this place by accident in  August 2013 and told myself : the food and vibe were SO great I HAD to come back soon!

Back in San Francisco in December and went back with a couple of friends - again stunning food AND service!!

Lamb Shank Vindaloo was perfect Samosas too

out of 50 Indian restaurants I have been to this is one of the top 3

If you love Indian food - Go there
author: Douglas C.

description: Great food. A bit expensive at times but the atmosphere and vegetarian selections cant be beat.
author: Clinton C.

description: I can repeat that this is not a typical Indian restaurant in that perhaps a truer description is a French restaurant that uses Indian spices and menu names in an Indian style. The word "curry" doesn't appear anywhere that I remember.   The food quality is top notch but when we left the restaurant my party of 4 all had the same comment that we didn't feel that we had Indian food that we had expected.  No complaints (except one minor) about the food, it just was a different experience than expected.  The single menu item that was sub par was the nan. Flavorless and cold. Other than that, good food that reminded us of India and since India is a large country with different styles might have been served there. Someplace.
author: Bill J.

description: Best Indian fare there is in the Bay Area. Sure, its a good advert for Indian food here in the bay. But if you're from India, the food isn't going to blow* you away. Ground your expectations!
author: R I.

description: Amber sure has  come a long way. I've been eating at the original in MV for a long time. In an old strip mall its a far cry from the upscale rendition of the Yerba Buena lane sleek branch. We came here on a whim because one of wanted Indian food. Upstairs bar with a light wall, several large dining rooms and many staff. We opted for the lamb vindaloo, sea bass curry and NIgella stuffed peppers. A chili bread and paratha were ordered to supplement. Food was good but I think the original's cooking is still more spot on and prices more fair. I guess you're getting locale and SF rent translations. However if you want a nice sit down Indian meal that has been contemporized, this is your spot.
author: Kim N.

description:
I wouldn't call myself an Indian food expert, but the meal here was delicious.  This is probably one of the trendier Indian restaurants in the area.

We sampled a ton of food including the roti, basket of naan, a vegetarian medley, the lamb, samosas.  Everything was tasty, although I must say that the naan and samosas were must orders.  They also have a good list of wines by the glass and beer selections.
author: Gloria F.

description:
I came here with my family on two occasions. Once for dinner for my dad's 50th birthday and another time for lunch on a day trip to SF with my family. Both occasions were satisfactory.

Dinner: Prices were slightly more steep (including drinks, we paid about $115 for the four of us) but the food was nothing short of amazing. We had palak paneer, a mixed vegetable dish, yogurt, and of course, the famous, fresh, soft, naan. The only complaint our family had was that we did not say "spicy". Usually this is not an issue but since this is an upscale Indian restaurant in SF, the food is a little mild to suit all the other ethnicities that eat at this location. But besides our food being a little less spicy than we would prefer, we thorougly enjoyed both dishes. I also ordered a mango mojito, which was fantastic! Minty, fresh, and perfectly sweetened. Finally, when we told them it was our dad's birthday, the waiter brought out three scoops of sorbet (mango, raspberry, and strawberry (?)) with a candle in one of the scoops. It was downright adorable and all complimentary. Our family was pleased at the service and how sweet our waiters were during our visit. 

Lunch: We wanted to try the buffet since we've heard so many good things about it--pretty great as well! We had a paneer dish, channa, khaddi, raita, endless supply of naan and some pakoras to start with. There were also some traditional Indian desserts (I wish they had some of that sorbet or some ice-cream instead). Overall the food was great, but I was surprised there wasn't a greater variety for a buffet. Regardless, we were stuffed and happy with our food! This was cheaper than dinner too so if you're looking for a slightly better priced meal, come for brunch on a weekday rather than dinner. 

I would love to return soon!
author: Anu P.

description: Good Indian restaurant both for lunch and dinner options! Tried couple of times and the food is quite good! Value for money and courteous staff!
author: Laxminarayana K.

description: Good stuff: Masala Chai, Garlic Naan, Cauliflower with yogurt is amazing, Kashmiri Roganjosh is not as good as Butter Chicken, Gulab Jamum as for desert. Good selection of drinks. This place is on the pricy side. There are other good and cheaper places with Indian cuisine in the city but this place is considered as a restaurant. If you don't mind going to North Beach, I would recommend The Curry Leaf place http://www.yelp.com/biz/curry-leaf-san-francisco?ytprail=1
author: Svetlanko I.

description:
The food is pure divine! But what's with the attendant at the front desk? He is rude. When I told him that our party of three was finally here and we were ready to be seated, he gave me a stare and said "yes just wait we will seat you when we can." And then he kept on startng at me with anger. He was just nasty in the way he said that. He has been similarly unwelcoming and rude during our previous visits, but this one topped it all. 
I hope management will replace him. We have decided to resist their yummy foods until this person is gone. Oh, I hope the wait is not too long!
author: Rich D.

description:
Amber India has become one of my favorite India restaurants. The ambiance is excellent- great atmosphere for a late night out with friends. It's usually a 15-20 minutes wait in the weekend but if you're willing to sit at the bar lounge (you can still order from the full menu there!), your wait will be much shorter. 

I went there after an event at the Press Club right opposite Amber India (another great bar!). My favorite dish was the Keema Naan- it's leavened bread stuffed with spiced minced lamb. A must-try. We had a very friendly waiter who spiced up the atmosphere with his humor and energy. 

Overall- great experience!
author: Vivien S.

description: Tried Amber India for a pre-show dinner at the Warfield.  Had reservation and we seated immediately with a nice window view.  The paper menus were a bit spilled on and food stained but that's my only complaint.  Cocktails were well made and tasty.  The service was spot on appreciated the recommendation on the tandoori sea bass.  My wife would give the food five star but for me it seemed a bit Americanized, what do I know?!  After dinner we had a drink in the lounge with again a high level of service and drinks. Good food and great service, enjoy.
author: Ian C.

description:
Wow this place is super expensive and the sizes are tiny. The food itself is OK, I've had better at Indian divey places for way cheaper and tastier and larger. $21 for the Butter Chicken and all you get is a cup of food!? And that doesn't even come with rice or naan.. you have to pay for those separately. The Kashmiri Roganjosh (stewed lamb) was very good but $23 for a small plate. The best though was the tandoori sampler but still expensive at $22. 

I think you will like the food here, and the atmosphere. Just be prepared to pay premium prices. You'd have to not care too much about money to truly enjoy your experience here.
author: Vol T.

description: Been here couple of times during the lunch and they had buffet which was really good. If i'm there in that area during lunch time I'll surely go there.
author: Sammi S.

description: Went for the buffet lunch with many excellent Indian dishes. They have a variety for everyone and have plenty of options for vegans.  The dishes are spiced for Indians so they have a little more heat than other restaurants.  They have a wide variety of vegitarian dishes that will give you exposure to dishes you may not get at other Indian restaurants.  A bit expensive but worth the trip once in awhile.
author: Ture A.

description:
Had dinner here and loved the ambiance, the food and the variety in the menu. The Idli Manchurian was spicy and delightful! 

The rotis and Kadhai Paneer mothwatering!

Only flip frikkin expensive.
author: Harsha G.

description: Came here for dinner right after worl. Ordered the butter chicken it was delish. I tried an appetizer that I didn't know what it was, and the bartender was nice enough to switch it for me to something else.
author: Melissa H.

description: Really delicious Indian food in a cozy, hip little spot off Market. We enjoyed the cauliflower and malabari shrimp appetizers, and the saag paneer was the best I've ever tasted. Amber is definitely on the list of restaurants I'll visit again when I'm in SF.
author: Maggie A.

description: Rare Indian food joint that understands the complicated flavored of Indian food and gives them it's due respect. Flavor of Indian food varies greatly between each dish, complemented by bread and or rice etc. Getting it right is not a small feat. Amber does get it right!
author: Kunal K.

description: Today as usual the lines were slow as molasses, the waiter brought a pen that wouldn't write making us wait for 5-7 more minutes just to sign the check and meanwhile, the manager comes to the table and tells us "guys, I have tons of people waiting to be seated so you better hurry up". How about managing the buffet lines better? If we didn't have to stand in line for 20 minutes each time, we would finish our meal and leave the place way earlier. But no, they won't do anything about it and still expect you to get out super quick.
author: kumar k.

description: Impossibly good.  We walked in and it smelled like an indian feast.  Super classy and nice environment, great service and really fast when the food came out.  I had the lamb curry and garlic naan.  It was so rich and delicious.  My girlfriend had an eggplant and almond thing with a cilantro curry like sauce that was killer.  Its a little pricey but totally worth it.  I'd say it's a great nice date location.  We are definitely going to be coming back here.
author: David P.

description: I only tried their lunch buffet.  Butter chicken was fantastic.  Chicken biriyani was great too.   Those were my favorites.  I liked having a proper salad (arugula) as an option at an Indian restaurant, which you don't normally get.
author: Julie P.

description:
Ambience: 4/5... WOW!!! I do love the lighting, the accents, the music, the hustle and bustle of this Amber India.  Great atmosphere for any occasion, date, catching up with friends or meeting with someone to discuss some business. 

Service: 5/5 The thing I loved about the service is that they take their job very seriously.  Our server almost seemed to be a perfectionist with the way he greated us, explained the menu and specials, took our order and checked on us.  I even witness him grabbing one of the food runners and bringing him back to the trey jack that he left, he wasn't too happy and you could tell he meant business.

Food: 5/5 I absolutely love Indian food...  My GF and I both agree that this place is by far the best in the bay that we have encountered so far. I got the Nalli Vindaloo...  A big piece of Lamb Shank with the perfect amount of spice and heat to kick your taste buds into full gear.  My GF got the Saag Paneer (vegetarian) which she said was the best Saag Paneer that she has ever had.  Garlic Nan! Great!

Price:  A little step but what you expect when receiving great service, amazingly prepared food and a great atmosphere. Money well spent and tip well earned. 

Overall: 5/5... There really wasn't anything that I didn't like about this place.  I believe I am handing out my first 5 ever.  I will dine here for special occasions but until I start making a little more money or paying less rent it will be just be for occasions.  Pretty pricy but well worth it.
author: Terrance H.

description: Best Indian food ever. A must visit! Try the butter chicken, the rice and don't forget about the naan! If only I lived closer, I have yet to find an Indian restaurant that comes close to the food offerings that Amber provides me.
author: Larry D.

description:
Three reasons why I won't come to this place ever again -
1) OVERPRICED and TASTELESS BUFFET : The buffet me and my wife had at this place today totally sucked. Even food trucks have more delicious food. At $25, having crappy chicken wings, rubbish baigan bharta and biryani and no fish doesnt make sense.
2) FOOD WASTAGE - So the waiter gives us a basket of nans without asking us. We don't even touch them and humbly ask the manger to take them away as we haven't even touched them. He said its contaminated and they will throw them off. We request him to give it to us in a to-go box so that we can give it to a homeless guy. He refuses saying that California law doesn't allow him to do so. We offer to buy those nans as we don't like untouched food to be wasted, he refuses even that. 
3) MANAGER : The guy whom we dealt for the above issue was the manager. Moreover he spoke in a demeaning tone. No hopes from this place.

This place is a big farce. I have No RESPECT for such places which force food on you and then throw untocuhed food off without even thinking about homeless people right outside their gate.
author: Sudipto D.

description:
Great Great Restaurant. A perfect blend of North Indian dishes with International Twist. The restaurant has two sections, lounge and the dining area. Due to high wait we first sat at the FCFS lounge. The ambience was just so perfect, nothing less than a 5-star lounge. We had few drinks with an amazing appetizer of Palak Chaat(A must have). 
Then finally after 45mins of wait(Saturday Nite), we got to the dining area. Ordered a tandoori starter and butter chicken. Great flavor and spice. They have a good collection of Wines too.
author: Prateek G.

description: Standard Indian fare at the lunch buffet.  Everything was good but the restaurant was crowded and the buffet was a little picked over by the time we got there.  Everything was tasty but nothing particularly unique or remarkable on the buffet.
author: Becky S.

description: They gave us menu stained in curry..imagine the unhealthy, unhygienic diet in kitchen. I asked for manager and the waiter said he is busy. I don't like when restaurant slack for no reason. When the price is so high for a basic meal
author: Atisha V.

description: After many recommendations from our friends, we decided to try this place. Perfect location,  Nice ambience, polite servers, good crowd and flavorful food. We had pesto naan, mutter kulcha which were really really soft and flavorful. Chicken biryani had just the right amount of spices and chicken was well cooked with flavor in every bite. A good experience overall.
author: Sudha P.

description:
This is a great option if you're at the Marriott or nearby. Amber India is newer, seems popular and gets a decent crowd. Here's the rundown on the grub:
- Palak Chaat (A-) impressive
- Butter Chicken (A+) this signature Amber recipe was awesome and is highly recommended
- Kashmiri Roganjosh (B+) Great take on Lamb 

Don't go out of your way to get here, but if you're at one of the hotels nearby, it's a good option.
author: Jeff F.

description: Tasty & tender lamb korma. Pesto naan very good. Avoid the chicken biryani, not authentic at all. Samosa is just ok. Chicken korma is good. Generally, food doesn't justify the high price. Wonder why it's so crowded most of the time.
author: T V.

description:
Opening night, epic fail. 
 
Lets start with the positive:

They spent coin on design. Sure the interior is a little gaudy and doesn't have a coherent theme, but in passing it looks nice. Location is convenient to the FiDi and you have to love how this little square is coming together with nice restaurants and open space.

Ok that's it, now the negative: 

Someone messed up in laying out the tables, there is too little room to navigate between each one as you try to make it through (btw I'm a skinny bitch, so if you're normal size or above good luck getting through). 

Service was a complete and utter disaster, the worst I've seen in years. I understand it's opening night and I was prepared for serious bumps, but wow. We asked the drink guy, the water guy, the manager all for a waiter. Finally got one 30 minutes in by getting up and tapping a waiter on the shoulder. No one was really apologetic, manager guy didn't help us (he seemed aloof). Typically on a restaurant's opening night the staff is fired up, strangely everyone seemed like they could care less.

Food was eventually ordered, appetizer and entrees. All came out at the same time after a painfully long wait. My rack of lamb was cooked unevenly, one section medium, another well, and yet another medium rare. Other things I tried (assorted naan, jasmine rice, some tandoori chicken, all fine but nothing remarkable). 

Definitely not hitting the mark in quality and service at their chosen price point.

Hope and pray Press Club does better, skip it or wait until you see better reviews.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars for $19.99 Weekend Brunch.  We decided to be gluttons and try Amber India's weekend buffet. 

Located inside Yerba Buena Lanes, the ambiance is a little more upscale for an Indian restaurant (definitely a plus) and the restaurant is pretty sizable.  We came in at noon on Sunday for the buffet and the place was pretty empty but within 1/2 an hour, the place was pretty packed with patrons.

In addition to the standard fare, there's also a Dosa station where someone is making dosas to order (very delicious).  There's an assortment of meats (butter & tandori chicken, lamb curry, fish curry, etc) and a variety of vegetarian dishes (only thing missing is my favorite saag paneer but they had another paneer dish).

Brunch comes with sparkling wine or mimosa and there's also a mini dessert area with fresh fruits and mini Indian donuts.

Definitely more expensive than our typical Indian places but it was also a nicer space. We saw everyone from couples to families celebrating birthdays there.

We also really liked the Amber India in the South Bay! (I think they are owned by the same folks =)
author: Betty C.

description:
Very classy decor.

Lots of options and friendly towards vegans. They have vegan dishes in the buffet (number depends on the day) and they offered papadum as a na'an substitute.

Can make reservations. Calling allowed us to get availability not on open table. They also said it was okay if some people did the buffet whilst others ordered off of the menu.

Sunday lunch buffet has mimosas.
author: Gee H.

description:
Delicious food, impressive ambiance, polite staff.. a wholesome dinning experience that comes at a high price tag.

Food was simply delicious.  Top winners that left us finger-licking were Palak Chaat, Cauliflower Bezule, Paneer lababdar, Dal Amber (their fancy name for Dal Makhani) and Pesto Naan.  However, Lachha Parantha was rather too thick and not so great, i would also skip ordering Mirch Ka Salem next time. Desserts were a hit and miss with Pista Kulfi being good and Mango Brulee being too sweet & barely edible.

Portions were average, food was served hot.

Staff is polite and efficient. While they refused to take reservations on the phone on a busy Saturday evening, they still managed to accommodate our party of eight after a 20-25 mins wait. The waitress who attended on us was very efficient and kept coming back to us to make sure we placed our order and got everything before the kitchen closed for the day.

Quality of food is good and service standards at Amber are well kept. That being said, the restaurant is definitely fine dinning and pricey (after all average price of naan bread being at $4 here, is a little over the top). All in all a good choice, when you are looking for a high end Indian restaurant.

Tip: Be sure to try their Mango Majito, it is one of the best that i have had in the Bay Area and an ideal pick whether made virgin or otherwise. Also, this place gets super busy on the weekends so plan your visit accordingly.
author: Chiku C.

description: Ambience and location are pretty good but the food to me is average, nothing out of the ordinary. But the price is too steep.
author: Arjun S.

description:
Amber India has a lunch buffet for around $17 and though you probably couldn't eat here every day, it's a great way to treat yourself (or have your company treat you :-)).  I especially like the vegetarian dishes in the buffet.  The meat dishes are good too but the vegetarian dishes are much better.  The food is also nice and spicy, which I was happy about.  They keep the buffet pretty fresh, bringing out new food quickly and the turnover is good being a business lunch hotspot.  Also, save some room for dessert - rice pudding and also vermicelli pudding.  The vermicelli pudding was the better of the two.

The servers were also good about coming around to the tables and refilling everything.
author: Jean K.

description: Food is tasty, good selection of non-alcohol drinks. Audience is above average, yet not so upscale experience.
author: Ilmia N.

description: Only food is good. Folks have an attitude. Person took away my plate with apparently no apologies while I was still eating food. One of my colleagues said - why did not you grasp the plate.
author: Raj G.

description: This restaurant is worth ALL THE HYPE!  I've had meals at many different Indian Restaurants all around the world, and this took the cake!  Our server (Joe) was very pleasant, informative, and just a happy person. He was really providing a nice experience for us by knowing everything about the dishes we asked for, checking in on us regularly, but not too much and not being pushy to get us out. We asked for something that was not on the menu, and without hesitation, he said yes, we can accommodate you. Our cocktails were delicious, appetizer (tandoori chicken) was probably the best I've ever had. It was marinated well and so juicy. Our meals (Chicken Tikka Masala, and Dum Biryani) came out perfectly! My husband, who is a foodie and quite the critic was impressed as well. Loved the service, the food, and the ambiance. DO NOT SKIP THIS SPOT and make reservations in advance.
author: Tish V.

description:
First dont listen to yelp this aint the financial district or union square this is soma... its closest 4th and market, where union square starts two to three blocks away on geary, and financial district is around montgomery NOT Powell...

anyways

this is a good brunch, lots of veggie options, and gluten-free...
Also the freshest salad i EVER seen at a Indian Buffet!

Also this is about 7-8 dollars more than your regular lunch buffet... remember u are paying for the environment...

the service kinda... ok... not the best but we didnt get left in the dirt either... 

Since indian dishes here I never seen before so a star for that... but if u want quick fast Indian food go to naan and curry but if your mom wants to eat somewhere nice and wants Indian then take her here...
author: Mari L.

description:
So. Let's talk drinks.
