We only ate one of them cos neither of us liked it. Shrimp was fine- nothing interesting about it.

Naan was puffy and good - was more hollow bubble bread than doughy and soft like I like. Was good though.

Drinks - the non-alcoholic mango mojito was good (and they can make an alcoholic version btw)

I ordered the Belotta which was strawberry  puree with sparkling wine and a sweet liquer. I didn't love it cos it was too syrupy and sweet. I even tried saving it by squeezing in a bit of lime but no luck.

Prices - super high so expect to be paying extra for the fancy setting. $40pp with only 1 alcoholic beverage, plain rice, 2 breads, 2 entrees. Not sure I would return, but it is in a safer part of town if you don't want to wander into the Tenderloin for the more traditional stuff.
author: Catherine N.

description:
Best Indian buffet period I have eaten Indian buffets all over the country and this one is by far the best ever. They have amazing variety and at the same time each item is flavorful and rich. I love the tawa fish they have, it is just great.

I cant say the same about their a la carte menu because I have never tried it and have actually heard that it is not that great, but the buffet is to die for.

I read some reviews about it being pricey, well it is and I would still go here even if it was priced higher than the $18 because I want the great food and great ambiance both and this is the only Indian place I can say gives me the whole experience. Its clean, classy and the service is great too.

Read a dumb comment about how food from a third world country shouldnt cost so much, obviously is ignorant about  India or how rich its food culture is. Better to stick to Mc Donald's I'd say! 

I go here multiple times a month and can vouch for their buffet as one of the best in the country!
author: Mandy K.

description:
A great experience.

Unlike most Indian restaurants, this isn't quite so traditional in the décor and ambiance - they really went for a modern and cool feel and they achieved that.  This place is a restaurant, but also has a cool bar/lounge area that's perfect for connecting with friends.  

I was here for Sunday brunch and it was fantastic.  Great quality dishes that were perfect in taste and presentation.  While they had some of the typical dishes you'd expect at an all-you-can-eat Indian buffet (chicken tandoori, chicken tikka masala, saag), most have a twist like the tandoori chicken having breast pieces (and the meat is tender and not dry) and the saag having corn.  There are also a few dishes I hadn't had before like stuffed potatoes that were sweet and savory with some great spices to make it unique.  The butter chicken was absolutely amazing - creamy, rich and flavorful, this is a perfect way to have chicken.

The buffet can range in price from $16.95 - to $19.95 (Saturday - Sunday)...just be careful since the price may be displayed as $16.95 when in fact it is $19.95 on Sundays.
author: Ken G.

description:
My mouth is watering as I am writing this review. 

This was absolutely amazing! Everything we had was fresh and fabulous from the lunch buffet. Absolutely amazing!

You should try this place STAT!
author: Lucy B.

description:
As a card-carrying member of the brown-people-from-India club, I used to say the original Amber in Mountain View had the best Indian food outside of India - I've easily eaten there a dozen times.  Fast-forward a few years ahead to today, when I finally had the chance to check out the lunch buffet at the SF location...what a huge letdown!  Over-priced and westernized - if you're in the mood for Indian, I'd suggest taking a short walk into the T-Loin for Shalimar or Pakwan...you can thank me later.  

Things started out well - there was a long line but we got in within 10 mins - I'll chalk that up to an Indian sista' hooking me up.  Putting our stuff down, we quickly made a beeline for the well-stocked buffet - they had a decent selection (maybe 10 dishes and 4 desserts - most dishes were veggie friendly) and full trays.  Piling on our plates, we sat down and dug in.  Before and after sitting down, we asked for an order of naan and were promised it would come soon - we didn't end up getting any naan until finishing our first plates!  

Sadly, the naan and the food weren't worth the wait. I'm all for being healthy, but naan with no ghee on it?  Sadness...we had two orders and both ended up being dry, chewy, and pretty unappetizing.  But of course the biggest letdown was the food - I'm not sure what's changed, but it seemed very catered to Western tastes, a la Trader Joes ready-made Indian food.  Tikka masala, mattar mushroom, saag paneer, "vegetable curry" (whatever that is - is that even a dish?) - all rich with ghee/cream but tasteless. I did enjoy the cilantro/mint chutney and the fish (seemed like it was marinated in the chutney), but that's about it.  

To top it off, the bill for some sub-par Indian food comes out to ~$20 per person - good food or not, $20 is high for a Indian lunch buffet.  Buffets in Little India (aka the South Bay) usually are under $10/person - I'm guessing here you're primarily paying for the location and decor (which seemed pretty standard trendy in the day time but I'm sure it's nice during the night).  

I've been thinking about making a return trip to the Mountain View location (it's been a few years) but now I'm thinking twice about it.  It's kind of like re-watching Thundercats cartoons as a grownup - you're just setting yourself up for a letdown.  Why mess with the happy memories?
author: Rosers M.

description: One of the best Indian food I have had in a long time. We ordered lassi, tofu tikki, palak chat, mirch masala, pesto Naan, veg biryani and a chicken item (my friend). Tofu Tikki is a must try. Period. I am not a big fan of Tofu even after being a vegetarian, but in this dish it was minced and I could hardly feel I am eating Tofu. The flavors were amazing. Not too bland either. Palak Chat was very well made too. Pesto naan is a new dish I had not tried anywhere else. Its Pesto in between two pieces of Naan. Went well with the mirch Masala. Liked the Biryani too. The best part of all the dishes were I could feel the flavors in my tongue with excess spice or hotness. My friend liked the chicken dish too. The ambience is awesome. We were lucky to get a reservation for 30 min from the time of the call.  Initially I felt it was expensive but after eating a very good flavorful dinner, I feel it is worth the price, ambience, location and service.
author: Shreyas P.

description:
Best Indian restaurant in the city hands down.  Yes, it's expensive for Indian, but you get excellent food and great atmosphere.  My absolute favorites are the lamb chops and the butter chicken with garlic naan.  And of course the Palak Chaat - the spinach appetizer that will make you crave spinach.  Oh and the tandoori fish.  I think you get the picture.  Everything I've ever had here I've enjoyed.  

The bar is also great.  There is an awesome bartender there, originally from NY who will take care of you.  STRONG drinks - and you can eat at the bar ;-)
author: Jennifer C.

description: Very nice restaurant with some of the best indian food we've had. chicken tikka masala, saag panner, and the best butter chicken ever! garlic naan was soft and fresh i will be back guys Definitely try this place!
author: Gurbhej B.

description: I went here for the Dine about town deal for $36 bucks for 3 course dinner. The food was fantastic! My friend and I loved it so much that we ate everything and I must say the portions were big for the two of us. We ordered the butter chicken and the curry vegetables which came with rice and the bread. Service was top notch; they always kept our waters full and checked on us periodically. I highly recommend reservations because on the Saturday night we went there the wait was 45 min to an hour. We didn't get a chance to visit the bar but it looks like an awesome place to kick it and have a few drinks. Would I come back? Certainly, but without the Dine about town deal it is going to be pricey.
author: Matthew L.

description: So good! The butter chicken and naan are absolutely delicious. Highly, highly recommend.
author: Mel G.

description: Excellent Food.  Superb Service.  Great Ambiance.  Worth the price!  Can't wait to go back again!
author: April K.

description:
I don't like going out for Indian food in SF most of the time since it seems like an overpriced plate of greasy vegetables and/or seafood and/or a piece of chicken (pretty much any Indian restaurant in the Mission and 'Loin qualify). At Amber, it is pricy but worth it -- the quality is there, the menu is interesting and offers something more unique than what I can get at home, and the food is flavorful and delicious. 

I have been to Amber many times and it is the only Indian restaurant I would recommend to friends in the area. 

The one complaint I have about this location is regardless of if you have reservations, there is often still a wait beyond that.
author: Richa A.

description: Went here on a Friday night.  We went early hoping to catch happy hour but the bar was completely packed.  We ordered a couple drinks and the samosas, but were so cramped we scarfed the food down and decided to sit at our table.  We ordered the chaat as an appetizer and the quick fried spinach was perfect!  This appetizer was light but fufilling!  Our table ordered various items, all of which were tasty.  The lamb korma and butter chicken were the stand out dish.  At first look the rice and other side dishes really look expensive.  However, the portions are large and 2-3 servings per order.  The Naan was mediocore, to me it was a bit over priced for 4 thin pieces.  Overall the atmosphere was nice but the menu was a bit expensive for what we were given.
author: Kate F.

description: I eat indian food A LOT, being vegan/veggie for almost a decade. this place is , perhaps, the finest indian food you can find in SF these days. its perfection. every dish, every spice, every presentation. 10 out of 10. Amber is Absolutely the best place to get an indian lunch buffet in the city, they have a wide variety of meat and veggie options, salads, YOGURT (which is some of the best I've ever tasted) and deserts. Its about 23 dollars, but its very very high quality.
author: Teal S.

description:
The restaurant ambience is spectacular. The staff, although very pleasant, had not enough help to accommodate the busy night. Hence, the service was slow.
The food was amazing; arguably one of the best I have eaten. 
I will be back!
author: Dan S.

description:
This restaurant was recommended to us by the concierge at the hotel we were staying downtown San Fran.  

We were going to order from the menu and could not pass up the buffet that was beautifully impressive right when you walk down the stairs from the entrance.  All the servers were extremely friendly and helpful and the selections were vast and tasty.  

We will be back for the veggie kofta that sounded interesting.  Not a traditional take on the kofta and that is what was so exciting about it!!!  I love thoughtful, creative fusion with traditional dishes.  There is always room to grow and combine newness to the old traditional ways...I appreciate this approach because I am a daughter of immigrant Indian parents with traditional values and western creative newness:)!!

I'm excited to go back!
author: Shipra M.

description:
This is an amazing Indian restaurant for its food (we had four appetizers and wine), ambience (warm/cozy sexy lighting and tall ceilings with art that wasn't stark or cold) and location (right near Bart and Yeurba Buena!) The best part, you dont smell like you've eaten in An Indian restaurant. It's a little pricey but well worth the cost and trip.

Enjoy!
author: Karen M.

description:
We decided on Amber India since it was close to Bart for our departure to Oakland airport. We arrived at 2PM. The hostess sat us in a booth. On the way, we walked past a buffet. We sat and turned to my wife and told her, I hope this buffet is not for us. The waitress came and true and behold, that is what they were serving. We asked if we could order off the regular menu and she said we could. We ordered drinks and were waiting for the waitress to bring the menu. My soft drink arrived first. We kept waiting and about 5 to 7 minutes passed with no drink for my wife or menus. Finally they delivered the menus. Another 5 to 7 minutes went by and we still had no second drink. I asked the waitress and she said she would check. The menus look good but pricey. We decided on the buffet since it was a better value.

We went to serve ourselves and it was pretty well picked over. The food also appeared as it had been out there for some time. We should have left, but my wife had not eaten all day so we decided to continue. The food was also semi-cold. Overall, the food was nothing to write home about. Once we did our first serving, our waitress came over and said that the buffet was going to close in 15 minutes. Ok, so why did they not say that to us before we sat down?? So now we found ourselves rushing to get food before they put it away. We decided to finish the food and leave.

Service was marginal, food was sub par, and overall a bad experience. I WILL NOT REPEAT!
author: Jose A.

description: I think so they are best Indian resturant to eat and drink the ambience is very nice special I come here for meetings and the food is also very tasty can't tell no to any thing to eat here
author: Raj S.

description:
Best Indian food I have had....ever. 

* great ambiance & atmosphere 
* sea bass curry: .......speechless. So amazing. The curry was so flavorful but you could taste every bit of the sea bass. Brilliant. 
* okra & lamb were also amazing. 

I started planning my next return before I left the restaurant. So good!!!!! Definitely on the list of favorite meals of all time.
author: Dianne G.

description: This is a fantastic Indian restaurant with excellent food. The choices cater to neophytes and folks wanting authentic indian. The servers were very knowledgeable.
author: Josh B.

description: Great place, authentic upscale Indian food.  Our waitress was very attentive. We started with the samosas which were yummy.  For our main dishes we had the Lamb Vindaloo, it was full of flavor not overly spicy.  My husband and I shared that and the aloo beans ki subzi.  The beans were cooked andante which went nice with the potatoes. Those two dishes were enough for us to share.  My only negative would be that they charge al a cart prices for the basmati rice.  Not a big deal just an observation of something I was surprised at.
author: Anne H.

description: Love the ambiance of the restaurant! I would say this is a high end Indian restaurant, but probably the best Indian food I've ever had! Must try the butter chicken curry
author: Ariel W.

description:
Living in the tenderloin for two years, I was not accustomed to the concept of a "fancy Indian restaurant". My usual go to places were dive-y Indian restaurants which mostly doesn't even accept card. 

Amber was a nice surprise. I can't say that the food is far better than my usual Indian restaurants like Shalimar and Chutney. But I won't say the food was bad either. Everything tasted yummy especially the Saag Paneer and Butter Chicken! I have always come here during lunch hours I've always did the buffet. The price for the buffet is OK for the good food and ambiance. I heard the ala carte menu can get a bit pricy though.

Overall I enjoy Amber, but I still would not prefer it over Shalimar or Chutney.
author: Libby K.

description:
Single-handedly, THE BEST INDIAN food EVER. The Naan is even good!
Started with a mushroom-type soup; delicious! Then the eggplant; OUTSTANDING, then the sea-bass; INSANELY GOOD, couldn't stop with the Ohhs and Ahhs.
author: Candace N.

description:
Food might be great, but the staff at the welcome desk is ill mannered. Specially , they are rude to indians, nothing new knowing the kind of behavior exhibited by the manager at the entrance who happens to be of indian origin.

We were told that there is an happy hour, while we were seated at our table. But we would have to go to the bar for the same and leave the table. We went to the bar and learnt that there was no happy hour it being the weekend. We get back to the manager saying we would rather order food and drinks at the table, and he rudely replied well your table is gone, wait until a table opens up. This despite me having a reservation through open table. Open table and yelp help prevent this behavior if you could, i know you do not support such unfair behavior.
author: Saurabh K.

description:
Amber India is a great place for lunch during the week. I have never been for dinner, but the lunch is buffet style and really good. 

I love the Naan bread, and of course recommend  the butter chicken yum!
author: Georgina G.

description:
Positives: Great service, ambiance, the lamb curry & sea bass curry mmm, sometimes you can watch a yoga class going on in the glass building across the street.

Negative: Feels pretty crowded inside; you'll probably get in for dinner, but might be practically sitting on top of another table.
author: Dagmar H.

description:
Had dinner here.

Pros
Service is very good
Food is very good- butter chicken was great


Cons
I dont like places that charge for RICE unless its really special.
Price- indian food shouldnt be this expensive people...its chicken primarily.

All entrees should come with RICE...not extra...I mean really? who is going to eat an entree without rice or Naan? So I can understand charging for Naan, but charging for Rice is like charging for a glass of tap water. 

So overall great food quality but I can get equally good and maybe more traditional dishes elswhere about 25% cheaper.

You pay for  a great atmosphere and good service with good food....
author: Stephen R.

description: Amber India has multiple locations but this one is the classiest. The food tastes pretty much the same everywhere but the customer service at this locations is not good and hence the 3 stars. Try their Palak chaat and butter chicken.
author: Ric D.

description:
Amber India is an upscale feeling place serving Indian cuisine...in case the name doesn't clue you in.  It's in a busy part of town off of Market, I think.  I'm not a local, so I don't recall, exactly.  Lots of shopping and other places to eat around it.  My wife and I always try to hit up the best local Indian place we can find on Yelp when we're out of town.

We come in the front door and the people at the front desk are dressed to the nines.  All the waiters are dressed very well and the guy that seated us was in a suit.  I felt very under dressed in my shorts and t-shirt.  Something of note...when we went in, they just kind of looked at us.  No one was in front of us, but we weren't seated immediately or even greeted.  This was kind of off putting, but I let it roll of my back because I'm laid back and it's just no big deal.  We were eventually seated after, I guess, they realized we were actually there to eat.

We were seated and everything went as a typical dining experience should go.  Our drink order was taken, we looked at the menu, etc, etc.  I ordered the butter chicken and my wife ordered the chicken biryani.  We had every intention of sharing.  When the food arrived, the chicken biryani came in a cast iron type of pot, which I think it was cooked in.  That was a pretty neat touch, keeping with the typical communal serving of Indian cuisine that I have had.  The butter chicken was served in a dish, while the rice was served separate on a plate.  Just as expected.

My wife is not much of one that can handle hot spice very well.  She will eat it, but not too much of it.  The chicken biryani was very spicy.  The spiciest biryani I have ever had, no doubt.  However, it was FANTASTIC!  Even my wife couldn't stop eating it!  She was pounding four glasses of water while eating, but she really did enjoy it.  The butter chicken was excellent also, albeit a little too sweet for us.  The biryani was definitely the highlight of the meal despite its spice level.

The service, aside from initial impression, was great.  Everyone was dressed well and we were treated very well.  Our drinks were kept full and the staff was classy.

If in the San Francisco area, I would definitely go back again.  Considering the weather there and how much fun we had while there, I see another visit as a definite possibility.  How can you have a definite possibility, anyway?  Meh...you get what I mean.
author: Brandon B.

description:
I am Indian, and have very picky about food.  I was skeptical, given that when eat Indian food at restaurants, typically it is in a more casual environment.

The decor and ambiance is very nice and classy.  The food is good, you will not be disappointed.

The only frustration was the quantity of food--the serving size was a little small.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Classy, trendy, up-scale Indian Restaurant in the heart of the city. Three-story restaurant. Plenty of waiters walking around to tend to needs, and very clean feeling for an indian restaurant. Went for the lunch buffet, and it gets packed up easily. I've heard dinner is the same.

BUFFET:
- array of appetizers & salads 
- 1 fish and 3 chicken entrees
- 3 vegetarian entrees
- tandoori breads & kebabs
- fresh cut fruits & dessert table
- to DIE for Mango Mimosas - first I've ever tasted and its bottomless! #YUMMM!


SUMMARY: Super expensive indian food. You can easily go down the street and get the same foods for way cheaper. The only thing you're paying for is location and ambiance. If you aren't trying to impress - go down the street. #RealTalk.
author: Monalisa M.

description: Average. Pushy staff. Looks nice from the street but the food tastes like slop. Just overpriced slop.
author: Ben S.

description: Still LOVE this restaurant. Came here on a Sunday for lunch and they had a buffet special for approximately $23 a person INCLUDING bottomless mimosas and champagne! What what?! They don't skimp on the food either. I helped myself to butter chicken, goat curry, tandoori chicken, basil shrimp, lentils, spinach, salads, naan, and an arrangement of deserts. What an amazing deal, you get to try so many foods for such a great price! They say Indian people and Chinese people can't do business together because Indians love a good bargain and the Chinese refuse to give one. Well, that's not the case here at Amber. The Indians gave a good bargain and the Chinese took it (happily). =)
author: Linda L.

description: The menu is deceiving! They had some special menu for the Christmas Eve, it says curries are served with rice, roti and daal, but our server told us it is not... It was a big turn off... We knew this place is $$$ so it's not that the prices on the menu surprised us but we didn't feel comfortable once the sever told us what was against what mentioned on the menu. We just ordered one item for the kid with us and decided to go to another near by Indian place! Will not recommend, you don't get what you see!
author: Amit S.

description: A little pricy, but the food is yummy. Perfect for lunch because of its central location in the Financial District and the buffet is great with lots of options. I'd never heard of "Indian-style" wings but had them for the first time yesterday and they were delicious. It took them a bit of time to get us our naans but besides that I loved everything about the experience here and will come again.
author: Jeyashri S.

description:
I'm giving this place 3 stars not because the food was good - it was - but there was such a loud table of guys that came in mid-way through our meal, that thought they were the only one's in the restaurant that it became nearly impossible to hold a conversation and this was my birthday dinner, so that left a little bit of a bad memory for me on the experience.

Ambiance - well - it's a really nice place.  I think I may have been overdressed as there were a lot of tourists types with t-shirts and ball caps that must haven't been able to get into Super Duper down the street.  Not that you need a tuxedo here, but it's a nice place, with an upscale menu and bar, so not necessarily the same as a Sports Bar experience for dining.  I understand they have several locations of this restaurant, so I'll cover the one in Union Square.

Food - We tired a lot - as I don't eat a lot of Indian food, but since this was a special occasion, I tried a lot of items.

Drinks - I had a Berry Martini - it had another name that makes it all India - fancy - but it was a Berry martini - tasty and you get a good kick out of that drink.

Appetizers - had the Sprouted Moong & Anjou Pear Salad - think Chopped Salad - India style - nice lime vinaigrette - recommend this for those veggiesaurs.

Shared an order of Aloo Peas Samosa - they bring two dipping sauces with it - one red and one green - the sauces were so good, I wouldn't let the waiter take them when we were done with the appetizers - I'd like an order of those to go - the appetizers were like an egg roll with spicy potatoes and peas.  We also tried the Black Pepper Crab - and that was kind of like a crab salad - nothing to write home about that one - it sounded better on the menu, then the actual presentation.

Dinner - I had the house special - Butter Chicken - the "signature" dish - of Tandor chicken in a spicy tomato sauce - if you haven't seen a clear thread here "SPICY" is the word of the day - but it's an Indian restaurant, so it didn't disappoint on spices - it just gives everything a very exciting little something extra that makes it unique.

Side order of the Saffron Pulao - the Indian version of rice - it was rice and I recommend you order your own bowl, as our waiter thought we could split it between the two of us - not really enough to cover all that you get with the main meal....BUT we order Naan in the "flavor" versions of Garlic and Pesto - a small up-charge, but I'm a big fan of both garlic and pesto, so worth the extra for me and I used it sop up some of that tomato sauce, which was soooo good, you can see why it is the house special.

Good service - we were never rushed.  All the food came out at a good pace and was always hot and flavorful.  The only bummer was the 8-10 guys that came in during the meal and really were not friendly dinners - this place isn't cheap when you add all the extras on, so when you get a Sports Bar yell fest going on during a really good meal, it does put a damper on the evening.  Worth trying but ask for a quiet table - not all the two-seaters are next to the "family" seating area.
author: Steve A.

description:
I went here for dinner with a couple friends, one of whom is an Indian food fanatic, and we were very impressed. I was surprised it was crowded considering it was a Monday night but then realized why . . . because it's awesome!

We went family style with the chicken masala, spinach, and one other dish that i'm forgetting. Anyways, I was very excited to find an Indian restaurant that was elegant, slightly upscale and would be great for a date night. I'd consider this place unique as far as Indian restaurants go.
author: Lauren B.

description:
After a long day of wine tasting in Napa having eaten minimal amounts of food, the bf and I came back to SF ravenous, craving the same thing: Indian food!!  We began our yelp search as soon as we got off the bart at Powell station, and within 2 minutes, trusty Yelpers led us to Amber India.  I usually relate good, rustic, hearty foods to hole-in-the-wall places, so I was a bit skeptical when I entered Amber India and saw its chic and contemporary decor.  But my skepticism melted away as soon as the naan smothered in butter chicken sauce met my taste buds.  Holy crap it was good.  The butter chicken dish reminded me of chicken tikka masala, only richer, creamier and a tad sweeter.  Equally impressive was the Bombay Biryani, a flavorful chicken and rice dish.  

Quite pricey for Indian fare, but presentation, decor and service made up for the third dollar sign.
author: Eunice J.

description:
Went there for Dinner Tuesday Night.  We were so hungry. Finding the restaurant using iPhone was a pain, every single app gives wrong directions.  The receptionist was unable to give direction properly and we wasted over 15 minutes going around, they can be better at it.

The decoration/ambiance is really nice.  We were seated at a table near entrance.  They have better seats, I can't complain because we arrived lil late.  Our order came out quick, we ordered Paneer Lababdar, Bhara Baaingan, Daal Amber, Rice, Nan, Roti, Raita & Gulab Jamun.  Let's start with the best, Bhara Baaingan was so delicious it's one of the best I have had so far.  Paneer Lababdar, good but not great. Daal had lot of creme; taste wise not bad, but could have been well cooked.  

The ONLY & REAL disappointment was the SIZE of Nan/Roti/Paratha & Rice.  Guys let's be fair.  One order of bread or rice SHOULD be enough for one person, the quantity of rice served was a JOKE.  

Prices for Dishes were NOT BAD.  Price wise, it's lil upside, it's understandable given the location, costs, rents etc. in SFO.  Two lil pieces of Gulab Jamun were $7, it's over the top.  

The ONLY area where they deserve 5***** is service.  It was awesome.  It's because of service I am giving it 4****.  Will Definitely go back.
author: Paul G.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised!

I usually avoid restaurants which have multiple locations within a city, always gives me a bad feeling about the place. Since I only live a few blocks away from Amber and saw the sign countless times I thought I'd give it a try before I went traveling.

The service was pretty good but the receptionist was a little dicey with certain customers, thankfully not with me. We got seated sooner than expected and the service at the table was great.

The food was pretty good as well. The garlic naan wasn't as strong as I was hoping but the sauces in the curries made up for it. The chicken curry was nice and creamy with a very runny sauce, which makes dipping all the more fun. The prawn curry we ordered was sadly a little thicker and a bit spicier. Still very good and we got it doggie bagged to eat the next day.

My only issue is maybe it's a little bit pricey for what's on offer. I didn't feel like I got anything special out of the experience yet paid a little more than what I usually would for Indian food. Would certainly eat here again though.
author: Greg C.

description:
I thought the food was good yet different. I invited a friend along who chose to look down on the restaurant only because he doesn't like people from India. How rude is that?! His fat ass order food and didn't eat it....  He didn't even leave a tip.  What a jerk! I paid for the meal and the very least as a gentleman, he could have left a tip... He even talked about the waitress.... Jack ass date..been knowing this fool for over 20 years and he left a sad review on this restaurant...also he said I was a blind date and he wanted to hurry up and leave because of the conversation...needless to say this jerk is married! Need I say more? I'm very happy I didn't take him to Yoshi's. I save this outing for someone with more class and less weight and more manners.

I enjoyed my food and the waitress was nice.
author: Alicia W.

description: Weekend buffet was $19.95.  Delicious food, including made to order appams.  Butter chicken, mutter paneer, it was all so good...and bottomless mimosas!
author: Nicole B.

description: What a joke. $28 to stand in line for 25 minutes, for a buffet!? The line literally snaked down the hallway past the bathroom. No thanks...I'll gladly take my  $28 and go to a restaurant that actually serves you the food, not the other way around. Isn't that why you go to a restaurant in the first place??
author: Jo E.

description:
We were excited to try this expensive lunch buffet ($23 per person), since our cheaper indian lunch buffet( $12), had gone down the hill over the years.

WOW...did we feel ripped off. I could not help wondering, with all the Indian people eating at this buffet, what they could be thinking about this food.

Why was it was terrible to us?
It was cold, bland(and I don't mean in heat, I mean flavor).
Butter chicken was alright, nan was flavorless, tandoori was not marinated enough nor had that nice charred flavor.

It was just mediocre for the price. We had much higher expectations based on the price. Our Indian food craving was unsatisfied and we visited our favorite (and much cheaper) Indian street food place over in Berkeley the very next day.

The best thing here was the rice pudding, seriously, but nothing special.
Dessert options were sad too.
While other drinks were included in the price, the Chai was not...very odd!
Service was insignificant. Layout of buffet was a little chaotic.

I would not recommend their lunch buffet based on our experience & will not return.
author: Elektra T.

description: My coworker and I decided to head over to Amber for some samosas and some wine. Were both vegetarian and they have a wide selection. Went straight to the bar and was quickly greeted. The bartender, didn't catch his name was very knowledgable and helpful (and had a really cool haircut) and served us promptly. He got to enjoy ambers amazing food and wine while watching their talented bartenders do thier thing. I'm giving this place 5 stars!
author: Michelle D.

description:
The ambiance of this place is ridiculously amazing. And you pay for it. 

Let's be real, the food at this place (although tasty) fails to live up to its price, surroundings, and service. I ordered the Butter Chicken, Garlic Chive Naan, and the Samosas. The Butter Chicken was really just Chicken Tikka Masala. I have an issue with them slightly altering the name of it to make it sound more original, but it was pretty good. Standard Tikka Masala sauce but the chicken was super tender and pretty juicy--rare for this dish. I just could digest paying $19.95 for a tiny bowl of it. The Garlic Chive naan was decent. Nothing special. Nothing you couldn't get for $2 somewhere else. But I paid $4. And the Samosas were good. I really enjoyed them because they were smaller. Possibly a negative? Maybe. Except smaller Samosas means a larger proportion of fried outer skin and I'm always down for some fried deliciousness. 

The service, however, was EXCELLENT. Not once did I ever need to ask for my water glass to be refilled and the waitress was super tentative and quick to replenish our basket of naan. The decor is beautiful, with rich woods and candlelight. The bar looks amazing, and I might go back simply to sit and have a cocktail. 

Overall, this place has decent food, although, in my opinion, not worth paying 3x what you could be paying for Indian food elsewhere. The restaurant is beautiful, but  if I'm going to be slopping up some tikka masala with naan and smelling like Indian food anyways, I don't really think I need to be eating by candlelight and sitting in a cushioned chair. Amber is a cool Indian eatery, but not anything to be blown away by.
author: Michelle Q.

description: Avoid if you are a single person. They will not give you a table even if there is one available. Happened to me 2 times in one week; so I know that I am not just imagining it.
author: G S.

description:
Amber India is amazing. Alas, you get what you pay for, because the quality of the food reflects in the price. 

The food is just awesome. I love me some Indian food, and Amber India is at the top of my favorites. My first experience at Amber India was in Mountain View, but the SF location is much better. 

The restaurant itself is really awesome inside, and it's perfect for a date night or taking your parents. My bf and I asked the server for his suggestions on food, and we were not disappointed with a single thing, from appetizer (crab), entrees (lamb stew and tandoori chicken) and rice, and dessert (mango creme brulee). 

The prices are pretty high, but it's definitely a meal you can walk away feeling like you got your money's worth. There's nothing worse than blowing a lot of money on a "meh" meal. 

DO get a reservation, as they can get busy.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Went to the Sunday Lunch Buffet and was amazed by the ambiance, food and spectacular service!!

Everything you have heard about this place is true when it comes to the butter chicken, its amazing!

Top picks
-Indian Butter chicken curry
-Panjabi style Lamb Korma
- Samosas with chutney
- Saffron Rice
- Mixed Lentil Dal
-Tandoori Chicken

As someone who hails from south Asian ancestry, finding a truly great Indian restaurant can be very hard, but Amber India is definitely one of the best in the bay area!!

If you are visiting SF make sure you come here for their Sunday Brunch buffet, 20 dollars all you can eat and they give you mango champagne, too! Highly recommended!
author: Sam N.

description: Great Indian food! I love lamb saag and although it wasn't on the menu, the waiter said it wasn't a problem. No reservation but they seated me right away and the service was excellent. It is a tad pricey but to be expected for the area.
author: Sugi W.

description: We tried 4 appetizers, 2 different naan, the sea bass and scallop entrees. Everything was delicious. I haven't eaten at a lot of Indian restaurants before. I really enjoyed this meal and would definitely come back again.
author: Paula Y.

description:
$30 for a lunch buffet is a bit much...for two, the tab came to under $80.  Normally it's ~$20 but I guess special flair for Mother's Day accounted for the $10 uptick.

You get what you pay for, though- high-quality ingredients like asparagus, saffron, oyster mushrooms, walnuts, and special stations for dosas (banana, spinach...), fusion Indian 'nachos' - puffy fried chip-like things with toppings like beans and yogurt.  I don't know if these items were special for Mother's Day only.

Mimosas were included.

Tasty food- I was full after one plate.  Great ambience.  Very crowded and a wait despite reservations- luckily the uber friendly wait staff let us in as early as possible.
author: SF O.

description:
Excellent meal here; the service impeccable, and the dishes were what it should be-- upscale, very well-done Indian food that can be adjusted to make it more spicy, the way Indian food should be.

Excellent fried spinach, and curries.  Seabass cooked to perfection. The naan is delicious.
author: Eric C.

description: Was able to dine here because I was staying with a friend at the Marriott who recommended it. So glad he did because everything was excellent! Since he had been here before, we trusted him to order the spinach paneer, butter chicken, a sea bass dish, and assorted naan. I also tried the samosas while waiting for a table in the lounge. Everything was delicious! My favorite dish was the sea bass; the fish was melt in your mouth buttery and perfectly flaky. So good. This is Indian fine dining at its best. I wish I lived nearby so i could take advantage of the lunch buffet! Tip: don't stuff your face here before bar-hopping. You'll be too full to feel a buzz!
author: Mymy N.

description:
I ate here with my ex and another family member a while back.  It was quite a treat!

We had some tandoori chicken, some chicken biryani and a few appetizers with naan bread.  VERY good flavor and the service was great.  We didn't spend a lot of time here though, we just stopped in for lunch really quick.  

But I LOVED their naan bread, it was crispy outside, soft inside and a light garlicky flavor-- just the way I like it.  The food was flavorful, but not overly spicy.  Great feel to the inside of the place.  Pricing is about average, but if you want good Indian food, I would advise you never to go "cheap".
author: Melissa V.

description:
In short: If you are going for the love of food, I recommend this place.  However, unless you want to rid yourself of your special someone, please don't plan a date or any special occasion at this restaurant. They people who run this place are bound to disappoint you.

Full Sob Story:

The food at this place is delicious, however, the people operating this place should not be in the hospitality business. The only reason I give this place one star is because of the food. Otherwise they don't even deserve that.

I had made reservations at this place for a special occasion. My in laws were visiting our place for the first time and I decided to take them to Amber.  We made a reservation for 8 PM on a Saturday night. We got the usual its unusually busy tonight and we can hang out at the bar.  We did not mind that as we were not in a huge hurry and didn't mind sipping on some cocktails as we waited.  25 minutes after our reservation time, they came in and told us that they had our table ready.  So we went to our table.  You would think that for making the customer wait 25 minutes after they would have given us a decent seat.  Oh but you would be so wrong about that.  The table was between the kitchen entrance and a place where all the waiters picked up water from. Further the table was diagonally placed next to a pillar making it really awkward for sitting next to the pillar.

On any other day I wouldn't have cared and just enjoyed the food.  However, I had made reservations a week ahead of time for a special occasion. This just started to get on my nerves.  I went back to the hostess and asked her if she could relocate us.  To which she complied and said we can go ahead and wait further at the Bar.  We waited  another 20 minutes at the bar/lounge. At this point we had been waiting 50 minutes past our reservation time.  So I decided to go wait at the reception.

At the reception, much to my surprise all the guests (parties for 3, 4, 5, 6 walkins... whatever the number)  were being seated promptly. This got me very annoyed and I approached the General Manager, Anupam Bhatia, mentioning the whole situation. Instead of trying to ease things for me, he blamed me for not liking our originally assigned table. He said that the awkward table between the kitchen and serving table was not as bad as I conjured it up to be and it was our fault.  Given that four people in my party were in consensus about that table, I hardly think his reaction was warranted. 

So all in all great food, but horrible experience. I will just not be going back on principle. I hope the chef moves to a restaurant that has a better hospitality team. Otherwise his success is being held back by the people who run the place.
author: M D.

description: Went to Amber for lunch and to my surprise encountered a rude person at the reception (the guy). It's embarrassing to take clients to this restaurant. Will definitely not come again. The only saving grace was the food was good.
author: Karan S.

description:
Great food but a little expensive for what it is.

Overall it's excellent Indian food: good spices, good flavor, and mostly authentic food. 

I started with the pineapple rasam. It's an unconventional recipe but was surprisingly delicious.

I had the butter chicken and naan for dinner. The chicken was delicious though I found it, namely the sauce, richer than necessary. I was told it was shredded chicken but found the chicken pieces to be a reasonable size. There were an unusually high number of small bones found throughout though.
author: Kevin V.

description: This has become our go-to spot for happy hours after work.  I just have to give a big thanks to the bartenders here for being able to accommodate all of us and be so friendly and helpful!  The drinks are tasty with the good prices.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Service was unbeatable. 
For Valentine's Day, they had a pre-set menu to choose from and when I asked what was vegan and it turned out that nothing for the first course or the third was vegan, our server went back to the chef and made a special request for me for some samosas that weren't even an option that night. The woman who was our server really made a point to make sure I was happy. And I didn't even ask her to go out of her way! She immediately took it upon herself and made the night that much better. 

And the food is already great on its own but it's the little things like that that make this Amber India the best. And worth every penny.
author: Audrey V.

description: Came here for happy hour and had a great time.  The ambiance is nice and I love the background music.  We got the edleberry mimosa which was great and shared two appetizers of the potatoes and puri puri.  The appetizers are exquisite and I would come back to try other appetizers.  The happy hour goes until 7pm which is another bonus.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This is my favourite Indian restaurant in SF! Both the food and the ambiance are worth the 5 stars. And I'm not easily impressed by Indian restaurants as my standards for good Indian food is set by so many great places in India. 

The palak chat is my favourite dish on the menu. Its served in the lounge as well and a perfect snack to go with anything from their unique cocktails menu.
author: Paawan K.

description: The service is wonderful but the place is Hella Loud! So it's not the place for a nice quiet dinner. The food is good but I would recommend doing a family style meal rather than ordering individually. I was surprised by the size of the restaurant. From the outside, it looks bigger then it really is. But the bar is nice and the food is well worth trying this place out for Indian cuisine.
author: Tony L.

description: Awesome butter chicken....better than what I have had in last few years in India also.
author: A M.

description:
I've said this a number of times to a number of people, but try as I might they just don't listen: my name is Robin, and I don't have a afternoon appetite. So when a colleague uttered the words "lunch buffet," I kind of freaked. Fixed prices! All you can eat! Mystery items! Dishes under heating lamps! All of that *plus* my mini mid-day appetite means that I am easily one of *the* worst people you could ever bring to a lunch buffet. But then something happened - after running through torrential SF rain (seriously, does it ever *not* rain here?) we opened the doors to Amber, and a warm waft of curried air hit me like a typhoon. 

I effing LOVE Indian food.

And this is no regular Indian buffet. With only about 20 or so items on the table, it was immediately apparent that - contrary to what one might think about buffets - quality actually trumps quantity here. In place of pounds upon piles of greasy, sauce-laden varieties of mystery meat (possibly chicken?), there were actual distinguishable dishes. And jeeeebus were they good. The right amount of spice, the perfect length of cooking time, the best Indian food I've had in years. Srsly. 

I rolled out the door happy and full, and felt like what I imagine Jason did when he finally got the Golden Fleece. Triumphant, I conquered the quest of the buffet.
author: Robin M.

description: The lunchtime buffet deal is the best! High quality Indian food with a great selection. Great dining atmosphere too.
author: Penny C.

description:
A gluten-free perspective:
It was almost a year ago since I visited Amber.  Unfortunately I'm disheartened to say that my favorite dish, the Biryani, has changed.  It's no longer the flavorful concoction that I remember and worse still they bring it out with a bread-encrusted top (which they then proceed to saw off in front of you).  It's all show and no taste (this includes my order of the Four-Chili Rubbed Sea Bass).  The only redeeming part of the meal was the Malabari Shrimps.  I'm sad to say that I probably won't return.  The price of their meals no longer match the taste.
author: G B.

description:
"This is the best Indian food I've ever had!" - Matthew G. (Julia G.'s elated little brother)

After an exciting Giants game I took the fam to Amber India for a nice dinner (ya know, because after stuffing our faces with hot dogs and ice cream we were still hungry). My family loves Indian food but because none of them live in San Francisco (or India for that matter), it's rare they have the opportunity to get high quality sh*t. 

Amber India is all-around top notch, from the impeccable service to 5-star worthy dishes; everything was just as it should be when you're sitting down to spend some of your hard earned cash on high quality food. 

The butter chicken and crispy spinach were my favorites; I will keep coming back again and again, just for those two things. That's not to say that the rest wasn't amazing too because it was. My father ordered a slew of stuff when we sat down; I can't remember it all by name or I would start listing. Just note, the entire menu is a win-win.

Where's Mary Murphy when I need her? Amber India is on my Hot Tamale Train! WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!
author: Julia N.

description: The shrimp dish I had was very good with just the right amount of spice. The temperature though was lacking which is the only reason I'm not giving it a 4 star rating. Beware they charge $4.50 for rice and naan (each) - it doesn't come with the meal. Reservations are recommended for 2 or more. There were a lot of kids there who were noisy...could have just been bad luck but other than that it has nice ambiance and a great bar/lounge area in the top. Good date spot minus the kids that were loud. I would definitely go again!
author: Neal B.

description:
Pretty delicious, yet pricey. The meals are not absurdly large (portion size). I think the food was delicious, but seemed to cost twice as much as what I normally pay for similar food.

If it wasn't for me being super ridiculously hungry and slightly intoxicated, I would have passed.  But whatever, the food was super flavorful and my company paid the bill!
author: Robert B.

description: Kutran Warqi on the bar menu! Yumm!
author: Tushar K.

description:
Dined at Amber last evening and ordered the Nalli Vindaloo.  It was without question the BEST version of Lamb Vindaloo I've ever tasted.  The lamb was truly falling off the bone, and the vindaloo sauce was spot on.  I couldn't recommend this dish more highly and this alone is 5 star worthy.

I had a side of rice and naan along with my meal.  One service item I wasn't completely pleased with was in asking for some raita with my meal.  I wound up with an additional bill item of $4.95 for spinach raita.  I would have simply preferred to have been told there would be a charge for it.  The raita didn't taste quite right at all to me with spinach, and I really missed the traditional cucumber version.

I sat at the bar, and some of the cocktails heading out to customers looked really great and were made with a lot of care.
author: Michael F.

description:
Really good, really authentic Indian food.  Spicy and delicious and really well informed staff.  Service was great except that we had to ask for more Naan bread a few times.  Would have been ok except my mouth was on fire and I was dying.  The table next to us hardly touched theirs and I almost reached over a grabbed a piece.  

The place was packed and LOUD and that was on a Tuesday.  Given the quality of the food, location and service, it is very well priced.
author: Kathleen H.

description:
To paraphrase Spinal Tap, this place deserves eleven stars (or six on Yelp).

The food was awesome, and they have a varied menu beyond the usual Indian staples.  I though the fig-orange tandoori chicken was incredible.  It's sweet and juicy and tender and orgasmic.   You get a great value for the price.  Service was very good, and they have a good drink / wine menu.  If I could, I would have tasted everything on the menu.  I can't wait to go back!
author: L S.

description:
Food from a third world country shouldn't cost this much.  Honestly there is nothing bad about this place, but there is also nothing great about it.  It's the type of place you'd want to bring your family for a nice dinner, but do not expect above and beyond Indian food.  The atmosphere is classy but not over the top stuffy or high end, so this is what you're really paying for here.

The daal makhi was terrific, but the rest of the dishes were boiler plate with a high price tag.  The fish curry had a fishy smell to it, and the calamari app was good but not as good as Aslam's Rasoi.  Some paneer tikka and a butter chicken were given OK nods as well.  Basic theme: it's just typical Indian food and pricey.  

The best Indian food in town for me is still Aslam's Rasoi and Dosa (limited menu of course)...not the best, but in this city it's the best we have.  Pakwan and Naan n Curry are still amazing to me, but only for a dive quick and dirty meal.  You're getting 3 stars, but I wont be back.
author: A A.

description: Best Indian buffet I've had in the area.  Particularly good spot for vegetarians and pescetarians. Full of flavor and there were even some lesser known dishes available (eg, kadi/gramflour).
author: Rachel S.

description: Impressed with dinner and service once again. One of my faves for sure.
author: Mark S.

description:
Good indian food, with mixed service at a high price.  But enjoyable.

Lunch buffet on Sunday is like $20 and a mango lassi is like $5, so it all adds up.  Sometimes they offer you a free mango mimosa but sometimes they don't; who knows how they decide. 

Buffet is usually great but more recently they've been putting strange rice dishes out there (if you ask for plain saffron rice, they will give it to you, no charge).  Recently service has been very friendly too.

Dinner is also pricey but it's the first indian restaurant that served my plate after bringing the food to the table.  What a surprise! 

Sometimes it's super crowded, so book on opentable and save yourself the wait.
author: Traci H.

description: Lunch buffet rocked my world. ROCKED.
author: Andrew K.

description:
The food here was delicious-best Indian food I've ever tasted. It was pretty crowded for a Wednesday night and we were seated in a funny arrangement very close to the table next to us-but, after a few minutes, we didn't even notice anymore.

The service was excellent and our waiter made some really nice suggestions--I got the baby-eggplant with caramelized onions and almonds and it was to die-for. The seasoning and spice were perfect. My fiance got Nalli Vindaloo (a lamb dish) and couldn't rave enough about it. The garlic naan and saffron rice were also very tasty and were nice additions to the meal.

Overall, a wonderful (albeit a bit expensive) meal and experience- a truly great, upscale place for a date. When I'm back in SF, I plan on going here agan!
author: Emily F.

description:
***Good***
Best Indian food I know of in bay area, whether it is south bay or in the city.

***Bad***
Pricey.  

***Recommendation***
Chicken Tikka is awesome. Boring recco I know. But it is great.
author: Nick K.

description: I was dying for some good Indian food the other night and this place really hit the spot! The cuisine is North Indian (as opposed to South Indian where Dosa's and Thali's are high on the menu). North Indian food uses a lot of ingredients such as tamarind, yogurt, and coconut and they're used in ways I would never have thought of! We started with the Calamari. It was cooked in a light broth infused with lime and chili and coconut milk. For our entrees we had what was THE most amazing Trout I've ever had - cooked again with coconut milk but this time in a thick spicy sauce. (I asked the waitress to turn up the spice level but you can choose not to). We also ordered these huge scallops cooked in a tangy tomato and tamarind based sauce and served with - wait for it - mashed avocado and banana! I'm not a fan of bananas but this was good!!!!! Ok so now I'm drooling ... You have to try this place. Make a reservation though as it gets extremely packed and note that most dishes range in the $18-26 range - but oh so worth it! Enjoy!!
author: Sabina H.

description:
the WORST customer service by waiters.  the HIGH-END indian restaurant can't even think of that.

So for those two I have mentioned,  We went there so many times for lunch buffet it was fine (because you don't interact with waiters much) and weekend dinner also bunch of times; Recent visit (which made us so frustrating to peaks that made us write this review) an indian waitress who looks pretty but as always looks are deceptive and she turned out to be a total bitch she was totally rude. So long story short, we ordered Paneer tikka we got it and as always quantities are very small for their 20$ prices for each item. We got hardly 8 small paneer cubes and that too taste was not that great compared to low-end indian restaurants which server far better indian food than this amber. So now I took a paneer tikka cube to eat i saw HAIR on it. I have not checked all paneer cubes though so I called waiter to show that and get another plate (till that I am fine; now she made all us frustrate with her answer) her reply is like this with out even apologizing: "Oh I have not seen any customer complaining before in last 3months; never seen thats strange let me show it chef will get another plate" this is her answer. We even told her "we have seen few COCKROACHES last time when we visited for dinner her reply: "Oh I have never seen that happen before" and she left. She got plate back now even with less paneer cubes than before. We finished our dinner and asked her to get check. So, by this time we were expecting she would at least take that paneer tikka money out from check; NO she still included the price. When we wrote less TIP for her (for such worst customer service we had obviously we should have not write even that 6$ for her service) she came back to ask for more money. And she even said directly to us if you want i can include tip and give you total then you can pay if you don't want to write TIP which was so RUDE and MEAN. Out of all above, after she gave shit about TIP we had to write a big amount for her even though she does not deserve a single penny; then she left and infront of us she was BITCHING with all other waitresses/waiters about us. (OMG never seen such kind of attitude people anywhere else she is definitely UNFIT for any job)

Come on!!! If you don't want to be a WAITRESS then go do some other job instead of customer dealing and giving shit to customers like this and making not to come to your restaurant again. I would definitely be not going again and I will not recommend my FRIENDS and COLLEAGUES to even visit this place. They have very less choice in MENU for Dinners hardly few to select and keep eating same thing whenever ever you visit. I never write any yelp reviews even though how bad restaurant is and their food is (I instead don't visit that place again) this place has good FOOD it will survive only if it keeps professional people as waitress and some hygiene.
author: Hari B.

description: There are a lot of restaurants that serve as good or better Indian food for less.  The dinner entrees are $20-30.  We had the Tandoori sampler (2 pieces of chicken, 2 prawns and 2 lamb kofta/sausages) and the Tandoori sea bass.  The sampler was fine but not great.  The sea bass was not cooked enough, it was wet inside, which was surprising because usually Tandoori cooks things dry.  Very disappointing.  Others in our party had the curried sea bass (better than the tandoori version) and some vegetarian dishes (also good).  The price was more alarming considering that bread and rice were extra.  If the food had been excellent, maybe the price would be OK, but it wasn't.  We've had better Indian food for half the price.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Top notch Indian!  Four of us ate family style so we all got to try many things and it was tough to say which I liked best.  Being from NY and spending a fair amount of time on Brick Lane in London I have had a lot of good Indian food and this place is right up there with the best.

Butter chicken was great but it is just their version of Chicken Tikka Masala.  It is great but in a restaurant this good you would do well to be more adventurous.
author: Free M.

description:
Excellent lunch buffet. Very clean and great lighting (though this was during day but I'm always impressed when lights are dimmed appropriately). It's the type of place you can eat with a client. Yes, it's pricey, but food was great and place was up to business standards. Good usual meat dishes (tikka masala, chicken curry, tandoori) and was very pleasantly surprised to find good variety of vegetables as well (okra, hearts of palm salad, mushroom salad, cauliflower and potatoes).

Highly recommended!
author: G S.

description:
We had dinner here right before doing dancing. We ordered the "dum" style lamb biryani and the black pepper chicken (kozhi melagu)  with naan. For drinks we had the pink elephant and a variation of a mint julep (forgot the name)

We thought the lamb biryani was great and the meat was really tender. However we thought the chicken curry left a bit to be desired and was too one note. The drinks were both great. 

Service was also good, our server was kind and courteous.
author: Arjuna S.

description:
Oh Amber....

From the amazing Pepper Crab starter to the Curry Sea Bass, this was one memorable meal. My father (a south Indian native and somewhat of a Indian food snob) was pleasantly surprised and was still talking about his Kashmiri Roganjosh on the way to the airport three days later. 

As everyone else has said- the drinks are great, atmosphere is very comfortable and the food makes you feel warm inside. 

Make a reservation for 2 or 12, you and your guest will not be disappointed!
author: Antonia L.

description: Bottomless brunch for $23+tax/tip, which is great value compared to amber's regular menu. Can't go wrong with it. Food-wise, around 1.5 times the usual variety of Indian dishes that I find at other buffets. Quality was above average (though nothing ridiculously amazing). Definitely tried some new dishes that I haven' seen before. Service was a bit lacking (slow plate collection and drink refills), but it was a busy weekend afternoon so a bit more excusable. Will be back again.
author: Will Z.

description: AMAZING! OMG. Best Indian food I've ever had. The restaurant didn't have a heavy smell of all the spices and such. And the food just melted in your mouth. Will definitly be going back!
author: Anna N.

description:
-Food: Loved the tandoori chicken wings and naan with lamb!
-Drinks: I had a shot of El Matador tequila. It was ok. The bf had "Amber Rose". It's not bad.
-Service: Our servers were pretty attentive, and we didn't have to wait too long for our orders.
-Atmosphere: It was pretty cozy in the bar area despite its size. The music wasn't too loud, and the couches are pretty comfy.

Will definitely come back! :)
author: Nicole G.

description: 5 stars for ambience, service, outstanding food. Beautiful decor, pleasant staff and delicious food with plenty of options for vegetarians. Tandoori chicken, fish curry and dahl were especially well done. Dosa/uttapam station was just ok, but everything else was so good the only drawback is overeating! Try the mimosa with mango juice for a special treat. Truly a somewhat hidden gem amongst the plethora of Indian restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Sarah M.

description: Bar bites are tasty Indian fare... Nothing out of the ordinary but nevertheless good Indian food.
author: Madhusudhan R.

description:
This review is just for the weekend lunch/brunch menu, which opens at noon and goes until 3:00 PM and is ~$20/person before tax/tip.  At first, I was a little hesitant about dining at a "higher end/fancy" Indian restaurant. Admittedly, most of my Indian cuisine experience has been from the hole-in-the-wall joints - and not knockin' any of them, because they for the most part have been delish. I just didn't know if I could justify paying 3x the cost for a dish I would generally pay $6-7 for... especially if I probably wouldn't be able to tell the difference between them.

So in the end, could I tell the difference between Amber's high quality ingredients and something I could get at say, Lahore Kahari?  Honestly no; I couldn't tell the difference between Amber's food and a (really good) cheap eat Indian food. But I will say that Amber's food is very good, and taste-wise, ranks very high in my limited Indian food experience.

What you're really paying a bit extra for is the fabulously attentive service (my mimosa flute and the BF's mango juice - both coming with the weekend lunch/brunch price BTW - were always refilled promptly when empty and our finished buffet plates were removed quickly), the nice sit-down decor, and the ambiance.  In the end, we left completely stuffed and satisfied with our meal and service.

I don't know if I would come here for dinner, as it is expensive and especially since I couldn't discern the difference in food quality between it and a good Indian cheap-eat. But I would say the weekend lunch/brunch is a good value, and an especially nice place to take out-of-town guests or for large groups without the typical SF weekend brunch wait.
author: Mercutio k.

description: Amazing food! We went in for the lunch buffet. Good price for the different selection of food. The biryani is delicious! Most of the stuff was gluten free!
author: Ally N.

description:
Been there many times.
It's pretty decent and good place as far as ambience and food is concerned. 
Tasted Good North Indian flavors here, close to that in India ..
author: Garima S.

description:
This review is specifically for the happy hours at Amber.  It was wonderful!  My friend and I came here for a drink before splitting on evening.  I believe it was like a hump day evening, so really we thought we'd easily find a seat.  However, come 5 p.m., when the happy hour starts, we got there to notice that it was already filling up quite a bit.  That's impressive.

Nice high ceilings, medium sound volume - mainly in the electronica regime.  That's certainly not my favorite, but it supplemented the trendy atmosphere affirmatively.  The mixologists seem to know what they're doing and as is now becoming a norm, they have Indian twists to all their drinks.  I of course went with my Old faithful gin martini and my friend got a glass of wine. 

The small plates were actually very delicious, reasonably affordable for a happy hour and feels just right after eating.  It's not overly filling and yet keeps your hunger down for a couple of hours.  I'm not fond of the location.  Too high profile and also too touristy.  But I can live with that.  I'm usually a guy who likes quiet atmospheres in not so jazzy parts of town.  Yet I think this place deserves 4 stars because they really delivered on a 5 p.m. happy hour affair.
author: Aditya R.

description:
This is the worst experience I had combined with too expensive rip-off.
The fried items are too oily, desert is not so great neither traditional drinks are worth what you pay.   For sure ambiance is good & seems like your are charged heavily  for only those decoration, ambiance. & since you paid for that so just a matter of little courtesy you got some random food (not least to mention, enriched of oil) ...this is the same food which some less expensive restaurant as well would have served for less price & may be even in more healthy manner, last but not least, do not try any Lassi (sort of butter milk) , it was kind of rotten but to suppress that test they added lots of salt & other powder to it. 

Good thing is you will feel proud about yourself for boosting economy, because gratuity is more than 20% on your bill :D :D :D
author: Prashant S.

description:
Definitely a place to go and spend some money on good indian food.
We went here for a little celebration and the wait staff, host, and serving staff was quick and professional.

The food was very tasty and we enjoyed the food enough to take some home with us.

We had the Chicken and the Salmon - don't remember the exact names but they were very very good.
author: Walter W.

description:
Stopped in with Classy Mike, with a guest appearance from Mr. Matt-boto, during our road trip from New York to Los Angeles.

This was our first stop in San Francisco, meaning that 1) I had just driven for 3500 miles, and 2) I wouldn't have to drive for a few more days.  Therefore, I figured, a celebration was in order.  

So, in the spirit of celebration, I immediately trampled a few children en route to the bar, where I delighted at the specialty cocktail list.  I think what I had was a Raspberry Julep (it was some kind of Julep, it's not listed on the web site at the moment).  Anyway, it was very good, and I sampled the others' drinks and they were also quite good, and I usually don't even like cocktails.

I immediately downed two drinks, so take my opinion of the food that follows with a lick of salt off the arm, but I thought the food was pretty, pretty, pretty good.  The butter chicken, the signature dish, was the real star of the table and not to be missed.  The break basket (an assortment of naan) was a unique addition to the meal as well.  I thought the fancy-shmancy decor would mean subpar food, but Amber is actually quite excellent.

Food: 21/25 stars
Ambiance: 21/25 stars
Service: 22/25 stars
Bathroom: I don't think I used it (pretty amazing, all things considered)
Probability of going back: 66%
author: Randy S.

description:
There is nothing wrong with this food. It tastes good, is cooked as it should be, and, as a plus, the atmosphere of the restuarant is nice and they have a lot of wines.

But I wouldn't go back. It's super pricey, and I think you are paying for the atmosphere and the wine list. 

Instead, go to Little Delhi a couple blocks over on Eddy. The food is fantastic, its hole-in-the-wall charming, and its the price you want to pay for lamb + rice (and...they have wine).
author: Catt G.

description: This restaurant does not believe in Hospitality, we called in for reservation they flat said no. So we walked in and it took us 45 minute to get the table. Food is average and very pricy. Not worth trying.
author: Ken P.

description:
On another girl's afternoon outing, my two best girlfriends and I went here for the all-you-can-eat lunch buffet. One of said friends is Indian and a vegetarian. The three of us showed up and after figuring out where the entrance to the restaurant was (a little confusing, really), we entered and made our way to a table. There were a number open and we, coincidentally, chose one near the carafes of mimosa. 

We quickly beelined towards the food, which was varied, ample, beautiful, and not alltogether authentic indian food. For instance, the raita wasn't traditional cucumber yogurt but was flavored. Not what you expect but not at all unpleasant. We each loaded up plates and chowed down.

Waiters arrived to pour us glasses of water and asked whether we'd like mimosas. We eagerly accepted once we were told they were included in the price of the buffet. Service wasn't wholly attentive, but we were delivered naan and had refills of water and mimosa at least once throughout our meal. 

It was a bit expensive but delicious and unique.
author: Lily R.

description: Amazing selection for vegetarians and non vegetarians. Weekend brunch is around 22 per person but includes bottomless champagne/mimosas. Great selection, excellent staff and delicious food.  Definitely worth it.
author: Nima M.

description:
Every time I leave Austin to go to San Francisco, my husband and I end up going to Amber India. The food here is amazing, which is why we keep coming back. Yes, it is a bit expensive for an Indian restaurant, but the quality of the food is very consistent. The cocktails are interesting, innovative and tasty as well.

Be sure to try the English pea, portabella and paneer tikka appetizer. It was probably the most tasty bite of food that I have had in a while!
author: Jooly G.

description:
Love this place. First let me start with the negatives. 
1 - They close at 2:30 and don't open again until 5ish. 
2 - Although the food is great, it's way too expensive (2ppl $80) 
3 - The lunch buffet is TIRED and needs more options 
4 - You don't have a dedicated waiter, whoever is walking by takes care of you. Just seemed a little to impersonal. 

Now, the positives :) 
1 - During the buffet, you can still order from the regular menu (thankfully) 
2 - has to be THE BEST Indian food I have eaten so far :) 
3 - Friendly staff 
4 - I wanted chicken tikka masala which wasn't on the menu but the waitress had the chef do it for me anyway 
5 - Great customer service. WE got a little lost and arrived at 2:10 and even though they close at 2:30, they let us stick around until 3:30. 

HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE SAMOSAS, GARLIC NAAN AND CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA :) 

Will definitely be going back here!
author: Sill D.

description: OMG! This place is the best Indian Fusion Food I've eaten. Took a group of women entrepreneur friends to dinner here followed by a night at the Ethnic Dance Festival @ YBCA. The atmosphere, service and food were all excellent. Definately take a group back here for another gathering.
author: Yehudit S.

description:
Review is for the Sunday mimosa buffet brunch.

I've been for brunch of times since opening and always enjoyed it, but as of late 2013 food is markedly improved from an already good level.

There were more curries than one could realistically put on a plate or even sample over the course of a meal -- not that I didn't see people trying. Please, people, you can go back, don't turn your plate into curry-mageddon. It varies each day but the usual suspects, chickpeas, okra, peas, butter chicken, were there, seasoned with a depth and complexity that made them new dishes after the hole-in-the-wall Pakistani-Indian dives all over town. There were extras like a live dosa and a self-serve puri station and three kinds of green salad. The standouts for me were three simple things: a simple paneer curry, where the homemade cheese was actually toothy and nutty flavored, a star in its own right, an excellent raita (yogurt sauce) as thick as greek yogurt but creamy and not sour, and two pudding desserts, the best something like tapioca pudding without the tapioca but with sandgrain-sized particles instead (kheer?), and a strong taste of saffron. The goat curry was also nice.

Be warned, this is not healthy food, it's from the "fancier it is, the more cream, butter, and ghee you add" school but not any worse than others.

Service was cheerful, attentive, personable, and capable, noticeably good service. As for the bottomless mimosas they didn't wait for you to ask, a runner was walking the room with a pitcher, if you left the table you might just come back to a full glass (and if you want to skip the OJ that's fine too). Decor is rather fancy and a little coccoonish for being a few steps under sidewalk level. Family, date, and business meeting friendly all at the same time, there was some of each. Also, a lot of Indian families were here.

All that, at an excellent value. The price comes to about $26.50 per person including tax and mimosa, tip extra, for a feast that will leave you in a tipsy food coma so strong you'll skip dinner.

I've been to the lounge for happy hour and late night snacks and drinks, a very nice place but I would rate it a 4 for that, brunch is the big deal.
author: Gil S.

description:
Went here last night on the recommendation of a English Indian.  He knows where the good food is.  Sure, we spend $120 between the two of us with no alcohol, but hey, it was a work outing!

Our server, Ciara, was sweet girl from N. Ireland, and she really knew her Indian food - nice in a server. We started off with the Pepper Crab cake, Palak Chaat, and Duck Kebabs.  Three appetizers is a bit much for two people, so we only managed to finish all of them!  The kebab's were my favorite app - perfectly cooked, and paired with a buttery, curry'y sauce to put on top.  Winning. 

Second course was 2 different dishes - Lamb Biriyani and Chicken Vindaloo.   Of the two, I preferred the biriyani - it was served in a pot that had been kept covered so that the rice, lamb, and spices had plenty of time to make the lamb fall-apart-yummy!  

Will definitely come here again, though i'll try to stick to $30/person instead of $60 :)  Didn't need to eat so much last night, but it was all so GOOD!
author: Jeff E.

description:
Wow this place is good.  The service was good and helpful and the food was divine.   

I started with an appetizer of dungeness crab with ginger, black pepper
and curry leaves.  It was served warm, there was plenty of crab and you could taste that it was fresh.  Great.

Next, as a main I got Kashmiri Roganjosh, lean cubes of lamb flavored with saffron, ginger and fennel seeds.  Again, great. 

No longer being allowed the luxury of sugar (desert), I finished my meal with a second appetizer.Palak Chaat, crisp fried spinach topped with yogurt & tamarind chutney.  What a wonderful plate of food!  The fried spinach was light as air and it's taste was concentrated.  The yogurt and chutney complemented the spinach with a bit of sweetness.  Absolutely perfect.
author: David D.

description: Having planned a special date night out in the city with my 13 year-old daughter it was my intention to find a very special place for us to eat and enjoy one another's company. Amber India turned out to be just that place as the food was extraordinary, the service absolutely perfect and the decor pleasant and soothing in a way that allowed us to enjoy our evening together beyond expectations. Without question I would recommend it to everyone I know. As for us, we can't wait to come back!
author: Jonathan M.

description:
This place has beautiful ambience and we found the staff helpful and responsive.  Although a cold draft was blowing on my head through the evening.  The cauliflower appetizer was superb.  The rest of the meal was OK.  I"ve had much better salmon and the eggplant dish was also just OK.  I think the items are over priced for the quality of food.

I would not go back for dinner.
author: Alzak A.

description:
Expensive ($170+ for a table of 5, no drinks), long wait times (1 hour+). Burnt butter chicken (the simplest dish there is).

Went there with a  bunch of friends on a Saturday evening. Wait time was longer than an hour, so hung out at the bar/lounge area. No one came to help us so we decided to seat ourselves. After about 10 minutes of being there, someone paid attention and after another 5 minutes, someone came around to take our order for drinks. We were a total of 5, but 2 of us were served water. Wow! Just wow! Appetizers were good, but we were terribly hungry anyway.

Later, when we finally got down to the main dining area, the food was pedestrian. Murgh chilgoza was remarkable as it was terrible. Butter Chicken, the simplest dish there is, was burnt. This is a A+ Indian restaurant, and is serving burnt butter chicken! 

Food was pedestrian. I've had much better food in almost all places I've eaten at, and the service was nothing remarkable. I'll have to give some positive feedback as the ambiance is good.
author: Xander C.

description:
I ate here with my wife for the lunch buffet.  For ~$17 per person, it is a little pricey as far as buffets go, but the quality of the selection and diversity of menu, it was quite impressive.
