My wife had eaten at the Amber India in San Jose and raved about the butter chicken.  Although I love Indian food, I don't eat it often enough and was looking forward to eating at a good quality restaurant in our neighborhood.  

Buffets can be a low-risk way of checking out a cuisine you are unfamiliar with, unless the restaurant offers only the low quality fare at the line.  At Amber, they did not skimp on the quality as they offered some of their top rated offerings like the butter chicken and curried sea bass.  I could have just been happy eating these two dishes with the fluffy, tasty naan that was provided.  The meal also ended on a right note - while I have never been impressed with the dessert options at most Indian restaurant buffets, the lemon sorbet was very tasty and I had to get  a few bowls.  They also had some fresh fruit offerings as well.

The service was attentive and friendly - overall, I had a great dining experience here.  I just felt it was a tad bit expensive for a buffet.
author: Bowdoin S.

description:
I'm a sucker for buffets sometimes and this one is among the better Indian ones I've had in the Bay Area. Food can be a little heavy, so be prepared. 

Excellent for vegetarians. 

It can be a little noisy and dark for lunchtime conversation. And sometimes one can get distracted by the amount of food options. But I've made lunch meetings work here before.
author: Labs P.

description:
Had the lunch buffet here on Sunday. It was a nice spread with Chaat, Pani Puri, Salads, 3-4 vegeterian main course and couple of non-vegitarian main course offerings. I tried almost each of them and they were pretty good. Pakora and Cilantro Tikki(?) were awesome! Tandoori Chicken was bland for my Indian tastes. The food actually is not all that spicy. There was a live counter for rice with Tamarind and Lemon rice. Tamarind rice was delicious.

I was kind of dissappointed with the sweets though. To say in short, I have had much better Gulab Jamuns and Moong Halwa before and I am not really a big fan of Rice Kheer. That said, I guess I would visit again when I miss the restaurant Indian food in future.
author: Sam B.

description:
As a lunch spot... pricey but you get what you pay for. 
Great ambiance,  Prompt service. fresh, lighter fare for Indian buffet. Great for business lunches - small to medium groups. As a fair-weather pesco vegetarian, this place has plenty of options. The tilapia is always moist, fresh & tasty, and the naan is warm and yummy.  
If you like the hole-in-the-wall heavy sauced, cheap and spicy Indian places, you'll hate this place.  This is really lighter, more refined fare that happens to offer a few of the heavier traditional dishes for the butter chicken lovers.
author: Lynn Marie A.

description:
Get right out of town. How does this place have 4 stars?

If you think Indian food in the mission is overpriced, wait til you come here and pay an arm and a leg for overcooked chicken. Even the rich sauce on the butter chicken could not disguise the fact that the cook fell asleep in the back. Portions are small considering the price, especially in the seafood dishes. The sauces were not anything special, and I can't recall any dish with even a touch of heat to it.

I came here with a big group and we probably ordered 12 different dishes between appetizers and entrees. The only dishes that I thought were worth the money were the fried spinach and the calamari. I never even got the roti I ordered, and trying to split the check between 8 of us was so crazy that I didn't bother to have her take it off the bill. What's another $2.50 when you're already paying $70 per person? Also our server pushed so much food on us when we were ordering that we wound up with too much, so don't get sucked into the sales pitch.

The wine was good, though. If you get tricked into going here, order a lot of it.

A final thought: any place downtown that can immediately seat a group of 8 people on a Thursday night with no reservations while the President is in town a couple blocks away should be approached cautiously.
author: J W.

description:
Once in a while, I experience something strange in SF.  It's called terrible service!  I'm finding that I end up going back to places over and over, and unsure to try new places unless I see a good review.  

Walked into Amber after a workout at SportClubLA, and it was 9:45pm.  Their hours are until 10pm, but both the hostess and the lounge-area waiter, urged that the kitchen closes at 10 and would have to rush our order.  Both looking at each other like , I hope they leave!

The restaurant looks pretty nice, with quite a few people sitting still inside.  My friend said that the Butter Chicken was supposed to be the best (she's Indian!)?  We left after being treated like an out of townie, I doubt I plan on returning here!
author: Mark K.

description:
I came here for lunch with a party of 10 for Dine About Town, only to find that for $1 more we could get the all-you-can-eat lunch buffet that included the DAT offering.  Talk about a no-brainer...

Seems like all the Amber India reviewers are raving about the butter chicken.  And for good reason: Tender morsels of chicken in a rich, spicy-not-hot sauce -- pour that stuff over a large plate of rice and I'd be more than satisfied.  Nonetheless it was quite a treat to sample from about a dozen other offerings.  The naan (Indian flatbread) was brought to our table piping-hot, fresh from the oven, and perfect when dipped in the butter chicken sauce.

The dessert table had fresh fruit (good stuff) and some Indian desserts (mostly not good stuff).  One was called Laddu, which according to our waitress were balls of chickpea-based flour and sugar and coconut.  Our party of 10 unanimously agreed that the Laddu was absolutely disgusting.  We didn't think it was Amber's fault that it tasted nasty -- just our uncultured American selves who are used to sickly sweet creamy American desserts.

The lunch buffet is certainly not cheap at ~$20 a person, but I thought it was terrific value.  Highly recommended, and I was so pleased with the experience that I'll come back for full-price dinner someday.
author: Gary D.

description:
I went here last week with my girlfriend to celebrate our anniversary and everything was fantastic.  Our waiter was very friendly and provided some great recommendations.  

We had the following:
- Aloo Peas Samosa - we found the interior of the samosas to be very moist, which is critical to a good a samosa
- sea bass made in the tandoor - the waiter recommended this to me and I don't believe it is on the menu.  If you love fish, choose this!
- my girlfriend had the Lasooni Saag Paneer.  I tried a few bites and enjoyed it.
- Saffron Pulao and Amber Special Naan (garlic chive) - delicious!
- I had two glasses of Gruner, an Austrian, and we both agreed that it was the best white wine we have ever had.  
- We finished the evening off with the Mango Brulee, which was suggested to us by our waiter.  Very good!

Yes, it was a little on the pricey side, but I did not mind it since it was for a special occasion.
author: Daniel G.

description: This is THE PLACE for good indian food in SFO. Irrespective of what you order, you won't get disappointed. Atleast, I didn't.
author: Anjan K.

description: My friend and I ended up here for lunch, but we weren't aware it was going to be a buffet. The line was long, and snaked through a bunch of the tables, but luckily we were seated far away from it. The line was so long we thought about ordering off the menu, but our waitress said that would take about 30 minutes. Buffet it was! And it was very good! The sprout salad and chickpea salad appetizers were both fresh and crunchy. The sundried tomato fries things were delicious, although a bit greasy. The clear winners of the entrees were the fish with a green sauce (sawa?) and the butter chicken, although the spinach paneer was also quite good. I didn't love the veggie options otherwise - the lentil stew and mushroom and peas were only ok. Be warned. - the buffet is $17 for lunch! This would have been a 4 star for me, except for the awkwardness and length of the buffet line.
author: Deb G.

description:
This was a great place that my friend and I discovered when we were in the city and were craving Indian food that was nearby. We went based on the Yelp reviews and glad we did. It was somewhat crowded on a Friday night but we got a seat right away and our food didn't take too long to come either. 

The ambiance was great and so was the service and especially the food. I don't go to Indian restaurants that often and most of the ones I've been to so far have been ok, but the food here is definitely more than ok. I think most of the menu is organic. I ordered the eggplant but tasted my friend's tandoori chicken too and both were wonderful. I would probably classify this more of a 'gourmet' Indian restaurant, given the food, atmosphere and presentation.

 I don't like spicy food but even though my eggplant dish was spicy it was worth it since it tasted so good-and there was a constantly filled glass of water nearby. I take one star off for the price, but you do get what you pay for, and if you want to splurge on great food, I highly recommend it. My friend's Mom, who was visiting out of town and likes Indian food alot was also very impressed as well.
author: a f.

description:
I'm always hesitant to leave a 5-star review for a place I've only visited one time, so I will reserve the last star for my next visit--which *will* happen. I went yesterday, a Tuesday evening, and there was no problem accommodating a party of two without a reservation. The location is huge, it's downtown after all, and the restaurants do tend to be a lot larger. The bathroom was exceptionally clean, as well as everything else in the restaurant. The ambiance was nice and definitely not too loud despite the room filling up. The server was pretty informative and attentive and our water glasses were never empty. We also got new silverware, which is always a huge favor to me, because I always forget to save it on the side. 
For two people, sharing one serving or rice, and one serving of naan was perfect. I can't wait to go back or try a different location. I would definitely recommend this place for some upscale Indian food.
author: Cindy M.

description:
Very good Indian food. The lamb chops are fabulous. The rest of the dishes are great too. My only complaint is the cost. I don't think I have ever dropped $100 on two people eating Indian food. Granted we did have a bottle of wine so total bill less $40 and it's still $60 for two people. But, the food is great and the restaurant is very nice.

The tell for this restaurant is that there are actually Indians eating there. Be wary of the Indian restaurant with only white customers.
author: Stephen H.

description: Great Indian food. Chicken Tikki Masala (butter chicken) is really great if you don't like super spicy food. Only bad thing is that the ambiance is pretty sterile/nothing special. Good for client lunch or dinner.
author: Katherine L.

description:
My party of 7 went to Amber India for my graduation dinner. This was my first time here, and I was a little apprehensive considering I had a lot of picky palates to please. Every other restaurant in San Francisco was booked solid that weekend, and I felt lucky to get reservations at the time we wanted.

This restaurant is good sized, and best of all--it is quiet, we didn't have to scream at each other across the table. We had plenty of room and everyone was very comfortable. The service was excellent, we were dutifully cared for, and the food was very flavorful. Everyone was happy (even the vegetarians and the no-to-spice/hot food!) and we all went nuts for the naan bread (sweet cocktails too).

I definitely recommend this restaurant if you want to impress your party and easily carry on conversations.
author: Allison B.

description: Meh. Food is fine. A bit overpriced. Service was not fine. Disorganized in seating process, waiter couldn't remember what we ordered (2ppl). If there's no wait for a table place, this place is probably OK.
author: Rachel J.

description: Very nice restaurant with some of the best indian food we've had. Garlic naan, tikka masala, and the best butter chicken ever! Drooling thinking about it.. Definitely try this place!
author: Pj P.

description: I wanted to give negative star but there was no option..I am writing this review while sitting here and staring at food and thinking how to finish it..from outside this place luks so cool but food sucks.. We ordered chicken biryani and cauliflower manchurian and it doesn't taste fresh. It seems as if it's all last night food..
author: Prashant L.

description: Food is amazing but the experience can be pretty bad when the manager sends a server twice to tell us that we should get up as there are many people waiting.
author: casti c.

description:
Very unique and delicious place for bunch!  Excellent & relaxing ambience w/very tasty Indian food & Champagne!  Great lunch for a sunny Sunday!  

(4.5 stars)
author: Neko N.

description:
Went at the last minute as a suggestion from the hotel.  

Butter chicken was great.  I had the Saufiyani Jhinga which had a great flavor, unfortunately the shrimp was overcooked.  

Beautiful interior restaurant.  

Would definitely come here again.
author: Rochelle J.

description:
Fancy-schmantzy Indian food...  It is a lovely venue with very nice food and drink, and you will pay for just that.  Decent vegetarian selection, with nut ingredients clearly labeled and an invitation to discuss dietary restrictions with your server.  Excellent.

I'm not sure why they had to make my sidecar upstairs.  Or what that creamy cheesecakey dessert was exactly, but I'd order it again in a heartbeat.
author: Andi T.

description:
Amber India was unlike most Indian places that I've ever been to. Very nice decor, almost club-like in setting. Great service.

Menu highlights:
Butter chicken - as other reviewers indicate, this is a very good dish.
Tandoori salmon - This arrived with about seven large chunks of grilled salmon, lightly seasoned, a bit heavy on the salt. Interesting, but my least favorite of the three entrees.
Basil tandoori chicken - Interesting tandoori style, though not really the traditional style I've been accustomed to. The addition of basil gave it a heavier flavor, but not overwhelming. Pretty good.
Samosas were served as the appetizer. Good, middle of the road samosas.

Only downside of the place was the dish of anise seed / candy nibs that Indian places always have by the cash register. This particular mix tasted like detergent and practically caused my mouth to start burning. Real nice scene to have a guy spewing bits of seeds all over the sidewalk to avoid his mouth from exploding. I would say you should partake from that dish at your own risk.
author: Geoff G.

description: Was with a group of friends getting together for a reunion.  Very tasty.  We order a few plates between the five of us.
author: Jonathan P.

description: I've dined here before and had a fairly great experience , so to my horror I just left the restaurant where a cockroach was crawling right beside me. I had a table for two not three. This unwanted guest was pretty disgusting. After showing a waiter who came and killed the bugger right in front of us, we asked to see the manager. After waiting 5 mins for the manager, who said he has had this problem constantly and its not going away! WTF! You have a restaurant that serves food and basically you have freaking cockroaches! We got covered for our drinks and canceled our order of food and got the hell out of the roach motel! Not saying to eat here because I think there food is actually really good, but I don't think I would go there again knowing that they have insects crawling around!
author: Sherry L.

description: Great lunch selection for Buffet with all you can drink mimosas. Quality chicken butter and goat curry. Def worth it. And bring ur appetite!
author: James W.

description:
Food was yummy, but for Indian food, the price I paid for dinner was a huge rip off! You don't get a lot of food and you have to pay extra for naan and rice!  I was pissed. There are plenty of places in the city that serve indian food that is just as good or better and for a better deal.  

That being said, I would go here again, but only for the buffet lunch. Although it was still kinda pricey, for the amount of food they provide and the fact that it is yummy, it would be a nice occasional treat! 

Overall, I'd eat buffet from here again, but I'm Never eating here for dinner again!
author: ANTRICIA K.

description:
My wife and i went to Amber a few weeks ago. The restaurant is located in the financial district. We drove around for a while looking for parking. You should plan out where to park before you go. The restaurant is modern and trendy. We ordered the 
Lahsooni Calamari ( 5 stars) its was like a spicy/bitter soup. unlike anything I have had  at an Indian restaurant.
Followed by butter nan and lamb qorma. Both were good. Amber is a very good Indian restaurant with a great menu. We are looking forward to going back and trying other items on the menu.
author: J T.

description:
Mother's day brunch buffet:
-Nice ambiance (awkward seat arrangement though)
-Delectable dosa station
-Some of the best paneer tikka I've tasted
-Unlimited mimosas included with the buffet
-Desserts to die for...
-Great service
-Not sure if I'd go a la carte though...
author: Shilpi D.

description:
Pretty average food. Been here on a buffet. Most of the items are cold, the lamb kebab was bad. 

Had to ask 3 waiters for a drink. Very bad service. Don't think will ever come here.
author: Sireesha A.

description: I'm docking them one star for being one of the restaurants that was sued by the City of San Francisco for pocketing the money they collected for the Healthy SF initiative. Honestly, if I had known about this earlier, I wouldn't have eaten there...
author: Dave H.

description: Upscale environment. High class service. The BEST indian food I've had in ages. This place is the whole package. Though a bit pricey; it's totally worth the indulgence. Take friends take family take your significant other,  I'm sure they'll all love this place as much as I did.
author: Hemin P.

description:
Deserves a 4.5-5, so I'll give it the benefit of the doubt.

The food is very high-quality, and the dishes are much more varied and creative than you'd find in any "normal" Indian restaurant. I had the chicken with yogurt, almonds, and cashews; that, the bread basket, and the vegetarian "dumplings" were all excellent.

Definitely the type of place I would take a date, business meeting, or even a large party.

If it had any flaws, it would be that it's slightly pricey. But definitely worth it.
author: Alex L.

description:
I had my doubts about this place...looked to much like a night club to be legit..but I was wrong. This place has some pretty good food.

They have an awesome garlic naan, the sea bass kokum curry was amazing, the have this eggplant dish that is super yummy and what I love is they give good portions on the rice. Love me some basmati rice.
author: Terrine B.

description: Had a mediocre buffet here. There wasn't a lot of food variety but most things were delicious.
author: Ellen C.

description:
Good fancy Indian good.  Started with the fried spinach, which was like eating spinach chips (good!).  The pepper crab was ok, very pepper-y.

For entrees, the butter chicken was rich but absolutely delicious.  Same with the sea bass.  We got the asparagus and cauliflower, which our waitress warned was spicy so we got it mild, so it wasn't too hot.  However, I think in hindsight we probably should have gotten something else.  (Maybe the eggplant since its sauce is similar to the butter chicken!)  We also got naan, which was good (slightly oily) and a side of rice even though we didn't order it.

Waitress was very nice helping us choose entrees and wine.

All in all, I'd go back (but only if I had the money to spare).
author: Ken L.

description:
If I could rate food and service separately, I'd give the food five stars and tonight's service one star.

Having patronized the Mountain View and San Jose locations multiple times, and having been very pleased with all aspects of the experience on all previous occasions, I was expecting friendly and attentive service throughout an evening taken at a relaxed pace.

Boy was I disappointed.  The treatment we received from our server Ciara totally detracted from the experience.  She was cold and curt, rushed us to order entrees when we'd only just chosen starters, and barely checked back with us except in the most perfunctory manner.  She was not the least bit engaging, and gave us the impression that she couldn't care less whether we were there or not.

Very bad for the reputation of that location, and very bad for their business.  Now I will think twice about ever going back there again, when I'm in the City and looking for a nice place to have dinner with a friend.
author: Randy S.

description: Wanted to enjoy a nice dinner with friends. Went here on a Friday 6:00pm. The bar was full but the restaurant was empty; perfect because we were looking for food and wine. The host selected a terrible table facing the wall in a corner of the restaurant. When i asked if there was any other option, she replied all tables were reserved, and did not provide any other alternatives. We took our jackets and left to HAKKASAN were they welcomed our business.
author: Luca F.

description:
We had a corporate event planned and had a table reserved. We have arrived early by 15Mins, we were asked to wait for ~1hour in freezing cold. They have split us into group of 3 and asked to sit on different tables.

If you are party of 5, you will get a place together, if you are group of more than 5+, you should wait for a good amount of time.

I suggest look for your own options, if you have guests with you.
author: Reddy Srikanth M.

description: Best india food I ever had,  butter chicken was super good, that's my must order every time I go there.
author: Nayila A.

description: Came here during our trip to San Francisco. The ambiance was nice and the food was really good.  It was a bit pricier than what I am used to paying for Indian food, but it was worth it.  Highly recommended.
author: Mark H.

description:
FLAVORS THAT MAKE YOU WANT TO DO THE JAI-HO BOLLYWOOD DANCE ON YOUR PALATE!!!

OMGood. If you want flavors that will explode in your mouth and bust a Jai-Ho on your tongue, you definately need to come on by. However, not really fond of curry dishes, it was a weekend to explore the palate of fine foods. Not everything Indian is curry, my lesson learned. Definately an atmosphere and ambiance where (ref. slumdog millionaire) if on their first date ever, Jamal would take Latika out to eat. But please leave the screaming babies at home.

PALATE 411.
I needed to play it safe. Read the reviews of Indians and non-Indians to see what would best fit my tastebuds. All I have to say is ORDER THE BUTTER CHICKEN. We had a table of four and we all ordered our own dishes because the serving size was not family style and suitable for just you. 

Our table ordered
* Tandoori Naan ($3.25) - shared 
* Wild Mushroom Teen Saag ($14.95) - shared
* Butter Chicken ($19.95) - my order
* Kashmiri Roganjosh ($21.95) - didnt try, i dont eat lamb
* Tandoori Ajwaini Salmon ($19.95) - didn't try friends order
* (2) sides of rice

The Tandoori Naan neutralized alot of the spice in the main dishes and it went very well if you spread some Wild Mushroom Teen Saag ontop. The Butter Chicken didn't taste like butter on top of chicken. It was wasn't really shredded either, just small cuts in a deep dark tomato base (bit spicy). Went well with the Tandoori Naan and/or Rice. Definately a must try!!!!!

WHACK(Y) SERVICE.
It was a 10... seating us right away, getting everything set, taking our orders and getting the food to us quickly and fresh, but after serving our meals there was no real service after that. My glass of water was nearly empty most of my meal time, i had to give the stink eye and a wave to a floor manager to ask for more rice, and i kept wondering what happen to the servers, the service, chiwalas? we were so abandoned.

But i will definately be back. First time eating real indian food and actually want to come back.
author: Jane A.

description: Definitely one of the best Indian restaurants out there. They are also somewhat modern Indian and bring some twists, which are always a pleasure. The tandoori is definitely the best and so is some of the chat items. Do not miss the palak chaat, which is superb!
author: Gopi V.

description:
Wow!  I've never understood why you'd pay real money for Indian food when you could go to Shalimar... but we had an amazing experience at Amber India.

The ambiance was nice but when it came down to it, the decor was a little hotel lobby.  The service was great, right down to the plating of the food at the table, which I was pissed I missed cause I was in the bathroom - but returned to a beautiful plate of food.  

The food was fantastic - refined and sophisticated without losing any of the Bombay back alley punch or hole in the wall street cred.
author: Linda L.

description: A belated critique I should have done months ago. I came here for the first time via "Dine about town." I can say I was quite delighted with the selections  they prepared: their classic butter chicken, duck kebab with a wonderful spicy yogurt sauce. There was also lentil soup and rice, of course. Frankly, the portions they served could have easily been shared between two people. I will be back for the second round of "Dine about town" this coming June
author: Anthony W.

description:
You have to assume it's good when there is a wait for a table of 1 at 9pm on a Thursday, and it is indeed good. I was promptly seated at the bar. The wait staff was personable and attentive. 
I ordered the butter chicken upon recommendation of the bartrndress. It was an epic win in my book. I don't like ordering rice a la carte, but that's hardly a complaint.  Yes, I encountered a couple of chicken bones. That might cost points on America's Top Chef, but this is Farrah's Yelp Review.  A few chicken bones tells me this is real deal home cooked shit!

I am so pleased. No wonder the reviews are so high!  

And now, I will pay my enormous dinner bill!  

The end.
author: Farrah F.

description:
Solid "upscale" Indian with fun cocktails.  After spending much time in South Asia it is obvious to me the people in the kitchen here know what they are doing.

Would like to see the hostess and the servers pick their game up about a half notch.
author: C D.

description:
Cute date place for sure!  Nice ambiance. Great service! but the food was ok...
I usually enjoy Indian food with lots of spice.  But this place not so much.  I can't really write what I ate cause to be honest it wasn't really that memorable. 

Sorry...
author: Ying F.

description:
I have been to this place for several times over few years and this is best north Indian restaurant in Bay area. I loved their lunch buffet over weekdays. I am being a vegetarian, quite have pretty good selections and everything I have order at this place was great and very satisfying meal. 

If you like hot and spicy food, you must try their: Masala Mirch ka Salan and Badam Bhara Baingan.

Customer service is great.
author: P c.

description:
We eat at the Mountain View location about every 2-3 weeks (often).  My wife and I decided to take her sister to this location to combo with various touristy stuff.  We had the brunch.

It was pricey - but the service, free mimosas, and great food made up for it.  A good variety of hot/cold, vegetarian/non-vegetarian.  As a vegetarian I felt I was paying more than I should have, for half the buffet I couldn't eat.  But hey - that's the life of a vegetarian at a buffet. :)

Great traditional Indian dishes.  Although most were on the spicey end - warning for those 2/5 spice level people out there!
author: Brian K.

description: Really good Indian food and decent cocktails! Our waiter was attentive and friendly. I think the dal is a little pricey because usually I am able to get a small portion at other places for under five dollars (it was like $14!) but the food was delicious.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Decor and Ambiance get 6 stars, nicest Indian restaurant I have seen in SF so far.
However the food, I did not appreciate as much. For a place so good otherwise, it was a let down. Nothing great at all, and the portions a pretty small.
author: Aditya M.

description: The worst restaurant. where do I start. Parking costs you $30, I mean I've been served the worst on rarity, but this restaurant's service is the worst of the worst. The place is super expensive like $25 for a plate of fried chicken, the staff is constantly rolling his eyes for any question or clarification we might have, I would say to move past these mean staff and find something more inexpensive and an amicable staff
author: John M.

description:
We were recommended Amber India for great Indian food in San Francisco and weren't let down. This is a nice, slightly upscale restaurant, a complete difference from the divey mom and pop shops I used to frequent when I lived in Berkeley.

This restaurant felt and looked cool. I thought our table was a little close to the people next to us, but there was enough noise in the restaurant that we could hear each other without really hearing the conversation of the people next to us.

We had pesto naan, which was really good, along with soup, butter chicken, and fish. I LOVED the butter chicken; it was creamy, rich, and perfect for dipping with naan. Our server warned us that the kitchen was a bit backed up when we arrived, but the wait for the food wasn't too bad.

Also of note - the server forgot to submit one of our appetizers, and when we pointed out the mistake she brought it out for our dinner and comped the cost of the appetizer on our bill. That's the service more restaurants SHOULD provide when they make an error! I'd love to come back and eat here again.
author: Denise B.

description: I'm from So Cal and this is a must go every time I'm in SF. Love their Butter Chicken and Garlic Naan. Environment is great. Walking distance to Union Square.
author: H T.

description:
I LOVE Amber. I had a great time here for dinner and I've been lusting after the food ever since I had tried Amber. Now I don't want to say that this is legit Indian food (heck, I wouldn't know) but they know what they do well and they stick to it. Amber's food is a bit Americanized but like I said, it's GOOD and I'm glad they keep at it.

What I had:
1) Aloo Peas Samosas -- potatoes were spiced just right! I usually am a pansy when it comes to spicy food but these samosas had a good 'kick' to them and the sauces that came with it were superb. 

2) Butter Chicken with Tandoori Naan and Saffron Rice -- MY FAVORITE. The Butter Chicken was tender and drenched in a rich, buttery, tomato sauce. Each bite I took with the saffron rice (which was, by the way, cooked just right and wonderfully fragrant on its own) was heavenly goodness. As if this wasn't satisfying enough, I used the crispy naan to dip whatever was left of the buttery tomato sauce. YUM.

3) Badam Bhara Baingan -- normally I don't like vegetarian dishes because I feel that too many spices are thrown in to make up for the lack of fat and flavor that comes from meat... but this eggplant dish was great. The eggplant drew a lot of flavor from the caramelized onions (which I love) and I think that was it. There were no add-on complex spices, just simple and savory. The caramelized eggplant and onion complemented the saffron rice so well.

4) Jaipuri Bhindi -- okra dish cooked with tomato and green mango. Wow. It was dee-lish to say the least. It was perfectly seasoned and it had a bit of crisp on the shell of the okra, which gave it a nice texture (I'm used to steaming okra, which makes it soft and gooey). Loved this dish as well! 

5) Mango Brulee -- okay, I LOVE anything mango so I might be biased... this creme brulee was sublime. The custard tasted like mango lassi -- sweet, fruity, with a bit of tang -- and, of course, the caramelized top layer provided for a nice crunch with the soft custard. I would definitely recommend this.

6) "Bru" Coffee Kulfi with Chocolate Sauce -- I don't like the taste of coffee but this frozen dessert was great... especially when doused in rich chocolate sauce. The combination was sweet! I think I'd stick with the Mango Brulee for dessert, though. 

I liked that they had a section for meat-eaters and vegetarians. Both had great dishes to choose from and all that I've tried were delectable. Amber has a great ambiance -- perfect for a romantic date -- and the service is quick. I'd recommend Amber to anyone!
author: Jenny O.

description: I've definitely had better Indian food. And the prices are very high and servings are far from generous.  I  was very disappointed in this place.
author: Jill P.

description: The fish is TDF. They were very friendly with our toddler. Gave her a free mango lassi. Lots of interesting, well-executed dishes with good quality ingredients. Perfect casual dining experience. Nice staff.
author: Marina N.

description: I am glad we showed up, for an early dinner. The line really started to build up around 630PM. I ended up ordering the Biriyani (of course), and it was delicious. Ever since Lahore Karahi changed ownership a few years ago, I have yet to find a restaurant that takes the necessary time and ingredients to make this a flavorful experience. Amber India comes in close second, so I am happy camper. It may not be $, although this is a nice dinner, in a nice setting.
author: Anthony C.

description:
One of the best Indian fare, I hv come across in the US. Quality is top notch, but comes at a price. DO try the Fried Palak, a unique take on Crispy Spinach.

There is a inside dinning room for 20-30 people, where you can order a Pre-Fixe at 65$/75$, offers a good but costly option.
author: Paresh B.

description:
Great service and wonderful food. Busy night but we were seated quickly and before the quoted time.  Service in the bar was good as well. Portion sizes good, except the rice, surprisingly enough. 3 entree orders will require at least 2 orders of rice.

I recommend the duck kebab, it was fabulous.
author: Eric B.

description: This restaurant provides a nice place to go out in the downtown of San Francisco. The food stays loyal to the indian cuisine and at the same time is done with good taste and some surprising elements. The atmosphere in the restaurant is great - both feel private and social. Service is good.
author: Gal S.

description: The best among the Amber restaurants that are in the bay area. Only issue is parking: finding it is such a chore.
author: Arun K.

description:
I have to give this place 5 stars because I've been a repeat patron and I've always been taken care of. 

I work with a lot of Indian folks and they always say that this is a great authentic place, but it is quite expensive. We usually go here in groups when there is a birthday or special event and we really enjoy the lunch buffet. 

I am a huge fan of butter chicken and glaup jaman (i spelled that really wrong) and Amber has a great version of both dishes.

I do enjoy that they have a cold bar and hot food and the place is very clean.

Maybe I'll go to amber this week lol
author: J-nine I.

description:
From my general experience, if the restaurant invests a lot in the ambiance then the food generally tends to not be all that great. And vice versa. So since Amber India is beautiful inside, my friends and I had somewhat low expectations of the food when we ordered. Also, since it is Indian American fusion, we weren't sure of what to expect. But luckily we were wrong. The food ended up being really good! We ordered the paneer lababdar, which is just your regular paneer tikka masala, saag paneer lahsooni, and three types of naan (chili cheese kulcha, pesto naan, and regular in case the other two sucked). The entrees were good in that they were standard from what I've had at other restaurants. Could have been a tad bit spicier but overall, good. The naans, however, were amazing! I was really weary of the chili cheese and pesto but they turned out so delicious and weren't too strong that they overpowered the entrees. I'd definitely recommend both. 

The bar area looked really cool but we didn't get a chance to sit so I would definitely come back to check it out.
author: Krishna S.

description:
Ok, so I have never eaten in the restaurant but I love their happy hour!  Great place to meet friends after work and relax over a few beers or mixed drinks.  Bartenders are super friendly and you can stare for hours at their lighted color-changing wall.

Love the decor and reasonably quiet atmosphere in the lounge.
author: Manuel R.

description: Have been here multiple times and food and we ice has been declining. Their health score is super low so I won't be going back for all these reasons.
author: K M.

description: Nice Amber version in SF but I prefer the other 2 options in mtn view and Santana row. It's a big place and was very busy on a tues night. We tried several veg appetizers, tandoor and entrees. Reason for 3 stars is that I was looking for more healthy options with less cream, non-fried, less oil etc. and there were very few of those options to chose from. Menu is more Indian fusion than traditional North Indian. Our service was excellent though which would make it 3.5 stars. Would not come back...
author: Mihir M.

description:
I went there the other night with a few girl friends and it was wonderful--we started at the bar for happy hour, and although I'm not a huge drinker, indulged in a very lovely drink, the Amber Rose, which was suffiently ginny and fruity at the same time. 

The bar tender was super friendsly, and it was a comfortable atmosphere in which we could relax.  For din we moved to the main dining room which is large, but remained cosy due to the dim lighting.  We all had differenet things, and I can only vouch for one, but they all looked lovely and everyone seemed content.  I went fr the wild mushroom saag, which was excellent--perfect levels of spice.  Although I could have used more wild mushrooms in it, it was still a success--and w/ all the naan I ate too, it was quite filling.  I think my only complaint is that $12 for the naan basket we got seemed a little steep--dinner w/ 1 round of drinks was around $150 w/ tip, so it's no Naan N' Curry, but is is a delicious place close to the MoMA.
author: Rachel N.

description:
First off, this restaurant is pretty expensive depending on what you get, my bill came out to about $54 dollars. But hey, it's worth it for what you get: classy decor and great food. I started  the meal with the delicious pepper crab cake (which was excellent), although I had a few shells in it :/ Then I had the seekh kebab nizami, and I can honestly say that was best kebab I've ever had. There was a group of us so we also ordered the chicken apricot kebab and I could've just had that by itself, it was so delicious. And of course we ordered the essentials, raita, naan, saffron pulao...long story short, everything was good!

I'd definitely recommend Amber to any indian food lover. It's definitely not cheap (so plan accordingly), but it's worth every penny.
author: Evin C.

description:
3.5 stars.

In what can only be described as a completely random group of folks meeting for dinner on a Saturday night - I was the token Chinese girl.  I represented well by rolling in 30 minutes late .... I would have been much later if my friend hadn't let me change at his place and then chauffered me over to this rather hard to find place.  (When you try to map this place on google maps, it shows it on Yerba Buena Island...)

Great cocktail menu ... so much so that I passed on my standard martini and had the pink elephant instead.  I think at least $4.00 of my drink was the lovely orchid that garnished it.  Are those edible?  Drink was tasty though, definitely a girly drink.

The food was good though I found the samosa's disappointing. (They were sad and shriveled.)  The rest of the food was yummy and packed with a lot of flavor which made sampling the huge assortment of food we got rather difficult.  But yes, the butter chicken is really that good (whilst the name terrifies me).  I had the sea bass per the recommendation of the server, but I didn't actually enjoy it that much ... I probably should have gotten the scallops instead. At the end I walked out stuffed, so net net, the food was adequate.

Pricy for Indian food, but you're paying for the location and the ambiance.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
I've lived in the bay area for years and haven't been to a better Indian restaurant.   A lot of restaurants in the bay usually use an excessive amount of oil or masalas to get flavor in their food, Amber India is able to make succulent food without doing so. I highly recommend the Dum Biryani.  Rather just pick any meat dish, you can't go wrong!

Do try and order a la carte, the buffet somehow isn't the same (though it still is the best buffet in the area).

Check out the bar, I ordered an elephant martini which turned out to be a girly pink, I got laughed at but it was probably worth it.  This place is on the pricier side, but worth every penny.
author: Prakhar S.

description: I've been here a couple of time on work lunches - it's the best Indian buffet nearby!. I really like the butter chicken and naan. There are lots of other good curries that tend to vary. I had paneer basil tikka masala which tasted pretty pesto-y, very different flavor than I was expecting from an Indian restaurant, but good. All of their vegetarian dishes are very good! The dishes change up some too so you won't get bored. Tasty rice pudding.
author: Christine H.

description:
I'm a frequent visitor. The atmosphere and environment is excellent. This is a great place for almost every occassion.

The only con I see is that the price is a bit steep for Indian food.
author: Leon S.

description:
Don't miss this place... You'll truly be missing out...
Food over and above the par of excellence. It gives your palette memories it will savor for days after. I picked Amber India after researching several review sites. 
A very nice ambient atmosphere with a lively feeling. When entering one immediately thinks- Too Loud, but after seated all's well. Thought has been put into the seating and sound absorption.
We started off with Cauliflower Bezule. A locally grown cauliflower floret sauced in coconut cream, mustard seeds and curry leaves. I hope to attempt an replicate this at home. We'll see. We could've easily devoured a dozen of these. 
Next came Amber's Signature Frontier Lamb Chop (Australian Lamb Rack) Paradisiacal! Prior to this event, a restaurant in Marigot, St Maarten had  my first place for rack of lamb, this place easily tied it. Melt in your mouth with perfect flavor. 
The lamb was shared with Signature Butter Chicken (Shredded Tandoori Chicken). My girlfriend has had many experiences with buttered chicken past. She was immediately taken back by the quality and taste of the dish. Stating "I've never had better! Nothing can even comes close" 
The sever was very attentive and personable. Outstanding. She was from Kazakhstan. 
Now for the negative side... We live in the Pacific Northwest... We won't be able to enjoyed each and every menu item that this outstanding restaurant has to offer :o(
author: Randell T.

description: Call them to reserve table space if you have a group. Lunch buffets are good and cost about $18 per head during the weekdays. Expect longer stand-in-queue time between 11:30 am to 12:30 pm on Fridays
author: Srikanth K.

description:
Unfortunately this can be an easy 5 - just need more customer service focused management.

To start with they have the weirdest seating - they split a booth (for 4) into 2 tables for two couples - how cozy! about 20% of the seating is in the form of these split booths. And it goes to about 50% for seating for two - so if you are on a date - you have a 50% chance of sitting in the same booth with two strangers.

Next our coffee and tea arrived almost after we were done with desert.

Food is almost a 5 - the butter chicken and Bhindi were outstanding. The rice, naan, paratha and desert were good. The $22 Rogan Josh - sorry I can make better. The $12 Crab appetizer had several pieces of shell in it - learn to clean it before you learn to cook it.

The decor is a 5.

So they have to nail all their dishes not just one or two and I believe they can get there with a little focus. Next they have to nail the service to justify the price tab - $180 for Dinner for two - I think this is a much bigger challenge because they need to get first-rate management and they might not feel the need because the restaurant is crowded. Fortunately, if you live on the peninsula you have plenty of Top price - top service and average price - average service Indian restaurants.

So net-net if you live in the city - give it a shot. If you live on the peninsula - spend your money elsewhere when you are in the city.
author: Hari B.

description:
I'd give it 4.5 stars if I could. 

The $16.95 somehow turns into a $19.95 buffet with taxes. And while it hurts my wallet so, the food is just so damn good. I cringe at the thought of paying that much for a buffet (and in the stuffy Financial District, at that) but WHOA that food is good. 

Make a reservation, it get's way crowded by noon.
author: ciara s.

description:
I had really high expectations of this place but I was left wanting more. 

The appeal of Amber India gives of certain sophistication but with more of modern touch. The neon lighting from the bar exuded almost a Las Vegas vibe without losing it's class. I found the customer service to be very attentive and approachable. 

However, when it came to the food, I felt this where Amber India dropped the ball. I ordered a chicken dish, that reminded me of yellow chicken curry, which tasted bland. The dessert menu was nothing exotic and/or memorable enough for me to mention. 

In the end, I don't want to rule out Amber India because they did have strong points in customer service and ambiance department, however, a critical point that should be reevaluated are some of their dishes. One must think that if restaurant pays enough attention to exterior details such lighting, they must do the same or more where it actually matters like the food!
author: C M.

description: I had the lamb and it was fantastic! Probably the best meal I have had in San Francisco!
author: Rich S.

description:
Went here for the lunch buffet and well... The service was great, the chai was delicious, and I will admit that food was great as well. The catch being is that it didn't really strike me as Indian food; it was more of a blend. 

And don't get me wrong, the food was great and I openly welcome blends of food but you can't really call this a straight Indian food joint. And while the food was good it wasn't good enough to warrant the price of it.
author: Shauna S.

description: A bit pricey but a beautiful setting! Would love to try out their brunch buffet =)
author: Tiff W.

description: Food was really spicy and delicious. I loved the paneer korma and the butter chicken the best. However, space was tight and seating was uncomfortable. The line to the buffet was also long and slow. They closed downstairs seating and crammed everyone up top in the lounge. Several other people including myself had to stand up multiple times to let servers and neighboring tables through. Either I came on a bad day or I dont think its worth the cost.
author: Say O.

description:
Must have is the the Palak Chaat. Crispy fried spinach that just melts in your mouth! 

Other notable entrees are the Butter Chicken with it's signature Amber recipe and Kashmiri Roganjosh. The lamb meat is tender and resembles a beef stew. Not gamy but just amazing flavors of saffron and fennel seeds. 

Safed Murg is chicken in a light yogurt sauce. It is great to help tame the palet from the spices of the Butter chicken. 

Palak ke Kofte which is spinach dumplings in an onion sauce is worth trying.

Of course, you need to order saffron rice and naan. 

Some cocktails to try are the Pimm's on Amber and the Pink Elephant. Pimm's reminded me of an iced tea and the pink elephant is perfect for anyone that wants a sweet cocktail. Watch out for the lychee. It is loaded with alcohol. 

Noise level can get a bit loud. Service is good but not superb. Our waitress was 'missing' for a bit. I had to ask for her to get our bill. 

I would definitely come back here!!!
author: Molly T.

description: I am sorry, after only being there an hour for the buffet lunch,  we were  rudely  asked to leave because there were people waiting.  I will never eat there again. Very arrogant host.
author: Vicki E.

description: We had the butter chicken and saag paneer, as well as naan.  All of it was delicious.  The butter chicken has a rich, smoky flavor and the saag paneer uses very fresh spinach and is delicious.  Naan is fluffy and warm.  But, this place is definitely pricey - definitely a splurge.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I took my date here for our first fine dining experience, and she LOVED it.

Perfect since she's vegetarian and I love Chicken Tikka Masala.
author: Kevin D.

description:
After falling in love with this food years ago after working a wedding that had Amber as the caterer, I'm thrilled they are in SF.  So thrilled in fact, that it's taken me this long to come in.  :/
I went in last night and I'm glad I did.  The butter chicken - oh man, the butter chicken.  We also got some sort of little spinach and almond ball that was good.  We sopped it all up with some naan and washed it down with a little beer and wine.
Sitting at the bar leaves a little something to be desired however - between slow to nonexistent service and snotty patrons I think I'll just stick to the restaurant.
Certainly not the cheapest Indian you'll find in town though.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Seriously the best indian food I've ever had. Apps were hot and came quickly while we waiting in the packed bar. Cool ambiance and vibe to the whole place. Dinner was great- get the lamb that comes in a deep, giant diamond shaped dish, covered in red sauce. 

I felt like a vampire feasting on the flesh of lesser beings.
author: Dave M.

description: Great value! Mimosas with mango juice are the bomb and the food is very high-quality. Highly recommend it and the weekend brunches.
author: Hanan H.

description: Not impressed with the buffet at all.  Sure it's nice that they offer non-typical dishes like paani puri, seafood curry, egg curry to name a few, but when it comes to taste - I think they could take it up a notch.  For the price one is paying, Amber is only offering ambiance....service and food is just average.
author: Bhavnak K.

description: Great tasting food with an unique twist to most dishes while retaining the authentic taste. Upscale and a bit expensive. Worth the money.
author: Piya K.

description:
The wife and I came to San Fran for a quick break from Vegas. Decided to try this restuarnt based on Yelp reviews.  There was a 25 minute wait on a Tuesday night, but well worth the wait.  We had the Keema Naan for a starter, if that had been great, I would have given 5 stars, but it was just ok.  The main course was excellent, and the service was very quick and friendly. We had the chicken tikka masala (which is not on the menu) and the butter chicken. The masala was pretty hot, but the butter chicken was an excellent balance. 

If you like Indian, I would say this is one of the best places I have eaten... Give it a try, you won't be disappointed.
author: Gavin P.

description: Went here for Valentine's Day. It was pricey, but mostly tasty. Unfortunately they only had a fixed menu (which wasn't mentioned when we made our reservations), and some of the options just did not seem well-thought-out.
author: Rajesh S.

description:
We went for dinner before catching a show at the Metreon.  First time there and we loved it. Beautifully designed and when you walk in, the smell of the Indian spices makes your mouth water. Service was excellent - attentive, good knowledge of the dishes, and a very welcoming attitude (thanks, Nicole).  Had the pepper crab appetizer which had whole pieces of dungeness crab, very tasty.  For the main course, had Butter Chicken (excellent, like Chicken Tikka Masala only better) and the Tandoori Sampler with great dipping sauces. Instead of just Naan, we tried their Assorted Bread Basket which I highly recommend.  To top it off, they even had our favorite Napa sparkling wine which we rarely find in restaurants.  

It is a bit pricey but considering the food, the location, and the overall experience it isn't out of line at all. All in all, I highly recommend Amber India.  We will be back.
author: Ken L.

description: Hearing that this is the best indian lunch buffet in the city, I had to try for myself. With high expectations, I'm sad to say they weren't met. Waiting in a line for 20 minutes that snakes around the entire restaurant to get rice is not my idea of an enjoyable lunch.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The food and happy hour deals are still great, but the bar staff ruined my experience this evening.  

I had been sitting at the bar for 10 minutes trying to get eye contact without being acknowledged and finally waved someone down to get a menu. 10 minutes later I asked to order a drink because I had still yet to even be greeted, and I was told "just a minute" without apology or explanation, while the guy fiddled with glassware.  After 10 more minutes, the friend who had arrived at the bar ahead of me paid her check and as we stood to walk down to dinner, a bartender walked up and asked if we need a drink! Far too little, far too late.  

I waited literally 30 minutes without even being acknowledged.  This is the worst service I have ever received in San Francisco.  I don't care how slammed and/or incompetent you are, you at least greet patrons sitting at the bar (it's only 6 or 8 stools long), acknowledge their existence and let them know you will be with them as soon as you can. The gals who used to always be behind this bar were great, but the guys who were there tonight were terrible!
author: Quinn S.

description:
Valentine's day:
Poor service for the money we paid for special valentine's day dinner.
Service was slow. Only guy who seemed to be working was the hispanic guy taking care of water and dishes. The tip we left was for him.
Food was okay. Weekend brunch is much better.
author: Rk K.

description:
You will enjoy a evening of great dishes and friendly staff at Amber India. 

I have ordered most of their dishes. The Kashmiri Roganjosh, Tawa Sea Bass, Saufiyani Baingan, and Shalgam Nalli are fantastic. 

Try a Acai Berry Caipirinha or Cucumber Mint âTaazaâ from the bar. It will increase you IQ by precisely 6 points per serving.
author: Michael G.

description:
Indian food buffet can be a very dangerous thing and Amber India is a "just okay" option for those who enjoy this type of experience.

I am not really into buffets myself but certainly appreciated all of the vegetarian/vegan offerings for my lunch the other day. Nothing really stood out with the various salads, vegetables, curries, tandoori options, and  desserts as the flavors lacked the spice and zest that I prefer in Indian food. Was it terrible? No. Do I feel inspired to go back and nosh again? Not so much. 

Amber India is very clean and has a modern aesthetic that doesn't seem to really match the overall ambiance either. The staff was friendly and accommodating so that was a major plus.

Bites are a tad on the pricey side and in my opinion don't seem to match the quality.

Overall a safe bet but your palette won't be thanking you anytime soon.
author: Marcia M.

description: I have been a big fan of amber. I come there atleast 4 times a month and thrown small parties all the time. Generally they have been so consistent and great with the food. What shocked me today was the manager. I just finished a business lunch and paid. I was in the middle of finishing my conversation and asked us to leave because there was a big line. I was so embarrassed in front of my guest. I will never go to bet again. This was the worst customer service I have ever see. Simply shocking
author: Ekta C.

description: Wow.  Crowded, hip, fun, fast, and delicious!  Reservations are definitely recommended as it gets packed.  We absolutely loved the chicken tikka with orange and figs.  Dip that with the avocado raita and BAM you have a taste overload!  32 hour dal (lentils) was well made and rich, the rice soaked it up quickly.  The eggplant dish was also incredible - whole baby eggplants roasted and then topped with a rich, thick Indian gravy.  Yum!  Overall this is one of the best Indian restaurants I have been to in a long time....
author: Alex G.

description:
It may be cheating to walk over a few delicious treats from a huge restaurant kitchen for sale at the Farmer's Market in the Metreon, but all is fair in foodie love and war!  I'm quite familiar with Amber's proper restaurant as it is my team's favorite Indian Buffet in the FiDi... allegedly right on with reproducing regional favorites.  Their to-go cart is a nice hold over between work celebrations.  Most interesting are the arbitrage opportunities.  The chicken wrap, for instance, sells for $6 whereas the proper restaurant prices it at $7.95.  Perhaps a reward for those dilligent enough to have sought this rather obscure Farmer's Market.

Chicken Wrap: Fluffy and fresh naan hugs chunks of chicken curry.  The chicken is mostly, if not all, white meat and surprisingly tender given the cut.  The curry is top notch with tons of distinctive spices and herbs.  They definitely don't skimp on their to-go items.  Not as greasy as a kati roll but tasty in it's own right.  

Samosa: Much more lightly fried than samosas from fast food, steam table and lower end joints.  Inside small cubes of boiled potato and peas are smeared with a dry spice rub.  Overall feels lighter than other samosas and when dipped in the yogurt/mint/cilantro chutney, it is definitely a treat.
author: Adam B.

description: great atmosphere, awesome part of San Fran. Wait staff was outstanding. Food was superb. Price reasonable. Fantastic vegetarian dishes - didn't miss meat eating here because the non meat dishes were excellent.
author: Jon E.

description:
BEST indian food I have ever had in my whole entire life! The butter chicken and the rice with the pie crust on it (I forgot the name of it) made me want to cry. You could taste all the ingredients and it all came together like something wonderful in my mouth. The waiter never let my water get half empty in my cup...love that!

I made reservations so make sure you do that if you go on a weekend in the evening. Beautiful place, great service and amazing ambiance. I went on a date with my boyfriend and he thought the same. It was a memorable time.
author: Andrea R.

description:
What a surprise! The chicken birka (sp?) was outstanding!! Try the mixed sampler appetizer. Everything we had was very flavorful and the portions are decent. The restaurant is trendy and has a separate bar area that seems perfect for the after shopping cocktails and appetizers. 

The best part was the leftovers the next day. I didn't get a chance to try any of their wines, next time.

I would highly recommend this place.
author: Colette K.

description:
Originally I thought there would be a special prix fixe menu for DAT, but alas that did not exist so, in a way, I felt like I was tricked into coming here for the brunch buffet. That was literally the only choice since it was either getting the $20 buffet or paying super high prices to order off the dinner menu. 

Dosa, Palak Paneer, Butter Chicken, Tandoori Chicken, Chipotle Grilled Chicken, Potatoes (of what sort I cannot remember). 

Dosa, Palak Paneer. I have two words and two words only: NOT IMPRESSED. Dosa, it was the first time I've had it and I didn't think it was anything special, just like an Indian flour omelette I guess. Palak Paneer, I've definitely had better elsewhere.

Butter Chicken, Tandoori Chicken, Chipotle Grilled Chicken. Basically all of their chicken was good. Butter Chicken was really good, but quite normal tasting, could have gotten the same elsewhere. Chipotle Chicken was also good, I liked that I could taste the charcoal grilled flavor of it. 

Champagne. Buffet comes with your choice of drink. Pretty good champagne though I must admit!

Naan. Pretty good, but definitely nothing to write home about since I've had the same elsewhere also.

Coca Cola. I got this because I love me some coke! :)

Soupy dessert I can't remember the name of anymore, Fruit, Pistachio Cake.

Soupy dessert was good, couldn't eat too much of it though because the coconut milk in it was super heavy. It had little noodles in it though, they were like really thin vermicelli noodles, super interesting but super good and different from anything I've ever had. 

Fruit was good, but can you really go wrong with fruit? 

Pistachio Cake. Me no likey. 

Overall, I'm not impressed with this place because I didn't think it was that great. Obviously service was barely had because it was a buffet. But also the service they did have was subpar. The hostess sat another table before us, even though we had arrived first. We were also seated at a booth, which were crazy dirty, stains everywhere and pieces of food everywhere, it was disgusting. Pretty much made me lose my appetite. It was also quite expensive for what was offered food-wise. I mean the only meat they had was chicken, that's not worth $20. You definitely pay for variety since their dinner entrees are about the same price anyways.
author: Constance C.

description:
I went for their New Years Eve celebration.  They had the place decked out with all kinds of decorations, yet still managed to keep the decorum of a nice restaurant.  The meal was 5 courses.  I was actually most disappointed with the main dish, which was a chicken and rice dish.  However, the paneed crab meat they had as one of the courses was absolutely phenomenal.  

I'd come again.
author: Aaron M.

description:
My husband and I arrived in the city and within a few hours we were Yelping to find a good Indian restaurant.  The place stood out among all others as a place to try.
We arrived about 35 minutes before the lunch buffet was due to end, but this gave us enough time to sample the phenomenal food available.
The food is fantastic, a great selection of dishes.  The wait staff were very attentive and friendly.  It just so happened that day, that they were offering free champagne, so we jumped on the chance.
The restaurant itself is fairly upscale with nice seating and tables.
If I get back to San Francisco in the near future, this place would be on my most wanted list of places to eat at !! 
It's also in a great location.  Definitely worth the visit.
author: Cherie D.

description:
The food and drinks are the bomb!!!

While waiting for our table we decided to get an appetizer and some drinks.  I'm not a heavy drinker so I never really know what to get.  I ask the bartender what I should get, and she was a little bit hesitant at first to give me a recommendation but once she saw me getting frustrated and how clueless I was about drinks, she step up her customer service and asked me do I like sweet, sour, and whatever else.  I said sweet so she recommended this raspberry and vodka drink that was delicious.

I would recommend the samosa with the chutney sauce as an appetizer for anyone not sure on what to get.

I had the lamb chops.  It was soft, tender, and cooked perfectly.  It made me forget about the fact that I was eating a baby lamb.

My girlfriend had the sea bass and it was good but not memorable.

Our waitress was kinda weird and awkward, but she gets the job done, so no complaints there.

On the expensive side but not a place to pass up.
author: James N.

description:
I love this place! There was a time when we went at least once a week, and in no way is this a budget friendly weekly visit kind of place. But my husband and I were obsessed! 

Favorites - samosas, the tandoor grill items - baluchi chicken, paneer, potato, manchurian, the okra dish, the paneer, the breads, the rice, the mango creme-brulee, the cocktails.

Great ambiance, excellent service! Need a reservation on a busy day.... We also did the buffet on Sunday when we had out of town family visiting. It was perfect!
author: Sapna E.

description: There goes my dieting . The good part is the service awesome good . Butter chicken gosh pulao are highly recommended . The samosas are crispy . However for a bigger group seating , it's not recommended . Came here for a friends bday and just had a lovely time .
author: Anu N.

description: We had such a good experience, we came back for our 2nd time in Sep 2013.  It's expensive here, but worth it.  We had the butter chicken, mixed vegetable korma, bhara baaingan, and papadam.  Service is always very professional.  If I remember right, the Blue Moon beer came with an orange slice, a nice touch.  Will definitely come back, this is one of our favorite Indian restaurants.
author: Dan L.

description: I see lots of good reviews for this place and frankly I don't get it.  Being from Chicago where we have great Indian restaurants , this place is way overpriced and the food is not authentic.   Sorry.  But I'm not impressed.     LOST MY BUSSINESS!!!!
author: Julio V.

description:
Like everyone else says- Get the Butter Chicken. Maybe a cousin to the chicken tikka masala except there's actually a huge chicken breast portion and its fabulous. Really, you will eat until it hurts.

A girlfriend and I came here post chinese new year parade craziness. The bar staff told us that it was obviously much more crowded than normal and they were slammed. So we sipped on our cocktails- I got a kumquat splash and I have to say its the first kumquat drink i've ever had and it was very tasty. So we waited for a bit longer than usual for a table and they hooked us up with two free appetizers to appease our long wait. Bottom line- classy place, good drinks, divine butter chicken.
author: Chrissy L.

description:
Pros: The interior was very nice and clean. We walked into this restaurant on a whim and we were pleasantly surprised by how flavorful the food was, especially the fish and the butter chicken. Another pro is that drinks were included in the price of the buffet and the they had a lot of drinks to choose from which included mimosas, mango juice, soda and ice teas and they were all refillable.

Cons: One of the major downsides of this place was that there was a lack of variety, there were only about 10 dishes to choose from and after about two rounds, you run out of different things to try.

Overall, the food was really tasty and we had a great experience and we would definitely come back.
author: Crystal L.

description: Reliable & delicious. Will be heading here a lot. Chai, mango lassi, eggplant, butter chicken, cauliflower app, naan- all great.
author: R C.

description:
You probably thought the same thing I did when you heard about the lunch buffet. "17 bucks? This had better be the best indian buffet I've ever tasted."

The thing is, it probably is the best indian buffet I've ever tasted. Everything is excellent. Seriously, if your not familiar with anything (and there are some dishes offered that will be unfamiliar to even veteran indian lunch buffet patrons) just take whavever. There is nothing on the buffet that isn't excellent. I know, because I tried everything. 

Don't miss the kidney bean fritters up near the front with the pakora (which is also very crisp and should be eaten as soon as you get back to the table) and the lentil dumplings, which taste like they're made from some kind of light refiined flour rather than lentils. And try the butter chicken. you have to try the butter chicken. 

They may not have the lamb you were promised by your coworkers, and your server may seem kind of disinterested, but don't let it get to you. Eyes on the prize. Butter Chicken.
author: matthew r.

description: Fairly upscale Indian, great service and very good food. It's a large place so it can get somewhat loud depending on where you sit. It's a little on the pricey side, but worth it in my opinion. Great spot to grab dinner if you're catching a movie at the Westfield.
author: Kristen A.

description: I went to this Resturant with some friends and their samosa was good however I had the salmon beetroot tikka ..it was horrible and the worst was that I got sick couple hours later..
author: ria m.

description: I've been to many Indian restaurants and have also been to India, I must say this is one of the best restaurants I've been to. It's an upscale, trendy place with attentive and very fast service.  The food was amazing and very generous portions. I will visit this place every time I'm in SF.  The asparagus soup was phenomenal and the chicken biryani was amazing. Highly recommend.
author: Saif A.

description:
I had New Year's Eve dinner here and I was impressed with the food. They served a five course fix price menu with several choices and something for everyone. 

The evening started with bubbly and an amuse bouche served in phyllo dough. It was decent, but not a sign of things to come. Often the amuse bouche is the best item the chef shares, definitely not this time.

For the first course, I got crab with ginger and curry, whild my date got spinach which was battered and fried. If you must eat vegetables, this is the way to go. Kidding aside, her spinach was outstanding. The crab was good, but the curry masked the sweetness of the crab. It tasted a bit like pulled pork.

From the tandoor we selected prawns and cottage cheese. Now, the kitchen was building momentum. The prawns were perfectly cooked and the cottage cheese was firm and flavorful. 

So far the portions seemed a little small, but they were first courses. The entrees came and my yogurt marinated rack of lamb was outstanding. It was so tender, I couldn't stop eating it and portion was big. My date's chicken was also much to her liking.

The two types of naan were great for collecting all the savory sauce served with the entree.

Desserts were decent - she had a cake and I had sorbet.

We selected the wine pairing too. It was good, though the first course came with a second sparkling wine, which was odd since they served complimentary sparkling wine to start the meal. The pours of non-sparkling wine were a little small. I finally had to ask for a refill with the lamb.

The service was good, but the pacing of the dishes was off, mostly the time between dishes was too long. It almost cost them a star, but the waiter said this was their first fixed price dinner ever, so maybe the kitchen is working out the kinks. I'll give them a break on it this time. I really enjoyed the food, so I'll be back.
author: Lefty R.

description: It may be a good place to eat ... Don't know didn't spent my time here and eat.  1 star for the Person at the desk who is arrogant and unfriendly.
author: Jigar P.

description:
I would definitely recommend Amber India.  The cocktails are yummy.  They have a good wine selection and most importantly the food is delicious.  It is a bit on the expensive side, but conveniently located near Westfield.  

I would recommend making reservations on Friday and Saturday via OpenTable - even if only 30-60 minutes in advance.
author: Mackenzie O.

description: Great bar/lounge friendly staff and really good Indian food. It had a kick but not too hot for those who can't take the heat.
author: Christal P.

description: The food is great, but the service is subpar.  The front of the house look and act like hostesses from TJI Fridays.  And over all, the table serve is slow and spotty.  Not at all a high end experiece.
author: Esther L.

description: Finally made it Amber India last night and it did not disappoint!  The butter chicken literally melted in my mouth.  The flavor of the sauce was superb.  We also got the lamb roganjosh which was good, although the lamb was slightly overcooked.  After the chicken and lamb arrived, I was feeling the need for a little veg but didn't want to order a full veg entree...so was really pleased when the server kindly offered that we could order a 1/2 portion.  The addition of the jaipuri bhindi was an appreciated one.  I will definitely be back!
author: Chi-Chi L.

description: Food came out very quickly, perhaps a cause for alarm. Most items were a bit bland- it felt like average flair. kulfi for dessert was the best part of the meal. Ambiance is slightly above average for SF
author: Shantanu V.

description:
If you love Indian food and are willing to spend $22 for a lunch buffet (includes the tip + tax), then I would recommend going here.

Be sure to arrive a little earlier before lunch-hour rush in order to not have to wait in a giant line. Food is tasty - there is a ton of variety for both vegetarian and non-vegetarian. The environment is also pretty nice and good for groups of all sizes. One star off because it is quite pricey for lunch... but other than that, pretty good!
author: Sweta A.

description: My favorite indian restaurant in the bay. Nothing to beat its cocktail collections, menu and the interior decor. The ambience is very sexy and excellent service. This is by far my favorite indian place and I never get bored of it even after visiting it 6 times :)
author: Aparna K.

description:
I was skeptical when walking into this place with all the fusion menu items listed on their website.  I'm an avid indian cook and have worked in Indian restaurants before therefore, I'm highly opinionated on the subject.  

These guys really do it right.  After this dinner I'm claiming them in my top three indian restaurants in the bay area. 

The service is impeccable and rightly so since their waiters come from 5 star hotels in India.

The food was phenomenal.  There was a few of us and all except me had very little experience with Indian food and they loved it. Here's a ranking of best dishes to get, although the lowest rank was still very very good.

- 4 chilli sea bass (rivals the sea bass at Mantra in Palo Alto)
- Kashmiri rogan josh
- Okra (Bhindi)
- Spinach appetizer (very unique dish, was awesome)
- Malabari Shrimp
- Butter Chicken

Thank you Amber for a great dinner.
author: Paul G.

description: We tried this for the first time this weekend.  Being from India and lived in the US last 20 years, it has been hard to find authentic indian food.  Yes it is good to go to the hole in the wall places, however, the holes in SF are not really clean.  So we decided to let go of the "dhaba" food idea and try a nice restaurant.  It is an upscale dining restaurant next door to Four Seasons.  The food was delicious.  It seemed like the chef tried to keep the dishes authentic but with a twist using ingredients one would normally not have associated with the dish.  Their spice levels can be increased but I guess that will need some more visits and I would need to emphasise it more.  Service speed could be faster...but beggars can't be choosers.  Will definitely go back...
author: BlueStar V.

description:
They have a great "all you can eat!!!!"  brunch deal on the weekends.  Comes with two glasses of champagne!  

The food is DELICIOUS!  Make sure you're hungry!
author: Grenache G.

description:
Great Service, our waitress Alexandra was incredible, even when we were a little drunk, she was a delight and attentive.  

Food was incredible, everything was great, the Dal & Butter Chicken was incredible.  The Mango Creme Brulee, was sweet, but not overly sweet, creamy with the perfect brulee top.  

It was a great dining experience, I will go back.
author: Troy C.

description:
I freaking love Indian food & when I was invited to a business dinner there was no way I could pass up Amber, after all I was craving some naan.

I have been to the Amber India in Mountain View and I will say that not only was the food 25% more expensive at the San Francisco location the food was also fantastic!


Naan:

Naan is pretty much the most important part of an Indian meal and their naan was disappointing. The naan was too crispy/crunch and I prefer doughy naan, which is why I had to dock a star. Yes, it's because of the freaking naan!


Apps:

Apple and Feta Salad - pretty solid

Samosa - served with chutney and mint. the somosa were pretty small, but very delicious

Rice & Lentil Cakes - spicy and excellent


Main Courses:

Saffron Chicken Tikka - the chicken is super juicy and awesome

Butter Chicken - everyone at our table said this was their favorite. Butter chicken is awesome, the name says it all

Dal Amber - lentils in a creamy tomato based sauce. Wasn't spectacular, but pretty good

Saag Paneer - almost like creamed spinach with chunks of cheese that had a mozzarella like consistency. Looked gross, but tasted excellent


Amber India is not cheap, but if you want a nice sit down Indian restaurant in SF with good service and a good atmosphere, then Amber is definitely the way to go!
author: Elaine S.

description:
This is a review of the lunch buffet.  In theory, $16.95 is a lot for an Indian lunch buffet.  However, this is a nice restaurant and the quality and large selection was worth it.  For one thing, the pakora were hot and crispy, something I have never encountered at a hole-in-the-wall Indian buffet.  There was a good selection of curries, most of which were really good.  The butter chicken was a little sweet for me, though.  The naan that they bring to your table is hot and good.  

I have been here for dinner, as well, but I think it is too expensive.  I will come back for lunch, though.
author: Amber B.

description: This is a high-end Indian Restaurant for when you want to have a wonderful dining experience, as well as a very unique spin on Indian food. We're Indian and we like this place!
author: Mansi P.

description: Lunch buffet.  All food was good - tandoori especially. Only complaint was lack of variety.  For a huge restaurant I would have expected a few more options.
author: Jay E.

description: We came here with our son on the 4th of July weekend.OMG!!!  If you get nothing else and you like fish-get the sea bass. RIDICULOUS!! And the lamb is spectacular as well. All the other common foods like the naan, saag paneer, all cooked to perfection but these 2 for sure are a must! Next time we're in San Francisco, we'll be back. Told 4 people that are in SF more often than us about this place. I am sure you will see more great posts!
author: Sarah Y.

description: I have been to the lunch buffets. I have to say they are delicious! I have to rave about the butter chicken is to die for!!! Especially with the naan and saffron infused rice. I also never had goat and tried it and actually really loved it. I love their tandoori chicken so succulent. My only big knock is the price!! $17 for a buffet is way too much and adding $4 for a soda??
