That's why I have only been here twice when I have money on a school day and being a beauty school student or student in general $$ is tight.
author: Nadia N.

description:
This is one of my favorite Indian places ever! The ambiance is so chic and sophisticated, perfect for a date or group a friends. My favorites include: 

-Sambhar Masala Spiced Scallops (the absolute best!) 
-Calamari Peri Peri 
-Butter Chicken 

Pair both with the Garlic/Pesto Naan and Absinthe cocktail and you'll be in Nirvana!

It's always busy so I suggest making reservations!
author: Tika S.

description: Food is decent, but service is terrible. They messed up my booking two nights in a row and I won't be going back. Last night I called to make a booking a few hours ahead of time; I spoke to someone to make the booking, they Yok my number and confirmed it. When I turned up they said they had no booking and would try to seat us in 20 mins. We went back 20 mins later and they said it would be another half hour. We went back and were eventually seated on some bar stools. Tonight I again called several hours ahead to make a booking, and was told they weren't busy and we didn't need to make a booking. Concerned by the issues the previous night, I requested again that they book a table however they advised to walk in. Just like the night before we turned up to be told they had no tables available and it would be half an hour wait. I used to like this place and had referred it to others, but Amber India, you're service this week has been terrible and I'll never be back.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Decided to try something different for the holiday and spent my Thanksgiving afternoon here with my friends. 

Made reservations over the phone for our small party as I heard the buffet might get crowded. The guy on the phone had a hard time hearing me for some reason but I didn't think anything of it until we arrived the next day. The host on duty said my reservation was for two not three but it wouldn't be an issue. I was a little annoyed that he wanted to be nitpicky about it but we were seated promptly so I let it slide. Note to self: Use Open Table or repeat info back to whomever is taking the reservation before hanging up the phone. 

Once seated, our waiter (I want to say his name was Carlos? Not sure.) arrived immediately with glasses, water and took our drink orders. The Thanksgiving buffet came with bottomless mimosas (oj or mango) but we all had to decline for various reasons (driving, work later, alcohol allergy) but we saw practically every other table indulge so I can assume they were pretty good. 

By the way, the restaurant vibe is upscale but not overly stuffy so I saw other diners in everything from North Face fleece & jeans to suits & saris. I dig that! :)

We were there early enough (1pm-ish, they opened at 11:30am) so we didn't have to wait to go through the buffet which I heard people mention on Yelp. We had also expected it to be strictly Indian food but they added a roasted Turkey carving station with cranberry chutney and for the day, some Turkey Tandoori. Everything was tasty and well seasoned, particularly the turkey and butter chicken. YUM. Through out our meal, our waiter and his fellow wait staff were great, refilling our drinks without us asking, clearing the used plates promptly and bringing multiple (!) baskets of fresh naan piping hot from the kitchen. The only thing that was a bummer was the mint chocolate gelato in the dessert station. It was more soupy than frozen. I think they may have been better off with something that could hold up with less effort like a chocolate pudding or custard?

By the end of our visit though, we were definitely stuffed in that Thanksgiving kind of way and too jolly to care. At  $24.99 a person (buffet + drinks included), it was a great holiday deal / indulgence. My friends and I are definitely considering coming back to try Amber on a regular weekday or for the weekend brunch. Or maybe on Christmas Eve or Christmas if they are open! :)
author: J. L.

description: The best Indian food I've had outside India. I chose their Lamb Rogan Josh - the meat was great, the curry was excellent and the service was good. However, because the place was so crowded and we were placed right next to the waiter's "desk", it only gets four stars.
author: Phil D.

description: Had dinner here last night. We had early reservations (6 pm) and were seated immediately. Our waiter was suberb -- we were a party of 6 (including two elementary school age girls) and he took his time explaining the menu. The Flash Fried Bloomsdale Spinach was out of this world - way better than kale chips!! Even the kids liked it; i've never tasted anything like it. The sea bass w/mango was my dish and oh so yummy. The 4 chile roasted sea bass though was the best dish on the table. The eggplant dish was ordered as an appetizer and we ended up ordering another plate of it. The spices were perfectly blended, nothing was overpowering. Only disappointment was the chai tea believe it or not. I definitely want to go back.
author: Helen W.

description:
The food was amazing. The manager was an asshole. We were 10 minutes late for our reservation, a party of 8. And he told me that since we were late that he no longer had a table for us? are you fucking kidding me? The hostess went out of her way to say that it was wrong of him to do that to us and she tried very hard to get us a table. we waited about 25 minutes. I couldn't believe how mean the manager was to the two girls working the front with him. It was embarassing to watch him boss them around, trying to put blame on them for HIS MISTAKE. 

over all the food was great, our waiter was amazing. I'm just in shock of the managers work ethic.
will not be returning.
author: Rachel P.

description: Second time back. Had the butter chicken which was tasty. I think this is a great upscale Indian restaurant. The ambiance is great and the service is always terrific.
author: Dana C.

description:
I'm not sure if they have a buffet like this everyday or it was a "Diwali-special-buffet". Whatever it was, it was the best damn Indian buffet I've had in ages. 

The first signs of the place being good was the presence of all the Indian folks. The quality is usually directly proportional to the number of ethnic locals. I've tested this hypothesis thoroughly over the years and once again, it was proved correct.

The vegetarian spread was quite impressive - chole, gobi, bhindi, paneer along with naan and rice. There were a couple of other dishes that I had to miss out on as I wanted to keep room for dessert. 

Yup, luckily, I had a peek at the dessert section before I started and it totally blew me away. Usually buffets come with 2-4 dessert items. Over here, there were at least 5. Five being the number I ate. There were more but as much as I wanted my stomach said no. Kala jamuns, rajbhog, gajjar halwa, kheer, and moong dal burfi. Don't let the names scare you away. They were quite awesome.

Washed my food down with a glass of good mango lassi. 

Oh oh oh, I almost forgot the apps (I'm still in dessert wonderland). Mushroom pakoras and a sort of veggie roll that is quite common in India.

Though I did get things when I needed them, service was not the most attentive. Otherwise, I just might have given them 5 stars.

Definitely recommended!
author: Harsha R.

description:
I used to come here after work for drinks with a coworker. I don't come here as often because, well, that job was terrible. But at least I was working for an awesome fun web site that is great for, ahem, writing reviews (exactly) like Yelp.

Anyway, this place has an awesome happy hour. The drinks are reeeeeally strong. Felt a buzz that was similar to the one I had back in high school drinking my first 40 oz. Oh, to be young..

I ordered some delicious and reasonably priced appetizers. The restaurant is  a bit swanky, but not pretentious. Definitely coming back to try their entrees.
author: Lee L.

description: I'm in love with this place. If this were in Chicago where we live, I would be a regular. I think it is a the best example in the US of high-end Indian (and I like it better than the low end Indian restaurants in most cities).
author: Shayan R.

description:
Pretty good food but the selection is very limited.

To their favor - it is a high end restaurant and logically that is to be expected.  

I went on a Sunday night and the experience was positive.  4 People total with a $250 bill...pretty reasonable compared to South Beach, Ocean Drive, Miami restaurants!
author: Chris X.

description:
The bar area at Amber is as fresh and modern as any spot in SF.  A gorgeous crowd shows up here daily for happy hour as the restaurant below cranks out quality traditional (and some fusion) Indian dishes. 

Definitely a go to spot for an upscale evening with that special lady. 

(speaking of special lady, make sure to check out the booty on the bartender there!)
author: Dru P.

description:
Our group of three came of us had weekday dinner plans here so we decided to catch the HH special at the bar beforehand. The bar is small and seems quite popular (i.e. fills up fast). 

HH menu at the bar offers certain special dishes and drinks at a more reasonable price, while the normal fares/bevs are also available.  We each had two drinks and shared two of the small dishes to nibble on before heading to our table.

Upon sitting down, we ordered a basket of nan, some rice and the below two dishes that were quite good:
Butter Chicken - the "signature" recipe of tandoori chicken
Lasooni Saag Paneer - spiced spinach and cottage cheese 

Total that night (including at the bar) came to $65/person.  We enjoyed all that we ordered but we really didn't order that much.  More like 3.5 stars but can't get past the high price point, so rounded down.

Take-Away: Good food, no doubt; Fancy Indian food, no doubt; Nice/formal setting fit for business events, no doubt; Pricey, no doubt; Repeat on my own dime?  HH, without a doubt; Otherwise, doubtful.
author: Carol K.

description:
5 stars all the way. I have been meaning to try this place out since it opened a couple years ago. Finally went with the FamBam this past Friday. The dining area is huge and the bar(where we were) is in a seperate loft area. The decor is fantastic and it's centrally located in the middle of downtown. The only food I tried were the wings, which were the bomb! They were very flavorful and spicy.

Happy hour here is amazing. Drinks that are usually $10+ are mostly $5. And they all pack a punch. I was expecting to have 5 or 6 drinks, and ended up not even finishing my 3rd. And I was still spinning a few hours later, even after pigging out. The "Amber Rose" drink was delicious and packed a major punch. It might have looked girly, but it was stronger than your drink. I guarantee it.

Thanks to the wonderful and beautiful Altana for taking care of us all night. Dennis is a lucky man! I will definitely come by for happy hour on a regular basis.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Wow.. the perfect  restaurant to take a date! The food was perfect, the waiting staff was the best, the courses came right on time and the wine selection superb.

I would highly recommend this place.
author: Ron R.

description:
Wow. After being told a 10 min wait and giving up our spot at Tropisueno to check it out, we were sorely disappointed with the 35+ min wait only to be told it would be 20more minutes. Service fail.

Amber, I will never taste your possibly delicious food. :(
author: cat c.

description: Booked Amber India for dinner with a buddy attending the same conference. When I arrived early, I had been walking around the city most of the day and was a running on caffeine. I opted immediately for iced water and a Mango Mojito - yeah!  The waitress assured me the Mango Mojito was not sicky sweet and it turned out to be quite smooth and well done - recommended for a nice cool down.  We opened with a round of pappad and naan and for the mains I had the awesome Tawa Seared Scallops and he ordered the Butter Chicken.   Both dishes were executed perfectly!  The service  and attention to guests remains top notched.    Whether you need to just satisfy a craving for Indian or have conference dinner guests to attend, Amber India can cover both with its varied menu, great location and optimum service.   Cheers.
author: G M.

description: Delicious food. It's a buffet lunch, but don't let that throw you off. Amazing chicken and veggie options, great for team lunches.
author: Dan L.

description:
You have to try the pepper ginger crab cake was easily the best I've ever had! It was 100% crab which is very rare these days.  

Of course I ordered the butter chicken which was great but I really wish they had Chicken Tikka Masala on the menu which is my favorite.  

The service was outstanding and the decor was very hip.  I'll be back for more next time I'm in town.
author: Dallas G.

description: Great ambiance and good food, however this is expected at this price point. I feel like for the price the curries and traditional dishes are just average, what you are really paying for is the ambiance and decor. One thing that is definitely worth paying for are items that you can't get at other indian restaurants or probably wouldn't feel comfortable trying at an inexpensive place. This includes the tandoori lobster (seems to be on the menu at the Mountain View location and not in SF), Scallops and Sea Bass. Basically its hard to find sea food in an Indian restaurant and when done well it can be wonderful. All in all worth a stop for a upscale night out but if your looking just to fill a craving for Indian food best to look elsewhere.
author: Dhruv P.

description:
We ate a lot!

Starters: 

- Spinach & Ginger Soup (Meh!)
- Pepper Crab (Yum!)
- Spicy Calamari (Yum!)
- Coconut Mussels (Meh!)

Entree:
- Butter Chicken - more like TOMATO CHICKEN... not Butter!
- Rice
- Chili Naan

Dessert:
- Mango Brulee (Meh!)

There were pros and cons to this place. I didn't think my waitress was all that... and I had a hunch that all this food wasn't cooked to order. The restaurant was really busy and our food came out really, really quick. All I could think of was that there was probably an Indian buffet line in the kitchen and it was being plated up as the order was put in. SERIOUSLY.

I use to wait tables and I knew when the waitress put our food order in and within 3 mins, our food was out. I did not like that feeling... esp paying $20.00 for a bowl of butter chicken with 6 pieces.

Anyhoo - I've had better Indian food... in London and in Santa Clara... just not in San Francisco. I'm still looking!
author: Carolyn N.

description: Far and away the very best India food I've ever had. The dishes were amazing and the flavor profiles district, beautifully balanced seasoning and lovely ambiance. Can't wait to go back.
author: Nancy B.

description:
Finally went here the other day for lunch. It's one of the most unique Indian buffets around! Yes, it's pricier than other Indian buffets ($16.95) but for a few bucks more you can try about 12-15 different entrees many that you would never see at other buffets, several very fresh salads and several desserts. The saag wasn't overcooked and mushy like at most other places; some of the spinach was still in leaf form. Arugula/bell pepper salad was yummy. And the semolina dessert was great. They also had these baby eggplant that was cooked perfectly.

It is 100x better than the buffet at Gaylord at Embarcadero, which I would never go back to now that I've had Amber.

Nice decor aka hipster Indian restaurant. Can't wait to go back!
author: Miki C.

description:
Had a girl-date with my bestie here for Dine About Town. We then saw Prometheus and went home and cuddled. Just kidding! We saw the Avengers.

What we shared and enjoyed:
+Palak chaat: Flash-fried spinach, yogurt, and a tamarind chutney. The chutney was the best part about this; otherwise, it was pretty greasy, but still tasty.
+Aloo peas samosa: three crispy, fried dumplings with spiced potatoes and peas inside, served with a tamarind chutney. Very yum.
+Butter chicken: Now, I don't eat chicken, but I can't NOT dip into the butter chicken's rich tomato sauce. Warning: it's addictive.
+Four-chili-rubbed fish kebab: Three cubes of sea bass rubbed with pink, green, Szechuan, and black peppercorns. Perfectly cooked and absolutely delicious.
+Garlic chive naan: We couldn't stop eating this damned bread! Chunks of garlic, sprinkled with chives. A perfect utensil to dip into the butter chicken.
+Mango lassi: a thick, blended, yogurt-based drink. Very tasty and well-made.
+Masala chai: Though it was good (and free refills were provided), it wasn't steeped long enough, and therefore tasted more watery than chai-y. 

The service was excellent: very attentive, our water glasses were constantly refilled.
author: Adena B.

description:
An oasis for a civilized lunch in the FiDi/Soma area. The service and ambiance is what draws me here, it's polite and peaceful. The lunch buffet ranks at the top of my buffet experiences, period. The selection is solid without being inundated with options. 
We had a dinner reservation this week with a friend and colleague was in from out of town. The plan was a nice, leisurely, early dinner within walking distance of the office. I get a call about 2 hours before the reservation letting me know that they are experiencing an unexpected facility issue (hot water, etc) and may or may not be open. They apologized and offered (provided we are still interested) that they will call us back within the next half hour with a definitive answer. The professionalism with which the restaurant handled the unexpected incident was very highly appreciated.
author: A L.

description:
Ambiance: 4/5 very nice 
service :4/5-  Reservations is suggested . Done reservation , they had done some glitch but at the end they have taken care well.
Food:5/5 excellent 
Baluchi Murg Tikka -  one of the best tandoor I had in Bay Area . 
Dum ka Murg - different and very nice flavored chicken 
Murg Parda Biryani- chicken dum biryani - they served boneless chicken in biryani and I would recommend one should try here . You will experience best Dum biryani in Bay Area

Assorted bread basket - did not like much , was ok ..
author: M A.

description: Went a bit early, by myself with no reservation. I was cheerfully accommodated and very well attended to by the staff. The food was incredible!  The staff helped with selections so I did not end up with something too spicy for my palate.  Would come back again without hesitation.
author: Sandy H.

description:
Impossible to find directions on the iPhone! Luckily, my girlfriend had been there before. Had a reservation for 9pm and got there at 8:40 pm. Saw a few vacant tables and more being available, so when I asked about when we'd be seated, I wasn't expecting " your reservation is at 9pm- it'll be a few more mins up seat you"! Mind you, we were the only ones waiting to be seated!
The food was good, but not authentic Indian. It was fusion food- americanised, toned down spices...we ordered extra spicy Baingan- which was quite bland.
But, service was quick; the staff was attentive.
author: Radhika A.

description: I wish this place existed in Los Angeles. It is like the Mastros of Indian food. Every detail and spice used is top notch. I always recommend this place to my friends to try out. I suggest the Tikka as well as the tandoori and the breads are amazing too!
author: Ben P.

description: Vindaloo, get the vindaloo. It is so delicious. It is pretty spicy so if you aren't for heat be careful. Really you could order anything you want here and be happy. This is the best high end Indian place I've ever been tried. Check out Press Club across the Lane before or after your meal.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Awesome place. The food is top class. Menu and serving style was splendid. 
Thumbs-up!! 
Although please make advance reservations...else the wait time could be long.
author: June C.

description: Ordered lamb and chicken. The meat is not tender enough and we have to use knife to cut it. Rice and nam not included. Expensive but not worth the quality
author: Martin H.

description: I'm a big fan! Their Murg plates are some of the best I've ever had. The service is excellent and it has a very classy, elegant feel to it.
author: Jesus R.

description: The restaurant is beautiful, the service is very good and the food is excellent. My only complaint is that its necessary to order a lot of extra side dishes in order to have a complete meal. Our wait person might have guided us a bit in this regard. Still, it was a very enjoyable restaurant experience.
author: Jack S.

description:
I came here for my birthday.  Made reservations for 9 via email and they were quick to respond.
My friends were running a bit late, so some of us decided to wait at the bar.  It's such cute setting.  Very clean and has a comfortable yet upscale feeling to it.
I ordered the pink elephant which is made with vodka and lychee juice.  It was sooooo good and refreshing.  For appetizers we ordered aloo peas samosas.  They had a great taste to it with some cilantro and this sweet tangy tamarind dipping sauce.  It was perfect.  Not too heavy which held us up for dinner :)
We were seated promptly.  The waiters were very attendant.
I ordered the kokum curry seabass.  The seabass was a bit fishy but not overpowering the dish.  I loved the sauce.  
We also had safed murgh.  It was made in this almond sauce.  It was very light.  Not your typical indian dish.  So if you don't like too much flavor, go with this dish.
Sambar masala scallops-I don't usually like scallops, but this was lovely.  And the sambar masala sauce was tasty.  
The butter chicken-was yumm. Can't go wrong with this dish.
The baluch chicken tikka was the best.  I was very surprised that my boyfriend picked such a great dish only because he isn't big on indian food.  These were cubes of chicken marinated in indian spices and grilled.  OMG i looooved it and he was very happy with it.
Kozhi Melagu had a great kick to it. I loved this dish.  They were accompanied with some Pesto and Chili thyme Naan.  
This is a great place to go on special occasions or just a night out.  I enjoyed sitting at the bar and wouldn't have minded staying and eating there if we didn't come with a big group.
author: Deepika S.

description: I went here for a business dinner with one other person.  It wasn't a planned meeting spot but I'm sure glad I stopped here.  It was crowded on this particular Saturday evening, but we were fortunate to get a table for two without reservations.  We ordered off the menu and had the most delicious naan bread brought to our table.  I ordered the butternut squash soup which was delightfully spicy.  I also had the samosas which were equally delicious.  I felt the service was good and the ambiance of the place was very nice.
author: Betty S.

description:
This is Indian food done in a very sophisticated atmosphere, all the way from food to the decor to the presentation.  

The lunchtime buffet is a little more expensive than most ($19.95), which I would usually have a problem with.  But not this time around.  I was so happy with the quality and variety of the food, and overall ambiance of the restaurant.  

Give it a try for lunch if you're in the area!
author: Angella S.

description:
The strength of this restaurant is unique, creative dishes that you don't find everywhere. I've had a million different versions of malai kofta, but never in my life have I heard of palak ke kofta. All of their vegetarian dishes were like that: a familiar base, but with a wholly new twist. The palak ke kofta were excellent with an incredible sauce, and I wish I lived in San Francisco so that I could try the other dishes!

The naan was quite good, though not the best. The drinks were fun and tasty. I didn't try my friends' dishes, but they were all completely delighted by their dishes.

Bottom line: creative dishes that you won't find other places that are still wonderfully Indian set this place apart from the cheaper Indian places and make it a worthwhile splurge. Great for vegetarians. Very nice atmosphere and great service, too.
author: Amanda J.

description:
The food tastes alright (I didn't note all that much difference from the many other Indian restaurants I've been to), but it's ridiculously overpriced for the portion size. Basically, a $25 "entree" gives you the equivalent of a small plastic bowl worth of greasy food. Naan and rice sold separately. 

The guy on the phone was pretty polite, so that's a plus.
author: Janet J.

description: I have come here over a dozen times in the last year, and I have yet to have a bad meal there.  The drinks are amazing, but I'm partial to the cuke martini.  In this last meal, the carnis had the tandoori sampler and the rogan gosh.  They both seemed to enjoy it. In terms of veggies, we had the saag panner (very good, not too creamy, panner soft not chewy) and the quinoa kotfa (soft koftas and the gravy is very yummy).  Naan is always good and hot.
author: Sheetal P.

description:
Review is for the lounge area only! 

although their happy hour menu is not as extensive as other establishments, the nice atmosphere makes up for it. If you come here early enough to score a table, the comfy seats will make you want to stay forever. 

Not the best happy hour deals in SF, but their potato (w/ peas) naan is amazing!
author: Vivian D.

description: The Buttered chicken and the chili pepper jack cheese naan are perfect! Best indian restaurant indeed.
author: Faten A.

description: GREAT buffet, nice selection, good quality, nice atmosphere.
author: Jason T.

description:
I tried to make a reservation on opentable for a party of 7 as I had friend visting from out of town and we decided to dine at Amber on the same day. Open table did'nt have anything available for that day so I was disappointed but I called the restaurant and they were able to accomodate us. So the lesson I learnt I was old school techniques definitely are still good. 

The food was awesome as usual, elegantly prepared with the right amount of spices and flavors and well presented. The only problem I have with this place is the quantity. As I am used to getting more quantity in most of the restaurants I visit, it's difficult for me to remember that the portions are small and I sometimes end up picking on the curries. 

The 'Bru' kulfi was awesome (Bru is a chicory mixed coffee thats really popular in India)
author: Rahul P.

description:
We've been to Amber India a few times and have never been disappointed. It's actually one of our favorite Indian restaurants in the city. Some of the dishes we've tried are:

Aloo Peas Samosas
Butter Chicken
Kashmiri Roganjosh (lamb)      
Zhinga Rubiyani (tiger shrimps)
Lasooni Saag Paneer (spinach)       
Saffron Pulao (rice)         
Amber Special Naan      

I can't speak for the lamb dish since I don't eat lamb but the people I go with love it. My other favorites are the samosas, butter chicken, rice, and naan. Their veggie dishes are also really good - everything is very flavorful and each dish is distinctly different from the next. 

The service is great and so is their wine list. I can see why this place is always packed. The bar area is pretty swanky and the decor of the restaurant is very elegant. I wish I lived close enough to come for their lunch buffet - it sounds awesome! 

The only down side is that dinner can be a bit on the pricey side, especially if you order alcohol.
author: Connie W.

description:
Being of Indian origin, I probably hold Indian restaurants to a higher standard than most.  You might call that a bias, but I would call it knowing what I'm talking about.  Amber India is a pretty restaurant, with a modern but comfy aesthetic.  The food, though, is about as boring as Indian food can be.  

Most Indian restaurants in the US start with an authentic Indian recipe, and then they cut the flavor in half (for fear of offending sensitive western palates).  Amber cuts the flavor to about a measly quarter of where it ought to be.  And to be clear, I'm not talking about "heat"; I'm talking about flavor (Indian food, as a general rule, is not intended to be "hot").

We had:
- Four-Chili Rubbed Sea Bass: The flavor was actually very good, but there just wasn't much of it.  The "rub" was apparently more of a gentle tap.  Very little of the flavors actually came through in the finished product.  Also, the fish was slightly undercooked.  And at $27, I was expecting more than 5 small pieces of fish.
- Subj Korma: It is a common cheat, among western Indian restaurants, to subtract spices and other expensive ingredients, and then make up for it by adding butter or cream.  And that's precisely what they did here.  This was, without a doubt, the blandest Indian-style vegetable dish I've ever eaten anywhere.  And at $16, probably the most expensive as well.
- Naan: It was good, but I suspect that if it were possible to subtract flavor from bread, they would have done so.  And $3.50 for a single serving?  That's crazy.
- Zafran Khuska: fancy name for white rice with a few spices thrown in.  Pretty good, but a really skimpy serving for $3.

Which brings me to my last point...I just can't believe that I paid $70 for all of this bland food.  Overpriced, flavorless...all style, no substance.  Do yourself a favor and go to Pakwan instead.  You'll get 3 times the flavor for 1/3 the price.
author: Ritik C.

description:
I have been to multiple Indian places in the bay area and to different ambers too spread across the bay area but the one in SF has the best food amongst them all according to me.

Things ordered  and loved 
 Duck Tinka Kebab    (appetizer)
 Aloo Peas Samosa   (appetizer)

the rest was standard chicken curry and naan

I was hosting a friend from the east coast and I could take her to an authentic indian place.

I can safely add amber sf to my list of safe places to go to when I dont feel the need to experiment.
author: Utsav M.

description:
A really good indian restaurant with great ambience.
Its a little bit expensive but ohh well its in SF Downtown.
Panner butter masala is great.
author: Sree Harsha U.

description: The butter chicken is to die for. Although this restaurant usually looks empty, it's only because the restaurant has so many seats. My family and I always come here for birthdays. The food tastes fresh and the service is excellent.
author: E R.

description: Amazing food!  I really enjoyed the palak chat and lamb vindaloo.  Simply amazing!!!! Was doubtful the higher prices would be worth it but it totally is worth every penny!!!!
author: Ana J.

description:
For two, we had:

Pappad's, thin lentil crepes, that you bite into for a satisfying crunch and end up asking for more mint chutney and also dip into the yogurt sauce meant for the chicken (I think). Shames potato chips, tortilla chips, and all other thin and crispy munchers.

Garlic naan, "to wrap the chicken and eat like a burrito", says my Indian (but not so Indian) boyfriend

Saffron chicken tikka, boneless white meat grilled until it's a bit charred but still incredibly juicy

Lamb biryani, which came with this...poofy bread top (think pot pie), 'cept the waiter cut a circle out of the top and didn't leave us the bread :(. I guess you're not supposed to eat that part, but I always eat my pizza crust. sadface. Inside was an amazing combination of rice, herbs, and lamb. happyface!

Shahi Tukda, aka the most bizarre bread pudding I've ever tried. It was crunchy, covered in grape jam, and sprinkled with silver!

Mango brulee, so yes, mango-flavored creme brulee topped with fruit! love at first crack. (I love cracking open the sugary top with my spoon.)

best Indian food I've ever had (3stars!) + cute interior and lighting (1 star) + the prettiest and most polite waitresses I've ever encountered (1 more star) = 5 stars!
author: Serena W.

description: Really well done.  I took Indian cuisine newbies, so I was a little concerned that this place wasn't traditional enough.  It turned out to be a very familiar experience with a few new-to-me things on the menu. The Palak Chaat was something I'd never had before, and I thought it was really tasty....crispy  without being heavy, well seasoned, etc.  The Samosas are good, but I prefer them bigger to increase the ratio of potato and peas filling to wrapper.  The butter chicken was a safe choice, but it turned out to be one of the best I've had. The tandoor items were mixed. I liked the chicken and shrimp, but I thought the lamb was tough and chewy. Onion kulcha was great!, and the drinks were well mixed.
author: Nick L.

description: Pricey, but the best Indian buffet in SF. Also, very clean restaurant.
author: Anand P.

description:
I checked in for my reservation, was acknowledged, and then ignored for 45 minutes. It was crowded, sure, but when I went back to check on my table, they thought I was just showing up for the first time, 40 minutes late -- and were snarky about it. I informed them of their mistake, and they seated us in about 10 minutes, then asked us to move to a different table after we'd sat down.

The food was good, though. And I've had better experiences in previous years.
author: Christopher M.

description: Really love this place. Would be great for date night. The cocktails are fun and really tasty! The food was truly exceptional although I agree it was pricey, but you def get what you pay for here. Service, ambiance, food, and overall quality is perfection!
author: Kimberly C.

description: Went there for lunch with my team. There is a long line at the buffet area, but the food is just ok, not surprise me at all. just moderate indian food. Perhaps dinner is much better?
author: Danielle M.

description: I have been here a couple of times for lunch buffet and love it. The ambience is good, the quality of the food is really good and its very tasty too. Though its kind of pricey to be a regular lunch spot, thus only 4 stars. Definitely recommended.
author: Umang D.

description: The whole experience was very enjoyable.  Food was good, service was good, location and ambiance are nice.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Amber had really good food and service!

Had the Jaipur Bhindi, Kofta, and Garlic Naan, and all of them were really tasty

Ambiance was very nice and intimate - ideal for a small group
author: Rahul D.

description:
These are what I look for in an Indian lunch buffet:

Food Quality - Good.
Food Taste - Good.
Customer Service - Fair.
Price - Overpriced.
Ambiance - Great.

Saw the review on Yelp and decided to try this place out. Wish we hadn't. This is one of those places that would be great if you have a Groupon or living social deal. Otherwise this place is completely overpriced. $18 for an Indian buffet lunch? We should have walked away, but it was cold and we were hungry. 

The selection was limited (only two different curries - chicken and lamb - and a bunch of other vegetable mixtures).  The naan bread was flat (not fluffy) and bland. Not really that great. The Butter Chicken was good though, and I had that each time i returned.  I don't believe there are dedicated service personnel to each table and its kind of just service each table. Which sounds great in theory, but there is no cohesiveness in the service (we would go a while before getting our naan bread, while being told someone was on it -- or go a while without refills of water). 

This is the type of place where you get your first plate, and immediately regret spending the money to eat there. Overall, the place was ok, and would be fairly priced if it were $9.99 for a buffet. 

The primary reason the review falls short of the 4-stars is because of the price.
author: Ben D.

description: Good food, great location and service.  We showed up on a Friday night without reservations and despite it being busy we were able to get a table within 15 minutes.  Would highly recommend the butter chicken and roganjosh.  Although it isn't the best Indian food I have had it was a solid 4 stars.  I would go back.
author: Chad N.

description: Very nice meal. The Butter Chicken is amazing, however I did find a small bone in it which was rather disappointing but it certainly didn't take away from tasty it was. The garlic naan is also amazing, not to be missed!!
author: David H.

description: Delicious food and nice peaceful dining environment. Prices were a bit steep though and I had to wait a long time for a refill on my drink. Overall a pleasant experience.
author: Brian V.

description:
the food is very good but the service could use some work. 

good : butter chicken, garlic naan, the tandori, all very tasty.

bad : service could be improved upon. my waitress messed up our order, brought us something else, charged us for it, and then didn't even comp the item she messed up. We brought the mistake to her attention but she did not fix it.

5 stars for food, 2 stars for service.
author: Hello G.

description: Food was excellent.  The staff was very accomodating and we were extremely amazed with how fast the food came to the table.  I have been here twice and yet to be letdown.
author: Tommy R.

description: The best Indian food in California. At par with Junoon@NY or Raskia@DC
author: Minx K.

description: I love Amber India! All I have to say is butter chicken, rice (of course I'm Filipino) and garlic naan - "You don't know Naan" (*Trina Voice*) until you've tried it! I also tried a really amazing fish dish, cod maybe? Whatever it was it was delish - the texture and taste was perfect! I went safe on the dessert, Molten Chocolate cake...I know BORING but it too was delish!!! They deserve 5 Stars - vibrant tasting food, just enough spice and a classy joint! Only negative thing I would say is that Yerba Buena Alley is a wind tunnel! Great when it's sunny but crazy cold when it's not. Layer it up and prepare yourself for a great meal. I'll be going there whenever I have an Indian Food hankering!
author: Christine L.

description: The food here was good, nothing too special. I've been to better Indian restaurants. I had the cauliflower bezule which was good but not amazing. The prices were a bit high so I recommend just ordering an appetizer. My rating is 3 1/2 out of 5.
author: Danny A.

description:
FABULOUS!!!!!
Hosted a 15 guest dinner party at Amber and the food was fabulous.
The waiter took individual orders from each guest and the correct food made it to each guest! The food was incredible, I can't wait to go back.

* The bar was beautiful, but the service was terrible! The slowest bartenders produced mediocre drinks... The bar needs to hustle when big groups come in!
author: Ashley S.

description: When ever my man and I make it to San Francisco we always try our best to have dinner here. I must admit we've not ventured off in the menu too much...our fav is the Butter Chicken and Amber Dahl. The cheese naan is the bomb! The food, service and ambiance all get an A in my book. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jo S.

description:
Perfectly adequate Americanized Indian food in a very nice atmosphere and nice location.

So long as you're OK with paying premium price for the atmosphere and location, (service was fine as well), as opposed to the food; it's OK.

There's better food to be had for this price or cheaper right nearby though, IMO.  (Bluestem just up the street, or Tropisueno)
author: Matt C.

description:
Amber has great food.  The Butter Chicken is their signature dish and it's basically as advertised -- chicken from the tandoor, rich tomato sauce.  It's extremely filling.  The roganjosh is rich and has a bright spice flavor; the lamb is meltingly tender.  The naan and rice are always made perfectly.  I particularly love their jaipuri bhindi, the okra cooked down with fennel seeds, tomato, and green mango.  The okra has just the right amount of sticky (not slimy!) caramelization, and there's just a hint of bright acid in it.  It's addictive and appealing even for folks who hate okra.

It's more expensive than your typical indian joint.  I am fine with that.  For some reason people expect that French food should be expensive, but not Indian food.  If a French place charges $20 for a great roasted chicken, then it's OK, it's gourmet.  But a great butter chicken dish?  Well, cue the bitching ... 

Indian cuisine is subtle, difficult to make well, and relies on the same laws of physics as any other cuisine:  fresh food, good technique, giving a damn, etc. etc.  Amber does all of the above.  They can charge higher prices, and it's worth paying up.
author: J W.

description: Had dinner here last night with some friends visiting from LA.  I got here a little early so had a cocktail at the bar while I waited for them to show up.  They have a decent happy hour at the bar but not at the dinner tables.  We had an early dinner (6pm) since we had children with us.  The place was empty so I was a little concerned but by the time we left at 8pm it was packed.  I understand why.  The food was very good-although the portions are small.  Seems to be the case at most trendy places where presentation is more important than the quality of the food but again the food was very good.  Note that there Zafran Khuska| rice had very little to no saffron in it. But what do you expect for a $3.00 side.  The Samosa  app was very good. My fav's were the Awadhi Lamb Qorma (awesome) and Butter chicken.
author: Dan D.

description: Give me Naan N Curry any day!  Amber India serves a very expensive lunch buffet that is not any better than Naan N Curry.  I'd rather save the $17 I spent on two lunches at Naan N Curry.
author: C L.

description: Amazing. The cocktails are perfectly balanced and the food is authentic in this trendy Indian treasure in the heart of the SOMA. I've been here 3 times now, and can honestly say I will return with gusto. Kudos to Amber India!
author: Alex M.

description:
This spot went from empty to packed in the span of about fifteen minutes -- modern decor framing the sunken dining room, we wandered in here for a buffet, necessary to satisfy my Indian jonesing. Ultimately I tackled a variety of dishes, from the butter chicken (shredded Tandoori chicken in a rich tomato sauce), piled high on Saffron Pulao (Basmati rice cooked on "dum" with saffron & spices), dishes ranged from mildly warm to chilled, and all were frankly pretty tasty.

I didn't have an opportunity to sample a cocktail this go round, but the naan was terriffic and time permitting I want to head back to sample some dessert. Service was present but rarely super prompt, and eats can be a little spendy, but in a pinch, Amber did me just grand. You've not seen the last of me, Amber. Count on it.
author: Kevin N.

description: Great food, prompt service. A little fancy and you have to descend to hades to dine.
author: Donald M.

description:
Dark, spacious, don't have to yell across the table = my favorite restaurant atmosphere

Great service, thoroughly enjoyed food
author: Hannah W.

description: When here for the first time ever eating Indian food and my was it amazing! It's a bit expensive but if you want good Indian food you can't turn this place down. We had no idea what to order so the lady basically ordered for us and let me tell you we had no leftovers :)
author: Amber T.

description: I went in today for lunch, having been there once before. Today, the young bitc# hostess was on her phone when I walked in, and didn't look up for several seconds after I'd been standing by the host stand. When she finally looked up, I said one for the buffet. She was rude from the start and didn't look like she wanted to be there. She was really rude. Oh, did I say that already? I guess you must have enough business if you think you can be rude to people. I had a very bad feeling about that, so I walked instead to Tava on Second - the people at Tava are so much nicer. Amber India, you're overpriced and your hostess should be fired. I am never going back to your place again.
author: Frank S.

description:
Located right across from the new Jewish Contemporary Museum is Amber India in the new Yerba Buena Center.  Dropped off one of my cars at the mechanic today so was stuck downtown and was walking around trying to decide where to eat when I discovered this.  Wow, this area is nice...I'm a native San Franciscan, but had no idea all this was here.  When did they build all this?

Have been craving good Indian food for the longest time and was trying to think of a good downtown Indian place when I suddenly saw a sign for Amber.  Had no idea this was here!  I was definitely surprised and elated.  Saw that they had a weekday buffet for $16.95 and thought it a bit pricey so I decided to pass and walk around the food court of the new Westfield Center first.  After seeing their prices for blah food, ($11.99 for mediocre looking plastic pack sushi), I hurried back to Amber for lunch.

Upon walking in, I was very pleased with the decor and the level of service.  For lack of a better description, this is the most yuppified, most upscale Indian restaurant I have ever had the fortune to dine in.  Needless to say, I liked it.  The wine list certainly made me happy as well.  I chose a glass of Sageland white riesling that I thought would complement the spicy food perfectly.  From my first sip, I knew I made a killer choice...it was delicious and a perfect pairing (patting myself on the back) which really added to the experience.  At $8.00, I thought it to be really reasonable too, compared to what a lot of others charge for a glass of wine in a comparable setting.

Upon seeing the buffet area, I was slightly disappointed at the selection as I had been expecting something on a grander scale.  Since it was Amber, I had envisioned something along the lines of Bombay Garden in Fremont which has a huge number of choices (although nowhere near the level of quality).  Regardless, what Amber's buffet lacked in variety, it more than made up for in quality.

Everything I tasted was wonderful (have to admit, I've been craving good Indian food for the longest time!) and paired with my wine choice, it was like a little bit of heaven in the middle of the day.  Their signature dish, butter chicken (shredded tandoori chicken in rich tomato sauce) and Sindhi Murg (juicy morsels of chicken flavored with fenugreek leaves and brown garlic) were my two absolute faves.  The pieces of chicken in both of these curries were surprisingly big and juicy, definitely moist and not dry.  Over rice, each of these was fantastic in their own way and I was impressed.  What can I say...the diet went out the window temporarily and I definitely ended up eating more than I had intended.

The only true negative that I discovered during my experience was their potato balls (not sure what they were called) which were really dry and tasteless.  They were so dry and chalky that I regretted getting them from the first bite and wondered if I was doing something wrong or if I was supposed to be pouring curry over them (I didn't) as they were so bad.  The tandoori chicken looked good, but the pieces I had were on the dry side...very different from the awesome chunks I had in the earlier curries.  Regardless, I enjoyed my lunch here today immensely.

The service was first rate too and you could tell that the staff was all very well trained.  When I first walked in, it was so dead that I questioned the intelligence of eating a buffet lunch in an upscale downtown Indian restaurant on a Monday in this economy.  Within minutes, the place was packed.  Wow...economy...what bad economy?

This was the best Indian dining experience I've had in a long time and my new favorite.  Food was first rate, as was the service.  Will definitely be back!
author: Roy N.

description:
Came here for a nice dinner on a Friday. For the area near the Metreon, I think Amber India is one of the better places to go. It has a bit of a strange design and the tables are strangely placed. I had to comment on the dance I did getting to the restroom. Because of the chairs.

We started with Aloo Peas Samosas, crispy and warm and hearty (4/5). The Ginger Crab was good but a bit pricey for the amount of food, despite it being crab (3/5). The naan was warm and chewy and wholly satisfying (4/5), with enough absorbing power to pick up all the delicious sauce of our entree. Butter chicken. I had heard about it before and it did not disappoint. Tender chunks of chicken in a warmly spiced, buttery sauce. My foodie partner was lactose intolerant but still endured the future discomfort; that's how good it was.

Overall a satisfying meal although you do leave smelling like the food, but that is what happens with most Asian food.
author: Dave K.

description: There drinks are good we tried almost all the cocktails. Bartender was extreemly nice, she made sure we drink water between our drinks :)) Butter chicken, lamb and cheese naan are gr8. Likes the rasmalai as well. Little pricy but worth the ambience and taste
author: Astha S.

description:
After swearing off Indian buffets due to a few too many unfortunate "incidents", finally decided to give Amber's lunch buffet a try based on a coworker's review. SO glad that I went! While the selection wasn't as extravagant and ostentatious as I'd expected, the food was all very well done. I'd estimate they had around 20 items broken out into a couple of different areas (salads, savory, rice / naan, desserts, etc.)

Unlike the other Indian buffets that I've been to, the quality and creativity of these dishes didn't disappoint (i.e., it wasn't just pounds upon pounds of greasy and flavorless chicken tikki masala and saag paneer). The usual dishes were definitely better than most others based on spice, flavor, and lack-of-greasiness. Additionally, they offer other, more creative dishes to appeal to the more adventurous spirit while still making them mainstream enough for the average diner. In particular, the pickled mustard chicken in the cold section that was to die for - don't overlook it just because its in the salad area!

It was totally empty on the Saturday afternoon that we went. I'd thought that this place was more popular, especially given its convenient location, but was happy to have attentive servers and plenty of space.
author: Nils H.

description:
Super tasty but super empty wallet! But definitely worth it! I had already gone to the Amber India in Santana Row and wanted to check out this location. 

Food was the same amazing quality, but the decor wasn't as impressive, but still pretty good. I would have liked to see the starry ceiling or something that stood out more than the dim lights and random stairs. 

If you want quality creative Indian food, this is the place to go, please don't order butter chicken and naan. Go to naan and curry for that! Try to be exotic in your selection because you really can't make a wrong decision. Everything I've tried was tasty and I've tried pretty much everything! My favorite dish was the crispy spinach chaat appetizer, definitely give it a try

Warning: The signature cocktails are a little strong. Enjoy!
author: Chirag V.

description: Don't special order.  They will mess it up and not take accountability for the mistake.   Customer is never right....
author: Hersch P.

description: The staff manager was really really rude. We wanted to celebrate birthday. We came in at 7:30. Two people in our group were late but we had already started ordering. The manager walked up to our table half an hour later and asked us to leave at 8:30 pm sharp because he had some other reservation. WTF! After I said if we are able to finish bday dinner by then we will. Then he kept coming over to our table and kept hovering over every ten minutes to see if we had left. This was really really bad and rude. He spoiled the birthday. Please do not go here if you want to have a good time. Food was amazing even waiters were really good but the manager was way too rude.
author: Khushboo S.

description:
Wow!!!!!!!!

My first Indian food experience EVER and I LOVED IT!!!!!

A friend and I decided to go here for Dine about town.

OMG...Literally and I tell you no lies, you can smell the food all the way down the block!!!

We got there at 5pm and the minute we viewed the regular menu there was NO WAY in hell we could eat off of the Dine About Town menu :)

So...we got at it!!!!

Our order:  Palak Chaat, Butternut Saffron Soup, Ginger Crab, Butter Chicken Tandoor Grilled Shrimps and Lacchua Paratha.

OMG...the flavors and spices came alive on my palette.  
The only thing I didn't try of course was the chicken but my friend absolutely loved it.
My favorite was the ginger crab.

The customer service from the waiters, servers and hostesses were SUPERB!!!  The ambiance of the place was subtle and remarkable.  I loved every minute of it.

Because I'm not a fan of spicy and lord knows I can't really take much of it the Tandoor shrimp was a bit much for me.  I couldn't eat it all because by the time I got to like the 3rd one, my mouth was on fire.

The one thing I wish I could change about the place was the bread (for lack of better words).  I wish we didn't have to pay for EVERY order as we had a lot and there were only 4 pieces.

Totally damage for the night:  $50 total each...kinda costly but worth it for a first time :)
author: Sandra S.

description:
Good food, spendy, seated without res on a sat night 630pm.  place was packed.  waitress was nice, food served fast. tasty.  the one in santana row is better (i would have thought otherwise).

drinks were ok, not great

hostesses think they are hot s and could use some attitude adjustments.
author: Anonymouse Y.

description:
I came here tonight for the first time. I have been meaning to try this place for a long time. They are usually busy so i was very happy to walk in and be seated right away.
I told the waitress my favorite dish, chicken tikka masala, She told me they could make it but it wasn't on the menu. She then told me about the butter chicken and how similar it was to thechicken tikka masala dishes i love so much and often get at other indian restaurants. I took her advice and got the butter chicken. It was Amazing!! best indian dish i have ever had hands down. 
I will without a doubt be coming back here. Great service and Great food!
author: Wes P.

description:
It's really too bad that the service here is slow as molasses, because it's one of the few places in the area that has seating for large groups.

I'd like to see more variety in their menu and when comparing to how much it costs to make the food, the prices are on the high side.  That said, the food is good, just kinda boring.

But for trying to feed large numbers of people, if I wanted indian food, I'd go elsewhere.
author: Hilary C.

description:
Great food, great quality! I have enjoyed two great dinners at Amber, the bar is cool to hang in and have a drink before dinner. The quality of the food is excellent, try the Seekh Kebab Kangari (lamb sausage, makes a good starter) also, Kadhai Paneer from the vegetarian menu, its a cottage     cheese dish, the best ever! As always with Indian food just order a few things and share family style. Don't forget your garlic naan!
Cheers
author: Patricia L.

description:
Amazing food and terrible, terrible service. Much like Neil B. wrote, our food took far too long without explanation or apology or complimentary anything for our taste. 

We arrived at 6pm to a lovely ambiance and had nice seating by the window. I ordered an amber blush to start and my boyfriend had a beer. The drinks took at least ten minutes to come out, though I'd highly recommended my non-alcoholic drink. Another fifteen minute passed before our mussels appetizer came out. We thoroughly enjoyed it with the fresh and fluffy naan. Our appetizer plates were removed and we literally sat for AT LEAST another awkward twenty-five minutes or so before our entrees came out. No one offered us extra naan to dip with our mussels broth and only once did the waitress briefly swing by and say almost coming. The ice in my drink melted away. In the time we waited for our entree, a lone diner finished his meal and left as did a neighboring couple who had arrived at about the same time we did. Finally, finally, our butter chicken and lamb shank came out without a word. The food was amazing but our whole dining experience took two hours!

Yes our water was kept filled and the busboys were very nice, but our waitress was distant. The problem could have easily been rectified with more friendliness, explanation, or apology or even free naan but alas, we left disappointed and angry. Did they have live lamb tied to the wall out back that had to be killed for our dinner hence the wait time?! No idea...
author: Jan P.

description: Came here for their Sunday brunch buffet and it happened to be on mother's day. Not sure if they had any special on that day.  But the food was good and the mimosa just kept coming!!!  I really like the ambience of the restaurant.  Of course with indian buffet, the spicy level is usually mild. So if you really like spicy indian food, you might not enjoy the buffet.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Tried the lunch buffet today, everything tasted pretty good. Definitely will come back next time I'm in SF.    Their veggie dishes were particularly good. Nice variety of choices offered and the decor is pretty cool too, I would call it modern artsy Indian.  Price is a bit steep for a buffet.
author: Eddie G.

description: The butter chicken and lamb curry is spicy, really really spicy... and that's what I was looking for. the wine was also really nice and the waiter recommended a Sicilian wine that had such a strong fruit/berry flavor. 2 dishes, 2 sides (rice and naan), 2 glasses of wine for 98 including 15% tip. Expensive for 2 people, but the amount of food could have served 3 (our second dish was barely touched)
author: Alex H.

description:
Its a bit of a hit and miss sometimes. On the bright side, they have an excellent location at the mouth of Yerba Buena Lane and the decor and nice and elegant unlike the dark and dingy I've come to expect from most Indian restaurants.

The buffet is usually a solid choice because of the diversity it offers. Having grown up in India, I sometimes find the food a bit bland, but you can get the dosas and uttapams made to order, but don't ask for extra spicy, it seems they want to burn your tongue out if you ask for it. Overall though, its great to have a non-shady Indian restaurant in the middle of the city when I'm too lazy to decide and default back to Indian food.
author: Abhinav S.

description: This spot deserves 5 stars, but an annoying ear piercing fire alarm kept on going off. It was a bit annoying, but all in all I LOVE THIS PLACE! I drink prices were really good around $10. I had there specialty drink which is Kiss of the Buddha. It was a mix of Vodka and American Absinth. I'm not really sure what else was in there, but I was 100% satisfied with it. It was so good. The ambiance of this place is amazing. Nice elevated bar and great seating. The lights behind the bar changes every 10 seconds or so which creates a new ambiance everytime. For the prices and location I was really satisfied and will be coming back here when i'm back on the West Coast.
author: Ron C.

description:
Great food and great service...yes, a lil pricey - but you knew that going in right? ;)

Dinner with a couple friends - we ordered: Samosas, Tandoori Stuffed Aloo, Butter Chicken and Badam Bhara Baingan (an eggplant dish) all of it was delish and everyone left stuffed and happy...
author: Aida V.

description: Was here on April 9th for lunch. I love Indian food. This was like a little up-scale to a few of the Indian restaurants I have been. Had the buffet. It was very good. I love curry and can eat it all day.
author: Greg W.

description: This is one of my favorite date night restaurants in the city. It's a little on the pricey side, but the food is always amazing. The wait staff is very polite and we always have a great time when we come here. I highly recommend it!
author: Claire M.

description:
Food/Service: Great. The butter chicken is luscious and was told it's a signature dish. The mixed grill appetizer provides an opportunity to taste a variety of their foods. I have been here several times and the food is consistently good.

Waiter recommended a sea bass dish. The fish was tender and moist, with the correct amount of char to add an earthy sweetness. It was almost better than the butter chicken, but nothing beats the butter chicken.

Bar: Nice. It's crowded at times, probably from the Marriot around the corner. 

Worth going back: Yes.
author: A I.

description:
Caveat: I'm rating this based on my experience at the weekend buffet

I don't get why everyone calls Amber among the best Indian food in SF. Its not, not even by a long shot. Given it was a buffet, I made sure to try at least a little bit of everything. I enjoyed the gold guppas, the naan, and the butter chicken but the rest of the items were eh. Nothing was horrible, but also it wasn't anything that would blow you away. And the dessert was lacking (no fruit and what they had wasn't great either). I've definitely had better Indian food in SF, even at some smaller hole in wall type places.

While the guy making the dosas is cool, and the setting is nice / classy, the food just its just isn't good enough to justify the $20 buffet price.
author: Rick P.

description:
We visited for dinner this past weekend.   Having eaten numerous times at the Santana Row location we knew what to expect.  
The interior is modern, elegant and service was attentive and professional.
I ordered a caipirinha and the hubby had a Taj.  I was pleasantly surprised that my drink was good yet not too sweet.  I ordered the salmon tandoori and thought it was ok-I thought it was a little overcooked.  The hubby had the butter chicken and he was quite pleased with his dish.  The raita was excellent but the basmati rice was just ok.   
They do a great job at providing an inviting ambiance and we would return because we enjoy the cuisine.
author: Lizete S.

description: Excellent Indian food, slightly higher price but great food without any doubts.
author: An M.

description: OMG this place was sooooo awesome;) we just absolutely loved it ~* Must try the prawn marsala the best ever......;)~
author: Allison K.

description:
Extremely disappointed in this place.  We got seated in an uncomfortable table sandwiched against the wall in a tight corner.  Our server was extremely inconsistent, asking for our order 1 second after we sat down and then when we asked for more time didn't come by for 15 minutes or so.  Additionally, my water glass was empty most of my meal when I could have used it to eat the spicy food.

As for the food itself, extremel underwhelmed.  The lentil/potato cakes tasted just like fried potatoes and were extremely uninteresting.  The palak chaat was fried spinach was interesting.  As for the main course, the vegetable korma just tasted extraordinarily average and the pesto naan tasted oily and gross.

On a plus note, my friend liked his cocktail.

Amber is supposed to be great food at appropriate prices with great service.  I found it to be sub-average food at inflated prices and horrible service.
author: Jeff A.

description:
Been here a few times now and i really like the food. It's hard to find Indian flavors that is not too over powering and have delicious. The decor fits perfectly and i love the big mirrors! Some of the cocktails were really yummy. 

I feel that it's time to update the menu a bit though. Maybe change it each season would be wonderful because all the dishes seems to blend together after a while.
author: Amy L.

description: I came for cocktails and appetizers in the bar for happy hour.  Good service but alittle crammed in the bar space. I like the central downtown location. I look forward to coming back for a meal.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Indian food is not something I usually crave...but Amber India changed all that.
author: C K.

description:
The best Indian food! Not your typical dive-joint greasy Indian Pakistani chow, but beautifully presented cuisine in an upscale setting. 

The pricey ($22) byrani is so good...I get it once in a while to go for lunch, eat half and save the rest for later.
author: N B.

description:
i came here on valentine's day without a reservation at 8pm. they were fully booked but accommodated us in the lounge area, which was very nice of them. HOWEVER...read on....

the seats were not very comfortable, but it is mainly for lounging and not for eating. since we didn't sit in the main dining room area, they told us we weren't obligated to order the prix fixe menu.

so we ordered an appetiser and 2 maincourses, and we got the appetiser in half an hour. , which was some shrimp with sprouts? that was delicious!
we killed it in like 2 seconds. then we waited for another half an hour for the food, we were starving, by then it was about 9pm and we thought we should ask the waiter where our food was. also since we were in the lounge area, waiters were hard to come by.

apparently they forgot to ring up our order. -_-""" okay. i guess we should've checked with them earlier. but since they took forever to take out the appetiser and the restaurant was busy, we didn't want to be too annoying....

then i noticed there were 2 seats in the dining area that had been open the entire time. i asked the manager about it and he said we could move there but we'd have to order the prix fixe. and since we already waited over an hour for our food, we didn't want to wait again. and then the manager LIED to us saying our food took so long BECAUSE i wanted to move there...but i asked about the food BEFORE i asked to move there. T_T

well the food came in like 15 minutes. i guess it really wasn't supposed to take that long.

i got some chicken curry? and my boyfriend got lamb shanks or something. we also got two orders of naan. the food was good. one of the best indian food i've had! i don't know about authenticity. they didn't give me any paupadams, so that was sad. 

and then the waiter offered soda on the house to compensate for our wait. not very generous, but better than nothing. feeble attempt to redeem itself.

regardless, the restaurant has a nice atmosphere, and maybe it's a one time thing. they were accommodating in the first place, but i do wish they made more of an effort to redeem themselves. they bumped their tip from 10% to 12% with the drinks. 

favourites: the food was bomb

do not want: not very generous...bad service. pricey for indian food.

last words: i guess we should have made a reservation. this is a fancy restaurant for indian food. good food, not sure if it's worth the price. but the food was good.
author: Celine L.

description:
We went here for dinner last night since it is in the neighborhood of our hotel and it was easy to get to.  We made a reservation on Open Table and that was easy too.

When we arrived, there were about two or three other parties seated in the dining room.  They proceeded to give us a table that was near where the servers gathered as they waited for their stations to fill with diners.  That was not the best choice. It was so distracting to be near the serving station when the rest of the restaurant was empty. 

Our server was great though.  We liked him very much.

I ordered a Pilsner ... and a few minutes later I was notified that they were out of my choice.  I ordered some red wine instead and it was fine.

We would have ordered appetizers, but honestly, I was ready to go before we even started.  We just ordered a main course and some garlic naan and we ate and got out of there within an hour.

The food is really good.  I liked the lamb and my husband enjoyed his vegetarian choice as well.  They know their spices and they use them.  The naan was good too.

The lamb was ~ $22 and I think it is a little pricey ... especially since you have to purchase rice in addition.  

I may come back and give them a try for the lunch buffet.  Next time, I will ask for a table in the main dining room away from the server's station.
author: Lee R.

description:
***CHECK YOUR CREDIT CARD statement if you pay by credit card!*** 
They charged more than the amount I signed for.  I did a quick search through their reviews, and this over charging seems to happen a lot.
author: Amy J.

description:
My new favorite Indian restaurant.  I had dinner here with a friend about 2 months ago and everything we ordered tasted great!  The place also seemed clean and restaurant staffs were very friendly. The price is also reasonable.

The place seemed a bit too crowded and tables seemed too close to each other. That's the only thing I didn't like about this place.
author: Mai K.

description: Dinner was great. They have some pretty innovative dishes. Try the Cauliflower Bezule (it has a very South Indian twist to the Gobi Manchurian) and the Chili Thyme Naan - both yum. They also have a pesto naan which is nice. What I liked was that the naans were not too big (and really soft!) and you could actually finish an entire naan - that happens very rarely. Dessert was yummy too.
author: Anusha S.

description: I'm a big fan of this place, but I have unfortunately found better Indian buffets in the city that I can walk to.  This is upscale with drunk wives on unlimited mimosas.  If that toots your fancy.
author: Mot Y.

description:
I have gone to the Amber in Santana Row and have loved it so I had high expectations for this one.  It has potential and I think being newly opened still needs to iron out a few things. Service is a huge one, this is a nice downtown restaurant so they need to be on top of their game.  We were waiting for our server to take our order and get our drinks a bit too long, and the place wasn't packed.  Now yes, we were hungry and annoyed that when we decided to take the bus there, we didn't think we would have to wait for it for over twenty minutes so I admit we were a bit annoyed to begin with.

Our waiter was very friendly and knowledgeable on the dishes, great energy,  but our samosas came out before our drinks and they were cold, so it was a sign they were sitting there already made instead of being made fresh.  This should never happen with this type of appetizer. 

The lamb we ordered was good but not great, it should have been more tender and slow cooked, the spinach and mushroom dish was great though, the bread was great, and I liked the option of the whole wheat naan.  

The ambiance was great, the place is very much downtown, not a lot of Indian influence, there is a lounge in the front to just get a drink.  The drinks were very good, they made a great martini and we got the flight of Grand Marinier for dessert which was excellent.  

Speaking of dessert, if you have lobster on the menu, which isn't a typical Indian dish, why not have some chocolate desserts?
author: Inga W.

description: Hey this place totally rocks for happy hour, you wouldn't even know its an Indian cuisine until ordering food. Eastbay people can catch the BART and walk only one block over. Sorta pricey, but otherwise, I enjoyed with several colleagues for a couple hours.
author: Betty B.

description: I think this has been the best Indian food I have eaten. I love Vic's, but this is at another level of good. The flavors and textures were excellent. If you like Indian food this is a great place. And it was a very nice atmosphere . I had a white wine that was also delicious.. It's a large restaurant, but the color and space felt cozy enough so that it was nice to spend time there
author: Marni S.

description:
If Amber India were a character from LOST, it would be Charlotte.

1) Charlotte's time on LOST was a lot shorter than we originally expected. Although I was expecting some pretty outstanding treats, the food wasn't *that* good (But mad props to the pesto naan for combining two of my favorite things: pesto and carbs).

2) Charlotte has a British accent. India was once conquered by England. 

3) Charlotte went back to the place she was born, only to die. Amber India has no connection to this one... just thought it was worth mentioning. 

4) Charlotte kept it simple in her two-toned t-shirts and jeans. This is where Charlotte and Amber India definitely diverge. The place looks pretty fancy. Almost to the point that you question the quality/authenticity of the food based on all your other Indian eating experiences. But the space IS really nice in its multi-level creation.

5) Charlotte drank water on the Island. We drank Pimms at Amber India. According to Webtender, "Pimm's No. 1 is a gin-based liquor made in England from dry gin, liqueur, fruit juices and spices. It was created in 1859 by the English oyster bar owner James Pimm. The recipe is still a secret, and only six persons know exactly how it is made." British? A secret? 6 people? Just like the Oceanic 6 who escaped from...... THE ISLAND!!!

The coincidences are striking.
author: Jared S.

description: We came here for brunch and it's so good! There are so many items to choose from and they have bottomless mimosas. All of the food is very fresh and flavorful.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Ok I finally made it here for lunch & I have to downgrade them to 3 stars. It's not that the food is bad, it's just not worth $17 for the buffet. For half that price I can get better food just down the street in the Tenderloin. Of course the ambiance is a bit different. 

Amber definitely caters to the work crowd. There were scores of young professionals enjoying their meals. The place was packed at 1:00 on a Thursday. 

The dishes I liked: Butter chicken, dal, saag paneer. 

So-so: Naan, baby corn spicy dish (not sure of the name), tandoori chicken, aloo potatoes. 

I would come back for their happy hour, but I doubt I'll be back for lunch or dinner.
author: Erin S.

description: Was a little disappointed. Dish lacked flavour, sauce was quite bland and while I was told it was medium heat it was definitely very mild. Mango creme brulee was very nice though, pity about the main.
author: Tracy O.

description:
We arrived at 6:30 and ordered promptly. At the time, the restaurant was pretty empty. Our appetizers arrived quickly, but our entrees did not arrive until 8:15. That's a pretty long time to wait for a restaurant in the States, and much longer than I ever had to wait at the Mountain View location.

Our server was very professional and handled our irritation with aplomb, so I'll knock it back up a star. The place was very chic and posh. The food itself was good but not exceptional. I'll qualify that by saying that I've never been to India and thus can't really judge its authenticity. There were plenty of Indian people dining there so I'm guessing it's pretty authentic. But to my taste I've had better Indian food in London, Tokyo, and Portland.
author: Neil B.

description:
The food, service and ambiance are all very nice.  Location on Market is not great and can make it hard to locate.  But based on the crowds, people are dealing with the location.  It is an elegant/fancy restaurant, which is different then most Indian Food restaurants in SF.  Service is attentive, although they were a little slow to seat us for our reservation.  They have good menu selection for food and drinks.

The food is very good.  However, I thought it was expensive since you get nickle-and-dimed for things such as having to order (and pay for) rice, papadom, naan, etc.   The entree prices at dinner were pricey.  The lunch buffet seems like a better deal, where you can get what you want with all the sides at a reasonable price.
author: Randy P.

description:
Dinner is wonderful!  Such carefully prepared Indian food and a great wine selection!  The only disappointment was the bhindi - too dry.  The eggplant with some sort of almond paste was amazing, as were most things.  

The lunch buffet - meh.  They lie.  There's no lamb and they will start to put the food away 15 minutes before 2:30.  You usually get what you pay for, but you can a get much better and freshly prepared lunch at Little Delhi for much less.
author: Amy D.

description: I'm no Indian food critic but this place was amazing. Came by recommendation from a friend and will definitely be back. Got a stewed lamb dish with jasmine rice and some garlic naan. Washed it down with 2 different IPAs. The vibe is really cool too. Low lighting, warm decor, downtempo tunes. Fantastic.
author: Dustin F.

description: Ambience is good. Food was slightly better than standard Indian.
author: Sujith K.

description:
3.5 stars.

Was in the area for Ad:Tech and not in the mood for a sandwich so Amber India it was. Their lunch buffet is only $16.95 and although there wasn't much variety, what they had was pretty good. 

The buffet consisted of vegetable pakora (Cold, soggy batter), various fried vegetables (All the batter was cold and soggy), various chutneys/raitas/pickled vegetables (I'd pass on all except the mint raita. That was really good.), butter chicken (VERY good. This is a must have), tandoori chicken (Great char on the outside, tender and moist meat.), fried white fish (Not sure what type of fish it was but it was pretty good. Crispy on the outside, sweet and flaky on the inside.), some sort of vegetable/chicken curry (Meh.) and also quite a few vegetarian dishes (paneer, lentils, etc.) all of which were typical Indian buffet food. The dessert table had a rice/tapioca/condensed milk sort of dessert which was weird. Very creamy, thick and sweet. I'm not sure if I liked it or hated it. Another dessert was some sort of cheese ball in saffron scented cream. It had a weird soggy texture I didn't like. They also had fruit salad which was whatevers. 

Side note: Make sure to get their butter chicken. That's the best thing there. Mmm slightly tangy, creamy and spicy with super tender chicken. This was fucking delicious! Also, the waiters bring you fresh naan, hot from the oven to your table. Dip that shit in the butter chicken and enjoy!
author: Beverly T.

description: Great Indian food with the perfect blend of spice. Buffet is a bit pricey but well worth it.
author: dar a.

description: It  is absolutely RIDICULOUS to pay this kind of money for food that is neither humanly raised,local or sustainable. Gross. Rip Off. You are paying a lot of money to eat cheap ingredients disguised as quality and animals that have been in cages their entire lives unable to even stand up. If you want GREAT organic Indian check out Lotus cafe in Fairfax of you are in the area. It's amazing people will spend this kind of money at places like this.
author: Kate H.

description: Really good food and service. Not your typical Indian Food on the menu. It is more like a Indian fusion, but it is really tasty. I liked the Tandoori chicken and the butter chicken which is like chicken tikka mashala
author: Afshin M.

description: I was in town for a few days & ate here on my first day since it was just around the corner from my hotel. At first glance, the selection for the buffet seemed limited but boy was I wrong. I barely made it to my second plate. The food seemed very fresh which was especially nice for the salad because who likes dull looking greens? The salad bar had three different variations of salads plus other veggies on the side you could add on. The food was all warm, savory, deliciously textured, and well seasoned.
