I can't remember the names of everything I had, but I know I was pleasantly surprised. Lots of veggie friendly options! I didn't have anything I didn't like. Just thinking about the food makes me hungry. Their naan didn't come warm, but was good nonetheless. I'm vegetarian so I was happy to see that my friends were able to enjoy some non-veggie options. They raved about the chicken & lamb and stuffed themselves as much as I did. Service was good despite the large amount of people there for lunch. The mango lassi was SO GOOD. Coming from SoCal, this has been the best looking Indian restaurant I've visited. The place was clean and neatly kept which provided my eating experience with good ambiance. I can't wait to be back!
author: Ana V.

description: I've had a lot of Indian food - including in India - and this place was top-notch. Everything I tried - Dal, pepper crab, chaats, masala sauce - everything was the best I've had in the city. It's a little on the pricey side, but it's worth it. I also like that the menu included both South Indian and North Indian cuisines.
author: Karin Z.

description: The curry equivalent of baby food - tasteless, characterless and bland (rather like the airport lounge decor). If you have no sense of what good Indian food tastes like this the place for you! (desrves a star for the excellent service however, friendly, quick and knowledgable).
author: Sam E.

description:
Most Indian restaurants that I've been too are usually rather dirty and adorned with hilariously fresh-off-the-boat decorations, but this is definitely the nicest Indian restaurant I have ever seen. The decor is very clean, modern, and sleek. The location right off of the Yerba Buena gardens is also excellent and the service is top notch.

For most Indian (or Chinese, Mexican, people of color, etc) restaurants, there is usually a trade off between the quality of the decor, cleanliness, or service, and the quality of the food. I do not believe that is the case here. Their spices are certainly not watered down and represent a force to be feared. The lamb vindaloo was fierce, but delicious.

Overall, I'm sure this restaurant will please any enthusiast of Indian cuisine, while still being nice enough to be a place where you can impress a date.
author: Tian X.

description:
The food is distinct, and clean, and we love the Butter Chicken and the Tikka Masala.  Plus, the Eggplant is yum.  Service was very courteous, but a little muddled, with people forgetting to bring plates when appetizer came and stuff like that. 

All in all, we would definitely go again.
author: Mark S.

description: All Indian food to me is compared to the Bombay Palace in Goteborg, Sweden. In that scale this is a solid "B". All of the ingredients were very fresh and not overcooked. My only critique is that the spices were a bit out of balance. The heat overpowered the sweet and the creamy. But, overall, very good and worth the $20 buffet price.
author: Food S.

description:
Five Stars:  Rogan Josh is always my yardstick for Indian food; Amber's is outstanding with succulent lamb, balanced spices that are moderately hot and lots of gravy for the naan bread.  Bhindi are perfectly cooked, naans are fresh and crispy coated with soft centers, the butter chicken is always delicious (if your cardiologist is okay with your cholesterol levels).  

Four stars: Some argue the prices are high - I think they are very fair for the quality of the food, service and ambience.  Keep in mind that this is a restaurant for a lovely evening out, rather than a 'hole in the wall'.

One star: Why are the dining chairs so darn heavy?  

SUMMARY: Amber serves my favorite Indian food in the Bay Area in an inviting dining room.  If you are new to Indian food, come for the lunch buffet; for less than $20 you can try the signature dishes (rogan josh and butter chicken) and several vegetable and rice dishes.  Locations in Mountain View and San Jose are just as well-executed.
author: Nerdy G.

description:
This food was special. The quality and presentation were noteworthy. But it was the flavor and great service that made the meal and experience memorable. I highly recommend this restaurant when visiting beautiful San Francisco.

We stopped in the nearby Press Club for some wine tasting. We purchased a bottle of Riesling from Chateau Montelena to have with our dinner and Amber waved the corkage fee due a friendly agreement that they share.
author: Doris L.

description: I'm a big fan of Amber India for $16.95 their lunch buffet including rice/naan is a good deal.   My favorite entrees are their butter chicken and chicken tikki masala.  Amber India is great at replenishing the buffet and its best to get there by 11:30am with or without a reservation.
author: Rich W.

description: Went for lunch and had the buffet.  Excellent for someone like me who is wanting to try more Indian fare but doesn't really know how to get started...  I was able to try a bite or 2 of a buncha different stuff without the commitment.  Found a few new favorites so I'd say it was a success.  I am not usually a buffet person AT ALL but this one was solid. Super convenient to the convention center too which is where I was working.  I would say you need to be there before Noon  for lunch if you wanna get in though - it did get crowded after that.
author: Lora L.

description:
Okay food, way overpriced for the taste and quantity, below par service, you basically pay for the ambience and location, and unfortunately, the lack of *good* Indian restaurants in the city.

We tried the Tawa Paneer Manchurian, Badam Bhara Baingaan, Saag Teen Mushroom, Daal Amber, and the Assorted Bread basket. The Saag and Daal were good, but nothing out of the ordinary....both tasted like standard items on most Indian restaurant menus. They had replaced the Paneer in the ubiquitous Saag Paneer with Mushrooms. The stuffed peas paratha was very dry. The tawa mushrooms were ok.

The food was served so fast, that it almost felt like it had just been warmed up in the microwave.  Even the naans weren't hot and didn't seem just-made, like you'd expect in most Indian restaurants. Besides, they brought out the appetizer and main course together....one would expect that such a restaurant has it's act together re: the sequence of appetizers & entrees. 

Granted the restaurant was busy, but it was not full, and we were seated past peak dinner time...so it's not even like they had a long line of folks waiting and needed to turn tables quickly.  Besides, they added 18% gratuity by default to a table of 5...isn't the minumum usually 6 people?

The cocktails sound better than they taste....plus, the server forgot one of the four drinks ordered at our table.

The saving grace of the meal was the Coffee Kulfi...tastes just like frozen creamy cold coffee.
author: Shweta V.

description:
Ambience- 5/5
Food- 4/5
Service- 1/5

Delicious food, beautiful ambience, a huge restaurant by downtown SF standards, but the service sucks!
Right from a snob of a waitress to a snail-paced service, this place was a rip-off. The food makes up to an extent for the slow service, but the attitude of people certainly does not.
author: A D.

description:
happy hour 4 stars
this place is a lot better for hh. they have a separate bar section and their hh ends at 7pm. they have food and drink options for cheap! totally recommend

lunch 3 stars
expensive indian food? really?? you're just paying for ambiance. the food isn't even as good as the cheap places, which was a dissapointment. but its a nice place to take people for work..
author: Jen S.

description: great indian.  best in sf, imho.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: ...1st time at amber...i enjoyed myself and the food...a glitch in the service in the  beginning was made up for...i'd go back...it is "spendy"...the flash fried spinach with yogurt is excellent...
author: Bob L.

description: Despite having traveled extensively through India and eaten in Indian restaurants around the world, I've never had Indian food that compares to Amber of India's. They elevate the genre to high art, and serve what feels like Indian Nouveau done perfectly. Amber India gets five stars plus a hearty WOW! from me. [And naturally, there are lots of options for vegetarians.]
author: Shalom O.

description:
Where to start:

 - All of our food came out within 5 minutes of our order (no exaggeration).  Food  is obviously not prepared freshly & the restaurant obviously makes no attempt to disguise the fact. Laughable.

 - Chicken curry was indedible.   At $20 a plate, this place is on the pricey-side - yet the quality of the chicken was not far removed from a Taco Bell.  Another cost cutting measure, I assume.

 - Zero flavor.  No heat.  lack of salt in any of the dishes.   Pepper Crab ached for lime, salt and cilantro.  

My first & only visit.  Overpriced.  2nd tier Indian.  Don't be fooled by the fancy location or ambience.
author: Vijay R.

description: food sucked. ambiance was ok.
author: reza n.

description: This is definitely one of the best Indian food restaurants I've been to. Firstly - it is upscale and chic...so many Indian places are not, but that doesn't mean their food isn't good. I was expecting the food to be pretty regular from this place, thinking that the decor and atmosphere would be the reason it was packed. Not the case! The food was fresh, tasty and original. All the regular faves mixed with some very eclectic creative dishes I've never had. So many choices! I wish I had come with a large group so we could try several plates. If I lived in SF I'd be going to this place once a week. Highly recommended! I cannot say enough about the breads too - all perfect! Eat your way happy at this spot.
author: Jeanette R.

description: Amber India is quality Indian food for a quality price.  The service, environment, and food is impeccable.  I came here with two co-workers, and we did "family-style" eating, where we all order entrees for the table.  I personally recommend the cauliflower appetizer that is cooked in a coconut sauce, and the tandoori sea bass.
author: Alexander S.

description: I have been to this place several times, mostly as a group with co-workers. The quality of food is amazing, restaurant ambience is good and the staff is very courteous and helpful. I love the samosas here and their eggplant dish. Do make sure that you have a reservation on weekends. We have been asked to wait few times cause we didn't have prior reservation.
author: Vishal S.

description:
All STYLE, no SUBSTANCE.  I don't recommend it at all.

My friend and I went in for drinks on a Friday night around 630pm.  Beautiful atmosphere with upbeat music in the background.  And that's where the love ends.

We were at the bar.  And, while the folks at the bar were friendly, we had to constantly get their attention to receive attention to order and refresh our drinks.  On the bartenders' recommendation, I had a femme fatale - the flavor was dull and couldn't really taste the many ingredients with any distinction.  The bartender asked me what I thought and when I said, "uh...it was okay"  He just looked at me puppy like as if to say sorry.  

We were hungry, and decided to have a few nibbles.  I attempted to order samosas - turns out they were out.  It would have been helpful to know that when I received the menu.   I asked for a recommendation.  "The cauliflower!" says the bartender.  We order it.  It bites - sauce is drowning the veg and is too creamy.  He asks us about it, and we say, "M'eh"  He smiles and goes back to what he's doing.  

We're still hungry so, against my better judgement, I inquire with another bartender - what else do you have that is good?  We didn't like the cauliflower.  "The naan w/tandoori chicken on top."  I'm thinking that would be fine, an Indian restaurant can't screw up tandoori chicken, right?!

Well, they did.  Again, too much sauce - oh! And since when does tandoori chicken have sauce?!  Looks like chicken stew on pan fried bread dough.  Naan oily and more fried than baked.  Ugh!  Again, we were asked our thoughts and shook our heads.

We eat a few bites (hungry!) and then get the check with most of the food on the plate.  I was disappointed that they charged us for every last thing.  At most fine places, I've been offered a replacement, or to have the food taken off.  I said as much and the bartender said "I can get my manager."   Well, I'm not in the mood to go through their escalation process.  Instead, I let them have my money but they've lost a customer.
author: K C.

description:
Lunch buffet. Really expensive and really worth it (particularly when it's expensed :D ). Quality curried greens, north Indian style paneer, channa, and dal, pan fried vegetable sides, and outstanding dessert selection including gulab jamun and a delicious creamy tapioca and vermicelli dish.

Courteous and attentive wait staff. Ultra modern temple of fine cuisine. A great place to take contemplative solace from a difficult work day.

For SOMA FM listeners, "Suburbs of Goa" is the precise aesthetic of Amber. For non SOMA FM listeners, this is a high compliment.
author: Alex B.

description: One of the better Indian restaurants we've been to and we've been to quite a few. The highlight had to be the meat preparation. The chicken was perfectly cooked and the lamb as well. The flavors were delightful. The service was smart and attentive from the hostess to help on the floor. If you like Indian cuisine you won't be disappointed. And the pricing was fair. It's closing in on five stars with its new menu additions.
author: Lawrence V.

description: Me and some girlfriends came here this weekend and I was pretty good.  Two had the butter chicken...one had the lamb and i had the duck appetizer.  All were very good no complaints here.  The decor is magnificent!
author: Destinee W.

description:
I arrived for happy hour by myself and sat at the bar.  The bartender was EXTREMELY BUSY as it seemed everybody in the place was ordering cocktails (not just wine and beer) and taking full advantage of the decent happy hour prices.  I was really happy that I was still taken care of even under the very busy circumstances.  I would recommend that this place employ 2 bartenders for the happy hour rush.  

I had some really great appetizers and especially liked the chickpea appetizer.  It's a fun and friendly atmosphere and I would definitely return again for dinner or lunch or happy hour because I found the food quality to be at a very high standard.
author: David H.

description: My husband and I had a wonderful time here. We had a reservation, arrived on time, and initially were seated very close to a man dining alone.  The three of us were sharing a bench seat and our tables were a only a couple of inches apart. It was so close that it was weird so we asked our hostess to be moved.  She obliged. There were plenty of other tables available so I'm not sure why they did that. We each ordered cocktails.  They were ok but not fantastic. Our food was very, very good, but not the best Indian I've had. (We ordered butter chicken and chicken saag.) for dessert we had the molten chocolate cake which was excellent.  This is a solid place to go if you're looking for good Indian food.  I'll add that the decor and lighting  was gorgeous.  The cost including drinks, before tip, was in the $150's. The real treat of the evening was our server, Belinda, who couldn't have been more professional, friendly,and helpful.  This restaurant deserves an extra star for her.
author: Teresa K.

description:
Amber India (SF) is a fantastic, modern restaurant to enjoy fine Indian cuisine. It's located in the new Yerba Buena Center (great location) and has a trendy bar / lounge (upstairs) along with the main portion of the restaurant (downstairs). The ambiance was fantastic when I visited - lively, full of energy, with very friendly and responsive staff. The restaurant is relatively upscale with prices to match, but this is definitely justified by the great food quality and setting.

During my most recent visit, I ordered the Palak Chaat (delicious - comes with tamarind & yogurt chutney), vegetable samosa, and the kadhai paneer (cottage cheese with spices, peppers, tomatoes, and onions ... I believe it was stir fried). Both dishes were excellent - authentic and with very rich flavors - and went well with the naan and rice.

I was a little disappointed that the menu did not correlate with the menus at sister Amber India restaurants in the South Bay (e.g., they do not offer Palak Paneer on menu - though perhaps they'd take off menu requests as well). Regardless, the menu at Amber India SF definitely holds its own. If you are looking for great Indian cuisine in SOMA, definitely put Amber India SF on your short list of places to visit!
author: Rishi N.

description:
We live a few blocks down and used to go there often for Sunday Brunch. Recently we stopped going because of poor customer service and some other reasons stated below.

The quality of food and the options of buffet have deteriorated in the last 6 months. 

To add to that, we had a terrible experience with their Indian Manager who claims to have joined 6 months ago and here is the experience.

We were hosting a lunch for party of 10 and we had a small baby who was asleep and we wanted to bring the baby in. When we go to the front, the hostess said we will have to pickup the stroller and bring it down the stairs. We were not happy about it but we said OK we will do that. Then she said, wait a minute we have an exit to the back side of the restaurant and you can bring the stroller from there so that you do not have to pick it up. We said Oh Great! That works.

Guess, what they blocked off the fire exit by placing a table for 4 and there were guests seated on that table. They made them get up to get our stroller in. While the guests moved and we were trying to come in the Manager comes running says - NO you cannot do that you cannot come in from here. You have to come from the front. I said what sense does it make now that your guests are up you moved your table and chairs out, let us in. After a lot of argument he lets us in.

On our way back we asked him, so do you have a handicap access which we can use to take the stroller out to the street and he shows us an elevator which was also blocked by a guest table and when the elevator opens up, guess what! It was used as a storage room. It was full of chairs and other crap. He had to move all those things out for us to use it. It is absolutely ridiculous! 

There were two problems with this:

1. THEY ARE NOT SUPPOSED TO PUT A TABLE at THE FIRE EXIT and block it.
2. THEY ARE NOT SUPPOSED To use elevator as storage!!!

After all this, if I were the manager of the restaurant, I will apologize to my guests for any inconvenience and ask them how the lunch was but obviously he did not do any of that and he had this attitude and was avoiding us.

I went upto this arrogant manager and said I would like to talk to your boss and I hear from him that his boss is out of town and will contact me. I NEVER heard from his BOSS!

I think this restaurant is sub standards and will never go there.
author: P V.

description: I went there for the Sunday buffet brunch. While they had a large selection, most of the food was just "OK"; the tandoori chicken was a bit dry; I only found two of the items particularly flavorful (the little deep-fried mushrooms and the vegetable dish with the string beans and corn).
author: Paul L.

description:
Last week, my boyfriend and I were looking for something warm, hearty, and spicy to escape from the rain. Amber India's combination of sophisticated interior, good service, and satisfying dishes made for the perfect evening out.

Amber has a wide selection of dishes prepared from the Tandoor (clay oven), but I instead opted for the Shalgam Nalli - lamb shank with baby turnips, caramelized onions and a yogurt sauce. The shank is braised for 6 hours and is incredibly tender - falling right off the bone. Our server warned us of the spiciness of the dish which was perfect, if just bordering on bearable. The Kozhi Melagu offers just as much flavor but with less spice - a black pepper chicken in a curry leaf, fennel, and onion sauce. A side of naan bread, basmati rice, and some cold cucumber yogurt to contrast the intense flavors were the perfect complements to our entrees.

They have a good wine list and inventive cocktails. For dessert, we had a mix of cognac and grand marnier served warm to go with our Gulab Jamun - warm cardamom milk dumplings in a subtly sweet sugar rose syrup. 

Amber India offers upscale Indian cuisine with complex flavors, refined interiors and service to match.
author: Britt M.

description:
i've been hesitant to try the place because most higher-end indian places have nice decor but bad ingredients BUT this place rocks! The ingredients were notably better: butter chicken, masala tea, rice with saffron, and the palak paneer. 
Each of those dishes were amazing to the last bite, each made with ingredients and spices I could taste. Amber also does not bring down the spice much and I saw people of Indian/Pakistani descent (ie non-white people) there which is a plus. The best chees ein Palak paneer I've ever seen, and I've have a lot of that! It was like the difference between artisan cheese and pre-packaged cheese.
5 stars because I gladly stand corrected -- it's a great find on Market next to the Peet's and near Westfield mall. Ambiance was also really nice, with wooden floors and nice art. Service was ideal with friendly staff anticipating our need for rice or water. 
This is higher end than Mehfil but not super high end...the meal for two still came out to about 25 each, not bad considering the quality of ingredients.
author: Emm C.

description: I don't usually eat Indian food not because I don't like eating Indian food but it's because there are more other selection of food everywhere. Amber is a classy restaurant and very clean too. Service is great as expected and the food is good too. The samosa is not burnt, the naan bread is fluffy and fresh, and I just loved everything I ordered from there. The bar is upstairs and you can order food there too. Most importantly the bathroom is clean and elegant. It's right next to the press club and tropisueno so if your ever in the area and craving Indian cuisine try amber out.
author: Lisa Z.

description: One of the best Indian restaurants in the bay area!  Extra star for butter chicken!
author: Mansi W.

description: Food was rather tasty. Had the butter chicken and snow peas. Service was pretty horrible. Made a 9pm reservation. Didn't get seated until 9:40. Didn't have a waitress until 10. Both hostess and waitress seemed very stuffy and pretentious. Guess that's what they are going for. Can get better food and a lot less money and attitude at naan and curry (and less quality food). Would recommend against.
author: Paul H.

description:
Great food, great ambiance, great location!

I came here with my boyfriend before going to see a show in the city and it was great!! DEFINITELY try the spinach chaat... im not sure exactly what it's called but it's on the appetizer list. SO GOOD. The entrees were good as well, I got the paneer tikka which lived up to my expectations.

If you want to get classy indian food, Amber is definitely the place for you! :
author: Ankita I.

description: As tourists, my boyfriend and I must have spent over an hour googling Indian restaurants in San Francisco, trying to find somewhere nice to go on our last night in town. Dosa was already way-booked, so we had to find something last minute. Everything we were pulling up seemed to be in bad neighborhoods, had no atmosphere, or were closed. We finally stumbled upon Amber which was a god-send...exactly what i wanted. Upscale atmosphere, warm, inviting, and great food. I could not have been happier with our choice. Food and service was excellent, and I would definitely return again!
author: Aimee R.

description:
I'd been wanting to try Amber India for a while since it's on my way home from work.  

The food is good, but the portions are very, very small.  For two people, we had the full Dine About Town menu (app, entree, dessert) plus another entree and order of rice/naan.  We didn't leave hungry, but not exactly satisfied either.  Our bill without any drinks was $72.

Don't think we'll return unless it's for the buffet.
author: Ava C.

description: Came here for a birthday celebration followed by the theater.  Wonderful!  Strong cocktails, with a good value for happy hour.  Excellent food with some unusual flavors.  This is an upscale restaurant right off of Market street, so it's perfect for dinner and shopping or checking out the ambiance of Union Square.
author: Sean T.

description:
- Aloo Peas Samosa: Kind of greasy & not very crispy.
- Badam Bhara Baingan: Large slices of tender eggplant w/ a very spicy sauce on top. May order it again, would ask for less spicy.
- Lasooni Saag Panee: Spinach & cheese.  Not  very interesting.
- Asparagus & Cauliflower Balchao: So so dish; again very rich.
- Dal Amber: Very flavorful dish, full of spices. Unfortunately it had too much cream.
- Kashmiri Roganjosh: Lamb stew, our favorite!  So delicious & the meat was not fatty.
- Butter chicken: No kidding about the rich tomato sauce, it was mostly cream. 3,000 cal?
- Sea Bass Kokum Curry: The fish was okay but again...way too rich.

The service was fine, once we got someone to wait on us.  We'd go back again & get the lamb & maybe try out a Tandoor dish. The vegetarian dishes here are definitely not that healthy.
author: TopCat W.

description:
I am very picky when it comes to Indian dining... I don't think that anyone can do it quite like my mama.

Needless to say, the score is Amber 1, Mom 0.  (Unless my mom can replicate the delicious Shalgam Nalli). (SORRY mom!)

Everything from the ambiance right down to the service (shout-out to my homeboy Krishna) is perfect.  

FOOD
Palak chaat (NOT at all traditional Indian food, but absolutely delicious), Pesto & Goat Cheese Tiki, and the samosas :).
Now for dinner - Shalgam Nalli.  Badam Bhara Baaingan (basically squishy eggplant drenched in curry... it's baaingan!... pun intended).  The rice/naan accompaniments are all tasty (it's pretty hard to mess up rice/naan, though).
Dessert - The gulab jamun isn't WONDERFUL, but it's always fun to explain to the non-Indians why they should order the "brown balls".  I usually finish the heavy meal with masala chai, because I'm too full to eat anything solid.

If you can't make it for dinner, go for their lunch buffet... it's less than $20 per person and you get a WIDE array of selections (appetizers, entrees, desserts).

Great food, great ambiance, just don't kiss your date right after dinner (curry breath.  not so hot).
author: Natasha S.

description:
Amazingly delicious and the decor was extravagant.

My boyfriend and I had dinner here and loved the atmosphere and the food!  It was near our hotel and right in the heart of SOMA.  Loved it, delicious, delicious delicous!
author: Chaka H.

description:
This place is pricey, but unlike some other pricey restaurants, the incredibly flavorful cuisine justifies their prices. Luckily I had a gift certificate. With tip for two people, it came to $125 for 3 drinks, samosas, tandoori shrimp, butter chicken, rice & two orders of naan (one would have been enough or we could has skipped the rice). We also got a complementary excellent tasting Mango Creme Brulee, for a minor order issue. All the food tasted excellent!  

At first I was pissed that that advertised happy hour turned out to be for the bar only. I was really tempted to just go get drinks at the bar and bring them over to our table, but I didn't feel like getting into an argument with our waiter. 

Shrimp and Lobster might not be traditional Indian cuisine, but there are plenty of decent traditional Indian restaurants in SF if that's what you're looking for. However, If you want to try incredible flavors, and if you're open minded enough to try non-traditional cuisine, then you should really enjoy this place. I would have given them 4 stars because of their prices, but if you have the money, it's worth the price, so I have to give it 5 stars.
author: Ron B.

description: The food here seems to be of very high quality and there are lots of very good options.  Portions are served correctly and it is nice to be able to eat family style with others at your table (and you can try some different foods.)  Wait times can be long so prepare with a reservation around dinner time.   The lunch buffet has nice variety, but the wait to get through it can be aggravating for large groups.  I was also disappointed that dishes don't seem to be very spicy.  Butter chicken was a disappointment, but the kababs were really good.  With all of that aside, the biggest complaint for me is the cost vs. other Indian restaurants in the city.  If you want style this is the place to go, if you want value go elsewhere.
author: Wes T.

description:
No points for you!  My review is mainly based on a bad experience I had with their reservation system, opentable.com.  If you are logged in directly at opentable.com, open a tab to go the restaurant's website, and then click on the opentable reservation link,  you will get 0 (zero) opentable dining rewards.    You can only earn dining rewards if the reservation is made directly through opentable and not through the restaurant's link to opentable.  

I think it is very deceptive.   Opentable.com is synonymous with earning dining rewards.  The restaurant website should have a large font note that if you reserve directly through their opentable link you will get 0 points.  Or, opentable should flash a big message on the screen warning that we will receive 0 points. 

The food was okay, but too expensive for what it was.  There are many alternatives where you pay less and can have the same kind of tasting food.  After multiple attempts to resolve this issue with opentable, I will never go back.  Choose your vendors carefully.
author: Chris W.

description:
Pros:  clean
            Food is pretty good
            Good service

Cons:  on a pricey side
author: Bayarea K.

description:
i thought this would be one of those trendy 'fusion' indian places, but i was pleasantly surprised at a lot of the familiar  typical indian food dishes on the menu. i shared an appetizer, entree and basket of naan with my friend and it was more than enough. i'd recommend the portobello, pea and goat cheese appetizer - it's basically like a falafel but...not chick peas. really delicious and satisfying and comes with a mildly spicy sauce. for the entree we went with everyone else's suggestions and got the butter chicken, which is basically chicken tikka masala. the chicken was VERY tender and the flavor was good, although it was lacking a bit in the spices department. and the most important part of the meal: naan - it was fresh out of the oven, soft, and flavorful. so happy to finally find a place around me that has better than average naan. 

the service here is fantastic - everyone is warm, friendly and polite. along with the decor and ambient lighting, it definitely gives the place a more upscale feel
author: Stephanie C.

description:
pretty good place. generally can get pretty crowded. it's a little pricey, but it's what you get for the location and atmosphere. 

definitely try all of the Nan and their cocktails are pretty good. 
business trips or a casual place to stop by to grab a bite is recommended. 

Don't worry, the food isn't too heavy if you plan on getting a little trashed that night.
author: Johnny N.

description: Nothing quite so irritating as being overcharged.  Just checked my credit card statement, and it appears that the server gave himself a 50% tip instead of the 20% I signed.  Terrible.
author: Kayla A.

description:
This review is for the lunch buffet.

As far as lunch buffets go, this may be the best one I've ever been to.  A very fresh apple/raseberry/goat cheese salad at an Indian buffet?  Yup.  There were plenty of veggie choices and one chicken, fish, and lamb dish respectively.  

The food was fantastic and adequately spicy without being too hot (a fine line at any buffet).  

Decor is nice and the place is very clean.  Staff is quick and amiable too.  

All in all, outstanding.
author: I I.

description:
BUTTERED CHICKEN !!

My fiancee came here a month ago and she was raving about the buttered chicken.   We finally came here together over the weekend.  I had the lamb chops which were good but not great... unlike the buttered chicken!  

The tenderness of the chicken and the sauce were very very good!  Highly recommended!  Plus it's a great looking place, great looking bar
author: George B.

description: I took my mom here for a girls' night out when she was visiting. I was really, really impressed to get a table right away on a Friday night, but we got there just before the rush started (around 6:00 pm). Food was absolutely awesome, Mom and I split the tandoori sampler plate and some starters recommended by the server. Will come back again!
author: Emily F.

description: I've had a couple of dinners here.  They're located near the Four Seasons.  Great service.  Upscale.  Nice ambiance.  Cool lounge. They have some of the best Indian food I've ever tasted - including places I've eaten at in India, but it's more Indian-fusion than traditional.  Their Butter Chicken is like a love poem to Tikka Masala.  So good. Get the Pappad, too.  It's a paper-thin cracker on, well... crack.  You'll need to go to rehab.  The SF Chronicle voted them one of the Top 100 Bay Area restaurants.
author: Tom B.

description: This place is amazing. By far one of my favorite Indian restaurants. Service is great and plenty of vegetarian options. My favorite is saag paneer, raita and the naan bread. Very fresh and delicious! Ambiance is relaxing and welcoming
author: Jess H.

description: I've been a regular here for quite some time. My favorites are the butter chicken, dal makhani, lamb curry, and saag paneer.
author: Romita J.

description: Had dinner with our friend Lori here Saturday night.  Friendly service, good drinks and the food was great but not cheap.  The three of us did not gorge ourselves and only had beer to drink (two each) and we dropped $157, tax & tip included.
author: Kevin M.

description: We came here for lunch on New Year's Day and loved the food and service. The food was amazing, service was very attentive and the ambience was great. Next time we want Indian food in San Francisco, this is our place! Highly recommend!
author: Erika s.

description: One of my favorite Indian places in SF. Very high end interior, and great food at decent prices. I actually prefer to eat in the bar/lounge area - they have a really good and reasonable tapas menu and it's a bit more relaxed.
author: Brian S.

description: Lovely Sunday buffet.  Good selection for vegetarians!
author: Shizzle N.

description: Was in town last week for large fruit conference. They seated me on time and the atmosphere was great. This is, of course, not your typical cheap Indian fare, which is also very good but in a different way. This was creative, yet not silly or fusion-y, Indian food. It was well-executed, flavored well, and very comforting. The chili-cheese naan was soft and just what I needed after walking around all afternoon in the chilly city shade ... The vegetable and paneer curry was most excellent. The whole meal really hit the spot, and I left quite happy. I'll definitely visit again.
author: Baron C.

description: I went to Amber this past weekend, party of 4. The service and atmosphere was great.  The food on the other hand was overpriced.  Tried the tandoori sampler, 2 shrimps, 2 lamb kebab, & 2 chicken kebab, we halved the food, shrimp and chicken were bland. Lamb was ok. Dinner, butter chicken was tastey but not worth $20 for a few pieces of chicken. There was another chicken dish ordered, it was just ok. The shrimp dish was good but like I said before this Indian restaurant is not worth the price. We also ordered naan and rice, rice should come with the dishes.  Total $120.
author: Rina V.

description: Love Indian food but never really found a great restaurant that could capture the full rich taste of the culture. The food was amazing and tasted fresh. The service was also amazing. The waitress paid attention to us-and all her tables-even though every seat in the restaurant was taken. The employees there are really nice and this made me feel at home. The menu is a bit pricey (total for 3 people came to about $80), but it was worth it and would definitely come back!
author: Julia E.

description:
Beautiful decor and dark, elegant atmosphere. There aren't too many upscale Indian places that actually taste good, but Amber pulled it off. They have a small but very trendy bar area, with some good drinks on the menu. 

- Tandoori Chicken: white meat was a little dry, but good, lots of grilled onions
- Kashmiri Roganjosh: good flavor, big chunks of lamb
- Pappad: thin, crispy, light, use the sauces
- Rainforest Cocktail: refreshingly delicious! very fruity

Service was excellent. Food timing was perfect. A lot of business people there and I guess with the Four Seasons right next door, they're bound to attract that type of clientele. Their happy hour menu looks cool with $5 wines and appetizers. Will check it out next time.
author: Linda C.

description:
Awesome restaurant for north Indian food. Buffet is really great, a la carte is very pricey.  

We have tried both weekend and weekday buffet;  weekend buffet is better and has more varitey than weekday buffet.  

Food tastes excellent.  The paneer that they serve is the best I've eaten.  All their dishes except the desserts taste wonderful.  The desserts are horrible.  Most of them are stale/old and absolutely no variety. It is the same moong dal halwa or gulab jamun.  If the desserts were good, I would have given 5 stars.
author: Viji K.

description:
Delicious! 

Samosas were excellent, if a little dainty. They went well with my just sweet enough Bulleit Manhattan.

We had excellent wine by the glass to go with our main courses. The butter chicken is so rich you'll be glad you ordered both rice and naan; but it's not so over the top that you can't enjoy the luscious bites of meat. The garlic naan was good but make sure your date eats it too - then neither one of you will mind the other's new garlicy aroma. A serving of Dal made it a nice medium-light dinner. We didn't try the desserts yet.

Great place to take someone from out of town, too - nice location near the movie theaters.
author: Mark A.

description:
Pricy but phenomenal. (450$ for 4 people wine included) 

Had heard great things about this place from coworkers.
Indian food is one of my absolute favorite foods, so was excited to go here for the 4 course newyears menu, newyears eve 2011.
I've eaten at many Indian restaurants in the city and this is absolutely one of the best Indian Resturant my opinion. The food was just superb. The naan breads were to die for and the curry do creamy and yummy. The place is on the pricy side of other indian restaurants, it's more towards "fancy Resturant prices" however, I think the interior is more of a casual Resturant so maybe a bit pricy but damn it's good food. We paid 400$ for 4 people for newyears, which isnt too bad, wine included, that being said, if you go to a smaller Indian Resturant like little Delhi on Eddie st. which is my other favorite Indian in San Francisco, it's a fraction of the price and in my opinion just as good food. That being said, I would go back in a heartbeat because the food really is  simply amazing.
This leaves me a little torn whether to give 4 or 5 stars, deciding on 4 only based on the slightly higher prices.. like i said.. the food is absolutely amazing.
it's a must try in my opinion.
author: Adam O.

description:
During the week of 2015 Photonics West at Moscone Center [Feb 11, specifically], having read a number of very positive reviews on Yelp, I joined the crowd for the lunch buffet at Amber India. Price was about 2X more than what I am used to paying for similar spreads, elsewhere, but this was downtown SF, after all. If you are accustomed to paying for meals at Spruce, then this will not seem expensive.
The restaurant itself was clean and bustling with staff, but they still managed NOT to refill my water glass, when it was empty. One very nice distinguishing feature was that they had a bowl of fresh Thai chili peppers on the buffet, which I appreciated. There was a Saag dish with large pieces of potato, which was very disappointing - the greens had little or no spinach and were underspiced and watery. The dish of carrots and peas was good and the cauliflower dish was good. There was also an OK dish with paneer. I can't recall the sauce they used with it. They offered entrees of Tandoori chicken and butter chicken [chicken Makhani], there was a dish with some sort of lamb or goat chunks that did not appeal to me, and a dish with well-prepared fish fillets, not drenched in any sauce, which I enjoyed. There was some sort of dessert that looked like a chocolate brownie [I passed] and an orangish-colored dessert that seemed to be sugar crystals with some sort of sticky vegetable-derived substance on it  [I passed]. Memory may be failing me here, but I think I recall a runny-looking sticky rice, too [I passed].
author: Ray M.

description: Upscale interior near the Four Seasons downtown with good people watching out the window (saw Jimmy Johnson walk by on Super Bowl eve.)  The Indian food is pretty traditional and well prepared.  You are paying for the high-rent and ambiance, however.  A classy place for a night out.
author: John K.

description: I've eaten here a few times over the years.  The food seems consistently high quality and the lunch buffet is quite nice, even if the floor plan of this place does not lend itself well to it. You definintely seem to pay a location tax, but one cant really fault the food too much
author: George D.

description:
Pretty decent, pretty pricey Indian food.

My meal was good - I had the butter chicken, but I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 5 because of the prices. For what you get, I think it is overpriced - my Butter Chicken was good but for that, rice and a glass of wine, once tip was counted it, everything came to $40+. I think you can probably do better in San Francisco and certainly find better value, but if you're in the area, fancy an Indian and a swanky restaurant this place probably fits the bill.
author: Ciera M.

description: I like this place and would go for an up-scale Indian meal. They have some interesting dishes, although typically a bit more traditional than the Amber in Santana Row.
author: Jigar C.

description: Yeah it's kind of fancy, yeah it's kind of whitewashed, but it's still the best Indian food I have ever had. Everything is absolutely amazing. Lasooni Saag Paneer and Kadhai Paneer are a must. Also, the Samosas, best I have ever had. The wine list isn't fantastic, but it beats most other Indian restaurants so I can't really complain.
author: Alfredo A.

description: Great lamb, and great appetizers!  Super fast service too!
author: Rebecca W.

description: LOVED the food at Amber.  It was my first time here after having heard rave reviews from friends & relatives.  Went for the weekend brunch buffet a few weeks ago.  I took off one star because although we had made reservations we still ended up waiting 45 min for a table.  We made it known to the manager and all of a sudden, a table was ready!  :-)  The restaurant was beautiful...very clean & modern. The buffet had some really unique items...a dosa (South Indian crepe) station & a chaat station.  Most of the items were delicious. Fish isn't something you see at an Indian buffet too often so it was a nice surprise & it was delicious!  Looking forward to going again.
author: Priya S.

description:
I went to a charity event at Press Club last night so we walked over to Amber afterwards.  The decor is really nice...the food was ok.  

Beet Salad:  i love beet salad too, but there was a weird taste to the salad
Butter Chicken:   MY FAVORITE dish...YUMMY!  
Lambchop:  it was ok
Garlic Naan: Loved it

Service was ok...food came out quickly, but there was a lag on our doggy bag. haha
author: Sandy L.

description: I have eaten here numerous times and have never been disappointed. But this time around Amber, you didn't quite hit that sweet spot. The menu has changed!! There aren't too many exciting veggie option anymore :( Our appetizer- the goat cheese tikki was not even hot when it made it to our table. And for some reason it tasted very different from what I recollect it to be. There was no pesto anymore! It wasnt bad... Just not amazing. Our entrees the jaipuri bhindi (was spectacular!) and paneer lababdar accompanied with fluffy naans did make up for the lackluster appetizer. We also tried the saffron rice which was light, slightly fragrant and ever so buttery. Service was slow even though the restaurant wasn't crowded.
author: Natasha I.

description:
$7.95 for soup during lunchtime. The soup was about 1 inch deep in a small soup plate. Incredibly overpriced with a flavor that was--meh.
The buffet looked good, but was more food than I wanted at lunch and more money than I wanted to spend. 

Service was also poor. Could have been we were there at the more tail end of lunch. Could be because we were in the back. Regardless, someone had to find a server twice to ask for menus and it took a long time to get water.

Will not be going back. Heard good things about the one in Mountain View, I may try that one.
author: Lisa P.

description: I like this place.  It avoids the peeling paint, grungy bathroom, tenement feel that some of the best City Indian places sport. The bar area was, well, cool. The menu is pretty traditional Indian. It would be interesting to see some experimental specials. Service was great and nice location at Powell BART. I'll be back to Amber.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Really loved the food here! Especially given that I'm not a huge Indian food fanatic and this was actually my first time at an Indian restaurant ever.  So I left very impressed with the food and overall restaurant. Lovely ambiance and great wines (that never hurts).

We ordered the tandoori naan, buttered chicken, tandoori chicken, pan seared scallops w/ mushroom  pulao, dried-shrimp-ancho chili sauce. This was all super yummy but of course we saved room for dessert, which was Kesari Rasmalai (Soft poached homemade cheese dumplings in a saffron flavored light milk syrup). YUM-O and very creative concoction. 

I'd definitely come back and maybe try happy hour if possible. Cute bar area too!
author: Natalie W.

description: A little pricy, but the food was great. Although chicken tikka wasnt on the menu, they offered to make it for us.  Naan was great... All in all great
author: Christopher Z.

description: So good! Went for the Sunday lunch buffet and it was great. Awesome selection, attentive service, and warm, bustling atmosphere. I was glad we made reservations, because it was very busy. I kept going back up so I could try everything. Then went back for seconds (and thirds!). Great way to sample lots of different Indian food if you are (like me) a rookie when it comes to Indian food.
author: A H.

description: Definitely a great place to go on a date or before/after a show. The restaurant is stunning, service is very excellent and the food was delicious... However, portions were SMALL. For a party of 4, we were streeeetttccccctching the dishes and hardly had enough on our plates after spliting the food between us. The bill came to $180 before tip and I left hungry... but that is my only complaint. I think a party of 2 wouldnt encounter such a problem. Solid place!
author: S. M.

description: Food is really good, buffet had a great variety and the Naan was awesome.
author: Carlos S.

description: I would venture to say this is the best Indian food in SF.  Try the okra dish...amazing!
author: Malak M.

description: Have not had Indian food since the last time I was in London.  Outstanding food!!  Great service,  total outstanding experience!  Would highly recommend.
author: Dave N.

description: I am used to eating Indian food from more dive-ish places, so the pricing at Amber is a bit steep from that perspective. However, the food is extremely tasty, the happy hour is really fun, and the buffet is such a tempation! I can only go to the Amber buffet on days where I don't plan on eating any other meals, since it is so hard to hold back eating such delicious food. They are creative with their dishes, it isn't always the same dishes you see in all indian buffets.
author: Kiran S.

description:
Four stars for food. Three stars for service. 
This review is for happy hour/lounge seating only.  
The food was good and good quality. Keep in mind this is upscale Indian and not your homey Indian food. 
Unfortunately service on our visit was sub-par. We could not find our server most of the time. 
That being said we will definitely come back for a full meal in the dining room.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
as this was close to work, went here with a group for bday lunch. The crowd was mostly business professionals perhaps coming in from the nearby offices or the financial district. For that many people in there, it was oddly quiet. our group, usually accustomed to being loud found it a little awkward. Sophisticated interior.
anyhow, the buffet selection and spread offered a great selection of dishes, much more than the Indian buffets i have tried. Food was good, but not worth the $17.
author: heather z.

description:
Great authentic Indian food in a very class restaurant!

Nice décor, great food and efficient (but not pushy) service.

You will pay more here....but you can have a great business dinner or pleasure dinner here.
author: Chris S.

description:
Oh my goodness. A week in SF and I went here twice. Food is very heavy, so plan on sharing  (and going for a long walk afterwards). But they have palak chaat! And their butter chicken! 

Although it's on the pricey side (and given the cheap eats in the Tenderloin - shalimar, pakwan, etc), you could get a much better bang for your buck a few blocks away. But that's not why you're here... enjoy the atmosphere & indulge... it's worth it!
author: Anika K.

description:
Amber has quietly become one of my favorite happy hour spots in town. Yes, happy hour. If their drink specials (which include some $3 beers!) aren't enough of a draw for you, there's also a bar menu with enough appetizers to make a full meal. Amber's food has always been a delight for me, so this just makes it like a low hanging mango to enjoy. Add in Chelsea, who's just a thrill of a bartender, and I sometimes wonder why I'd go anywhere else. 

P.S. I still think they should show Bollywood movies on their flatscreens, though. 

P.P.S. They've reduced their lunch buffet pricing... still not inexpensive but more like $16.95, and that's just too good to pass up.
author: Nish N.

description: I don't have too much to say about this place.  It's too pricey for Indian food, and nothing I had was so good that the price was justified.  It's a very attractive restaurant, to be sure, and I'll probably go back for a happy hour if they have such a thing there, but I can think of a number of better places for an Indian dinner (including Amber's sister restaurant of the same name in Mountain View, which feels less pretentious and food-focused).
author: Zain K.

description:
Amber, why must we have this love-hate relationship? I keep pulling for you and telling everyone to give you a chance but you keep letting me down! (not your butter chicken, that still gets me every time)

My last two trips to Amber have been failures. My first one was a fly-by for take-out. I haven't had a full sit-down meal at this location yet so I figured I would check out their evening dining menu and grab some food on the go. I noticed they didn't have saag paneer. Strange, right? I asked the hostess and she graciously offered to have the cooks make it anyways. One order of saag paneer. One order of butter chicken. Two orders of naan. No rice. Grand total: $42!!! That's even including the 10% discount for carry-out! 

Trip number two was for the lunch buffet. Food was fantastic but god help me, fix your service! We had to ask for refills of naan and water several times throughout the meal. The restaurant was practically empty and all the servers had to do was check on our naan and water levels. For the real kicker, they had the nerve to tack on 15% gratuity. Absolutely uncalled for and plain tacky for a lunch buffet. 

Amber, I think this is the start of a long and painful break-up...
author: Susan L.

description: great ambience and a good food! nice place for lunch with a group
author: Hemant B.

description: Good indian food. My friend and I we went here for buffet and liked the butter chicken.  Like all the other reviewers say, it's a bit pricey.  They also overcharged me by a few dollars. They probably changed the tip amount I put on my bill, and to think I already gave them 18% tip!!  I'm going to my credit card company to dispute this amount.  So definitely not coming back again.
author: P. Andrea B.

description: Heard about this place from a relative.. Food was absolutely delicious! I got the butter chicken which i think is their house special. The chicken was melt in your mouth good, and even though their portions aren't huge, I was full by the end of my meal and so was my husband. We had great customer service, but my only complaint is that it is a little on the pricey side. Other than that I was completely satisfied :)
author: brianna t.

description: I went here on a weekend visit for my sister's birthday and it was great. On Market st. so it was close to our hotel right off Union Square. We had a large group and they were super accommodating. The service was stellar and the ambiance was upscale but comfortable. Everyone at the table ordered a dish then we shared family style and everything I tasted was delicious. Defiantly recommend if you like eating good Indian food in a pretty place.
author: jourdan f.

description:
Dinner party of 10 with a baby.  Service was excellent and the food was even better.  We shared family style, which was so nice to try so many flavors.

Two dishes that really stood out were the Scallops and the Saag Paneer.  The scallops were something new to me, and cooked perfectly.  The Saag Paneer was thee best I've ever had.  Everyone agreed.  The cheese was incredible.  

The ambiance, food and overall experience can justify the pricier Indian Food, $40 per person.
author: HY L.

description:
Okay, fine! The lunch buffet is DELICIOUS!

...and happy hour drink specials are pretty fantastic as well.
author: Stephanie P.

description: The sea bass kebab was amazing! Actually, everything we tried was excellent (spinach balls--can't remember the real name--were also delicious).  I also loved my pink elephant martini. Great service, very attentive staff, and beautifully decorated.
author: maria g.

description:
This is a great restuarant.  Super service and terrific food!  They made a paneer tikka masala (it wasn't on the menu) especially for us. The badam bhara baingan is amazing!! We also had the palak ke kofte.  I've never had anything like that dish before.  That dish is a must order item. The wine recommendations were perfect.  For dessert you must try the bread pudding.  
Don't be scared by the prices. The restaurant is pricey but the food is excellent and the service is top notch!!
author: parag s.

description:
I wanted to take my Aunt and Uncle, who were visiting from Florida and love Indian food, to a nice Indian restaurant.  A friend suggested Amber India.  We had a great experience!  

The atmosphere was such a nice change from the "standard" Indian restaurant.  The food was served quickly and hot, and was served family-style so that we could share.  The Naan was, literally, the BEST I have ever had!  I suggest getting the mixed bread basket.  They had an extensive wine and cocktail list, and the prices were reasonable (though the print on the drink menus could be larger!).

My only 'negatives' are that the vegetarian menu is limited and the rice was plain and not very tasty.  That said, however, I have now found a great Indian restaurant at a great price ($115 for three dinners and drinks).  Can't wait to return!
author: Beth S.

description:
Amber India has done a few things right. The chic atmosphere, tasty menu, cheap (happy hour) drinks and good service makes this place a keeper. 

I love the space-- the reds and yellows all work together so well on the walls, decor and furniture and there's a good amount of seating in the bar area. It's a big enough space that you don't feel crowded on top of other people, but small enough to still be intimate.

The girls and I had so many $5 Amber Indias (a raspberry-infused Gin cocktail) that they ran out of raspberries and had to start making it with strawberries! I heard the strawberry version was just as good.

We ordered a handful of appetizers and all were tasty. The spicy chicken wings were especially yummy. I loved the peppers and onions that were sauteed in.

The waitresses were another plus. They were very attentive and kept our glasses full! I love a place with good service, and although I heard that their dinner menu is a bit more pricey than Happy Hour, I may return to this place- it's pretty fab!
author: Ieesha C.

description:
Meh.

Came here for the $17 lunch buffet. The plates, ambiance, and diners reflected the price, and the food itself seemed to be at least somewhat aware of it, but the selection was way too limited for what we were paying. Of the three meat dishes available, only one of them wasn't fish or chicken, and I've eaten at enough $10 buffets to come to expect a little more selection in the beef-and-lamb area than that. The puffed rice dish was soggy, too.

That said, sogginess aside, the rest of the food available was pretty good. If you're a vegetarian or just aren't big on meat, this would probably be worth the price; if you like beef and lamb and are considering the buffet, I'd suggest looking elsewhere.
author: JR H.

description:
I had the veggie okra dish and it was good. 
I was there for lunch and they had a buffet style which i did not like and front desk was poorly managed, crowded and people were passing in and out due to buffet's location.
Anyways, we were seated and did not want to do the buffet and ordered our frood from the menu. Waitress was rude and the food was just like any other Indian restaurant. Nothing spectacular. So, i do not want to go back. It has a nice bar area, and a nice ambiance but unless i had frireworks for food or service, i dont really care for their looks. 
Meh. There are million other Indian restaurants in the city and the search continues.
author: C A.

description:
This is a great date night spot. I have been here three times (all evenings, so can't speak to the lunch) and each time the service is impeccable, ambiance nice and the food excellent.

I do think it is just a tad overpriced, especially for the wine/drinks, hence four instead of five stars. 

As most everyone else has mentioned, definitely try the butter chicken, it is amazing.
author: Rick H.

description:
My partner and I are big Indian food lovers. 

We've tried many many places in San Francisco. No place makes better, and more authentic dishes than Amber India. 

I'm vegetarian, and they make the best cranberry nut pockets in a delicious sauce, as well as their butternut squash soup with curried pumpkin seeds. 

Their leavened bread with chilis and chese is the best, dipped in the soup is a meal in itself.

They have delicous desserts as well, which isn't always the case at an Indian Restaurant. Definately a bit pricey, but worth the cost.
Very much our favorite San Francisco Indian Eatery.

Enjoy!

Update...so we just got back from over 3 weeks in Northern India. We had delicious, fresh, spiced well amazing food while there. This place is just the ticket in SF for your Indian food delicacies. Very authentic!
author: Johnny G.

description:
My Indian friends tell me that this is one of the best, if not the best, Indian food in San Francisco.  To me, that speaks to it authenticity.  In terms of tastiness, I agree wholeheartedly.

The restaurant is very clean and well decorated.  It's certainly a more pleasant experience than Naan and Curry where you get your own utensils... so it's just different.  Much more of a presentable and refined dining experience.

Parking isn't great in that neighborhood... but what good restaurant in SF has good parking?
author: Jon S.

description:
All I can really say is amazing! Have the Sea bass its a winner. Sweet with coconut and spicy with the curry. Sit at the bar/lounge or in the dining area you can't lose. The sexy lighting in the lounge is awesome! I don't mind the plasma on the wall because they were thinking about some of us guys that need a little bit of sports center in our lives.  Bring a date or a small party of 4 and you'll love it.  Oh and please have the apple feta salad; it will be one of the best salads you will ever have. 
I hear they have a buffet but I'll pass and go for dinner and the lounge. Did I say that the food is good? The lamb and sea bass are winners! And the vegetarian looks pretty good as well. Can't wait to go back.
author: Karim R.

description: Went here because it was close to our hotel. They stay open until 10, which is great in this area. The food was decent Indian fare. There was a wait (even though it was 9pm) so we just ate at the bar. Very strong drinks! My boyfriend had the sea bass fish kabob & felt the portion was very small and it was a little raw in the center- he said the marinade was very good though. I had the paneer l...something. Similar to a shahi paneer, but not as creamy. It was good, not fantastic, but good. We had the cheese stuffed naan...but couldn't find the cheese or peppers mentioned in the description. You ate better off ordering regular naan. Overall- it has a good bar...good for drinks.
author: Mojos G.

description: Last night in San Francisco.... my friend and I went to eat Indian food.  We didn't have reservations and got seated right away.  The service was excellent, the waitress was so attentive and when the food came, she served us.  The food was fabulous!  We ordered the Butter Chicken and then a pepper chicken dish.  Both were curry dishes.  With a side of rice, and of course Naan bread.  The Naan was a cheese and chili bread! Service to Ambience to Food - everything was excellent!  This place is definitely a must do if you're craving Indian in San Francisco!  And it's not too far from Union Square!
author: Lora H.

description:
We had lunch at Amber recently.  We chose the buffet, which we rarely do, and it was a good bargain.  The place is beautiful, two levels, well decorated and clean.
The staff was very cordial and informative.
We selected many dishes from the buffet.  Some of the favorites were: butter chicken, fried cottage cheese, spicy lentils, baked bread, marinated mushrooms, Tandoori chicken.  Everything we tasted had nice flavors, spicy but not mouth burning, and all the food was fresh. The naan was good but we have tasted better.
This place pushes the envelope beyond the traditional Indian dishes.
author: george k.

description: Excellent vegetarian options, great service, delicious food. We made reservations on Open Table for 8pm on a Friday evening and were seated right away. We'd go back.
author: Sarah B.

description: I've always passed by this place before from Metreon and wondered how the food was but finally got a chance to try it since we celebrated a private birthday party on mothers day and turned out to be great! The food was good, great lunch buffet and mimosas.
author: Nikka L.

description:
It's not the same without the butter chicken!!!!!

and the sweetest server Krishna ... he really knows his stuff!
author: A T.

description: Best lunch buffet in the city. Yes, it's also the most expensive. But it's really so much nicer than anything you get at any of the other places, and the ambiance is fantastic. So, save up & eat here once rather than going elsewhere twice...
author: Alyssa P.

description:
A beautiful restaurant and lounge with a great happy hour. I came for a drink and light dinner at the bar on my birthday, after attending the symphony, and it was a perfect denouement to the evening. Service was spot-on and friendly, and the food was delicious. (Thanks, Chelsea!) The batata vada (spiced potato dumplings, $5) I was recommended was zesty and plentiful - 5, two-inch spheres with a pair of sauces to drizzle over them. I splurged on the duck breast kebabs ($11) and never looked back. Actually, my eyes were closed in bliss most of the time, so I didn't look much of anywhere! Each piece of duck was incredibly tender and delicious... and over 1" cubed! A single order includes 3 skewers, each with 3 cubes of duck and interspersed with onion and green and red pepper; a dish of curry dipping sauce came on the side.

Happy hour runs from 4-7, Monday through Friday. Specials are on the website, but include about a dozen appetizers at $5 each, draft beers (2) for $3, house wine for $5, and a trio of cocktail options for $5.
author: Bill B.

description:
You're paying for an upscale dining experience and, to a lesser extent, the food as well. It was solid food, don't get me wrong, but combined with good service and a nice setting made for a nice evening. (The fact that I wasn't picking up the bill didn't hurt either).

The appetizers were delicious, especially the pesto goat-cheese tikki. The entrees were a little average, but I was with my vegetarian parents so I didn't get to try the chicken. The bar looked really cool if I had arrived early.
author: Brian B.

description: Went here for father's day for the lunch buffet. Although the buffet is a little bit pricey, it's actually a little bit good for buffet food. I've had a lot worst in terms of buffet food. That mango drink is pretty good too. I can definitely taste the freshly cut mango in the drink. I have to take a star off for not providing a discount for those who are working for a particular company (which shall remain anonymous) and the wait service. It was alright, but it seems like you have to wave down a waiter before they actually give you water or drinks you ordered.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
If money is not an issue, this place is the tops for Indian in SF. If you are on a budget, opt for the lunch buffet (around $20 per person, and available as eat-in or take-out). 

Skip the fusion fare and stick to the classics: saag paneer, shahi paneer, bhindi and butter chicken. 

And for those of you who don't know your tikka masala from your murgh makhani, lemme break it down: 

Murgh Makhani or Butter Chicken, like the one you get here, is cooked on the bone and simmered in a tomato, butter and cream sauce - hence the meat is oh so tender, and flavorful. 

Chicken Tikka Masala on the other hand is pieces of chicken (usually the breast) skewered and cooked in a tandoor (which tends towards a tough chewy texture as a leftover, and in the hands of the inexperienced) and then cooked in tomato, butter and cream sauce (or more likely, drowned in that nuclear orange super-sweet sauce most Americans identify as an Indian classic). 

I always go for the former, not the latter. So I'll take a $20-80 meal at Amber over a $10 meal at Naan N Curry any day.
author: Dilli S.

description:
MAKE RESERVATIONS!!! The saag was my FAVORITE DISHHHH!!! Love the atmosphere. Very clean and nice. It was a little dark tho, which made me very sleepy I guess also cus I had a long day at work.
But i definitely will go back.
author: Cindy L.

description: Food was excellent. Ordered Badam Bhara Baingan, which is an eggplant dish in a spicy (but not too spicy) tomato based sauce. The slivered almonds and crunchy fennel provided excellent texture and pops of interesting flavor. The Naan is excellent as well. My one gripe is that they were not accommodating to my young children. Every high chair I was provided was broken, and one of them broke entirely in the seat (dangerous!). Service was slow, even after it was clear my children were not happy (I wanted to get the heck out). Needless to say, I bore many dirty looks while I waited for   food and eventually, the check. Excellent food, however. Just not a place to take little ones.
author: J H.

description:
SEA BASS MOILEE...BUTTER CHICKEN...GARLIC NAAN.  

(my shortest review...just order the above and spend your next day drooling and dreaming....mmmmm...perfectly spiced...yum...yum.)
author: Black X.

description: Everything we ordered was excellent. I had the butter chicken and the eggplant dish and both were excellent. My niece had the chick pea masala and was a little disappointed but my mom had the lamb and said it was incredible. The naan bread was not greasy at all. Nothing was too heavy or rich, which is perfect for me. I definitely look forward to trying more dishes here.
author: Maria D.

description: I have been dying to try this place and finally got the chance for my birthday. Great quality food, but not spicy enough. I'm sure you can ask them to doctor the dishes to your liking. I expected a bit more from the ambiance. It was strange to eat samosas while watching someone jog on a treadmill at the gym across the way, but I am told that Amber India is all about the lighting, which wasn't apparent at 6pm in August. I am definitely going back because the food was really good. Next time, I'll go when it's dark out and ask for a little extra spice in the food. One more tip, their version of Butter Chicken is really Chicken Tikka Masala. And it is spectacular!
author: Michelle D.

description:
Went with 3 other Indian friends for a Friday Lunch Buffet ($16.95).  The ambiance is nice.  Good selection of food for an Indian buffet (both veg and non veg items).  We all began our first plates with appetizers...yum.  The chutneys were so good.  However we all felt the actual entree items were bland, definitely not as tasty as the food looked.  

I'm not a fan of Indian desserts so I didn't try any but my friends did and none of them seemed to like any of the items.

On a side note, I didn't like that you had to pay extra for garlic naan.
author: Ami S.

description:
I have to agree with the rest of the Yelpers out there but here are a few unique things we noticed.... 

The food is excellent- we eat Indian food quite often and this will now be at the top of our list 

1.Locals in the know: There were several Indian families and singles eating there- and we were their early (pre-theather dinner). To me if you visit a restaurant in which the cuisine is highly regarded by the people who know what good food is supposed to taste like than you have discovered a gem- too often you visit places that just try too hard, Amber is not one of those knockoffs. It is the real thing. 

2. Something expected and unexpected: We of course had the butter chicken, which was mouthwatering... I would recommend it for people who don't even like curry- it had a very unique combination of a mild spice followed by a mint aftertaste so it basically counterbalanced. HOWEVER.....we absolutely LOVED the Kashmiri Roganjosh which is a Lamb delicacy from the Kashmir valley with saffron, ginger & fennel seeds. We have never had lamb so tender and Delicious. No fat, gristle or rubbery texture here! 

3. They served our favorite that wasn't on the menu. I love Channa Masala (garbanzo cooked in Punjabi style) but to my disappointment it wasn't on the menu. I mentioned this to our server, she said no problem and out came the best we had ever tasted. 

4. The service was fantastic.... it was busy but we called at the last minute and they got us in- no wait. We had 8 pm tix to see Wicked and were of course running behind- no problem- not only did they bring our food hot and fast but it was clearly made to order and included a speciality dish. 

Bottom line is that we loved it sooo much we decided to pack up our leftovers to go- which we never would have done before going to the theater- and walked/jogged the 5 blocks back to the car (in 4 inch heels) just to make sure we could have it for dinner tonight- when we discovered that the car valet had left (another story) we smuggled it into the theater, good thing it want crowded and the containers were sealed! The show was great but the dinner was fantastic!! We cant wait to go back!!!!
author: Katie K.

description: friday evening happy hour..six pm arrival...up to crowded bar...mixologist bar with creative drinks..taking longer and servicing slow...an eternity to get a drink...taking what is available from others...amber allowing overflow to downstairs restaurant area for drinking...finding the staff friendly and restaurant accommodating..sipping downstairs and seated..finding the atmosphere quite nice and fancy...small bar food bites carefully prepared...restaurant downstairs fairly empty...finding the crowds vanishing after happy hour end and back to premium pricing...easier to get drinks at full price...few potent tasty manhattans and a slightly dazed start to a san francisco weekend...
author: Hen A.

description: The food, drinks and atmosphere were wonderful. it was not as dressy as we had hoped, I think partly because it is near the shopping district. we shared butter chicken, lamb vindaloo, naan yogurt and fabulous cocktails.
author: Michelle H.

description: This place is amazing. It's a semi-casual place.  It's kinda pricy for Indian buffet but it's amazing. Some could say its a bit price for a Indian buffet but I like this place. And if I like a place, I wouldn't mind putting out good money. I like the atmosphere as well. I wouldn't mind taking a date here.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
I happened to meet a group of friends here at the last minute and decided to give the food a go.  I found the food to be a bit below par for the price.   Their lamb dishes were a bit on the salty side and the Balucci Chicken Tikka was so so.  For the price I expected something more.  I do hear the Butter Chicken is good, though

When it came time to pay I was billed twice.  I called the manager the next day to resolve the issue.  I had to make multiple phone calls and eventually had to take the time to stop by the restaurant to ask for my money back.  The excuse given to me was that they forgot to charge one of our party and decided to charge my card twice without notifying me.  I told them that they made the mistake and charging me twice without notification was unacceptable and asked for my money back.  The manager processed the refund, which I'm still waiting for, but forgot to give me a receipt.  

Update:  The people at Amber have reached out to assure me that it was an honest mistake and that I will be refunded my money.  It's an appreciated gesture on their part.
author: Ehb T.

description:
Negative one point for the way they treated me, three for the food, for a total of two. 

First, the food: some of their dishes are on par with other good Indian restaurants, but some are on par with the not so good restaurants. Some of the dishes are too oily, which is common with Indian and Pakistani food that I've had around the bay area. For the prices they charge, I would expect all the dishes to be on the better side. 

As for how they treated me: I walked in and was told to go to the lounge, as they serve dinner there. Even though I asked the waitress where to sit, so therefore she knew I was there, she did not help me. All night. She spent quite a while talking to the very nicely dressed couple in front of me, and another couple to the side of me, and another couple who came in right behind me, as well as a group who came in after me. She did come over to ask a perfunctory, "How is everything?" while I was eating, but she did not bring me water, give me a menu, take my order, serve my food, or bring me the bill. Thank goodness the bartender did all this; he even refilled my water after I'd drunk it while waiting for fifteen minutes for someone to take my order. How do I know it was fifteen minutes? The time stamp on text messages I replied to while waiting to be helped. The waitress also took forever to take my credit card after I put it in the book, stood up the book, laid the book flat, and opened and closed it once or twice in the hopes that she would notice. It's not that they were so busy, as evidenced by the fact that she had time to lean and chitchat with the nicely dressed couple again. So when I realized after I'd left that the name on the receipt was a female name and not male, I called to ask that my tip be given to the bartender, as he was the one who had helped me all night. The response the woman on the phone gave me was, "I talked to the manager and he says he's not going to discuss this with you again. But the bartender will get his tip." Um, what kind of a response is that? Especially when the manager did not talk to me directly. If I owned a restaurant and my employees had ignored a guest that way, I would at least have gotten on the phone myself and apologized. It occurred to me that maybe the person who answered the phone was the waitress herself. But since I wrote the restaurant a letter about it and they haven't bothered to reply, I take it that they do not value my business. So if any of my friends ever suggests eating there, I will tell them why we should go elsewhere.
author: N Q.

description: Food here is consistently horrible. I'm guessing the great reviews are from tourists who have never had decent Indian food.
author: Eater S.

description: My boyfriend and I had reservations for a 9pm dinner, and we sat there for about 25 minutes before a waiter came over to take our order.We came to try the Dine About Town menu, but ended up ordering off the regular menu because there wasn't much difference in price. The food was good but definitely not worth the +$90 bill for two people! That included one small appetizer, two entrees, and two desserts, no drinks. Overall, service was horrible.
author: Pamela v.

description: I made a reservation the night before, but opted for Bluestem Brasserie instead (which was great). So we decided to try again the next night--a tuesday night. It was packed, and we couldnt get in for 30 minutes. The lounge was offered, but the music was so loud I couldnt hear anyone, or read the menu! We were seated later, and waited for our server for a bit. I got an eggplant dish--which was cold, and sparce. We ordered the amber special bread, however got regular. My mum ordered sea bass, however it was masked in the thick grey green sauce, hiding any freshness of the fish. Her entree was cold as well. I loved the idea of Amber, however I think they might be inconsistent in their food service.
author: Brittany B.

description:
i've come to amber several times, both in sf and in san jose. im basing this review, however, on my most recent visit - which was on valentine's day. 

we came for the sunday brunch and arrived at 1:30. At first glance, the food already looked cold. 

in any case, i set my biases aside and headed for the appetizers:
