- asparagus uttapam - 3.5/5: didn't have a whole lot of the asparagus taste but still good)
-chicken achari - 5/5:  soft, tender, and succulent. this was definitely a fave
-pani puri - 4.5/5: the puris were slightly stale, but pani puri always tastes good to me, so it gets a high rating
-chickpea patties (i don't remember what exactly) - 4/5: crispy on the outside, soft on the inside

the main dishes, however, is where i was really disappointed:
-aloo bhindi/ baigan/ tawa vegetables/ yellow dal/ black pepper chicken : 2.5/5 stars
-butter chicken: 4/5: one of the better dishes
-palak paneer: 4/5: also one of the better dishes. creamy and spinach-y
-garlic naan: 4/5: a one star deduction because it took them FOREVER to bring it out

dessert
-chocolate pastry: 3/5: ehh, not very flavorful
-sooji halwa: 5/5: YUM, just like how my mom makes it! very delicious!

drinks:
-pink elephant: 5/5: luckily, they made this right
-masala chai: 4/5: heavy on the masala, but it hit the spot

other:
service: 5/5: the manager (i think) was especially friendly and considerate. 
ambiance: 5/5: its expensive and in sf...so what do you expect
prices: expect to pay at least $25 per person if you get non-veg items

i have to say, i am usually very satisfied with my visits to amber. i've found, though, that i'm happier choosing from the a la carte menu than opting for the buffet. based on my other visits to amber restaurants (at least half a dozen times), i'd give their food a solid 4/5 stars. definitely worth trying.
author: Asmita J.

description: Mega-delicious food in a crowded area of SF with annoyingly tough parking. Butter chicken is rich, and lamb-and-rice (I know it has a fancier name, can't recall) was perfectly seasoned. Atmosphere is kind of swanky corporate, but that rhymes with its context.
author: Stephen Z.

description: very authentic and very trendy.. recommend reservations in advance. really good sauces and tender meats and foul . i thought there was too much mixture of dark meat on the butter chicken and chicken tikka masala dishes. maitre d and floor managers do a really bang up job and pick up the flack for inattentive waiters.
author: Michael O.

description:
Excellent Indian food, but they need to kick up the service, particularly during lunchtime.

This Amber is supposed to be an elegant restaurant for high quality food and superb service. This Amber has lived up to these expectations on two (dinner) occasions).  

Lunch, however, is a completely different experience. It's chaotic. It's super casual, which is fine, but that's NOT an excuse for Amber to dial things down on their end. The service has been inexcusably terrible on the last two lunchtime trips (on weekends nonetheless). We spent way too much effort looking for waiters to fill our water glasses, bringing us naan (it arrived 30 minutes after we started the buffet), and paying the bill.
author: Lissa T.

description:
In town for business and SO HAPPY I came across this restaurant. I found it through Google Places - just blocks away from my hotel with great service and food.  Granted it was a slow night, Tuesday night.  I sat in the bar - it was not packed at all, very pleasant. 

To start, per recommendation of a Yelper, I had the Cauliflower Bezule - good, varying flavors and textures.  I was delighted with my entree, the Badam Bhara Baingan - braised baby eggplants.  It was warm with a crunch from the almonds and a kick from the spices. The tomato sauce played nice with spoonfuls of basmati rice. I ordered the Chocolate Molten Cake to go - not sweet and it had a taste I couldn't figure out (I guess it was the spice), okay but I don't think I would order it again. 

Overall, very happy with my meal and service.
author: Cristina B.

description: The food here is really awesome especially if you go for the lunch buffet.  I liked the chaat item, butter chicken, dhaal.  Their vegetarian menu was super delicious.   I also liked the service - attentive and friendly.  The ambiance is upscale and also not so noisy.  One of the best indian restos in the bay =)
author: Hema K.

description: I went here twice and really liked the food here - highlight was the chicken biryani. they made it so well. This is a great place but is very expensive. I'd have given it a 5, if it was a bit cheaper (and would have visited this every week)
author: Siva G.

description: Yummmmmmmmm. I had never heard of this place until a friend suggested we try it out after work last week. I had passed it several times but never had enough curiosity to walk in. I am SO glad I finally did! The butter chicken is an absolute MUST, literally melts in your mouth. The garlic and herb naan is also really good. My friend had the sea bass and also really enjoyed it. Overall Amber is definitely on my repeat list!
author: Mallory M.

description: Came in for dinner after business trip. Sat down and got completely ignored by the wait staff as they walk around and played grab-a**.  Walked out and did not try the food.  Avoid for service.
author: Hooman S.

description: Love Love Love the Biryani especially the Hyderabadi chicken Biryani. The ambience  can be slightly better. The food is great and so are the drinks. The waitresses are slightly uptight compared to the Amber India in Santana Row. 'I highly recommend
author: Laks C.

description: Absolutely awesome.  Eggplant was fired and spicy.  Needed lots of water.  Could stop eating it. Garlic herb naan was superb. Mint chutney had a kick as well.  Will definitely return to this place.
author: Greg K.

description:
If price is the most important thing to you, then hit this place during Happy Hour. The interesting and different drinks are decently priced and the apps are cheap. 

While the food in the main dining area is kind of expensive for what it is, it does taste very very good. Unlike most Indian restaurants where there were 5 of us and we would order like 3 or 4 dishes, at Amber, we ordered 5 dishes and ate every last bit as the portions aren't out of control, which I do like. But they are like $20 a dish, so even for the portion, it was a little much for me. The service was very quick! So it's good if you are starving, which we were. 

One thing I would recommend is the not-ice cream for desert. I forget what it was called, but it looks like ice cream, but it's not and it tastes a little different. It was excellent! Ask your server. They'll know what it is.
author: Rebecca S.

description: The meat quality was very good, and there was a variety of Indian foods to choose from. This is a must-visit place for anyone who is a fan of Indian cuisine.
author: Jun W.

description:
Really delicious food -- the butter chicken and also the paneer, in particular.  We went for the weekend buffet.  The food was very fresh and well seasoned without being overpowering.  If the review was based on the food alone, I'd add another star.  However ...

The downside is that the service was really slow, which made me thankful that we were only waiting for drinks (and later, the check) instead of food because otherwise we might have died of starvation.  It could be that they just want you to be sure of your requests.  If that's the case, be warned that you have to feel strongly enough to ask three times.

From the bait and switch file: It was also slightly off-putting that the sign at the door promises a lavish Indian buffet for $16.95 while the bill sneaks in an additional $3 per person just because it happens to be Sunday.  

So to end on a positive note: go hungry.  You won't be disappointed.  Just make sure your thirst is under control and make sure you don't have anywhere to go afterwards.
author: Matt O.

description:
Wow, I don't think I can compete with Jane A's review, she summed it all up pretty well. My friend and I had great service, the food was very yummy, we started with the Aloo Peas Samosa and I had a nice glass of their Shiraz, although the Syrah caught my eye and I wish I would have tried it... For the main course I had Butter Chicken which was very very yummy! I tried my friend's dish which was Jaipuri Bhindi and it was pretty good as well. 

Our service was really good, the whole staff was friendly, I would recommend this place to anyone who is wanting Indian food. Please do keep in mind that you will pay more than you would for your average Indian restaurant however you get a much better dining experience.
author: Bobby B.

description: Went here for dinner.  Found that the prices were very high and serving sizes small compared to other Indian restaurants.  I think the sea bass entrée had just 6 chunks of sea bass and was about $24.  The service was also poor.  Seemed like no one wanted to wait on our table and they just wanted the bus boy to do everything.  Instead of staying for dessert at Amber we left and went elsewhere.
author: Allison M.

description: Happy Hour here is a steal! Drinks are STIFF and there's a good assortment of tasty appetizers.
author: Maggie L.

description: This place is pricy but the food and the ambiance are great. They even have a lounge area with a full bar. Anything you order here will melt in your mouth and you will feel like you are on cloud 9. I still dream about their butter chicken. It is unbeatable.
author: Cari G.

description: Went during lunch on the weekend and they had a buffet. Im not a buffet person and was able to order on the main menu. I had the Sea bass in curry and it was ok. The curry tasted pretty good and was seasoned well. My partner was not content with the buffet. But if you order the buffet you get bottomless mimosa's so thats not bad
author: Kevin D.

description:
Had a bad stomach after eating here, Was told the manager would call me, never happened. 
ALso i used to be a fan of this restaurant. But their quality of food has gotten really bad, now. Amercans should demand better Indian Food, and FRESH er...
author: Noor K.

description:
Gazing upon splendid marble and shiny fixtures twinkling from recessed halogen lighting I found peace, inner tranquility, and the meaning of Amber - its bathrooms are the most wondrous thing about it.

I loved Amber's ambiance but probably would've enjoyed dinner and authentic Indian cuisine someplace cheaper.
The vegetable samosas weren't flaky or crisp. Try Crisco! The filling was bland.

The mixed grill appetizer featured a mystery-meat-looking sausage along with non-tandoori-pink-in-the-middle chicken. Dear salmonella gods, please have mercy on me.

The shrimp moilee had a vague cream sauce reminiscent of Spanish tapas, not bad, but not Indian and not memorable.

Sadly, my favorite dish, chicken tikka masala, looked exactly like the delicious tawa sea bass - minus the deliciousness. Suspiciously, the butter chicken looked exactly like what I'd expected from my chicken tikka. I hope my friend didn't mind me stealing most of his butter-chicken-tikka-masala-whatever-the-hell-charge-22.99-for-it-tastes-like-crack-creamy-and-delicious.

Lastly the service was a bit off. It was incredibly attentive, but in a clingy, clueless, grandmotherly way. It was hard to finish a sentence of my gossipy stories before grandma would ask if we wanted more drinks, more food, or sweaters! 

"Grandma, you know I love you, but can I please finish my appetizer first?"

2.75 * stars
author: Brady K.

description:
I've been to Amber India a handful of times for the lunch buffet, happy hour, and a quick drink. Not bad.  Not bad at all. The lunch buffet isn't inexpensive, but you can't really expect it to be considering the location and the fact that they built this restaurant from scratch.  Treat the buffet as an informal tasting menu where you get to try a bunch of the restaurant's offerings.  My favorite buffet item is the butter chicken, which, I believe is Amber's signature dish.

The happy hour is a great deal. The three special drinks are $5 each. I'm quite partial to the Manhattan made with Bulleit bourbon. Much tastier and significantly cheaper than the one at Ducca.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
Took my gf here for a special night out .. Not impressed .. I'm about to leave. Reservation for 8pm. Couldnt seat us until 845 .. Went to the bar .. Fought for 25 minutes to get a drink. Horrible service . About to leave

..... 

UPDATE.  WOW  I'm really impressed.  They totally changed my view.  I think they just got slammed by a large party. 

Had this been a NORMAL restaurant they would have just given us our table. However, they sincerely felt that it was below par to make someone wait for so long for a table.  They gave us a free appetizer and dessert and also apologized three times (from three different people including the manager).

Further, the food was EXCELLENT.

They even charged my iPhone when I asked them as I had run out of power (SO NICE).

Anyway.  I changed my 1 star rating to 5 stars.  What a great company / restaurant.  

Will definitely be going again.

Oh.  One complaint is that the customer base was somewhat older and frankly not dressed to impress.  Many tourists, tennis shoes, t-shirts, etc and in the 40-50 age range.

Dude.  You're not at the ball park.  Take a shower and get dressed before you go out on a friday!
author: Kevin B.

description:
This review is for the lunch buffet only.  

I headed over to Amber India for lunch one Friday and found the place packed - we actually had to wait for a table for two.  Once we were seated I realized just how large the restaurant is.  There were so many tables that I was a bit concerned when I saw how small the buffet was.  More importantly I was concerned when I saw how many hungry looking people were standing in line holding empty plates.  Crowds aside, I found Amber adequate but probably not worth the $16 price tag.  

There was a cold crispy rice salad that was pretty tasty and some smoked salmon that just seemed out of place.  About 4-5 curry selections, my favorite being the one with the chick peas and the lentils.  The fried potato fritter was tasty, but made me miss having some sort of pakora.  The catfish was delicious and moist, which is impressive since it has to sit out on a hot plate.  The biggest disappointment is the naan - NOT good.  It is really more like a store bought pita than a hot crispy naan.  My guess is that this is not made in house because it was neither hot, nor particularly fresh.  While bread does not seem like a big deal, when you are paying $16 I kind of expect fresh delicious bread.  Not sure I would return for the lunch buffet.
author: Dana H.

description:
The spinach salad appetizer here is phenomenal.  It's crispy and sweet and spicy all at once.  Neither my girlfriend or I could get enough of this dish.  The food was incredible with complex flavors and meat so tender that you could actually cut it with a fork.  

Then there was the naan bread.  We ordered the whole wheat naan.  It was buttery and flaky, literally hot little sheets of tasty naan peeling off as I dipped it in the sauce and scooped up the amazing chicken biryani.  

This place is phenomenal for a date or taking your parents to for a nice meal.  It also happens to be right across from the Jewish museum, next to the MOMA , and just down the plaza from Beard Papa.  Needless to say you can make a complete day of eating in this neighborhood, with a phenomenal break for some culture.  

My only issue with this place is this.  For two dishes and an appetizer, diet coke and iced tea (re: NO ALCOHOL) the bill was over $70!  I checked the bill twice and it was no hallucination.  The food was phenomenal to be sure, and unlike some cheaper Indian restaurants, the dishes didn't have a lot of bones in them, but at double the price!  

I went to Shalimar recently and got four dishes and drinks, sans alcohol, for just over $45.  Amber has a tremendous ambiance, but the question is is that worth paying double the price?  I'm no so sure.
author: Adam E.

description: Loved the weekend brunch! Would give 5-starts if they changed the buffet-items periodically though..
author: venu p.

description:
I've only been once and had their $15 buffet and tried a little bit of every thing.  Very pricey but the food is very delicious.  I don't know what they do differently, but all their curries have this really amazing richness to them.   The naan is very buttery and flaky as well.

I would give it 5 stars if the buffet price was a little reasonable.
author: Mack D.

description:
Amber India is bigger inside than it looks from outside.  It's nice and well decorated, the bar has a cool color changing wall, and the floors are marble, the place looks CLEEEEEEEAN.

The food was delicious, had a roast duck skewer appetizer, roasted prawns and curry chicken.  It was yummy, we ate it all, then licked the metal serving bowls and plates, and vacuumed up every last grain of lemon rice...

Amber's dessert menu has $50 shots of Hennessey Paradis - oh we fancy, huh?  And prices are a bit high IMO, and there are probably places that can get me just as full for half the price. All the same I'd come back again, the restaurant is great for hot dates and intimate meals.
author: Stephen A.

description: Food is decent but not worth the price. There are a lot of other better indian resturants. It is very pricey if you go alone as there is no thali option and leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Vipul J.

description: The lamb and butter chicken was awesome. The ambiance is beautiful. Service was ok, that's why i knocked off a star. Overall, a must try Indian restaurant. My one and only tip if you go for dinner is GET A RESERVATION, or else you will regret the long wait.
author: Mary L.

description:
Right across from the Press Club wine bar, if you are BARTing in or taking the MUNI then hop off at Powell street and you're there. 

It's a little pricey for Indian food, but you can taste the quality and freshness. A good workaround is to go during happy hour, which is when they also have $5 drink specials. 

I recommend the assorted bread basket which has a variety of naan. Get there early and grab a comfy cushy seat and people watch.  The decor is quite lovely and makes you feel a little like you're in LA.
author: Benita S.

description: This place is stylish but soon expensive. Luckily I went with my boss, who paid for it. The greatest thing is that this place offers buffet lunch, which is a deal breaker if you love Indian food. What sets this apart from other Indian restaurants is the hip decor and the less commercialized Indian dishes that they serve. I'm not sure of the names of these dishes since it was a buffet but if you're into new , powerful and spicy tastes, make a note of this restaurant!
author: Dmitri S.

description: Great food and great service!! The fried spinach (Palak Chaat) is to die for. A few other favorites are the Basil Chicken, Four-Chili Rubbed Fish Kebab (Sea Bass), and the samosas. We had my boyfriends birthday here and everything was perfect. Its a great space for a large or small dining party.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
OMG...definitely a must try.  I usually have some skepticism eating at an "all you could eat" buffet, but everything...yes, everything was fairly fresh and definitely tasty.  There is not a huge array of food, but enough to pick and choose.   The three chicken dishes were superb!

BTW, we were there during Oracle week...and the place was packed. A large handful of the customers were of Indian descent (probably more like 40%), and the restaurant was staffed accordingly.  I will definitely be back!
author: L. L.

description: I come to this Amber India since it is close proximity to work.  They have one of the best lunch buffets.  Everyday they have a different selection.  Some days are better than others but I do how they provide different variations of Indian food.  The only thing about the buffet is in a very small space.  When it is crowded it is hard to get through.  The ambience is nice and intimate.
author: Christine Y.

description: This place is so amazing! The restaurant is very nicely decorated and the waitress we had was very knowledgeable about everything on the menu including wine. She helped us all pick items and then we shared them. She even served each of us with our own small portions. Every thing that we had was very delicious. The only negative thing I can say about this restaurant is the price. It was a little high, but you definitely get what you pay for. I can't wait to go back again!
author: Andrew P.

description:
Customer feedback is not taken seriously. 
For this Thanks Giving, I went for a lunch Buffet and there was one fish dish next to Veggie dishes and they have added word fish in a blue color pen which is not at all visible. By mistake I took it and later on I realized and told them to mark it with a black pen and write in large font. He said he has put the name of the fish, as a vegetarian, I won't be knowing names of fish, when I told him that he totally ignored my feedback. No matter how grand a restaurant is, if customer feedback is not taken seriously, I would not go again. For a business to sustain and last for long time, Customer First attitude should be part of the culture.
author: Sarat A.

description: I have had better Indian food for much better price. It is clean, service and ambiance are good. It would be a good choice if I wanted to have mediocre to good level Indian food translated for common public taste. Utility to price ratio is low. Service is very good.
author: U D.

description:
4.5 stars.

I loved, loved, LOVED this place and can't wait to go back to try more of the goodies on the menu!

Started the night off in the bar. I was pleasantly surprised to find that they had a Happy Hour menu. Who knew??? I decided to go with the Amber Rose and two of these sent me on my way to feeling reallllly good. 

When we sat down for dinner, we decided on the spinach appetizer, butter chicken, grilled lamb chops and paratha. What's there to say other than everything was delicious. The tomato-y sauce on the butter chicken was perfect for the basmati rice and the bread to be soaked into. The sauces for the spinach and lamb went perfectly with both dishes. 

The only regret is that we were too full to order dessert. My money would have definitely been on the mango brulee. We also agreed that this would be a perfect place to come with many people so that you could sample more things from the menu. 

Oh well, next time...
author: Jen N.

description: Great atmosphere! Very reasonably priced.  I know my Indian food and love authentic cuisine. The butter chicken was fantastic and the sauce was delicious, get some naan because dipping into the sauce will be in order. The taro dumplings are also a great dish even if your'e not vegetarian, they are very hearty and once again the sauce is delicious. Their ginger alcohol drink was amazing.
author: Marat P.

description:
Amber India Alert - Blase Food with Decor to Compensate

An over priced tourist destination for clientele unfamiliar with truly excellent Indian food. A great feast for the eye only. Leave with your pallet unsatisfied.

I ordered Calamari, Basil Chicken Tikka, Paneer Tikka Lal Mirch (Indian cheese), Kesar Elaichi Gosht (lamb).

The appertizer was overcooked -the calamari was approaching rigor mortis. Each dish arrived in increasingly delayed increments. Everything was overcooked and with the same flavor for each dish.

Indian food, much like French food, is supposed to be cooked in a slow manner with special attention to the concoction of flavors. Amber India did not really serve Indian food. There is a prevalence of poor quality Indian food throughout the bay area, which probably explains the low expectations of easily satisfied eaters.

Service is also mediocre.

Two stars are for the decor -which is quite appealing. The bar also might not be a bad place for a night in the city.
author: Mona I.

description: This was the only place available in the area to take in 5 people at rush hour and it was amazing. Naan was freshly made, all the food that we ordered from fish from tandoori to different masalas it was all so amazing. Biryani one of the best I have ever eaten. We had 2 people from France with us and you know how picky they are with French bread and wine, but they actually loved this place.
author: Roman N.

description:
My first thought upon entering this restaurant was "why is there so much marble everywhere?".    This is a really  beautiful restaurant, some might say over-the-top beautiful, but Indian people are known for going over-the-top with their marble (see: Taj Mahal).    

I was disappointed with my visit to the San Jose location of Amber, but decided to give this one a try.   Our dinner here was wonderful.  The duck kabob appetizer was very tender and flavorful, though it didn't really taste like duck.  The tandoori Seabass was some of the best fish I have ever had.  The mushroom palak was bland and not very good, though I liked the idea of mushrooms in palak.   The braised lamb shank with roasted turnips was a nice dish, the lamb was very tender and the flavor was good (once you've had the lamb at Bukhara in Delhi no other lamb can measure up).   Chocolate kulfi was a great way to finish off the meal.   

Note: This is the 2nd most expensive Indian dinner I've had in the Bay Area, the most expensive was at the now closed Gaylords in Sausilito.
author: Ranjit M.

description:
My colleagues and I just ate dinner at Amber. I loooooove Indian food, and I've eaten a ton of it over the years. Without a doubt this was the best I've had anywhere. 

Be sure to try the Tandoori Ajwaini Salmon, which may be the most delicious thing I've tasted in my life that didn't contain chocolate. If I come back as a salmon in a future life, I would jump into a fishing net if I could count on the honor of winding-up in the tandoor at Amber. Yes, THAT good.

I also strongly recommend the 'Black Grapes ka Shaki Takuda,' which they describe as a saffron bread pudding with black grape marmalade. It's beautifully presented, delicate and otherwise difficult to describe -- not what I picture when I think of bread pudding. Even better.

Perfect service and a gorgeous interior help to round-out a truly wonderful dining experience.
author: Todd H.

description:
Best Indian cuisine that I've experienced so far!

Buh-Buh-Butter Chicken! Tinka duck kabob app was the best! I cannot rave more about this place but it was the overall experience combined with great service and exceptional cuisine(okra, samosas)! Even the Taj Mahal beer was delicious! I couldn't believe that it was smooth and reminded me of a nice amber ale of some sort! Make sure you order the different types of naan(garlic was my fave).
author: Chris A.

description: Agree BEST, big and beautiful Indian restaurant, expensive but dude is nothing better then this, go for it NOW NOW NOW!!!
author: Ana G.

description: Yuck.  I mean, YUCK!!!  The food is mediocre.  The place is too busy for what it's worth.  Must be the location.  The front desk staff is the worst.  They lost my reservation.  Then I had to wait for 20 minutes to be seated.  They wouldn't let me take my table until my friend arrived - she was late. Really?!  Finally, when I got to my table, I asked to send my friend over, when she arrives.  They told me to go and fetch her myself, because they were too busy!  Really?!  The waiters, however, were really nice, as well as the bus boys.  Hence, 2 stars.
author: LANA R.

description:
What is it with Indian restaurants?  They draw you in with the aromas and the colors and the tastiness of the food, but somehow it's never quite right.  I grew up in the London, where "Indian" long since became the new "local" in things culinary, and I ate Indian as often as anybody, but as soon as I moved overseas I dropped the habit.  I ate at Amber India on Yerba Buena Lane - a great location - and left satisfied with my food, but a bit  indifferent to the whole experience, but indifferent in a way that was somehow familiar...

It's a nice room, sleek in its design, echoing the clean, contemporary feel of Yerba Buena Lane, itself one of those oases of presentable style amid the truly mixed bag of scenery off Market St between Union Square & SoMa.  It buzzes at lunchtime with a combination of business lunches and more social encounters, and its large, street-level windows provide a full view of people passing along the lane, contributing to the general sense of movement in the room.  

All-in-all, it's an upbeat, comfortable place to be, at least at lunchtime.  The design and location contribute to that atmosphere, and so does the lunch buffet, which is available during the week.  It's long been my view that this is the most appropriate way to deliver Indian food, and at Amber India it's well done.  Great butter and tandoori chicken, as well as a good mix of vegetable dishes, Indian appetizers and chutneys.  It's presented well too - certainly well enough that you could take a client or a discerning friend along with confidence.

But still it's not quite right.  The service, while discreet and friendly is a bit patchy.  The hostess looked flustered, empty plates sat on the table for too long and the coffee that we ordered was simply revolting (but our server seemed to be struggling with it so we let it go).  The food is good, but hardly worth the lofty scores Zagat lavishes on it - and by the way, many of the most anomalous scores to be observed in that guide in cities the world over tend to be awarded to South Asian cuisine.  Beware!  Amber India is a reliable, good quality Indian restaurant in agreeable surrounds, but there are many, many better dining experiences to be had in this town.
author: Dom B.

description: Went here last night for my birthday dinner.  I had been to the delicious brunch before, but never for dinner.  The cauliflower app was excellent and the service was fabulous as well.  Our waitress made a deliciously overwhelming menu very easy to navigate by sharing her favorites and every bite was great.
author: Jean P.

description: We go here for the ambience! I surprised how huge this place is. Nice, trendy indian restaurant. It can be a little expensive but two dishes with naan and rice can easily feed 4. We tried butter chicken and garlic naan which were good. Also paneer tikka appetizer was great. I would be back!
author: Sheena S.

description: An Indian colleague had recommended this place and the different Indian colleague we invited to dinner said the food was good. For appetizers, we had veggie samosas and Cauliflower Bezule (cauliflower florets in coconut sauce). The cauliflower really stood out as we'd never had anything like it before. For non-vegan mains, Kashmiri Roganjosh (lamb), Kadhai Jhinga Makhan Masala (shrimp), and Dal Amber. For vegan mains, we ordered the only two that the menu listed, Jaipuri Bhindi (okra) and Masala Mirch Salan (jalapeno peppers in a tamarind coconut peanut sauce). Saffron rice and brown rice, parathas and garlic naan for carbs. Everybody too full for dessert. I can see how some people consider this place overpriced, but in my experience, higher end prices like this go along with the stellar service and classy ambiance.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Made reservations online for a Monday evening--we were promptly seated upon arriving. The restaurant has dim lighting and modern decor, but not as upscale and trendy as I had anticipated. You could wear jeans and not feel out of place. Atmosphere was loud and crowded, I wouldn't consider this place for a romantic quiet dinner. 

We ordered the samosas appetizers which were a little cold and not that crispy, the mint dipping sauce was interesting. We also had the butter chicken and Kozhi Melagu, both were flavorful and went well with the rice and naan. Our server was prompt, but wasn't that cordial when greeting us. 

Overall the dining experience was pleasant, nothing too spectacular. Honestly I was expecting more for the price and rave reviews, but it's a nice place if you're in the mood to splurge a little.
author: Betty J.

description:
I'm happy Amber expanded to SF.  After making a lot of trips to the mothership in Mountain View, I was impressed by this upscale adaptation of one of my go-to indian spots.
This Amber verges on fancy and is a calm place to have a business or family dinner, or romantic date like I did.
The bar looks inviting, but I didn't get to visit this time.
author: Thomas K.

description: I always thought I had already done this review...... I reference Amber in all of my other indian restaurant reviews..... Anyway, the reason I always reference it is because Amber is the best of Northern California, by far. You can't beat it. Their buffet is amazingg, but dinner is even better. We get the shrimp appetizer (very light, but SOOOO delicious, I could drink that sauce!), I get the tandoor chicken that isn't marinated in yogurt, just spices, and ask for the sindhi murg sauce (its a tomato based sauce, SOOO delicious!) on the side. We share basmati rice, boyfriend gets the butter chicken, and we share garlic naan and chili naan without butter. My mouth waters just dreaming about it. Everything tastes so fresh and wonderful. When we go to the buffet we love trying their veggies like the curried broccoli, the mushrooms in the tangy red sauce, and the potatoes that are perfectly seasoned. Boyfriend and I always make sure we eat here whenever we go shopping in the city. We look forward to it every time.
author: Michelle S.

description:
update on Amber - had another great dinner here with friends - we were to meet in the bar for drinks before and there was no service! No bartender no wait staff nothing??  Strange but true.  

We mentioned this to the host as we were seated for dinner - they apologized profusely and gave us a free dessert!  So all is forgiven - but watch the service in the bar and if they disappear again - go see the host immediately - they will fix it.  Until next time they are getting 4 1/2 stars.
author: Julie B.

description:
Walked in and impressed with this Indian restaurant, not your typical Indian joint. 

Tried the following:

Shalgam Nalli - Free Range, Natural, Niman Ranch 6 hour braised lamb shank and baby turnips in caramelized onions & yogurt sauce. This dish was plenty and a bit spicy, but fall off the bone good and a must try.

Asparagus and Cauliflower Balchao - Asapargus and cauliflower tossed with onion, tomato and home ground Goan spice mix. This dish was great as well.

And of course had to have naan. 

The food at Amber was extremely tasty even with it being a bit spicy. Next time I will ask my food to be prepared mild.  

From our waitress to the bus person to the guy who inquired about our dining all had CLASS. Definitely 5 of 5 overall.

There was just one thing I found a bit cheesy about Amber being such a classy place, was the "Suggested Gratuity 15-18%" printed on the bottom of the check. Based on great food and outstanding service I'm sure your clientele would tip accordingly. I left a 20% tip. No big deal, just my personal opinion.

Definitely a place to go when you have the urge to $PLURGE. 

I will be back!
author: Reggie R.

description:
- The wait was incredibly long, but at least the cocktails were delicious. 
- As mentioned in many reviews, butter chicken was good. 
- Eggplant dish was a bit spicy.
- Naan was great but the kitchen ran out when we asked for a second basket. They gave us rice instead, but it's not quite the same...

Yes, they take reservations, but that doesn't mean you won't still wait half an hour or more.
author: Jay K.

description:
Butter chicken.  This dish is amazing.  In a group of 6 people, we devoured this dish and then proceeded to eat the sauce.  I guess my friends and I have no shame but the sauce is now something I dream about.  Really.  
The only down side is the cost.  I think that I have become accustomed to sub $10 Indian food entrees and it was painful to fork over some more money...that being said I've never dreamt about food from those places.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Went there tonight with my wife.  We've been there for Happy Hour before and really like the apps and the $5 drinks, but this was our first time for dinner.  We had a fantastic meal.  The Salmon Chimichurri was moist and flavorful, but the Amber Dal lentil dish was one of the best dishes we've had in a long, long time.  The service was exemplary as well, but we were there a little earlier than normal.  One nice feature is that it's very close to Bart.
We'll definitely be back for dinner!
author: Scott G.

description:
It saddens me a bit to break over two years of silence with negative words, but there's something I need to tell you.  To put it succinctly (consult with your programmer friends if this makes no sense):

HTTP/1.1 303 See Other
Location: http://www.yelp.com/biz/mehfil-indian-cuisine-san-francisco

"It was their opening night!" you may say.  I'm normally pretty generous with my stars (and I'm a big fan of the Amber location in Mountain View), but their failure was so comprehensive that it was almost comical.  I assume my co-diners will relate the full story so I'll spare you the repeat details, but let's just say that I'll try again in a month or so and see if they've figured the whole service thing out.  

The food was not bad.
author: Russel S.

description:
To quickly go over the bad, they really need to improve service. There is no excuse for poor service at 2pm at a buffet restaurant. All they have to do is refill my water, and take my plate when I get up.

That being said, this is very high quality Indian food, to the point where $17 feels like a bargain for all you can eat deliciousness.

The butter chicken was, as expected, amazing, although it was especially nice for a restaurant's signature dish to live up to its reputation, I've been disappointed recently with others. The carrot pudding was the other huge standout.

In general though, everything was delicious, and they had quite a large variety; the goat was the only thing I wasn't a huge fan of.
author: Mark A.

description:
we happened to stumble upon amber india after being told of a long wait by a nearby restaurant.  i've never had upscale indian food before, so this was a first.  i was pleasantly surprised by our meal, although the menu was a little hard to read since you couldn't tell which dishes had curry or just a tandoori style of a meat.

eats:

butter chicken: their version of chicken tikki masala, my favorite entree of the night.  the sauce was very rich and flavorful with the tomato hint.  it tasted great with the garlic naan.

black cod with curry: the cod was a bit oversalted and didn't have the texture i usually prefer for fish.  the curry sauce that was accompanied by it had a lot of flavor though.  

samosas: best appetizer we had.  it comes with a great chutney sauce and a type of indian sauce.  

tandoori sampler:  i did not like the lamb sausage at all, but the chicken was the best thing on this sampler platter.
author: Carli F.

description:
I feel pretty brave right about now. Why? Because after reading the wretched reviews of a few trusted co-workers, I pretty much figured this place was as good as dead to me and wasn't going to get an ounce of my time or patronage. But then last night, my co-worker and I decided to cut out for a glass of wine and since this was nearby and he had spotted a bar in here the day before, we decided to give it a go.

And I am really glad we did, because we had a great time. The place is totally cool looking and I loved the big red panels and the fact that you can sit and people watch as you chat it up at the bar. Rumor has it, they will be adding a patio area and that is going to be great and I'm definitely looking forward to that. As for the staff, again, I was totally happy with the service and attention. Our bartendress was Christine and she was totally friendly and welcoming. After my friend left, she still kept me entertained and that is always the sign of a cool bartender. She also really knows her wines and that is a win win in my book.

What I will say is that this place isn't cheap. Not by any means, but for a really nice glass of red after work in a perfect location, I'm not mad at it. Can't really vouch for the food here, but when you have good wine, who needs to eat ;)
author: Stephy S.

description: There was a 15 minute wait so we went to the lounge for drinks.  Lots of Indians around so we thought that was a good sign =) The lounge was nice and trendy though I did not enjoy my drink (way too gingery).  We were escorted to our table and we both ordered butter chicken.  It was very good but seems a bit over priced for $17.  I suppose you are paying for the atmosphere.  Would go here if you are in the area and want to impress your date.  One of the best curries we've had in the States.
author: Kelly T.

description:
If you think India is Ashrams, user support and barefooted people herding cows then you are thirty years behind and in dire, dire need of a visit to Amber India.

If you think Indian food has to be what you get at Shalimar or Nan & Curry - large quantities of wonderful if roughly prepared and inexpensive food served  at all hours in dodgy surroundings, you are in dire, dire need of a visit to Amber India.

Food at Amber India is prepared with the precision usually associated with the best run French kitchens. For example, every piece of okra used in their spiced okra with onions (Jaipuri Bhindi) was hand sliced to just the right thickness as opposed to just thrown into the pan. Biryani (basically rice with meat) comes to the table with a piece of nan backed over the top to stop flavors escaping a steam - an extra step I've never seen before, and I eat a lot of biryani. Flavors were dense and and spices were always distinct but never overpowering. 

Service is quick, friendly and very knowledgeable. Decor is attractive and the noise level never precludes conversation. It has a great looking bar separate from the dinning area, and next visit I might start with a drink there and then move onto dinner. 

The bill for a two cocktails, appetizer, two entrees, roti (crisp bread, sort of like hard taco shells) and a split desert was $91 including tax but before tip.

Some fun facts to scare and/or amaze your date with
- Stuff on the menu that says Jaipuri come from the Jaipur region of India. Jaipur is located in the east and called The Pink City because of its pink stucco architecture. 
- Indian breads can be made thin because they are made from hard wheat atta flower, whose  high protein content allows doughs to be rolled out very thinly.
- India is the largest democracy in the world, the second most populous country in the world, the creator of the decimal system, algebra, trigonometry, (arguably) calculus and the game of of Chutes And Ladders.
author: Bill S.

description:
This was my first Indian food experience and despite my hesitations and insistence that I don't like curry, I thought the food here was very good.  The 3 star rating is a result of the service/management.  

We had a group of 16 and we all arrived right on time for our 8pm reservation.  We were told our table wasn't ready and that we should go order drinks in the bar and we'd be seated in less than 15 minutes.  The bar was too crowded for us to fit there plus I hate being told to go order drinks when my table isn't ready so waited for our table by the entrance.  15 minutes came and went and we were not seated until about 8:45pm.  I get that we were a big group but when you have a reservation, you expect to be seated within a reasonable period of time.

To make up for the wait, the manager sent out some salads for us to get started.  

The food was quite good - we got to try many different dishes that we all shared and some of the standouts were the pesto naan, the garlic naan, the butter chicken, and sea bass moilee,  The decor is nice as well.  Perhaps you're paying a bit more for the prime location and luxe interior since it comes in on the pricier side for Indian fare.

When the bill came, we were outraged to find that they had charged us for the salads that the manager had comped.  This was a $60+ mistake and considering we spent well over $600 on food and drinks, we were not impressed that they were trying to charge us for something we hadn't ordered.  We pointed this out to the waitress who returned with a corrected bill so quickly it almost seemed like the second bill was already prepared in case we found the error.  

Too bad they tried to swindle us...coulda been a 4 star place in my mind.
author: Carrie L.

description:
I'm gonna admit that I'm don't exactly know Indian food very well, but Amber India was pretty good. I had the weekday lunch buffet there which was $17.

The selection was quite small for being a buffet, but I was pretty stuffed at the end of the meal. I'm also not a fan of spicy food, but the Butter Chicken (which I think taste just like Chicken Tikka Masala) was delicious--pair it with some naan and it's heaven. Service is good and the ambiance is really nice.
author: Tammy C.

description:
I went here with my wife for our First Anniversary. The food was surprisingly authentic. We were expecting a watered down version of the Indian food. But they had the original flavor, taste and texture that you might get at the top restaurants back in India. The seafood dishes are excellent and the portions reasonable

Definitely a place to impress your Wife or a Date.
author: Arun P.

description:
Guys just order freakin anything on the menu you are sure to love it....
I tried both veg and nonveg dishes here...never had such good Indian food in US ( I have been to all major cities...NYC, Chicago, Atlanta, Orlando, jersey, Seattle, Charlotte, Dallas ....no restaurant is as good as Amber.

Also tried "New Delhi" and "Little Delhi" in sfo but those are nowhere near Amber.... You do pay a little more at Amber but boy it's more than worth it........
author: Saurabh M.

description:
I only give such a harsh rating, one star, because we were completely mislead by the girl on the phone. Both my fiance and I are vegan and we were told there would be plenty options for us. Some of you may be thinking...wha!? but I saw lots of veggie dishes, sure they may be veggie but they're not vegan and they can't be made vegan. 

For an Indian place I was quite surprised that we had such limited options as vegans, usually we have no problem at all. OK, so tell me why this place puts dairy in their rice!? That's crazy talk, nonsense! We asked if they could make the rice without dairy for us and they said no, because rice takes a long time to cook. This is understandable, considering we waited forever to order our food and didn't feel like waiting another eternity to order.

The Naan also is not vegan, sometimes Naan has butter on top but all Indian places I've been to can exclude the butter and it's vegan. Not Amber India (aka dairy/egg industry stock holders), they put egg in their Naan. 

So we settled on the eggplant and the okra, minus rice, which were both the worst Indian food I've ever had. OK maybe that's a little harsh, but it wasn't good. F*ck the fancy decor, I'd rather go to a cheap Indian place that makes real Indian food. The eggplant was very boring, and the okra was soo soo salty. The first bite was alright but after that I felt like my insides were shriveling up.Our server was so frantic and all over the place I felt like my head was spinning. He was nice, and helpful, I'll give him that. 

They do get one star for their cocktails, those were pretty good. I would go back for a cocktail, but only a cocktail.

Damnit, don't screw up Indian food, it's just wrong!

And it was my birfday....it's OK though, I was presented with a vegan ice cream cake once I got home, thank you Maggie Mudd, with my picture on it!
author: Sarah P.

description:
I heard that this was the place for amazing Indian cuisine. While it was tasty, I don't necessarily feel that it was "the place." I mean, it's good. But I just don't feel it to be all that there is. Oh well...that's just me...

I've been here a few times before for drinks with friends. The last time I came here for a few spirits with friends, Chelsea was working the bar. She's a sweetheart and I've met her a few times before in the Financial District bars (I believe she worked at Cosmopolitan before?) Anyways, her drinks were pretty good and she was, of course, friendly as I remembered.

When I came here for the food, we were told by the hostess that Amber India had just been voted the Best Indian Restaurant in San Francisco. (Note - never mention something like that, because instantly you are throwing your standards so high that it's almost impossible to meet them).

Dinner consisted of appies of Aloo Peas Samosa, which were decent (nothing quite special about them). Dinner was the Tandoori Stuffed Aloo, which was ok but a bit dry and not necessarily what I had hoped for...and the Butter Chicken, which I was happy with because it was just the right blend of spices, flavor and moist meat. 

The setting was nice, and fairly quiet. The actual environment was defintiely modern chic design, though I'm not necessarily sure if it completely fits with Amber India's cuisine. 

It's definitely got many different aspects of being great...but not sure if they are blended together appropriately. Who knows...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Great decor, good service and the food never disappoints.  Great for carnivores, great for vegetarians.  

We had a 7:15 reservation and were seated immediately.  It was Cinco De Mayo, so the amateurs were all getting wasted at Mexican restaurants, not upscale Indian ones like this one.

They tried to seat us side by side in the window bench at a table for 4, but we declined and they just brought over a chair from another table.  No big deal, but they probably should have asked our preference rather than just sticking us there and making us object.  They fixed it quickly, but a 5 star restaurant would not have handled it that way.  Minus one star.

We ordered one thing and the server brought the wrong item.  When my guest pointed out that it wasn't right, the server told us it was "nearly the same thing" i.e. take it anyway because at least it's chicken like the dish we ordered.  OK, nice try, minus another star and take it back.  Probably wasn't the smartest thing to do.  The manager probably needs to point out how insulting this was.  A four star restaurant would never have done it that way, so now they are down to three.

Waitress came right back and apologized, said they were taking care of it.  They probably just scraped the sauce off of it and put the right sauce right back on it, but who cares, we kind of wanted what we ordered.  We later ordered a third glass of wine to split and the waitress brought two full glasses on account of the fact that they messed up the order.  Right on, +1 star.  They end up with 4 stars: some minor mishaps but all graciously taken care of, though we had to object twice.  

A peaceful, relaxing night, with excellent food.  A five star restaurant would never have treated us this way, so I can't quite give them a full 5 stars, but overall a positive experience.  It's my third time there, the first two times the service was excellent,  and so this was a notch down from what I expect from that place but I'll still be back.  

About $100 incl tax and tip with 3 glasses of wine for two people, two entrees, no appetizers and no dessert.  Somewhat pricey.  Service probably needs some working on, but overall a recommended place.
author: Charles G.

description: I stopped by for dinner and ordered an off-menu vegetarian biryani at the recommendation of the waiter.  On a scale of one to five, I'd say it was OH MY GOD!!!  You certainly earned your tip, young waiter.
author: David M.

description:
As the first reviewer to actually eat here :-), I would give it 3.5 stars.  I've been walking past Amber for the past year, waiting for it to open.  The decor is quite swanky, especially the lounge/bar area.  The dining room booths are comfortable, but the tables in the center are pretty close together.  A nearby patron brought this to the attention of a manager, as one of her dining companions was continuously bumped as the numerous waitstaff brought us our courses.  

The only beer on draft tonight was Pilsner Urquell.  The sommelier/spirits advisor mentioned that they would soon have a hefewisen on tap.  Luckily for us patrons, the Blue Moon keg would not fit in his fridge.  We are saved from Coors' poor imitation in favor of a hefe from New Belgium, a much more reputable brewery.  For any of you Brits, they do have a Pimms drink.  I was recently exposed to this tasty drink from a British collegue.  If you want a refreshing drink with fruit and cucumbers (!?!?), try it.  

We ordered the Aloo Peas Samosa for an appetizer.  These were savory, but quite small.  They were served with tamarind sauce, but missing the ubiquitous mint chutney.  While my samosas were warm, I would prefer them to be served at a higher temperature.  

For the main dishes, we ordered their famous Butter Chicken and the Paneer Tikka Lal Mirch.  The Butter Chicken definitely lived up to its reputation.  Deeeelicious.  The Paneer was also good; the chili spices gave the cheese a nice kick.

For dessert, we tried the apricot kulfi and Joe had a Chai tea.  I was told the Chai was flavorful.  The kulfi was served in a unique cone shape and was a perfect ending to the meal.  One of the bussers confirmed the deliciousness of the dessert :-)

The waitstaff was accommodating when they were at the table, but our waiter was absent for long periods of the time.  I think he told another table that they were short two waitstaff.  But for the opening day, it was pretty smooth.  I've definitely witnessed worse.  The bussers were very attentive to clearing plates and our waters were always promptly refilled.  

The food was good.  The atmosphere was nice.  The waitstaff was diligent.  So why three stars?  The price.  Too expensive.  I can name several other nearby fairly upscale Indian restaurants that are not as pricey.  I guess that the prices reflect the location and the modern decor.  

Will I go back?  Sure, if someone else is paying.
author: Jory R.

description:
Whoa - my credit card was overcharged at this restaurant, so thinking it was an innocent error (?), I called the restaurant and spoke to the manager.  
He did not apologize once, which was bad enough, but he told me that he would refund the difference back to my card.

This was over two months ago.  I have yet to see any refund.

I'll make sure to update this entry if I ever see the money.  In the meantime, I say FRAUD.
author: Samantha W.

description: I simply LOVE this place! Everything I've tried is delicious but I am a big fan of the butter chicken. OMG so good! Dinner is pricey, but they also have a buffet lunch that you can try.
author: Gabriela L.

description: I had high expectations and I left being a little disappointed in the food.  The restaurant is beautifully decorated and the service is great...but the food is a little bland and over priced.  I've had much better food at Indian dives and at those big quirky Indian buffets you can find in the valley.  The butter chicken had tomato sauce in it which I found strange.  Maybe the food is flavored for a more Western audience.  I had hoped it would have been better.
author: Kari S.

description:
This place has good food: I will give it that much.

But beware the invitations to eat lunch here from your coworkers and peers of a more spendthrift bent. They won't tell you how much it will cost at the end. I really wasn't interested in spending $30 on lunch, but was caught unawares by the lure of a nice time out with the office-folk.

We could have gone to Naan and Curry and I would have been a lot happier. What's with people getting a kick out of spending 3-4x what they should for their food? Save it for a more meaningful occasion...
author: Nicholas F.

description: Brunch Buffet, it is delicious. I love a buffet style well who doesn't but with Indian it is even more of a treat. I have never had the same tika masala in all these years. Amber is about luxury and for Sunday Brunch they include a mimosa and plenty to choose from with a variety of meats and veggie dishes. A good sign to me is when Indian People are actually eating at the Indian restaurant, and there were plenty of  them young well dressed couples and families - think bring the folks here- enjoying the sun downtown.  Clearly they know well prepared Indian food and so will you if you go. The vibe is just this side of hotel but 20 bucks is easily well spent on a Saturday with all the places to go to walk off your indulgence.
author: crystal j.

description:
After people calling me out for being too harsh on this place in my first review I decided to come back here Saturday night for a cocktail. My friend and I sat at the bar, which has some pretty cool lighting going on. I can see this becoming a place to grab an expensive cocktail for the conference goers and tourists that are in town, it's got a good location and the drinks were pretty stiff.

It was around 11pm when our drinks arrived and the place was pretty empty. My Manhattan was pretty good although it was a bit on the pricey side, considering there are other options nearby. When we first sat down there was no music but some did come on towards the end of our visit, hopefully they'll keep the music going since it did make the place feel less sterile. We were informed that they'll be having a DJ on certain nights in the near future, it'll be interesting to see how that might impact the ambiance of the restaurant which is definitely within earshot.

The service was definitely better than my last visit but we were asked rather directly to tell our friends about the place, I tend to prefer when restaurants/bars just focus on a good product and service rather than trying to pitch me on promoting their establishment.

I'm still hesitant to go back here for dinner due to the terrible service we received last time. I ate at Osha last night and it was just the polar opposite of Amber in terms of service...our water glasses were never empty, we got our meal promptly, etc. etc.

I hope Amber gets better but after two trips it's just not making the cut for it to become a regular haunt of mine.
author: Bryan B.

description: Great Indian buffet lunch.  Great to do every quarter.
author: Paul M.

description: Rude hostess; everything else about dining experience was great.
author: V R.

description:
Loved it loved it, loved it!
Finally they have opened in San Francisco and I got my fix last night. No other place does the butter chicken and the dal makhani like these guys. The lamb biryani was really special too.
The wait staff is very nice and warm.
I am a sucker for Indian food and I am glad that I can enjoy it on a date with my honey in such a beautiful setting.
Highly recommended.
author: Elsa T.

description:
Okay I JUST had dinner here after getting some shopping done at Nordstrom.  Ever since my last trip and going to Amber in Santana Row, I have been looking forward to come to this new location on my next trip up.  Last time I was up here was April to May this year and I was literally standing there saying... "Open Open Open!" like those Mervyn's commercial.  

Before I start my full review, this place only get 1 to 1.5 stars at most for food and 1 extra star only because service here was pretty good.

Finally they opened a few months ago and we needed to grub around the mall since it was getting late.  We were seated immediately.  The decor of this locations is much more hip and chic than the one in Santana Row, but I prefer the decor of the one in Santana Row because of their starry ceiling.  It's a little too red for me at the bar and the dining space was too crowded.  The servers kept bumping into my sister or the table, which gets points deducted.

I have decided that their appetizers are not very good overall in either location.  We had the fried sun-dried tomato and goat cheese appetizer that barely had any cheese.  It was very heavily flavored but lacking.  I told my sister I really wanted this appetizer because how can you say No to FRIED CHEESE! ^_^ Boy was I let down.  Then the server highly highly recommended the shrimp appetizer that is specially prepared in banana leaves with coconut, cashew, almonds, and more as a sauce.  We thought this was a little better than the other appetizer but not by much.  The flavor was so-so but nothing that blew my mind away.

For our entree we both wanted the Frontier Lamb.  It's what really made the whole meal last time and why I gave them a highly coveted 5 stars for the other location despite horrible service.  I was SOOOOO DISAPPOINTED! My sister's lamb came out decent, half flavorful and half dry... the one they set in front of me was SCORCHED! BLECH! All the pieces had no meat and was burnt to a charcoal crust.  I wanted to send it back, but they said to keep it and they will make me 2 more pieces.  DUDE! The dish was not even that edible.  They should have given me a whole new order! Boo!

So began the debate... what's more important... the taste of food or service?  Of course both really matter, but at the end of the day ... the Taste is what's most important! I mean why do we pay for good service if the food sucks?  Of course in a perfect world we could have both being spectacular, but that rarely happens.  The people who worked at this location are MUCH NICER than the one on Santana Row, but the food was not tasty at all! If I ever go back, it will be to the Santana Row location despite questionable service.  

To give an even better idea of how bad the lamb was... I couldn't even eat it! My quote came from the title of my post on the Santana Row location... my new one that I will write soon will have to be... Mary's Lamb Died in Vain! The rack of lamb was almost burned beyond recognition.  =*(
author: Kat L.

description: Yum yum yum...thus far my favorite Indian eatery in SF. The palak chaat, dungeness ginger crab and pesto naan were my favorite. Nice ambiance and service was fast and friendly. Do yourself a favor and EAT HERE!
author: Robin J.

description:
I'm rarely in this neighborhood. I'm rarely impressed by anything in this neighborhood. But, on my way back to BART, I needed a drink.

What a beautiful bar. Over-the-top, yes, with the backlit marble, changing lights, and ultra-modern couches. But the liquor selection was excellent. One Old Raj martini, dry, please. Generous, well-made, with friendly service. Didn't try, or even inquire about, the restaurant.

Oh yeah, and the fact that the bartender shared tastes of the promotional bottles of wine he was evaluating didn't hurt, either.
author: Matt R.

description: Fancy place to sit and chat with your friends.  The bartenders are lost.  They make you wait.  Take your order.  15 minutes later, they tell you they can't make your drink because they don't have the ingredients.
author: Byron L.

description: Went here on New Year's Eve.  We were a bit pressed for time as we had a concert to get to in an hour.  I was worried when it took the waiter a long time to get to our table.  Once they were aware of the time crunch they got our FABULOUS lamb chops, eggplant dish, and kabob appys to us very fast.  If not for the initial wait at the table I would give them 5 stars.  I highly recommend trying their delicious Indian cuisine.
author: Tom P.

description:
Food: The food was delicious, it's a buffet and I don't usually like buffets but since im new to Indian food it was great because I got to try lots of different things. Curries were yummy, not overbearing, lots of spices--the food is prepared well and presented beautifully for a buffet. They have a pretty good selection, things I particularily liked were the catfish, lamb curry, potato fritters, and kidney bean cake. oOoO they had a spinach and mushroom thing too. The only thing I didn't like was the lemonade--this place is kind of healthy so it tasted like lentil seed was in the lemonade or something. I tried the Kesari Rasmalai dessert (soft poached homemade cheese dumpling in saffron flavored light milk syrup) it tasted weirdd like spongy! I like weird tho so alls good. They have buffet from 1130-230 on weekdays so you can def. find time to squeeze in. 

Service: Service was friendly and they left you alone to eat (a plus, I hate when waiters keep bugging you to "service" you). When we asked for bread the second time, the girl took kind of long and we finished it without it by the time we came. Ohwell. 

Ambience: A very classy place, upstairs there is a lounge/bar area that is beautifully lit (more so probably at night) its away from the hustle and bustle of downtown. A nice place for a business lunch or with friends. Id be depressed if i came here by myself  :'(
author: Amy S.

description:
The guys from work (who are Indian) love to hit Amber for lunch, so that recommendation, combined with a craving for Indian food, combined with the need for a first date idea brought me here on a Thursday night.  

We had started with a couple drinks in the bar area and dug the atmosphere so much that we decided to just eat there.  Went with the butter chicken, tandoori ajwaini salmon, and some regular naan.  All were phenomenal.  The mango sauce was absolutely perfect for the salmon and if you like salmon, it's a must-try.  

At $20 per most entrees it seems pricey for Indian, which is probably why most are going 4-stars here.  At lunch, it's a much better value.  But either way, Amber's a hit for great Indian food in a nice atmosphere.
author: John H.

description:
Yes, there is cheaper (a lot cheaper) and better Indian food in the Bay Area. And no, the food does not have the same glorious flavor that the food in Pakwan does. But they do have lobster on the menu - and I have not seen that on an Indian menu in the Bay Area. Have you?

I think the restaurant goer definitely needs to go with the right set of expectations - its going to be expensive and its not going to taste like your favorite road side dhabha between Patiala and Delhi or for that matter your mom's cooking. With that in mind, the cocktails are stiff, the staff is friendly and the food is decent.
author: Abhi S.

description:
So I just had a very enjoyable meal here. Still, only 3 stars because it is really expensive for what it is.
The good:
-the space is really nice. I didn't notice any problems getting to the back room where they seated us. We were given a table for 6 for the 4 of us, so had a nice roomy space.
 - the service was warm and friendly. from the moment we walked in we were treated well. our server was nice. my water glass was refilled. dishes were cleared between courses and i didn't feel like we waited too long (my dining companions felt we waited too long for our drinks to arrive; I personally didn't notice. It definitely didn't feel like it'd been open for less than a week.
- the butter chicken was GOOD. we've had it at their other Amber India locations and it held up here. We also had a really nice fish dish. 

the not as good
- charges for naan and rice.
- the lamb dish was ehh
- prices were way out of wack especially compared with other locations. we'd be better of bringing home takeout from the mt. view location.

So given all the economical indian restaurants in SF I likely won't be hurrying back here. But I did have a really enjoyable meal and would encourage anyone to give it a try.
author: Margie L.

description: Aloo Peas Samosas were pretty small and pretty good. We enjoyed ourselves overall and its a great family-style dinner.
author: Lil R.

description:
Holy Cow! (Oh how appropriate since there is no cow served on the menu).  I started off with a Vodka Zen drink... kinda sweet, but very interesting.  My friend had the lychee and that was better.

We ate everything... sea bass, shrimp appetizer, eggplant something or other... honestly, I can't even remember what we ordered, but the food was sooo delicious, service excellent, and ambience beyond intriguing.  Invited a group of 6 who were in town for a conference.  

Experience was fantastic.  Recommended by a Pharmaceutical Rep who takes a lot of doctors out to great restaurants.  Thumbs up!
author: Kim J.

description: Excellent introduction for a recent fan of Indian cuisine.
author: Oswaldo L.

description:
Best Indian food in San Francisco. Having grown up in India, this is the Indian food experience I've craved for for almost 10 years. And its here finally.

Incredible food, top-notch ambience, wonderful music, yummy cocktails that pair extremely well with the delightful food. A beautiful space with entrance right opposite the Jewish museum.  The bar area is 2nd to none with beautiful decor as well, a perfect spot for drinks after work.
author: Bharat J.

description: Took my team here for lunch. If I hadn't been driving with someone who had been here before, not sure I would have found it. It's nestled just off of Market. The space is absolutely beautiful and the smell as you walk in is intoxicating! We opted for the buffet lunch. I usually avoid buffets, but this one was well done - everything was perfectly cooked, looked deliciously, and (most importantly) still hot. Highlights were the saffron rice, dal, tandoori chicken, and grilled basa. The service was spotty, but the food was absolutely delicious!
author: Eme L.

description: I've been here a few times and will definitely come back. The food is great and service is decent as well. I've never had to wait long for a table. I like their appetizer and dessert options as well - they make for a full meal. The downside is that it's kind of pricey for indian food ($20). I like the lunch buffet style option because it gives you a ton of variety. Another downside is that for moderate (5 or 6+) sized groups you'll have to pay an 18% gratuity (which is normal when you think about it but considering that you're self-serving, it seems a bit excessive).
author: Tushar K.

description: I always come here when someone else is paying, so I eat my fill and have zero complaints!
author: Lisa T.

description: Although Amber is on the pricier side, it definitely is worth it.  Everything is divine.    I have gone back countless times for the Idli Manchurian and Baluchi Chicken.  My entire family loves Amber, so I am a regular customer and will continue to be so.
author: Sonia M.

description: Love this place!!! Great food, service and ambiance! Most of our order was delish! One item was a little to hot/spicy for us and they took care of us...suggesting we try a different dish at no charge. We will definitely try them out again!
author: Shannon R.

description: Butter chicken is bomb!  Also try the sea bass. But what really is the best is their service, from water being refilled meticulously to the manager coming up to check on us and thank us for our business. Best Indian food in the city.
author: Angelika R.

description:
Dined at Amber two days ago in a group of twelve, so I think my service comments should carry some weight.  The service was fine.  Our waitress was able to describe the minute differences between Butter Chicken and Chicken Tikka Masala, even though the latter wasn't on the menu.  She was very friendly, and tended to us well.  We were a large and ungainly (figuratively, not literally) group, and Amber handled us with ease :-)

And the food?  Incredible; I just didn't want the meal to end.  Best Indian food in SF, similar to how the Mt. View location garners a "Best Indian Food in the Valley" rating time after time.  GREAT Butter Chicken!

The only significant, unavoidable downside is the price, and this is what is holding back the five star rating.  $23 is what you pay for fairly small dishes.  That being said, we ate family style and the bill was only $42 a person, drinks included.  Not bad at all for the best Indian food in the city at a high end location with great decor.
author: Nate H.

description: I came here to celebrate a friend's baby's first rice ceremony. We had the backroom to ourselves and enjoyed the Saturday buffet brunch. There was a wide variety of choices for their buffet, and everything was fresh and delicious..My favorites were the orange roughy and the tandoori chicken. I normally stay away from buffets but would definitely go back to Amber India again.
author: Mimi T.

description: Have enjoyed every meal here.  Even have had two parties here and the room is well situated to have quiet time with team...
author: Flip F.

description:
Amber had the best restaurant-Indian food I have had since I can remember.

I was part of a private party with a prefix so of course the service was fantastic.

I'll speak for the food, though - they attended to every dietary concern of everyone in the party, and the food was fabulous. Everything was creatively presented and left me satisfied.

Recs: palaak chat (fried spinach), sprouted moong salad, aloo samosa, butter chicken, and dal.

Cocktails were strong and good too.
author: Lina L.

description:
My husband took me to Amber for my official birthday, because the previous night on my real birthday, there was a misunderstanding and he didn't realize that the WHOLE WEEKEND is my birthday and he was supposed to be being nice the WHOLE WEEKEND. Instead it was something more like ahole weekend.... anyway, back on topic. 

We parked at 5th and Mission per the recommendation of the phone agent, a little far for my shoes, but doable. 

We were greeted by the manager who remembered us from their other locations, and he made sure we got a really nice booth seat by the window. 5 stars.

The ambiance was very elegant but not stuffy. No kitschy Indian stuff, more clean and simple, and the bar area was really stylin'. 4 stars (would be 5 if it were just a tad bit more eclectic, I like crazy shit)

The service was 5 star. The waitstaff were bubbly and friendly and always made sure we weren't waiting for anything, had full glass of water, and were really well trained in the ingredients and  flavor nuances of the food. They seemed to have a genuine passion for the food, but the restaurant has only been open 2 weeks, so i guess they're not sick of it yet. 

The grub. Galouti kebabs. OMG, they are soooo amazing. Simple and a little herby, and absolutely tender as can be. If you think you don't like lamb, you haven't tried these. The chutneys were fantastic as well. 5 stars. 

Everyone orders the butter chicken, because it has always rocked. I have to give it 4 stars though because the chicken wasn't cut carefully and I got 2 nasty pieces of gristle/bone in my gravy. As a reformed vegetarian, this ruins my whole week.  

The Amber Dal is really delicious 5 stars, and the paneer dish was tasty, but had a very thai/chinese flavor because of the bell peppers so 3 stars on that (well prepared, just not my personal fave). 

Rasmalai, hard to go wrong, and they were even able to leave off the pistachios, which I am allergic to. The dumpling wasn't quite as tender as some other places, but it was still delicious. 4 stars.

Wine and sommelier, 5 stars. Great choices that were reasonably priced by SF standards. The sommelier came out and gave us a nice history of the geography and climate of the region our wine came from which was really fun. 

Overall, this is a fantastic restaurant, with delicious food and great service. I'm sure in no time flat it's going to be hard to get a seat on a Saturday night, so go now, before all the tourists find out about it.
author: Darcy V.

description:
After much suspect, Amber India finally opened their San Francisco location.  I had frequented their Mountain View site, which is way too inconvienent for me.  Considering that I work in the Financial District, and I am often entertaining lunch guests, Amber India has been my "second home".

It's nice to have everyone recognize you when you walk into the door, and it's always comforting to have consistently good food and service.  

I've also enjoyed celebrated dinners here, and my guests have found the cocktails to be most magical. 

The lunch buffet is an absolute bargain.  Because of it's great selection and reasonable price, it is a very good way for an "Indian-food-virgin" to get acquainted with some Northern Indian cuisine.
author: L L.

description: We showed up at five minutes to six and were able to be seated immediately, The staff was very friendly and willing to offer some suggestions. The Butter Chicken was Awesome, just the right seasoning without being greasy or too spicy. My wife ordered the Lamb Biryani, They prepare it in a copper pot and use the Naan to create a cover which perfectly keeps the rice and lamb moist. Our waitress was very friendly and helpful, the entire meal was above and beyond our expectations. Get there early as the place fills up quickly.
author: Neal R.

description:
I attended a lovely "Sari Soiree" at Amber last night, and was pleasantly surprised (the other patrons may also have been pleasantly surprised to see a group of sari-clad Desi girls adding some "authenticity" to the quasi-Indian atmosphere -- I was wondering if they sent us the Indian waiter because we were all in traditional garb).

I admit I was a bit skeptical about this place prior to dining here. I knew the vibe would be "hip" and the food would be "Indian fusion" but I didn't have high expectations for the taste. Luckily, the menu was extensive and everything we tried was yummy. I really loved the goat cheese and sundried tomato tikkis, and the daal was bomb. The paneer manchurian appetizer was also delicious.

Amber's drink menu was also pretty cool, though expensive. Actually, everything at Amber was expensive (think $8-$10 desserts) but oh-so-tasty. Tres Bombay. Service was very friendly, but kind of slow.

I'd love to go back, but even more so if somebody else was paying.
author: Vandana M.

description:
I had to try it again. This time I didn't eat all day and then went for dinner so I was hungry. I didn't think it was possible but I loved it even more than the first time. I had to order the lamb chops again, and what I love about Amber is they give you a full rack of lamb. I went to Dosa last week and for the same price I got 2 small lamb chops. At Amber it is something on the order of 9...it is a huge. The chops are truly amongst the most savory and delicious cuts of meat I've ever had.
I also noticed the Samosas are served in quantities of 4. Every other Indian place I've ever been to serves 2. 
I had to have the Dal again and it was as good as before. Along with some galric nan to soak it up, this was worthy of The Last Supper. This may be my number one pick of all time, out of all places I have reviewed. I can't wait to go back.
author: Matt H.

description: Amazingly tasty bhindi was the best, dal makhani is for real. They know how to make tasty indian food. Love this place will keep going there.
author: Vibhu B.

description: I love, love, love Amber Indian! I gave them 5 stars instead of 4 because I have been there many, many times and the food and service is consistently excellent. I always look forward to Amber Indian and highly recommend.
author: Miss B.

description:
I love Amber India's buffet.  I've been to it three times in the past year and it never disappoints.   All the items have a depth of flavor that you just don't find at other Indian restaurants.  The only "dish" that I haven't been impressed by is the naan bread.
