The restaurant interior is beautiful.  I've found the service to always be attentive.

Going to Amber India is such a special treat!
author: Juliana S.

description: BUTTER CHICKEN! So tasty. definitely have to be willing to splurge when coming here but the food is rich and authentic. Try the buffet price, I have found it well worth the $16.95.
author: Caitlin R.

description: Very nice and fancy place. Food is very good.
author: Pratik T.

description:
One reviewer, below, who posted on 12/9/2008 reports the Amber lunch buffet price at $16.95 - not $19.95 which is what I paid.  If that's correct, then I'll happily up it a star, from 3 to 4 stars.  (The difference being half a glass of wine, which anyone with sense would want to enjoy in that lovely room!).

What's the story, Amber?  Is lunch $16.95 or $19.95?  Big difference in how the value is perceived by those of us not on expense accounts!  

At $16.95 I'm far more likely to come 3 or 4 times a month.  (Even if I'm not allowed to take home my leftovers, grumble...).  

Anyone have any info on the "true price" of the buffet lunch at Amber?
author: Juliana C.

description: Seriously finding this place took an effort. It was raining and google map gave me a wrong direction. My friends and I were lost in a very sketchy alley and turns the place was at the other side of the building behind Starbucks. When were were there, i was at first surprised because you could only see the bars and i was a little scared because of the limited seats. Turns out they have another floor where it is for dining.....THANK GOD. I love the atmosphere and ambiance. Its very romantic, dark and warm. I ordered the butter chicken and it was amazing. You better combine it with the rotis to make it more flavorful. For dessert, it was kind of interesting because i had the bread pudding and it was a very different taste than the usual....i wouldn't say its the best but i like how its different compared to the usual kind of bread pudding.
author: Cavin T.

description:
On their first week of opening, four on the floor baby. This place is going to be a hot spot in weeks to come. The food is Top Notch, the service is professional and friendly, and the drinks are as good as they sound. 

I can't wait to bring family from out of town to a HIgh End Indian Bistro. Don't get me wrong, I love the many mom and pop shop Indian Restaurants around this city, but checkered table cloths and plastic cups are for the Wharf.

With their beautiful decor and people first attitude, Amber is going to do more than just fine. 

Fine work to all the staff!
author: Mr. M.

description:
I've been waiting a long time for Amber India to open, being a long time fan of their Mountain View location.

I went today with a large group from work to have the lunch buffet.  Although it is pricey (19.95/person for lunch buffet), the food is fantastic.

The butter chicken is as good as it is at the sister restaurant in MV.  As a bonus, the selection is much bigger than MV location, and I would say that the quality of the food is better as well.

The chutneys are awesome - the pineapple cumin raita is so good.  My friend made me go back for the fried catfish dish, which was excellent as well.

I didn't try everything - there's too much - but the only dissapointment was the paneer with shittake mushroom - I thought it was a bit bitter.  But the dal, the paneer dish, some of the veggie dishes, and of course, the butter chicken were all very tasty.

This will have to be a new destination if I have vendors taking me out.  :-)  I can't afford to eat like this too often (nor can my waistline afford it).
author: Bill V.

description:
2 stars for the ambiance...

The food was good (we had the Butter Chicken and the Paneer Tikka Lal Mirch) however you can find similar quality food in the city for about a quarter of the price. 

The cocktails were a bit - much. I ordered the Acai Berry Caipirinha - it came out pretty much all cachaca, with no acai berry. In hindsight I should have sent it back -lesson learned.

I'm not sure I would return as there are so many other great Indian food options in the city for a fraction of the price.
author: Summer C.

description: I'm kinda a foodie person. I've eaten Indian food from Philly to PDX! This is by far the best Indian Restaurant I've been to... If you ever go to San Francisco this is a must eat!!!
author: Joe C.

description: Excellent Indian food but with expected higher prices. Portions are adequate.  Service was fine.
author: Len J.

description: What I got wasn't worth the money. 4 little piece of circle balls which was suppose to be chicken for 10.00! Plus another 2.95 for rice! I was out 15 bucks and hungry again by 3pm. Lunch was at 12pm! They were suppose to be kabobs but came diffrently. It looks like the buffet is really popular though and older guy who was the hostess was really nice and warned me that I should do the buffet to go.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Get a grip people.  You cannot fairly review a place until it has been open a couple of months.  Geeze its like some of you couldn't wait to have this place open just so you could tear it down in your review!
Now I am being unfair to give them 4 stars  but hey...I would rather up the stars and be clueless than give them one star for not having everything up to par on opening night. 
****NEWSFLASH:  opening night is almost always crap, and so are the first couple of weeks or even months!  You try opening a restaurant and making it perfect right off the bat!
I will check out Amber in a couple of months and may very well change my rating.  I suggest you one-star raters be open minded and consider doing the same! Dayum!
author: Suzanne L.

description:
4 for food and ambiance. 2 for price.

- Butter Chicken ($19.95) - can't go wrong with this one. Butter Butter Butter cream and tomato sauce. Great on rice or for dipping.
- Seabass Kokum Curry ($24.95) - a dark brown sauce with coconut milk, little chunks of sea bass are cooked in it. Sauce didn't stand out.
- Palak ke Kofte ($14.95) -  spinach dumplings filled with cranberry and almond. Liked this one for its uniqueness but you only get about 5 dumplings so you don't feel like you get very much.
- Lamb Chop Frontier ($28.95) - rack of lamb that the group liked a lot. Gamey I hear. Served with tasty yogurt raita with little walnut pieces.
- Asparagus Cauliflower Balchao ($14.95) - greatly lacking in cauliflower, the sauce was more tart.
- Bombay Bohri Biryrani ($20.95) - large chunks of chicken flavored the rice with spices. Tasty but wished for more rice given the price of this side dish.
- Bread Basket ($11.95) - Mutter Kulcha (filled with peas and potato), Lacha Paratha (made with whole wheat), Naan - I've had better breads that were bigger and fluffier.
- Pappad ($2.75) - Lentil crepes that serve as chips for picking up sauces. Typically free in other restaurants.

Honestly biggest beef (pun intended) with Amber is the price. Food was good but really could get the same flavors in places a third of the cost. Granted atmosphere is way better - friendly attentive service, beautiful venue, and plenty of seating. Those are the trade offs I guess.

Tip: bring gum for after the meal! Very key if you're here on a date.
author: Cindy W.

description: I love..love this place. My husband and I drive 2 1/2 hours to eat here...plus we love a trip to the city. The butter chicken is to die for and the amber dual is a fav as well!  Everything we have had here is YUMMY!!!! We have had great Indian food in South America...this place always reminds us of that!
author: Ann S.

description: Love this place. The food here has never disappointed us. We have tried the chicken appetizers, butter chicken, vegetable kofta and biryani. They have all been great and consistent. The ambiance is great and I highly recommend it.
author: Al K.

description:
F***ing DELICIOUS.

Ambiance is on point. 

Service was great. 

Theres nothing more I can say about this place....

STRAIGHT CRACK!!!!!

5 Stars. Fast.
author: Cam K.

description:
The food and ambiance were fantastic, however, the lounge service left something to be desired.  

We arrived without a reservation on a Saturday night.  The hostess said the wait was 20 minutes, so we headed to the bar.  After 15 minutes of sitting in the lounge, we had to ask a cocktail server to take our order and waited another 15 minutes for the drink themselves.  The service in the lounge was long and the server was rude. 

That being said, once we were seated in the dining room, the service and food were excellent.  We ordered Badam Bhara Baingan (baby eggplants), Arbi ke Kofte (Taro dumplings), garlic chive naan and regular naan.  The Badam Bahara Baingan was simply devine; the flavors were intense, leaving a nice kick at the end.  I would come back for this dish alone. Arbi ke Kofte was lovely and the sauce was rich and buttery (great for dipping naan).  

I would definitely recommend this restaurant if you're looking for a trendy ambiance and excellent food, just make a reservation and be proactive in the lounge. :)
author: Amanda B.

description:
i went there on a tuesday night....for the first time.
The restaurant is very close to the Westfield mall in SF. It was very classy and elegant. The restaurant is huge and also has a bar area. The decor is beautiful and relaxing. The place is packed with Business people.

I went with two other friends.
We started with the Palak Chaat, which i was a little skeptical about at the beginning. However, it was delicious, and the way they made it was excellent. I ordered the Badam Baigan ( eggplant) , which was topped with almonds and gravy. IT WAS ABSOLUTLY DELICIOUS. i HAVE NEVER TASTED BAIGAN LIKE THIS ANYWHERE ELSE. IT'S TO DIE FOR. The gravy was sweet and spicy and melts in your mouth. They order Butter chicken and Panee tikka masala wiht rice and some naan.

We order some drinks and desert. The whole experience was nice.
The service was really pleasant and friendly. They really pay attention to details.

I think it's pricey and would go only for an occasion. It's not an everyday thing.
I would recommend it to anyone who wants to make they day special.

Especially for a date...lol
author: Sonia D.

description: This chain is the best Indian in the Bay Area, hands down.  This location gets 4 stars instead of 5 because you pay up for that privilege, unlike the bargain you get at the Mountain View location.
author: Mike G.

description: Dedinately a great Indian spot. Lunch buffet is tastey. Service is good.
author: Simon B.

description: Nice Indian restaurant with a good ambience. The food was excellent and with very attentive service. It was that good that I went twice within 4 days as i enjoyed the food that much during my short trip in SF. Highly recommended.
author: Chris W.

description:
Sorry for the belated review. Went here with 3 friends who were new to Indian food. I wanted to sample another North Indian restaurant in the city.

Location: it was a rainy Saturday, so I was glad I got to BART in to Montgomery or Powell. It is easy to pass by, but it's near the ROSS. Tip for GPS users: don't input the address, as it may give you Yerba Buena Island.

Decor: very nice, the bar area was very suave and chill. Had a nice TV to show college football. The red decor is very romantic, so great for couples. The seats were very comfortable, although you have to go downstairs. 

Service: the servers were friendly and got us seated right away. They explained the dishes and made great suggestions.

The food: the entrees were great. We started with the standard appetizer fare: pappad and samosas. The samosas were smaller than normal, which actually is good since it doesn't kill your appetite before entree-time. I ordered the tandoori chicken(half). Pretty above average taste for the chicken, but didn't stand out in particular. Even though it came out sizzling from the oven, it didn't have as much zing even with the lemon and peppers. 

I noticed more seafood items than normal, and vegetarian items which are both pluses in my book. I actually prefer the latter while my friends really liked the salmon tikka and sea bass. We ordered the Bombay Bohri Biryani, which was a tasty chicken & rice dish(really tasted the saffron in that). Top that off with naan and the meal was complete.

Overall: I would give this place a higher mark, but I thought for the pricey dishes, the quality wasn't as great as I thought it would be. Having said that, the restaurant is great for a date or intimate dinner. Great service, and I really like the location if you're spending a nite in the city near Embarcadero/SOMA. There is a good variety of seafood, chicken, and vegetarian dishes for you to try and/or bring family/friends. However, if you wanted to introduce someone to North Indian food that's not too pricey, I'd probably go to Roti or Maharani.
author: Neil N.

description:
Is the food good here?  Yeah, it's pretty good.  I had the eggplant, good sauce, not super oily like a lot of Indian food can be.  But is it worth $30 per person without drinks, HELL NO!  

Perhaps restaurants like New Ganges, Pakwan, Shalimar and the like have spoiled me, but I can get good Indian food for under $10.  Is it worth it to pay triple for the nicer environment?  I'm not really sure.

However, I will be returning for happy hour: $3 beer and $5 snacks, count me in!
author: Olivia T.

description:
I enjoy the food at Amber India which is a true compliment because I usually detest the faux Indian restaurants in the Tenderloin. The chef does a great job at balancing spice without overwhelming the underlying meat and vegetables. 

Went there on a Saturday night with a group of 8 - this place is great for group dinners since Indian food is usually eaten family style so its both economical and fun to try different dishes.

Food - 4 stars. We started with the pesto and goat cheese tikkis (3 stars), paneer appetizer (4 stars) and mixed grill (4 stars). Their tandoor (aka barbeque stuff) is consistently good so I recommend it.  For dinner, we tried the daal (heavy on cream so 3 stars), butter chicken (5 stars), kadahi paneer (4 stars), mixed vegetable (2 stars - unappetizing) and Shalgam Nalli (5 stars). The rotis are better value and better tasting that the naan so go for the rotis. The cocktails were great but I was disappointed not to be able to sample the wine list. 

Service - 2 stars. Very disappointing for an supposedly upscale restaurant. Server didn't show up for 20 minutes after being seated and only after we had to ask the hostess to send the server to get our drink orders. The food showed up pretty quickly but the service was unimpressive. Server was efficient but did not offer any recommendations or help with the menu. Post dinner, it was another 20 minute wait for the check. Clouded an otherwise enjoyable experience. 

Ambiance - 4 stars. Modern with comfortable seating. Noise level is appropriate. I like the decor and the mezzanine bar area which is inviting for happy hour. 

Would go again but hope, hope, hope they improve the service.
author: Rumesha A.

description: We were in downtown on a Sunday afternoon andcstopped by for early lunch. We got a table in the caffe section right away even thogh we had a 3 months old baby with us. We ordered one from each of their aoetizerd and everything was great. The stufg friendly, the place was quite and the food came super fast. Reason for not giving five star rating is the price of food. This is tasty indian fusion, but nothing out if this world. Not difficult to make traditional flavors, but more like regular fusion cuisine with a touch of art.
author: Laura S.

description:
probably the best indian food i've had in the city. great cocktails, and the food was amazing. the butter chicken practically melted in your mouth and i couldn't get enough of the sauce! the service was great, i loved that it was kind of a dressy atmosphere, and i just had a great dining experience there.
p.s. chai=bomb!
author: Lisa B.

description: The butter chicken is one of the best things i've ever tasted. I like my food extremely spicy, and when it wasn't spicy enough they took it back and make me another one. One time i was there, my cocktail took a couple minutes to come out and they took it off the bill, amazing service, amazing food.
author: Chris W.

description:
Had tried their lunch buffet and found it overpriced for good, but not off the charts, food. Then tried their dinner. Their duck tandoori kebab with caper sauce is off the charts. The lamb roganjosh is the most flavorful I've ever had. The fish kebab, in crushed pepper and yogurt sauce, was amazing. Loved the spinach walnut raita (yes, it isn't traditional, but it is yummy). 

Enjoyed the vegetarian dishes, the korma and the spinach, but not enough to recommend this place to someone who is only going to eat the vegetarian dishes. The value (quality versus price) just isn't there for vegetarians.  As it is, the price is much higher than I usually pay for Indian food.

The dinner service was attentive enough for us to feel comfortable getting in and out in time to see a show at one of the nearby theaters.
author: Vena V.

description: The lounge area is pretty cramped, but yes, drinks fit the standards. The lounge is really just an area to get started. Come here only if you have dinner plans. The ambiance is classy. The food, though, isn't worth the price. It is full of flavor, but no mind-blowing pleasure for the taste buds. Service is prompt. No Jedi servers, but pretty close. It is accessible and in the heart of Downtown SF, which invites traffic. I would expect spicier from and Indian, though.
author: Kara Y.

description:
Crestfallen.

That's how I feel after eating at Amber India - SF.  I have been waiting for five years (really) for Amber to open an SF store.  They kept promising me every year, yes, we're opening a store in San Francisco.  Well, it's open.   :-(

The ambiance is amazing.  They've really made it nice.  And very chichi.  It doesn't feel terribly INDIAN though, which is kinda what you want when you go to an Indian restaurant.  But it's so gorgeous, I'm okay with it.

The waitress we had was over-the-top cheery.  It seemed like everything on the menu was her favorite.  And she kinda went overboard about everything.  Like, instead of asking what kind of naan we wanted (plain), she proceeded to list all six naan options.  But I guess it's not just what she said, but how it was delivered.  Like a newly minted Bennigan's waitress.  (And I used to wait at Bennigan's so I KNOW).

The food was disappointing.  While the shrimp salad was fantastic, the butter chicken just wasn't the same (the "same" being the most amazing dish on the planet served at Amber India - Mountain View).  The vegetable korma lacked taste as well.  And both my date and I left with stomach aches.  

Overall, is it the worst Indian food around?  Nah.  But my expectations were high, so I feel particularly bummed.  

---------------------------------
For the City's BEST Indian food, visit Shalimar at Polk and Pine.
author: Scott W.

description: Great food, good service how ever when visiting with a service animal (Guide Dog) we were told we could not sit in the main dining room even though we had reservations.  We were stuck in a corner table in a walkway watching all the staff going in and out of the kitchen.   So if you are vision impaired or have sympathy for those needing assistance I would recommend finding another restaurant which would not be too difficult given all the wonderful places to eat in San Francisco.
author: Thomas R.

description:
So we went to the Press Club (which is right across the alley) and thought we could grab dinner with all of the yummy wine they were serving, but we were mistaken. Since we were still hungry, we ran across the alley for an appetizer and YES, another cocktail.  We shared the butter chicken, naan and each had fabulous mixed drink.    

It was really good.  The butter chicken was rich and chicken was tender.  I highly recommend this place and will definitely be back again.
author: A L.

description:
It was almost a five star review for Amber except for the fact that I went during their lunch buffet and they assumed that we were there for the buffet.  We didn't know to just get up and serve ourselves, and one of us did not know if we were going to eat the buffet.  We kind of twiddled our thumbs for a while until we figured that we should just get up and grab stuff.

I went to wash my hands before eating and the bathroom was clean, well maintained, and smelled wonderful.  Always a good sign.

I had EVERYTHING in the buffet.  The fish, the lamb, the buttered chicken, the tandoori chicken, lentils, basmati rice; etc.  It was all done very well and I wish I had a slightly larger table so I could chow down.  Although, I felt a little bit not at ease to do that in such a beautiful, clean place.  

It was all delicious.  After stuffing my face, I grabbed dessert, which was their vermicelli pudding and tandai brulee (spelling?).  The pudding was better to me because it was not as sweet as the brulee, but both were good.  

I will definitely be returning (maybe a less inhibited next time), and if you like Indian food you'll definitely love Amber.  It's a little bit pricier than your standard Indian restaurant, but it's worth every single penny.
author: Wilson K.

description:
My husband and I went to Amber India for their lunch buffet to celebrate a big event. We didn't have a reservation, but the hostess was friendly and was able to find us good seating. 

The food was okay. I've had much better, but it wasn't terrible here. They had plenty of vegetarian options on the buffet, and enough options for my meat-eating husband as well. They do cater to the Americanized palate, with butter chicken and Mimosas. Don't expect it to be authentically good.

The ambiance was nice, but the service wasn't great. My husband's water glass sat empty throughout the entire meal. The table next to us got naan right away, while we got ours with the bill... huh?

I was also disappointed that traditional tea was not included in the buffet, but sparkling wine was. Who the heck expects sparkling wine with their Indian lunch, but not delicious Chai? Maybe if they switched this they could cut back on the expense a bit. 

Bottom line - not worth $45 for a lunch date. They need to work on delivering the same service to every table. We certainly didn't get any, while we watched our neighbors get great service.
author: Zee S.

description: came here for brunch, and almost everything was fantastic.  The pakora and kormas both really stood out for me, but that doesn't mean the other dishes were bad.  The flavors, while all good, are fairly similar.  If during brunch you do like i do, and put everything on 1 plate, you may not notice distinct flavorings between each of the dishes.  It's a minor point though honestly.
author: Phil J.

description:
Had the lunch buffet two days in a row, and both times was very impressed with the food.  Usually the lunch buffet in an Indian restaurant is overcooked, overspiced, with greasy gulab jamun and watery kheer.  Amber India's is completely different.  Food is appropriately spiced (hot, yes, but not overwhelmed with spices) cooked but not to a mush, and the desserts are fantastic. 

What's not so great sometimes is the service.  Lunch is really busy, sometimes they forget you're there.  It happens.
author: Katherine W.

description: Probably the best Indian food I've ever had.   Classy restaurant and service.  It costs a little more than the average Indian restaurant, but you get what you pay for.
author: Richard E.

description:
I ate the lunch buffet with my director the other day. The hostess was very nice and the waiters were quick to bring us drinks (water) The buffet set up was interesting. The plates are by the salad. Indian salad is simple lettuce, onion, cucumber so I skipped it. The chat mix was awesome, onion, garbanzos and other stuff, really good texture. It was a bit odd to have the raita, tumeric and chutneys with the salad before the entrees which I usually top with the sauces. The dishes were complex and quite different than most Indian dishes I have had. I have had many. Some of the unusual flavors worked for me and some did not. 

We finished our food when the naan finally was served, that was a miss. Having worked at an Indian restaurant I know it takes awhile to bake, but it really was a miss. 

The decor, finishes, ambiance is very very pleasant. I will try again and order off of the menu.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Best interesting Bellini ever!  Well, I might even say my favorite cocktail  in the city!  (or at leas pretty close to being my very favorite ;). 

I believe they call their house bellini "Belota", and what's so unique about it is that it's got the licor 43 and fresh strawberries muddled in it.  It's not that sweet either, so you can keep drinking one after another (which I have!).

Me and my friend hung out at their lounge section before sitting down to have our dinner, and I'd have to say that it's a nice comfy lounge and the cocktails are definitely interesting and yummy.

I do also really like their food.  I know that it's pretty pricey for Indian food, but the place is pretty darn classy, great service, and the portions are actually very large!

Their butter chicken sauce is more complex than most I've had, and I think it is definitely one of the best items on the menu.  However, they do have some interesting items that you don't normally see in typical Indian restaurants.
author: Sophia F.

description:
Disclaimer: This review is only about their drinks. 

As far as mixology goes, Amber is one of the best kept secrets in the city. I've tried more or less their entire cocktail/martini menu and I must say their drinks are the bombay (pardun the pun)! They are all made with equal parts of style, creativity and taste.

My favorite drink is the Vespa, a cold and calculated mix of cucumber and schezuan vodkas among other things. It leaves this cool numb aftertaste which I am told is the cucumber (but it could be something else?).

If you want to grab a cocktail somewhere that's not a total scene, choose this place. It's quickly becoming a regular spot for me and my crew.
author: Jonathan H.

description: I don't understand why this place does not have 5 stars -- This is the ALL TIME BEST indian food I have ever had and I have been to India!  Well worth the price and I recommend you ask the server what to order as they know best!  The spices fill your senses from the moment you walk into this restaurant!  I have never been disappointed with any dish and find each new dish to be a new tasting adventure!   If your in San Fran and like Indian food this is a MUST GO to place!
author: Connie R.

description:
One of my favourite places to eat in SF. Yes, it's more expensive than your average Indian, but you get what you pay for. Anyone who says the food is the same needs their taste buds checked - I'm an Indian junky and this is the best Indian food I've had in the US, by leaps and bounds.

If you like duck, fer gawd's sake, get the kebabs...juicy, succulent, tasty, zingy, mouthwatering-heaven. They seem to have trimmed down the menu since last year and my favourite had disappeared - the Murg Nizami (chicken flavoured with cardamom), but after asking the waiter about that, he popped to the kitchen to check with chef and came back to say they had the ingredients to make it and would do so happily. I was a happy camper, as I'm in love with this dish. The BF had the Sea Bass Moilee  - I'm not much of a fish person, but I'd consider ordering this dish for myself...wonderful sauce, and the fish just melted. Accompanying that, we had the Jaipuri Bhindi, probably the best okra dish I've ever had - so many Indian places over here seem to use larger, older okra and somehwat stew them, with the result being stringy and mushy, but not at Amber. 

Yum yum, chocolate bum.
author: Dan L.

description:
Dined there Friday night, 7/11/08.  Ambience/decor very classy. Shrimp salad and chicken asparagus soup appetizers were excellent.  Butter chicken and chicken tikka masala (not listed on menu) very tasty.  Vegetables korma good, but not great.  Naan toasty and moist-- just what you want.  Total bill for 4 people w/ 2 beers and 1 coffee drink= $120.
Waiter was on top of things, but a little too chatty.
Bottom line: If you don't want to pay to be in a nice setting, you can get just as good food up in the Tandooriloin at Pakwan, Chutney or Shalimar, but you will have to step over the junkies to do so.
author: charles g.

description: Went for the lunch buffet, a friend had said they went there with co-workers. Food was good! I like their version of a lot of the menu items! The atmosphere is a little too stuffy for my taste however.  I don't know what it is about upscale restaurants, and the clientele do rich people like snooty people to serve them?  Shouldn't you kiss ass more to that type of clientele?  Lol, oh well I'm not rich so I don't know.  The service was a little too in my face, I think maybe they could have been just bored since it wasn't too busy.  And as I said they were like snooty robots. Don't need to be my bestfriend but lighten up a little staff, you do want us to be there right? Still, the mushrooms were to die for...
author: S F.

description:
Another local restaurant that has slipped. I went for the buffet but it looked like lots of friend and gravied bits of nothing substantial. What happened to the good buffet items? Instead I ordered three appetizers tat looked somewhat South Indian, off f the dinner menu.
Ambience is its strongest point. However the menu has reversed from South Indian to 95% Punjabi, and the quality of the South Indian dishes has taken a nosedive. If the chef can't do them well, PLEASE do us all a favor and remove them.
Masala mixes are tasteless and seem to be several days old; the Malabar shrimp was tasteless. Curried crab appetizer was fairly good - seemed cooked to order. But not a single freshly cooked curry leaf in sight. Instead I got a vague nutty taste of popped whole mustard seeds and spices, but not nearly as fresh tasting as it should be if the vaghar was also cooked to order.
Lamb kebabs were overworked dish. Ironically the lamb itself was very good. The yellow cold stuff "dill sour cream" tasted like pimento cheese - why even include it? It didnt go withthe lamb. The mint sauce and tamarind sauce also didnt go with the "masala" lamb. Very off. A better match would have been a fresh yogurt sauce with a touch of vaghar.
Mango mojito was the best thing.
The chef could try to do less and be less garnish and appearance oriented.  While I understand that SF is still not very South Indian savvy, no one can do everything well. Do less and do it well. Make it taste fresh and eliminate the sauces and pastes made yesterday. We can taste it.  
Lastly please get  the waitstaff to stop walking directly into female customers. And please inform the Maitred at the front what saunff is and what it is for.
author: Nan L.

description:
I'm a long-time fan of the original Amber India, a rich gem hidden away in a strip mall in Mountain View, so I jumped at the chance to try out the new SF location.

The wait staff were still a little nervous about making everything run smoothly, but the service was excellent.  (I didn't realize why they were nervous until I read the reviews of their opening night.)  So it looks like they've quickly pulled things together in the first couple days.

The food was delicious, making no compromises on ingredients.  The butter chicken was excellent, though not as heavenly as I remember it in Mountain View (or perhaps that's just nostalgia?).  The fish kebab was delicate and smooth, and the chicken biryani was more substantial/filling.

The bar area is upscale-loungey and separate from the dining area, perhaps a good nightlife launching point.  The cocktails were tasty (try the bertolli(?)) and the bartender introduced himself to us, bubbling over with enthusiasm, which was a little odd.

The only reason it gets 4 stars instead of 5 is the price.  This might be the best Indian food in the city (I haven't tried enough places yet to judge), but you can easily pay half as much for something almost as good nearby.  Fortunately, I was being treated to dinner this time.
author: Michael M.

description: Just came from a Delicious dinner, with Palak Chatt to the Sea Bass Korma. Although we  thoroughly enjoyed the dinner our waiter "Alldrin" was so very inattentive I could only leave the "Busboy, Chris" a tip. With my name being in the computer from having eaten there so many times, I have never had such bad service. I was really annoyed by the manager having to poke in our dish to see if it was chicken or fish. At those prices one should know what the customer has ordered and not have to have their dish prodded to make out what it was. I will think about driving to Santana Row's Amber next time or at least make sure that "Belinda" our usual waitress is serving us for the meal.
author: Brenda S.

description:
finally tried this place, after waiting about a year for it to open. They're open till 3 for lunch, which is a big plus for me, as I'm usually not ready for lunch until at least 2, which means there are lots of places I simply never connect with. Went this afternoon expecting to order off the menu, but they had a buffet that looked good and offered a chance to graze through a lot of different dishes. I usually avoid buffet anything like the plague, but I'd had the buffet at their San Jose location and it didn't suffer from the usual congealed buffet mediocrity, plus I was curious to try a number of items and at their high prices it would be expensive to sample so many dishes otherwise.

So I did the buffet--$23--and came away stuffed to the gills and very pleased with the food. Everything I tried--at least a dozen items--was carefully and thoughtfully prepared from high quality ingredients. Portions actually on offer on the buffet are small to ensure that they're refreshed often. As you would expect, items made from--ugh--chicken breast are too dry, but only the worst food puritans go for the white meat, so I can't really blame Amber India. Nevertheless, the buffet warned me off of those dishes before I spent $20+ on an entree order.

Even though it was a buffet service was quite attentive--another benefit of lunching late. The decor is generic modern upscale with a pleasant but slightly sterile ambiance a bit better suited to a business lunch than a meal with an intimate.

The buffet is all-you-can-eat and with food of this quality it's possible to do some serious damage, so come when you're hungry and the price won't seem quite so exorbitant.

UPDATE: the last time I went they changed their lunch hours and now close at 2:30 weekdays. Major bummer! But they're still open till 3 for lunch on weekends.
author: Bambooo S.

description: Just wanted to drop a line about the great food and ambiance at the Amber restaurant at Yerba Buena Lane in SFO.  But more than that, Victor and his staff went out of their way to accommodate my mother in her wheelchair and made sure we had the most convenient table for her.  Thank you!
author: Kusum W.

description: Great Indian dinner. We had one appetizer, bowl of tandoori naan, the butter chicken and the sea bass curry. 3 glasses of wine + 4 vodka cranberries(we were on vacation), bill was about $140. Great food but I'm not sure if it's worth the price. Maybe it's because I'm from san diego and there are a ton of indian and middle eastern places here that are just as good and much more inexpensive. But Amber had an excellent atmosphere, convenient location and very friendly hostesses. We walked in here without reservations at 630 on a saturday night and the wait was 25 minutes. We had tried the Tropisueno mexican kitchen a few doors down first, but they kind of scoffed that we didn't have reservations and said the wait was 50 minutes, so this was definitely refreshing to be greeted so nicely at Amber. Our server was very attentive but very quiet. The lounge area was packed and yes you do see quite a few Indian people here which is a great sign.
author: Elika E.

description: Amazing saag paneer.  Butter Chicken was a little too sweet.  Pesto Naan was too good to share.  Tandoori appetizer sampler was a great idea if you are not sure what to get.  The samosas were some of the best I have ever had.  The saffron rice was good too.  Everything had heat, but it wasnt too spicy.  Get the cucumber raita to cool off if you cant take the heat.  It was packed so getting refills was a little slow, but other than that the service was good.
author: Mimi D.

description:
I somehow knew the ratings would be a bit low.  Amber is one of those places you just love to hate.  With overdone decor and overpriced indian food, hater ratings are no surprise.

But I have to say, I like Amber.  The atmosphere is modern without being cold and exotic without being uncomfortable.  The food is pretty good, although very heavy and spicy (read: you won't want to dance afterward).  I'd recommend sitting at the bar and bringing a close friend or two.
author: Zuzzi E.

description: By far one of the best Indian food I have had in the US. The Dal Makhni was amazing and so was the methi chicken. Really authentic North Indian food.
author: Satwik S.

description: I am becoming a fan of Amber. The upstairs bar area is just so pretty, the atmosphere makes me happy. I am serious, it calms me down and cheers me up all in one. The appetizers are great, the wine is too. I love the bartender let me quickly taste to make a decision on my red wine. This is just a sleek, fun place that can  fully feed you and has amazing smells. Heck it has fed me well on appetizers, try and share nothing we ordered was bad. They were incredible.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Summary:
Food, Service and Ambiance: All 5 out of 5

I went here for dinner with my wife today after shopping at the nearby Westfield. Got a reservation on OpenTable quite easily.  As soon as we came in, we were greeted warmly by a gentleman who seated us at a nice booth. The decor of this place is great for any restaurant, it is definitely outstanding for an Indian one. The drinks menu looked extensive; they had a very good wine selection as well. The food menu was an interesting mix of what we usually expect from an Indian place but also had some new dishes and variations on traditional cuisine that looked very "gourmet" style.

Deciding to eat vegetarian today, we had:
Paneer Manchurian appetizer: It was more like a Paneer chilli, but quite delicious.
Kadhai Paneer: Very well done onion-tomato based gravy and the paneer pieces were perfectly soft and delicious.
Vegetable Elaichi Korma: Highlight of our meal. The Elaichi (cardamom?) flavor was distinctly mouth-watering and satisfying in each bite.
Naan and Saffron Rice: Good quality.
Couple of diet sodas.

The service we received was way above what we expected, even at a nice restaurant such as this one. Everyone serving us was polite and attentive. We had requested spicy entrees, and when we thought our entrees were too spicy, they were very happy to replace our entire meal. The server even got us an appetizer "on the house" while we were waiting for our milder entrees to be prepared.

The price of the food we had was quite reasonable. Our bill for the table including an appetizer, two entrees, naan, rice and two sodas was only $55 including tax. 

This place compares to the food, service and ambiance you get dining in a 5-star hotel in India. So far I have eaten at Pakwan, Aslam, Roti Indian Bistro, Little Delhi, New Delhi, Mehfil and Chaat Cafe here in San Francisco and this place beats them all hands down.
 
Overall, we left the place feeling great about the whole experience and will highly recommend it to all yelpers.
author: A C.

description:
Yes, that's right! When I gave 5 stars to this place, yelp says:
"Woohoo! As good as it gets!"

This restaurant is THE BEST NORTH INDIAN FOOD IN SAN FRANCISCO PERIOD!

So, this is what happened:

Me and my hubby were hungry and were returning from a full day of shopping, really exhausted and wanted some good food really bad. So, we thought let's try Amber India as it was so close to the mall. We entered the restaurant and were greeted really politely by one older gentlemen. He gave us a really nice, romantic corner seat. The ambiance of this place was amazing! Our server, Maggi, was super friendly came and took our order: Paneer Manchuran, Kadhai Paneer, Vegetable Korma, Naan and saffron rice. We asked them to make food our a little more spicy than a medium. 

But when our food came, we had a couple of bites but it was way too spicy! We couldn't handle the heat and asked our server to replace it if possible. She was very apologetic and changed it right away. She got us Diet Coke and Raita (Yoghurt) and was trying to do everything for us to neutralize the heat. Moreover, while the chef were making our new food, he sent us some spinach chaat to nibble on as well which was delicious!

Within 5-8 minutes, our food arrived, guess what? They not only got us the entrees that were spicy but also got us new rice and naan. We had our fresh dinner again!

Now the food, you cannot get a better North Indian Food in this city! It was very delicious and the spiciness was just perfect! The aroma in the korma reminded me of food from my favorite restaurants in India! It was exactly like food from 5 stars restaurants in India and service from 7stars! 

We were just very impressed by the service and the quality of food! JUST AMAZING! We will definitely go back there and recommend you going there too!
author: Shikha C.

description:
Disappointed with the quality of food. Bhindi was poorly cooked and dal had lot of condensed milk in it.
The seekh kaboob was poor quality. Nan was excellent.
author: shaukat a.

description: One of my favorite spots to eat in SF. The room decor is amazing, food and service top notch quality. I highly recommend the butter chicken,  and Orange Fig Chicken (Yum!). If you want an authentic and delightful Indian Cuisine experience, Amber is it.
author: Kwajoankoma A.

description: This place offers a change from the regular Indian menu that we see at all other indian places. Discovered a good dish palak chat at this place.
author: Y U.

description: The appetizer of minced chicken kababs ( Murg taj kabab)  were the right flavor and the palak chat was great downed with Kingfisher beer. My friend who was trying indian food for the first time had the All time American Continent's popular Indian dish " Butter Chicken" and I had the Amber Dal with rice. Yummm ! I plan to go back again this trip. This was a Sunday night and the place was not very crowded and service was excellent.
author: Shashi B.

description:
Convinced company friends to come here for lunch to celebrate the holidays.

Loved the buffet. Not cheap, nasty Indian food. High quality ingredients, fresh frutis and vegetables, made to order naan. Great ambiance and service. More expensive than a typical Indian restaurant, but worth it. This place is probably the best Indian restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Christine P.

description:
I have been to Amber several times and rate the food quality amazing. 
I recently went for the Sunday buffet,  which is a good vaule for a variety of wonderful indian dishes.  

The service is a bit slow and does need improvement.
author: Shima L.

description: We hosted a holiday party in the lounge area and could not have been happier with the food, service and atmosphere. The waitstaff were all extremely helpful and kind and knowledgable, the manager worked with me to create a menu and make it a special night for our guests, and the food and drinks were both over the top amazing. The restaurant and bar are both great options for dinner or a snack/cocktail.
author: Jeanine J.

description: After the incident, I wrote an email to the manager who wrote back apologizing, saying the new staff needs a review on their policies, as they should not have taken a credit card to pay for "our meal" over the phone and we should not have received a call the next day asking us to call in with our credit card. I appreciated the prompt and professional reply. Without the incident, I would have rated this place a 3-star.
author: Sheila S.

description:
My only regret is I was working and didn't have time to sit down for dinner here, so I ordered takeout instead. The interior of this place is beautiful.

The curry I ordered was absolutely delicious and I will definitely return to sample the rest of the menu when I go back to SF!
author: nick d.

description: Come here everytime I'm in SF. Great Indian food, Butter Chicken and the naan is awesome. The bar is small and cozy with very cool decor.
author: Matt B.

description:
Coming from London, who have some of the best indian food. Amber is definitely a good selection if you are in SF! 
I personally love their Butter Chicken and Bhindi with some soft Naan.
I recently had their sheik kebabs which were great but slightly expensive. 

Love the ambience too! ALWAYS busy, call in advance
author: Ria J.

description: I was in town for a conference and stopped in here for dinner twice during my stay because I liked it so much. Very convenient location near Union Square. The dish I fell in love with was their eggplant dish (Badam Bhara Baingan). It was to die for. They also had great rice and naan and the service was good. The ambience is very cozy and kind of romantic. When I am back in SF I will be returning to this place!
author: Brit T.

description: The ambiance is definitely nice.  I was happy to be seated quickly.  I've heard great things about some of the dishes here, but my friend wanted to stick to the classic paneer dish, so we got that as our entree.  I didn't think the paneer dish was amazing, unfortunately, but we ventured out of the traditional for the appetizers, and I'm glad we did.  We got the portobello and goat cheese tikki and the palak chaat.. both of which I really liked.  The palak was super crispy and different and the tikki and sauce it came with were both really tasty.  The garlic naan was good as well.  I requested some green chillies on the side to help flavor the paneer dish, and was glad I did.  They brought out a plate of onions, lemon and chillies that were super spicy.  I ended up having to cool my mouth with some mango lassi (which actually wasn't the best lassi - the straw they gave was useless as the drink was too thick to use a straw).  We polished off the meal with a ras malai which was super yummy as well.  I'd definitely go back and try some of their fusion entrees next time!
author: Rachana S.

description:
WOW - This place is amazing. I had a great time here. Food, service and decor is Avon.
For appetizer I had super scrumptious Spinach Chat- which was phenomenal. I have never had spinach done that way ever before.
 I also had Duck Kebab which was also excellent. 

Mine and my friend's entree were also good. For Dessert we shared a Coffee Kulfi - which was also great.

Service was attentive but not over bearing. Only gripe was drinks arrived much after the apps.

They have cool bar.  And I agree with Nish below  -  get rid of the sporting events on the plasma screen. This is not a Ball Game and Beer kind of place.
author: Loren A.

description: went with my family for an buffet the dosa was made right in front of us and very delicious, loved the food and the dessert i chose was moong dal halwa it was perfect, tasted like it was made for an queen, perfect and authentic it tasted like  how my grandma and mom  used to made with pure ghee and lots of dry fruits.we did not have to wait long got seated right away service was excellent, they made sure we got hot fresh naan  and checked on us to make sure we were taken care of well, would love to go there again.
author: M K.

description:
How the hell do you even describe Amber's new digs in San Francisco?  It's the most upscale Indian place I've ever been to outside of India or London.  If you like Indian food, then you have to go, period.

Amber's original location in Mountain View is fantastic, one of the two or three best Indian restaurants in the Bay, if not the best.  The San Jose location is very upscale, and great in its own way.  I waited on bated breath when I heard that it was coming to SF, and waited, and then waited some more.  Finally, when it opened, I visited half a dozen times, and have been back a few times since.

At least here in the US, Indian food has been largely relegated to "cheap" food status, the home of $10 buffet or $20 meal.  Amber definitely isn't that kind of place--I don't think I've ever spent more for Indian food in the US than here.  The new location is absolutely beautiful, and every detail, from the lights to the thick carpeting, has been done with luxury in mind.  The food, as always, is amazing.  So why only 4 stars?  Well, if my wife and I are going to drop $200 for food and a bottle of wine, I expect something transcendent.  The food here merely lives up to Amber's strong reputation in the Peninsula and South Bay, albeit in a much nicer location.
author: Ty D.

description:
This place is solid.  Their signature butter chicken (great marketing. you can't go wrong with this name but if you mess it up...) was tasty.  I mean TASTY.

For appetizers, try their duck tinka kebab.  It's tender and full of flavor. Chicken tikka and most of their lamb dishes are great.  Only dish I tried that was mediocre was their sea bass moilee.  Definitely recommend trying Amber India at least once.
author: Bernard M.

description: Great service, great atmosphere and good authentic Indian food.
author: Amanda S.

description: Food was decent, ambience n decor I certainly liked. Everything else was sub par- the lady at the door who's primary function is to manage seating n reservations, told me it was a 25 min wait to a table, only to tell me 30 mins later upon my further inquiry, that it would take another 30 mins!!! I ended up eating a full course meal (given I had already ordered) off a coffee table at the lounge, NO apologies either! I wasnt the only one- folks next table to me were complaintful of the same. For a place that expensive, I'd say good service is rather basic, else it kills the experience. If I weren't in the mood to be pampered, I'd have rather tried one of those quaint hole in the wall haunts with better food.
author: Jay M.

description:
We've been invited to dinner at Amber twice, both were a hit. We started the evening with cocktails, I really liked the Asian Lemon Drop, tart and not as sweet as other drinks. 

I have a gluten and soy allergy, which was easily accommodated. We ordered the Mushroom Teen Saag, the Fish Kebabs, and a Paneer dish, which were safe for me to eat. I'm pretty finicky about Indian food and find most of it to be really heavy and greasy. This was filling and rich without that heavy greasy feeling.

The bar is nice for waiting and having a drink if you show up early enough. Otherwise, it gets pretty full. 

The restaurant has a nice ambiance, though the bench seating feels a little lower than the chairs. I didn't really mind, but I thought I'd mention it. I look forward to going there again.
author: Fabienne J.

description: Amber definitely has solid indian food, and a nice atmosphere but they're not amazing. And they're pretty pricey for an indian place with only moderate sized prices. If you're in a bind it's a safe bet but not worth seeking out. Although the lunch buffet is tasty, with a decent selection (although still pricey).
author: Megan B.

description:
Excellent, excellent, excellent!

We came by for lunch buffet recently and the place was pretty packed.  Luckily, we had reservations so we were seated promptly.  The decor was modern, clean, and sleek but what caught my attention is how yummy the food looked and smelled.  

The buffet selection was very good, complete with a dessert bar.  They served naan bread at the table so that was pretty convenient.  My favorites included the butter chicken, cabbage, lamb curry, and pudding... gosh, I went back twice for more.  

The lunch buffet price is super reasonable and no wonder it's a hit among all the working lunch crowd.
author: Betsy C.

description:
i am wary of buffets. sometimes, they really suck.
but i've had several awesome experiences with indian buffet in NYC and after seeing the good reviews on this place, and being in the area, i dropped in. the atmosphere is lavish, the presentation is absolutely beautiful, the food was fresh and oddly gentle on the spices (catering to an american crowd that can't handle its heat). very nice very fresh naan, without that extra sheen of grease that some restaurants figure is fine. very good for indian buffet. i'd give them five stars if they also gave me fresh dosa like my fave place in NYC. 

but $15 dollars is just right for very good indian lunch buffet.

and a crowd of indians came in and packed the place after i went in, so they're doing something right!
author: Annie W.

description: My husband and I enjoyed one of the best Indian meals ever here.  Everything we had was delicious.  We also tried something new for us and thought it was fabulous... the flash fried spinach.  We weren't sure what to expect but the waitress said it was one of her favorites so we went with it.  Also the butter chicken was outstanding and I could hardly get enough.  I can't wait to go back again!
author: Wendi O.

description:
Really delicious food. Tasty appetizers, nice choice of main dishes. Kinda hard to focus on those things, though. It's easy to be distracted by the abysmal service. 
Seriously, if you order a drink, don't be hopeful about it arriving anytime, like soon. No, it'll take a couple more reminders before that happens. And then, once it arrives, it'll probably taste good, but you'll be so busy muttering under your breath at the server's lack of serving abilities that you won't be able to enjoy it. 
This was pretty much the story of our night. It's amazing how poor service can completely ruin a good meal. And it's not like they spilled something down a shirt or brought us the wrong things. It was just complete, rampant, incompetence. 
If you're willing to overlook that (and if you can do that, you deserve my sincere congratulations), the food might redeem this beautiful restaurant.
author: Purnima M.

description: "It is THE BEST experience with super delicious food I ever had in US in last 7 years".  I am an Indian and a foodie and lived in NJ.
author: Tushar A.

description:
good atmosphere, nicely decorated inside. 
Good for a birthday party I say.. 

Food - quite good. my friends from India love this place. so I guess it's good.

but it's quite expensive
author: Cindy N.

description: Delicious baigan (eggplant) and the chili thyme naan is a must. The raita was too thick and tasted like Greek yogurt instead of traditional Indian. Short walk from the westin so it was an easy choice. Dont think they know much about wine since my reisling was freezing cold when It arrived. So dont go for the wine. I'd definitely go back. Be warned, if you ask them to make it spicy...they surely will.
author: Peter F.

description:
Excellent food! Great atmosphere and service. In town for Salesforce conference and gave Amber a try. Butter chicken and garlic naan was great. 
Jeff, Keith, Bridget, Laura and Jason
author: Jeff A.

description:
Came in yesterday for the $17 lunch buffet - pretty average food, not worth the price or time.

+ves
+ nice location, close to Market St
+ very nice interior, clean, decent service
+ Tandoori chicken (when it came out) was great

-ves
- a very average buffet, about 11 dishes, 7 of which were vegetarian and all looked the same
- the fish was terrible, covered in some thick, too spicy breading
- the lamb looked like dog food, tasted just as bad
- the butter chicken was all sauce, you had to fish around in the large dish to get any chicken (it was very nice when you got it)
- the chocolate mousse was terrible, seriously who taste tested this before putting it out?

Avoid the lunch buffet at all costs. Try Naan-N-Curry or get a hot dog from 7-Eleven.
author: Joseph T.

description:
This was our first meal in SF due to its proximity to our hotel.  The wait staff was excellent.  There weren't too many people in the restaurant so we had the exact amount of attention one would need (always a full water glass, not pushy, cocktails were fast in coming).  

The food was very good.  I failed to deviate from what I usually get at Indian restaurants but it gave me a good benchmark as to the quality of food.  The quality was super.  

Highly recommend this place.  It's not cheap but as we learned in SF, very little is cheap.  :-)
author: David H.

description:
My boyfriend and I kept walking past this place whenever we decided to go see a movie at the Metreon.  Since he's from the UK, he's a big fan of curries, and I had gone to India in the Summer of 2007, so I'm just a big fan of Indian food in general.

Well, we finally were there around dinner time, so we decided to go in one rainy Sunday evening.  First off, the place is gorgeous.  Comfy chairs to boot.  There weren't a lot of people there, so I was slightly worried about the food, because I'm a firm believer in packed restaurant = delicious food goodness. 

We ended up ordering the duck kababs (I have to get used to kababs, since it's how they do things in the UK) as an appetizer, and two lamb dishes.  Lamb is my favorite food, and he likes it too, so we got the Kashmiri Roganjosh (one of his favorite dishes) and Shalgam Nalli (a braised lamb shank).  We also got a bottle of wine.  We also ordered chili thyme naan and lacha paratha.

So, the duck was amazing.  Super tender, and the sauce it came with we both wanted to eat with a spoon.  I don't know how they got it so tender and delicious, but I would recommend this dish to anyone who eats duck.  Both of the lamb dishes were also amazing.  Quite spicy and not dumbed down for American people, like many of the Indian restaurants I've been too.  The spice and the flavors were so close to the food I had in India, I was in heaven.  After one bite, my boyfriend said we were going back there again!  Both the breads were quite tasty, but I prefer paratha to naan in general.  

As they bring the dessert menus, I mention that if they have Galub Jamun, we're getting it.  I fell in love with them when I was in Kolkata, and since the dinner was fantastic, I was sure that they were going to do a great job of them as well.  Since they are indeed on the dessert menu, I ordered it.  There were two of them, which let both of us have a nice bite at the end of the meal, and he had never had them before.  He just loved it!  I did too.

We're definitely going back to this place.  The food was just amazing.  If you're a big fan of authentic Indian food, this is the place to go.  It is a bit spendy though, so there may be places that are also good, but not quite as expensive.  I've yet to find them though.
author: Grant T.

description:
First off let me say that the Amber India restaurant, hands down, is run by the most insulting and incompetent management staff I have ever encountered in any restaurant in my 34 years! We ate there last night, the food was overpriced for what it was, and I wonder about the secret ingredients that found their way into our food. More importantly, I question managements ethics.

Initially when our food came out, 2 members out of our party of 5 had HAIR in their meals. I passed the hair to my friends who confirmed it was what I thought it was (It was squiggly, lightly colored, thin in nature, and definitely human). Normally I wouldn't make a big deal out of this sort of thing--We have all experienced this at one time or another-- however when the waiter came around, I gave it to him and expressed my displeasure. About 10 minutes later the manager returned and asked me "So this is what you found in your food? You see it is a fiber, so you are okay." That didn't explain the hair in my buddies food which was a foot long, and what's more hilarious is that what the manager presented to us, looked like something he had just plucked out of his sport coat. Even my friend sitting across the table could see that this fiber couldn't be any more dissimilar from what I handed to the waiter - it was short, dark, and very rigid. When I told the manager this, he simply flipped the fiber over and said "What about now?". Jerk.

I can't emphasize this enough, if the manager had simply come out and apologized, perhaps even offered a desert or some other small concession, we would have been fine. Instead he chose to insult our intelligence and try to cover things up. 

My gut feeling is that if you have someone at the helm of your restaurant disguising health and safety issues, do you really want to entrust them with your food? Think about that the next time you are considering Indian food in SF. Avoid this place if possible.
author: Ryan H.

description: Yum. Attentive service, less than five minutes from my hotel and delicious food.  Great crispy spinach, naan and butter chicken,  what's not to like?
author: Lisa B.

description: A great date place. The service is amazing, very attentive, friendly great staff. The decor is very nice and classy and great location. The food was really good, got the samosas, butter chicken, rice, and saag paneer. Everything was delicious if not a little tame on the flavors (and I don't mean spiciness, I mean flavors). Definitely pricey. Probably would not have come if we didn't have a gift certificate, which really helped. Recommended, but because we are in the east bay, we could easily go to Berkeley for great Indian at less cost.
author: J E.

description: IT was great! but there was some confusion involved.  Turns out Sunday buffet is $19.95 before tax, and includes champagne.  I don't drink, so i didn't see the justification of adding $4.00 to the bill :p.  Good as it gets and it was great and amazing, but it was difficult to digest.  Quick Tip, don't eat breakfast or anything period, for best results. Try a three day fast and PACE yourself during the meal.  Don't Eat too quickly, and be sure to masticate properly ;).
author: Gurvinderpal S.

description: Excellent food, great service. The best Indian food I've had in the USA.  The buffet at weekends is truly amazing.  Mimosas come with the buffet too.  They're always ready to top them up.  I always eat too much here because it's just so good.  And it's really keenly priced too.  Don't walk her: run!
author: Steven R.

description:
Went to Amber yesterday post movie. Planned on just getting a drink but it turned into a couple drinks and a meal. Joanne (sp?) was incredibly friendly and helpful. 

Had mint&cucumber taaza and was very good. Had duck kebab and nann- amazing. Then ordered lamb stuffed naan and samosas stuffed with spicy potatoes and peas= both were amazing. 

great service and food! Good Saturday afternoon!!
author: Art A.

description: My first time trying Indian food, a friend of mine was nice enough to take me here. The butter chicken was delicious! I could probably eat that everyday and not get sick of it. Yum.
author: Miss H.

description: I was underwhelmed by the lunch buffet.  The food was okay, but not better than what you can find at any number of Indian dives, and I'm not sure that the prospect of having MORE of it was a real winner.  But it seemed like a clean and comfortable joint, or maybe they bring it for dinner.  As is--if I need to plan a boring corporate event, I'll think of Amber but not for any nice lunch downtown and not for a meal out with people I have anything to talk about with. Like Roy's, it's a place better left to the convention center crowd.
author: Luke M.

description:
I was just at Amber lastnight with a group of friends after a night at Press Club (across the corridor) 

This restaurant is class all the whole way. The butter chicken is great, the calamari is spicy "just right and perfect" 

Everyone ordered a signature cocktail and I ordered a greyhound w/ Ketel One and we were a happy party of 7! (BTW gratuities are included in bill, soo don't add additional tip even if you split the bill) We tripled our tip, Our Hostess deserved it but could used a tip myself. 

Great decor, Marble stairs, Amber lighting and beautiful layout.

FRIENDLY STAFF. 

Everyone will definitly be back
author: Lady O.

description:
I had lunch here.  19.95.  Full Buffet.  Service was great.  Decor is awesome. Food is actually very delicious and fresh.  The nan was plentiful.  

I have a hard time with buffets in general because I find it's hard to appreciate the food...I begin to feel like a cow eating out of a trough.  So given I paid 19.95 knowing entrees normally run a little more, I figured I'd pace myself and TRY to appreciate the food.  It fired back...the food was really good and I wanted to try EVERYTHING.  The plenty of veggie dishes.  The fried and well seasoned catfish.  The lamb curry.  I was comatose the rest of the damn day.  This lunch visit single-handedly inspired me to re-activate my gym membership. (not kidding)

I give it 3 stars because overall it was OK.  I guess if it was a little less expensive I would have rated it higher.  I would recommend it if you don't mind spending $21 for good indian food.  I wouldn't dare coming to dinner here.
author: Adrian N.

description:
-----------------
This place is a little pricey (for Indian food) but totally worth it. Service, decor and location are just great. Upscale Indian dining to take a break from usual Naan & Curry's spicy_oily_food+self-service routine in SF :)) (yes I eat there a lot)

I ordered Galouti/Shami Kababs from the appetizers section. I am from the place which is famous for the best shami and galotuti kababs. I did not expect the kababs here to be so good!! They just melt in your mouth..and the spices were perfect. 

Butter chicken was great....so was Spinach+mushroom+babycorn. Tried that with naan and paratha. Getting assorted bread basket is also a good idea. 

Like this place, can't wait to go back there sometime soon and enjoy kababs with Macallan...nice!! :)
author: A K.

description: I have to admit this is one of the tastiest Indian food I've had outside of India! Honestly I went there twice and every dish I had was amazing and so authentic. It had a great feel to the place and the main host even recognised me on my 2nd visit, considering the restaurant was packed the week I was visiting. This place was recommended by my sis who visited earlier in the year and it kept upto my expectations, I will surely visit this place when I come to San Fran again!!!
author: Sonia S.

description: For high-class Indian, this is the place to go.  I've been to their San Jose location more often, but I actually prefer the ambiance at this one.  Service is great (though my coworker knew the manager, so that might have helped), food is great, prices are a little high but you get the polish and the ambiance for that price.  I take people here for fancy Indian meals, then I go with my friends to Chutney for real (and cheap) Indian meals.
author: Sia K.

description:
This review is for their happy hour.

My gfs and I went here after work on a Friday night for good drinks and appetizers before watching Valentine's Day at the Metreon.  

My friends got there about 20 mins before me and they'd ordered food and drinks.  When I got there, I tasted their amber rose drink and decided against it and got the other amber drink.  It took them awhile to bring me my drink and when the waitress handed it to me, the apple from the drink dropped and she didn't even apologize!  And since it's been 20 mins since my friends ordered our food, we decided to ask her how much longer it'd take.  In response, she said, "I don't know how long it takes for appetizers."  She didn't even offer to check or come back to tell us!  Finally, my friends went to the manager and asked about our food because we only had 15 mins before the movie started.  The manager came by and apologized and told us that our food was delivered to the table NEXT to us!  We were appalled about the whole situation...the waitress completely forgot about us and the people next to us finished the food they didn't order...

The manager personally delivered our food and offered us complimentary shots from the bar or comp the appetizers.  We were rushing so we told him to comp the dishes and for the check.  

We ended up running to the movie theatre and had to sit separately since we were so late!

I definitely wouldn't go back for happy hour but maybe for dinner sometimes.  Hopefully the service will be 100% better.
author: Phuong H.

description: Buffet lunch was fresh, always full. Great mix of options. We were at union square - hungry & wanting something out if the crowd. A few minute walk after we found this place on yelp. Yum yum.
author: Chris M.

description: Interesting.  The place has a reputation, was expected to be busy and it was.  We had a reservation and were seated promptly.  Not the best table (for two) as the better seating seemed designed for larger parties.  The menu choices were good but we were a little disappointed that they couldn't work with our dietary restrictions as several dishes/sauces were prepared in advance and wouldn't/couldn't be modified.  The two dishes we shared were old favorites that had an interesting and different spicing than what we were used to - nice.  Service was polite and mostly prompt.
author: Kent K.

description:
I've stopped by a couple times just at their bar which is cool looking and great to hang out at.  My friend is in love with their kumquat spash drink.  I find their drinks great, but there isn't one favorite one for me, though the pomegranate one was pretty good, but you have to find the right bartender to make it for you.

As for food it was delicious, though I didn't do the ordering so I have no idea what I ate.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I was in SF for a convention and wanted to eat dinner in the vicinity of my hotel, but something different. This place fit the bill. They are innovative with the ingredients. I enjoyed having several options for non-alcoholic drinks besides the usual mango lassi and sodas. Their corn and fava bean tikki was absolutely delicious as was the accompanying tomato based dipping sauce. Silken Tofu with vegetable Kofta is an excellent choice for vegetarians, along with some rice and tandoori roti. The portions are generous. I felt guilty I could not take my leftover food with me. The prices are higher than your average Indian restaurant, but so is the quality of their food.
author: Bliss H.

description: I am not going to lie - Indian food scares me a little bit.  I have a sensitive stomach and I am not well versed in it - a combo that could be deadly.  So when my friend suggested we eat here, I smiled and bared it - praying I survived.  The place is an absolutely beautiful dining atmosphere and our waiter was awesome - we basically let him order for us.  We started with the Palak Chaat - crispy spinach that was soo good - I was kinda sad that we shared it.  Julia had the Butter Chicken and I went for the Shalgam Nalli - delicious lamb with a kick.  They were both good but I actually like Julia's better.  We rounded our meal out with Saffron Pulao and Lacha Paratha - both the rice and bread were great.  The meal was good and the service was great - a very cool atmosphere for a nice dinner or date.  I survived it with no stomach issues and a desire to go back - cheers to that!
author: Arica V.

description: I came here for the lunch buffet.  The atmosphere is warm and inviting, and the place was clean.  Possibly my first time experiencing fine dining for Indian food.  Well, while I enjoyed most of the food I would say there really wasn't that much of a variety for entrees.  I was a bit disappointed by that, because the salad bar consisted a significant part of the menu and the dessert selection was limited.  I enjoyed the warm toasty naan bread they bring to your plate.  Line moves slow, wonder if they figured out a better system to strategically place foods to move the buffet line along.
author: Peachie Y.

description: It's a little hard to explain but in almost all their dishes I could really taste the spices and flavoring. Admittedly I'm an Indian food novice, but a lot of the other restaurants I have eaten at the dishes seem to get overwhelmed by one flavor but at Amber you can really taste the multitude of ingredients that go into it. Anyway the food was fantastic and the service great. The butter chicken and kashmiri roganjosh are definitely my favorites.
author: Procter F.

description: The lunch buffet is not bad, the menu ok...good for office lunch party
author: Marsaulina V.S V.

description: I loved the ambiance and the lovely smells as we entered.  Its a high end place but the staff was friendly to us in casual appearance.  The samosas were lovely.  I had the spinach dumpling Kofta and it was just ok.  The sauce was a bit salty to me.  The naan was beautiful and hot from the oven.  My friend had the asparagus cauliflower dish and the sauce was delightfully gingery and tasty!  My husband and her husband had chicken curry dishes which they liked but were not blown away. Everything was a bit mild and deigned for folks that don't really know Indian food. They are British and have high standards for curry. The presentation and service were lovely, but overall it was a bit overpriced .
author: Liz F.

description: I expected great things.  The hostesses hassled me on the phone about a reservation I had made instead of just graciously welcoming us.  I was charged $8 for a bottle of Pelligrino; no bubbles is wayyyyy cheaper.  The standard, very popular dish, Chicken Tikka Masala, wasn't even on the menu and when I asked about it, the waiter kind of rolled his eyes and said they could make it for us.  I have had a much better version of this dish here locally in Santa Rosa and at 1/2 the price.  The naan was very good.  I won't be in a big hurry to go back to this place.
author: Gail C.

description:
We've talked for years about driving down then Peninsula to visit Amber India, but never got around to it. Then we heard last fall that they were coming to the City. And then they opened, about a week ago. Now, I know, give them more time to work out the kinks, blah, blah, but we've been waiting and this is the 3rd one so they should have it down to a near science - and they do. The main door needs better signage, which I'm sure is coming. But once inside, the flooring is amazing, the room interesting, and then you're either in the bar (which is beautiful) or the dining rooms, which are very chic. 

And the food is sublime, absolutely wonderful. Like being in some 5 STAR restaurant in New Delhi, and we love India and have been there many times. The duck tinka app is so good I could make a meal of them alone. This is not traditional Indian cuisine, but that cuisine adapted to the place and the produce found here, way beyond fusion food all the way into fabulous food, nothing like it in the City.
The roganjosh is to die for, plain and simple. The calamari app is sooooo spicy I thought we were in Goa, and made me miss playing in the waves and the great food there. The butter chicken - there are no words, period. It was the best I have ever had anywhere in the world, period. And the naan, oh my gosh, my partner the baker was captived, and said it was the best he had had in a long long time. Every dish we ordered was perfect, perfectly prepared, perfectly spiced, perfectly served.  Drinks from the bar were very good, the lassis we had were just the thing for the spice, and we had to pass on desserts as we were too full, damnitall. This is a decidedly upscale Indian restaurant, situated in an upscale area. If you love Indian cuisine, come here.
A great addition to our City.
author: William M.

description:
oh yeah...my first 5 star rating has arrived. Met up with some old work colleagues to catch up and we landed here. The meal, service, wine list, and experience was nothing short of outstanding. It took just a few minutes to heed the advice of our server and "just trust him". 

All the way down the line: samosa's, duck kabob (siiick!!), butter chicken, sea bass....by this time we were losing it we were so happy i don't even remember what else we ordered. some lamb dish, a date with ganesh, hell I don't know. the food was off the charts. the bartender was incredibly knowledgeable about the wines, and almost to the point of entertainment, really wanted to know how we liked each one.

Go to this place now!
author: Matt M.

description: The best Indian I've had so far: butter chicken, saag paneer, tandoori sampler, salmon, raita, garlic naan. All of it was incredible!! Will make this a tradition when I come to the Bay Area.
author: Asal G.

description:
Despite some very mixed early reviews, we decided to give it a shot based on a friend's recommendation. The food was quite good, the presentation was nice and the service was excellent.

I think this is a great choice for an outing where the atmosphere and service are an important component, and money is no object (say, a business dinner or meeting SO's parents for the first time) - but for just getting some good Indian I would have to go with Mehfil, not as impressive a scene, but much cheaper and more classic Indian.

So, they have certainly worked out many of the kinks early reviewers mentioned, the atmosphere is nicely upscale, without being too pretentious or overbearing, and the food is very good, if a little on the expensive side.
author: Ben K.

description: I absolutely love the decor of this place. I had a couple drinks in the lounge/bar area, where there was lots of open seating on a Saturday night around 9-10pm. The drinks are delicious! Yes, they are quite pricey but wonderful. I'd love to come back to try the food. I was told that they have a lunch buffet, yumm.
author: Stephanie U.

description: I went to their buffet and it was amazing.  Loved the mushroom Tava and pander dishes.  Dessert as chocolate was great!
author: Ami P.

description:
I would have never come here on my own, but my company decided on this place as a treat for our team rewarding a job well done.

With that in mind, realize that I didn't have to pay. This *does* effect my review ;)

The bar: the Manhattan I ordered was STRONG. Less sweetness than I usually expect. (I'm not complaining, though. It was goood.)

The restaurant: They seated all ten of us in the back room across the entire restaurant from the bar. I can not complain about the service in this place at ALL. They were completely attentive and catered to everything that we needed. (Although I did order a cocktail that I never received...might it have been canceled out by the multiple bottles of wine ordered at our table? I didn't care...wine was enough!) 

When the wine was brought out, they made an excellent presentation to each person and the bartenders were knowledgeable about the pairings. They were very open to any questions. Each and every server was ultra-friendly. 

We had a plethora of appetizers, entrees, and desserts at our table, so I got to try a rainbow of food. The samosas were good - nothing stark-raving amazing, but good.
