Not as spicy as the traditional home-made samosas I have tried in the past. I ordered the Sun Dried Tomato & Goat cheese Tikki appetizer, which kinda seemed like fancy Indian fried cheese sticks...but trust me: delicious. I had a bite of the AMAZING Sweet Potato Salad (and the presentation for this particular salad was super-impressive). We also had an Amber Mixed Grill, which was meat, and the only meat I eat is fish. I can assure you: the tiger shrimp on this platter was super-fly. ;)

For my entree, I ordered the Tandoor Grilled Shrimps. When the platter was brought out, I guess I was shocked at how...little was on it. For $23.95, I would just expect more.....food. They were, however, absolutely tasty...and since I was eating off of other platters on the table, I didn't even have the ability to finish my food. 

Other things I tried: garlic na'an was phenomenal. The Saufiyani Baingan looked super-meaty, but the spicing was great. The Mushroom and Baby corn Teen Saag was my favorite. The spinach in it was flavored perfectly. Without a doubt, my favorite thing that night. Even the carnivores devoured it.

Dessert happened...though I still wonder how. The Gulab Jamun was surprising good. (The dumplings were the right consistency and there was a perfect amount of syrup to cover them. Someone made the comment that you eat one of the two dumplings, and it's like eating a whole meal.) I was not, in any way, a fan of the "Thandai" Spiced Crème Brulee. Too much Indian spice...not enough...good. Period. I also didn't expect the Chocolate & Mango Lassi Cake to taste so...unique. I wish there had been more chocolate involved, but I guess that's not very traditional, now is it? 

I guess the wine made us a little loud. They shut the glass doors to our room later on, but I thought it was great that they had the space to do it. The privacy was nice!

Overall, great experience. The waitress didn't even blink when I made the unique request to bag up any leftover vegetarian or fish dishes left on the plate. I walked away with a super-random sampling of rices, na'an, and three different dishes, in a cutesy-little white bag. 

I'd probably have fainted if I picked up the check, though. For that, minus a star. I guarantee the experience would have been different if it was coming out of my wallet ;)
author: Danyell K.

description: We had an amazing experience at Amber. Anyone who has rated this less than 5 stars is crazy. The food was by far the best thing I have ever tasted and this is coming from a native Indian from Delhi. But I have to say, what put our experience over the top was a beautiful and kind hostess by the name of Himali. If you go to the restaurant, be sure to ask for her. She took care of our picky demands and surpassed our every need. People who rated this restaurant poorly are upset only because they dont have the common sense to make a reservation and show up at the actual reservation time. We saw another couple that showed up 40 minutes before their reservation and make a crazy hissy fit because they could not be seated. Come to this restaurant for the food. Come to this restaurant for the service from people like Himali. Come to this restaurant because you want the whole experience of something you have been missing in your life. This is a real experience, from a real person and I hope my enthusiasm influences your decision to come to Amber.
author: Kunal S.

description: The Indian food was just okay, especially for $17 for the lunch buffet!! The buffet had limited selection, mostly vegetarian, and funny tasting butter chicken. I came here during a conference at the Convention Center alone. I thought I could sit and enjoy my food and get some work done. As a party of one, they chose to seat the parties of two that came in after me before me.  I was waiting so long, they even forgot about me and seated another party of one before me. As I sat down, a waiter started talking aggressively with the hostess for sitting so many two parties at four party tables. she responded that she only had two party tables and then began to speak in another language when she saw me looking. I felt rushed and unwelcome. If you re looking for a place for a productive and delicious lunch, I think there are other Indian places in the neighborhood that would work better.
author: Nicole E.

description: This was fantastic!  The decor, the ambiance, the service, the food - it was all some of the best ever!  This was my husband's first taste of Indian cuisine - he loved it!  Our waiter was so helpful in giving us information on how spicy the dishes were and made very good recommendations.  Try the butter chicken!!!!!!
author: Kathleen W.

description: Amazing cocktail called Cucumber Watermelon! Just the right amouny of sweet! Also amazing to taste....Keema Naan, Malabari shrimp and chef's chicken curry!
author: MeeSun B.

description:
The food was most excellent, albeit a little more expensive than I'd expect for butter chicken.  The lamb was pretty phenom, especially with the mini-turnips.  If you like Indian food, then I'd recommend.

However, if you love booze like I do, then you must come to Amber India, if only for the bar.  I ordered "Fire & Ice", which is an Indian-inspired drink and my friend ordered a Vesper, which he uses to test bartenders.  We were pleased when the drinks were delivered by Mr. Slicky McPinstripe Pants, the sommelier/bar manager.  The speech he proceeded to give us must have been inspired by Bacchus, because his words were divine. I'm not sure I've ever seen such passion with respect to booze.
author: Mark J.

description:
Since my very suburban mother is weary of entering the Tenderloin where Indian food is delicious, plentiful and cheap, we decided to return to the posh Amber India.
  
The dining room really is gorgeous and this time I noticed a private dining room - nice.  The banquettes are quite comfortable.  Give me a booth any day.  

We ordered the okra which was absolutely delicious.  I really liked the combination of smokey onion, gooey okra and garlic.  We also tried a different chicken curry (murg something) which was okay.  I'd definitely stick with the butter chicken next time.  We tried the 6 hours braised lamb shank which was supposed to be hot.  It registered a quite tingle on my tongue initially but the heat did build after consuming more.  The server told us it was a 7 on the hot scale but I thought it was a four at best.  However, the lamb meat was so tender.  I liked that I got to feel a bit cave-womany with the huge shank bone on my plate.  

I know it was quite pricey for "ethnic" food standards but I have enough leftovers for lunch today!
author: Monica L.

description: I have come here for dinner with friends several times. Expensive food which tastes alright. Portion sizes are small. Right I agree, the butter chicken is good. Good for dining. I think it a little overpriced but with the ambience and a nice bar, I would give it three stars.
author: Chetan K.

description:
While I was in SF I decided to use my iPhone and its' wonderful Yelp application (app) to find places to eat within walking distance of my hotel.  With that, I ended up in Amber - India.  Well, it would have been walking distance but my excellent tour guide Hazel was a little hazy on where to go...get it...I made a funny.  Anyway...  

Atmosphere - dark, fancy, clean, modern, very cool bar/ lounge area, friendly

Food - This week I was letting the Yelp app decide for me as to what to pick off a menu.  Therefore, I opted for the well-reviewed butter chicken, as it was mentioned 116 times (now 117) in Yelp reviews.  I assume all positive.  It should tell you that...yes?  When my Butter Chicken arrived, the dish consisted of nicely cut, tender pieces of Tandoori chicken in a red sauce w/ a side of rice for the table.  I requested medium spice and the dish was almost too spicy but delicious nonetheless.  On a future visit, I may go less spicy to take in the flavors of the sauce.  For bread, I ordered the Bread Basket, which consisted of Mutter Kulcha, Lacha Paratha, and Naan.  The Mutter Kulcha was my least favor of the three as there was too much of a taste of potato...if that makes any sense to you.  To wash down this flavorful meal I had the Mango Lassi, which was good but the added salt was something I was not accustomed to in my Lassi.  Note - Lassi is a great drink but it will make you thirstier.  Make sure to have water nearby or you can end up drinking 10 lassi without blinking an eye. 

Service - The service here was great.  Everyone made you feel welcome, staff members seemed to put great effort into accommodating you, and ensuring your visit to their restaurant was a pleasant one.

Price - a little pricier than other places in the area but reasonable for the quality and quantity you receive, especially in downtown SF. 

Overall - Despite having that 311 song ringing in my head as I write this review, I will definitely visit this place again.  Next time I may try one of their desserts or hang out in their inviting lounge.  As this place will..." take me away from the norm".
author: Eric D.

description: I like the Santana Row one better, in terms of food. The ambiance here was much nicer, but the entrance is weird. The food wasn't that tasty; paneer appetizer (too soft), garlic naan (not fresh garlicy enough), raita (yum), saag paneer (bleh). I didn't get to try the famous drink they have (fire something..) bc we had just driven from Napa.
author: Kermy K.

description: Absolutely phenomenal food and great ambiance, perfect for dates!
author: A S.

description:
I've been meaning to check this place out for a while, and I finally did last weekend for dinner- definitely not disappointed.   Started out with some cocktails, of course and some pretty inventive options- all pretty tasty, but on the pricey side.  I don't eat much meat, so then followed with several veggie appetizers that we all shared.  My favorite appetizer was probably the pesto and goat cheese tikki- very tasty and also had a great dipping sauce- I believe it came with 5 pieces.  The paneer tikka lal mirch was also quite good.  I've had paneer tikka in a lot of different ways, so it's hard to find a unique take on it, but Amber really did a good job here.  

Next were the entrees.  The star of the show for me was undoubtedly the butter chicken- amazingly good.  I usually find butter chicken a little too creamy, but they really made it well flavored without being too heavy.  The baluchi chicken tikka was also quite good- just know that it's a non-curry chicken dish.   The dal amber and aloo asparagus were good vegetarian entree choices.   

The main complaint I had about the restaurant would have to be the prices- averaging about $20 per dish, definitely adds up to a steep bill by the time you're done.  But, overall, a great dining experience.  The restaurant is in a great location, right near the Four Seasons and also has a great bar area to grab a drink while waiting for a table.  The decor and ambiance is also welcoming and a fun place to come with a group.  Friendly, helpful wait staff too- we ended up having to change the number in our party about a million times, and they were very accommodating each time.   So, a great choice for an upscale North Indian restaurant in the city, if you don't mind dropping a pretty penny on a night out.
author: Urmi P.

description: This place was nice but big.  I felt a bit lost in the restaurant.  The food was good, but nothing special.  I would seek a smaller place that has more charm - and locals visit.  I think this might be a tourist trap.
author: Mark F.

description:
This place recently opened in the neighborhood and prior to my visit here, I had never eaten Indian food.  I have many friends who swear by it, but something about the smell of curry and spices when you even walk near an Indian restaurant that never really appealed to me.  It's the kind of smell that lingers.

I remember when I was in college, I went to look at an apartment, The 
add claimed it was newly remodeled and carpeted and painted.  Upon getting up to the stairwell landing, no one needed to tell me that an Indian family had lived there.  The strong smell of curry and other spices was permanently engraved in the fixtures despite the new carpets, and paint coating.  I digress.

My wife recommended this place because of a recent write up she read in the newspaper.  I agreed to go as I had nothing better to do and we had absolutely no food at home to eat.

Upon entering the restaurant, I was amazed by the decoration and fixtures.  Very clean and sleek.  The bar area was lit up like a Christmas tree.  I could not wait to indulge in its offerings.

However, the distinct smell of Indian cuisine permeated the air.  Luckily, it was not powerfully pungent or overwhelming.  it was more of a warm welcoming smell of good food being cooked here.

Our waitress, a cute, well mannered and pleasant host  delighted my wife and I with her interpretations of the menu.  Her recommendations were strong and highly considered but we did not venture too deep our first time around.  We played it safe and went with the signature dishes The Butter Chicken and the rack of lamb accompanied with Dal Amber and Saffron Pulao.  All delicious and excellent choices.

For our appetizers, we began with the Duck Tinka Kebab, the Smoked Sweet Potato Salad and our waitress accidentally brought out Aloo Peas Samosa.  She left it for us to enjoy at no charge since we had not ordered it.  

Overall, I overcame my prejudice of Indian food and gained a whole new dining perspective.  I was very pleased with my experience, the service and most important, the food.  

I will definitely revisit this place in the future!
author: Javier O.

description:
I love Indian food and was impressed with their location in Santana Row, so I was very excited to hear Amber was opening a new location in San Francisco.  My friends and I were attending a cocktail reception in SOMA, so we decided to have dinner at Amber afterward.  

I had heard rave reviews about their butter chicken from my colleagues, and it did not disappoint.  We devoured the butter chicken and its amazing sauce!  We also tried the Paneer tikka, the Malabari tiger shrimp, tandoori chicken and garlic naan.  Everything was delicious!  Although the food at Amber is much more expensive than the Indian restaurants in the Tenderloin, the amazing food and beautiful ambiance completely justifies the price difference.

The only reason I can't give Amber the five-star rating it deserves for the quality of food was the level of service.  Our server completely messed up our bill and had no idea what we ordered, so I had to name all of the dishes we ordered for her to redo the bill.  After waiting for the corrected bill for 20 minutes, the server overcharged my friend's credit card by $50, so we waited again for her to correct the charge.  

Since I absolutely loved the food at Amber, I still plan to return, but I'll wait a bit before my next visit in hope that they improve their service.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Big fan.  Check out the buffet on Saturday or Sundays.   For $20 you get to try many different dishes with Nan.  Great innovative and different beer list.  Manager likes good beer.  He has found some beers from Germany that you can only get on a seasonal basis and are on a short list for distribution.  Got to love that it is not the same old stuff that all other bars have.

 As for the food - we have gone twice and both times the food was really good.  Try the green condiment - it has nice sweet spice.  Great mix of flavors and the decor is tops for an Indian restaurant.  

Added plus: no screaming indian music playing in the background.
author: Doreen D.

description: I wish I could say I've never had better Indian food, or better Ambiance or Better Servers. But..  I've had better of all those things and hence Amber you'll get the 3 stars. Not a bad place if you've some good company!
author: Sumit G.

description: This is strictly a review on their Happy Hour which is weekdays from 5-7PM.  I reccomend definitely getting there before 6 to snag a table as it tends to get packed after that. Love the raised bar area, the decor and their bar menu. They are heavy on their wine pours which suit me just fine and for $5 a glass, really how could one go wrong???
author: Susana M.

description:
This is for the weekend lunch buffet. We arrived while they were still putting food out. The food was not bad but not that exciting either and the chicken dishes were lukewarm rather than hot. They had a dosa and uttapam station, and I ordered dosa but got uttapam; it was tasty but I had wanted to try dosas and left un-dosa'd.

Warning, the mixed vegs in sauce at the salad bar are meant to be consumed in very small quantity with other stuff. Don't pile it on your plate (not their fault, but a warning would be nice for us gringos).

Boos for the $1.25 health service fee added without prior warning on the buffet price list posted outside. I don't mind the fee itself but hate it being a surprise.

Would have been satisfactory (although still 3 stars) for a $10pp buffet tab but disappointing for a $20pp buffet tab.
author: Charles B.

description:
great food.  shoddy service.  at least management realized that the service was shoddy and made up for it.

we got there 30 minutes early to meet up w/ friends at the bar area.  after getting a few drinks for over 40 minutes, we started to wonder if the hostess was going to come by and let us know that our table was ready.  each person of our party had gone to ask about our table and each time we were told that we'd be told the moment a table becomes available.  

finally, after close to 30 minutes after we were supposed to be seated, i went and said this to the hostess and at that point she said OK let's seat you.  she sat our party of 4 at a huge round table that seats 8 and that is located right next to the kitchen.  we couldn't even hear each other talk.    at this point i hail down the manager and he immediately got to work on getting us a better table and sure enough he did.  he said that he would  make sure the food we ordered would make it over to our new table.

for apps we got the pesto and goat cheese tiki, murg taj tikka and calamari peri peri.  the tiki was a indian version of a poppers and were quite good.  the tikka was very flavorful and reminded us of my mom-in-law's chicken kebabs.  the calamari had great flavor but was a tad bit overcooked.

for mains, we got the basil chicken tikka, rogan josh, butter chicken and lamb chop "frontier".  the tikka was moist and unique with the basil flavor really shining.  the rogan josh was as good and traditional as it gets, the lamb was cooked very well.  the butter chicken was beautiful and rich.  the lamb chops were excellent and cooked perfectly.

management was very nice in comping us one round of drinks and the rest of the dining experience was very pleasant.

i've also been here for there lunch buffet and was not too impressed.

overall great food here.  if you can deal w/ the shoddy service then you'll have a great time!
author: Swarup B.

description: Man, one time I was here and they had a BEET DESSERT that tasted kinda like kheer, but with the most incredible MOUTH FEEL and flavor. It's so good, I love this place but what's with the 3 dollar chai?!!
author: Brittany L.

description: I love the food, decor and service.  The decor is first class.  I've been hooked on Amber since it opened and continue to take friends and family there.  It's such a nice place that I would feel comfortable and safe having a first date there with a lady who might not be familiar with Indian food.
author: Peace L.

description: Standard northern Indian food for double the price of most places. I won't go back. Kinda wish I owned it though. I'd sit in the back on a pile of samosas, laughing at all the suckaz.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
I'm no indian expert but I thought the food was great.  The girl and I went for a birthday dinner and loved most of it.  The butter chicken and naan was better than I've had anywhere else.  The Samosa's weren't that greasy and the soup we started with was excellent.

We had a lamb/rice dish that was a little heavy on saffron but the meat was super good.  Our waitress was a bit over the top with random commentary but her intentions were good.  

I'd go back for the eats for sure.  Not cheap for Indian for sure but compared to other restaurants with similar decor it wasn't extravagant.
author: Eamonn T.

description:
I am pretty traditional in my love of Indian cuisine, and when I saw that they put sun-dried tomatoes in their pullau and roasted portabella mushrooms in their raita I was both mildly insulted (whitey likes regular Indian food - really, we do) and expected the worst from the food. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The food, even the dishes with the superfluous "gourmet" ingredients, was pretty tasty. 

I believe I might have a different opinion if I had been paying for the food out of pocket. But as company lunches go, it's definitely not a bad place to go.

(If you ARE paying for your own meal and want something a little more authentic, go the extra three blocks and hit up the Chaat House.)
author: Angie R.

description:
Great Service. Beautiful ambiance. Chic Bar area. 
Just a bit over priced and the food was kinda bland -  strange for Indian food.
author: Peanut S.

description:
We went here for their Sunday lunch buffet.  We've been to the Mountain View location many times, and love the food - although I think the quality has slowly slipped a bit.  

The SF lunch buffet was far superior to Mountain View.  Many more choices, and very unique as well as tasty.  Love the butter chicken and one of the lentil dishes.  The only not so great dish was the naan which was too similar to bread, instead of being light, crispy.  Still would highly recommend.
author: Paul C.

description:
Had a great dinner! A great friendly, attentive staff, Amazing drinks recommended by the fantastic bartender, Best curry I've had in years!!! Yup, it ain't cheap but it is worth it!!! Had the sweet potato salad and tried some of the panner appetizer- spicy and delish! The Paneer and Korma mains were to die for!!!
Spicy and savoury not too hot and not too oil which is usually my complaint for indian food- although I love it dearly- not good for the waistline! But tell me something that is besides celery and working out???
I'll go back - not everyweek $$$$ but once in a while...
author: Cee R.

description: Since first starting this review I've been to Amber India three times and  each time deserved 4 stars.  What's great: The food - get the spicy lamb or the butter chicken - seriously those are fantastic. (Though the  last time I went they didn't have the spicy lamb on the menu).  What's even better: the bar area (which is a great place to stop into after work) and the drinks - get  the vodka w/ Chambord  & ginger beer.  What could be better: The service - each time I've been the service has been what made e stop from giving the pace 5 stars.
author: Natasha R.

description: I do not appreciate over sweetened Butter Chicken. Overall food was meh!!!
author: Jay S.

description: great food, lovely ambiance, but over priced when the customer service is factored in.  This is a 3 star review because it IS one of my favorites, but the reviewer who said the customer is never right IS right!  They spilled plum sauce all over my to go order and "apologized" as I had to get drippy plum sauce off of every thing from the carpet to the desk, the utensils (you get the picture)...For the price, you could do much better at Little Delhi on Ellis. Nothing like going somewhere they value you as a customer!
author: shelley p.

description:
I'm no expert in Indian food, but we had an enjoyable dining experience overall.
Our waitress was very friendly and provided good recommendations.
The butter chicken and Awadhi Lamb Biryani were the highlights of the meal - (both recommended by the waitress).
Great decor, location, food and staff member.
author: Linda T.

description:
i have never been a fan of indian food because my first experience was a HORRIBLE one, but Amber India brought me to a whole new level of appreciation of indian food.  for starters, the ambiance is amazing, first class service from the bar all the way through the dining area.  the servers were very attentive and gave great recommendations!  our server krishna was awesome! 

now on to the good stuff, the food:  AMAZING.  i highly recommend the duck kabobs and of course the naan bread with dipping sauces for starters.   main courses:  butter chicken and the seabass by far.   great establishment!
author: Daniella J.

description: Definitely a great place for an upscale dinner.  We arrived a few minutes early so the hostess lead us to a separate bar area.  The decor and ambience is beautiful.  Our hostess forgot to grab us so I had to get her attention to get seated.  Once we sat down, I immediately noticed that as dimly lit as the restaurant was, the lights that line the edges of the room are horribly bright and pinpointing.  It was a little blinding so my boyfriend and I scuffled the table a little to make it less distracting.  The food was amazing.  We ordered the paneer, tikka masala, garlic naan, basmatic rice and a few appetizers.  It was all delicious and the portions are massive.  The GM made his rounds and ensured that we were satisfied with our first time and offered some history regarding the owner and the other locations they have throughout Cali.  I would recommend this place to anyone!
author: Miko E.

description:
An Indian lunch buffet can be dangerous on so many levels. Luckily, the lunch buffet at Amber was dangerous-- but I liked it. 

The newly-opened decor reminded me of a Four Seasons Hotel. Amber is right next to a fitness club, and if you're lucky and you time it right, you can get a view of a yoga class next door on the second level. (Yeah, try stuffing some naan in your mouth and watch them work-out and NOT feel guilty. Dare you.)

The food was pretty good Indian. They had a variety of veggie options, including eggplant, spinach and those little round potatoes. I stuck mostly with the Paneer and rice, scooping it onto out hot naan. The service was pretty great, I will say. Never did our cup run on empty, and when our plates did go empty, they were taken away, making way for another round.

While Amber did not provide the best Indian food, it certainly was a nice way to spend lunch. The buffet will run you about $20/person.
author: Bryan B.

description:
Went to Amber India for date night prior to a movie downtown.  Have to agree with folks that the interiors are stunning.  I really liked the bar area.  Seems like there are good happy hour specials and a cool vibe among folks.  

The service was attentive and flexible, which we appreciated...  

Now to the food...  I thought that the sea bass was tasty, and the eggplant was good as well.  However, it was a bit pricey, considering what you could get from Naan and Curry or Pakwan.  I understand that this is a classy downtown place, but please.  

Overall, a good time, but will need to wait a bit to let my wallet recover.
author: Greg K.

description:
I'll give this place three and half stars. We've been there twice, once for the lunch buffet, and once for dinner. The decor is very nice, nicer than the one on Santana Row, although I did kinda like the shooting stars effect on the ceiling in Amber Santana Row. 

The second time we went, we made a reservation, only to have to wait for about 15 minutes when we got there. Which wasn't so bad, and I would be inclined to excuse that had we not been given one of the round tables up front. We had a party of four, and not only was the table too big, it was strangely high. I felt like a kid at the adults table.

The food at Amber is tasty, and the ingredients are of high quality. But the dishes are not the most authentic. Still, for the Bay Area, and San Francisco in particular, it is one of the best Indian Restaurants available. The Butter Chicken aka Chicken Tikka Masala is not bad, we had a lamb dish that was quite good, a shrimp dish that was very good, and an eggplant dish that was overly gingery. Too bad, I usually love eggplant. The Gulab Jamun is very nice, and the Halva is decadent and yummy. We'll be back, most likely with friends, as it's a nice environment to spend an evening with others. But my friend summed it up when the check arrived - it's the most expensive Indian food I've ever had.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Delicious indian fare, absolutely stylish interior design...

We ordered about 5 dishes, plenty of food for 3 people. The tiger prawns fried rice was impressive, about 8 tiger prawns cooked together with basmati rice. Yummy. Their mixed grill was nothing to shout about but the lamb seekh kebab was really awesome. I'm a big fan of mango lassi so each of us ordered a glass of mango lassi after my recommendation. As predicted, refreshing as well as very soothing after a meal of spicy food. 

I think Amber is really good for casual night out with friends/co-workers. It's not too noisy, so, this is really an awesome spot to mingle and chat. Their bar area seems to be pretty neat and very amazing decor. It's a little bit pricey for everyday dining, but definitely something on my list for a rewarding plus entertaining night with friends.
author: Amy Y.

description:
I've been here a few times on weekends for their lunch buffet. If you can't get past paying $20 for an Indian lunch buffet, stop reading now. 

The selection of food is pretty decent at the buffet and includes some non-standard food some of which is on the more innovative side. It seems like they use real quality ingredients in all their food which results in a very satisfying culinary experience. The problem is that the food goes down so easy, that you'll be reaching for your couch and remote five minutes after you're walked out of Amber. If you don't like lamb or goat, try it here. They get good quality meat and do great things with it.

Amber is the kind of place you'd go for a special occasion or to introduce newcomers to Indian cuisine. They have a nice wine and beer selection that you would expect when you're greeted by the restaurant's modern marbled decor. It is on the other end of the Indian food spectrum from Shalimar (a phenomenal hole-in-the-wall SF establishment ****). 

I would give Amber 4 stars, but they lose one for price. Note that they are expensive relative to other indian restaurants, but not other fine dining establishments.
author: Alexander S.

description:
I went here with my date a few days ago.   It was a nice upscale establishment, conveniently located near my work and his home.   The hostesses were very nice, even though it was a Saturday night, they managed to get us in.   

Our table was a nicely situated booth.  One suggestion I might have would be the proximity of the tables, they were a little too close in my opinion. 

The wine list was extensive, and I give them credit for that.  Also the waiter was very nice, and gave us plenty of time to order.  

The food was quite delicious.   They arrived in a good timed sequence. 

And then, I might say, the service went down hill.   I went to use the restroom, and my date told me that when I was gone the bus boy came and cleared off the table, also taking the plate from my date when he was still eating.  Even though I was finished,  I still think that is very rude, since I might have still wanted to eat some more when I got back. 

The bus boy then came back to the table when I came back and started wiping it down, shaking the table while at it, and not even apologizing for doing so.   Then to top it off, he stepped on my shoe!  Also without apologizing!  

And then, when my date and I were ready to leave our table,  I could see the bus boy waiting close by.  like a table over... not cleaning but waiting for us.   

I can understand that they might want to go home, and that it was getting late, but still.  That is no excuse. 

Also the restroom is what you might find at a food diner, totally not on par with the surrounding ambience.

The waiter I might add, when offered dessert refreshments, he mentioned chai tea.  and when my date and I ordered, he comes back and tells us that he is out...   Always bad to offer something, when something is not available.

I would rather prefer takeout from this place.
author: Thomas R.

description: Excellent food, lovely atmosphere, attentive staff.  We eat a lot of Indian food at up and down scale places, and the quality and presentation of this food is great.  Yes, you can eat perfectly good Indian for less, but the whole package here is worth the price.
author: D. M.

description:
If someone gave me the choice between high end fancy Indian food and a hole-in-the-wall in the 'loin, I'd choose the loin every time.  That is until I ate at Amber India.  To be fair I've only been there for their buffet, but in many ways that is a great way to sample many of the dishes at a restaurant at once.  

The ambiance an location is great.  The decorations are rich in color and elegant.  now onto the food...I wasn't expecting much, just your typical lunchtime Indian Buffet.  But I was proved wrong.  I started out with a bit of salad, Veggie Korma, Saag Paneer, and some Butter Chicken.  The first thing I noticed was that everything was piping hot, which is not always true for a buffet.  Secondly everything was flavored really well with some good spice.  The Butter Chicken was definitely my favorite, rich, tomato-y,and flavorful it packed a bigger punch than a typical Silicon Valley buffet.  The only part I did not care for was the Naan, which I found to be a bit stiff, chewy, and lacked the character that I like in my Naan.  Overall for 16.95 it is well worth the money.  You'll walk out full and satisfied.  I know I'll be back!
author: Stephanie T.

description: I had a fabulous dinner here yesterday before watching a movie at the Metreon.  This place is quite fancy and spacious, while the food matched the decor.  My date and I shared the butternut squash soup, butter chicken, chicken tandoori, rice, and naan.  The soup was delicious, as was the tandoori chicken which arrived on a sizzling hot plate with two sauces, a slightly spicy green and slightly sweet red.  We indulged the butter chicken that was smothered in a rich tomato sauce, which didn't go to waste as long as we had naan and rice to soak it up with.  This was a nice treat, since my date and I often dine at much lower budget Indian spots, where the food seems more greasy.  Next time I'm here I will try the cocktails!
author: Linda P.

description: I didn't know I could get Indian food for happy hour so I were happy when my friends decided we would meet there after work.  Great happy hour atmosphere and beer is only $3.  I quite like the very well marinated spicy chicken wings that comes with a very rich accompaniment of lots of onions and yellow bell peppers.  A well-portioned appetizer at a good price of $5.  The chicken wings are small though but  I guess it's the way it is for happy hour.  I also tried that dish that comes with mint sauce.  I wish I remember what it's called but I cannot right now.  I guess that means I'll go back to try out more dishes :)   One drawback, this place gets so noisy when it gets packed because there are big windows around and there is nothing there to absorb the noise.
author: Bella A.

description: An excellent restaurant with great food. I enjoyed the atmosphere, with lights toned down and great service. The food is Indian with a modern take on it. The appetizers were particularly creative. Definitely try the seafood while you're there. The only thing that really put me off was the fact that waiters (who were otherwise good) were really pushy at the end of the meal with the check. They came by 3 times to see if we had put a card/cash down yet or not. And came back within 15 seconds with the receipt for signature. I can understand such haste if the restaurant is very busy and it is a peak time but the guests had mostly left and it was almost 1130pm at this point on a Thursday night. I hope they improve on this for next time.
author: Vikram A.

description:
I had an overall decent experience at Amber India. Went on a Saturday night with three friends from out of town. 

The decor of the place was really nice, very modern/loungy/clubby feel to the place, with a nice lounge/bar area for me to hang out in as I waited for my perpetually late friends (30 minutes) to show up. Also, the restaurant was big, seemed like it could hold a lot of people.

But it did feel kinda strange that the place was pretty empty overall, I felt like virtually the whole restaurant staff was waiting on us that night (Saturday!?!). Don't get me wrong, they were extremely nice and helpful, and there were a couple other tables, but it felt as if there should be more patrons and the place would have been more lively. Also, it may just take some more time to get the word out.

Food was excellent, though quite pricey (4$ for rice??).

I'm definitely willing to go back sometime and see if the word on the place has gotten out. Also, need my wallet to recover a little :)..
author: Amit S.

description:
(Lunch Buffet)

Very tasty buffet items, wonderful Almond pudding dessert. Staff was OK, nothing special, but it's a buffet, who needs staff anyways ;)

Of all the Indian buffet lunches I've had, this place has the most interesting and sometimes unusual dishes. Plenty of selection for vegetarian to meat dishes with a couple of salad and dessert options.

Only downside is this is the most expensive buffet lunch I've ever had in my life. Not a place I can afford to visit often, but once and a while, when really hungry for some haute-cuisine Indian dishes, this would be a worth it.
author: Gordon M.

description:
Went here on a Friday night.  I was able to send an email and make reservations the day before (they got back to me the same morning).  There were a few available tables when we got there, but most of the tables were taken.  The ambiance was great, and the service was wonderful (our water glasses and wine glasses were always full, the staff checked on us, etc.)

We had the sun dried tomato/goat cheese and the smoked sweet potato salad to start.  Both were great, and the sauces that accompanied them were tasty (one was minty and the other sweet and sour).  They accommodated me and made me chicken tikka masala even though it wasn't on the menu (I asked how the butter chicken was compared to chicken tikka masala, and the waiter said they could make me tikka masala--my favorite!!).  The food was all great, and paired great with the Riesling.  The one downside is it's on the pricey side, though that could be because other than Dosa, I haven't been to more upscale Indian restaurants.  I've generally been to places like Naan N' Curry, where you'd get the same types of food (though not as tasty or clean) for a fraction of the cost.  But I would definitely recommend this place.
author: seta a.

description: this is by far the best indian food with alot of flavor and if u like spice this hits the spot the chicken tikka masala the butter chicken also the lamb is very good pretty much anything you order you cant go wrong at all, they have a few locations but in my opinion this one is the best and the decor is fabulous inside as well very upscale looking im indian and indian restaurants are hard to please me but this one for sure is excellent  so you must try!
author: Roshan K.

description: Lovely restaurant. Intimate ambience, soft lighting, warm earth tones.  Clean.  Delicious entree: chicken masala dish was excellent. Appetizers (names escape me) were equally as  wonderful. Apricot(?) sauce with naan, and the other sauce was perfect. No opportunity to try dessert so don't know if it's good. I imagine it would be.  I'd definitely come again.  Not advisable to bring little ones, which I did.
author: R S.

description: I came today for the sunday brunch, which is $19.95. They have a ton of food varieties including the butter chicken, which again was super delicious. They bring fresh naan to your table and today, it included a complimentary mango mimosa, which made the price very affordable. Amber India is sleek and modern and you do not leave smelling like food. Just be careful of overeating as you will want to take a nap soon thereafter!
author: Natalie S.

description: My wife and I took some friends to dinner here and were wowed by the ambiance, drinks and food. While the food was delicious, I felt the prices reflected the ambiance more than portion sizes or service. We will go back again because the drinks and food are worth it!
author: Daniel H.

description: Yum! This place is incredible! Definitely one of the best upscale, Indian restaurants I have ever tried. I also love that they have a few South Indian themed dishes and not just heavy curry options. I recommend the paneer and the butter chicken is also quite delicious. The weekend lunch buffet is one of the best deals in the city and I always leave feeling so full and content. Service could not be better and the ambiance is fun, hip and elegant - perfect for a night out. HIGHLY recommended!
author: Shannon F.

description: I went to a birthday dinner here with a fairly large party.  They gave us the large semi-private room in the back of the restaurant.  Though I don't remember exactly the dishes we had ordered, I remember walking out quite disappointed with the food.  Given the food is mediocre, I thought it was overpriced.  In addition, the service was extremely slow.  The only thing that I found positive about the restaurant is the ambiance.  The décor is modern and nice though you can't really tell it's an Indian restaurant.  You're really paying for the ambiance and not the food.  They also have a great selection of drinks and the lounge is cute, but the food is lacking...what a shame!
author: Jessica T.

description:
this place has great potential.

big space. cool sexy lounge and lighting. stiff drinks. 
there is a bit of a identity issue with the large plasma playing football and the traditional music that was so low, i asked to increase the volume so i don't have to hear the conversation of the group at the bar.

they need some world music like alcazar, barfly, or budda bar music to match the sexy ambiance.

the food though? yummy. and i travel to india up to three times a year.

1. raita was thick but light if that even makes sense. helps balance the heat from all the below dishes.
2. samosas were wonderful
3. sun dried tomato and goat cheese tikki was ok
4. lamb kebab was spicy and very good.
5. chicken tikka was also tasty.

I've gone a few times when it was quiet so it wasn't smoky. i heard that they allow it which is odd for sf.  i smoke cigars so i don't mind the smell. i could see though if you don't want to be inhaling second hand smoke while eating and drinking that it might not be the place for you.
author: Anh V.

description: Yes. Very tasty all around - the somosas and butter chicken are letter perfect - but felt a bit sting by the bill when it came.  Solo eats with one glass of wine +$50
author: Rick N.

description: Came here for a business dinner with a party of 6. The ambiance, service and food was great. It was nice that the food is served and portioned in such a way that the table can choose to share dishes or have their own. The Nalli Vindaloo (braised lamb shank) was our favorite!
author: Jamie J.

description: Very good. We ate there twice in fact. The lamb vindaloo had a nice level of spice. The cucumber martini was very good too.
author: B H.

description: mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.... ate at the bar last saturday.. food was so good that i am actually craving it again. the butter chicken was sooooo good!!!!!!!!! try any drink on the menu. the garlic naan and cheese filled naan were also scrumptious!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Best. Indian. Food. Ever.
I have been a longtime fan of Indian food, and I've eaten a lot of it: home-cooked, nice-restaurant, quickie-dive, chaat, street cart, takeout, I've had and liked it all. But the food we had at Amber really knocked my socks off.  
We started with the duck kebabs: moist and flavorful, not at all greasy. Then we had tandoori stuffed potato: potato Shells hollowed out and stuffed with nuts, veggies and delicious spices.  We also had the butter chicken. It was super-rich (actually, everything we had kind of fit that description, so I wouldn't come here if you're looking for a light meal), creamy, well-spiced, tender, and, well...buttery.  Enough adjectives? The tamarind sauce actually tasted like tamarind instead of just sugar syrup the way it often does, and the mint chutney was simply delicious! I felt like I could taste the spices in everything in a really amazing way, and everything had just the right amount of heat.  Even the naan and the rice were a cut above!
The atmosphere was romantic (we were in the side room in a corner, so it was more quiet than the rest of the restaurant), the service was attentive and friendly w/o being obsequious.
My waistline and my wallet probably couldn't withstand frequent visits, but I can't wait to go back!
author: J W.

description: outstanding food and atmosphere. Loved the scallops and okra. Affordable and fun too, :)
author: scott g.

description:
Went here for their weekend brunch with a big group. The food was ok - the typical. They had a good variety and had a live station for indian crepes. The service on the other hand was seriously lacking - just to order drinks we waited 10 mins and then they forgot and got it 20 mins later!!

Ordered bread and that took a good 15-20 mins and asking 3 people. Our food got cold in our plates just waiting for the bread. 

Ambience was good and the proce was reasonable for a buffett in the city.
author: P From CA C.

description: Went there for the buffet lunch today with a friend. The food was fresh and nicely spiced. The buffet selection included the usual stand-by dishes but executed very flawlessly. I clearly tasted the spices in each dish instead of the usual muddled, overcooked flavors. The dining room was contemporary and the tables were nicely spaced apart. Service was efficient and friendly. It was a bit pricey for lunch, $16.95, but well worth it.
author: Anh Thu V.

description:
With the kind of money they charge for Indian buffet, you had think that there would be some lamb, fish on the menu and there will be a huge variety of food. All they had was catfish with ajwain  (indian spice, mainly used in pickle) and it didn't deserve second helping, i wasn't even able to finish the first helping .

There was nothing on the menu that was remarkable. Only the pani used in golgappa was good. 

The dessert spread was also a disappointment. With 20 dollars charge you would expect some decent dessert, not at this place. 

Very average food.
Go to Bombay gardens for cheaper and better spread, it isn't amazing but its only 10 bucks and better than amber. 
or better yet go to Pakwan in mission and have a blast for 20 dollars. go with Friends to pakwaan, order a variety of dishes and have your own buffet. 

 positive- Service and ambiance
author: snigdha c.

description: 2/5 is the best rating this can get... I ordered naan, some chicken curry and chicken biryani....naan is made of wheat ( that was a surprise..coz never I have eaten naans made of whole wheat which I didn't like though) and chicken curry has lot of mustard seeds....(who would put mustard seeds in a chicken curry....obviously the gravy doesn't feel rich)  and the biryani is good ...but...I have been cooking biryani's from the past 5 years and am pretty sure they used some packet masala....... Not worth trying this restaurant with that kind of prices....
author: Louie C.

description: Restaurant was crowded on a week night and a good mix of Indians and non-Indians. A good sign. They were kind enough to accommodate us immediately despite our being 30 minutes late to our Open Table reservation. The food options were a very eclectic choice. Most were based on a typical Indian dish (North Indian for most part with a few exceptions) but they often had a unique twist. It made it hard to choose  one item to eat. We went with the Malabari shrimp curry as an app which was full of flavor with a strong spice that didn't overpower the flavor but you definitely noticed by the end. For my meal I had an excellent Lamb Korma. The meat was very tender and the curry was similar to the shrimp - lots of great flavor and a variety of spices you could taste but the heat was complimentary and not overpowering. The only exception to our meal was my companion's order of a Tandoori Four Chili  Sea Bass. The fish was very well cooked and juicy from the yogurt based marinade but it did not have any chili flavor let alone 4 chilies. We even asked the waitress if we had gotten the wrong dish but she insisted it was not.  All in all a great meal and I would definitely come back since there were so many other interesting choices on the menu.
author: Shankar S.

description: Delicious food, high energy atmosphere, trendy place, great service.  Would go again.
author: Jane S.

description:
I can still remember segments of the training session that I went through for my first restaurant job.  One of the principles laid down by management was, "...never mislead the guest, especially about how long they will have to wait for a table."  

Unfortunately our experience at this restaurant got off on the wrong foot.   We arrived on a Friday night, expecting there to be a wait for a table.  (Read the last sentence carefully, we expected to have to wait for a table!)   When queried as to the length of the wait, the hostess responded, "no more than 20 minutes tops."  Based on this assurance that the wait would be brief, we grabbed a table in the lounge and ordered a drink.  Carried away with the good company of our group, we didn't notice that 45 minutes had elapsed.  I marched off to the hostess stand and asked for our table.  We waited another 15 minutes before being seated.  I relayed my displeasure with the long wait  to the hostess by asking her to reference when we were placed on the waiting list.  We were displeased with our handling but not because we had to wait.   No, no. no, we were displeased because the amount of time that we had to wait was far beyond what was promised.  

In all fairness, the restaurant responded perfectly.  The manager came to our table, and expressed his sorrow that the wait time provided to us was inaccurate.  

The complimentary appetizers were excellent.  For the three of us we ordered two entrees and rice and shared them family style.  Good move.  It was a lot of food.  The quality was very good.  The spices did not overpower the entrees.   I can't recall the name of the dish, but there is a shrimp appetizer which comes in a dark sauce.  This was so very, very good.  If you go here, ask for this appetizer if you can't discern it from the menu.  

We skipped dessert.  All in all we had a pleasant and enjoyable experience.  We were especially thankful that the ambiance did not include cheesy Indian music playing in the background.  Instead, you can expect a modern dining room with subdued lighting and full of conversant, full of life clientele.  I will return to this place, but I will make a reservation next time.  

Hope you enjoy it.
author: Richard R.

description:
As one would expect from upscale ethnic cuisine, the food here is pretty white-washed. The decor here is nicer than at any Indian restaurant I've ever seen, but don't let that fool you into thinking that your $15 entree actually tastes like it's worth $15.

Come here if you're looking for some decent-to-good Indian food in a high brow venue. But don't come here thinking that you're getting excellent Indian food.
author: Nuveen D.

description: Ordered naan and butter chicken. The naan was OK and the butter chicken was pretty good and rich. I would come back but the prices are a bit expensive for the quality of food for me to highly recommend this place.
author: Chas B.

description:
Not bad, not great.  We sat at the bar for dinner and ordered roganjosh Lamb, a shrimp appetizer, chili naan and rice.  The lamb dish was nice and pretty standard.  The shrimp appetizer was solid as was the accompanying mint sauce.   Food in general was good. 

The bad:  The bar service was like amateur hour.  It was quiet so there should have been a lot of attention paid to the customer but instead the bartenders spent their time and energy listening to some loud talking manager and cleaning up behind the bar.  I had to call the bartenders over to order, had to point to the items on the menu since the menu is still unfamiliar to them and had to push them for a drink.  

Atmosphere is interesting.  Alot of money was spent on the bar and I personally like it, but S.F. doesn't typically go for this type of thing.  Also, the layout of the rest of the restaurant is extremely awkward with an entry door kind of less obvious than the emergency exit further down the alley.  

All in all, it needs some serious work on service while the food is good.
author: Nick S.

description:
Came here on a weekday night to celebrate our last dinner together with my sister. I was surprised that the interiors were nice with clean designs and the dining room is spacious. We ordered the Aloo Peas Samosa, it was ok, nothing special about it. Then the rest of our food came together - I learned that's how they do it in India and the server portions out the food in your plate. I loved the butter chicken although it is pretty expensive for the small size. The goan scallops were good too. We also had the saffron rice, pesto and garlic naans. The latter was an additional order and it came late but the server, Margarita did great and after we followed up for it, came right out. The Elaichi Korma was just some broccoli, corn and carrots (recommended by our server) but it wasn't that great. For dessert, I decided to try the Kulfi since I haven't had it before. It was just the ice cream shaped like a cone on a plate with some sauce and sprinkled with pistachios...very expensive for $8 but still good. The bottle of wine we got, a 2006 Pinot Grigio, paired very nicely with our dinner. 

I guess I won't mind paying a lot more for an upscale indian resto (once in awhile). Food and service is great, as well as the ambiance. I was glad that we ended up eating here for a special dinner with my loved ones. I will definitely be back to try out their lunch buffet for $20.
author: Eloise L.

description:
Currently, it is the Best upscale Indian in SF. 

Location & Place: A bit hard to find, yet once finding it you will understand the great location. When entering, a welcoming level of sound, mild smell of Indian food, and good lightening surrounds you. 

Food: Superb chicken dishes. Appetizers were great  (kebab, some sea food). Good Naan. 

Why not: A bit pricey, main courses are small in size.
author: Guy H.

description:
awesome find! after already throwing back drinks with co-workers, additional much needed celebratory drinks were in order! we literally stumbled upon amber india and that was the best thing ever. the bar area was pretty quiet and totally intimate. 

we ordered a couple glasses of proseco and the bartender offered to add elderflower, which is now my most favorite thing in the world! i'd love to try this place out for dinner someday. my only regret was that we were offered a bottle of champagne, but declined since we'd already had 4 drinks...but ended up drinking enough glasses to equate to a full bottle! oh well, next time!
author: Marjie T.

description: The environment is cosy. The seats are fairly good. However the waiters were kinda kept asking us if we finished the dinner. Anyway, it's worthy for having another dinner in there.
author: Yubo Z.

description: Being Indian and a food fanatic we don't very often eat Indian out. We were very impressed with the service, food and the ambiance - all three were amazing! Highly rate this restaurant all 5 stars. We loved all the dishes we tried - bengan curry, malai kofta, yeallow dhal, spinach chaat, naans and salad...were all presented and served with that little extra touch you don't often get in other Indian restaurants. The food has been prepared to cater a diverse crowd, but it was still very delicious.  It was my pleasure to write a review for Amber.
author: Ashmita P.

description: Very good lunch buffet. Nice ambiance and location too.  The servers are attentative. Can improve on the desserts though.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Go here for an upscale Indian meal when you're in the area.  The ambience was modern and chic, the service was good, but the food was a little dumbed down.  We didn't get the heat that we requested, and while my chicken tikka was perfectly cooked, it was lacking in spice.  My husband got the lamb korma, which was nicely cooked as well, but the spice level was just not there.

It has a nice drink/wine menu.  You end up paying for the location.  Two drinks, two entrees, one appetizer, and naan ends up costing you close to a $100.  Not unreasonable, but not what I normally pay when eating Indian.
author: Carol R.

description: Amber restaurants probably serve the best Indian food in the bay area. This restaurant in the city has a great lunch buffet for it's variety, taste and atmosphere.  This is also a great place for a stylish dinner in the city.  My last visit there I tried the Kozhi Melagu and it was very flavorful.  It's a South Indian black pepper chicken dish and I really enjoyed dipping naan bread in it.
author: M. B.

description: I have been to Amber India a couple of times, and I enjoy the food here. My favorite dishes here are: Moong Salad, Panner Tikka, Spiced Okra, Black Dal and the Raita. The food is flavorful and tastes excellent. The portions are good sized (can share with another person). I also enjoy the drinks here, I had the kiss of buddha and the raspberry drink. Service is good, the food was hot when served. The price are slightly high but worth it if you enjoy Indian food. If you are looking for a good Indian restaurant in the city, I would suggest this one. Neat and classy atmosphere at the restaurant. Suggest to make reservations before going.
author: Anu R.

description: I tend to avoid indian food, as it's quite heavy and I don't know what it will do to my stomach.  However, Amber India was truly a delight.  It's upscale indian food but done very well.  We ordered mostly vegetarian items like the spinach, fritters, lentils, eggplant, cauliflower.  There were a few meat eaters in the group so the tandori chicken and fish was ordered as well. Everything was sooo delicious and the quality of the seasoning and preparation was quite evident.  This place is not cheap, so it's best for more special occasions or the business lunch.
author: Ka C.

description: Love to location, decor, friendly staff (waitress was a bit too friendly...haha) and food was also delicious! We made a reservation but it took a short wait to be seated. It was packed. Bar area was welcoming. We started with a duck appt. We also ordered the butter Chicken, Lamb Shish, and Lamb Biryani. We also ordered three Naan baskets- two would've been fine! Food was tasty and better than expected. Usually the hole-in-the walls are the most authentic tasting but I would highly recommend this restaurant.
author: victoria r.

description:
amber has a pretty decent happy hour that goes until 7pm, featuring $3 beers, $5 cocktails and $5 bar bites... but make sure to check out their regular bar menu, which features $3-4 naans (including a delicious pesto and the keema naan with minced lamb!). the pimm's on amber is pretty tasty, and they make their manhattans with bulleit bourbon, too.

centrally located in the wind tunnel called yerba buena lane, this place is definitely worth checking out after a long day at work!
author: Andrey C.

description: Amber India serves fantastic, beautiful, spicy, fragrant food.  I've taken lots of groups there and my guests are always blown away.  It's not your basic Indian spot -- this is a white tablecloth place and prices are in line with the quality and atmosphere.  That makes it more expensive than most Indian places, but it's totally worth it.  This time 3 of us shared the duck kabob appetizer and the butter chicken, lamb roganjosh, and Jaipuri bhajan (okra) with some naan and rice.  Everything was delicious, and it was more than enough food.
author: Robert W.

description: This place is pricey, but the food is some of the best I've had of its kind. The lamb was ridiculously tender, and the tandoori chicken was cooked to perfection. We also tried the butternut squash soup, which had just about the most interesting combination of spices I've tasted in a long time, and the crabcake, which was a well-designed balance of flavors. The only place where Amber might improve is in the energy of the staff -- while they are all very friendly and attentive, there is a bit too much of a California-casual vibe for a place of this quality. That said, I still give it five stars because the food was so damn good.
author: Tal R.

description: One of the best Indian buffets in the bay area. A little pricey but you get what you pay for. Very authentic and flavorful.
author: MrsNIFTY G.

description:
like my buddy Erin S. says, "I smell 4 stars!"  we like absinthe and never quite know what to mix it with until we got to happy hour here and the bartender offered to mix us up some trial absinthe drink- corpse survivor (a pale green drink shaken vigorously with absinthe, gin, lillet, lemon and mint) and another absinthe cocktail that looked like a greenish lemon drop with a sunken cherry in a martini glass.  we were beyond impressed, to say the least, and she gave it to us for $5.  our friend Hun Hun loved the sour hit of the corpse survivor and downed it in 2 seconds.  the bartender was friendly and chatty and open to suggestions for improving the drink.  lucky us!

the bathrooms are super fancy and smell like a nice cantaloupe.  the restaurant was completely deserted even though it was dinnertime.  i would much rather order some bar snacks and sit in the lounge during happy hour.
author: Holly B.

description:
I give it 2 stars because the nahn, roti and sea bass were good.  Other than that, I found it underwhelming.  The butter chicken and lamb tasted like they were seasoned in the exact same way.  

The cocktails were atrocious.  Every "specialty" on the cocktail menu was unbalanced.  I tried each of my friends' cocktails and they all made me wince.  The ambiance is nice, but not sure I will return.
author: A J.

description: Probably the most different chicken tikka masala I've had. Yes, it's not on the menu but like for the others here they were happy to make it for me. Over the years I've probably tried more than 15 Indian restaurants around the world. This was the first for me that served tikka masala with a really thick sauce, barely enough to cover the rice. Oh and why do some Indian restaurants include rice automatically and some make you order? Anyway, the chicken tikka masala was good, garlic naan too.  Giving three stars only because I didn't walk out telling myself I can't wait to come back. Service was great.
author: David T.

description: I have reviewed the Amber in Santana Row, which has been consistently good. I have eaten here a number of times each time the service was good. We ate here on a Saturday evening, I had made reservations, when we arrived, the guy/ Mgr at door said no such name on his computer, I even recognized his voice from my call. I asked him to look again despite his stressing, no reservation. Then  he said yes it's here. When I asked how come he didn't see it earlier, he snapped at me that " youre 3 mins early"!!  To be fair it was a busy night for them but to have attitude for no reason speaks to the level of unprofessionalism that is the norm in most Indian restaurants. This was no different. We were finally seated in an area which was in the walkway in front of a pillar and high traffic for servers. I requested a different table, there was one empty in next booth. The woman who took us to the table snapped " it will be another half hour to 45 mets" again I was taken aback at the expression and attitude. In fairness the mgr did say it wouldn't be that long. We ended up sitting and eating at bar and when our table was ready and she came to tell us I kindly told her we were ok where we were, which again garnered an irritated glare. I thought I was helping them since I was already seated and this would allow others waiting to get a table sooner. A bad experience to say the least. The food was " meh". I will avoid this restaurant in the future. I am sure they don't care. And that's the point here. They don't care.....
author: G P.

description: This is my favorite Indian restaurant anywhere.  I am FAR from an Indian food expert, because until recently I never lived in a place that had much good Indian food.  But, I like Indian food a lot and I LOVE Amber.  I've been for weekday lunch, weekend brunch and once for dinner.  The best deal as far as I can figure is the $12 weekday lunch buffet, if for no other reason than you can sample just about everything.   It seems to always include the butter chicken (yes, it is that good as others have said), two other meat dishes, at least one fish dish, three or four vegetablees, the paneer, chick pea dumplings, several salads and dessert.  Yes, I know there are $6 lunch buffets all over but they aren't this.  A beautiful, elegant setting, a very extensive buffet selection, highly professional service and truly fantastic food... not typically found for $12, let alone $6.  So, back to my original point.. I don't claim to be an Indian cuisine aficianado.  So, I asked my apparently Indian and apparently honest server (after confirming that he was, indeed, from India), "So tell me, is this really good Indian food?  Because I think it's great, but I don't know what's considered great by Indian standards."  His response, "It's very good.  There's other places you could find more exotic authentic dishes but the food here is very good by Indian standards.  It is one of the four best in the area."    He went on to tell me that of the four, one is in the East Bay, one is on the Peninsula (so I promptly forgot their names since I don't frequent these areas), and the fourth is Dosa on Fillmore.  He cautioned me againest Dosa in the Mission, but said Dosa on Fillmore is where Indians love to eat... as well as Amber.  I believe him.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I went in yesterday.  The food was excellent.  High quality, although yes, possibly not the most authentic (its sort of a fusion tailored to a western palate, I believe), but definitely delicious.  Tried the Shrimp Moilee and Butter Chicken and its recommended.  I think there is a further opportunity to improve upon it and make it a little lighter and healthier in terms of the sauces and hence only 4 stars.  Also perhaps more innovative if its not meant to be completely authentic fare

The service was excellent and our waitress and table staff were very attentive, polite and did a great job.

The one aspect of the restaurant I did not appreciate was the lighting..  The spot lighting around the periphery of the restaurant space was garish and quite uncomfortable.  Direct lighting in a restaurant is NOT a good idea.  I provided the feedback but was not sure if the restaurant was quite as receptive toward it.  Although the general ambiance is good, there is more opportunity to improve the ambiance in the restaurant with the lighting and make it a more pleasing dining experience given the higher dining price than your regular neighborhood Indian restaurant.
author: Leroy R.

description:
Came in on a Sunday for a quick dinner with a friend. Sat at the bar area so I can't comment on the regular dining room. The space has a nice atmosphere and is very clean. 

Overall the service and food were good. We ordered the Samosa, Butter Chicken, a spiced fish dish, rice, nan and some other stuffed Nan dish. Main entrees are good. Everything else was decent. Only gripe was the bill came out to $120 which included a couple of beers for each of us.  

Probably won't come back for dinner but may a good happy hour spot.
author: John C.

description: delicious food!! like absolutely delicious! definitely my favorite in the city for north indian food.. everything is really good!! including the cocktails  :)
author: Malika S.

description: We came here late on a Friday/Saturday nite right before closing and they sat us down immediately (awesome). It had an upscale Indian food setting, similar to Roti but a lot bigger inside. I think our server forgot about us, since they shoved us to the very back room (fine by me a lot quieter and a room to ourselves) but the manager took our orders. We had the butter chicken (fantastic), garlic naan (decent), and the four chili rubbed fish kebab (skip next time). It felt very formal, like I was at a steakhouse or something, where they bring your food out and explain what it is and serve you. I want to come back for their lunch buffet since that is what everyone seems to rave about. They are pricey for dinner, so the lunch buffet might be more bang for your buck. I will definitely be back soon.
author: Kristy H.

description: Mmmm, butter chicken!  I've had many different dishes here, and have loved them all, but the butter chicken is pure love. For drinks, the Indian Rain is delish if you like them sweet and tart.
author: Desirea C.

description: WOW we loved this place! We went for a pre-theater dinner, and were pleasantly surprised. I've had great India food (even lived in northern India for four months) but this food was really special. Well seasoned, well balanced. Service was great, and the decor is warm and inviting. A class act all around.
author: Richard T.

description: A little over priced for all it is, but the decor was lovely, and its in a great location. Unfortunately, I was on a date with a regular last week, and it ended badly, so I doubt I'll ever be back.
author: Polly Prissypants ..

description: A lot better for lunch now that they took the price of the buffet down from $20+/person.  I think it's now around $16 and on a hungry afternoon it's worth it.  Also good for dinner but make sure to call ahead.  Sometimes when the conferences are in full swing this place can get crowded.  The naan is addictive, especially the chili and garlic flavors, and I would especially recommend the butter chicken, which is simply perfect.  Each visit the service has been slow for our table but others sometimes seem to be visited often, so perhaps some inconsistency on that front.  Cost wise still on the high end of what you would expect for good Indian, but I think the modern, contemporary ambiance (especially in the bar area) helps them target the business crowd.
author: Matt C.

description: I have eaten here 5 times and I LOVE IT. I am to the point where I just let anyone else at  the table order whatever they want - its ALL so good that I don't care what they bring. Great service, good cocktails, wonderful lighting so everyone looks great.  Best sexy indian food in san francisco. get there!!
author: patricia d.

description:
This is a very sexy restaurant.  The ambiance is amazing, and the decor is beautiful.  I am a huge proponent of the importance atmosphere to the dining experience as a whole, so +2 stars for the vibe alone.  The location is great too.  All it was a very aesthetically pleasing experience.

That being said, the food was good but not excellent.  I had the butter chicken, and the sauce was great, especially with the rice and naan, and the portion was HUGE, but I don't think that this is the best Indian food I've ever had by any means.  I would come here again, but I do think that its a bit overpriced if you base the calculations on quality of food.  

Basically, if you are down to pay $$$ for good food and amazing ambiance, this is your place.  However, if you consider ambiance to be secondary, you should probably look elsewhere for Indian food.
author: Jackie D.

description: Had dinner at Amber India this past Saturday night. I am a very picky eater when it comes to Indian food. They made chicken tikka masala for me as it wasn't on their menu. My date had the Butter Chicken which I thought tasted more like Chicken Tikka Masala and which I did like much better. We had some naan and a few sauces to start. I thought the service was excellent and the food was pretty good. If you want chicken tikka masala- definitely go with the butter chicken! That was especially good! The dishes don't seem that large but the food is pretty heavy! We had our dishes with naan and rice. A great comfort meal and great atmosphere!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Really good! And classy.
In SF on business and wanted a great dinner - especially to reward someone for hard work. He chose Indian, I chose the place (from yelp). We had the butter chicken, some lamb dish, and the eggplant balls - and some other stuff. All great! Great service. Have since recommended it to others who can afford the pricey menu.
author: Sue F.

description: This place was a nice refuge from the crazy creepy outerspace that is Union Square. As you walk up you notice the bar is visible from the outside with floor to ceiling glass walls and it kind of interests you to check it out a little more. The dining area is just as nice with a relaxing ambiance and good dinner music. I got some fruity cocktail that was very good and very strong. The menu is actually very overwhelming with so many delicious sounding options! I got an eggplant vegetarian dish and my friend got some variation of chicken curry. We were both very pleased with our dishes. Overall, I was pleased with my dining experience but the reason behind my four star rating is because of the service/server. It kind of took a while to receive our drinks initially and when we asked the server about the different spices or ingredients he "didn't know." I thought that was kind of weird, isn't that your job to know? I just felt for the prices and the atmosphere this place is trying to create, the staff should be on par with that and have more knowledge of what is on the menu. But, I bottom line, I would definitely go back.
author: Michelle M.

description: Long wait for the food, but understandable due to the fact that we ordered the tandoori lamb - which was perfectly cooked and delicious. If we would have known we would have ordered some appetizers. Plus, it seemed like the chicken had been sitting waiting for the lamb too - but overall delicious. Oh, and as everyone said - the butter chicken is a must.
author: Chelsea J.

description: This is my favorite Indian restaurant in the Bay Area. It's a medium sized restaurant, but it is not loud or noisy.  You can easily have a quiet conversation. It's nicely decorated, but not highly fancy.  I love the Indian food here. Before becoming vegetarian  I loved the chicken tikka masala. I also love the vegetarian entrees. Our family always gets the "frontier naan". It has fruit inside. I enjoy the dal, and also the mattar paneer , malai kofta, gulab jamun, and most all the vegetarian entrees. It's hard to choose.  My husband tends to get the lamb seekh kebab. Service is good. I have ordered out from here a few times for dinner parties. I would definitely order to have it ready 20 minutes earlier than you thought you would want it. A couple times I was in a panic because they were running late.
author: Rosanne P.

description: Good but not as good as the Mountian View location or the Santana Row one.
author: Joe B.

description:
Nice atmosphere (not casual) and very attentive staff (we were eating before the crowds).  The food was ok - I had fish and it flirted with a tad bit too salty.  Also the paratha was less layered than I'm used too - it was almost but not quite just a thick flat bread instead of a flaky layered bread. 

Depending on where you're seated you might find yourself feeling like you'd been placed in a fish-bowl as the windows onto the plaza (if it can be called that) are expansive.

We came here early on a weeknight and there was NOBODY in the place - in fact the serving crew was having a pre-night meeting in the back glassed 'meeting room' section of the dining room.
author: Joel S.

description: Pricey for salty food.  This is the absolute worst Indian food I've ever had! The positive is that I only had 6 small pieces of chicken as my meal so I didn't have to force too much down. Yes 6 pieces of dry, salty chicken for $24. Never again.
author: Petromela B.

description: This is one of my favorite Indian restaurants in SF. Great food in an upscale setting!
author: Liss J.

description: Ok, this is good friggin food.  I've eaten a lot of indian food.  And this is good.  Get your girl, grab her hand and your wallet, cause you'll need it, and go get you some chicken makhani with naan.  It's dimly lit, and you can go walk in the park afterward.  I recommend this place, but I have to tell you, it's not health food.
author: Amir B.

description: love it...everytime  we go there its a delight....best indian food in the bay area...highly recommend it
author: A S.

description: Talking about spicy, this is totally different kind of spice, unlike Thai food, the Indian cuisine spice is a lot more intense, the flavor linger for quite a while,  I ended up with a pretty bad heart burn but love the taste.  Samosa, is delicious, overall my lunch experience was quite an interesting experience and bombarded with the spices but  what really help is the Mango Lasi
author: P C.

description: Well executed Indian food that one cannot find everyday.  They do the basic dishes well and there are dishes that you just won't find in your local Indian hole-in-the-wall.  Service is good, well-appointed interior, but somehow the food lacked character.  No pizzaz.  Soul-less Indian Food?
author: Laurence H.

description: So this is for the one that is in the Farmers Market in the Metreon (whatever it is called now. Anyone know??). Yum 6 bucks for tandoori with curry rice and 2 for a samosa. I was in heaven. If you want to do Amber in style this location is a nice way to go. Hit the MOMA and the Jewish Contemporary Arts and then dine fabulous at Amber. If you want to schlep it in the gardens then hit the one in the farmers market.
author: Monera M.

description: Lovely upscale Indian restaurant.  Food is flavorful and delicious.  Mixed drinks are also enjoyable.  Much prefer the flavors available at Amber over Dosa (either Filmore or Mission locations).  The butter chicken is to die for - I'm salivating right now just thinking about it.  Service is prompt and courteous.
author: Lev E.

description: I had the chicken tikka massalla (SIC) -- my favorite Indian food, ever, and I've eaten a lot of Indian food in my day. This Indian food is that flavorful. I went for the regular dining experience, not the buffet. A lot of places tone down the flavor, but this place refuses to do so! Expensive, but worth it!
author: Epicurean _.
