description: Modern, upscale ambiance. Hip bar/lounge. The butter chicken sauce was quite heavily tomato flavored; I didn't find many hints of yogurt or other flavor underneath. To be fair, the menu did point out that it was a tomato-style sauce. I'm not 100% sure the food merits the high prices charged, but overall, it was quite good and I left full and happy.
author: Al I.

description: I've come here often with my partner in crime to indulge in some needed libations after work on many occasions. The big open windows are perfect for people watching (although they become problematic if co-workers walk by when I am already finishing my first drink at 4:30 PM). They have $5 drinks and apps during Happy Hour which fits into my budget nicely.  The service is always superb and my fave bartender Chelsea practically has a drink waiting for me when I arrive. They also installed a large flat screen, so if conversations lulls - you can check the score of the game. I plan to spend a good amount of my hard earned cash here in the months to come.
author: Megan C.

description:
I've been waiting for Amber to open since they started remodeling the space.  I was really pumped for it.  It looked so cool inside.

I haven't been this disappointed since the Milli Vanilli scandal broke.  In 1990.  When I was 7.

I arrived about 10 minutes behind the rest of the group.  I walked in and started making my way to the back of the restaurant but was stalled because I couldn't figure out how I was supposed to get there: the only immediately obvious route (you know, the one that goes like, from where you're standing to where you want to go) - was blocked by people sitting at tables.  But no, it turns out you are actually /supposed to/ squeeze between those peoples' chairs to get to the back of the restaurant.  Okay...sure.  Whatever.  Sorry to the guy I tapped on the head with my messenger bag.

I sat down.  They had water, but nothing else.  The drink guy came along shortly and took our drink orders.

Then we waited.

Drinks arrived maybe 10 minutes later, short one - quickly fixed.  Whatever...okay, sure, opening night, get your act together, cool.  Oddly, though, no one seemed to want to take our food order.  I mean, they like /really/ didn't want to hear it.  I started the timer on my watch.  At about 10 minutes, we asked the water guy if we could order.  Mind you this is 10 minutes on my watch, which is like -10 for the rest of the group.  So we'll call it about +20 minutes, we asked the water guy if we could order.  Sure, he says.  But oddly no one came to get our orders.  Then the drink guy returned (he had introduced himself as the sommelier, more or less), and we asked /him/ if we could order.  Sure, he says.  But oddly, again, no one arrived.  So really, the most obvious interpretation of this is that they just really didn't want to take our order.  Maybe they were ordered out.  Maybe they were just confused on the first night of business.  But really...just take the order.  You don't even have to make the food, but come on, at least take the order.

At any rate, another 15 minutes passes as this is going on.  Finally I stood up, walked into the other room, and /touched/ someone who had just come from another table taking an order, and told her we would really like to order.  She snapped to attention and took our orders immediately.

Then we waited.

At T+55 minutes, most of our food splashed down, including our appetizer.  The bowl of rice took another 5 minutes.  The *rice* came 5 minutes after the rest of the meal.  What, did you run out of rice?  Do you not have enough rice-making capacity to produce sufficient quantities of rice with 5 groups eating in your massive restaurant?  You could've started making the rice when we walked in and had it ready to go.  You had 55 minutes to make the rice.  I'm just sayin.

As for the food - the butter chicken (also known, more or less, as chicken tikka masala) was neither here nor there.  The actual sauce was really well prepared, very creamy, well spiced - but the first two pieces of chicken I ate caused me to ask my foodmates if I had been served "off the gristle end of the chicken," and the large piece of meat in the middle of dish which I expected to really enjoy turned out to be decently overcooked.

So basically, guys...get it together.  For serious.

Also, as Cody C. pointed out to me...their web gallery (http://www.yelp.com/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.amber-india.com%2FSanFrancisco%2F%3Fgallery%2301) is just stock photos from the OS X wallpaper collection.  really?
author: Oliver N.

description:
On only it's second day in the big bad world, we decided to check out Amber for lunch because it was close and presumably nice. It certainly looks fancy with its marble floors, upstairs full bar, marble staircase leading down to a marble foyer where there was a buffet set up. The dining room also looks fancy. It has large booths on either side and tables in the middle. Perhaps it's the size of the furniture rather than the number of tables, but it seems overcrowded and you have to carefully walk between them to get to the nicely set up private room at the back. It has glass doors that were opened to make the dining room larger, but seems like a nice spot for a private gathering for around 25.

Our hostess was very nice and we were greeted by our waiter almost immediately. I wanted to order a la carte because no Indian lunch buffets (I know of) are ever hot enough for me to enjoy, but the prices of the entrees made it clear that the $20 buffet was the way to go. The food looked good, certainly smelled good and there was a nice variety of dishes. We were told naan would be brought to our table, which took a good 10 minutes after we got back to our seats. The naan was just alright for me - I like it thick and bready, but this is the more thin airy variety. The food was, as I fully expected, not spicy, but it was flavorful, well prepared and, except for some fatty lamb, had great texture. I particularly liked the saag, which had cherry tomatoes and some excellent paneer.  The Indian rice pudding and fruit desert was very nice. Probably my favorite part of the meal.

If the folks last night felt ignored, I felt almost inundated by the service as new people kept coming by the check on us. I got the feeling that either they had nothing else to do since it was so empty (at 12:30pm) or they were genuinely worried we weren't OK. Although the naan took 10 minutes, everyone was at least responsive when we mentioned it - yeah, I said everyone. We thought it was a little odd, so we decided to look up the reviews from last night; I was amused by how bad they were compared to our current experience. Ah, the wonders of modern technology. About this time, some manager type person (who later ID'd himself as Eric's infamous Mr. Slicky McPinstripe Pants) came over to check on us and made a comment about Aaron's Yelp shirt. We talked about Yelp for a sec and that our friends had been there the night before. This guy seemed super eager to please us, but it bothers me when staff pulls the Yelp card because I don't know if they're doing it because they're scared of us or because they want to be nice or because the service is genuinely helpful and attentive. Anyhow, I did appreciate that when we commented that the food wasn't spicy enough, he had the chef make us a tomato chili chutny to liven up our food. It made a nice addition to the dishes and I actually got some spicy into my lunch. 

Being a tiny girl, buffets aren't really my thing, and although I'd love to try Amber for dinner to see how I like its spicy dishes, the entree prices make that unlikely in the near future. There are so many amazingly good, cheap Indian places in SF that either proximity or the need for a nice restaurant will have to bring me back. I'll definitely make the effort in a couple months when they're into the swing of things. I've also got my eye on the back room for a private happy hour or something.
author: Kristina A.

description: I went to Amber tonight and enjoyed the meal, although its not the best Indian in town (see Lahore Karahi).  I did like the modern decorations, the wait staff, and the mango creme brulee- yummy!
author: Cara J.

description: Who knew an all-you-can-eat Indian buffet would be this good?  I am not crazy about Indian food, but this place is good.  Mostly chicken selections on their buffet menu and all the dishes were seasoned well.  The spicy dishes were the best and I really enjoyed their rice!  Centrally located in downtown SF.  The interior is very nicely decorated, but for a place that serves buffets, there sure are a lot of stairs to get through just to get your food.  Overall, a great experience!
author: Chris R.

description:
"Truly a feast for both the mouth as well as the eyes."

I got a little lost getting to this place and so did quite a few people according to the staff on Valentines night. Directions are poor on Google maps so beware. It took me over the bay bridge. My luck it was in the heart of San Francisco. I was going the wrong way. I was an hour late for my reservation. The staff still accommodated me on arrival and we were seated very promptly. This place is a little expensive but well worth it. Service is great. The food was presented in a Picuris way.  Very stimulating for the eyes and belly. This place truly offers top-notch modern ambience in a romantic setting. The wonderful music playing transports you away. The Amber Rose Drink allows you to float on a cloud. I have to say if your visiting San Francisco and into Indian food you must visit this place. If you let your opportunity to visit such a place escape you, your missing out on a modern piece of Indian food perfected.

Service: A-
Food: A+

Overall: A+
author: Reyna D.

description: I have never seen such an expensive bill for Indian food before.  The food was about 3 times more expensive than what I typically have spent, but wow was the food delicious.  The butter chicken was amazing.  The other dishes were excellent too, such as the pepper crab (fresh crab!), black cod, tandoori chicken, etc...  All of the ingredients were fresh and I didn't feel greasy/heavy despite eating so much food.  Most of the people there seemed to be celebrating a special occasion, so it's not your everyday haunt.  The restaurant itself is fancy and big.  You can dress up if you'd like or go casual, but it looked like most people were dressed up a little.  There is also a separate bar area where you can order small plates and a happy hour that lasts until 7pm.  Yes, the price is way up there, so for economic purposes I can't be a regular here, but I always dream about Amber's food when I'm craving a good curry...
author: Justine L.

description: Typically you can't feel attractive eating Indian food.  You get full, bloated, and sleepy.  Amber India in San Francisco solves that problem.  I swear, You actually feel sexy eating curry.  It might be because you get to have a cucumber-mint signature martini along with your dinner... or because you get to eat things like chicken bruschetta and mango-lassi-and-chocolate cheesecake. It's swanky, sleek, and the food actually perfects the balance of creativity and authenticity - neither is compromised.   Go.  Eat.  Be Sexy.
author: Maulie D.

description:
Are you kidding me?  The first thing I read when I investigate Amber is the equivalent of a Yelp gang bang, how disgusting.  I too would like to go to restaurants across the globe on opening night and expect to be treated like more than a guinea pig...but that would be stupid of me because life in restaurants doesn't work that way, or don't you know, oh my, you don't!  The day any of you give levity to your self aggrandizing remarks with any kind of restaurant experience, other than being a GUEST, I might actually not do what I'm about to do.
First off, why go to a restaurant that has an expensive menu and then knock off stars for it being expensive?  If you're a cheap bastard go to cheap places, otherwise you're just an asshole looking for something to complain about.
This review is personal, you have insulted the very soul of the reason Americans are becoming more willing to try Indian food.
A brief history lesson:
Amber Mountain View was the first and will remain the most authentic of the Amber franchise.
Amber Santana Row came next, it was Amber's first attempt at fusion, they have been wildly successful regardless of your thankless rants.
Amber Cafe is a less successful, mutated version of simple Amber fare with no flare, only name.
Amber Union Square is the latest incarnation of an extremely vibrant and continuously evolving concept that Indian food can appeal to anyone.  
Amber India is the only Indian restaurant I have ever known that has deviated from typical Indian cuisine yet remained at the very pinnacle of excellence in food preparation, presentation and delivery.   In my own circle alone, every human being I have dragged into an Amber has left with an appreciation and understanding of Indian food that can't be grasped by the inexperienced in an afternoon buffet at your typical Indian restaurant.  Why?  Because the chefs at Amber strive to make their food palpable to a larger crowd than the food savvy, world traveled, adventurous tongue, like my parents, for example.  
Amber Union Square is not Amber Mountain View or any other typical Indian restaurant and you do yourself, as well as the menu, a great disservice in expecting that it will be.  How will you ever know the joys of Dal Amber when you are still expecting a simple black or yellow Dal?  What about the succulence of salmon soaked in mint chutney and then seared lightly to bring out both the flavour of the chutney and the incredible consistency of perfectly cooked seafood?  And the butter chicken, like children in a daze, I have watched hordes practically fall into their bronzed bowls, fainting in anticipation.  Oh, the naan, well, anyone who has ever had it cooked for them by an Indian mother knows that it ought to be light and slightly thin, it means its fresh cooked where as the thick, doughy variety is frozen and reheated, most likely not on the tandoor, or did you just think that was a type of chicken...
Essentially, I've read, that Amber is too much for you, your pockets, your mouths, your ability to stay seated and be consumed in the amazing act of breaking naan with another, impressed more with an unusual experience than your ability to malign it with ignorance.
author: Madame A.

description: I was pleasantly surprised with a beautifully decorated elegant dining room. Romantic atmosphere. Service was nice, hostess was very helpful. The food was also excellent. Supposedly they're known for their butter chicken, which I have to say was quite yummy. I also got a spicy tomato based lamb dish or was it chicken...anyways, I would definitely go back.
author: Royce L.

description: very good authentic indian food! dont miss this place if you crave some naan, curry, and yogurt!
author: nicole s.

description:
Don't you love it when people write "This place was delicious!!! (Blah blah inconsequential chatter, end of review.)" That's basically 82% of the reviews on Yelp.

Who are these people. There are a lot of things you can derive from Joe Public reviews like a sense of what the place looks like, anecdotal service experiences, crowd, what's on the menu, without building up a degree of trust in that semi-anonymous person's judgement. But taste? How do I know there's any accounting for Darcy McHorninerd's taste in Indian food?

Usually I can disqualify people based on their profession of love for chicken tikka masala.. but really that's unfair, it's like disqualifying Italian reviews based on how much the reviewer loves for spaghetti with meatballs. And spaghetti with meatballs can be pretty good sometimes.

There were a lot of review like this on this place after it first opened, so I didn't quite know what to expect other than it has a good reputation down on the peninsula and is ridiculously expensive. 

Well, I'm happy to say that even after stepping off a plane after two weeks in India and dining with a native South Asian chick, this place was pretty solid for both of us. Probably the best North Indian food we've had in the city. (I still like Dosa for southern.) Let me break it down -- some people think of Indian food like they think of Mexican, they actually prefer it greasy and cheap and uninventive, as if that's "authentic". This is not such a place and if you're that type there's no way you should come within 50 feet or you will die laughing at the prices. But if you're willing to pay $22 for a biryani (even I'm cracking a smirk as I write that), what you'll get is nicely spiced with a good amount of masala and some moisture retained in the rice and meat. Whereas some use oil to compensate for dry, overdone biryanis, this one was cooked right. A cut above what I've come to expect here.

Also enjoyed the drink list.. had a nice glass of Chinon. Made a mental note to visit the bar/lounge upstairs after work sometime.

But is the food twice-as-expensive-as-anywhere-else good? Probably not.
author: Tom L.

description:
To clarify, it's 3.5 stars.  Food is good, but also pricy.  Enjoyed their happy hour menu, and happy hour drinks were decent too.  Weird thing is that I tried their drinks at dinner (different drink) once and it sucked badly.  

Lunch buffet is $20 (~$25 with tax/tips). Great selection, fresh food, good naan, good service. Though expensive, I wouldn't mind going occasionally when in the mood.  There are simply other more affordable yet awesome Indian choices in the area.
author: E H.

description: I really liked this place. The decor is beautiful, and finally a restaurant that does it right. I'm shocked at all the really unforgiving reviews here. It's as if  they expect the best. Some people just cannot be satisfied however. Just remind me not to invite them over to my place when I'm cooking. No thank you. Au revoir!!
author: Lucian J.

description: The food, service and ambiance are all excellent. We started off with drinks and apps and right away noticed the difference in quality from most average Indian restaurants. The Naan and Samosas were tasty, bot not heavy. We shared several entrees and all were equally well prepared. It's definitely a bit more spendy, but well worth it.
author: Jeff P.

description:
My wife and I SO wanted to like the new Amber India in SF, but alas there were more negatives than positives.  My wife's Indian and the Mountain View Amber India catered our wedding, so we feel like we know what the food should taste like.  

First off, the location and the decor are great.  It's a very sheik, polished, and upscale atmosphere.

BUT... we have problems when:
-  All of the waiters and waitresses are non-Indian (our waitress didn't know any of the Indian names for any of the dishes)
-  Many of the classic North Indian dishes we're familiar with weren't on the menu
-  Dishes were 5-10 dollars more for the exact same dish at Amber India Mountain View
-  We found chunks of cartilage in our chicken curry
-  Our water was served to us with no ice.  When we asked for ice they brought us a glass and we had to spoon in the pieces ourselves (if we were paying 10-15 bucks a dish, that'd be no problem, but if I'm paying almost $30 a dish, I expect high end service)
-  The drink menu was a poorly made xerox copy with the left hand side cut off
-   No wine list was available and not all of the wines described by the waitress were actually available
-  Food was WAY under spiced.  We actually asked that our food be made spicy and instead we received very bland curries
-  Samosas were small and not very flavorful.  The mini-samosas looked nice, but just didn't taste that great (they weren't exactly hot either)

Other than the things I already mentioned, service was okay.

Unlike the Amber India in Mountain View, there were very few Indian patrons and the place just didn't feel or taste very authentic.  The place felt pretentious.  The Amber India chefs are good, but by trying to please the SF tourists they are losing the real flavors and character.

Not to pile on, but there are also some problems with their website.

It's sad, we were so hoping to have a good, nice Indian place in SF.  

If you're looking for good cheap Indian food and don't mind a place with no atmosphere or decor, check out Shalimar on Polk Street.

If you want a little bit more of a nice dining experience, and don't mind a bit of a drive, head down to Mountain View and eat at Amber India Mountain View (even the Santana Row restaurant was better than the SF one).
author: Damian S.

description: Fancy décor, amazing eggplant, overdone chops, very sweet and unknowledgeable bartender.  If you know their menu well and know exactly what you want, it'll be a great experience.  Otherwise, you might find yourself unpleasantly surprised.
author: Tati K.

description: Fantastic lunch buffet for about $17.  There were three or four chicken dishes and the best mutter paneer that changed the way I think about paneer.    Mmmmm tandori catfish!  One of the best daals I have ever tasted and raita that is spot on.  The diversity in choices and care in each dish makes it a very worth-while nice lunch downtown.
author: MJ C.

description: Food was good, but very pricey. Buffet with tip cost 22$ per person. Can try once, but not frequently, unless you have a lot of $$$ to spend :)
author: Aussfchi R.

description:
Great Location and great interior.  We went there for lunch buffet, little pricey for $17 a meal, not enough varieties for a vegetarian. 

Sooji halwa was fantastic, but our friends did not like butter chicken. 
I will go there but not very often..
author: Cool B.

description: Pricey, but the decor and menu selection make it worth it.  Lunch buffet was $17, and there were so many different items to sample.  Bored with ubiquitous chicken tika masala?  Come try any number of alternate masala entrees.
author: Ken B.

description:
I've had my eye on Amber India every since it opened- I'd heard good things about its other location in the South Bay and I really wanted to see whether its offerings would hold up well against my favorite Indian food joints.  Luckily expectations held and we had a wonderful lunch here.

We decided on eating the lunch buffet versus ordering a la carte because really, its hard to turn down a buffet.  Start off with Amber India's version of a samosa- the taste is the same, but the presentation ups your enjoyment of it.  I noticed that some of the items from the buffet don't necessarily show up on their regular menu- for example, there was a deep-fried catfish fritters dish that was enjoyed by us all, but it isn't anywhere on the take-out menu.  Likewise, there was a lamb curry that was superb (in that I detected almost zero gaminess), but again, no mention of that dish in their menu.  It also seems like some of the other vegetarian dishes featured in the buffet line are unique to it- there was a cabbage dish with coconut that was lovely, another dish with garbanzo beans, a potato dish, a paneer with peppers dish, and yet another one with dal- all of which were well-seasoned.  

As for the meat dishes, I especially liked the butter chicken, which came with a deliciously rich sauce that was perfect with the rice and the naan.   I liked the balance of sweetness and tanginess in the sauce and the chicken was super tender.  A word about the naan- its super hot outta the oven and its crisp on the outside while fluffy on the inside.  Rather than leaving it steaming on the buffet line, each table gets their own basket.  The Baluchi chicken tikka- a boneless chicken leg- was tasty, but I missed the slight charring on the flesh that usually comes from being roasted in the tandoor oven.  

We managed to leave just enough room for dessert, which featured almond halwa and a variation of the rice pudding seen at other Indian buffets.  The halwa, which is like a super-thick almond paste, is  really sweet, but perfect when slathered onto the naan.  The rice pudding was made with a thin vermicelli instead of the standard rice and it was very good- the cardamon wasn't too strong and the vermicelli added a different texture.

Now the food was great, but we also appreciated the elegant surroundings and the attentive wait staff who always kept our water glasses full, our plates cleared, and the naan coming.  At $16.95 per person, the lunch buffet is certainly pricier than other places I've been, but everyone in my party thought it was well worth it.
author: Angela H.

description:
Amber was on my list of places to visit for a long time. However it seemed a little pricey which kind of pushed it down my list for a while. Also I believe that the upscale restaurants, specially indian ones tend to "tone down" the flavors. With Indian food I expect a lot of flavors and some spice. We finally ended up going there for an occasion and were definitely not disappointed.

For starters we had wine, and I must say they have a very impressive wine collection. We had the malabari shrimp which was exquisite. The highlight for the evening for me were the lamb chops. I would give this a 10 star rating if it existed. The lamb was cooked just perfect the flavors were just perfect. I can still feel the taste in my mouth... yum yum. I would go back to amber just for the lamb chops.

Other than that we ordered a black pepper chicken dish which had a sweet flavor to it, not too much too my liking and also a rogangosh which was nice. The service I would give a 2-3 star not the best. But the food is definitely worth the trip.
author: Ash O.

description: Went to Amber India for lunch and it was fantastic.  Usually indian food buffets are pretty gross, but this one is the exception.  All the food was well-prepared and the buffet area was clean.  There were probably 15-20 different choices, and it was nice to have the ability to try everything.  The lunch buffet also came with a drink.  Hightly recommend this place if you are in the market for a nice lunch...
author: Justin G.

description:
eating dinner in the lounge- area- bar suits me better than eating in the dining room.  expensive and consistently scrumptious.   i don't own a television so eating and watching television and jabbering away makes me feel so nostalgic ( 7th grade bedroom).   This place is the perfect antidote for an after work meal and drink, if only my dog were allowed.
  
ethan the bartender is terribly knowledgeable to- a -fault about every drink he serves.  Tonight I have learned that my bfs beer was made in Germany ran by nuns in a convent.  for over 225 years nuns have brewed this beer in a monastery.  ok-great.  lovely service, I've ordered every vegetarian dish and I always like the food.  clean, not too much salt, no stomach ache.
author: Noel J.

description: Must try their Butter Chicken dipping "naan" with its curry. chicken tikka was tasty too. if u r going on  a weekend, it'd be better if u had a reservation. it gets crowded. also from my personal experience, don't eat curry before clubbing. it gets nasty! u get what i mean? lol. but let alone, the food's awesome!
author: Sarah O.

description: Ok today we tried the lunch buffet and yes it was only 16.95 which is fantastic.  There were a lot of dishes, and yes... the spices were a little different than normal.  My coworker said that the daal was a little different.  However, I thought overall all the dishes were good.  i especially enjoyed the cauliflower and the stuff cottage cheese.  There were three different types of desserts, which were all very different.  I liked the one with the grape preserve and silver on top.  All suppppppper sweet though.
author: Janet S.

description: Nice ambience and lighting (2 stars)...... but 3x the price of Pakwan. 1/2x the performance. Tandoori appetizers were not freshly prepared - cold on arrival. No apology on reporting. Lukewarm service and follow-on dishes. Wasted dollars. Not a landing strip for this aviator.
author: noflaps c.

description: I have been here twice for lunch buffet. for$16.95 each person, drinks extra, but fresh hot regular naan included. There was a great assortment interesting and delicious hot dishes to try.  The dining room is a really nice space, uncrowded with comfortable chairs.   The staff are really attentive and pleasant. There were some nteresting salads and dishes that set themselves apart from other Indian buffet. (Mushrooms, cheese curry, pan fried fish). I think this is good for casual lunch, friends and family. Looks like they have a full bar and happy hour.  Ginger ale was $4.00 though!
author: Betty L.

description:
The place was highly recommended by a friend but what a let down! Wobbly table - adjusted by napkin - will do. Dirty sauce container  - eww - will surely not do! Food - not entirely bad actually but for a $200+ dinner (for 4) there are so many better options in the Bay and the 'Burbs that these guys surely need to work harder! 
The best part was we were served a complimentary appetizer and on checking the bill saw that we were actually being charged for it - lol! The Santana Row branch is so much better - good for us that it's closer ;)
author: Sudeshna S.

description: Came here for the lunch buffet during the weekday.  The variety wasn't overwhelming - just enough to satisfy you.  The price of the buffet isn't cheap, but moderate given the fact of the location and the decor of the restaurant.  It's a lot nicer and cleaner than most indian restaurants I've been to.  Most of the food were good - flavors weren't too over powering, just right.  You also get refills on the naan bread.  The chai tea is yummy.
author: Katniss B.

description: nice place, good food, very busy so have to make reservations in advance
author: Sunny C.

description: My wife and I have eaten here a couple of times, most recently with some friends.  The dishes here are all very interesting, with great variations on what you find in more traditional Indian restaurants.  We really liked the Malabari shrimp appetizer.  For dinner, we have tried the butter chicken, Kesar Elaichi Gosht and pan seared scallops; all were terrific.  This is probably my favorite Indian place anywhere in California (Trishna's in London is better, but a bit of a hike).
author: Richard M.

description: Went for lunch with a friend. The buffet was plentiful and fresh. They had a lot of veg choices which were delicious. The food was warm to hot on the taste side. I tasted a bit of everything I cleaned my plate so I would say nothing I ate was disappointing. I look forward to going back for lunch again or dinner sometime.
author: Analise T.

description: This is indian food gone high class. The setting was very elegant and the service was impeccable. We started off with the Samosa which was a bit bland but half decent. Then we ordered five dishes, Baluchi Chicken Tikka, Kashmiri Roganjosh (lamb curry), butter chicken , Saufiyani Baingan (egg plant) and Mushroom and Baby corn Teen Saag. All the dishes were decent but I especially liked the eggplant and the butter chicken. The desserts were not that great, in fact we had to send the kulfti back because it was horrible. We had two desserts in total and a couple of drinks. Unfortunately this place is way too expensive for what you get andI don't think I can justify coming back. Our tab came to $200 for four people. Prob the most expensive indian dinner I've had in a long while.  The third star is only there because the food was quite good.
author: Christopher Q.

description: We came here yesterday for lunch,they were offering a $16.99 buffet.  The buffet was highly representative of their menu, and indian food in general.  It was delicious.  I went back for thirds of the "butter chicken" which is their version of chicken tikka masala.  I highly recommend their buffet since each entree on their menu on average costs $20.  Ambiance is great, location is great, and service is quite good.  We'll definitely come back.
author: Marisa N.

description: This was my primary dining location during my recent San Francisco visit. Main reason was that this place was very near to Marriott Marquis where I was staying. The food was very tasty and the staff was very courteous and understanding. I will definitely try to eat there again on my next trip to SF.
author: P J.

description: This review is for the upper bar area only.  I visited the bar this afternoon with a friend of mine, and Rashi (the bartender) took really good care of us.  I've never been to this place before, but I was made to feel like I was a regular.  Rashi, thanks for taking care of us so well.
author: Jay B.

description: OMG!! all i could say, amazing food, amazing drinks, amazing atmosphere. Delecious, yummy. it is a bit pricey so if you are on a budget avoid but if you got the cash to spend go there and enjoy the amazing food and place, very nice people
author: marian m.

description: Tried the chicken tandoori "burrito" wrapped in naan at the Island Farmers Market in the Metreon, the old Sony space.  YUM!
author: Aimee B.

description:
I am a snob for Pakistani and Indian food.
This place, regardless of how expensive it is, deserves 3.5 stars but I upped it to 4 for effort.

Ok, it's a nice blend of Indian with some French flair.
It's the only Indian restaurant where the chicken tasted like real chicken and not reprocessed collagen. Only Pakistani restaurants can do meat well as far as I'm concerned. Furthermore, their tandoori fish was fantastic. I was impressed and that is hard to do. (see first line above)

The samosas were decent but beef as usual is prepared on average in Indian restaurants. I guess that's what you get for being Vegetarian for thousands of years and then deciding to cook beef like it was lentil.

It's an upscale Indian restaurant that I would take a brown friend for their birthday. But not my Mom...still not good enough for her.
author: Faisal M.

description: Wildly overpriced!  Sure the surroundings are nice and the service is fine but the food is nothing special and not worth the expense.  Did anyone else think that the tables are too far away from the bench seating?  And you can't just slide them closer because they make this horrible sound on the stone floor.  You have to lift them up to pull them closer otherwise you're like a mile from the table.  Dinner for two consisting of one appetizer per person (loved the shrimp salad), one entree per person (disappointed with the butter chicken), and one drink per person cost a total (with tip) of $120.  The location of the restaurant will likely allow it to survive due to all the business travelers attending conventions on expense accounts, but I don't think it would work in other parts of the city.  There is better Indian food available and at much cheaper prices.
author: Tom S.

description:
This place is five-star all around.  Delicious Indian food, with unexpected pairings (strawberries work well with couscous!), great friendly service in a beautiful space.  

I am seriously considering this place for Valentine's dinner, it just has that special ambiance that elevates a restaurant to the five star level.
author: Localista I.

description: Eh. Lacking flavor. No kick.
author: Marie P.

description: First off, what a beautiful restaurant!! Just lovely and well appointed, it was a really gorgeous restaurant and it gave everything a fine dining appeal. The prices are a little more than your average Indian restaurant but I wouldn't say they are outrageous, entrees are in the $20-$30 range and appetizers around $7-$15. Got the famous butter chicken, YUMMY, get this!! It's soooo good, kind of like chicken tikka masala but with much more depth of flavor and none of the greasiness you can find at Shalimar or Naan and Curry. Also got the Samosas to start, these were great, not greasy and with a lovely mild flavor. Served with two delicious sauces. We also got the lamb kebabs which were good and had quite a kick to them! Our waitress was great and even served the food onto our plates for us, what a nice touch! I would definitely come back here for a nice night out.
author: Cathy T.

description: Marble, prime location, beautiful settings... not your average Naan 'n' Curry. I was utterly impressed with the stylish setting. The location is a bit difficult to get to if you don't know your way around San Francisco -(Right across the hall from the press club, for those of you who know).  Entering the door, the aroma of the spices fills your nostrils. The food at Amber is SO flavorful and SO good. As Indian cuisine is typically vegetarian, it was amazing how the chef combined different meats with different Indian spices. Our waitress was so helpful in aiding us on choosing the right dishes. The paneers and salmon were incredible. It's pricey for an Indian restaurant, but WELL worth it. I'd love to try more of their dishes... maybe one at a time because they are HEAVY! Not a place for picky eaters.
author: Rada I.

description: I'm an Indian by nationality and have traveled to over 50 countries around the world and sampled food everywhere. Trust me, this is definitely as good as it gets when it comes to Indian food. This deserves six stars.
author: Nishant K.

description: nice lamb curry and butter chicken and pesto garlic nan.  A little on the pricey side for Indian food but the ambiance and service were good.
author: Dennis D.

description: I'd like to temper some of the 5 stars out there. There are Indian restaurants in the city with better food but the overall experience in Amber was very good. There aren't too many Indian restuarants that really go to town on the decor and that's where this place excels. It's flashy (literally) and reminded me a bit of a top end hotel. The service was friendly but not exactly speedy considering the number of diners on a Sunday night. So the food was above average but not fantastic. I think the cost here is largely going on the location and the decor. Would I go again? Yes I definitely would.
author: Ian D.

description:
When it comes to Indian food in a restaurant, I have high expectations. As soon as I walked in, I saw how trendy it was inside and immediately was turned off. When we sat down and saw the menu and its crazy prices and random names for very basic dishes I was like "great, this is gonna suck". I went with a group of 4 girls, and we ordered, the butter chicken (standard dish that will say so much about an Indian place), Kadhai Paneer (Grilled Veggies and Cheese in a tomato base sauce), Wild Mushroom Teen Saag (Mushrooms in Spinach base). We asked for it to be medium spicy, since we had some non-spicy fans.....The food comes out and we take a bite and are blown away with it. I was in shock at how spicy the butter chicken was....It was spicy yet so flavorful! I was a very happy camper. The Kadhai Paneer was also amazing. The dishes each seemed to incorporate different spices from different regions of India. I didn't care too much for the Mushroom Saag as I don't really like Mushrooms, but others in my party did. The Spinach part was really tasty though. Overall, I was mostly impressed that the food wasn't typical heavy Punjabi style. I didn't leave feeling like I inhaled loads of cream and oil. Instead, I went back to my hotel, kicking myself for even talking bad about a place before I even tried the food. (I'm Indian, I can't help it) 
I would give this place 5 stars, but I take one off because of the price and customer service (not as attentive as I would have liked). But either way, this place is on my list of restaurants to visit when in SF. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Rona D.

description: This is an expensive Indian restaurant with excellent decor. I have been to this place 2-3 times. On my visit there i ordered paneer with peas, tandoori shrimps and egg plant.  They have nice food, but nothing extra ordinary. It is definitely pricey as average entree costs $25 which is quite expensive for an Indian restaurant.  You are definitely paying for atmosphere
author: Hasham Y.

description: I found this place on yelp and everyone was right about the butter chicken.  The flavor was very smooth and did not overwhelm you like most Indian food restaurants.  The garlic nan was excellent as well.  One of the best things about this place is the atmosphere; it's definitely upscale but the prices were still reasonable.  I would go back!
author: Cole S.

description:
Ambiance = A
Service = A+
Food = C

Very trendy and a great atmosphere but i'm not craving to go back for the food!  I wanted to try Amber because the Butter Chicken was highly raved...well, I'd rather go back to Swagat in Walnut Creek for some Chicken Tikka Masala anyday.  The food is definitely geared toward a non-traditional palate.  Butter Chicken should not taste sweet.  Blek!  On a positive note, the Idli Manchurian was unusual yet very tasty.  Notice most of the 5 star reviewers are Non-Indian.
author: Preeti P.

description: upscale indian food and great service.  all the dishes i've tried at amber were delicious and you can differentiate the quality of ingredients over other hole in the wall indian restaurants.  i've also tried their lunch buffet which is also great.  $20 bucks for a lunch buffet but you get quality food and good variety of dishes.
author: Helen T.

description: Fantastic food, excellent service, beautiful restaurant, great atmosphere, and outstanding service.  What more could you ask for??  Don't miss it!  As busy as the restaurant was, the waiters are super attentive, friendly, and efficient.  After dinner don't miss walking around the Yerba Buena Gardens and seeing the stunning memorial to Martin Luther King Jr.
author: D S.

description: This restaurant was outside of the norm for Indian restaurants. The decorations were modern and fine, the ambience was social, but the food--authentic. I brought my whole family here, and was pleasantly surprised by the less "deep Indian" feel to the place because it made my brother, sister, and dad more comfortable. Those three do not often eat Indian, or any ethnic food for that matter, and it was a good place for them to give more mild flavors a try. The three of them shared two orders of the fig and orange chicken tikka, and loved it. We also had a samosa appetizer that my brother and mom enjoyed, and the saffron pulao (flash fried spinach salad) which was crunchy yet fresh and delicious. She had the chili rubbed sea bass entree, which I tasted and did not like very much, though she seemed to enjoy it, and I tried the subj chettinad (vegetarian mixed vegetable curry), which was exquisite. It was the dish I ate the most of so I can rave about it most extensively. The flavor was what I would consider the heart of Indian cuisine--a perfect blend of typical herbs and spices, sweet and hot, thick and vegetable-y. In addition, we had plenty of roti and naan, each plain, pesto, and garlic, as well as rice. It was nice to find an Indian restaurant that offered the healthier brown rice in addition to the usual basmati white. The place also has a great location, among other nice shops, restaurants, and department stores. Within walking distance of all of my favorites (AllSaints, Saks, Juicy, Starbucks, Pink Berry, etc), it was the best place for a fun and enjoyable evening in Union Square. Highly recommend!!!
author: Alli T.

description: Awesome restaurant.   The chicken tikka was the best I've had - at over $20 bucks it should be.    I tend to judge an Indian restaurant based on its samosas and its naan.   The samosas were flavorful and not greasy.   The garlic naan was good but I've had better- hence 4 stars.     Great place to take a date with an adventurous palate.
author: Fred X.

description:
I consider myself extremely picky when it comes to Indian buffets and after having a very mediocre experience at Amber Mountain View I was pretty hesitant to try the buffet in San Francisco. However Osho's where we were originally going to was closed for lunch and so we decided to go here and see if Amber could redeem herself. And boy! she sure did!

First off the ambiance was beautiful.Shades of red and orange greet you when you walk in and it set the mood for a perfectly enjoyable afternoon to come. We had the buffet ($17.00 per person). Here's some of my favorite dishes from it:: 

* Papri chaat & Pani Puri: Popular Indian snacks  containing dough wafers made from refined white flour and oil served with boiled potatoes, boiled chick peas, chillies, yogurt & tamarind chutney. Went back for third's! 5 out of 5 

* Aloo Tikkis : spicy potato cutlets eaten with mint chutney- Delicious!! 4 out of 5 

*Black Lentils simmered in cream : Perfectly cooked and my favourite dish at the buffet. 10 out of 5..(seriously it was that good!) 

* Kadai Panneer: Indian cottage cheese cooked with green bell peppers, fenugreek, bay leaves, cardamom & tomato. 4 out of 5 

* Saffron Rice: I love long grained Basmati rice but I am not a big fan of saffron, yet I'm really glad I tried this. It was perfectly cooked with just a  very subtle hint of saffron. 4 out of 5 

I didn't care too much for the chole (spicy garbanzo beans) or the peas in cashew sauce, but in all fairness I saw the other people going back for seconds on those, so it may have just been my personal taste. Hot naans are served fresh at the table and mimosas are included in the price! : ) 

One suggestion for Amber is that they should have little placards with suggestions for what goes with what. If there were people who were'nt very familiar with Indian food they would not know for instance how to season the papri chaat (with yogurt, tamarind and mint chutney) and doing this may help them.

For desert there was chocolate orange mouse, payasam and sooji halwa. Oh and for all you Desi beer lovers- they have Kingfisher! 

A delightful way to spend a beautiful Sunday afternoon in the city.
author: Natasha J.

description: I was a little hesitant about going to this restaurant as I am not too familiar with Indian cuisine, but I'm glad I did go.  I decided to go with the Mixed grill appetizer as my main dish as I wanted to have a mix of food.  I am not a big fan of lamb, but the ground lamb kebab was very tasty.  The chicken also had a wonderful spicy flavor (not hot).  The shrimp was just okay.  My co-worker had the butter chicken and that made me have food envy as it tasted great.  The naan with garlic was very good too.  A very fancy place with good selection of different beers.
author: Dave U.

description: I'm an Indian food FREAK.  From LA to London, from San Francisco to Rome, it seems I've eaten at ALL of them.  I have to say, truly, that Amber India is the single best indian restaurant I've ever been to.  Fabulous food (try the seabass maille).  Beautiful environment, attentive service, nice decor, it's a terriic place.  And second best, in Santa Monica go to "Gate of India" on Ocean/SM Blvd.  Not what it seems from the sidewalk - definitely order the bhel puri.  But Amber India beats even them.
author: Wendy K.

description: Restaurant interior is good and staff is very friendly. They have a large variety of food to chose from, but pricewise, its a bit high end. One of the best retaurant in San Francisco, if ambience is considered. I don;t mind rating this restaurant with good stars in the way it is maintained!
author: Ro R.

description: I really liked this restaurant.  I thought the food was excellent, service was wonderful and on top of it the interior decor looked beautiful, modern and clean!  They just recently opened this restaurant in SF so I've noticed that the waiters are still getting the tables/food order confused....but I would give them some time before I go back again and I'm sure by a month or so everything will be running smoothly!  I would recommend making a reservation in advance..especially if a convention is in town!
author: JenJen W.

description: The best part of the weekend buffet was the mimosa.  The food was just okay.  A couple of dishes were actually not good at all.  I was a little surprised in both the poor quality and the lack of selection, considering the high $20 price tag.
author: Jessica P.

description: Maybe it is because I haven't had really good indian since moving to the west coast...but i thought Amber did a great job with some of the more traditional dishes like chicken tandoori while also adding a little more invention with others--the butter chicken was really amazing. The service was spot on and the place is really beautiful. I would definitely go again next time I am in SF!
author: Sylvia S.

description: After reading all of the reviews, I decided to try the lunch buffet at Amber India.  For $16.95, plus tax, I thought it was a decently priced deal.  The restaurant itself was attractive & service was prompt & efficient.  Though not an expert on Indian food, I found the food here to be very, very good.  Some of the dishes offered for the lunch buffet were a spinach & feta salad, spiced chickpeas, catfish, tandoori chicken, butter chicken, chicken curry, basmati rice, a potato & spinach dish, & a dish with mushrooms, veggies & various spices.  As others have mentioned, the butter chicken was the stand-out.  The bar area looks like a nice place for a Happy Hour gathering as well.  I will definitely return soon.
author: Tina B.

description:
A beautiful space that kicks Indian cuisine up a notch in San Francisco, Amber is in a class of its own. Its truly fine Indian dinning. From the warmly decorated trendy space to the dishes that food is served in, Amber does it with class.

The food was really delicious. I had Kadhai paneer (really authentic) and my husband had lamb with turnips which he said was really good. The rice was cooked perfectly and Naan was out of this world - light & fluffy. Its def. pricey, we had already had appetizers and drinks somewhere else and running too late to try dessert so just two dishes + one glass of wine cost $80 including tips.
author: Anu Y.

description: The food was ok. The drink I ordered was horrible. I can't remember what it was called but I they put way too much sweet & sour in there. The service was pretty bad too. Our drinks came after our food (and after we asked about them 3 times) and in general, they were very slow and inattentive.
author: shadi m.

description: A good happy hour spot if you want a pretty and comfortable setting.  Good wines and free popcorn!
author: T D.

description: The name Amber does not sound Indian, the look does not look Indian but the food is really really good Indian! I have been to the San Francisco restaurant twice and I have to say it was good twice. The deceiving part is the it looks like a non-Indian restaurant with a sleek bar and dining area. The staff was knowledgeable but the only thing is they love their best sellers but for the adventurous I would go off the recommendations and pick what you like. The second time I went with okra and that was really good. The must tries are Duck Tinka Keba, Four-Chili rubbed Fish kebab (let it sit for awhile), Butter Chicken and my favorite the Garlic Naan (Mr Keebler call me and we can ask for extra Garlic).
author: Toby N.

description:
Really smashing food, great service and a lovely atmosphere.

We were seated promptly even though the place was pretty busy on a Saturday night. The waitress was friendly and helpful, and drinks arrived soon afterwards.

The food was delicious. Top quality ingredients, superb taste, perfectly cooked and wonderfully spiced. I was amazed that a downtown SF restaurant could deliver such a fantastic meal (many nearby are mediocre at best). The scallops were delightful---tender and juicy---and the baluchi chicken a real treat. Bread was a little greasy but that's really my only complaint.

Sure it's a little pricey but it's seriously tasty. I'll be back for sure.
author: Isaac H.

description: Went last night with a friend, and we loved it.  Awesome, unexpected,  $5 happy hour with really tasty and original drinks.  The butter chicken and lamb were awesome, and the service was great.  We were really stuffed, but kept eating because we just had to, since it was so good.
author: Vivian P.

description: Very nice food great service ,food presentation and wine selection also good
author: Shailesh G.

description: It's very pricey. But definitely worth trying out at least once. I recommend going for weekdays lunch buffet. Specially those of you who are not Indian origin. Amber offers variety of dishes we get back in India but are normally not present in most restaurants in the states.
author: Ehlan S.

description:
When I heard Amber was coming to San Francisco, I was very interested. I have been a fan of their original Mountain View location for some time and have also been to the slightly more upscale San Jose location (which has better ambiance but worse quality food I would argue). I went to the SF one for dinner and immediately noticed the even-more-upscale-than-San-Jose decor. It seemed like a high-class hotel restaurant with mirrors on the walls. However, not every customer seemed to dress according to the looks of the restaurant. I saw one guys in shorts with a baseball cap turned backwards...I feel like I wasted my time trying to dress better than usual for this place.

But really, it is about the food. Started with the Duck Tinka Kebab thanks to a recommendation from the waiter. It was just meh; it was weird to think it was duck when it reminded me more of chicken. It was edible but a little tough and boring. Sauces didn't do much to improve the flavor. For main course, I went with the butter chicken, Amber's signature dish. Butter chicken at the Mountain View location is one of my favorite individual dishes in my eating history! Flavorful but not overpowering, creamy but not rich. But at the San Francisco location, similar to the San Jose location's butter chicken, the sauce is more watery and spicy. And for 20.95 for the dish, the portions were rather small. 

I would say go to Amber India in SF if you must have that upscale environment or the assortment of cocktails (I myself tried the Bellota...tasted like a strong sparkling wine with strawberry pieces thrown in). The lunch buffet here might be better as I have found at Amber restaurants the quality in taste is the same, and you would get more variety and quantity of food. But for the prices at dinner, the product is not worth it.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Came here for happy hour with co-workers.  Drinks and appetizers were $5 - what's not to like?  :)

We came on a Monday - the waitress is also the bartender on Mondays and Tuesdays.  She forgot one of our drinks and when my coworker went up to the bar to remind her, she apologized profusely and gave her the drink for free.  What's not to like? 

The chicken wings are really tasty here as well as most of the cocktails.
author: Ling L.

description: This is the best Indian food ever!  I specifically recommend the butter chicken,  but anything on the menu is good.  The staff are also extremely nice, your water cup is never below half filled and it is not crazy expensive for what you get.
author: Brynn C.

description: The ambience is simple and elegant.  The food is quite delicious although we went there after I got mixed up for being tired and hungry at the serving of fifth floor! Ordered some food and came out quick service, we did not finish our food and wine....their lamb rack is over marinated and salty, also the salmon, but their calamari  and beets salad appetizers were fun to eat!
author: cecille p.

description: Excellent north Indian/ California cuisine-inspired delights in a fun environment. Highly recommended!
author: L T.

description: Service was great. Room a bit noisy. The spinach appetizer was fabulous. The lamb tandoori terrific, but the salmon tandoori disappointing. The fish could have been fresher. I would steer clear of the fish dishes and concentrate on meat.
author: cecilia b.

description: Ate last night at this fine restaurant... the food... the ambiance is just fab... but the staff... especially our two waiters from Nepal, Suresh and Sautosh were exceptional!  It's worth going back just for their warm, attentive service.
author: MJ P.

description: On our way to the press club we decided to stop by this restaurant and grab a bite. Upon our arrival we were cordially and promptly seated. The ambiance of this place is very nice and upscale and the bar area very well setup. The food seemed to definitely live up to all the hype this place has recieved. Everything tasted fresh and the selection was immense. Infact the manager there also gave us complimentary wine passes to the press club, smart business sense I think so. I will defintely re-visit real soon again.
author: Raj K.

description: Had dinner here tonight with some friends. We walked into Amber after our initial restaurant of choice, Pazzia, couldn't provide a high chair for my son, even though I specifically mentioned that while making the reservation. Amber got us seated within minutes without a fuss and moved the table next to us to fit a high chair! The inside was spacious with nice lighting and upscale décor. The food was as good as their Mountain View location thus maintaining their #1 rank in my books for Indian restaurants in the Bay Area! Our favorites included Palak Chaat, Dal Amber, Badam Bhara Baingan and the Mango Mojito. The service was top notch with very friendly waiters who picked up my son's Legos every time he dropped them. I just wish the portions were a little larger -- cost us $$$ to fill our stomachs :) We only tried their vegetarian selection this time but will be back for the non-vegetarians dishes soon!
author: Shari A.

description: I suspect this restaurant survives on one-time tourists who perhaps don't have high expectations or know what Indian food should cost/taste like.  It's been a long time since I've had to ask for a manager at a restaurant.  We ordered a dish for the kids and specifically asked for it to be mild as it was for the kids.  The dish comes out and it's so spicy that I'm actually sweating eating it (and I can take a lot of spice).  Kids can't eat it at all.  I call the waiter over and ask if this is as mild as it gets.  He said he asked the chef to make it mild.  He didn't apologize, offer to fix, etc., and I wasn't about to order another one if they couldn't make it any milder.  Then, 35 mins in to dinner, one of the dishes we ordered never arrived.  At that point, I called the manager over, explained the situation, and he offered to quickly make us another batch of the dish for our kids.  But at this point we were agitated and it was too late.  They did remove the dish from our bill without us having to ask, but the whole thing felt very amateur.  I think the server was probably new/inexperienced so I feel bad coming down hard on him, but you got the feeling that this place just didn't care much what kind of experience their guests actually have.  Note that the dishes are 2x+ what more casual Indian food costs ($20+ for butter chicken; $17 for saag paneer), which would be acceptable if the food were actually exceptionally tasty.  But this food did not taste any different or even as good as much cheaper/more casual Indian places around SF.  I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Mae O.

description: great food and tasty dishes nice ambience. good trained staff
author: Skm S.

description: I went to this place about a month ago.  I've never really been a fan of Indian food until I had dinner at Amber, but now I am.  The butter chicken was really really good with the rice and naan.  This place is a little bit too expensive for me, but I want to go back again sometime in the future.  The bar looks nice as well and the service we got was pretty good.
author: Ryan K.

description: Overpriced for average Indian food. Positives were that it is a nice place to sit down and talk and the food was fine. The problem was that waiters kept trying to nudge us to leave even though it was a weekday night and half the tables were empty. Menu is trying to make unique Indian dishes but there was nothing extraordinary about my lamb or the other dishes at the table that I tried. I've been to much better Indian places for the same price. All in all, very disappointing.
author: Sourabh M.

description: Wow, this place was deeeeeeelicious!  The food was fabulous, though the heat could have been kicked up a notch.  No complaints though.  The service was quick and the waitress was friendly and helpful.  I would love to go back to this place on my next trip in a few months.  Yummmm!
author: Sarah B.

description: One of our favorite brunch places. Good food, good service. We strongly recommend it.
author: M H.

description:
For the uninitiated or tourist crowd not so familiar with San Francisco, I'll begin by telling you that the entrance is on the open public space(walkway) in Yerba Buena Center and closer to Market Street than Mission Street.  Upon entry, I noticed the  marble floors  and the eclectic character of the interior design and artwork.  Eventually I found the backround music to be eclectic also.  As other reviewers have noted, the restaurant could be described as pricey and the ambience would not suggest otherwize. The crowd inside on the day I was there, mainly consisted of  convention goers from nearby Moscone convention center. And I guess for those people on an expense account and on business it's not such a bad deal.
  On the day I went, I was charged $19.95 for the weekend buffet per person.   I could describe the offerings as "distinctive".  Each had unique flavor, so the ten or so dishes being offered were all of unique flavor.  On the meat side,  I liked the tandoori chicken which were big pieces of chicken and not too dried out like I sometimes experience at other buffets.  I also like the simplicity of the lamb or chicken sheesh kebab. Another pleasant surprise was the mehti paneer which had pieces of cheese in their entirety. Many times in buffets the cheese winds up all melted and dissolved because of excessive heat but not this time.  I'll also say the butter chicken was good.  What I like to do is get some rice and put the butter chicken and sauce over the rice so the sauce soaks in.
And you can try the mango mousse for dessert or alternatively fresh fruit.
So those are the facts.
author: Jerome W.

description: I visited thier sister location in San Jose and it was the best Indian food I have ever had. It is definetly a cool ambiance. Not a traditional drab Indian food location.
author: Danny B.

description: 3 thumbs up! I've been out of town and have been anxiously awaiting to check this restaurant out. We ate dinner here Saturday night around 8pm and I was delighted that we were seated right away. This is a higher end Indian restaurant and I was not disappointed by the service, food, or the atmosphere. Very cool place and it reminded me of restaurants in Las Vegas. We started out with the Alleppey Steamed Mussels, Duck Tinka Kebab, Saffron Pulao, Garlic Chive and Chili Thyme Naan, Kacchi Mirch ka Gosht  and finished off with Gulab Jamun for dessert. (they're like warm pastry balls bathing in a sugar liquid.) Although I am not a fan of lamb, the Kacchi dish was  excellent and reminded me of a tender beef roast. Total price was a little over $104 and I think that it was well worth it.
author: Hieu D.

description: I went for there lunch buffet and really it was quite impressive. They had plenty and it all tasted quite good. It was $20 which is kinda steep for a buffet.
author: Cristian M.

description:
I dined here for a birthday party for one of my good friends.  If it weren't for the birthday,  I don't think I would have ever discovered this place because it's quite hidden.  It's located on an alley way by the Jewish Museum.  ((When you google map this place - they bring you to Daly City so be careful!))  Anyway, Amber India is a very chic and trendy Indian restaurant. I'm not the biggest fan of Indian food but this place wasn't half bad. We ordered family style so we were able to try a nice variety.  
For appetizers, we ordered shrimp, naan, and lamb skewers. The shrimp was very tasty especially if you're a fan of spice.  I don't eat lamb so I didn't try it.  I had their naan with the special "yogurt" it comes with.   Yum!   Their entrees weren't as memorable as I would have liked hence the three stars.   We ordered a variety of chickens and curry with rice.  They were all pretty good.  I would highly recommend the butter chicken.  The value is all right - a little on the pricier side.  The service was phenomenal!  We had a fabulous server: Karan!  He helped us take pictures all night long and he was good at it!  He knew more functions on my friends camera than she did.  He would help us take pictures in black and white and different angles.  At the end of the night, he comp'd us a bottle of champagne to toast my friends birthday.  
In the end, I consider it a pretty good restaurant since I would be willing to go back and bring new friends to try it.
author: Jess C.

description: Although the restaurant itself had pretty decent food I was rather disappointed to see the lack of cleanliness in the place. For some reason I found the servers and bartenders clothes and apron dirty, as well as the cloth napkins. We kept trying a few cocktails to get a decent one to drink. The décor on the other hand was great and the concept of the place is interesting.
author: G M.

description:
The butter chicken will not disappoint. Great atmosphere.

A bit pricey.
author: Rich C.

description:
FIRST YELP REVIEW!  I actually attempted to yelp this right after I finished eating my meal, but sadly, the yelp app on the iPhone doesn't allow me to write reviews (they really should add that option in future updates).  

Anyways onto the actual review!  My roomie J and I came here as an early bday dinner for me.  We were running a little late for our 8pm reservation so we phoned to let them know and they were perfectly a-ok with it.  Got to the restaurant and the first thing I noticed was the wonderful decor of the place - it is absolutely gorgeous!  We ordered the Butter Chicken, the tandoori salmon (forgot the name of the dish), garlic nann and rice.  The Butter Chicken is TO DIE FOR!  I will make future visits for that dish alone.  The salmon was simply ok, nothing really to write home about.  Nann and rice were nann and rice, but I would say Nann-N-Curry has better nann.  We also ordered the Chocolate Mango Lassi Cake for dessert and it was "interesting"  to say the least.  It was described to be a cheesecake, but turned out to be more like a 2-layer moose.  I'm still not sure how I feel about it yet.

Also for all you alcohol lovers out there, Amber has a very NICE bar with an impressive liquor and wine list.  I ordered the Belotta, which is an "Indian Bellini" and it was bubbly goodness =)  I was also surprised to see that they had the Vesper under their cocktails considering I've been to many bars that either didn't know what it was (I'm not sure how they passed bar tending school), or didn't know how to make it (sigh).  I will definitely check out the bar more next time.

Overall I'd say it's more 3.5 stars but I'll bump it up to 4 for the Butter Chicken!
author: Carrie F.

description: Very good Indian that is innovative.  I had potatoes stuffed with paneer that was darn tasty.  Our friends had a traditional Indian (butter chicken) dish that they enjoyed very much.  We had a very good experience at this restaurant.  The decor is very nice and the lighting behind the bar is pretty awesome.
author: Rise G.

description:
So I had read the mostly good or great reviews and some of the very negative ones so I went in with an open mind. The occasion was the visit of an Indian gentleman from Canada, and my friend and I sought the opinion of some important thought leaders in the South Bay Indian-American community on where to take him in San Francisco. The answer was unequivocal: Amber. 

I started at the bar with a glass of the Riesling (from Germany), a 2007. The bartender had kindly warned me against the Gewurztraminer as being too sweet. But I was quite disappointed with the Riesling, itself being too  sweet, flabby, and lacking in complexity or interest. When she asked how I liked the Riesling I told her I was sorry I had not ordered the Belgian beer they had on draft. She quickly whisked away the Riesling and produced a glass of beer instead (at half the price). Very nice. When my companion arrived with the bottle of wine we planned to drink for dinner, a 2004 Riesling from McLaren Vale (Australia) we opened it to pour her some: huge difference (fine, dry, minerally, a bit of diesel on the nose at first - great with the food later). Their wine list by the bottle has a 2006 Australian Riesling, and I would recommend that with the food.

For dinner two of us had the prix fixe special. For $24 we got a spectacular salad of spinach lightly breaded with garam flour and fried, a choice of four entrées, an herbed rice, tiny salad garnish, tamarind and mint sauces (which we already had with the papadam), and a kind of ice-cream dessert. Our vegetarian companion ordered the Jaipuri Bhindi (slivers of okra cooked with fennel seeds, tomato, and green mango) and the Kadhai Paneer (cottage cheese batons with coarsely crushed spices, stir fried with peppers, onion and tomato), plus a side of raita (thicker than I had ever seen before, which made it easy to eat). For our entrées we chose one each of the signature butter chicken (shredded tandoori chicken in rich tomato sauce) and the lamb chop "Frontier" (Amber's signature recipe of rack of lamb - two double ribs - marinated in yogurt and garam masala, ordinarily $27.95 on its own). We also got some regular and garlic naan.

This was way too much food. The prices might be on the high side but we found the portions huge, and for less than $30 each of spectacular food we brought some home. Even though the prix-fixe meals were served on their own plates with rice and salad garnish, we put all the dishes in the center of the table and ate family-style. I must say, we were all taken by the flavorful food. The lamb was tender and with the mint chutney very nice. The butter chicken was delicious and not swimming in butter. The okra was fabulous, and plentiful. The two spinach salads were too much for the three of us, and the two ice-cream desserts (like tall hockey pucks already sliced with dabs of chocolate sauce in the corners) plenty for the three of us.

Service was friendly, helpful, and competent. The bartender kept our bottle of wine on ice at the bar until we finished our beers (roughly after our salads), at which point our server set up an ice bucket on the table. She refilled our wine glasses a couple of times and we refilled them on our own a couple of times when she was busy. The busboys kept our water glasses filled always.

We found the decor comfortable and sophisticated, with a nice edge in the bar. We did not need to raise our voices to converse but I don't recall overhearing anyone else's conversation either. The chairs are beautiful wood and leather and frankly a bit better for sitting back than sitting forward; they are also quite wide (which we were not).

Compared to Mantra and Junnoon in Palo Alto I found the menu more traditional, though they do have some dishes they describe as Modern Indian. It had none of the feel of London's Bombay Brasserie and I think well reflected what Californians look for in a top Indian restaurant. My companion from the City is already planning to return.
author: Dan P.

description:
I would go back... 

app - sun dried tomatoe goat cheese item - too gingery, a bit spicy, just ok. I'll try the other 2 veg apps next time.
entrees - paneer makhani (not on menu but they make it if you ask) - pretty good. stuffed aloo - creative, tasty, a bit of a smoky flavor, presentation was great as well. the other veg entrees looked good as well, next time I'd like to try them.
rice - pulao, standard
paratha - tasty 
dessert - some mango/chocolate thingy, not good...spongey like meringue pie, which I don't like. they brought it out as a birthday dessert which was nice of them.

service - great, polite, quick

ambience - nice. looked like they had a nice bar as well.
author: bhavna p.

description: DELISH!  The menu has a great variety of Indian dishes, including more obscure traditional preparations as well as modern/contemporary takes.  The sommelier was very helpful, and the wines we had were excellent.  We were seated rather slowly (even with a res.) but they made up for it.  Service was impeccable once the meal started.  I definitely will be back!
author: S B.

description: excellent.  from the gorgeous, sultry ambience, to the delicious cocktails (lychee martinis get two bulbs per drink!), to the absolutely mouthwatering, perfectly-spiced cauliflower yogurt dish, hearty onion chili kulcha -- seriously, some of the best we've ever had, and we've lived in india! -- to the shrimp and the palak chaat, we just ate SO well here and are so glad that we meandered in from the street to do so.  we will definitely be back.
author: S P.

description:
*Good Indian food - lots of variety and great ingredients*

went here with a friend for lunch.  initially a little skittish with $15-$20 entrees.  $20 buffet helped us to make a decision.  i don't usually think that buffets are worth it - esp for lunch - but this one was.  i like Naan and Curry a lot but this lunch buffet blows its ouf the water.  of course, i'm not sure if it's 2 x as good ($20 buffet versus $9).

*highlights included butter chicken, fried salmon, lamb curry, chicken tikka masala.  also other beef and seafood as part of the offerings.  plenty of vegetables and the sauces are rich and flavorful.  

it's a neat, clean and fancy space close to the Yerba Buena Gardens, Metreon and Four Seasons.  would be a neat place for happy hour but for the drink prices.  

our waitress was friendly and helpful.  i didn't like the vibe from the hostess trio but this improved post-meal.  allegedly there is a lot in curries that may help to improve mood.  they have an attendant that vigilantly watches the buffet area.  

i'll be back for dinner.  i wouldn't come here every week but it was definitely enjoyable.
author: Jimmy F.

description: Food was fabulous.  Yes, it's more expensive than what you'll pay at Pakwan, but you can't walk into a white-linen, candle-lit, marble floored kind of place, and expect to pay ten bucks for dinner.  And besides, every dish we had was fabulous, and I'm willing to pay a little more for that kind of consistent excellence.  The place was quite pretty inside, and the service was good, if a bit over-eager.  I would highly recommend.
author: Michelle A.

description: Went there for happy hour.  I had the shrimp salad and it was very tasty.  the service was very good.  I wish the bar area was a little larger.
author: Kool B.

description: Different vibe than most classic Indian places - a little more modern. Very good food though. Left very satisfied.
author: Jon N.

description:
Impressed with the restaurant, service, and food.  The bar area not so much.  Bar area is too small, has large sports screens, and little room to move around and/or sit.

The restaurant on the other hand had outstanding service, authentic and delicate indian food, and nice ambiance.  Went with a group of girlfriends as really enjoyed the experience.
author: S A.

description: delicious indian food served in an upscale, modern environment. i was invited to a post-birthday dinner dinner here on a recent saturday evening. butter chicken is one of their most popular dishes, and it's not hard to see why. tandoori chicken pieces simmered in a flavorful tomato cream sauce pairs perfectly with the fragrant rice and naan. all the dishes we ordered were amazing, except for the lamb which i didn't try since i'm not a fan of lamby flavors. you really can't go wrong with the menu, as im sure it's hard to pick a bad dish here. our waitress was also very helpful. she had recommended a cocktail which was not well received, when notified, she promptly switched it out. the meal was quite enjoyable, delicious food, good wine, great atmosphere, and the best company....i was one happy birthday girl that night.
author: helen l.

description: We made a reservation but upon arrival were rudely informed that our table was not available, no prediction of the new time could be given, more tables were in front of us (even though the other guests did not have a reservation) and we should find room in their crammed bar to wait. More so, the hostess did NOT even offer us a complimentary drink for our inconvenience. Like fools, we chose to wait.. 1 hour! Still, the hostess acted indifferent,  nonsympathetic or apologetic - true sign of her incompetence. One hour later and there was no hope or indication that the restaurant was progressing towards honoring our reservation. We complained to the manager who in turn reprimanded us for giving his hostess a grief. We marched out to go somewhere else. Such a poorly run establishment! CRO what we could see,the food is not authentic Indian and full of cream. How could anyone give this place raves?
author: Martina M.

description:
I had dinner here at almost the last minute, in an attempt to satisfy the food preference for a friend's birthday dinner. I've passed this place in the past on the way to the Metreon, but hadn't ever thought to go here for dinner. They've only been open for about four months or so I think. 

Overall the meal was okay/good -- not terrible nor the best I've ever had.

We started with the samosas which were great because they were served with some yummy sauces...much better than the type we grab at those fast food local Indian restaurants in the city, so we were optimistic from there.

Next we had the duck kebabs -- I liked them to start, then perhaps due to the power of suggestion from my friend, I thought the accompanying sauce had a liver-like aftertaste. We ended up sending it back, but the waitress & one of the chefs (?) were very accomodating & offered a tasty mango chutney to go along with it but we ended up ordering another paneer (cheese) dish which was pretty good (again, compared to the same which I've ordered at the fast food places).

For our entree we had the specialty tomato-based butter chicken, which was very similar to chicken tikka masala in my book. I took some for leftovers & was slightly surprised to see the sauce had almost solidified, likely b/c it's butter based! (Don't order this dish if you have high cholesterol!)

Another entree we had was the lamb chops in the tandoori section, served on a sizzling platter The sizzle was mostly in the sound...the dish itself wasn't anything special. Plus the platter was so hot that the accompanying onions were burnt so we couldn't eat them.

We had rice & an interesting pesto naan (Italian-Indian). For dessert we had a chocolate/fruit mousse-like cake which wasn't bad.

The ambience & the service were GREAT. They went out of the way to make us happy. The tab was almost $100 for two people, a little steep for an Indian dinner.

This place has gotten mixed reviews, as mine is, so maybe give it a try yourself! Maybe go for drinks & order an appetizer for starters. It's a nice set-up in either case.
author: D L.

description:
Go for the service.
