Admittedly the chicken wasn't as well cooked as I had hoped and I brought this to the attention of the waitress, if only to let her know, not to be a pain.  The response regarding this was amazing.

I don't condone or approve of people who complain just to get things taken off of their bill, having been a waitress for many years myself, but the manager and waitress were extremely professional and corteous even before the chicken incident.

I'll be going there again.
author: Molly R.

description: OK so I am sad to write this, but Amber ripped me off.  yes folks, be very careful and check your account balances after eating here.  The waiter was very very slow in serving our party - and we were a group of 7!  You would think with the 20% tip they'd be more attentive - took them over 20 mins to get our drink order, we also ordered cocktails and tons of food when he finally came.  They also don't disclose what they are exactly sending you when you are in a large group and how much it would cost, which is fine, whatever.  But the worst part was when we split the bill and the waiter charged me TWICE for my bill.  OK no biggie. I found out luckily when I checked Mint - thank god for mint.  Anyways, I called the store twice the next day, no apologies form the person who answered.  I also sent an email with a copy of my receipt, and a detailed message with my bill etc and I didn't get a single response back.  I called the store again to confirm that she would tell the supervisor and she promised I'd get a call back from him, never did.  To this day I have no idea if they even reimbursed me.  What kind of service is that???!  Wow.  I'm astonished at this place, and once again embarrassed that my people behave this way when it comes to restaurant service.  Its just dishonest and obnoxious.  Come on people, GET IT TOGETHER!
author: Mima G.

description: For the expense of the lunch buffet, this is not worth the price.  The rice is really oily and butter chicken too heavy, both intended to fill you up so that you won't eat more.  The atmosphere makes a nice impression, but that does not a good meal make.  It seems to have high ideals about itself, but I have had equally good lunch buffets for 7.95!  I would search around for a place less audacious but more satisfying next time I'm looking for Indian.
author: Henry J.

description: My first try at Amber was really great. I guess the reviews helped me choose the right items. Butter Chicken, Sea Bass Tawa Dish, Some vegetable Korma (forgot the name). All were excellent dishes. We also tried the Alleppey Mussel appetizer which was average. Cost is definitely high but compared to other hotels in this price range the quantity was satisfactory.
author: Biju A.

description:
Service was extremely poor. We only saw our waitress when she took our order and at the end of the meal.  We did flag her down in the middle to reorder drinks and get more condiments and she forgot the condiments.  A tell-tale sign of good service is if other waiters/waitresses not assigned to your table notice that you're "looking" for your waiter/waitress and proactively stop to ask if they can help you.  This restaurant has not trained their folks to do this.  For the price you pay for the food they should!

I would go back only for drinks at the bar .  The restaurant itself is beautiful, nice energy to the place and good location.  The drinks are amazing...props to the mixologist.  

Food was tasty  but portions were way too small to walk away satisfied.
author: Christina D.

description: Yummy Indian food.  Tried their buffet lunch and for $16 it was pretty good.  Butter chicken, potato patty and lamb curry.....tasty!  I would definitely go back.  Service was also great.
author: Uinii H.

description:
Wow, I was shocked to see that this place only has 3.5 stars, it definitely deserves at least a 4!  I want to rate this 4.5 because I don't like to give perfect scores for anything.  My boyfriend and I went here for dinner and even though it was a Friday night and the place was packed, we were able to get in w/o a reservation after just 20 minutes.  I still suggest getting a reservation in the future because that place was packed.  We didn't want to wait around so we just walked around the area and grabbed a drink elsewhere and they called our cell phone when our table was ready, talk about great service!

The food may not be 100% authentic (there were some random ingredients) but the overall taste was DELISH!  We started off with the duck appetizer and honestly, I have never had a more succulent or flavorful duck morsel in my mouth.  Our murg and lamb main dishes were equally yummy.  Although I have reservations about paying over $20 for Indian dishes, the portions were massive and we ended up barely finishing half of our food.  That's not saying we didn't try to stuff ourselves silly because the food was so great.  I can honestly say this is now one of my favorite Indian restaurants in the city.
author: Lucks N.

description: The Butter Chicken is great. Definitely a great date place.
author: Vik L.

description:
Having been exposed to Indian food years ago by a British roommate my expectations are fairly high.  While the food at Amber India is delicious I couldn't help thinking to myself that it tasted inauthentic.  

The decor is gorgeous--it's not often that you find an Indian restaurant in the city where the atmosphere outdoes the food.  I appreciated the banquette seating; a definite pleasure when eating such hearty food.

The service here was awful.  In fact it was so bad that I hesitate to recommend Amber to friends.  While our server was attentive and made great suggestions, he checked-in with us so infrequently that at one point I thought he had gone home for the evening.  In substitution for our waiter were very rude runners and busboys.  They seemed more interested in clearing out the restaurant than serving their guests.

The awful service stripped this restaurant of the polished veneer it took evident care to create.  Do not be fooled.
author: Elijah T.

description: We recently went here for an office lunch.  I'd been here before; the food is decent, if a little overpriced.  In this case, we had someone with us who had very particular food allergies.  So we called in advance and the employee spoke with the chef and told us that it would be no problem -- that we could order anything off of the dinner menu and they could prepare it however we requested.  So we went.  And she tried to order grilled salmon without any sauce or seasoning and a side of grilled vegetables.  The waiter said it would be easy enough but about 25 minutes later he came out with a plate of 6 boiled shrimp and a side salad.  He apologized and said that's all they could do because they were busy.  And then they had the gall to charge $22 just for that plate.  It was ridiculous.  And our colleague was not even satisfied; she had to warm up some food from the fridge when we got back to the office.  If they can't cater to special diets, then they should be up front about that and not make any claims otherwise.  And they definitely shouldn't charge up the wazoo for a plate of nothing.  We'll be finding another office lunch spot.
author: Rachel S.

description: We had initially planned on trying Amber during DAT but realized quickly that the lunch buffet at $16.95 would give us a lot more choices than the two DAT courses for $17.95. So frankly, I don't think it makes much sense for the restaurant to participate in the program, at least not for lunch. There was a nice selection of your typical Indian fare (butter chicken, dahl, tandoori chicken, samosas, etc.) but there were also some less common dishes like braised eggplant. The food was flavorful and beautifully presented. I would go back for lunch.
author: Heike H.

description: This place is beautiful, the food is wonderful and the service was outstanding.  My friends and I ate there for dinner when we visited San Fran and really enjoyed the prompt and attentive service. I still think about the food months later!
author: Melee T.

description:
Unfortunately Amber India in San Francisco is a far cry from its South Bay sibling.  The food is better in the South Bay and more authentic.  Amber obviously has a high rent payment to cover, which is why the prices border on outrageous and the service is only okay.  That said, the quality of the food is terrific, the decor is pleasant and the chef was very willing to make modifications to their existing dishes to accommodate our culinary preferences.

We had the Chicken Tikka, Sikh Kebab and Saag Aloo (which was not on the menu) which were very tasty.
author: Liz C.

description: FABULOUS...! Santosh the owner...has made his country proud by opening the restaurant in the financial district! Awesome food and so is the service. I recommend it for anyone to go anytime, especially if you have a birthday to celebrate....
author: Mel P.

description:
Went today for lunch with two of the colleagues from work. The staff is sweet, doesnt do unnecessary talking and is efficient.

They have a good space and place is bright because of the glass windows and has a classy ambience overall. 

The food was quite good. I am a vegetarian and I felt that their food had a freshness and no stale effect. The Vegetable tikki was good. 

Might find a bit pricey but, it costs to maintain quality in the city. I recommend going there!

One star less because I will go again and edit the post again. Its very important that I find the freshness in the food next time I go as well!
author: Nimisha T.

description: i walk past this place all the time, but finally went in.  yummmmm!  the butter chicken was fabulous.  it was a bit on the pricy side, but i will definitely be back!
author: Alisa M.

description: Recently had the opportunity to sample their food at the March of Dimes event.  It was absolutely delicious and I can't wait to go to the restaurant!!!!
author: Michele M.

description: Recommended to us by the concierge at the Fairmont Hotel.  The food was very good, atmosphere nice.  The service, however, was atrocious, totally unacceptable.  I do not care how good the food is, if the service is rock-bottom poor, I'm just not interested.  There are too many great restaurants in San Francisco with good service to avoid wasting time at this one.
author: Michael G.

description: I think that people that say that if you want good Indian food, go with an Indian person -  are totally right. I take everyone here and everyone loves it. When I was pregnant, I was in here 3 days a week. I have been coming here for years and it is the best Indian restaurant in San Francisco. (Hands down, the absolute best.) The staff is amazing. Tej is the nicest man in the world and the food is SICK good. For Vegetarians, (like me) please try the Dal Amber and the Paneer Tikka Lal Mirch. I get them both - every single time. You will want to find me and thank me for this recommendation. No worries; I feel your respect. :-) My husband loves the Rogan Josh and the butter chicken. I do not care for a single appetizer at the place - my girlfriend loves the coconut cauliflower - and the desserts are a little above okay, but the dinner is so good that I could not even take off a star. Get the entrees and you will have a favorite Indian restaurant. We would not steer you wrong. Go!
author: Tripti P.

description: We showed up for the lunch buffet on a weekday. The buffet is very well done, lots of variety and deliciously prepared. This is a top-notch Indian restaurant. This is not a cheap lunch (17 bucks) but it's really good.
author: Steve H.

description: I was SO looking forward to this meal, as Indian is my favorite cuisine.  The aromas were amazing. After talking to our very helpful waitress, we ordered just about everything she suggested - chicken special, the fried okrah, and the rogan josh lamb - and we emphasized mild for everything, mild mild.  Sadly, everything, even the okra, was inedible due to too much spice - my poor dining companion was sweating due to all the spices, poor guy!   We boxed everything up in hopes his wife who loves everything spicer the better could at least enjoy the tons of expensive food we couldn't eat.  Made us very sad!
author: Colleen H.

description: a great alternative to the boring business lunch. 20 bucks all you can eat indian food buffet....yumm!  think of it as an interactive food adventure in the middle of the financial district.  everything i tried was fantastic. the staff was super friendly and the ambiance is sleek.  i can't want to come back and visit the bar which has a very swank vibe.
author: Angela N.

description: I recently ate at Amber, and I was very pleased with my meal. I went with my family, and we ordered dishes for the table to share. I love Indian food, and Amber was easily the best Indian restaurant I've ever eaten at. Not only was the food great, the atmosphere and location was spectacular. Located right near Market St, it's in perfect walking distance of Union Square. Amber was a great restaurant all around, I would recomend it to anyone fond of Indian food.
author: Marie C.

description: this is as solid a restaurant as i have been to in any amount of time, much less indian food. 4 people sharing family style, and they arranged for it that way. for apps the samosas, duck kebobs and calamari all rocked! the calamari were huge! entrees we had the shrimp moilee, butter chicken, lamb chops and seabass. i would say all were fantastic but the lamb chops, which were a bit small and overcooked. service was quite good and the restaurant is beautiful. bit pricey for indian food i would say, but i would go back here for sure
author: Rich B.

description: Have only been for happy hour, but that alone has earned a good review from me.  First, its the only place in the city I've found Bhani puri, real chaat.  Second, great drinks.  Third, great bar - nice vibe, nice staff.  Yay.
author: Margaret S.

description: We were a party of 9 so when we got there we wanted to wait at bar before we were seated giving time for rest of the party. 2 of us went ahead and sat at the bar and must have sat there for at least 12 minutes before any of the 3 bartenders even looked at us. And its hard when the bar hardly fit the 3 of them. Then after finally ordering my TAJ MAHAL beer it took her like another 8 minutes to even find it in the fridge and it was obvious she didn't know where it was. So then we were seated and left with our menus and when i say LEFT i mean left. When we finally got someone's attention we were just trying to get water. If the service was better I would of gave it more stars and really the only reason Amber gets these stars is because the food is DELICIOUS! But there is plenty of competition out there with Indian Cuisine so to me SERVICE has to come with an establishment considering the price!
author: Brenda S.

description: The food in the buffet was excellent with a sufficient variety.  My big complaint, for my party of six, was the 15% tip added to the bill.  15% for a buffet!!
author: Scott J.

description: Not so much. I will say the restaurant was very crowded and they were trying to seat a party of 45 who had made reservations, and had been waiting for 45 minutes for a table when we arrived at 8:30 - but the restaurant is large and should be able to handle the people it seats, or agrees to seat. Once we were seated the server was quick, we got our delicious appetizers very quickly - the fantastic Cualiflower with Coconut, Papadums, and this lightly fried spinach dish were very very tasty. We were excited to eat our entrees,  as we were starving. We continued to starve for another 45 minutes until they brought our either freezing COLD or steaming hot entrees. My lamb kebabs were in the same shape and size as dog poop, and some pieces were freezing cold, others room temperature. There were originally 4 pieces of this minced lamb dog poop kebab, and I took one off the plate and ate it. We told them it was cold. They returned with ..... 3 hot pieces. NO. The first order you brought me was WRONG, so you need to fix all of it. Not just the pieces that I didn't touch. All of it. Also, they took away the delicious spinach appetizer before we were done and when we asked for it back, the busboy said "Sorry, no" I guess once he'd taken it off the table, he couldn't put it back on the table? I was not impressed, but it seems like they were having an off night with the service. I would go back for cocktails and apps, not dinner.
author: C W.

description: i had a great time at this place today. The food was really good and different from other indian restaurants for sure. I finally see what the hype over butter chicken is because it was the best i've ever had. The service was really nice and this is an extremely upscale restaurant. The only downside is that it is really expensive, been a while since I paid that much for indian food, i've gotten use to the chaat cafes and naan n' curries of the city. But this was definitely a nice change of pace. The food is definitely high on quality, ambiance is nice, and service was great. Nice selection of alcohol as well.
author: Vishal M.

description: I ate here with a group of friends we ordered a lot of food and everything was great- the scallops and butter chicken wereamazing!! drinks were good, I loved the decor and atmospher.  I cant wait to go back!!!
author: suzanne T.

description: Oh my, oh my, oh my, YUMMMM!  As much as I love checking out new places, I'm going to have to make this a regular stop on my restaurant circuit.  Spicy...check.  Great service...check (they actually serve the meals from the platter directly to your plate!).  Tasty and unique Indian dishes...check.  Ahhhhh.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  Manageable prices.  It's not Naan n Curry cheap, nor is it DOSA expensive.  Go...now.
author: Melinda G.

description: Pretty pricey ($87 for 4) for a Sunday lunch buffet, but the food was tasty.  Butter Chicken had a nice sweetness and the vegetarian dishes were full of flavor, though there was zero spiciness.  Kheer was strictly meh.
author: Jeff B.

description: I was SHOCKED by the prices! I have never seen that level of prices on an Indian menu for small portions and average cuisine. The dinner entree average was $22. Our food took too long to arrive and our server was slow. On the plus side, it was less greasy than many indian places. The decor was nice and the wine selection was good. But, I will not return.
author: Anna M.

description: I've been here several times and have taken several people and we all say the same thing.  The apps are great, the wine selection is fantastic but the main dishes (at least for vegetarians) are just ok.  The only reason to go here IMO, (and it is worth the trip every time) is for the Pesto and Goat Cheese Tikki.  It is among the most amazing dishes I have ever had, and everyone I introduce it to has the same opinion.  If you go here do not miss out on this truly unique and divine appetizer.
author: Pedro S.

description: Great restaurant and beautiful ambiance. Amber's buffet variety was marvelous - appetizers such as Pudina chicken, Tamarind flavored yogurt and my all time fav Gol Gappae (popular street chaat in India) were top notch; I had approximately 8 of them. Curries and other dishes such as chicken tikka masala, panner lababdar were too good, except for bhindi (okra). I loved the Halwa (dessert) and Mango mimosas.
author: G A.

description: I would give 3.5 stars if I could. The food is good, certainly acceptable but I don't understand the fuss- perhaps I am not a connoisseur. The butter chicken is supposed to be the signature dish, it is fine but honestly I can't really differentiate it from other less upscale Indian restaurants. The atmosphere and decor are really lovely though and I would say it is a good place to go with a group of friends on a Friday night.
author: Lynn G.

description: I love indian food.... but amber isn't really indian food to me.  Yes it has eh spice but i find it to be too salty.  For lunch they have a pretty good buffet $20 bucks for all you can eat.  Good selection, I guess.  I dont know how to describe it besides its not your ordinary indian food that you would find at a Naan and Curry.  I'd say it has a contemporary twist that just doesn't really satisfy me.  I did enjoy their butter chicken and lemon tandoori chicken and fried catfish (which was kinda salty but wrapped in naan it evened it out.  I was kinda sad that the naan wasn't placed in the buffet.  Instead they have someone come around to drop off naan in our baskets.  Service isn't the best either our whole table was waiting for th waiter to come around to refill our drinks but it never happened.  Kinda disappointing to me since we were 1 of 5 groups that were in the restaurant at the time.  I dont think i will be coming back here anytime soon since its out of my budget.
author: Jenn Y.

description: I was a little cautious about eating in an area near the convention center. In my experience, this is rarely a good choice. The inside is beautiful (wish I had my camera). The staff was friendly, accomodating of our six-year old and very gracious. We are vegetarian so we sampled many of the vegetarian dishes and the samosas (which are a favorite of mine). The food was some of the best I have had. I am fairly picky about my Indian food...I don't like when it is greasy and gloppy and not delicate on the palate. It was fabulous. Very cool bar too! If we had not had a six-year-old in tow I would have definitely hung out there for a while.
author: maya a.

description: Amber India located in the newly opened area between Market and Mission, providing access to Yerba Buena Center, is a great place to have dinner before heading off to a show.  My brother and I had dinner there before attending an Alonzo King Lines Ballet performance at the Center.  My brother had been for there lunch (nice buffet), so it was our first time for dinner, and we both agreed it was a repeat.  The interior is nicely decorated and provides a comfortable, yet elegant setting.  The service was very professional and friendly.  Our waiter was top notch.  He made recommendations without being prodded.  Maybe not everyone would appreciate that, but the more you eat out, its nice to run into wait staff that takes the job seriously and knows their stuff in regards to the different dishes, how they go together, wine selection, etc.  If you're going to spend some money, especially in a higher end restaurant, then the staff should live up to the price tag.  We placed our orders, a shrimp dish and a vegetarian, which we planned to share.  Our waiter suggested we change one of them since we had order two relatively "dry" dishes.  He suggested another shrimp dish with a sauce that would compliment the vegetarian dish we had order.  We took him up on the recommendation, and we were both extremely happy we did; delicious!  In addition, we stuck with ordering just a glass of wine each versus our normal bottle, since we were going out afterwards.  Again with the recommendations, our waiter complimented my choice of wine, which upon further questioning on why it was a good choice, made my brother switch his original choice to mine.  The wine went well with our meal and enhanced the overall experience.  The serving sizes were plenty for two people, and we had to leave a little behind, so I would suggest only ordering one dish per person if sharing.  In regards to spiciness, our dishes were nicely balanced.  One had a little zing to it, but did not overpower all the different spices in the dishes.  Based on our experience with our waiter, this will be a good place to go and have someone help you make a choice if you are trying to avoid dishes with too much spice/hotness.  There are so many choices in San Francisco and so many good restaurants, so to help narrow it down, consider this; if you want an elegant, but comfortable restaurant, expert waiter service (in a friendly way, not a "full of myself" snobbish way), tasty ethnic dishes, you can't go wrong with Amber India.
author: E. C.

description:
Yeah, it's alright. It has an interesting menu that spans from traditional, to 'progressive' or modern, they really love categorizing types of foods. One of our appetizers was a duck dish, and all of us agreed that you if we did not KNOW it had been duck, we would not have guessed it - it just seemed like a random meat-tasting meat marinated and done in the tandoori oven. Also, I believe someone else mentioned this in a post -- the sauces? They have no sauces. They don't serve any chutneys or dipping sauces for the naan (which, for 3 bucks an order I expect to stay fluffy and warm throughout the whole meal, they should just bring AROUND nan to the tables that decided to pay for it, instead of putting it in a basket infront of you and letting it get cold and stiff like at any other Indian restaurant that serves naan just as good if not better). When one of us asked for a spicy sauce, it was very reminiscent of the kind of chili-oil/paste you would find in a chinese restaurant.

 So yeah, it's good but there's many places that are not only better and where you can savor the flavors of what you're eating, and for a better price.
author: Samantha D.

description: Definitely worth a visit.  The food was very good.  Started with a strangely Chinese appetizer that was nevertheless tasty, moved on to the okra and the tandoori prawns.  Okra was amazing and the prawns were very very tender and spicy.  The service is excellent and the space is lively without being an echo chamber.
author: Jeff B.

description: As seems to be the trend with most of the comments posted, my wife and I loved this place and will be back tomorrow.  One thing to note is the expectation that all Indian/Pakistani restaurants will be priced like Pakwan is unrealistic.  This place isn't, nor should it be, given its impressive marbled decor and other superior touches.  Moreover, it won't be priced like it's Mountain View counterpart either - this is undeniably a cut above that place.  Now if it was priced like the Four Seasons next door, you would have a valid complaint, but so far most entrees are between $20-$25 and that fair [IMO] for the calibre of food that they serve ... and along the lines of what Slanted Door and Bong Su charge, albeit for Vietnamese cuisine.  An upscale indian restaurant with high quality food has long been missing from S.F. and I'm glad it has finally arrived.  I expect this place to do well.
author: B S.

description: After a visit to the Jewish Museum across the alley, I spotted the Amber sign and recalled the recent "Amber Alert" in the food section of SFGate, so we decided to give it a try as it looked inviting enough.  Reading the reviews of previous diners, I'm a bit surprised that people would write such negative reviews based on an opening night experience, especially since such information is not likely to be helpful or representative of what the place is going to be like for other diners--more likely its just a form of revenge for someone's ruffled feathers.  In any case, its all irrelevant in my case because we had a fabulous time at Amber and everything, from the service to the ambiance and the food was first rate;  apparently it only took them a couple of days to get things together.   I had the tandoori Lamb Chop "Frontier", a "signature" dish, and it was a delight---a generous portion, tender and tasty.  Along with that we had the tandoori stuffed aloo, walnut and spinach raita, an order of pappad that came with two delicious chutneys, and the saffron rice.   A nice addition was the savory serving of butter chicken which the chef sent out as a gift, as he apparently felt  we could use something with a little sauce.  All was perfectly complemented by a glass of Temperanillo.  Dessert was the kesari rasmalai, a light and refreshing finale.   It was definitely the best Indian food I've had in a long time; in fact, I had virtually lost interest in that cuisine recently, even after a trip to India last year where I never had restaurant food this good.
author: David T.

description: I had been waiting for what seems like a year for the opening of Amber India in SF and in my experience, they didn't disappoint.  The food = delicious (delightful spins on indian cuisine favorites: samosas, butter chicken, saag with dill-mushrooms-minicorn, and saffron rice), the drinks, really good (i had the pimm's amber, highly recommend it) and the service--the management must have been reading the yelp reviews for earlier in the week--because I will say that their service was almost over-attentive...sometime to weird awkward moments, but that was ok.  It is expensive, but it is definitely worth it to spend a little more for the ambience, tasty spins on what you'd get from your run-of-the-mill local indian restaurant, and (what i thought) great service.  I am giving four stars, for now so i can go back in a few months to see if they get their groove down, which I think they will given it IS the same management from the mountain view location which I loved. I can't wait to try their lunch buffet!
